title: Attacking Bush's Environmental Record
description: This is a 30-second commercial created for the Sierra Club, attacking the environmental record of the Republican candidate Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. It began running yesterday on television stations in New Hampshire, which holds its presidential primary on Feb. 1.

title: Yeltsin's Pneumonia Barely Raises an Eyebrow in Washington
description: Not long ago, whenever Boris N. Yeltsin caught a cold, the more nervous Kremlin watchers in the Clinton administration reacted with alarm. But this week, Mr. Yeltsin caught pneumonia, and Washington stifled a yawn.

title: EMUSIC.COM TO ACQUIRE TUNES.COM FOR $130 MILLION
description: EMusic.com Inc. said yesterday that it would buy privately held Tunes.com for about $130 million in stock. EMusic, based in Redwood City, Calif., sells music that can be downloaded from its Web site in the MP3 format. Tunes.com, based in Chicago, is an online music news company that operates RollingStone.com and DownBeatJazz.com. The combined company will operate a network of music-oriented Internet portals. Shares of EMusic.com were up 43.75 cents, to $16.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: A Clinton Adviser to Join Lazard Freres
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., a close friend of President Clinton and a leading political power broker in Washington, is giving up his senior executive position with the law firm Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld to become a partner in Lazard Freres & Company, the private investment bank, in New York in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASTENBERG, ARTHUR
description: FASTENBERG-Arthur. On November 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Eve for 66 years. Cherished father of Francine and Irwin Levine, and Elaine and Leon Smith. Adoring grandfather of Lori, Karen, Daniel, Susan and Jessica. Great grandfather of David, Benjamin & Julia. Devoted brother of Milton, Abner, Selma, Marvin, William and the late Leonard. Dear uncle to many nieces and nephews. He will be sorely missed. Services on Wednesday 10:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Freed Detainee, Praising Imprisoned Sheik, Plans to Revive Mosque
description: After spending three years in detention on the basis of secret evidence, Nasser K. Ahmed said yesterday that he planned to use his freedom to revive the Islamic movement that federal investigators say was a haven for the terrorists who carried out a bomb attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Mahathir's Party a Big Loser in Malaysian Vote
description: KUALA LUMPU  The Malaysian general election has produced a convincing victory for the ruling coalition but a striking loss for the party of Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad.

title: Three Vignettes Afloat In Romantic Obsessions
description: ''Beyond the Clouds'' was shown as part of the 1996 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 28, 1996. The film opens today at the the Screening Room, 54 Varick Street, at Laight Street, TriBeCa.

title: Badillo Says Community Colleges Need to Improve Graduation Rate
description: Fresh from his success in winning approval for a plan to remove remedial students from the senior colleges of the City University of New York, Herman Badillo, the university's chairman, said he would next take aim at the community colleges and what he calls their ''appalling'' graduation rates.

title: Japanese Intervene Again, but the Yen Edges Upward Anyway
description: The yen approached a four-year high against the dollar yesterday as a second day of efforts by the Japanese central bank to stem the currency's rise crumbled in the face of expectations for strong demand for Japanese stocks.

title: Sotheby's and Wine Dealer End Auction Arrangement
description: After five years of auctioning fine and rare wines together, Sherry-Lehmann and Sotheby's have parted company.

title: Fearing Instability, Malaysians Keep Leader
description: Like other nations, Malaysia has a national anthem. But it also has a theme song, played repeatedly in the recent election campaign, Frank Sinatra's ''My Way.''

title: Court Rules Police's Cab Task Force Is Unlawful
description: New York State's highest court struck down a New York police program yesterday in which plainclothes officers in unmarked cars stopped taxis in high-crime neighborhoods at night, ostensibly to confirm the safety of the drivers and discourage assaults against them.

title: Rebuilding Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: At Odds on Crash Theory, Officials Are Cooperative
description: In his first public comments on the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990, the director of the F.B.I., Louis J. Freeh, said today that the Egyptian authorities were cooperating with the inquiry into the cause of the crash and would investigate a list of leads at the request of American law-enforcement officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, LUZ
description: RUBINSTEIN-Luz (Lucy) D. of Farmingdale on November 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Edward B. Devoted mother of Allan and his wife Joanne, Gisela and her husband Edwin Hirschberg. Loving grandmother of Larry, Elizabeth, Victoria and great grandmother of five. Friends may visit Friday 7-9:30 PM and Saturday 2-5 PM, at the McCourt & Trudden Funeral Home Inc., 385 Main Street, Farmingdale. Services Saturday 3 PM in the funeral home. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Cross of Christ Lutheran Church 576 Deer Park Avenue, Babylon, New York 11702, would be appreciated.

title: Cashing In On 'Millionaire'
description: With the November sweep officially ending tonight, network program executives spent yesterday taking stock, and talking about game shows.

title: Startling Ending for Young Writer of Promise
description: As his first novel was being typeset, Robert Bingham, 33, was found dead in the bathroom of his TriBeCa home on Sunday. A law enforcement official said that the authorities believed that Mr. Bingham, the last male writer in the storied and contentious Kentucky newspaper family, had overdosed on heroin.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA TERMINATES PURCHASE OF ASCENT
description: The Ascent Entertainment Group said yesterday that the Liberty Media Group, the cable-television programming arm of AT&T, had terminated its $572 million purchase of Ascent amid fears Ascent would not succeed in selling its sports assets. Ascent has threatened to cancel the planned $461 million sale of two sports teams and an arena to the billionaire Donald Sturm. Liberty's chairman, John C. Malone, wanted Ascent for the pay-per-view entertainment and Internet-access services it provides to hotel guests. He did not want the sports assets, which include the Denver Nuggets basketball team and the Colorado Avalanche hockey team. The stock of the Denver-based Ascent fell $1.25 a share, to $12. Liberty Media, based in Englewood, Colo., fell 93.75 cents, to $41.8125.

title: Crew Backs Company That Erred on Scores
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he would urge the Board of Education to continue its contract with the company that miscalculated thousands of test scores, as long as the company paid $500,000 in damages.

title: New Computer Worm Is Said to Spread Rapidly
description: variation of a computer worm that caused widespread damage in June is now spreading rapidly by electronic mail, three antivirus software companies said today.

title: Advanced Micro Updates Processor
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. introduced a new version of its Athlon microprocessor on Monday that is faster than the Intel Corporation's top Pentium III computer chip.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOXER, DAVID H.
description: BOXER-David H. Dec. 1, 1994. Always remembered. Beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather and great grandfather.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have demonstrators who are continuing to express their point of view. Most are doing it nonviolently, some are doing it violently.''

title: DELL COMPUTER TO SELL MACHINE FOR BASIC WEB ACCESS
description: The Dell Computer Corporation, the leading direct seller of personal computers, introduced the Webpc yesterday, a slimmed-down machine intended to let novice PC users get online quickly. The Webpc is Dell's first attempt to attract inexperienced computer buyers. The new device, which comes in five colors and resembles a coffee maker, costs less than $1,000. That includes a 433-megahertz Celeron processor from Intel, a 15-inch color monitor, a CD-ROM drive, a printer and one year of Internet access through Dellnet, the company's service.

title: Profitable Canadian Banks Making Plans for Cutbacks
description: Canada's biggest banks are reporting record total profits, while laying out plans to cut jobs and branches to further increase their rates of return. In a country where banks dominate the corporate landscape and are already a focus of consumer discontent, advocacy groups are saying that fatter profits probably mean people will pay more for less service.

title: First Spring Game Set for March 2
description: The Yankees announced yesterday they would open their spring training schedule on March 2 when they play the Toronto Blue Jays at Dunedin, Fla.

title: 10 Districts Are Named In Test of School Choice
description: In its first foray into school choice, the New Jersey Department of Education yesterday announced its selection of 10 school districts that will be the first to accept, tuition-free, students from any district in the state.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Conseco, Its Stock Sagging, Focuses on Balance Sheet

title: Judge Annuls Arbitrator's Pay Raise for Daily News Drivers
description: Raising the specter that The Daily News could go out of business if forced to pay more than $18 million in back wages, a Federal District Court judge yesterday overturned a pay increase granted by an arbitrator to the union representing the newspaper's drivers.

title: How a Town In Wisconsin Went Mad
description: It may not have a headless horseman charging murderously through a Gothic forest, but James Marsh's film ''Wisconsin Death Trip'' frequently suggests a semidocumentary offshoot of Tim Burton's ''Sleepy Hollow.'' The movie, which opens today at Film Forum, is a visually audacious riff on Michael Lesy's macabre 1973 cult classic book of vintage photographs and news clips chronicling the human tragedies that engulfed the rural farming community of Black River Falls, Wis., in the 1890's.

title: A Group Without a Center; Rockefeller Investment Arm Trying Not to Look Back
description: There's finally a nip in the air, and the energy level around Rockefeller Center is ratcheting up. The Christmas tree will be lighted tonight, the refurbished skating rink is full of figure eights and the new Banana Republic flagship store is drawing crowds. The buildings somehow seem to glitter.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PRICES SOAR. Coffee prices jumped on expectations that dry weather will reduce Brazil's crop, the world's biggest. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 16.1 cents, or 14 percent, to $1.3035 a pound.

title: 2 Schools, 2 Strategies, One Goal: Keeping Top Students
description: Emily Armstrong's first child was a pioneering kindergartner at a new experimental public school on the Lower East Side nine years ago. Her daughter, Brighid, thrived, and so did her school, the Neighborhood School, turning its funky mix of children of ex-hippies, professionals and working-class immigrants into the top-ranked elementary school in the district, and one of the best in New York City.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Paper Plate Art At the Modern

title: True North will acquire Stein Rogan, a shop that specializes in digital communications companies.
description: AN agency company that was early to explore cyberspace is expanding again in the fast-growing realm of digital communications, acquiring a New York shop specializing in online and offline advertising for dot-coms.

title: On Klickitat Street, Beverly Cleary Is Forever Ramona
description: Beverly Cleary sometimes forgets that she is a world-famous writer. Or she simply refuses to believe it. Even after 50 years of fan mail and book signings and awards, attention unsettles her, especially when it comes in concentrated doses as it has since the release of her latest children's book, her 38th.

title: The Trouble With Sherry
description: WHEN you sit down at Solera, the Midtown Spanish restaurant, a little bowl of green olives appears on the table. I find that this prompts a Pavlovian response. Olive and brine means manzanilla, the featherlight, bone-dry sherry that may be the finest aperitif wine known to humanity.

title: Our Towns; Discarding Usual Script On the Police
description: JUST as the killing of Amadou Diallo was seen by critics of the New York Police Department as evidence of deep troubles in the department, the death of Aquan Salmon here in April was viewed by neighborhood activists as revealing rot at the core of the Hartford Police Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELKIN, JULIAN
description: NELKIN-Julian. 85. Lake Worth Fl., on November 30, 1999. Formerly of Great Neck. Devoted and loving husband of Rae. Caring father of Susan Lee, Alan and Henry, and father-in-law of Marianne and Janice. Wonderful grandfather of David and Kelli, Jonathan, Emily and Dylan. Brother of Mildred Grumet. Brother-in-law of Esther, Louis and Claire, Irving and Rhoda, Buzzy and Roy. Dear uncle and great uncle, friend to many. Above all, he was a mensch who will be missed by all he touched. Memorial contributions to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc., 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach Fl 33407.

title: Clinton Calls Brady Law a Success and Backs More Limits
description: Celebrating the sixth anniversary of the Brady law, which mandates waiting periods and background checks for gun buyers, President Clinton said today that the system had blocked more than 470,000 gun sales to ''felons, fugitives, stalkers and others prohibited from purchasing firearms.''

title: Accounts
description: * Bestselections.com , New York, an online luxury goods retailer, to Ziccardi & Partners, New York, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $13 million.

title: A Chaotic Intersection of Tear Gas and Trade Talks
description: Four members of President Clinton's cabinet and hundreds of other American officials came to Seattle this week to push America's agenda on free trade.

title: Russians Briefly Detain U.S. Diplomat, Calling Her a Spy
description: Russian officials said today that they had caught an American spy as she was preparing to meet with her Russian informant and confiscated an array of sophisticated espionage equipment.

title: Mahathir, in Victory, Is Dealt a Major Loss
description: KUALA LUMPUR  The Malaysian general election has produced a convincing victory for the ruling coalition but a striking loss for the party of Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad.

title: Ginseng Therapy for Farmlands
description: It can be worth as much as gold, and it grows.

title: Editors' Note
description: A Critic's Notebook article last Wednesday pondered the relative professional dependability of lawyers and journalists, as reflected in the movie ''The Insider.'' The film is a dramatic adaptation of events four years ago, when CBS, perceiving a threat of a devastating lawsuit, eviscerated a ''60 Minutes'' broadcast of an interview by a tobacco industry whistle-blower.

description: Son of Rao's

title: Sandwiches That Travel
description: SO you thought you'd seen the last of turkey for a while, right? Sorry. BOERUM HILL FOOD COMPANY in Brooklyn serves a turkey club sandwich ($6.50) that is so good it may make people forget that turkey is only for holidays. Turkey breast and thick strips of bacon are served on excellent hallah, moistened with tangy cranberry sauce and sweet-potato puree and given a little zing with mustard and mayonnaise.

title: Luongo Tastes Defeat as Islanders Fall to Stars
description: After the Islanders and the Stars finished their cautious match tonight at Nassau Coliseum, New York goalie Roberto Luongo had a .500 record for his career and Dallas had a .500 record for the season. This was pretty good for Luongo, two games into his rookie season, and not too good for the Stars, 25 games into their defense of a Stanley Cup championship. But both teams seemed somewhat satisfied.

title: Navy to Train Off Puerto Rico With Live-Fire Issue Unsettled
description: An aircraft carrier and an amphibious battle group will begin training this week even though the White House has yet to decide if the ships will be able to use a Puerto Rican island for the final live bombing practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENAS, FRAN
description: PENAS-Fran. On November 29, 1999. Daughter of the late Enrique and Minnie Penas. She is survived by her life partner, Julie Gonzalez and her brother Henry Penas and mourned by her family and many friends. Memorial services will be held at The Church of the Holy Apostles, 28 Street and 9th Avenue, NYC on Saturday, December 4th. at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, 2129 Stanley Hills Drive, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046

description: KAUFMAN-Rita Skydell. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a dear friend, a life member and respected leader of the YU Women's Organization who was devoted to advancing the ideals of our heritage and imparted this legacy in word and deed to her children: the late Judith, and her husband Baruch Hurwich, Gerald S. (and Carol) Kaufman, Belda (and Marcel) Lindenbaum, and Carol (and Melvin) Newman. Her values were those shared by her siblings: Hilda Riback (and late Rabbi Sidney Riback), A. Harry (and Rebecca) Skydell, Rabbi Adrian (and Dr. Ruth) Skydell, Irving (and Ceil) Skydell, and Anita (and Chaim) Chanowitz. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family, who have been dedicated supporters of YU. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Dinah Pinczower Chairman, National Board, YUWO

Wollner (deceased), devoted father of Linda (David) Cashdan of Washington, D.C. and Donald (Martha) Wollner of Brooklyn, N.Y. and adoring grandfather of Melanie Cashdan, Richard Cashdan and Preston Wollner.

title: When Neatness Doesn't Count
description: AT a time when Mediterranean accents seem to dominate American menus, a little German is creeping in. Spatzle, the tiny dumplings of Eastern Europe, are turning up where couscous once did, alongside duck, venison and fish.

title: With 20 More Points, Jets Could Be Winners
description: If only . . . that is what the Jets' season has come down to. And while the what-if scenario is often the last refuge of the loser, in the Jets' case the might-have-been resonates especially loudly because of what everyone had expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEB, CHARLES H.
description: LIEB-Charles H. age 92, a retired lawyer, died Sunday at his home in Easton, Connecticut. He was a member of the N.Y. and CT. bars and practiced for over 55 years in NYC. He was a senior partner in the law firm of Paskus, Gordon & Mandel until that firm's dissolution in 1986. He then served Of Counsel to the law firm of White & Case until his retirement in 1991. Mr. Lieb was copyright counsel to the Assn. of American Publishers from 1966 until 1986. He is survived by his sister, Babette Lieb Riffin of UpperMontclair, NJ; his sister-inlaw, Peggy Lieb of N. Caldwell, New Jersey; two nieces and four grandnieces. Interment will be private. A memorial Service will be held 12 noon Saturday, December 4th at the Aspetuck Valley Country Club in Weston, CT. Donations may be made in his memory to the American Red Cross.

title: Fed Governor Says Rates Might Increase
description: Federal Reserve policy makers may decide to raise interest rates again to keep the United States economy on a low-inflation growth path, a Fed governor, Laurence H. Meyer, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORNARI, VIRGINIA
description: FORNARI-Virginia (nee Korman). Age 53, adored wife and best friend of James; beloved mother of Matthew; cherished daughter of Alfred and the late Florence Korman; sister of Mary (Herb Gardner) and John (James Hoback); & daughter in-law of Misa and Harry Fornari. You were taken from your loving family much too soon. We shall miss your radiant smile, your caring heart and your love of life. Funeral service on Thursday 11:15AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Interment to follow. The family will receive friends Thursday evening only, 1020 Park Avenue. Donations in Ginny's memory, may be made to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: Summations Concluded In Suffolk Extortion Trial
description: The prosecution and the defense completed two days of final arguments late yesterday in the trial of John Powell, the former leader of the Suffolk County Republican Party who is charged with conspiracy and extortion. The jury is to begin deliberations today after receiving instructions from Judge Jacob Mishler.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: National Guard Is Called to Quell Trade-Talk Protests; Seattle Is Under Curfew After Disruptions
description: Downtown Seattle was placed under curfew and the National Guard was called in tonight, after the city was engulfed in demonstrations that threw the opening of global trade talks into turmoil.

title: Hiring of White Guard Who Killed Black Youth Stirs Anger
description: Elected officials and guards at the Passaic County Juvenile Detention Center today criticized the decision to hire as a guard a white former police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager in Paterson five years ago.

title: APPLIED HOLOGRAPHICS OF BRITAIN TO ACQUIRE RIVAL
description: Applied Holographics P.L.C., a British-based maker of holographic films used for security devices, agreed to buy a rival, Optical Security Group Inc., for about $64 million to add products and expand its North American operations. Applied said it would begin a $7-a-share cash tender offer for shares of Optical, a maker of specialized optical security devices. Optical makes imaging-based foils, labels, laminates and coatings that protect documents and products from tampering, forgery or counterfeiting. The Denver-based company lost $5.6 million for the year ended in March on revenue of $14.2 million. Its shares rose $1 each, or 19 percent, to $6.625.

title: Sports of The Times; Leadership, Not Ridicule, Is the Key
description: NETS Coach Don Casey stood in an empty Continental Arena yesterday afternoon after a pregame shoot-around. He spoke about wide-ranging, far-reaching subjects -- everything from Robert De Niro and James Dean, to playing hurt versus playing it safe, to Keyshawn Johnson and Stephon Marbury, to the difference between venting in frustration and providing inspiration.

title: Ex-Students Sue Rutgers Over Strip Allegations
description: Earl Johnson, the former Rutgers point guard, recalled today that he initially thought a free-throw game that his coach, Kevin Bannon, ordered the team to play two years ago -- in which players were forced to remove an article of clothing after missing a shot -- would be fun.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOUGHERTY, JAMES W.
description: DOUGHERTY-James W. November 25, 1940 to December 1, 1995. When? Tish

title: Business fliers worldwide are increasingly using the Internet to research and book their flights.
description: BUSINESS travelers worldwide are increasingly embracing the Internet to research and book their flights, an annual survey by the International Air Transport Association has found.

title: Panhandler Is Arrested in Brick Attack
description: A panhandler with a criminal record that stretches back nearly two decades was arrested yesterday and charged with attempted murder in the Nov. 16 brick attack of a young woman on a Midtown Manhattan street, police officials said last night. The arrest was made after a witness to the assault identified the man in a lineup, the officials said.

title: A Deal Is Reached on Family Planning Money
description: President Clinton today put into place the final piece of a compromise to give limited aid to international groups promoting abortion rights while enabling the United States to pay its back dues to the United Nations.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Borrows Clinton's Shadow Back to Share a Bow
description: Vice President Al Gore asserted today that the nation's prosperity was the central imperative of his campaign, and he gave credit to President Clinton -- and himself -- for the booming economy.

title: Nissan to Cut U.S. Work Force
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's money-losing No. 2 automaker, said today that it would cut 10 percent of its United States work force, or about 1,000 jobs, by March 2001 as part of a global restructuring plan announced last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGATSTON, GLADYS
description: AGATSTON-Gladys (nee Cole). On Nov. 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arnold S., DDS, devoted mother of Warren S. of Rye Brook, NY, & Elaine Fersten of Coral Springs, Florida, predeceased by brother, Melvin Cole. Also survived by grandchildren, Amy Grolnick, David Agatston, Jennifer Agatston, Marc Fersten & Caren Nabridge & nine greatgrandchildren. Private memorial services to be held.

title: College Says It Has Money for AIDS Lab
description: Allen L. Sessoms, president of Queens College, said yesterday that the college had lined up the $6 million in private contributions that it needed to build an AIDS research center. But he said he could not name the company that is making the donation until the paperwork was in hand, which he expects will be this week.

title: Creationist Captain Sees Battle 'Hotting Up'
description: Since dedicating himself to creationism 20 years ago when he was a disillusioned science teacher in Australia, Ken Ham has found that progress can generally be slow, but hardly as slow as his evolutionist adversaries would have the world believe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESLIE, BETHEL
description: LESLIE-Bethel. The original ''The Exact Center of the Universe'' family mourns the passing of our first ''Enid'', a great actress and friend. Elsa Daspin Haft, Producer Joan Vailthorne, Author John Tillinger, Director and Cast: Frances Sternhagen Reed Birney Marge Redmond Sloane Shelton Tracy Thorne

title: Study of Ill Gulf War Veterans Points to Chemical Damage
description: Some veterans of the Persian Gulf war who have complained of chronic illnesses have signs of brain damage caused by exposure to toxic chemicals, the authors of a scientific study partly financed by the Pentagon reported today.

title: City Will Take More Time to Impose Shelter Work Rules
description: City officials said yesterday that new rules to make work and other welfare requirements a condition of shelter for homeless families would not go into effect today, despite an earlier announcement by the city's homeless agency.

title: Executives Sentenced in Securities Fraud
description: A former chief executive of the Ferrofluidics Corporation, Ronald Moskowitz, was sentenced yesterday to more than eight years in prison for securities fraud and conspiring to inflate the company's stock price.

title: Australian Museum Cancels Controversial Art Show
description: After the furor created by the ''Sensation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra has canceled the show, which was to have opened there in June.

title: MOBILE SATELLITE MERGER
description: Australia's largest telecommunications concern, the Telstra Corporation, and a Dutch telecommunications company, Royal KPN N.V., will merge their mobile satellite businesses early next year. KPN will have a 65 percent stake in the new company, which will have headquarters in the Hague; Telstra will own the rest. KPN and Telstra will combine assets worth $200 million to start the new company, which will have 350 employees and expected revenue of about $250 million in 2000.

title: Embraceable U
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Vining, Tutor to a Future Emperor, Dies at 97
description: Elizabeth Gray Vining, a Quaker schoolteacher who was tutor to the shy, lonely boy who became Emperor Akihito of Japan, died on Saturday at Kendal-at-Longwood, a retirement community in Kennett Square, Pa. She was 97.

title: Quick Trip To Turkey
description: SHISH KEBAB is a quintessential Turkish dish, but this twist on the classic combination of lamb and peppers takes a great idea and makes it easier. First of all, this dish can be made indoors, although in good weather the initial browning could certainly be done on a grill. Second, it makes its own sauce, a combination of yogurt and the juices exuded by the meat and roasted vegetables.

title: CALENDAR
description: Classes, From Sushi to Tea

title: Taylor Enters No-Contest Plea
description: COURT NEWS

title: Greens With Unwilting Flavor
description: ONE striking characteristic of the American palate at the end of the century is its preference for more assertive flavors over bland ones. People now favor red wine over white, fiery salsas over ketchup, espresso over the standard morning blend and very dark chocolate over milk chocolate.

title: HARRIS TO BUY LOUTH AUTOMATION FOR $85 MILLION
description: The Harris Corporation, which is transforming itself into a communications equipment company, agreed yesterday to buy closely held Louth Automation for about $85 million to enter cable and satellite markets. Louth provides systems and services that allow a broadcaster's list of programs and commercials to run in an automated environment. Harris, based in Melbourne, Fla., began shifting its focus to communications equipment from office equipment in April with its spinoff of Lanier Worldwide. The Louth acquisition gives Harris automated technology to strengthen its position in the international television and radio broadcast markets.

title: Merger Mania Got You Down? So, Start Thinking Small
description: WE might be forgiven for concluding that everything in corporate America is getting bigger and bigger. The global couplings in autos, oil and gas, financial services, telecommunications and now pharmaceuticals sometimes give the impression that the business world is driving toward an acquisition apocalypse. When the dust settles, we will all draw a paycheck from the same employer.

title: VODAFONE WANTS TALKS
description: Pressing a hostile $127.7 billion bid for Mannesmann A.G., the British wireless giant Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. urged the German company to ''discuss our proposal with us in the interests of all our shareholders.'' Mannesmann began its defense against Vodafone on Monday, saying it would make more profit as an independent company from a boom in voice, data and Internet services. But Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, insisted in a statement, ''Mannesmann has not advanced any argument that contradicts our view that we can capture more of this growth together.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERLY, CHARLES M.
description: WERLY-Charles M. of Duxbury, MA, November 29, age 93 years. Husband of the late Jane (Woods) Werly. Father of Jane E. Werly of Delray Beach, FL. He is also survived by 7 nieces & nephews. A Funeral Service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Washington St., Duxbury on Saturday December 4th. at 3 PM. Interment in St. John's Cemetery is private. Donations in his memory may be made to the Jane Woods Werly Scholarship, Ithaca College, Ithaca, New York 14850.

title: Mortgage Buyers to Raise Price Limits

title: Accountability and Mr. Arafat
description: Corruption and patronage are serious problems in the West Bank and Gaza Strip territories administered by Yasir Arafat and the Palestinian Authority. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, LUKE DANIEL
description: LYNCH-Luke Daniel, Sr. Died peacefully after a long illness on November 27, 1999 in Naples, Fla. Beloved husband of Marjorie for 55 years. Devoted father of Luke Jr. (Nancy), Dorsey (Joyce), and Dan (Cornelia) Lynch and Carol Manire (Michael). Big Chief to 11 grandchildren. Brother of James. Mr. Lynch was born in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn on August 2, 1921. He graduated from Regis High School in N.Y.C. (1939), attended Fordham University and graduated in 1944 from the U.S. Naval Academy (Class of 1945). While at the Naval Academy, he was class vice-president, played varsity basketball and baseball, was a company commander and a five-striper. He served in the Pacific Theater on the U.S.S. Alabama, which participated in the Japanese surrender at Tokyo Bay. After the war, he graduated from Columbia Law School (1949), and went on to a career specializing in insurance and reinsurance law. Mr. Lynch was a former senior partner of Mendes & Mount as well as LeBouef, Lamb & Leiby, where he represented Lloyds of London. At the time of his death, Mr. Lynch was a senior partner of the law firm of D'Amato & Lynch in N.Y.C. and a Director of Queens County Savings Bank. He was a former president of the Cherry Valley Club in Garden City, NY. The family will receive visitors Thursday, December 2, from 7-9, at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave, Garden City. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 3 at 11AM, St. Joseph's Church, Fifth Street and Franklin Ave, Garden City. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the U.S. Naval Academy Alumni Association-Class of 1945 Fund, U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, MD.

title: A Deli on the Upper West Side With Weeks of Tradition
description: AS a child on Long Island, I used to fantasize about Andel's, the local Jewish delicatessen. I'd walk through the door to be captured in a billowy aromatic embrace of vinegar and coriander, cabbage and rye, garlic and pepper. I'd look at the glass display cases, piled high with potato knishes, kugels, whitefish and funny gummy candies that looked like slices of fruit. I'd see the franks on the grill with a tray of sauerkraut, and mysterious steaming canisters, where the pastrami and corned beef lived. If only I could be locked in the delicatessen overnight, I thought, free to eat whatever I wanted.

title: FINLAY ENTERPRISE TO END OPERATIONS IN FRANCE
description: After three quarters of losses, Finlay Enterprises plans to sell most of its stores in France and shut the rest to reduce costs and focus on its United States business. Finlay, a New York-based operator of department-store fine-jewelry counters, said it planned to sell more than 80 of its 130 French stores to the closely held Histoire D'Or, a French jewelry retailer, for an undisclosed price. The rest of the stores will be closed. An edict from the French government forcing the company to abandon its discount pricing policy hastened the sale. Finlay leases about 1,100 jewelry departments from stores in the United States and France. Finlay's shares rose $2 each, to $14.375. They have risen more than 80 percent in the last year.

Mr. Gros-Pietro, 57, the former president of the Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, the industrial holding company, is expected to give the chief, Vittorio Mincato, free rein to forge a merger strategy to give Eni the scale it needs to compete globally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOYLES, WILLIAM P.
description: MOYLES-William P., 69, a business executive and lawyer, died at his home in Sewickley, PA. from complications resulting from Parkinson's Disease on Saturday, November 6, 1999. Born on June 1, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, He was educated at Xavier High School, NY., earned a Bachelor's Degree at Georgetown University and after serving in the United States Air Force, received a law degree from Harvard University. Mr. Moyles practiced law with Mendes & Mount and Donovan & Leisure in New York from 1957 to 1967. At that time, he became Head of the Legal and Mergers and Acquisitions Departments for Control Data Corporation in Minneapolis. He was with Control Data from 1967 to 1973. In 1973, he accepted an executive position with Gulf Oil Corporation in Pittsburgh where over the next eleven years, he was a Group Vice President in charge of Corporate Development and Administration as well as President and CEO of Gulf Oil's Real Estate subsidiary. After the Chevron Corporation purchasesd Gulf Oil in 1984, Mr. Moyles became one of the founding partners and President of MMC Group in Pittsburgh, a private equity investment firm focused on leveraged buyouts where he worked until his retirement in 1994. Mr. Moyles served on various corporate boards and was a member of the Board of the School for the Blind. He was a member of Allegheny Country Club, The Duquesne Club, and The Rolling Rock Club. Surviving immediate family are his wife Virginia Moyles, three daughters, Virginia St. Pierre of Alexandria, VA, Margaret Curran of Philadelphia, PA, Frances Fisher of San Francisco, CA, a sister, Mary Jane Murray of New Rochelle, NY, two brothers, Phillip Moyles of New York, NY, Kevin Moyles of Dallas, TX, and seven grandchildren. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers to please send memorial contributions to the Movement Research Disorder Foundation, Department of Neurology, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, Ohio 44195.

In a solo piano performance on Monday night at the Greenwich House Music School, he didn't make his compositional skill irrelevant by the desire to display technique, or lose himself in the grip of someone else's harmonies.

title: Paid Leave for Parents
description: President Clinton's plan to give states the option of providing unemployment insurance benefits for new parents is good for working families. The 1993 Family and Medical Leave Act gave workers the right to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for a newborn child or sick relative without losing their jobs. But many low-income workers cannot afford to take any amount of time off without pay. The new experimental project, which would be totally voluntary, would allow states to subsidize a leave following the birth or adoption of a child if they so chose. At least four states -- Vermont, Maryland, Massachusetts and Washington -- have proposed legislation to extend unemployment benefits to parental leave.

title: Eyes Covered but Seeing, A Novelist Looks Inward
description: One thing to know about Kent Haruf, author of the novel ''Plainsong,'' is that he wrote the first draft of the book with a wool stocking cap pulled down over his eyes. He would sit typing blindly in the unheated basement of his unpretentious white frame house in this sleepy town trying to visualize the high, dry Colorado plains of his childhood. He would try to imagine two little boys whose mother leaves them because she is so depressed and a half-Indian girl who is pregnant and has nowhere to go. Written in sparse, clean language, ''Plainsong'' is a novel about kindness and how it comes in unexpected ways.

title: Love That Lemonade Stand
description: I had no entrepreneurial ambitions until I came to America. I'd love to say I was one of those kids who set up a lemonade stand or had a paper route. But I didn't. I just wanted a job that paid more than my dad earned as a civil servant in India. I came to America in 1971 at age 22, got my M.B.A. at Kent State University, worked for a steel company in Ohio, then joined I.B.M. as a salesman. After six years, I said, O.K., this is it, time to go back and resume my life in India. But I was in love with a woman named Ruth, and it was either Ruth or India. I was torn. I went back to India in order to make a decision.

Built in the shape of a sail, the structure is designed to reflect Dubai's seafaring heritage. It soars more than 1,000 feet, making it one of the world's tallest hotels. With some 1.2 million square feet of floor space, the Arabian Tower features several engineering innovations, including a double-skinned, Teflon-coated fiberglass screen facing the water. Though Dubai has in the past discouraged recreational travelers, the resort heralds a new era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDILES, GEORGE
description: CONDILES-George. 72, formerly of Jackson Heights, Queens, residing in Yonkers, NY died of complications from cancer in Columbia Presbyterian Hospital on November 30, 1999. Born in NYC, he was the son of the late Domna Petros and the late Gus Condiles. He was the beloved husband to his adoring wife Callie Annis Condiles whom he married in 1954. His career as a New York City Chief Engineer and Building Manager for such properties as 488 Madison Ave. and the prestigious 277 Park Ave. office building, owned by Stanley Stahl, which he managed since its inception, spanned 40 years until his retirement in 1997. As a kind hearted, gentle man he made a lasting impression on everyone he met. Known as an expert in the field of engineering his respect of his fellow man and dedication to helping others in every aspect of life gained him much loyalty. A graduate of Long Island City High School, he served in the United State Army receiving an honorable discharge in 1946. Attending Farmingdale University he graduated with an engineering degree. He is survived by his wife Callie, who was the light of his life. As a devoted father he leaves his adoring four married daughters: Donna Geller, Adrienne Kostakis, Diane Condiles, Pamela Mediavilla and their husbands. His most precious joys were his five grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother Paul, a niece and two nephews. The wake will be at the Sinatra Funeral Home, 601 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, (914) 963-5263 on Thursday and Friday evenings from 7-9PM and Friday afternoon from 2-4PM. Services will be at 9:45AM, Saturday, December 4 at Holy Trinity Church, 10 Mill Road, New Rochelle, NY. Donations preferred to Holy Trinity G.O. Church.

title: Copland, Best Savored Selectively, Not Broadly

Things we don't find: size, weight, monumentality, spirituality, profound joy, profound sorrow. ''Completely Copland'' -- three weeks and a baker's dozen of concerts and side events devoted to this American composer by the New York Philharmonic -- is an excellent opportunity to poke at the less-known corners of one man's work. But I wonder how comfortable Copland would have felt having his music rattle around in so grand a format.

title: Taking Care Of the Architect On Your List
description: The never-ending project: a husband and wife team, Bernd and Hilla Becher, have spent the better part of four decades taking highly coveted pictures of pure forms. They shoot only on overcast days in stark black-and-white; the results are shadowless images of forgotten water towers, grain elevators, gas tanks and pipelines, primarily in Europe and North America. Now, there is ''Bernd and Hilla Becher Basic Forms'' (Te Neues Publishing, $22.95). The book is as much a testament to the Bechers' particular brand of documentary art as a homage to the grace and stature of the buildings themselves. Pictured, starting above: a cooling tower, a spherical gas tank, a structure for turning stone to gravel and a water tower.

His courage, wisdom, & compassion will always be remembered. Funeral services Thursday, December 2 at 1PM at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, NY.

title: Nets' Two Stars Attempt to Coexist
description: They are the Nets' two best players, the ones who will lead whatever revival takes place on what is currently one of the National Basketball Association's most wretched teams. Yet for much of this season, Stephon Marbury and Keith Van Horn have been as mismatched as polka dots and plaid, clashing on the court and keeping their distance off it.

title: SINGAPORE BROKERAGE MERGER
description: Two of Singapore's leading brokerage firms -- Vickers Ballas Holdings and G. K. Goh Holdings -- agreed to merge to form the biggest brokerage firm on the island state. The new brokerage firm will be called Goh, Vickers, with Goh Geok Khim as the executive chairman. Singapore's financial industry has been consolidating to gain the size and ability to compete regionally and take on the competition resulting from the liberalization in the island's financial services industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, DONALD PAUL
description: McCORMACK-Donald Paul. Of Westport, Connecticut, November 29. Retired Chief Editorial Writer for the NY Daily News. Husband of Patricia McCormack. Father of Christopher Paul McCormack. Brother of Jean Crowley and grandfather of two. Interment services with full military honors Saturday, December 4, 10 A.M. in Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport followed by a memorial Mass at 11A.M. at Assumption Church, Westport. Memorial contributions may be made to the Donald P. McCormack Memorial Fund, C/O Town of Westport Parks and Recreations Department, 210 So. Compo Road, Westport, CT 06880.

title: Rancor in House on Choice of a Chaplain
description: The choice of a new chaplain might have been expected to draw together the members of the House for a rare moment of spiritual harmony.

title: In Miami, The Designers Come and Go
description: From Milan to Coral Gables, Fla., to a new 4,500-square-foot space in the Miami design district. That's the path that Dilmos took in bringing its art furniture -- like the nearly six-foot-tall Michelangelo cabinet (left, $3,500, cribbed from the Sistine Chapel and hand-painted in Italy) -- to American shoppers. ''We wanted to be where the energy is,'' said Simona Ciancetta, the showroom manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMSTEIN, SOLOMON
description: BLUMSTEIN-Solomon. On November 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Eva. Dear brother of Sidney Blumstein. Loving uncle. Services Thursday, December 2, 1:15P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Taming Greeting Card Clutter
description: FORGET the Scotch tape and thumbtacks. Here are seven practical solutions, vintage and new, for organizing and displaying holiday greeting cards. Most of the designs reflect the holiday theme, but others can be used year-round to bring order to mail, photographs or other memorabilia.

title: U.S. Report Finds Airport Security Breaches and Criticizes F.A.A.
description: Undercover government inspectors have thwarted airport security so easily that in some instances they have been able to wander through cargo areas, go through gates and even board airplanes and sit down while pretending to be passengers, officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRELL, JERRY
description: TERRELL-Jerry. We are deeply saddened at the passing of Jerry, our beloved friend for over 40 years. He was a truly warm, kind and very giving person and we will miss him terribly. Our condolences to his dear wife, Sylvia, and daughters, Shelley, Fran and Barbara and their families. Bill and Lili Goldberg and Family

description: Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema flew to Tripoli today, the first head of a Western government to visit Libya in eight years.

description: After a decade of preparation, scientists have for the first time decoded the information in a human chromosome, the unit in which the genetic information is packaged.

description: Q. Are there two types of DVD drives that can record data? If so, which should I get?

title: Residents Complain of Lack of Assistance After Newark Plane Crash
description: The trail of wreckage and debris strewn along Kent Street last Friday by the crash of a small plane has been cleared away. But what remains is a wounded neighborhood where many say they are too traumatized to stay and where some bitterly complain that the city has yet to make good on promises of counseling, relocation and emergency help.

title: China Says Its Computers Are 'Basically Ready' for Year 2000
description: After months of belated preparations and testing, China is ''basically ready'' to enter 2000 with only minimal disruptions from computer breakdowns, a senior official said today.

description: Quarterback Jim Miller, who leaped unexpectedly from third string to starter this season for the Chicago Bears, was suspended today by the National Football League for four games for taking a dietary supplement containing an anabolic steroid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENBERGER, HERBERT J.
description: FREUDENBERGER-Herbert J. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the death of Herbert J. Freudenberger, beloved father of Marc J. Freud, vice-chair of our Real Estate Executives Committee, and father-inlaw of Nikki Freud, Director of Strategic Initiatives. A renowned psychoanalyst and prolific writer, he had a lasting influence on his profession which remains as his permanent legacy. We extend our sincerest condolences to Marc and Nikki; to his wife, Arlene; daughter Lisa Freudenberger Roth and her husband Theodore; daughter Lori Freudenberger; and all the members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Andrew J. Singer, Chair, Real Estate Div John S. Ruskay, Executive VP

title: HONG KONG PHONE STAKE
description: Japan's largest cellular phone company, NTT Mobile Communications Network, will buy a stake in a Hong Kong mobile phone venture owned by Hutchison Whampoa and Motorola. Motorola's interest in the venture, the Hutchison Telephone Company, Hong Kong's largest mobile phone operator, will be reduced to 25.1 percent from 30 percent after the acquisition. Hutchison will remain the venture's majority shareholder and will continue to handle day-to-day management of the company, Motorola said.

title: A Little Camus On the Calendar?
description: There was a time, not all that long ago, when you got your calendar from your insurance salesman or maybe your accountant or your automobile mechanic. The earnest photograph or painting of a lake in front of a mountain, or perhaps a row of birch trees, to tack on the kitchen wall. Fairly feeble but traditional glimpses of nature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKEY, ROBERT, DR. D.D.S.
description: BERKEY-Robert, Dr. D.D.S. of Sarasota, FL., and Monroe Twp., NJ, beloved husband of Eveline (nee Sherman), devoted father of Richard Berkey, Daniel Berkey and Joan Wilyamowsky, dear brother of Bernard Berkowitz and Seymour Berkey, grandfather of six. Funeral services at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey, today at 1PM. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

Funeral from the Memorial Funeral Home, 375 Broadway, Newport on Friday, December 3, 1999, at 11:00AM, followed by a graveside service at 11:30AM in the Rhode Island Veterans Cemetery, Exeter, RI. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Calling hours will be held on Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. A prayer service will be held on Thursday evening at 8:30PM in the funeral home. Memorial donations may be made to the Comprehensive Epilepsy Program for Evan Alexander Hodge, 110 Lockwood Street, Pediatric Neurology Suite 342, Providence, RI, 02903.

description: GILBURNE-Janet Betty. On November 29, 1999. Cherished wife of Allen for 44 years. Amazing mother to Elizabeth and Jessica. Loyal friend to so many. We love you, Janet. Precious cargo. Say goodbye Thursday, December 2nd, 3PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

title: Black Masks Lead to Pointed Fingers in Seattle
description: It took only a few minutes for the people in the monarch butterfly costumes and union jackets to realize that what was planned as the biggest American demonstration yet against global trade here had turned into a burst of window-breaking and looting late Tuesday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAECKEL, JOSEPH

title: Hockey, Behind the Mask and on the Web
description: OF the four major-league sports in North America, hockey has the best trophy, the most exciting playoffs -- there is more tension in a Calgary-Edmonton divisional semifinal than there has been in all 30 Super Bowls combined -- and the most inspiring championship ceremony. Players from the winning team skate around the arena and take turns hoisting the Stanley Cup overhead, which is somehow preferable to the baseball ritual of running around a shrink-wrapped locker room and spraying Tim McCarver with Budweiser.

title: PRESIDENT CHIDES WORLD TRADE BODY IN STORMY SEATTLE
description: With Seattle's streets locked down by the police and National Guard, President Clinton delivered two impassioned pleas today for nations of the world to use trade agreements to protect the rights of laborers and the environment, and delivered a pointed attack on the World Trade Organization for the secrecy of its operations.

title: Married, With Arias: Romance Onstage, Too
description: The Metropolitan Opera brought back its storybook production of Donizetti's ''Elisir d'Amore'' on Tuesday evening, but more to the point, the company brought back the tenor Roberto Alagna and the soprano Angela Gheorghiu, who are married to each other, to sing the romantic leads.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sturdy, Translucent Dishes From Down Under
description: As heavy as stone but made of translucent resin, the serving dishes from the Australian company Dinosaur Designs make for festive table settings. The durable (though not unbreakable), dishwasher-safe tableware began with the art-school explorations of Louise Olsen, Stephen Ormandy and Liane Rossler, who attended Sydney's City Art Institute in the early 80's. Hand-painted resin rings, necklaces, bangles, earrings and cuff links led in the 90's to jugs, platters, serving dishes, bowls and vases in a range of more than 100 jewel-like colors. Above, green plate, $55, blue plate, $120, orange bowl, $150. At DKNY, 655 Madison Avenue (60th Street): (212) 223-3569.

title: New York Parents Give Chancellor a D for Crowded Schools
description: A consortium of parent groups has accused Chancellor Rudy Crew of failing to do enough to reduce class size in overcrowded schools.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about a fund-raising trip by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to Texas, and a call he made on Gov. George W. Bush in Austin, carried an incorrect credit. It was taken by The Associated Press.

title: Yen Falls on Hints of Move by Central Bank
description: The yen fell against the dollar yesterday on speculation that the Bank of Japan would step up efforts to curb the yen's strength, which threatens to stymie economic recovery in Japan.

title: SHOPPING MALL OWNER TO BE SOLD
description: The Ontario Teachers Plan Pension Board, one of Canada's largest pension funds, has agreed to buy the 78 percent of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation it does not already own for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($1.56 billion). Cadillac Fairview, based in Toronto, owns 102 shopping malls and office buildings in Canada and the United States. It was put on the block in late September because two New York investors -- the Blackstone Group and Whitehall Street Real Estate Partnership, a unit of Goldman, Sachs & Company -- wanted to sell their combined 30 percent holding.

description: Seeds and Sales

title: Chris Gaines Plays a Cowboy
description: Pop music is a strange and mercurial world, where performers constantly reinvent themselves. The latest example of this was the country superstar Garth Brooks's donning of a wig and fake facial hair and releasing a fake greatest-hits album in the guise of a fictional rock star named Chris Gaines. To explain the concept to his country audience, Mr. Brooks presided over a special on NBC in September and a spurious tell-all documentary on VH1 last week about his rock creation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the appointment of Frank Lalli as editor in chief of George magazine misidentified the organization he once served as president. It is the American Society of Magazine Editors, not newspaper editors.

title: Logging On to the Stars
description: THERE are billions and billions of stars in the universe, as Carl Sagan used to say, not to mention galaxies, nebulas, comets, planets, moons, asteroids, satellites and space stations. No wonder, then, that people who are not familiar with telescopes may scoff when they hear star-gazers complain that it is hard to find things to look at.

title: AT&T and Charter Plan Cable Swaps
description: The AT&T Corporation, soon to be the largest United States cable television company, and Charter Communications Inc. said yesterday that they would swap cable systems serving about 1.3 million customers as they consolidate their regional service areas.

description: LaMAGNA-Liborio J. Died on December 1, 1999. Survived by his wife, Anna, sons, John, Richard and Robert. Reposing George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle Thursday, 7-9 PM, Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass Saturday 9:30 AM Holy Name Church, New Rochelle.

title: For Devils, Practice Just Adds to a Team's Discord
description: The day after only one player showed up for an optional practice, all 23 members of the Devils were present for this morning's skate. Still, it did not go off without a hitch. Jason Arnott showed up late for the second consecutive time and will have to buy dinner for the team.

description: Pittsburgh (5-6) at Jacksonville (10-1)

description: Manufacturing expanded in November for a 10th consecutive month and was on track to finish 1999 with the highest rate of growth in five years, a survey of business executives showed today.

title: At a Meeting With Voters, Gore Talks About His Plans, His Family and Himself
description: Following are excerpts from Vice President Al Gore's remarks on Nov. 19 as he met with about 60 people in a home in Keene, N.H., as transcribed by The New York Times. As he usually does, Mr. Gore made an opening statement and then took questions. The latter questions are condensed.

description: Senior defense officials of France, Germany and Britain are trying to reassure the United States prior to a NATO meeting on Thursday that rapidly coalescing plans to create an independent European military intervention force would not weaken the Atlantic alliance.

title: Tall Ideas, Small Rooms (12 by 12 by 24 Inches)
description: CUTE can be sophisticated. At ''Small Wonders X,'' an auction at Christie's on Monday, 15 miniature rooms by interior designers will be sold to benefit the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club in the Bronx.

title: For McCain, New York Ballot Is Tough to Crack
description: No matter how well Senator John McCain does in the early presidential contests, he is facing inhospitable terrain in one of the next skirmishes, the delegate-rich New York primary on March 7. Republicans in much of the state will not cast their ballots for Mr. McCain, his campaign concedes, because his name will not appear on their ballots.

title: Hurtado Is Released Because of Quota
description: Eduardo Hurtado of Ecuador was chosen yesterday by the MetroStars as the player to be released to comply with Major League Soccer's foreign-born player policy. The move was made to make room for the imminent arrival of Lothar Matthaus of Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSSELMAN, REV. JOSEPH GEORGE, SJ
description: MUSSELMAN - Rev. Joseph George, SJ, reposing at the St. Francis Xavier High School, Jesuit Community Chapel, 30 West 16th Street, NYC, on Friday 3-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Francis Xavier Church, Saturday, 10AM. For information, contact Farenga Brothers, Inc., Directors. (718-654-0500).

title: Another Debate That's Too Fair
description: Tonight, six Republican presidential candidates are scheduled to square off in a crowded debate in Manchester, N.H. They will be treated equally because that's the ''democratic'' thing to do.

title: Riviana Deal in Wild Rice
description: Riviana Foods Inc., the producer of Success brand rice, said today that it had acquired the Anheuser-Busch Companies' Gourmet House unit for an undisclosed amount of cash to build on its existing rice businesses. Gourmet House, of Clearbrook, Minn., produces and sells four wild-rice product lines. The acquisition will create a new line for the Houston-based Riviana, which already uses some wild rice in its products, the company's chief financial officer, E. Wayne Ray Jr., said.

title: Software Puts Personal Touches On Holiday Cards
description: IF the baby won't sit still for a photo wearing a Santa's hat, there's an electronic solution. Software for designing greeting cards, as well as desktop publishing and photo editing programs, will plant a digital hat on the baby's head, insert a frame and holiday note around the picture and, with a decent color printer, produce a professional-looking holiday card.

title: Art in Germany Crosses the Borders; The 'New Man' Keeps Popping Up in a Sprawling Exhibition About the Century
description: In any other country, a show reviewing the art of the last 100 years might well be considered a run-of-the-mill retrospective. In Germany, where art has often mirrored history with chilling accuracy, a vast exhibition called ''The 20th Century: A Century of Art in Germany'' is bound to raise questions, not least the political responsibility of the artist in times of war and peace, oppression and freedom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASTENBERG, ARTHUR
description: FASTENBERG-Arthur. On November 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Eve for 66 years. Cherished father of Francine and Irwin Levine, and Elaine and Leon Smith. Adoring grandfather of Lori, Karen, Daniel, Lauren, Susan and Jessica. Great-grandfather of David, Benjamin & Julia. Devoted brother of Milton, Abner, Selma, Marvin, William and the late Leonard. Dear uncle to many nieces and nephews. He will be sorely missed. Services were held.

title: Few Members Of Large Sect To Face Trial, Beijing Says
description: More than 150 people have been formally arrested in connection with the crackdown on the Falun Gong spiritual movement, a government official said today.

description: This was the week Bill Bradley was supposed to make a serious foreign-policy address at an appropriate forum: Tufts University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. Editors held space on their front pages.

title: Officials Say Witness Saw Troopers Fire In a Panic
description: A witness who said he saw New Jersey state troopers shoot three unarmed men during a traffic stop on the turnpike in April 1998 has told investigators that the officers appeared to fire their weapons in a panic, as the three men, two blacks and a Hispanic, drove their van away from the police, investigators said today.

title: Webcams Focus On Day Care
description: SUZY O'MARA of Hoover, Ala., watches her 18-month-old daughter, Morgan, all day long. That would not be unusual if Mrs. O'Mara was a stay-at-home mother, but she works full time as a claims adjuster at the State Farm Insurance Company in Birmingham, and her daughter spends her days at the Samford University day care center in the city.

title: Online Investors Grasping Initial Offerings
description: White-collar workers used to fret that if they lost their jobs, they might wind up flipping burgers. Dean Browning is making up for at least part of his lost wages by flipping stocks of newly public companies.

title: You Can Have Digital Images Without a Special Camera
description: YOU have all of the software for your digital darkroom -- now how do you get the photos in there? There are a variety of ways, including scanning, downloading from a digital camera or the Web, or copying from a compact disc. Even with the right equipment, issues of size, pixels and dots per inch can be confusing. Here is some help for figuring out what you need.

title: Clinton's Plea: 'Open the Meetings'
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech today to representatives at the World Trade Organization meeting here, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company.

title: Searching for Fashion Advice? You May Be Sorry You Asked
description: DO I need a personal shopper? Recently I showed up at a party in a dress that frankly looked like underwear. I would like to believe that an expert personal shopper would prevent me from repeating that sort of fashion tragedy.

title: New Jersey Man, 19, Is Accused of Drowning His Doting Grandmother to Steal Her Money
description: Mattie Chapman devoted her life to two things above all else -- her church and her grandson, Brandon Cowser -- her friends said yesterday.

title: INSMED PHARMACEUTICALS AGREES TO ACQUIRE CELTRIX
description: Insmed Pharmaceuticals Inc. has agreed to acquire Celtrix Pharmaceuticals Inc. in a stock swap valued at $140 million. Insmed, a privately held company in Richmond, Va., focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of insulin resistance, a condition related to diabetes and some other diseases. Celtrix, based in San Jose, Calif., develops drugs to treat degenerative conditions related to injuries, chronic diseases and aging. Under the agreement, each Insmed share can be exchanged for 3.5 shares of a new holding company formed for the acquisition, and each Celtrix share can be exchanged for one of the new shares. Celtrix shares rose 37.5 cents, to $1.9375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANG, HSICHU
description: CHANG-HsiChu. Age 82, of Cape May, NJ, died on November 29, 1999. Graduate of Yale University. Husband of Margaret (nee Holland). Also survived by children, grandchildren & a sister. Services will be private, at Evoy Funeral Home, Cape May, New Jersey.

title: Mets, Others Wait on Olerud
description: The Mets aren't the only ones waiting for John Olerud to decide if he wants to continue playing in New York or go home and play in Seattle.

title: Bronx Father, 19, Is Charged In Beating Death of His Infant
description: A 19-year-old Bronx man who called the police after his infant son stopped breathing on Oct. 30 has been charged with beating the child to death, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Finally, a Lineup With a Familiar Face
description: Laura S. Weiner was called in to review a series of police lineups in the two weeks after she saw a man throw a sandy-colored, brick-shaped paving stone at the head of a 27-year-old woman walking along a Midtown Manhattan street last month.

title: Neighbors Say Bronx Courthouse Will Only Mean More Congestion
description: If the administration of justice is not, by design, a particularly pleasant process, in the Bronx it is downright uncomfortable. Jurors line up in the hallways, because there is no waiting room. Criminal parts have been created in a building that was meant for civil cases alone, meaning that defendants must pass through the halls, sometimes brushing shoulders with their victims. There are civil judges without courtrooms.

title: Apartment Complexes Sold
description: Lend Lease Real Estate Investment Inc., the largest manager of pension-fund real estate assets, has teamed with the Essex Property Trust Inc. to buy two Southern California apartment complexes for $126.5 million. They paid $64.5 million for the Coronado at Newport South in Newport Beach, Calif., and $62 million for its sister property, Coronado at Newport North. The seller was not identified.

title: Knicks' Wallace Is Out of Step
description: The talented John Wallace expected to return home and find his way around the Knicks' system as easily as he would his old neighborhood.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I mean, here we are, in what is supposed to be the happiest, mellowest city on the planet, and look what's happening.''

title: Church and State Debate
description: In arguments in a case involving parochial school computers, the Supreme Court felt its way toward a more far-reaching debate over the relationship between government and religious schools. Page A32.

title: Leo Buys Stake In Dallas Agency
description: Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Company unit of the Leo Group, said yesterday that it had bought a minority interest in Moroch & Associates in Dallas, a retail field marketing agency. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: INFORMIX AGREES TO PURCHASE ARDENT SOFTWARE
description: The Informix Corporation, a maker of database software, agreed yesterday to acquire a rival, Ardent Software Inc., for $880 million in stock. Informix will swap 3.5 of its shares for each Ardent share, making the deal worth $38.50 an Ardent share based on Tuesday's closing price. Ardent's shares jumped $5.50, to $31.75, in Nasdaq trading, while shares of Informix dropped $1.3125, to $9.625. Informix, which had 1998 revenue of $734.9 million, makes database-management systems that let users store, retrieve and correlate information in a network. Ardent, based in Westboro, Mass., develops databases, software tools and data warehouses for business, industry and government. It had annual revenue of $119.3 million last year.

title: Government Proposes Regulations for Embryo Cell Research
description: To a dissonant chorus of cheers and objections, the National Institutes of Health released draft guidelines yesterday for governing research by federally financed scientists on human embryonic stem cells.

title: Bias Unit Examining Incidents At Several Catholic Churches
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily said yesterday that his Brooklyn diocese had experienced a ''chilling'' rash of incidents recently involving the desecration of sacred symbols, destruction of property and attempted break-ins at Roman Catholic churches.

title: MCI Worldcom Stock Falls More Than 5%
description: Shares of MCI Worldcom Inc., the No. 2 long-distance communications carrier, fell more than 5 percent yesterday amid fears that revenue growth is slowing as a price war continues in the residential long-distance telephone market.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS. Cocoa prices fell after growers in the Ivory Coast ended a protest that had disrupted exports from the world's biggest grower. In New York, cocoa for March delivery fell $32, or 3.6 percent, to $867 a metric ton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, RITA
description: KAUFMAN-Rita. Ohr Torah Stone Colleges and Graduate Programs and especially Midreshet Lindenbaum, its faculty and student body, records with deep sorrow the passing of Rita Kaufman, a magnificent, majestic matriarch in Israel. She was a woman of rare honesty and integrity who knew exactly where she stood as well as where everyone else ought to stand. Her devotion to her late husband Benjamin, as well as to her family knew no bounds and her commitment to her tradition and her people was total and genuine. Her greatest legacy is her exemplary children, the late Judith, Belda, Carol and Jerry and their spouses-children and grandchildren-including her twenty-five great grandchildren to whom she bequeathed her commitment and forthrightness. Now that she is joined with her husband in their eternal reward, I am certain that, despite the midrash, she will take her rightful place not at his footstool, but as his complete partner. The family they created togetherunto the fourth generation-continues to cast their splendor over all of Israel. With ever lasting love and admiration. Shlomo Riskin, Chancellor Ohr Torah Stone Colleges and Graduate Programs

title: Bucs Rookie Is Ready for Prime Time
description: Back in training camp, and in preseason games, Shaun King looked like a rookie who was ready. But Tony Dungy, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' coach, insisted that a timetable not be set on his young quarterback.

title: Why Some People Compete And Others Are Explainers
description: It is perhaps some comfort to the national teams who will seek world titles in Bermuda in January and again in the Netherlands in August that there is one team they will not have to face. The foursome that won the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams in Boston on Sunday at the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals has players of three nationalities and therefore cannot be a unit for world competition.

title: . . . And Then They All Read Happily Ever After
description: ''We should never grow so old, or change so much, that we cannot find room in our hearts for the wisdom of children's books,'' writes Judith Viorst acutely in her foreword to a charming new anthology of quotations, ''What the Dormouse Said: Lessons for Grown-Ups From Children's Books,'' collected by Amy Gash and illustrated by Pierre Le-Tan (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill; $14.95).

title: Messages for the W.T.O.
description: Tuesday's street scene in Seattle -- the chanting demonstrators, the tear gas, the National Guard -- seemed a flashback to the 1960's. That the protests were aimed not at a divisive war but a peaceable meeting of the World Trade Organization made the whole thing even more surreal. The chaos conveyed a warning to both sides.

title: Nassau Democrats Seek Budget Summit
description: A month after Republicans adopted a budget they said would address Nassau County's fiscal problems, the budget process today began to look like a free-for-all with no solution in sight.

title: PG & E TO SEEK BUYERS OR PARTNERS FOR TEXAS GAS ASSETS
description: The PG & E Corporation plans to sell or seek partners for its natural gas pipelines and plants in Texas as part of a restructuring intended to improve profit. PG & E acquired the pipelines, which have a book value of $2.5 billion, in 1997 and 1998. The San Francisco-based company said in a federal filing that it would consider selling the entire 8,500-mile Texas pipeline system and nine processing plants even if it has to record a loss on the sale. PG & E hired Lehman Brothers to advise it. The natural gas unit has not performed as well as PG & E expected because of reduced profit margins on natural gas and fuels like propane and butane that it extracts from gas.

title: Big Names Lead in Holiday Internet Sales

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, ELIZABETH
description: FOSTER-Elizabeth Read, 87, historian and educator, died peacefully in her home November 27, 1999 in Wayne, PA. She was born on June 26, 1912 in Chicago, the daughter of Conyers Read, a historian, and Edith Coulson Kirk Read. She grew up in Villanova, PA., and graduated from Vassar College in 1933. At Vassar, she saw classmates forced to withdraw because of the Great Depression, and so organized a successful undergraduate effort to raise enough funds to bring them all back. In 1932-33, she was elected head of the Vassar student body and vice president of the National Federation of Students. In 1933-34, she worked as assistant dean in charge of residence halls at Barnard College and as grading supervisor for the Educational Testing Service. She received an M.A. in Sociology from Columbia University (1934) and, with support from a Vassar fellowship, a Ph.D. in history from Yale University (1938). At Yale she was drawn into the study of English parliamentary history under the aegis of Hartley Simpson and Wallace Notestein. In 1938, she married Richard W. Foster, a bookseller; they had four sons. She returned to academic life in 1953 as a part-time instructor of history at Ursinus College, Collegeville, PA (assistant professor 1956, associate 1962) and a visiting associate professor at the University of Delaware (196263). Her first book, ''Proceedings in Parliament 1610'' (2 volumes, 1965), established her as a leading scholar of Stuart England. She was appointed Research Fellow and Acting Director of the Yale Center for Parliamentary History (1965) and Professor of History at Bryn Mawr College (professor emeritus 1981). As first dean of the Bryn Mawr Graduate School (1966-70), she reorganized it as the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences (dean 1970-73). She worked to raise the faculty and student standards of the Graduate School and to enhance its position nationally, especially through her service on the Committee on Policies, Plans and Resolutions and on the Executive Committee of the Council of Graduate Schools. She presided over a period of rapid growth in the Graduate School, including two new programs (Biochemistry and the History of Science), and was an effective seeker of federal funds for education. She also found financial support for part-time study and actively encouraged graduate student self-government and faculty research. Her interests in the history of English parliamentary and judicial procedure and recordkeeping were further developed in three books, ''The House of Lords 1603-1649'' (1983) and two studies of Henry Elsyng, clerk of the parliaments 1621-35, ''The Painful Labour of Mr. Elsyng'' (1972) and ''Judicature in Parliament by Henry Elsyng Clerk of the Parliaments'' (1991), and in numerous articles. After retirement, she was special advisor to the president of Bryn Mawr College on various projects, including design and construction of new library facilities and the expansion of the science building, and continued her lifelong association with the editorial board and advisory council of the Yale Center for Parliamentary History. In 1979, the Yale Graduate School awarded her its Wilbur Lucius Cross Medal for outstanding achievement in scholarship, teaching and academic administration. She was a member of the American Historical Association (editorial board of the ''American Historical Review,'' 1979-81), the Conference on British Studies (council, 1968-73), the Royal Historical Society, Society of Antiquaries, the British Museum, Middle Atlantic Conference on British Studies and other professional associations. In civic and private life, she was active for some years in the Pennsylvania League of Women Voters and the Federation for Planned Parenthood, and was always interested in supporting education opportunities for women. She is survived by her husband, Richard W. Foster; sons Richard C., Timothy, Benjamin R. and Daniel W.; and six grandchildren.

title: Did Someone Say Fish Tank?

''I've always thought that bathroom fixtures should be more interesting to look at,'' Mr. Beckert said. His commode (left, $1,200) swaps the conventional porcelain tank with one made of partitioned acrylic. From the front, it appears the fish are swimming placidly around, unaware of imminent danger. From the top, the ruse becomes apparent: water drains and refills from the rear of the tank only, leaving the fish safe from harm. By special order through Elseware Design; (718) 963-4155 or www.elseware.to.

title: A Perfectly Normal Day, but Then It All Changed

In this case the calamity of a child's death is meant to shatter all the humdrum routine that once defined Alice Goodwin (Ms. Weaver) and her life on a Wisconsin farm.
