title: A Timeless Spirit of Giving Melts That Hardened Heart
description: ''A Christmas Carol'' has been so candied over the years, starring everyone from Bill Murray to Scrooge McDuck, that in the popular imagination it has lost the dark vision of poverty that inspired Dickens's tale. But redemption as extreme as Scrooge's has to come from the bitter depths of misanthropy. TNT's lively new film restores the hardheartedness of the pre-reformed Scrooge while retaining the delight he later finds in joining the human race. With a vivid texture of 19th-century Christmas festivities -- full of songs, dances and bowls of punch you can almost taste -- and with Patrick Stewart as a Scrooge whose transformation makes sense, this is a glorious ''Christmas Carol.''

The stock of SFX dropped $6.4375, to $27.50. An analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, Richard Greenfield, cut his cash-flow estimates for SFX this year by $5 million, to $245 million, because of slower ticket sales related to fear about Year 2000 computer problems. The company's SFX Sports Group includes the sports-marketing company Integrated Sports International, which manages a number of prominent professional athletes.

title: After a Freudian Century, There Are Good Dreams and Bad
description: It was a one-sided affair from the very start. In the early 20th century, modern artists fell in love with psychoanalysis -- with Jean-Martin Charcot's thrashing hysterics, Sigmund Freud's interpretation of dreams and Carl Jung's universal archetypes. Alas, the love was not returned. ''Charcot disdained symbolism, Freud was suspicious of surrealism, and Jung was unmoved by abstract art,'' writes Lynn Gamwell, the curator of ''Dreams 1900-2000: Science, Art and the Unconscious Mind.''

title: Setting a Price on Nazi Slavery
description: More than 50 years ago, millions of citizens of Central and Eastern Europe were compelled to work under monstrous conditions for German companies and the Nazi state. Concentration camp inmates, mostly Jews, were used by the companies as slaves in manufacturing facilities inside the camps. Others, mostly non-Jews, were deported to Germany and made to do forced labor in factories and on farms to sustain the Nazi war effort. Hundreds of thousands of people who survived these ordeals are still alive. But all are elderly and thousands die each month. If they are ever to be compensated for their nightmarish suffering, it must be soon.

title: Supreme Smoke
description: The Supreme Court justices heard arguments on Wednesday in a case testing the Food and Drug Administration's authority to regulate the nicotine in tobacco products. The skeptical tenor of the questioning indicates that the court is likely to issue an opinion that rejects the agency's assertion of jurisdiction, wiping out entirely the agency's 1996 initiative aimed at preventing tobacco companies from spreading nicotine addiction by selling and marketing their deadly products to young people. That would be a shame. There are arguments on both sides of this controversial struggle, as was demonstrated by a district court decision upholding the F.D.A.'s jurisdiction and a split appeals-court decision against the F.D.A. This is hardly an open-and-shut case of overreaching by a federal agency.

title: When Passion Turns to Poison
description: On a rainy night in London in 1946 two men meet in a park, and one invites the other home to talk. And as Maurice Bendrix (Ralph Fiennes) climbs the curving staircase with Henry Miles (Stephen Rea), voluptuous memories of adultery rush in. Images of the two somber men are interspersed with the sound of rustling silk and sudden, erotic flashbacks: Maurice, with Henry's wife, Sarah (Julianne Moore), on the same stairs several years earlier, passionately clutching her as the two were about to make love for the first time. When it comes to holiday films worth swooning over, here's the one to see.

Household International, based in Prospect Heights, Ill., provides services like consumer financing, credit cards and credit insurance. Renaissance is to operate as a wholly owned subsidiary. title: USX Buys Tube Company
description: The USX Corporation, whose U.S. Steel Group is the nation's leading steel maker, said today that it planned to buy out the 50 percent stake in an Ohio tube company held by its joint venture partner Kobe Steel Ltd. The venture, the Lorain Tubular Company, has two mills in Lorain, Ohio, that make steel tubes for use by the natural gas and oil industries, USX said. The tube company was formed in August, after USX and the Japanese steel maker sold their joint-venture steel-bar business. Lorain Tubular will become part of United States Steel. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: New York's Unfair Primaries
description: In more enlightened states like California or Maryland, where choice is considered a crucial part of the voting experience, ballots for presidential primaries list almost any contender who has been in the news. This is not the case in New York. When the state's voters go to the polls next March 7 to decide who should represent the parties in the presidential race, some familiar names, especially Republicans, could be missing from all or some of the ballots in New York's 31 Congressional districts. The reason is that New York's arcane rules conspire to keep all but front-runners off the ballot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MILTON F.
description: LEWIS-Milton F., 86 years old, investment banker & philanthropist, died Thursday morning of natural causes at his home in Teaneck, New Jersey. A resident of Avon by the Sea, New Jersey; and Venice, Florida. Born in 1913 in West Hoboken to Edmund and Emily (nee Materka). Lewis, devoted father of Patricia A. of Teaneck, Vincent J. of Saddle River and Maureen W. Corbett of Oradell, grandfather of Vincent J., Colleen A., Robert M. and Maureen C. Great-grandfather of Katherine Rita. He graduated from Francis Xavier High School in New York City. He later attended night school and graduated from New York University. Mr. Lewis had a long and distinguished career in the securities industry. As an investment banker, he rose to the position of Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors of Howard, Weil, Lobouisse, Friedrichs Inc., a member of the New York Stock Exchange and other leading exchanges. During his career, Mr. Lewis served on more than 20 corporate boards, including Marcal Paper Mills, Kings Super Markets, Morrison Inc. and Welterow Inc. As a supporter of various Catholic Charities and organizations, Mr. Lewis' guiding hand was felt by many people especially the needy. He and his wife founded the Foundation of the Care of Migrant Poor in Venice, FL. He was a valued member of the Archbishops Committee of the Laity of the Archdiocese of Newark. Mr. Lewis was formerly active on the boards of Seton Hall University, Caldwell College and Marymount College. Over the course of his life, Mr. Lewis has been honored by several notable institutions and distiguished individuals. He was elevated to a Knight Commander of the Knights of Malta, St. Gregory and the Holy Sepulcher.

title: Jazz, Out of the Shadows And Into the Spotlight
description: ''Sweet and Lowdown'' is an appealingly personal film for Woody Allen, and not in any tired sense of what personal means. It celebrates the kind of vintage 1930's jazz that has tootled through the soundtrack of many a previous Allen film, and that finally has the chance to occupy center stage. In ''Sweet and Lowdown,'' the spotlight shines on a traveling musician who is as impossible as he is talented, embodying the jaunty yet soulful spirit of the music he plays. The film doesn't have much more of a guiding idea than a favorite jazz-lover's notion: that it would have been great to step back into this rollicking phase of jazz history and find out what the near-greats were like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LLOYD HILTON
description: SMITH-Lloyd Hilton. A resident of Southampton, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, died Wednesday October 27, 1999, in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Smith often quoted the Mark Twain exclamation, ''If I cannot smoke cigars in Heaven, then I won't go,'' was 94. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, the deceased was a member of The Yale Class of 1929 where he was Editor of The Daily News. Following graduation he pursued a career in finance in New York City, and was a founder of Argus Research Corporation and Laird Inc. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy, achieving the rank of Lt. Commander, and seeing action in the Pacific, on the legendary aircraft carriers, The Hornet and The Wasp. Following the war, Mr. Smith was active as an independent oil and gas producer and was Chairman of Paraffine Oil Company in Houston, TX. He served on numerous corporate boards, including Curtis-Wright Corporation, Information Storage Systems, and Falcon-Seaboard Inc. He was also a Director of The Michael DeBakey Medical Foundation, and The Museum of Fine Arts in Houston. The deceased was well known as a staunch supporter of The Republican Party. He was a Founding Director of The National Review Magazine, and along with Paul Nitze, The Committee On The Present Danger. He was also a major benefactor of The American Spectator Magazine and The Heritage Foundation. Mr. Smith had been a Member of The National Golf Links of America, The Brook, The Southampton Club, The Meadow Club, and The Racquet and Tennis Club in New York, and The Everglades and The Bath and Tennis Clubs in Palm Beach. Mr. Smith was predeceased by his wife, Elizabeth Keith Wiess, and his sister, Elizabeth Smith Hamilton. He is survived by four daughters, Camilla Clay Smith, Sandra Isabel Lloyd, and husband Douglass Smith, Sharon Keller, and husband David, and Sydney MacPherson, and husband Barry, grandchildren, Robert Livingston Gerry IV, Lloyd Harriman Gerry, Christopher Schaefer Keller, Michael Roland Keller, Elizabeth Cairns MacPherson, Ian Barry MacPherson, Megan Keith MacPherson, and great grand daughter Katherine Lloyd Keller. Funeral services were held Friday October 29, 1999, at 3 P.M. at The Episcopal Church of Bethesda By The Sea, in Palm Beach. Interment was on Monday November 1, 1999, at The Southampton Cemetery. The family has requested memorial contributions be made to the donors' favorite charities.L

title: A Spiritual Tug of War In the Australian Outback
description: ''Holy Smoke'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 8. The film opens today at the Sony Theaters Lincoln Square, 1998 Broadway, at 68th Street.

title: Thinking to Live, and Living to Think
description: Successful novelists are the luckiest people. When something really bad happens to them, when they need to hash out the meaning of their lives, they have alter egos to talk to: always available and never bored, if not always sympathetic. For Ginger Andrews, the heroine of Marsha Norman's beautiful new one-act play, ''Trudy Blue,'' the lesson may be that alter egos are addictive and no match for the warm-blooded comfort of real human beings, no matter how flawed. Especially when you've just been told you have two months to live.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: You can see why the people lining up for ''Mansfield Park'' at the Paris Theater might do a double take. Behind glass doors just a few feet from the ticket booth, a very inviting U-shaped bar beckons, just the thing for the serious moviegoer in need of a deep martini before wrestling with Jane Austen.

title: Animated, But Hardly By Disney
description: For five minutes or so, in an animated world of harsh black and pure white, a foolish cat, who clearly doesn't understand the universe it lives in, chases the moon. It goes to sea to get closer; it jumps from rooftop to rooftop; it pounces on the moon's shadow. Then the cat grows older, and tired. ''Time went by,'' it explains in voice-over. ''Now I don't run anymore. I wait.'' And in a matter of seconds, ''The Story of the Cat and the Moon,'' a charming Portuguese feather of a film by Pedro Serrazina, ends with a surge of rare, gorgeous emotional power, seemingly out of nowhere.

title: Four Arrests Provide Glimpse Into Smuggled-Heroin Trade
description: Federal agents investigating money laundering in Queens followed a pair of suspects to the Bronx on Wednesday and stumbled onto a collection point for heroin smuggled in from Colombia by couriers who swallow the drug, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNAHUM, MICHAEL
description: BENNAHUM-Michael. On November 1, Michael Bennahum, 58, died of cancer at home surrounded by his family. He is survived by his soulmate and wife Leslie, his children David and Samantha who gave him so much joy, his aunt Stella whom he loved dearly, and his brother David whose care and love were constant. Though taken so soon, we were blessed with every moment Michael shared with us. His generosity extended to his work as an investment banker, film producer, and Democratic social activist. His greatest gift was the gift of inspiration, especially to the young where he gave them the confidence and clarity to extend themselves in pursuits that seemed beyond their reach. His legacy will live on through all the lives he inspired. In the words of the poet R.M. Rilke, ''I live my life in circles/that reach out across the world./I may not complete the last one,/but I give myself to it.'' Burial in Binyamina, Israel. Memorial service Tuesday, November 9, 2:30 p.m. Beir Chapel, Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55th St. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Membership In Key Group Within U.N. Eludes Israel
description: A move to admit Israel to a group of European and other nations so it can take part more fully in United Nations activities seems to have stalled because the Europeans cannot muster a consensus, diplomats say.

title: Washington Kicker Apologizes to Fans
description: After getting letters from some upset fans, Washington place-kicker Brett Conway today apologized for saying, ''Half the fans are drunk'' at Redskins games.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Naum Gabo

title: 'God's Parking Lot' Is in Conflict With Rome's Ancient Past
description: One of the more ambitious Italian construction projects for the year 2000, a Holy Year for the Roman Catholic Church, is a $45 million six-level underground garage inside the Vatican.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: DELAY ON NATWEST BID
description: Possibly delaying a bidding war for National Westminster Bank P.L.C., Britain's Office of Fair Trading said it had extended the deadline for the review of the Royal Bank of Scotland's hostile bid for NatWest until Dec. 29. Britain's Takeover Panel formerly had until next Monday to determine if the bid would be referred to the Competition Committee, but it requested more time to complete its review. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONEY, DONALD F.
description: MOONEY-Donald F., Esq. Born July 9, 1926. Died November 1, 1999. Beloved father of Kathleen, Mark, Donald, Joanne, Jacqueline, Matthew and Paul. Husband to Florence, grandfather to Michael, Megan, Nicole, Annabelle and Kevin. Survived by sister Pat and brother to deceased, Jack and Margaret. Alumnus of Regis High School, Fordham University, St. John's Law School and member of the International Maritime Association. Wake services, Wednesday & Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at Lincoln Park Funeral Home, 625 McLean Avenue, Yonkers, NY (914-963-1550). Mass, Friday 10:30 AM at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Nepera-Park, Yonkers, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Sisters of Charity, c/o Sister Elizabeth Vermaelen, Mt. St. Vincent on Hudson, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471 apppreciated.

title: BMG Is Said Ready to Close Country Label
description: BMG Entertainment is preparing to shut its 10-year-old Nashville label, Arista Nashville, according to executives inside the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, SAMUEL
description: KARP-Samuel, on November 2. Beloved husband of Helen. Dear father of Bruce and Stephanie, Iris and Louis, and the late Walter J. Cherished grandfather of Stacy, Walter, Jennifer, Jessica and David. Dear brother of Louis and Martin Karp and Gerry Lapayover. Service today, 1PM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATURAL MICROSYSTEMS CORP., Framingham, Mass., a maker of Internet-based phone switches, agreed to buy a closely held rival, Qwes.com, Tustin, Calif., for $57.9 million in stock.

title: Mike Ockrent, 53, Who Directed On Broadway and in London
description: Mike Ockrent, an acclaimed British director whose light touch invigorated musicals and plays in London and New York, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. He was 53.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, SELMA
description: BERKLEY-Selma. December 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sidney J. Berkley. Loving mother of Marjorie B. Krug, Constance B. Margolin and Audrey B. May. Cherished grandmother of Dana Krug Lichtenstein, Nora Krug, Drew Margolin, Dale Margolin, Suzanne May and Elizabeth May. Great grandmother of Sam Lichtenstein. Devoted sister of Ira Gissen and the late Julia Barnett. Memorial service Sun., December 5th, 3PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, RITA
description: KAUFMAN-Rita. Her home was our house of delights when we were children visiting New York. As adults, we learned from her strength, often cited by our mother, as Aunt Rita met the triumphs and tragedies of her life. Happy memories of Aunt Rita, Uncle Ben, and their splendid children are a blessing to us. Gabrielle Ribach Propp & Deborah Ribach & Zwang

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Fabian Marcaccio

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DANNENBERG, MYRA
description: DANNENBERG-Myra. In cherished & loving memory of beloved mother & grandmother. Always in our thoughts. Barbara, Richard, Sudi, Olivier, Jason, David and Icoline

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLIN, ELIZABETH
description: COUGHLIN-Elizabeth (Aunt Liz) On November 1, 1999. Loving sister of Francis, the late Daniel and Augustine (Uncle Brother). Loving, helpful and caring aunt to ten nieces and nephews and 21 grand nieces and grand nephews. Former Chief Archivist of American Mental Climax, past President of Soropotimist International of New York. Long time resident of St. Francis DeSales Parish, Manhattan. Member of the famous Brefni Court Association in Rockaway. Reposing at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave.(81 St.)N.Y. Visiting 7-9pm November 3rd; 2-5pm & 7-9pm on Thursday, November 4th. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Francis DeSales Church, 135 E. 96 St. Manhattan, Friday, November 5th, 1999 at 10am. Burial in Calvary Cemetery Friday. Donations in lieu of flowers to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, N.Y. 10461 in her memory would be appreciated.

title: Thank You, Mr. Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: Peace Reigns, So Mozambique Faces Its Poverty
description: Seven years after the guns fell silent, jackhammers are ringing, new hotels are rising, new schools are opening, and newly paved roads are rolling across the land.

title: NTT DOCOMO INVESTS $410 MILLION
description: The second-largest mobile telephone operator in the world, NTT Mobile Communications Network Inc., disclosed it was paying $410 million for a 19 percent stake in the wireless business of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. of Hong Kong. The investment was previously disclosed, but the amount was not revealed. Stephanie Strom

title: Widowed Mom of 7 vs. a Loan Shark
description: What actress wouldn't be tempted to play someone as gosh darn lovable as the title character of Anjelica Huston's film ''Agnes Browne''? The indefatigably plucky, good-humored mother of seven adoring children in 1967 Dublin, Agnes (Ms. Huston) is a twinkly-eyed, salt-of-the-earth gal and ideal mom who rarely loses her temper despite being poor and newly widowed with mouths to feed and a job selling fruits and vegetables in an outdoor market. How does Agnes do it? Only heaven and the creators of upbeat radio serials and popular novels and the people who turn them into treacly feel-good movies could really tell you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, SAMSON D.
description: PRICE-Samson D. Died November 2, 1999 in Greenville, SC. He was 96 years old. He is survived by his wife, Ruth; his sons, Kenneth, Edward and Arthur; his grandchildren Giselle, Andrew and Stephen; and his daughters-in law, Graciela, Patricia and Sandra. He was a pioneer of the frozen fruit industry. He was a founder of Chill-Ripe Fruit, Inc., Frosted Fruit Products, Inc., Mid-Valley Products, Inc, and Empacadora Santa Clara, S.A. He was devoted to his family, his church and his industry.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Thomas Schutte

title: Even When They Play at Home, Rangers Have Not Had the Heart
description: In better times, the Rangers would be looking forward to tonight's contest at Madison Square Garden. The game, against the Montreal Canadiens, is the Rangers' first at home since Nov. 13, a three-week span. And beginning tonight, the Rangers play seven of their next eight games at home.

title: Man Shot in Subway Was Trying To Rob Another, the Police Say
description: When the police responded to a call of a man shot on a subway platform in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, officials said, the officers initially thought the wounded man was the victim of a robbery gone awry or an unlucky bystander.

title: A High School Without a Home; Academy's Temporary Location Is Drawing Bitter Complaints
description: The building's tenants had complaints that if not familiar, would sound plausible to just about anyone who lives in a neglected New York City tenement. Rats scurrying around piles of garbage on a narrow sidewalk just outside the entrance. Mice infesting rooms and closets. Unsecured and poorly lighted stairwells, with marijuana smoke wafting up from the floors below. Weeks without incoming phone service. Harassment by addicts from a nearby drug treatment center.

title: The Euro Slips Briefly Below Dollar's Value
description: Europe's single currency hit a symbolic and political low point today when it briefly dropped below the value of the United States dollar for the first time since its introduction nearly a year ago.

title: Scientists Criticize Limits on Foreign Visitors to Laboratories
description: A committee of the National Academy of Sciences, the nation's top scientific advisory group, has criticized a federal crackdown on visits by foreign scientists to the nation's nuclear weapons laboratories, saying worries about security must be balanced by the benefits of the visits and by the scientific openness they foster.

title: FIRST STERLING AND MAIN STREET BANKS AGREE TO MERGE
description: First Sterling Banks, a suburban Atlanta bank, agreed yesterday to acquire its neighbor Main Street Banks for stock worth $115.9 million. First Sterling, based in Kennesaw, Ga., said the merger would create the largest community banking organization in the Atlanta area, with assets of more than $900 million. First Sterling shares jumped $2.75, to $13. Main Street, a closely held bank based in Covington, Ga., has 13 branches and $500 million in assets. Main Street's shareholders are expected to hold about 63 percent of the new company's 14.1 million common shares.

title: Morgan Stanley Names Chief Legal Officer
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company has hired Donald G. Kempf Jr., a senior partner with the law firm Kirkland & Ellis in Chicago, as its chief legal officer.

title: Queens College AIDS Lab To Be Taken Over by CUNY
description: Just days after the president of Queens College announced that the college had met a deadline to raise private money for a biological research center run by a famed AIDS researcher, officials at the City University of New York said yesterday that Queens had not met the deadline and that CUNY would take control of the project and try to salvage it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, JOSEPH
description: FORMAN-Joseph. It is with profound sorrow that Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center/Rutland Nursing Home, its Board of Trustees, Medical/Dental Staff, and all personnel mourn the passing of Joseph Forman, esteemed Board Member. Sincere sympathies to his wife, Jean, and family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David Minkin, President Emeritus Stanley Mandel, Chairman Of The Board Linda Brady, M.D., President and CEO

title: Digging Antiquities (Two Ways)
description: Antiquities are like sweatshirts: they come in S, M, L and XL. For aficionados of the extra-large, Christmas begins every November when Prof. Christopher Ratte of New York University's Institute of Fine Arts gives his illustrated report on its excavations in Aphrodisias in western Turkey. N.Y.U. has sponsored the archaeological dig at Aphrodisias, a Greek city founded around the second century B.C., since 1961.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Joan Jonas

title: Police Continue Search For East Harlem Rapist
description: The police continued their search last night for a rapist who has attacked three young women in East Harlem housing projects, most recently on Nov. 24.

title: Just Another Girl on the IRT, But Is Lydia Fit for Peoria?
description: You see her all over the subway, this girl Lydia, hip-hop cartoon character, rappin' poster girl for public health. See, girlfriend's in a jam. Got chlamydia from her lover, ''but didn't want to tell her father, mother, sister or her brother.'' So she gets some advice from her best friend Bea, a veritable expert on S.T.D.'s.

title: The Big City; The Handout That's No Help To the Needy
description: WHETHER or not Paris Drake is guilty of flinging a brick at a woman on 42nd Street, his sudden notoriety is not doing a lot for New York's image. The stories of his life raise an obvious question: why was a crack addict with a history of violence and a long rap sheet prowling the streets?

title: A Tribute to Dr. King
description: After 15 years of waiting, the National Capital Planning Commission has approved the building of a memorial for Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Washington D.C., on the shore of the Tidal Basin between the memorials of Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson. This announcement will surely spark a debate about whether a private citizen deserves commemoration in the national monument core, among structures built exclusively for former presidents. The answer in Dr. King's case is a resounding ''yes.'' His leadership redrew the American civic map and places him squarely in the tradition of both Lincoln and Jefferson, whose themes he drew upon and deepened.

title: EgyptAir Rumors
description: To the Editor:

title: AVANT IS PAYING $24 MILLION TO ACQUIRE ANALOGY
description: The Avant Corporation, which makes software used to design microprocessors, agreed to buy Analogy Inc. yesterday for $2.48 a share in cash, or about $24 million, to gain its technology. Analogy makes products used to design and manufacture chips and other devices that convert analog signals, like voices, into digital ones. Avant, based in Fremont, Calif., had 1998 revenue of $227.1 million. It will add Analogy's mixed-signal technology to its product line and allow the company to enter the military, aerospace and automotive markets. Analogy, based in Beaverton, Ore., had revenue of $26.8 million for the year ended March 31. Shares of Analogy, which have fallen 28 percent this year, rose 37.5 cents, to $2.25, on Nasdaq.

title: Unintentional Weight Loss
description: Kevin Williams disclosed today that he had lost 37 pounds during his monthlong hospitalization for complications of a throat infection that spread to his heart and lungs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOW, ARTHUR M.
description: DUBOW-Arthur M. Of East Hampton, NY and Patagonia, AZ, on December 3 at age 66. Beloved husband of Barbara Shattuck Dubow and devoted father of Alexandra and Charles and grandfather of William. A graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School, Mr. Dubow became a venture capitalist and pursued an active and rewarding career investing in South Korea, as well as in the oil and gas business, the publishing industry and film production. He was a member of the Harvard Club of New York, as well as Boston's Somerset Club and Tavern Club. His great passions were education, international affairs and Bernese Mountain Dogs. He was a man who was loved by many and will be deeply missed.

title: With Rally, Devils Stay Happy At Home
description: After several days of disenchantment within the Devils, there were smiling faces throughout their dressing room tonight after the team's best offensive production of the season, a 7-4 triumph over the Ottawa Senators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNING, MARY BAVETTA
description: HANNING-Mary Bavetta. March 17, 1899-December 2, 1999, witness to the century. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Howard B. Loving mother of Howard C. and Robert W. Devoted grandmother of Biagina, Robert Carlo, Charles, Ruth and Peter. Visitation at Duffy's Funeral Home, 255 9th St., Brooklyn, Saturday, 7-9 PM, Sunday, 2-5, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Augustine's R.C. Church, Sterling Place and 6th Ave., Brooklyn, Monday, December 6, 9:45 AM.

title: Corzine Forgoes Award, Citing Divisions on Abortion Views
description: In an unusual collision between New York abortion politics and New Jersey's United States Senate race, Jon S. Corzine has announced that he will forgo an award from a charity operated by the Archdiocese of New York, saying that some Roman Catholic officials had been reluctant to honor a political candidate who supported abortion rights.

title: The China Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Nokia Sales Forecast Pushes Stock Up
description: Nokia, the world's biggest maker of cellular telephones, said today that its sales would rise as much as 40 percent next year and it increased its forecast for mobile phone users worldwide. The shares rose 8.6 percent.

title: Bush in Debate: The Right Stuff?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrebet Puts Pass Behind Him
description: Coach Bill Parcells went out of his way this week to encourage Wayne Chrebet, who could not hold on to the fourth-quarter pass in the end zone Sunday that could have tied the Colts in the final two minutes.

title: Op-Art
Trade Ministers Sidestep A Sticky Issue: Secrecy
description: Trade ministers today ducked significant action on a problem that helped make the World Trade Organization a punching bag for protesters: the veil of secrecy surrounding its proceedings.

title: RADIO ONE TO ACQUIRE ANOTHER PHILADELPHIA STATION
description: The urban music station chain Radio One Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the Philadelphia radio station WPLY-FM from the Greater Media Radio Company, a privately held radio operator, for about $80 million. The alternative-rock station will be Radio One's second station in Philadelphia. The other station plays urban music, although the company said it would not change WPLY's format. The station will be the 27th for Radio One, based in Lanham, Md. The purchase should be completed early next year.

title: E. J. Safra, 67, Banker and Philanthropist
description: Edmond J. Safra, the banker and philanthropist who died in an apparent arson at his Monaco penthouse today, built a vast banking group with Wall Street hustle and old world conservatism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIEFSON, FREIDA
description: KIEFSON-Freida. Loving mother of Laurie and Ruth. Grandmother of Elizabeth, Zachary and Gabriel. Widow of the late Bernard Kiefson. Died of a heart attack at 87 years of age on December 2, 1999. Services Sunday, December 5, 11AM at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue near East 9th Street NYC.

title: Pioline Outlasts Hewitt as France Evens Davis Cup Final
description: There was something for every fan in the sold-out Palais des Expositions. For the hundreds of green-clad, wig-clad Australians, there was Mark Philippoussis' victory in the opening singles match. For the thousands of French spectators, there was Cedric Pioline's victory in the second.

title: Vote Favors Hancock's Plan to Go Public
description: Policyholders of the John Hancock Life Insurance Company have approved a plan for the company, the fifth-largest United States mutual life insurer, to become a public company after 137 years of ownership by its customers.

title: Bush Has Tough Words and Rough Enunciation for Iraqi Chief
description: At the Republican debate here on Thursday and at a news conference in nearby Bedford this morning, George W. Bush said that if he was commander in chief, any discovery that Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, was building weapons of mass destruction would touch off a swift and punishing response.

title: Gene Rayburn, 81, Longtime TV Host of 'The Match Game'
description: Gene Rayburn, who became a mainstay on television from the 1960's to the 80's as the amiable host of ''The Match Game,'' died on Monday at his home in Beverly, Mass. He was 81.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BANK BALI SHARES DROP
description: The shares of Bank Bali closed down 75 rupiah, at 650, on the Jakarta stock exchange in the first trading since Aug. 12. The drop reflected dilution of shares by a rights issue that was announced on Thursday. Under the plan, Standard Chartered of Britain will buy about 20 percent of the bank and take full management control. Under a previously announced plan, the government agreed to buy the entire 99-for-1 rights offer and then sell 20 percent of its stake to Standard Chartered.

title: Chechen Refugee Convoy Machine-Gunned, Leaving 14 Dead
description: An automobile convoy of Chechen refugees heading for the western border was strafed with machine-gun fire today, apparently by Russian helicopters, and a doctor who treated survivors said as many as 14 people had died in the flaming wreckage.

title: Mandheera Journal; Somali Militias Now Undergoing 'Rehumanization'
description: The raw material for peace in northwestern Somalia comes in the unlikely form of men like Suleiman Saxardire Ismail, who admits freely to having robbed, looted and hijacked cars, including one that contained his aunt. He said it was even possible that he had killed people along the way.

title: Buoyed by Job Data, Nasdaq and S.& P. Rise to Record Levels
description: Forget the Federal Reserve and the threat of higher interest rates. That seemed to be the message from investors yesterday as they snapped up stocks, sending two of the market's benchmark measures to new highs and leaving the Dow Jones industrial average just 40 points short of a record.

title: Madeline Kahn, Comedian Of Film Fame, Dies at 57
description: Madeline Kahn, the Oscar-nominated comedian best known for her work in the films ''Paper Moon'' and ''Blazing Saddles'' and in the Broadway revival of ''Born Yesterday,'' died yesterday in a Manhattan hospital. She was 57 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Malamala Returns To a Familiar Place
description: Before the Jets took off on the run last season that took them to the American Football Conference championship game, Siupeli Malamala, who had been with the team since 1992, was waived. He sat in his Long Island home, not too far from the Jets' training camp at Hofstra University, and watched his former teammates reverse years of losing.

title: THE TIMES CAPSULE
description: In its sixth and final Millennium issue, The Times Magazine shifts from looking back over 1,000 years and focuses instead on the future, with the aim of preserving for people in the year 3000 a sense of what it was like to be alive today. The issue describes everyday practices bound to bewilder this era's descendants, a guide to species soon to be extinct and ''A New York Minute,'' a project in which nearly 100 people documented the same moment in the life of the city.

title: Journal; The Strange Legacy of Matt Drudge
description: In a move that would have incited headlines less than two years ago but barely rated column items two weeks ago, Fox News Channel ended the brief TV career of the first New Media journalistic superstar, Matt Drudge, by ''mutual consent.'' Attention should be paid to this cautionary tale, and not for the reasons you might expect.

title: Return Elgin Marbles
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Journal; Joint-Religion Panel to Study World War II Vatican
description: After centuries of cold distrust, relations between Roman Catholics and Jews have undergone a period of great warming since the early 1960's, thanks to high-level discussions (and new local ties) between both groups.

title: Accentuating the Negative
description: To listen to the candidates, one might think this was an especially nasty campaign. George W. Bush and Steve Forbes keep decrying the politics of personal destruction, a line they picked up from Bill Clinton. Friends of John McCain charge that Mr. Bush's allies are spreading ugly rumors about the temperament of their guy. Gary Bauer says Mr. Forbes's supporters are spreading unfounded rumors about a relationship of his with an aide.

title: McManus Redeems Himself And Gives St. Joseph a Title
description: As he stood on the 10-yard line awaiting the kickoff, St. Joseph of Montvale's Pat McManus looked up at the massive screen showing a replay of the previous play and he saw himself, in living color, tumbling to the ground as Delbarton's Jermaine Pugh darted inside of him on his way to a 40-yard touchdown run. In the stands at Giants Stadium, where the Delbarton fans were still celebrating, McManus knew that the crowd of 8,511 was watching, too.

title: PAIRGAIN TECHNOLOGIES PLANS TO CUT ITS WORK FORCE
description: PairGain Technologies Inc., a maker of telecommunications products, said yesterday that it would cut its work force in Tustin, Calif., by shifting production to Mexico. The company will move its high-volume manufacturing operations to Monterrey, Mexico, through its contract manufacturing partner, SCI Systems Inc. of Huntsville, Ala. The number of job cuts was not disclosed. PairGain said it was determining the size and timing of the cuts and planned to help affected workers find other jobs. PairGain makes hardware for digital subscriber lines. These use existing phone lines as conduits for transfer of data at many times the speed of traditional modems.

title: Republican Family Squabbles
description: The first Republican presidential debate with everyone participating probably left Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain in their recent positions as the front-runners in New Hampshire. Mr. Bush seemed confident, if tightly programmed, while committing no major gaffes. Mr. McCain dealt genially with questions about his temperament. Steve Forbes gave a combative performance and may have sealed his role as the main conservative alternative after picking up the endorsement of The Manchester Union Leader.

title: Stock Options at DuPont Photomasks
description: Employees of DuPont Photomasks, based in Round Rock, Tex., could make millions of dollars from the company's decision last year to cut the price they must pay to exercise stock options -- a move that was made during a temporary slump in share prices.

title: A Devotion For the Duke, With Oomph
description: ''Pas de Duke'' won the honors of the evening hands down on Thursday in the first of three ''Ailey Celebrates Ellington'' programs to be presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at City Center. Matthew Rushing and Linda-Denise Evans danced this teasing gloss on the ballet pas de deux with extraordinary wit and an easy, playful technical assurance.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Winner of '36 Heisman Auctions His Trophy
description: The Heisman Trophy that was awarded to Larry Kelley of Yale in 1936 was purchased for $328,110 yesterday by the owners of a sports bar and restaurant in the Hudson Valley.

title: Trump's Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: Jaywalkers Blithely Sidestep Barriers
description: Even as hordes of shoppers descended upon New York City, police and transportation officials made their own holiday preparations last week by rolling out a sweeping traffic plan to bring some order -- and civility -- to the most congested areas.

title: Sidelined by Medicaid
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Are Optimistic Despite Repeated Failure
description: There was no swagger, but there were an awful lot of smiles on the Nets' faces. Less than 24 hours after losing a tight game to the defending champion San Antonio Spurs, the Nets were feeling good about themselves today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, VICTOR
description: SCHUSTER-Victor. Retired architect. 68. Passed away Monday, November 29, from respiratory failure at St. Barnabas Hospital in New Jersey. He is survived by his beloved wife of forty-nine years, Magda. He is also remembered by their two children Zsuzsa and Andras, and six loving grandchildren. Victor fled the oppression of the Romanian government and emigrated here in 1968 from Koloszvar, Transylvania. He will be dearly missed by all.

title: Officials Seek Tougher Law On Petty Crime
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki each proposed laws yesterday that would sharply increase the penalties faced by people who repeatedly commit misdemeanor crimes, like trespassing, turnstile-jumping and selling small amounts of marijuana.

title: Rangers Solve Problems At Expense of Montreal
description: The Rangers were treated to something last night at Madison Square Garden that they had not heard in nearly a month: cheers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, RAE KATZ
description: TOBIN-Rae Katz Age 85, died on Monday, November 29, 1999. The light in Rae's eyes showne with intelligence, love, good humor and wit. With heart and mind, she nurtured her family, fought for a better world and nursed her husband Mike through his terrible battle with Alzheimer's. She left the world a better place. We'll miss this warm and wonderful woman. Rae is survived by her sister Norma Katz Menter, her son Daniel, her daughter and son-in-law Susan and John Schoonover and grandchildren Carl, Danny and Julie. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave, NY, New York 10017.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEXTRON INC., Providence, R.I., bought a French subsidiary of the German pump maker KSB A.G., to add to its line of oil and gas pumps. Terms of the purchase of KSB Annecy were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESTER, ALEXANDER CAMPBELL
description: CHESTER-Alexander Campbell. 84, former president and chairman of H. Muehlstein & Co. died near his home on Shelter Island, NY of a stroke on December 2, 1999. He began his career at Muehlstein as the traffic manager in 1938 and retired as chairman of the board in 1978. Soon afterwards Muehlstein was sold to Mobil, some years later to be sold back again to the management. After retiring he began a second career, working for Century 21 in Oradell, NJ. He was a member of the Gardiner's Bay Country Club and the Boca Raton Hotel Club, with homes in Shelter Island, NY, Fort Lee, NJ, and Boca Raton, Fla. He is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Gladys; a daughter, Gail of Berwyn, Pa.; two sons; Alexander C. III of Washington, D.C. and David of Newton Square, Pa., a sister, Lillian of Toms River, NJ and five grandchildren.

title: SPECIALTY CATALOG IS SOLD TO GOLUB ASSOCIATES
description: The Specialty Catalog Corporation, which sells women's wigs and hairpieces through catalogs, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the closely held Golub Associates for about $21.8 million in cash. Golub will pay $5 for each share of Specialty Catalog, which had about 4.4 million shares outstanding as of Nov. 1. Golub is an affiliate of Golub PS-GP L.L.C, the general partner of the New York investment group Leg Partners III, which holds a 13.7 percent stake in Specialty Catalog. The shares of Specialty Catalog, which is based in South Easton, Mass., rose 56.25 cents, to $4.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURAM, MAGGIE
description: DURAM-Maggie (nee Barnett), of New Canaan, CT, passed away on December 1, 1999 in the Chestnut Hill Benevolent Association in Brookline, MA. She was an active member of the Christian Science Church in New Canaan, CT and she created Maggie Duram Interiors. Maggie touched many people with her talent, most of all, with her love. She was an elegant lady, a very special person who will be missed and remembered by us all. Her husband was the late Arthur E. Duram. Her brother Robert predeceased her. She is survived by her loving son Michael, daughter-in-law Ellie, her brother Dr. Lawrence Barnett, sister-in-law Pat, nieces Tracy and Linda, nephews Bill and Buzz. She is also survived by Robert's children, Pamela, Phyllis, Bonnie, Robert, Betty. As Maggie always said ''love is what it's all about.''

title: Giuliani Protester Is Arrested in Vandalism Inquiry
description: The police arrested an organizer of a protest against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and searched his apartment as part of an investigation into graffiti vandalism, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. The price of natural gas fell almost 5 percent as a recent cold snap proved too short to deplete supplies. In New York, natural gas for January delivery fell 12 cents, to $2.331 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OCKRENT, MIKE
description: OCKRENT-Mike. You were a shining star and a dear friend. We love you so much and we'll miss you forever. Alan, Janis, Anna and Nora Menken

title: CHESAPEAKE BEGINS TENDER FOR SHOREWOOD PACKAGING
description: The Chesapeake Corporation began its tender offer to shareholders of the Shorewood Packaging Corporation yesterday, in a bid to buy the rival company for $17.25 a share in cash, or approximately $500 million. The tender offer is scheduled to expire on Jan. 3. If the transaction is completed, Chesapeake will also assume about $270 million in Shorewood debt. Chesapeake, based in Richmond, Va., said it estimated the acquisition would result in annual savings of at least $20 million. On the Big Board, shares of New York-based Shorewood were up $1.5625, to $17.25, and Chesapeake was up 18.75 cents at $31.

title: Vanguard Health Care Fund to Reopen
description: The Vanguard Health Care Fund, which has been closed for most of the year, will reopen to new accounts effective Dec. 20, Vanguard Group Inc. said today.

title: Mexico Suspends Plan For Hefty Deposit on Cars
description: The government, in an awkward about-face, has scrapped a plan for deposits of up to $800 from travelers crossing the border from the United States with vehicles not registered in Mexico. The program lasted two days.

title: Questioning Poverty Claim, Judge Delays a Sentencing
description: A federal judge ordered a hearing yesterday into whether Patrick R. Bennett, a Syracuse businessman accused of orchestrating one of the largest financial frauds in American history, was still hiding assets stolen from unsuspecting investors.

title: U.S.-Mexican Team Seeking Clues From Exhumed Bones
description: They were three middle-aged men, and when they were dumped into a desert grave, two were wearing boots and a third had on tennis shoes. Their heads were wrapped in cloth, and one appears to have been wearing only underwear. They were probably shot to death but might have suffocated.

description: In what amounts to a legal genuflection to Beijing, Hong Kong's highest court ruled today that the Chinese government had the right to overturn its landmark decision earlier this year that granted residency to more than a million people from mainland China.

description: Inside the highly insulated Yale world of limestone arches and wrought-iron gates, no one is yet willing to say that Suzanne Jovin, a bright-eyed student who was stabbed to death almost a year ago, has faded from memory.

description: Kenneth W. Starr, who spent five years investigating criminal accusations against President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, said today that Mr. Clinton ''has yet to come to terms with his own responsibility'' in trying to ''play games with the law.''

description: A Brooklyn teenager was acquitted of murder yesterday in the stabbing death of another youth in a dispute arising from an after-school basketball game.

title: As Coke Regains European Sales, Parents Say 4 Children Are Still Ill
description: There were roadshows and beach parties, rock concerts and free handouts to refurbish the European image of Coca-Cola, the world's most famous brand. Yet, five months after 250 people in Belgium complained of sickness they attributed to contaminated soft drinks, prompting the biggest recall in Coke's 113-year history, a number of obstacles are frustrating the company's effort to put the scandal to rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSOP, HARRY
description: KASSOP-Harry, Dr. On December 2, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Harriet. Devoted father of Mark Kassop and Sue London. Loving grandfather of Erika, Allison, Erin and Phillip. Funeral services Sunday, 10 AM, ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills. Donations may be made in his memory to a charity of your choice.

title: Cuban Boy Is Smiling, But No One Else Is
description: At first, his story was tragically simple. Television news footage showed a smiling, big-eyed 5-year-old boy playing with new toys bought for him by relatives in Miami's Little Havana; a lucky child who had survived a disastrous crossing from Cuba that drowned his mother and stepfather and eight others. Elian Gonzalez, clinging to an inner tube in the cold water off Fort Lauderdale last week, was a miracle, people here said, a gift from God on Thanksgiving Day.

John and Linda Cross and the Art Omi Boar

title: Bank Magnate Killed in Fire Laid to Intruders in Monaco
description: Edmond J. Safra, a multibillionaire who built a banking empire that specialized in catering to the very rich, suffocated in a predawn fire on Friday in his luxury duplex penthouse here on the Riviera, and the local authorities said the fire had been set by two hooded intruders.

title: 6 Iran Scholars Drop Meeting, Faulting I.N.S.
description: Six Iranian scholars invited to a conference in Georgetown University have canceled their participation, saying they were harassed and humiliated by immigration officials on arriving at Kennedy International Airport, the organizer of the event said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Jets-Giants, The Silent Rivalry
description: AT 11 o'clock yesterday morning, Coach Bill Parcells of the Jets marched into a cramped interview room and sat behind a table on a platform. He had just run three miles and he looked refreshed.

title: Lincoln Center Gets $1.5 Billion Renovation Plan
description: A wide-ranging renovation plan that could cost as much as $1.5 billion is now under review for the 40-year-old Lincoln Center, the nation's busiest performing arts arena. The options include new buildings, rooftop extensions and performance spaces as well as an opera museum and visitors' center, engineers who conducted the survey reported.

title: Childs Passes on Criticizing Marbury
description: This wasn't Chris Childs at all. Somehow, the typically loquacious Childs restrained himself from delivering a punch line right into the jabbering jaw of Stephon Marbury last summer.

title: City Warns About Shelter Requirements
description: All homeless families in New York City's shelter system will soon be warned that if they fail to work or meet other shelter and welfare requirements, the city may seek foster care for their children, Giuliani administration officials said yesterday.

title: Celebrating A Spirit Most Blithe
description: Of all the gifts possessed by that supreme jack-of-all-show-business trades, Sir Noel Coward, none surpassed his gift for friendship. Although Sir Noel expressed a wistful pessimism when it came to his love life, his deep and abiding friendships were another matter. On Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall, where the cream of the cabaret world gathered to celebrate his centennial, the reminiscences and excerpts from diaries and letters that poured from the stage created an affectionate portrait of the legendary sophisticate whom Edward Albee, the evening's opening speaker, described as resembling ''James Bond's gay uncle.''

title: National News Briefs; Electronic Privacy Group Sues Security Agency
description: A leading privacy advocacy group filed a lawsuit today that seeks to force the National Security Agency to release its records on potential government surveillance of the Internet communications of American citizens.

title: Clinton Senate Campaign Gets a Full-Time Director
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton began to lay the groundwork for the next phase of her United States Senate campaign yesterday, selecting Bill de Blasio, a senior adviser to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, to serve as her full-time campaign manager.

title: Crucial Victories Make Case For Woman as World's Best
description: To select the best female performance in a calendar year one would seldom go beyond the winners of the World Women's Teams, but there was no such event in 1999 -- there will be two in the year 2000. But an excellent case could be made for Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif., who at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in Boston on Sunday completed a remarkable triple in board-a-match play. This is the toughest form of team contest, because every trick may be crucial and fierce concentration is essential.

title: North Korea, Apparently Seeking to End Its Isolation, Agrees to Resume Talks With Japan
description: North Korea, one of the most isolated and bellicose countries in Asia, has made some unexpected diplomatic overtures in recent months, suggesting that its Communist government is itching to come out of its shell, or at least see what the rest of the world has to offer.

title: S.E.C. Takes Aim at How Companies Report Revenue
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, saying it was worried that some companies book revenue -- and thus profits -- before they should be able to do so, issued guidance yesterday that could lead to some companies' being more conservative in reporting revenue.

title: Bush Rivals, Fresh From Debating, Try Pointed Banter
description: A day after the Republican presidential debate, Steve Forbes escalated his attack on the front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, by mocking the governor's responses to questions about whether he had used drugs.

title: Pokemon Mania Takes On Criminal Proportions
description: Sometimes a Pokemon is just a Pokemon.

title: LANDEC HAS ACQUIRED APIO FOR $23.9 MILLION
description: The Landec Corporation, a maker of temperature-activated packaging products, acquired the closely held Apio Inc. for $23.9 million in cash and stock to add a direct link to growers for its produce-packaging business. The transaction creates a company with about $200 million in annual revenue. Landec, based in Menlo Park, Calif., paid $8.9 million in cash and issued 2.5 million shares of common stock valued at $6 each to Apio's prior owners. In addition, Landec will pay up to $16.75 million over five years, including $10 million based on Apio's performance. Apio packs and sells fresh-cut fruit and vegetables from growers in the Santa Maria, San Joaquin and Imperial Valleys of California and in Arizona and Mexico. It has 124 employees.

description: Global trade talks ended late tonight in complete failure, with the United States abandoning any effort to put together a new round of global trade talks.

description: Criticized for paying too much attention to the ''horse race'' aspect of presidential campaigns, political reporters and analysts have been chastened. Now they have glommed onto boxing metaphors instead, desperately portraying each of Gov. George W. Bush's opponents as a fighter with ear-biting potential.

title: Rwanda Approves Visa for U.N. Prosecutor
description: Rwanda relented today and agreed to grant entry to the United Nations war crimes prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, whose first trip there was canceled because Rwanda was angry that a top genocide suspect had been cleared on a technicality.

description: A fire that began on Sunday at a sewage composting plant in an industrial neighborhood here continues to smolder.

title: Charlie Byrd, 74, Guitarist Who Imported Bossa Nova
description: Charlie Byrd, a virtuoso jazz guitarist who was among the first to popularize bossa nova in North America, died on Wednesday at his home in Annapolis, Md. He was 74.

title: SEVERN TRENT TO CUT 1,100
description: Britain's second-largest water company, Severn Trent P.L.C., expects to cut 1,100 jobs in the next three years to meet price targets set by British regulators. The news follows last week's announcement from the utility regulator Ofwat that the average water bill for British customers will be cut by 12 percent as of next April under new price controls.

title: From Rotting Leaves, a Mighty Anger Grows
description: Down the road from the Ferrari dealership and over the hill from the Canine Beauty Shop lies a coarse little patch of land euphemistically named the Holly Hill Resource Recovery Facility. In other words, the Greenwich town dump.

title: Two Are Promoted To Replace Lawrence
description: In an effort to shake up their offense, the Islanders sent right wing Mark Lawrence to their Lowell, Mass., team in the American Hockey League yesterday after he cleared waivers. They recalled wings Vladimir Orszagh and Jason Krog from Lowell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMAN, MAX L.
description: FEINMAN-Max L. On December 2, 1999 at age 94. Long-time physician, surgeon and teacher. He graduated from Long Island College of Medicine and served as a Captain in the U.S. Army during WWII; Chief of Surgery at Lefferts General Hospital, affiliated with Wyckoff Heights Hospital and Doctors Hospital (Beth Israel Medical Center North), faculty member at the New School for Social Research and author of ''Protect Your Heart''. Long-time member of Brooklyn Jewish Center. Beloved husband of Sylvia (nee Mann). Loving father of Jeffrey and Richard. Loved father-in-law of Judy Squire and Tana Gegen. Devoted grandfather of Jessica and Robin. Services were private.

title: 234,000 NEW JOBS IN NOVEMBER KEPT ECONOMY HUMMING
description: The tireless national economy kept spinning out new jobs in November, assuring robust economic growth in the final months of the American Century.

title: Gifts for Body and Soul on New York-Havana Flight
description: More than anything, the objects packed carefully into luggage for the first direct flight from New York to Havana in nearly four decades told the story.

title: Probe to Mars Becomes Silent, Its Fate Unclear
description: An American spacecraft on a $165 million mission may or may not have landed safely on Mars today, its fate unknown in the ominous radio silence that followed the scheduled landing time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Stays at 4.1% And Inflation Appears Tame

title: QXL.COM IN EXCITE DEAL
description: Europe's largest online auction company, QXL.com, said it had agreed to make its service available through co-branded auction pages on the Excite@Home Corporation's Web sites in Europe. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The alliance aims to make more auctions available to Excite users and to give QXL more exposure to Europe's Internet users.

title: President Halts Target Practice By Navy on Puerto Rican Island
description: President Clinton today ordered a halt to live-fire military training on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques and an end to all exercises there within five years unless local residents agree to an extension.

title: STRONG JOB GAINS IN CANADA
description: The economy in Canada added another 60,000 jobs in November, and the unemployment rate dropped by three-tenths of a percentage point, to 6.9 percent, the lowest level in 18 years, Statistics Canada reported. So far this year, the number of employed Canadians has risen by 313,000, a 2.1 percent gain. The tightened job market has increased the risk of higher inflation, and economists expect the Bank of Canada to match any increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board in the United States over the next few months.

title: Police Tactics in Question; 'Stop and Frisk' in New York
description: New York City has experienced a dramatic drop in crime over the last few years, in part through a vigorous effort to ''stop and frisk'' suspects. But a report released this week by New York State's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has raised troubling questions about the program. The statistical study from the Columbia University Center for Violence Research and Prevention found disproportionately higher ''stop rates'' for blacks and Hispanics than for whites. The rates remain elevated even when adjusted to account for higher crime and arrest rates in minority neighborhoods.

title: Citing Revolution, Czechs Again Demand Leaders' Ouster
description: Ten years after the Velvet Revolution ending four decades of Communist rule here, tens of thousands of Czechs once again filled Wenceslas Square today to jingle their keys and call for the resignation of the country's political leadership.

title: APPROVAL IS WON FOR JOINT PURCHASE OF ICO GLOBAL
description: The cellular-phone pioneer Craig O. McCaw and Subhash Chandra, who runs India's most popular television network, won United States Bankruptcy Court approval yesterday for a joint purchase of the satellite-telephone company ICO Global Communications Ltd. Mr. McCaw will be the largest shareholder in ICO, which filed for bankruptcy protection in August, days after a rival, Iridium L.L.C., did the same. Last month, ICO won court approval to receive $150 million in short-term financing from Mr. McCaw to keep the company afloat. The court yesterday approved a second investment by Mr. McCaw and Mr. Chandra of $75 million, to be followed by a $275 million infusion by both investors. ICO's shares have not traded since the company filed for bankruptcy protection in August.

title: With World-Class Times, U.S. Veterans Dominate Meet
description: When word filtered into the hallways of the natatorium that Jenny Thompson had tossed off the fourth-fastest time ever in the women's 100-meter butterfly, Lea Maurer shrieked in amazement and dashed down the hall.

title: Phone Gear Maker Is Sold
description: Performance Technologies, a maker of communications equipment, agreed this week to buy the closely held MicroLegend Telecom Systems Inc. for about $43.6 million in stock. Performance Technologies will issue about 2.2 million shares for the purchase. It will take a fourth-quarter charge of $1.9 million, or 14 cents a share. MicroLegend, based in Ottawa, makes products based on a signaling technology that is the backbone of common phone functions like caller ID.

title: At 100 Games, Army-Navy Is Still Big
description: Among the classes Nate Hunterton, a senior at Army, is taking this semester are Systems Engineering, Human Resources Management, Organizational Theory and Design, Organizational Behavior and, not surprisingly, Military History.

description: BERNBAUM-Keren-Or. On December 2. Funeral services will be held on December 5, 12:30P.M. at The Piser Chapel, 9200 Skokie Blvd., Skokie, IL. Donations in her memory may be sent to Coalition for the Homeless, 89 Chambers Street, New York, NY 10007.

title: State Court Rejects Appeal on Trash Pickup
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has refused to hear an appeal of a lower court ruling that communities cannot exclude apartment buildings from municipal garbage collection.

title: Tommy Atkins, 75, Adventurer Who Became a College Librarian
description: Tommy Atkins, who made a dramatic escape from Poland during the cold war and later became a college librarian in New York, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Boca Raton, Fla., where he had a winter residence. He was 75 and lived in Manhattan.

description: A sports caption on Thursday with a picture of Shaun King, the Tampa Bay quarterback, carried an incorrect credit. The picture was by The St. Petersburg Times, not The Seattle Times.

title: There's This Girl Who Turns Into a Boy and Gets a New Attitude
description: To Justine, a very pretty 17-year-old virgin, men are mysteries, ''like the 'X-Files'. '' It's time, she has decided, to leave her chastity behind, but she's having trouble choosing the lucky guy. ''How,'' she asks, facing the camera, ''do you know it's Mr. Right Bloke?'' Justine lives in London.

title: G.M. Is Said to Be in Talks To Buy Engines From Honda
description: The General Motors Corporation appears intent on expanding its relationships with Japanese automakers, and is talking with the Honda Motor Company about a three-way deal in which G.M. would use engines designed by Honda in cars G.M. builds in North America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEROYIANIS, PAULINE
description: GEROYIANIS-Pauline. On December 2, 1999. Loving mother of William, Katherine, Elaine, Louis and Elizabeth. Beloved sister of William and Gloria Bodouva and Aspacia and William Dzanoucakis. Also survived by 6 loving grandchildren. Funeral from Fairchild Funeral Chapel, Manhasset, NY.

description: The signs flow by on Interstate 55 in south St. Louis County.

description: To the Editor:

title: Baptists' Ardor for Evangelism Angers Some Jews and Hindus
description: For generations Southern Baptists, like many other evangelical Protestants, have worked from a sense of biblical imperative to convert people to a belief in Jesus Christ. But over the last 10 weeks, a series of high-profile proselytizing efforts by the Southern Baptist Convention have angered members of other religious groups who regard the efforts as crossing a line.

title: New Disguise For Infection Of Computers
description: The first of what experts fear could be many malicious software programs masquerading as the Year 2000 computer problem began spreading on Thursday. The new program hides on hard drives, poised to begin destroying data on Jan. 1.

title: New U.S. Standards for Meat Are Snared in a Court Fight
description: A federal judge in Dallas has halted the first effort by the United States Department of Agriculture to close a meat plant that consistently failed inspections, setting up a test of the government's tougher new standards for meat and poultry.

title: Phillips Rues Trade That Brought Bonilla
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips acknowledged the glaringly obvious yesterday: if he knew then what he knows now about Bobby Bonilla, he would not have made the deal last year that brought Bonilla to the Mets for a second go-round.

title: CERPROBE, CIRCUITS TESTER, ADDS OZ TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Cerprobe Corporation, which makes products used for testing integrated circuits, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held OZ Technologies Inc. for about $36 million. The price paid by Cerprobe, which is based in Gilbert, Ariz., consisted of $19 million in cash, $6 million in notes and 1.5 million Cerprobe shares. OZ Technologies, which is based in Hayward, Calif., makes test sockets and other devices. Cerprobe said the deal makes it a complete provider of products for semiconductor test integration. It will take an unspecified charge in the fourth quarter for acquisition-related costs.

title: Predicting Which Predictions Will Come True
description: A quarter of a century ago, Look magazine published a symposium in which leading scholars, scientists and social thinkers were asked to peer into the foggy beyond that goes by the name of the Next Millennium and tell what they saw. Among those invited to participate were Mike Nichols and Elaine May, then a youthful comedy team.

title: TriQuint Will Split Stock
description: TriQuint Semiconductor Inc., whose stock price has increased eightfold since March, said on Thursday that it would split its stock two shares for one. The maker of integrated circuits will distribute an additional share for every share that is held on Feb. 1, 2000. The extra shares will be sent out Feb. 22. Shares of Triquint closed today at $87.75, up 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading. That compares with a price of about $10.50 in early March.

title: How the Elegant Practice of a Craft Can Be High Tech, Too
description: When Curtis Erpelding, a cabinetmaker in the Seattle area, wanted to hold a piece of wood firmly on his bench, he used an ingenious method: he would jam a long pole with one end against a ceiling rafter, the other against the board. He adjusted the tension by moving the pole slightly one way or the other on the rafter. No need to keep cranking a vise to clamp the wood in place; just one swift motion.

title: Police Tactics in Question; Handling Protest in Seattle
description: Seattle is a city with a tradition of liberal politics and civility in public discourse. So it was a shock to see the host city of the World Trade Organization meeting face down protesters with tear gas, rubber pellets and the National Guard this week. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRA, EDMOND
description: SAFRA-Edmond. It is with profound grief, and immeasureable sorrow that we mourn with the entire House of Isreal, individuals and communities, throughout the globe the sudden death of one of our noblest princes Edmond (Son of Jacob) Safra A''H. We can not be consoled. As an early, generous, and continuing supporter of Sephardic Bikur Holim he shared our vision and commitment towards helping those among us suffering and struggling with illness and poverty. His constant support encouraged and enabled us to grow and achieve our goals helping individuals and families in crisis and in need. As President and CEO of Republic National Bank he truly saw himself as a trustee of the Almighty, using his talents, resources, and good fortune to improve and refine the world. Through his generosity making it a kinder, compassionate, and more godly place. Through his actions he inspired and taught that we are measured not by what we have, but by what we give. He was a giver and contributor to life, a partner with G-d in the development of education, goodness, charity, and almost every worthy cause. His heart was as big as the world for his vision knew no boundries. Remaining true to the faith of his fathers, he lived in grace. As Abraham Abinu he returned to his maker with his days, full of good and charitable deeds. His name will be eternially blessed. Board of Directors Sephardic Bikur Holim

title: AIDS, the Worsening Catastrophe
description: Even though new drug therapies continue to cut AIDS death rates in wealthy countries like the United States, the news from the AIDS front is chilling. In the developing world, the situation is catastrophic. Even in the United States, where AIDS deaths have been declining, the spread of the AIDS virus continues unabated, with new infections accruing at roughly 40,000 a year for several years now. The only real gain is that drugs are helping the victims live longer. Infection rates are on the rise among minorities, women and young people as AIDS in this country becomes increasingly a disease of the poor and disadvantaged.

title: Faithful to the Love of His Life: Hot 30's Jazz
description: IN ''Sweet and Lowdown,' the new film written and directed by Woody Allen, Sean Penn plays Emmet Ray, a fictional jazz guitarist of the early 1930's whose neurosis is unlike that of any previous Woody Allen hero. Although self-confident to the point of arrogance, Ray nevertheless knows that he's only the second-best guitarist of his time. No. 1 by consensus and in Ray's own opinion is the Belgian-born jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt, a real-life figure whose recordings with the Hot Club of Paris and with such visitors to France as Benny Carter and Coleman Hawkins made him the first foreign-born player respected as an equal by American musicians.

title: Nov. 28-Dec. 4; A New Scale of Risk In Difficult Childbirth
description: For women caught in a difficult labor, a study offered reassuring news about the safest way to deliver the baby. Contrary to what many doctors and patients had assumed, once labor has begun using forceps or a vacuum tool poses no more risk of brain hemorrhage to the newborn than performing a Caesarean section. All three methods are linked to a slightly higher risk of brain injury than a normal, spontaneous birth, but researchers say the increased risk appears to be due to abnormal labor, rather than to the method of delivery. title: Nov. 28-Dec. 4; A Hunt for Bodies On a Mexican Farm
description: In one of the largest joint law enforcement operations undertaken by Mexico and the United States, 65 forensic experts from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and hundreds of police officers and soldiers began to dig up shallow graves at a farm near Ciudad Juarez, across the Rio Grande from El Paso, Texas. The search for bodies of people who have run afoul of drug traffickers was set off by an FBI informant who led authorities to the farm and to three other nearby burial sites. Even though the first five days' efforts unearthed the remains of several people, it remained unclear how far the operation would go toward resolving riddles over the fate of scores who have disappeared in northern Mexico, most after detention by policemen working for traffickers.

His latest, ''All About My Mother,'' which opened here last month and in Europe six months ago, is topping his previous box-office records. But Mr. Almodovar is just one of many Spanish directors who are making waves.

title: Channel One's Mixed Grades In Schools

With its school-board-friendly business model, it has built a captive audience of eight million schoolchildren, and it has set off controversy all along the way.

title: HOTEL CHECK-IN: Setting the Stage for a Stay; Celebration, Fla.: A hotel in keeping with the atmosphere
description: The town of Celebration, Fla., suggests nothing so much as a movie set, a kind of Pleasantville where artful design re-creates some ideal bygone American village. The community seems constructed more for camera angles and lighting setups than residents. In this Orlando-area development, opened in 1996 by a Walt Disney Company subsidiary, perfectly kept homes with quaint porches are nestled among perfectly sculptured lawns.

title: Sounds
description: Here's a late-20th-century kind of question about life in America in the late 20th century: What did it feel like? Or, as some late-30th-century cultural historian might put it: Which manifestations of popular culture did Americans coming of age in the late 20th century use to help them perceive and organize reality? What were the rituals through which they bodily expressed their deep emotions? What gave the era its sensibility? The answer, I think, or anyway the beginning of one, is perhaps easier to get your head around than the question. Take a half-hour or so and listen to Elvis Presley's ''Mystery Train,'' the Beatles' ''Ticket to Ride,'' the Four Tops' ''Reach Out I'll Be There,'' Bob Dylan's ''Like a Rolling Stone,'' Run-D.M.C.'s ''Walk This Way'' and Nirvana's ''Smells Like Teen Spirit.'' What late-20th-century America felt like had mostly to do with popular music.

title: A Sign of the Season: Dancing Snowflakes
description: There seems to be an infinite number of people who perennially buy tickets to get their holiday dose of ''The Nutcracker.'' Some never grow tired of the ballet, no matter how many times they see it. Others say they buy tickets ''just for the kids'' but take some private comfort in the familiarity of watching Clara and her wooden soldier. And then there are those who just do not like ''The Nutcracker,'' and one reason is that it is the same year after year.

title: HOTEL CHECK-IN: Setting the Stage for a Stay; Santa Monica: A glamorous beach hotel restored

title: THEATER; Where Mae West Was Even Racier
description: IMPERSONATORS and cartoonists have always gravitated to Mae West because in performance she usually seemed to be impersonating herself, exaggerating her femininity and commenting on her own outrageousness.

title: For a Loyal Mayor, It's Payback Time
description: Timing can be everything in politics. And Ed Rendell had a timing problem. A Democrat, he is winding down his second and final term as mayor of Philadelphia and, by every indication, hoping to parlay his widely praised stewardship of that job into an even bigger job -- governor. But what to do between early January, when he leaves the mayor's office, and Election Day 2002, when the state will elect a successor to Gov. Tom Ridge?

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Jaron Lanier

title: BUSINESS: DIARY; When Company Names Age With the Century
description: Company names are driven by changing fashions. In the 1940's many a Republic this or Liberty that was born. In the 1960's cryptic three-letter combinations were the rage. Now everyone puts dot-com on the end. But there was a time when ''20th Century'' in a name bespoke a brisk, modern enterprise of tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMAN, MAX L.
description: FEINMAN-Max L.. On December 2, 1999 at age 94. Long-time physician, surgeon and teacher. For the Times Capsule, we set out to document the texture of life today, at least in a single place at a single moment. And so, on Sept. 9, 1999, at 9:09 a.m., a moment chosen strictly for its symmetry, more than a hundred writers, photographers, artists, sound recordists, filmmakers and students fanned out across the five boroughs to document a single minute -- the same minute -- in the life of New York.
