title: An Encyclopedia of Lost Practices; The Cigarette
description: An amerindian invention (circa a.d. 1400) designed to wreak revenge on genocidal Europeans by addicting them to the inhalation of carcinogenic fumes from a lighted bundle of tobacco leaves. Far and away the most popular form of recreational suicide ever devised, by the late 20th century smoking had become the object of an ethical/medical/legal imbroglio that reached its apogee in 2010, when the precedent set by government bans on smoking was used to forbid fried eggs, going without an overcoat in cold weather, not using sunscreen at the beach and thousands of other human activities alleged to be self-destructive. Narrowly defining the pursuit of happiness, the United States Supreme Court had ruled in Snopes v. Lucky Strike (2007) that happiness by definition excluded any and all activities posing potential dangers to health and safety and awarded Snopes $16 billion in damages. Secretary of Public Safety Ralph Nader (see ''The Cromwell of Connecticut,'' p. 398) interpreted the ruling narrowly and applied it vigorously, ultimately banning the driving of automobiles, aviation, swimming, contact sports and even living in houses -- where statistics showed most fatal accidents occurred -- as risky and thus inimical to the pursuit of happiness. The long-term results were by and large salutary: for example, class-action lawsuits dried up and lawyers vanished overnight and the difficulty of dying spurred such population growth (see ''The Safety-Boomer Generation,'' p. 983) that America's No. 1 export by 2342 was families, leading to the colonization of the moon, Mars and Detroit. The biggest winner of all would, oddly, be France, where the sale of so-called ''smoking visas'' to visitors from the outside world led to an economy so wealthy that, in 2763, France purchased Germany, ushering in an era of European amity and stability that has obtained to this day.

description: On the corner of Howard and Third Streets in San Francisco's trendy SOMA (South of Market), men in black whisk cars into the depths of the W's garage. Another man in black hands out key cards. A third, wearing a wired headset, zipped me through the lobby of this new entry in the W hotel chain, abuzz with a young, hip crowd, up to the 23rd floor and careering around a few corners down a dim, narrow hallway with black and tan horizontal-striped carpeting, cool blue lights and glowing green exit signs.

title: A Game Amahl Marches Triumphant
description: ''AS a little boy of 3 or 4, I became lame,'' Gian Carlo Menotti says. ''Something was wrong with my right leg. There are pictures of me being pulled around in a little wagon. The doctors didn't know what to do. So my nanny took me to the miraculous Madonna at Sacro Monte in Varese, the priest blessed me, and I walked. But the only thing I really remember from that wonderful day is that my nanny took me to lunch, and it was the first time I ate a pickle. I still like pickles.''

title: An Encyclopedia of Lost Practices; The New York Times
description: What was The New York Times? The short answer is, it's what you're holding in your hands, if, that is, you still have what we call ''hands.''

title: The World: Friendly Fire; In a War, Even Food Aid Can Kill
description: AT a remote outpost in northern Kenya where nomadic herdsmen used to roam, a town with Western comforts has sprung up, its population composed of well-intentioned aid workers and hard-knuckle bush pilots. Lokichokio, as the place is known, is the springboard for United Nations food deliveries into southern Sudan. But to the cynical, this oasis in the desert has become the catering headquarters for the Sudan People's Liberation Army, a rebel group with Christian and animist beliefs that has been battling an Islamic government in Khartoum for 16 years.

title: Messinger's Out of Politics, but Politics Aren't Out of Her
description: Last Tuesday evening, in the middle of teaching a class about city government at the Hunter College School of Social Work, Ruth Messinger indulged in a fleeting self-reference.

title: A Priest Bids Farewell To Pulpit, Police and Films
description: The Rev. Robert W. Castle sits backward in a pew at St. Mary's Episcopal Church on West 126th Street, a column of sunshine illuminating his gray beard, and remembers the arrests that have punctuated his 45-year career.

title: How to Make a Time Capsule
description: At the end of the 20th century, the image that comes to most people's minds when they think about time capsules might best be described as retro-cornball. Picture a small-town tableau of pasty institutional faces -- officers in a bank, say, or directors of a department store. The men, porkpie hats on large heads, and the women, cameos pinned to embonpoint, might be seen in the local paper clutching gleaming steel shovels and smiling gamely at the metal canister they are about to entomb -- a box filled with the day's newspaper, train schedules and weather forecasts.

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Santiago Calatrava
description: The proposal by Spain's foremost architect conveys an uncanny feeling of having been revealed rather than created. Neither willful nor contrived, it seems to emerge organically from the task it is meant to perform. For this reason, Santiago Calatrava's is the entry the judges chose to build.

title: Sonoma Harvests a Home-Grown Cuisine
description: CALIFORNIA food is being defined at last, and nowhere better than in Sonoma, which is finally escaping from the long shadow of Tuscany.

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Maya Lin
description: Since 1981, when she was a student at the Yale architecture school, Maya Lin has spoken for the power of simple, quiet forms.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 5, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Hair Today
description: As one who does not have mere bad-hair days, but rather an unbroken series of bad-hair decades, I understand, quite personally and pathetically, how much hair means, how important it is to self-image and one's sense of humanness, and how hard it is to give it up. So to those brave individuals who donated a sample of their hair to the Times Capsule, who gamely plucked six strands by their roots, grimacing, grunting and even, in the case of one macho-looking fellow, shedding a few tears in the process, I take my hat off -- or would, if I were ever foolish enough to flatten my hair with headgear in the first place.

title: Gardening
description: It is the condition of gardeners, Nancy Mitford writes, to spill over with ''boring herbaceous enthusiasms.'' By using the word ''herbaceous,'' Mitford doesn't mean to exclude the boring enthusiasms caused by woody plants. It's just that Sir Leicester Kroesig, the character she's describing in ''The Pursuit of Love,'' is the epitome of herbaceousness, a paragon of self-satisfied dullness. His garden is a ''perfection of vulgarity . . . each individual bloom appearing twice as large, three times as brilliant as it ought to have been and if possible of a different color from that which nature intended.'' His garden is ''a riot of sterility.'' Like so much in Mitford, this is funny, true and unfair. To fill a garden only with flowers of the color and size that nature intended is to abandon horticulture or to admit that ''natural'' merely means ''familiar.''

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; The Cooper Union
description: Most of the invitations to join the capsule competition went to individual architects or design firms. But one went to an army of future designers: the students of the Cooper Union, the art, architecture and engineering college in New York City. They attacked the project from several directions, as a challenge to their historical, graphic and calligraphic skills as well as to their artistic and architectural imagination. Their capsule entry became a semester-long project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSCH, ESTHER (NEE ABELSON)
description: BERSCH-Esther (nee Abelson). Of Bergenfield, NJ (formerly of Englewood and Boca Raton, FL), on December 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Loving mother of Caryl Adler of Jupiter, FL, Myron Bersch of Wallingford, CT, David Bersch of Trumbull, CT and Howard Bersch of Englewood, NJ. Dear sister of the late Murray Abelson and Anna Meshel, also surviving are 16 grandchildren and 24 great-grandchildren. Graveside services will be held on Sunday, 11:30 AM, at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY. For information, Hunt Stellato Funeral Home, 1601 Palisade Ave, Ft. Lee.

title: The Shape Of Justice Is Undefined In Cambodia
description: One year after they surrendered last December, life has improved for two top leaders of the brutal Khmer Rouge. No longer on the run, they live openly among their old comrades in a remote border town, free of the threat of government attack.

title: A Risk-Taking Perfectionist Behind the Camera
description: ''BEING a cinematographer is, in many ways, like being a psychoanalyst,'' said Benoit Delhomme recently at his studio here on the outskirts of the city. ''We let the director of a film talk, and then, from just a few key words, we guess what's in his head and come up with the images that he seeks.'' He smiled. ''Unlike a psychoanalyst, however, we don't have to cure the director. On the contrary, if he's a bit mad, it's even better.''

title: An Encyclopedia of Lost Practices; Talk Radio
description: Pretty early in the 20th Century G. K. Chesterton wrote a memorable sentence about a new invention: radio. ''How strange it is that mankind should have invented a machine for speaking to the whole world at precisely the moment when no man has anything to say.''

title: Jersey Boy Makes Good And Comes Back Home
description: NOTHING against Los Angeles and palm trees and power lunches and all that, but Kevin Smith is pretty happy with his Hollywood-by-the-Navesink, with its scrub pines and convenience-store takeout.

title: Ericka Guthrie, Bernard Dorsey Jr.
description: Ericka Ann Guthrie, the daughter of Barbara Jean Guthrie and Raymond Ulysses Guthrie of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married yesterday to N. Bernard Dorsey Jr., a son of Patricia Ann Dorsey and Nelson Bernard Dorsey of Reisterstown, Md. The Rev. Paul LaCharite performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Somerville, Mass.

title: Trucks and S.U.V.'s On the Merritt Parkway
description: I remember well my first trip on the Merritt Parkway when I was a teenager in the 1930's (''A Group Pushes to Preserve the Merritt,'' Oct. 24). It seemed a marvel then, and does some of the time now.

title: Not Much Pressure In Chasing Cold Cases
description: Regarding the Nassau County Police Department's cold case squad [''Nassau's Cold Case Squad Picks Up Chase,'' Nov. 21], it appears that such an entity is like the backup quarterback who goes in when his team is down 24-0 late in the game. He's not expected to win, but if he does, what could be sweeter? A lot of the pressure is off.

title: Commercial Property; Bites and Bytes at an Old Cookie Factory
description: WITH the production lines that baked the first Oreo cookies long gone, the owners of the blocklong former Nabisco plant between 15th and 16th Streets have cooked up a new recipe for profits that has put food on the ground floor and is now folding in tenants such as Oxygen Media, Major League Baseball Productions and New York 1 News on the upper floors.

title: Justine Laccetti, James McVaney Jr.
description: Justine Ann Laccetti was married yesterday to James Patrick McVaney Jr. The Rev. Kevin B. Walsh performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Falls Church, Va.

title: Many Families, Many Values
description: TO get everything done, the single father pictured above combines watching Sunday football with household chores. His home, in Cleveland, was one of 10 visited by Courteney Coolidge as she photographed the changing face of the American family. Her show, ''American Families: Beyond the White Picket Fence,'' opens on Wednesday at the 92nd Street Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-28

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEROYIANIS, PAULINE
description: GEROYIANIS-Pauline. On December 2, 1999. Loving mother of William, Katherine, Elaine, Louis and Elizabeth. Beloved sister of William and Gloria Bodouva and Aspacia and William Dzanoucakis. Also survived by 6 loving grandchildren. Funeral from Fairchild Funeral Chapel, Manhasset, NY.

title: A Legislator's Words Show Lack of Tact
description: One's sexual orientation has absolutely nothing to do with one's qualifications as a businessman, a human being or an elected official. Family values are exemplified by adopting, loving and raising five children, as well as maintaining a devoted and monogamous relationship with a partner for 18 years.

title: Kindness in Good Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Doctors Who Make House Calls
description: INEVITABLY, whenever Sydney Stanton's children and grandchildren come to visit the same thing happens. ''After they leave, my computer is not the same,'' she said. ''They change everything around. This last time I couldn't find my address book.''

title: Faces in the Crowd, for $105 a Day
description: SOME days, Flip walks out of his Manhattan apartment dressed as a Hasidic Jew, black hat flapping in the wind. Other times, he swaggers out in the uniform of New York's finest. When he needs to drive, he slips behind the wheel of a cab.

title: More Families Opt for Home Schooling
description: OVER Labor Day, while families all around Long Island were shopping for sneakers, backpacks and notebooks at back-to-school sales, Ben Coburn, 11, and Malka Coburn, 9, the children of Cindy Salwen of Center Moriches, were quietly continuing the courses of study that they pursued throughout the summer.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Is it unfair to suggest that these annual lists of the best books may say as much about the editors of the Book Review who do the choosing as about the books chosen? Hardly. This year, in the dark of winter, all nine editors began worrying that fewer outstanding books seemed to be coming their way than before. Writers and publishers were grumbled about. ''Will there be no best books?'' traveled from mouth to mouth right into November. In fact, the mantra became useful. Large newspapers run on too many meetings. When you heard ''no best books?'' at least you knew you were in the right place.

title: Using the Right Terms For Indian Entities
description: Re ''Land, Wealth and Power Within Shinnecocks' Grasp'' [Nov. 21]: I take issue with but one little point; that there are ''currently 555 federally recognized tribes in the United States.'' Not the number, but the word ''tribes.'' There are 555 recognized native self-governing entities. But the word ''tribe'' usually refers to groups of some distinctive cultural unity and/or uniting political authority. In the 17th and 18th centuries the relevant word was typically ''nation.'' That older term, with the modern connotation of elevated prestige, is back in fashion among native peoples themselves.

title: The Many Barriers To Gaining Employment
description: I read with interest the articles on Nov. 7 [''Silicon Island, Wired but Underpopulated'' and ''For Employers, Boom Economy Puts Odds in Job Seekers' Hands''] regarding Long Island's high-tech industry and job market. I can tell you from personal experience that the technology companies are truly hypocrites; they did not tell you that they have a selection process that shrieks of age discrimination. There is no doubt in my mind that they look at a resume and immediately toss away any that might give a hint that the applicant is more than 25 to 30 years old.

title: Rooms With Attitude: New York; Millennial minimalism
description: I sat on my bed in Room 1111 and tried to feel red. Urging me on was a pamphlet explaining that each of the hotel's 193 rooms showcases a primary color -- red, yellow or blue. ''Think about how color affects your moods, your psyche, your sense of place,'' the pamphlet intoned. This marriage of interior decoration and ''color theory provocation,'' a concept inspired by Alexander Theroux's book, ''The Primary Colors,'' was designed, according to the pamphlet, to arouse the senses.

title: N.Y.U.'s Shuttle, Plus Tour Buses, Seen as Two Too Many Intrusions
description: Over the past year, New York University has increased its shuttle bus service, making travel between dorms and campus more convenient for students. But neighborhood residents complain that they are being inconvenienced. And the extra bus routes, they say, have opened the area to an influx of nonuniversity tour buses.

title: HOTEL CHECK-IN: Setting the Stage for a Stay; Bombay: Rooms with a view of the Arabian Sea
description: Press a button and swish, the day curtains swing shut. Press another, swish, the night drapes swing into place.

title: Liberties; Keyes Goes Kaboom!
description: Have you ever noticed that Alan Keyes and Marvin the Martian sound alike? Those stentorian, pear-shaped, apocalyptic declarations?

title: Richard Eakin Dies at 89; Did His Lectures in Costume
description: Richard M. Eakin, a professor of zoology at the University of California at Berkeley who captured the attention of his pre-med students by appearing at his lectures dressed as Charles Darwin, Louis Pasteur, William Harvey, Gregor Mendel and other greats of science, died Nov. 25 at his home in Danville, Calif. He was 89.

title: Only Black Commissioner to Resign
description: THE county's only black commissioner is resigning next month, prompting concern from some influential blacks that he is being unfairly forced out.

title: Singing Out for Floyd
description: The flood waters from Tropical Storm Floyd have receded in North Jersey, but the damage is done. Now, rock 'n' roll bands from the New Brunswick area want to help the victims put their lives back together.

title: Ticker-Tape Cachet
description: Often stuffed into a pocket with a fleeting glance, that business card might bear a closer look. Internet companies like Xceed (XCED) and Fashionmall.com (FASH) have begun adding stock ticker symbols to their cards, eliminating the need to flip through Dun & Bradstreet. ''I definitely get some interesting comments because of it,'' said Nancy Fermaglich, 29, an account executive at Fashionmall.com. ''At my age and the crowd I'm around, it's very impressive to work for a public company, especially a dot-com one.''

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Kenji Ekuan, GK Design Group
description: How to protect a capsule? Many designers rely on the human instinct to preserve objects that are beautiful. The more traditional approach is protection by burial. Kenji Ekuan draws from both approaches but adds a cosmic twist.

title: Q & A
description: Looking for Maigret

title: When a 'Hit' Is a Grand Slam
description: WHEN Paul Sagan left his job as president of the ailing new-media division of Time Warner three years ago, he described the frustration of trying to measure online success. ''You have 'hits,' which don't really mean anything,'' he said. ''So you were always grabbing at clouds.''

title: Closing of Upper East Side Hospital Blocked
description: A judge ruled late Friday that Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital cannot sell its three-building complex on the Upper East Side and must continue to provide health services to that community.

title: Is The Fur Still Flying?
description: I HAVE never worn fur. Maybe because my mother did. The women of her generation got mink coats from their husbands as door prizes for surviving the perils of car-pooling and keeping the dinners warm. And it didn't hurt that the neighbors would see that business was good.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; An Added Anchor for Newark's Downtown Revival
description: LESS than a month after the last workers at the former Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company headquarters in downtown Newark packed up and left, a new single tenant, International Discount Telecommunications, began moving into the 20-story building.

title: Safra, Fearing Intruders, Could Have Saved Himself
description: French investigators said today that the billionaire banker Edmond J. Safra died of smoke inhalation because -- even after the police and firefighters arrived at his penthouse -- he still believed that he was in danger from masked intruders and refused to leave the bathroom where he had barricaded himself with one of his nurses.

title: Covent Garden Reopens With a Flourish
description: Backstage tours, exhibitions and free concerts will be offered by the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden when it reopens tomorrow after a two-and-a-half-year, $360 million renovation, which included a new 420-seat studio theater, a rooftop terrace and reconstruction of the cast-iron floral hall.

title: Economic Debate Emerging in Race
description: The presidential candidates are setting out increasingly specific economic policy positions, highlighting differences within and between the parties over how to take advantage of and extend the nation's prosperity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PSATY, CLAIRE
description: PSATY-Claire. Of North Miami Beach formerly of Forest Hills, Queens, cherished wife of Martin Psaty, former New York State Assemblyman and Queens Jewish Center President; devoted mother to Beverly (Barry) Pomerantz, Alan (Sarah) Psaty, Madelyn (Michael) Schatten; adoring grandmother and great grandmother; loving sister of Rabbi David Ringelheim and Shirley Wertheimer. An Aishes Chayil concerned for family, friends, community. Past Democratic Party District Leader, Sisterhood President Queens Jewish Center. Services held in Florida, December 3, 1999.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a vignette on Page 163 of The Times Magazine today about Green-Wood Cemetery, part of the article called ''A New York Minute,'' appears in some copies without its last word. The final sentence should read, ''They tell me that 135 groundskeepers maintain these 478 lush acres, but all I know is not a single living soul came into view during the minute I stood watch.''

title: Public Needs First
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel
description: Anyone who has traveled to one of the remoter parts of the world knows the feeling that comes over you when you realize, suddenly and viscerally, how far you are from home. The sensation is both terrifying and exhilarating, as if the distance across oceans and continents were opening up directly under your feet. It's like taking a hit of some mind-expanding drug: in the streets of a foreign city, the contours of things acquire a clarity that's often unrealizable in your native land. From Marco Polo to Graham Greene, writers have relied on this peculiar high to lend a kick to their powers of observation and have gone seeking the drug in ever more remote valleys and villages.

title: Community College Enrollment Reaches an All-Time High
description: Full-time enrollment in New Jersey's 19 community colleges reached an all-time high this year after falling slightly in 1998. Part-time enrollment remained nearly steady from last year, though drastically down from the early 1990's.

title: Vandals Disrupt Long Island Phone Service
description: In an act of vandalism that left hundreds of people on Long Island without phone service, several Bell Atlantic cables were cut in Babylon and Lindenhurst yesterday, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Protect Tools and Pots From Harsh Weather
description: THE recent spate of mild weather gave many gardeners a false sense of security, but winter is on its way.

title: Talks With Gay Playwrights Offered in Course at Purchase
description: ASK Craig Lucas what a gay play is and he is likely to, purposefully, reel off flip definitions, often heard by some people:

title: George II
description: A Charge to Keep

title: Nov. 28-Dec. 4; A Big Maybe About AIDS
description: Ever since American doctors discovered AIDS in 1981, the origins of the viral disease have been a scientific mystery. Many scientists believe that H.I.V.-1, the main AIDS virus in the world, derives from a simian virus in chimpanzees. But the unanswered question is how the virus jumped to humans. The most widely accepted theory is that passage must have occurred in blood-to-blood contact, like a bite or cut during the slaughter of chimpanzees.

title: Dinosaur Food
description: To the Editor:

title: New Rules Governing Lead Paint
description: CRITICIZED by landlords as too strict, by tenant groups as too lenient and by co-op and condominium experts as too vague, the new regulations on lead-based-paint that went into effect Nov. 12 as New York City's Local Law 38 of 1999 affect the vast majority of dwellings in the city.

title: Ivy League or Briar Patch?
description: Correction Appended

title: POSTINGS: Compendium on Rents and Housing; A Glitch Adds 250 Copies
description: Due to a perhaps fortunate glitch, a usually hard-to-get compendium of research on regulated rents, the city's economy and the housing market published by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board is a lot easier to come by this year -- and, for some buyers, cheaper.

title: A Rising Star Needs a League of Her Own
description: YAEL Averbuch knows what she wants to be when she grows up: a professional soccer player. The ambition of this 13-year-old girl is not at all thwarted by the fact that there currently is no professional women's soccer league in the United States.

title: On Trial at the Met: the Art of the Connoisseur
description: ''FAKE'' is an unkind word to say to museum curators. But the Metropolitan Museum has heard it many times in the past two years, after one of its most highly touted recent acquisitions, the Chinese scroll painting titled ''Riverbank,'' attributed to the 10th-century artist Dong Yuan, was accused of being a 20th-century forgery.

title: His Roadside Fans
description: To the Editor:

title: Translating a Call for Help
description: Guo Tian Liang stood on a dark street corner in Sunset Park a few weeks ago inspecting his empty leather wallet. The $40 it had contained moments earlier was gone. So was his cell phone. So were the three men who had just robbed him on his way home from work.

title: Food; Good and Plenty
description: Dear descendants, May these recipes allow you to taste life as we, your ancestors, now know it. They represent the foods we grew up on during the last half of the 20th century -- the meals we stuffed ourselves with at church suppers and family reunions, in school cafeterias and at local restaurants.

title: Go Ask Alice Again
description: What, Alice must once have asked the Mad Hatter, is the difference between an annotated book prepared by an editor and an edited book peppered with notes? All the difference in the world, the Hatter would have replied: one plays the notes for the sake of the text, and the other plays the text for the sake of the notes. Martin Gardner's ''Annotated Alice'' (Norton, $29.95) is now back, in a new, ''definitive'' form, to remind us that this is so, and why. A conventional edited edition is there to elucidate its text; Gardner, on the other hand, plays the text -- goes right round the floor with it, bringing in physics, psychoanalysis, literary history, math and logic -- for the sake of notes that are compressed little essays on all the subjects the text inspires.

title: Nov. 28-Dec. 4; The Adults Are At It Again
description: Children are often caught in the middle of divorce. But when the child is a Cuban refugee with family on both sides of the Florida Straits, the custody battle is as much political as it is personal. Probably more.

title: Moms, Don't Complain If You Work by Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome to Paradise
description: From dot.com executive suites to fast-food service counters, the worker is king. Employers have to roll out the red carpet for potential hires, and multiply the incentives for workers to stay. Competitive pay is only a start. Employers have been known to troll the competition's after-hours hangouts, or to turn their cafeterias into four-star restaurants. What are the most creative ways you have found to hire and keep employees? Or the best blandishments you have been offered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Freshman Dismisses Hofstra Seniors
description: As Giovanni Carmazzi, Hofstra's senior quarterback, limped off the field today after being sacked early in the fourth quarter against Illinois State, his teammates and the crowd of 5,586 at Hofstra Stadium applauded him as if his farewell were at hand.

title: Staying on Guard For Medical Errors
description: THE National Academy of Sciences asked Congress last week to create an agency to monitor medical errors -- and to require health care providers to disclose errors that cause serious harm. An academy report suggested that 44,000 to 98,000 people die each year because of such errors in hospitals alone, more than the toll from highway accidents.

title: Pop Gates, 82, an Integrator of Pro Basketball
description: Pop Gates, a member of the Basketball Hall of Fame who starred for the renowned all-black Renaissance Big Five team in the late 1930's and 40's and helped pioneer the integration of the postwar professional game, died Wednesday at his home in Harlem. He was 82.

title: Hollywood on Hudson (Both Sides Now); New Jersey's Film Industry Grows With New York's, Not at Its Expense
description: It would be tempting to view New Jersey's recent overtures toward the film and television industry as just another skirmish in its long rivalry with New York City.

title: Ideas & Trends: Do No Harm; Breaking Down Medicine's Culture of Silence
description: DR. MICHAEL LEONARD, an anesthesiologist and chief of surgery for Kaiser Permanente in Denver, was operating on a cancer patient a few months ago when he reached into a drawer for medicine. Inside were two vials, side by side. Both had yellow labels. Both had yellow caps. One was a paralyzing agent, which Dr. Leonard had correctly administered to keep the patient still during the operation. The other was the reversal agent, which he needed next. ''I grabbed the wrong one,'' Dr. Leonard recalled. ''I used the wrong drug.''

title: Of Mothers, Fathers and Generals
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith Kramer, Howard Kessler
description: Judith Kramer, a lawyer, and Dr. Howard Kessler, a radiologist, are to be married today at Temple B'nai Israel in Millburn, N.J. Rabbi Steven Bayar is to perform the ceremony.

title: Art
description: On my first evening in New York, some 30 years ago, I was privileged to meet Duncan Phillips. That anyone still wore white gloves when coming out to dinner was deeply impressive to me. So was the exquisite attention he paid to my ludicrous remarks about the museums of a country in which I had arrived for the first time only 24 hours before.

title: Bastion of Confederacy Finds Its Future May Hinge on Rejecting the Past
description: In earlier decades, when the battle flag of the Confederacy still defined Alabama's racial climate from atop the State Capitol, other states made sure that businesses on the move knew the precise nature of the flag's divisive symbolism.

title: A State's Habits Disputed, Sort Of
description: So, ''Connecticut people go a little nuts doing business in New York, where the day starts at 9'' (''Who are We? Nuts and Bolts; No Sunbeam,'' by Colin McEnroe, Nov. 21).

title: F.Y.I.
description: Push-Me-Pull-You

title: Heather Kamen and Marc Katzin
description: Heather Tara Kamen, a daughter of Sandra and Michael Kamen of Stamford, Conn., is to be married this evening to Marc Lane Katzin, the son of Isabel and Richard Katzin of Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz is to perform the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: In Diverse Town, Both Sides Take Turns at Atrocity
description: Following are excerpts from two reports by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe about Prizren, a town near the Albanian border that was ethnically mixed before the war. The population of 80,000 was about 70 percent Albanian, about 11 percent Serbian and about 19 percent other nationalities, including Turks and Gypsies.

title: An Art Form of the Streets, and for the Streets
description: Not many New Yorkers looking for artistic inspiration turn to manhole covers. But those who do so tend to be as passionate as, say, lovers of British shock art. Where other people see only a utilitarian metal disc and think only of pipes or cables, the cognoscenti see beauty, history, symbolism and wide-open design possibilities.

title: POSTINGS: $5.5 Million Project at 12th and 46th; At the Intrepid, A New Center For Visitors
description: ''It's not one of my typical landlocked projects,'' said William Suk, referring to the new $5.5 million Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum Visitors Center to open in the shadow of the bow of the U.S.S. Intrepid on Pier 86 in late June.

title: Is This Albacore Heaven? No, It's Just the Outer Banks
description: If the vagabond false albacore that cruise our shores on their way to winter grounds rouse your angling lust, you will be hopelessly love sick once you encounter the albies of North Carolina's Outer Banks. Stronger than, but just as fast as, their northern relatives, they are, on average, twice as big. A fish of 20 pounds is not uncommon.

title: Police in Denial
description: To the Editor:

title: Crushed by a Horse
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Foreign Tutorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Play-by-Play Coverage, From a Distance
description: John Paul Dellacamera and Tommy Smyth are accustomed to traveling to some of the most desirable European locales without ever leaving Bristol, Conn. From a tiny soundproof room there, the announcers work as anchors for ESPN2's live English-language coverage of the European Champions League, the top soccer club competition in the world.

title: Rooms With Attitude: New York; Feather beds, duvets and a grand view
description: I was told that my room, like many at the W Tuscany, would be large, but no one mentioned the view. An enormous window looked from this spot at Park Avenue and 39th Street onto a dazzling New York cityscape -- brownstones, a church spire and the Empire State Building. I plopped onto the pretty checked daybed near the window, wrapped myself in the chenille throw and gazed at the city lights. The floor show ended at midnight, when the Empire State's yellow and orange topknot blinked off. I fell asleep humming Gershwin.

title: Ideas & Trends: Stationery Cycles; Naming With 20-20 Hindsight
description: THE calendar is winding down for hundreds of companies and organizations named after the waning century.

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Antenna design
description: Reflecting both Eastern and Western traditions, the entry proposed by this design firm transcends the rational. It turns to the ancient Japanese idea of a ''dream pillow'' to explore the mysteries of cultural receptivity. In an era that is increasingly driven by the exchange of information, much depends on the ability to distinguish meaning from noise.

title: HOTEL CHECK-IN: Setting the Stage for a Stay; Bangkok: Serenity in the frantic Thai capital

The same can be said of how parents regard their kids, and Quentin Blake, the masterly British illustrator, does just that in ZAGAZOO (Orchard, $15.95; ages 5 and up), his wonderfully wry sketch of what happens when a twosome becomes a threesome.

description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Fashion Model Agent
description: ''As a man dealing mostly with women in the fashion and beauty industries, the image that I project has to be smart, simple and visionary,'' said Michael Flutie, 41, the owner of Company Management, a modeling agency. Two years ago, Mr. Flutie had the vision to wear Tibetan love beads. ''I stopped wearing them when I was in an airport in Paris going to New York and everyone had them,'' he said.

title: Sean Hodgson, Karin Walter
description: Karin Linnea Walter, the daughter of Mariette and Leif Walter of Askersund, Sweden, was married on Friday to Sean Wesley Hodgson, a son of Dr. Jean Morgan and Dr. John Hodgson of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas E. Nicoll performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont.

description: SONGWRITERS have long waxed poetic about the power of a smile to attract friends and romance. Susan I. Larson of Carmel says that even an unseen smile can help sales people. It is all a matter of attitude, she said, and a good attitude can be sensed by a person at the other end of a telephone call.

description: Last Thursday, Jean Griffith Sandiford planted flowers at the grave of her son Michael Griffith, who was killed nearly 13 years ago in a racially motivated attack in Howard Beach. It was a private act of remembrance.

title: Ideas & Trends; Due Process, But How Much Is Due?
description: FOR well over 100 years, the Constitution has guaranteed that no ''person'' should be deprived of life, liberty or property without due process. For just as long, the nation has wavered on whether such rights apply only to American citizens or extend to the millions of immigrants who, legally and illegally, live in this country or arrive at its borders.

description: Brittney Wertheim, a daughter of Judy and Harvey J. Wertheim of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Adrian David Hegarty, a son of Maura Hegarty and Dr. P. title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Wes Jones
description: All time capsules are about protection. This one makes an ostentatious display of it. It incorporates two metal containers, one for storing three-dimensional objects, the other for a microengraved nickel HD-Rosetta disk on which data can be safely stored. The containers are then armored with mechanical bolt-on components: motorized doors, automatic argon gas injectors, atomic clocks and viewing devices. If the capsule should come under attack or stress -- an earthquake, say -- it would automatically close up to protect its precious contents.

title: Knicks Enjoy a Fantasy at the Nets' Expense
description: Allan Houston and Marcus Camby of the Knicks were in a world of make-believe Friday night, casually making spectacular alley-oop plays for a credit card commercial. But the dispirited Nets have been making opponents' fantasies come true this season, and today at the Continental Arena they granted a wish for Houston and Camby.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Luxury Complexes Find Room at the Top
description: WHEN Jackie Cottrell's husband, Karl, a research engineer, was transferred two months ago from Rhode Island to Tarrytown, the couple didn't feel ready to purchase in Westchester. They decided to rent instead for a couple of years, see how the job worked out and how they liked the area.

title: Deregulation in 2000 May Begin Quietly
description: THIS fall the Manufacturers Alliance of Connecticut became the first power aggregator licensed in Connecticut, in preparation for competition in the electricity industry on Jan. 1. As an aggregator, the Waterbury trade group would buy power from a wholesaler, passing the power and the savings to its members. The group is in talks with about 300 companies that are interested in signing up for bulk power purchases. The group will then negotiate the best deal with a power supplier.

description: To the Editor:

title: Another Italian Restaurant, but a Presence
description: LONG ISLAND has a longstanding love affair with Italian restaurants. They are the peoples' choice when we eat out. Therefore, when yet another Italian spot opens, there is hardly a ripple of interest. When that opening is in Glen Cove, the Island's epicenter of Italian dining, it ranks as a nonevent.

title: Pan Am Strategy: Alternative Airports
description: Hoping to capture a share of some big markets by flying out of smaller airports nearby, the newly revamped Pam Am Airlines has begun flying 727's -- carrying between 25 and 50 passengers daily except Tuesday -- between Portsmouth, N.H., 66 miles from Boston, and a little airport north of Orlando, Fla., in Sanford. The fare advantage is that a traveler can buy a ticket and fly the same day with no penalty. The typical walk-on round-trip fare is $216, as opposed to about $975 between Boston and Orlando without the 14 days' notice.

title: No, a 90's Club, Baby
description: ''The space is inspired by Op Art, which predates Austin Powers,'' said David Baxley, the owner of Centro-Fly, a new club at 45 West 21st Street, where Tramps used to be. So please don't call it shagadelic or say it looks like a Target commercial, because the club's name comes from a Milan department store designed by Gae Aulenti in 1965. Mr. Baxley's wife, Sally Bennett, designed the 11,000 square feet with such mod details as mirrored bars, white leather banquettes and sunken lounges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, SYLVIA MARIA
description: ROSE-Sylvia Maria. died suddenly at her home on Wednesday, December 1, 1999. She was born in Baghdad, Iraq on December 27, 1926, daughter of Catherine Behnan Arbuthnott of England and the late Cyril George Arbuthnott of Ootacumund, India. She was a graduate of National College of Shwaifat of Lebanon and the Convent of French Sisters School of Presentation. She married Edmund Charles Rose in 1947. Mr. Rose died in 1989. Surviving are a daughter Patricia M. Kluge of Albemarle; a son, Ernest Rose of Southbourne, England, UK; a grandson, John W. Kluge II; two brothers, Douglas Arbuthnott of Surrey, England UK and Dennis Arbuthnott of Cornwall, England, UK. A candlelight funeral service will be held at St. John the Baptist In the Woods at the family estate on Saturday, December 11, 1999 at 3 pm with the Rev. Father Gregory Salomone officiating. Private entombment will follow in the family crypt. Information: Hill and Wood Funeral Home, Charlottesville, Virginia.

title: Alter Egos Who Put the 'R' in R.S.V.P.
description: SEATED at her mahogany desk on the fifth floor of a town house on Sutton Square, surrounded by prints of thoroughbred horses, Meredith Palin juggled the details of a busy life spent between homes in Manhattan, Southampton and Lyford Cay, in the Bahamas. Not her life, her employer's.

title: The Nation; Gimme Shelter: Same Song, New Tune
description: NO big city can match New York City for its ungrudging support of the destitute. Alone among American cities, the city has legalized the right to shelter, and no city can touch the scope or the magnitude of benefits that New York City spreads among the poor. But now the city has become a model of toughness with a series of new demands on the homeless.

title: Barkley Hits Shot as Red Storm Hits Form
description: Erick Barkley has spoken proudly about his off-season workout regimen: hang around with the Nets' Stephon Marbury and shoot 300 jumpers every day. The new basketball season hasn't exactly begun the way either one of the best point guards from New York envisioned, but yesterday, Barkley broke out of the slump that had sunk his shooting average lower than Marbury's relationship with his teammates.

title: The Dendur Mummies: Weren't They a Punk Group?
description: WALKING briskly through a hall full of Egyptian sarcophagi in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Ann Dexter-Jones remarked, ''It must be amazing to come to work here every day.''

title: Nobel Economics: Spending the Check
description: ON a late October morning, Robert Alexander Mundell sat Buddha-like amid stylish clutter in his Claremont Avenue apartment, two blocks from Columbia University in Manhattan. The magic moment when, amid fairy-tale pomp, he will receive from the King of Sweden the heavy gold medal engraved with Alfred Nobel's stern profile was still weeks away. But life had already changed profoundly for Mr. Mundell, 67, the flamboyant Canadian-born economist whose ideas paved the way for the euro, the European currency.

title: Rooms With Attitude; Hip boutique hotels care a lot about style. What else do they deliver?
description: IT isn't in the dictionary, but the term boutique hotel has become shorthand for a hotel with high-concept design and personality, one that aspires to originality, attracting a young crowd with hipness rather than grandeur, and (at least in the early days of the trend) moderate prices. Trailblazing boutique hotels include the Royalton, the Paramount and the Mercer in New York, the Triton in San Francisco, and the Delano in Miami. But the trend can be traced as far back as Blakes Hotel in London, a clubby luxury retreat carved from a pair of Victorian townhouses that opened in 1981, where no two rooms are alike and the restaurant is as adventurous as the decor.

title: Another Outlet For Belgian Chocolate
description: Neuhaus, a Belgian chocolatier since 1857 with about 200 boutiques in 65 countries, opened its fourth Manhattan location at the end of October in Grand Central Terminal. Part of Neuhaus's plan to open 20 American stores by 2003, the location (at 42nd Street and Vanderbilt Avenue) is just one of three Neuhaus has opened in the past few months; the others are in San Francisco and Seattle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, DONALD SCOTT
description: Myers-Donald Scott. Born West Chester, Penn, April 4, 1925, graduated Scarsdale High School and Colgate University, served in The Army Airforce as a B-24 Bomber Pilot during World War II. Donald was with the New York Telephone Company for 37 years serving as an Officer for 17 of those years, most recently as Vice President Switch Services. He retired in August 1984. He moved to Vero Beach in 1985 from Chappaqua, NY. He was married to Genevieve Dullum for 41 years, she died in 1986. Donald was a past director of the Chase Manhattan Regional Bank of Rochester, NY, a past director of the national Bank of Westchester, White Plains, NY and a past trustee of the Village Savings Bank of Port Chester, NY. He was a director of the Mutual of New York Real Estate Investment Trust. He was past president of the New York School for the Deaf. Donald was a member of the Trinity Episcopal Church in Vero Beach, FL. He was also a member the Bent Pine Golf Club, Vero Beach Country Club and Eastward Ho! Country Club in Chatham, Mass. Donald is the son of the late Alice and Clarence Myers. Clarence was the Chairman, President and CEO of New York Life Insurance Co. Donald is survived by his wife Virginia; daughters Barbara Kappauf of Bridgewater, NJ, Patricia Casby of Sudbury, Mass, and a son Roger of Sugarland, TX and six grandchildren. Burial will be in the Colgate University Cemetery in Hamilton, NY. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to the New York School for the Deaf, 555 Knollwood Road, White Plains, New York 10603

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Jurgen Bey for Droog Design
description: When the Dutch collective known as Droog Design considered what things last for centuries, its members settled on three categories: heirlooms, trash and tombs. Jurgen Bey, one of Droog's members, proposes piggybacking capsule data on all three forms. The most arresting of these involves using human bodies as time capsules.

title: Auckland
description: Auckland can count its geographic blessings. This port city, anchored on wide harbors and steep hills that evoke comparisons to two other baysiders along the Pacific Rim, Sydney and San Francisco, will be the first major urban area in the world to celebrate the arrival of 2000.

title: With Wit and High Spirits, a Musical Wake-Up Kiss
description: THOUGH much admired, Cole Porter is never mentioned as one of those innovators who forever changed the content or the direction of American musical comedy. He is seldom spoken of with the same reverence with which we talk about Irving Berlin, George and Ira Gershwin, Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, and especially the canonized Rodgers and Hammerstein. Porter, who was writing shows from 1916 until 1958 (he died in 1964), had his share of hits, a lot of flops, but only one generally acknowledged classic, ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' which opened on Broadway on Dec. 30, 1948.

title: The World; At Last, the Face of Peace in Ulster. But No Smile Yet.
description: THE set jaw, the tight grin and squinting eyes of Martin McGuinness were once the focus of Ulster's security alert notices, but today they are the face of Ulster's new politics.

description: SOME girls grow up denigrating themselves, doubting their competence. Others, of the princess persuasion, are told, and raised to believe: ''You could be anything at all.''

title: An Encyclopedia of Lost Practices; Reproductive Sex
description: There's a good chance that you have no idea what sexual intercourse is -- or was. This is assuming that you are a layperson (no pun intended -- well, you wouldn't get it anyway); a specialist (a paleourologist, for example) might have some vague, academic notion. Sexual intercourse was the union of the male and female genitalia resulting (with often stunning rapidity) in the ejaculation of semen from the penis into the female reproductive tract. As a form of reproduction, it was a rudimentary method of achieving genetic variability. The fertilized egg, or zygote, possessing the normal diploid number of 46 chromosomes, represented a recombination of parental characteristics. I know, compared with your advanced life-fabricating technologies, all this must seem like so much Cro-Magnon finger painting.

description: Upon its opening, in 1928, the George V was hailed as the last word in opulence. World affairs were conducted at the grand hotel on the Avenue George V in Paris's Eighth Arrondissement (it became an official branch office of the League of Nations), and during the liberation of Paris, Gen. title: Doubting Rescuers, Banker Suffocated
description: Investigators said yesterday in Monte Carlo that the billionaire banker Edmond Safra, barricaded in a bathroom during an attack on his penthouse apartment, died of smoke inhalation because he apparently mistook police officers and firefighters for intruders and refused to come out. Mr. Safra had a cell phone with him when he took refuge in the bathroom and spoke from there with his wife, who encouraged him to come out, a prosecutor said. But Mr. Safra heard banging on the walls and believed intruders were still after him.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Evening Hours column on Nov. 21 about a fund-raising event at the National Arts Club on Nov. 18 misidentified the beneficiary. It was the club itself, not the Winterthur Museum, Garden and Library.

title: From the Coach's Corner
description: Strong Investments, providing further evidence of the blurring lines between no-load fund companies and traditional brokerage firms, plans to offer what it calls ''personal coaches'' -- customer service representatives to help investors manage their portfolios.

title: The Nation: Don't Read This; If You Do, They May Have to Kill You
description: NO government organization has been better insulated from public scrutiny than the National Security Agency. Its very existence as America's premier eavesdropper and code-breaker was classified for decades, and the N.S.A. -- also known as ''No Such Agency'' -- has been able to keep the press and Congress largely at bay even as the Central Intelligence Agency has come under increased scrutiny in the wake of its cold war excesses and failures.

title: Nov. 28-Dec. 4; Nothing New For Kuwait's Women
description: For the second time in a week, Kuwait's all-male parliament said no to an effort to grant women full political rights alongside men. The United States had urged passage of such a measure. But on Nov. 23, the parliament overturned an effort by the Persian Gulf state's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, to accomplish the enfranchisement of women through a decree, and on Tuesday it defeated an effort to do so through a legislative bill. That left the vote restricted to men over 21 who have held citizenship for 20 years and who are not members of the armed forces or police.

title: A Monument Maker On a Smaller Scale
description: WHAT artist in history can boast of capping a career as grandly as Gutzon Borglum did? But his Mount Rushmore has overwhelmed his own story; everybody knows the four chiseled presidential heads but only a small percentage of Americans know the name of the monument's creator. Borglum and his career are currently being fleshed out at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center in an exhibition titled, ''Out of Rushmore's Shadow: the Artistic Development of Gutzon Borglum.''

title: Many Retirees Find It's Time to Go to Work
description: Dr. Bill Schwartz likes to think of the Samaritan House clinic as a model of inefficiency. The small clinic for the poor in this Bay area suburb is so heavily staffed that doctors can take half an hour to talk casually with patients about a backache. They hang out in the office reading medical journals. They chat with each other in the hallways.

title: Ex-Outsider Adjusts to Life as a Power in Nassau
description: The blooms were fading on the Election Day bouquets and Judith A. Jacobs was in her office here planning the ceremony next month where she will become presiding officer of the Nassau County Legislature and her fellow Democrats will be sworn in as the majority party for the first time.

title: Holiday Programs Abound at Purchase

Today at 1 and 5 p.m. Clara meets her handsome Prince as Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker'' weaves its magical spell with the New York City Ballet principals Miranda Weese and Damian Woetzel heading a cast that includes students of the Conservatory of Dance, and 350 local children accompanied by the Purchase Symphony.

title: An Encyclopedia of Lost Practices; The Elvis Phenomenon
description: As you tune in the elvis tabernacle choir singing for the huge nativity celebration on Jan. 8, 3000 . . . or as you pass your priest in the street, his jeweled bell-bottoms flapping, his belt buckle gleaming, his cape and scarf flowing out behind him (he lunges, he points . . . at you! He grins. ''Hey, darlin','' he says. Blessed, shriven, you continue on your way) . . . you may wonder what it was like back at the beginning, before the cathedrals were built and the liturgy fixed in stone, when the first ministers emerged to spread the good news -- the power and the glory of Elvis.

title: Where Have the Confident, Happy Heroes Gone?
description: AGENT FOX MULDER didn't look so good. In the two-part season premiere of ''The X-Files,'' he was lying in a hospital bed, paralyzed by an alien virus and staring blankly into space, pretty much at death's door. The Cigarette Smoking Man, Mulder's longtime nemesis, leaned over him sympathetically and urged him to let go of his useless six-year quest (to prove the existence of space aliens, to uncover a government conspiracy, to find his abducted sister).

To flaunt your personality, swing your hips, to look as dangerous as sin and not feel crushed by the old mental baggage . . . the ''right'' shoe, the ''right'' hairdo. Who needs that?

title: Architecture
description: AMERICAN BUILDING: The Environmental Forces That Shape It. By James Marston Fitch with William Bobenhausen. (Oxford, $40.) ''As completely as fish in water, people are submerged in their own environment,'' James Marston Fitch writes. ''But, unlike fish, people act upon their environment as well as being acted upon by it.'' How we do that -- through our natural and artificial responses to light, heat, cold and sound, to say nothing of space, time and gravity -- is the subject of this revised version of a classic work first published by Fitch in 1947 and now thoroughly updated (with the help of the architect William Bobenhausen) to reflect the immense technological changes since then. Their masterly and surprisingly accessible investigation of the functional aspects of architecture addresses issues that few nonprofessionals consider, though the world would be greatly improved if they did.

title: At Last Blush
description: People in the future will have no idea how embarrassing it was to be alive now. Looking back, they will perhaps be able to understand our joys, our appetites, our fears and our insectlike frenzies; by an exercise of negative capability, they may feel some of the few sorrows they give us credit for. But the true, deep, mortifying embarrassment that came over us sometimes when we looked at how we lived and the times we made -- that will escape them, I'm sure.

title: A Palace Of Culture, But Whose Culture Is It?
description: CURTAIN time at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts brings an almost overwhelming flurry of activity. Recently the National Symphony Orchestra and the San Francisco Ballet vied for audiences in the main auditoriums. Upstairs, in the Theater Lab, a cozy space designed for experimental works, a very nonexperimental comedy, ''Shear Madness,'' about a murder in a beauty parlor, played to a group of out-of-towners. In the Terrace Theater, ''The Whiteheaded Boy,'' a turn-of-the-century Irish classic, ran a two-week season.

title: In 100th Meeting, Navy Runs Past Army
description: Quarterback Brian Madden and kicker Tim Shubdza led Navy to a memorable victory over Army this afternoon in the 100th meeting of a series that began in 1890.

title: When Grandparents Have to Step In
description: Maggie Lee, 60, raised six children a generation ago, but the death of her daughter has left her in charge of four young children. More and more grandparents in the city are again doing the heavy lifting of parenthood, and are being helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Ms. Lee said she hoped her grandchildren would be more cooperative after seeing her birth certificate. ''I thought if I showed it to them, they would see I'm an old lady,'' she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, MARTIN
description: HARRIS-Martin. March 13, 1933December 1, 1999. Adored husband of Boots (Lauren). Cherished dad of Michael, Clint, Rex, Saroya & Eytan Chissick. Playful Grandpa Marty to Patrick, Brooke, Richard, Daphna, Avital and Zev Shmvel. Cherished son of Josephine and the late Samuel. World's best friend, pilot, motorcycle rider, restaurateur, son, husband, grandfather. A kind, gentle, caring man who touched all he met with love and humor. Marty always had time to help a friend and counsel those in need! Marty would have loved any contributions to be made to Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital, NYC. Funeral services were held on Friday, December 3.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Keeping a Will Current, And Other Estate Tips
description: WHEN Alan H. Rosenberg's cousin -- a widow in her mid-80's with no children -- died alone in her Manhattan apartment in 1993, he believed that he would be the executor of her substantial estate. But no one could find her will, and the lawyer who wrote it was long since dead.

title: From Ho Chi Minh to Snapple: A Mural Project Evolves
description: If you're cruising up the East River and you glance at a waterside building in Red Hook, you might think you've stumbled across another of those corporate billboards that seem to spring up daily. A painting depicts a Snapple bottle floating above the Brooklyn Bridge as children beam beatifically.

title: Going Online And Finding A Window On the Times
description: ''Y2K,'' the playwright Arthur Kopit's thriller about a computer hacker who ruins a couple's life, opens on Tuesday in a Manhattan Theater Club production at the Lucille Lortel Theater. Mr. Kopit and Katie Hafner, who writes for the Circuits section of The New York Times, exchanged e-mails about the play. Here are excerpts from their correspondence.

title: Armed Forces In Colombia Hoping to Get Fighting Fit
description: The beleaguered Colombian military, which has spent much of its time in recent years stung by surprise guerrilla strikes, wants to transform itself into a force that could instead take the offensive against the rebels and their drug-trafficking allies, military officials here say.

title: Rooms With Attitude: Washington; A warm welcome (plus 2 phone lines)
description: By all rights, the staff at the Hotel George should have recoiled from me. I arrived late on a lazy Sunday when I had taken a vacation from shaving, showering, wearing clean clothing or any other semblance of civilized behavior. But what they did, even before I pulled out my credit card, was give me a spectacularly warm welcome. The woman at the front desk extended her hand to shake mine. The bellhop appeared instantly and struck up a friendly conversation. If the point of a boutique hotel is to establish a more intimate environment than larger establishments can or do, then the George was hewing beautifully -- and, in my case, bravely -- to that mission.

description: HOLDERS of the American Express Platinum card, especially those who delight in flashing it, may want to start leaving home without it.

title: Tomorrow's Ruins Today
description: Most of what we build today won't be around in 100 years, let alone 1,000. Our steel-frame and curtain-wall skyscrapers are major symbols of our age, but there is every reason to surmise they won't be here for long. Their life expectancy is 50 years or so, and that assumes assiduous maintenance. It's also hard to believe that people in 1,000 years will still be willing to sit in cells up there pushing pieces of paper around. This is a very special, recent, odd way of life, vastly at variance with the grand fantasy of its setting.

title: Judith Randall, Howard Siner
description: Judith Lynn Randall and Howard Walter Siner, editors and writers, are to be married today. Justice Peter Cusick of State Supreme Court in St. George, Staten Island, is to officiate at the bride's home in Randall Manor, Staten Island.

title: The View From/Somers; Families Make Baubles And Holiday Memories
description: THEY stay in the attic or cellar most of the time, wrapped in tissue paper or nested in boxes, inanimate objects all but forgotten 11 months of the year. Come December, the Christmas ornaments are brought out, and one is reminded once again of their power to call forth memories, to elicit emotions even though they are merely pretty pieces of glass or wood or paper or lace.

title: A Grand Entrance
description: It takes a mastery of life's necessities (paying the bills) to produce the stuff of life's sustenance (theater, music, Shakespeare.) Debbie Chinn has demonstrated a knack for traveling the bottom line, and now, after fund-raising jobs at the Center Theater Group of Los Angeles and the San Francisco Symphony, she has been named managing director of New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in Madison, beginning on Jan. 10. ''Till then, it's back and forth,'' she said from San Francisco.

title: Hoboken Makes Its Case to Be No. 1
description: Nearly an hour after tonight's game had ended, the Hoboken players were still scattered across the turf at Giants Stadium, celebrating as loudly as they had been the minute the game ended. As accustomed to winning as the Red Wings are, this celebration raged on as if the team had something to prove.

title: Even in Transition, A Seamless Sound
description: A MUSICAL organization goes through constant minor transitions: changes in personnel, changes in repertory. Chanticleer, the 20-year-old male vocal ensemble based in San Francisco, has weathered its share of those. But now it faces a greater change, with a new general director and new performing ambitions.

title: Photography
description: The end of a century in which photographic reproduction went from rude infancy to a universal adulthood provides occasion for celebrating the role that books of photographs play in presenting and preserving history. There are, of course, the expectable compilations of camera pictures from the last 100 years -- American Photography: A Century of Images'' (Chronicle), inspired by the recent PBS program, and ''Century'' (Phaidon), a gargantuan British effort. More interesting are the books that focus comprehensively on photographers whose pictures have helped define both the history of their times and the history of photography as an art. These range from the sublime (''Edward Steichen: The Early Years,'' discussed below) to the subversive (''Pictures,'' from Arena Editions, which lets us see the Robert Mapplethorpe sex images that nearly put an art museum director in jail in the late 1980's). In between are surveys of work by well-known practitioners such as Ralph Gibson (''Deus ex Machina,'' Taschen) and Mary Ellen Mark (''American Odyssey,'' Aperture), as well as by less-known talents like William Gedney (''What Was True,'' Norton).

title: The Skyscrapers, the Subways, the Sewers

Another is a compilation of stories about the life and labor of New York City transit workers, who are given little thought -- until something goes wrong. Finally, a former New York City chief borough engineer, Richard Herschlag, weaves a fast-moving thriller, moving from engineering to architecture to the intricacies of sewer flows, all played out against the glamour and grime of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELAZAR, DANIEL
description: ELAZAR-Daniel. The Officers and Staff of United Jewish Communities deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Daniel Elazar, Professor at Bar Ilan and Temple University and Founder of The Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs. Dr. Elazar was passionate in his committment to the Jewish people, Jerusalem and Israel. Among his many contributions to organized Jewish life is his legacy of organizational analysis that includes The Jewish Agency for Israel and the Federation system. Dr. Elazar brought a spirit of compassion, generosity and dedication to all of his work, enriching the lives of all he touched. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Charles R. Bronfman, UJC Chairman of the Board Joel D. description: TEN years ago, when the choreographer Rosane Chamecki left her hometown, Curitiba, Brazil, to come to New York, she knew her life was going to change, or, as she puts it in a thick Portuguese accent, ''be transformed.'' She arrived with her dance partner, Andrea Lerner, and together they immersed themselves in the downtown dance scene and began choreographing for each other.

title: The Year 2000 and the Force of Change
description: It is early December. Before long, people all around the world will be counting off the final seconds as midnight leaps westward from time zone to time zone, carrying us all at long last into the year 2000. The closer the moment comes, the clearer it seems that our expectations for it have been, in some sense, overly dramatic. The mere arrival of the midnight hour will not occasion a rip in the surface of time nor, with any luck, will it trigger a generalized electronic debacle. But the coming of the year 2000 does have the merit of drawing our awareness of history and our expectations for the future into a tighter focus. With that in mind, this page will present over the next few weeks some reflections on what that focus reveals about the human journey through the past millennium and into the new century.

title: Cooking
description: Persephone and pomegranates: what was that story again? Something about the underworld, and the seasons changing because she ate some seeds? You'll want to remember the specifics -- and what to do when garnet-red juice splatters all over the kitchen -- once you begin exploring this season's cookbooks. You'll find history and plenty of recipes, but no stain remover.

title: The Labor Pains Of a Leftist Musical In an Angry Era
description: FOR the thousands who cheered it in the late 1930's, Marc Blitzstein's musical play ''The Cradle Will Rock'' blazed like a comet of hope in the dark Depression skies. The millennium was far away, but Armageddon was now. Germany was rearming, Mussolini had seized Ethiopia, and the Spanish Civil War seemed like a dress rehearsal for a final confrontation between Left and Right. The American economy was again on the slide, and labor strife across the country was taken as the beginnings of class warfare.

title: A Surrealist Composer Comes To the Rescue of Modernism
description: ''NOWADAYS you're eclectic or you're nothing,'' a graduate student at Princeton University said recently when I inquired about the reigning philosophy of composition at that old bastion of utopian purity. Talk about signs of the times! By that new-Princetonian token, Thomas Ades, the English composing phenom (still under 30) is really something, and the records keep coming. The fourth and latest Ades disc from EMI Classics brings ''Asyla,'' the 23-minute symphony-in-all-but-name that has just won its young composer Louisville University's Grawemeyer Award, the biggest plum the classical-music world now offers.

title: To Whom It May Concern
description: Who -- or what -- will open the Times Capsule a thousand years hence? Correct predictions are considered the ultimate test of the hard sciences like physics and chemistry. For those of us in the so-called soft sciences -- like historians, evolutionary biologists and stock-market investors -- our predictions are constantly derailed by independent variables and the impact of unpredictable events like assassinations or asteroid collisions. This observation applies emphatically to the soft science that might be called time-capsule apertology, the science of opening, from the Latin apertus, meaning ''open,'' and the Greek logos, meaning ''thought.''

title: Consumers Beware
description: With the start of the holiday shopping season, the offices of Gov. George E. Pataki and the Westchester Department of Consumer Protection are advising consumers to be wary about mail-order sales, direct purchases, credit card fraud, Internet sales and warranties. The county's consumer protection code requires retail merchants to display signs stating the store's return policy at or near the cash register, said Elaine Price, director for consumer affairs in Westchester. When buying from a catalog, consumers should read the small print, keep the catalogs -- along with copies of advertisements, any filled-out order forms, canceled checks and charge card account records -- until after receiving the item and inspecting it, she said.

title: Nouveaux Riches Learn the Rules
description: SINCE 1984, when he bought Oheka Castle, Gary Melius has met many wealthy Long Islanders who live in grand homes on the legendary Gold Coast.

title: Making Viewers Wonder Why They're Uneasy
description: MARIA MARSHALL is not the first visual artist to use her offspring in her photography-based work. Sally Mann is probably best known as the person who has been there and done that. But if Ms. Mann's documentarylike recording of her children's often-naked adolescence was provocative, Ms. Marshall's work is more jarring. She taunts the viewer with images that are both creepy and often hilarious, while pushing every conceivable moral and psychological button. Ultimately, the work is about adult anxieties.

title: Some Homeless Irked by Plan That Could Separate Families
description: Louis Nelson was once a caseworker for New York City's Department of Juvenile Justice and a construction worker when his strength allowed. But two years ago he became homeless when meeting his rent payments, caring for his family and managing his alcoholism became a treacherous juggling act.

title: Impasse on Trade Delivers A Stinging Blow to Clinton
