title: To the Rescue: Help for Stranded Motorists
description: SRABANI GUHA was just approaching downtown Hartford at Exit 51, heading east, on Interstate 84 when she heard the bang. The left rear tire of her Nissan Maxima had blown out. As she looked for a place to pull over, Ms. Guha, a University of Connecticut graduate student , thought of her meeting before dawn the following morning and wondered if she could make it home on three tires.

title: Sports of The Times; Fordham Adjusts to New Rules
description: IT could never be the proudest moment of a grown man's life, sitting down in the living room with an expectant teenager to make an impassioned speech that is really a plea. But it has become more humbling over the last decade and a half, since Bob Hill helped recruit Danny Manning and a championship team for the University of Kansas. The promises made are more one-sided than ever, the young dribblers agreeing to nothing more than showing up, and that is if the pros don't offer them enough to change their mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, WALTER
description: GREEN-Walter. On November 26, 1999 in Palm Beach, Fl. at age 90. Devoted husband of the late Eileen Green. Lovingly remembered by his daughters, Cornelia Stebel and Lizabeth Conescu, his sister, Florence Radbill, his sonsin-law Michael Stebel and Paul Conescu, his grandsons, Ronald Conescu, Jeremy Conescu and Jacob Stebel, and many nieces and nephews. Those who wish may make contributions in his name to the Lake Worth Public Library, 15 N. M St, Lake Worth, FL. 33460.

title: Environmental Ratings
description: Environmental Advocates, an Albany-based nonprofit group, has released its 1999 ratings of representatives to the State Legislature.

title: BENEFITS
description: Hip-Hop Honors

title: Protesters Sling Muck at Mayor's Picture
description: In a city where the mayor had sued a magazine for making fun of him in bus advertisements and tried to close a public museum for showing a dung-festooned Virgin Mary, it might have seemed foolhardy to throw dung at a picture of the sometimes prickly politician.

title: Luxury Sales Soar
description: Sales of luxury homes in Westchester, Putnam and the southern Dutchess region so far this year have already topped the luxury sale figures for all of 1998.

title: Woolworth in New Jersey: A Love-Hate Relationship
description: Atlantic City's lifeguards bought tanning lotion there. Menlo Park shoppers flocked to the chain's first art show. Customers in Elizabeth bought sheet music after pianists performed requests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANISH, PHIL
description: RANISH-Phil. Beloved husband of Hedy. Devoted father of Abe Ranish and Sara Rabbani. Cherished grandfather of Eric, Ariana, Daniella and Tiffany. Services Sunday, 12:30PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Young America and Abracadabra Need Swift Turnabout
description: With three races down in the third, critical round of the Louis Vuitton Cup series off Auckland, New Zealand -- the winner of which will challenge for the America's Cup -- the time has come for the New York Yacht Club's Young America team and Hawaii's Abracadabra syndicate to make a stand.

title: Greetings From 100 Years Ago
description: Jacob B. Johnson 3rd's father flew in to Newark International Airport for a visit a few months ago and complained that he couldn't find a postcard depicting his native city of Newark. Mr. Johnson, his son, has found some -- as an antiques dealer with a shop in Montclair, he collects Newark memorabilia -- and they are around 100 years old. He has reissued them in a set of 12 ($14.95). The cards depict, among other scenes of Victorian Newark, Hahnes Department Store, the Newark Library, Branch Brook Park Lake and holiday shopping on Broad Street, which is also available on a holiday greeting card ($19.95 for 15, with envelopes). Since he began selling the cards earlier this fall, Mr. Johnson says sales have been surprisingly brisk. ''So many people are Newark natives or their parents were born here,'' he says. ''It's like a postcard from home.'' Newark Postcard Company, (877) 847-8600, fax (973) 481-2210. The cost for shipping each set is $1.65, and there is a 6 percent sales tax for state residents.

title: Exporting a Business Lesson
description: Rene Preval, the president of Haiti, was not quite able to keep his appointment last week to visit Dumas M. Simeus, his former countryman, in Mansfield, Tex. ''He has a country to run,'' Mr. Simeus explained. In two previous meetings, Mr. Preval had sought to learn how Mr. Simeus's example as the founder of Simeus Foods International, the largest black-owned business in the state and 11th largest in the nation, could be applied back home. ''He is consumed by entrepreneurship fires in his belly,'' Mr. Simeus said.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Triad of Festivals

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAMPANATO, PAUL
description: SPAMPANATO-Paul. It is with great sadness that we note the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Mr. Paul Spampanato, manager of the Edson. Paul was a dedicated, loyal and integral part of the Intrepid Museum team. He will be dearly missed. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, the Fishers, and all of our friends, we extend our sincerest condolences to his father, Gary Spampanato, Director of Protocol. Lt. General Martin R. Steele Bill White M. Anthony Fisher and all at the Intrepid

title: Wary Neighbors and a Little Blue Car
description: DAVID VICTORSON bought his single-family frame house off Fordham Road in the Bronx in 1972 for him and his wife. It's impressive, more than 100 years old, big as a barn, with oak door frames topped by carved Corinthian capitals, a winding balustrade, working fireplaces and a Tiffany-style stained-glass window in the foyer. The house on Grand Avenue suggests an earlier time, when the Bronx was still the country, before brick single-family homes and apartment buildings sprang up around it.

title: A Renaissance Man of Metalwork
description: UBALDO VITALI works among gods and goddesses, tritons and angels, mythical creatures and statesmen from all ages. At his workshop here, one can meet the Emperor Vespasian, a dancing Mercury, the goddess Diana, a troop of horses and birdlike shapes formed from the bronze, gold and silver of centerpieces, tea services and tureens.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Murray Hill; A Quiet Enclave Close to Midtown
description: THE Murray Hill neighborhood, an urban enclave just south of Grand Central Terminal and the Midtown office district, is known for its 19th-century brownstones, clean streets and trees -- 505 of them according to community activists. But, say real estate professionals, it is also notably undervalued.

title: Just as Spiritual, It Turns Out, as He Was Cool
description: THIRTY-FOUR years ago, Duke Ellington and his orchestra set up shop at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church the day after Christmas, accompanied by a chorus, four solo singers, a tap dancer and a recording crew, and gave the New York premiere of a group of original compositions collectively billed as ''A Concert of Sacred Music.'' Though the results were uneven, the composer had no doubts. ''This music is the most important thing I've ever done or am ever likely to do,'' he later told a friend.

title: At Threshold of Old Age, Still Caring for Children
description: Maggie Lee, a 60-year-old Harlem resident, spends her days as an aide to an 86-year-old woman who lives in Washington Heights. When she gets home, she looks after four grandchildren and her husband, who had his left leg amputated below the knee because of diabetes.

title: Lawsuits, Politics And the Fate Of Tobacco
description: ARGUABLY, it was the export that made America. On a per-acre basis, it is the nation's most profitable cash crop. And one of its offspring is the world's most heavily taxed consumer product.

title: After Fire, Friends Rally to Aid Musician
description: BEFORE an Oct. 18 fire that nearly destroyed his farmhouse here, David Amram was known as the musician in Jack Kerouac's circle of Beat poets; the composer who collaborated with Leonard Bernstein, Dizzy Gillespie and Charles Mingus on jazz and classical music; the man who wrote the sound track for the films ''Splendor in the Grass'' and ''The Manchurian Candidate''; a pioneer of world music who wore necklaces made of flutes and whistles; a teacher and frequent guest conductor of orchestras like the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the Nashville Symphony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, SALLY
description: RUBENSTEIN-Sally. On December 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Bernard. Devoted mother of Judith Leitner and Lawrence Rubenstein. Loving mother-in-law of Ronnie and the late Saul Leitner. Dear sister. Cherished grandmother of Jill, Kara and David. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, JOHN ALAN, M.D.
description: BLUM-John Alan, M.D.. ''Jack.'' Urologist, educator, father, grandfather and beloved husband, died suddenly November 30, at his home in San Diego. Born in Brooklyn, NY, February 2, 1933, son of Louis and Polly, and brother of Bob. Educated at Dartmouth College, NYU Medical School, Univeristy of Minnesota. Served in the US Navy Medical Corps in Vietnam, retiring as captain. In San Diego he joined urological associates in private practice, but remained active in academics and was a leader in numerous civic and professional groups. He enjoyed sailing, photography, travel and outdoor adventures, especially with his wife and family. He is survived by his devoted wife Debra, his sons Jeff and Fred and daughter Jackie (Fogel). He also had eight grandchildren who will miss their ''Pop Pop.'' Memorial donatons may be made to Planned Parenthood of San Diego, Mercy Hospital Foundation or San Diego Blood Bank.

title: Political Memo; Two G.O.P. Foes Locked in a Sweetness Offensive
description: Only eight weeks before the New Hampshire primary, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain find themselves in a ferocious competition for first place in the polls here. Mr. Bush views Mr. McCain as his only impediment to the Republican presidential nomination. And that is how Mr. McCain views Mr. Bush.

title: Discovering Greatness in Lyndon Johnson
description: Like many Americans, I was deeply opposed to Lyndon Johnson's pursuit of the Vietnam War. My views on the war have not changed, but my opinion of Johnson has. I believe now that with the exceptions of Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt -- and perhaps Theodore Roosevelt -- Lyndon Johnson was the greatest president since Abraham Lincoln.

title: Plant a Living Fence, Grow a Life Preserver
description: EVER since I visited the Rodale Institute Experimental Farm, in Kutztown, Pa., this fall, I have been thinking about wildlife corridors.

title: Cyber-Spaced-Out? Therapy Is $150 an Hour
description: MINDY LEWIS was hyperventilating. After working all morning to finish a project due that afternoon, she had planned to print it out and look at it over lunch. Two hours later, she was still sitting at her computer, her coat half on, her spirit mostly broken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, BEATRICE
description: UNGAR-Beatrice. Beloved wife of Philip. Devoted mother of David. Devoted sister of Gilbert Helman. Esteemed member of East Midwood Jewish Center Sisterhood. Services today 1 PM, at Weinstein West End Funeral Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Shiva will take place today and Monday, 1819 Ave. L, Apt. 1G, Brooklyn. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Want to Be A Quiz Show Host? You're Sure?
description: WAITERS, trying to be cute, say it all the time. So do some E-mail correspondents, who have discovered that it makes a snappy one-line reply. It even came up in a recent press conference at the Justice Department.

title: Beware Winds and Furtive Rodents
description: Erect windbreaks a foot or two away from newly planted or marginally hardy shrubs by attaching burlap to sturdy wood stakes driven into the ground before it freezes hard.

title: What Was War?
description: I know what you'll think when I suggest putting a peace symbol in the Times Capsule: that this is an act of mockery, a way to document the ditzy idealism of the 1960's for a presumably incredulous posterity. You probably expect me to throw in a picture of John and Yoko staging their ''bed-in for peace'' or of Yippies trying to levitate the Pentagon. But in fact I make this nomination in a post-ironic spirit. I think what will amaze people in 3000 A.D. about peace symbols is not their idealism but the fact that they were ever considered idealistic. The end of war between nations is a nearly certain achievement of the next millennium, if not the next century.

title: Saying No to W.T.O.
description: The protests against the World Trade Organization in Seattle last week may seem like a postmodern update of the 1960's. ''Whose streets? Our streets'' was the chant as young demonstrators dared the flak-jacketed police to drag them away. But the antic style of the loose coalition of environmentalists, unionists and others obscures an earlier and more instructive historical parallel: the anticorporate insurgency of the 1890's.

title: An Iguana Came to Breakfast
description: THE moment our boat came into the quiet cove at Guana Island, my every requirement for a tropical vacation was fulfilled. Brown pelicans, the undersides of their wings reflecting the blue iridescence of the Caribbean, were diving just off a powder-white shore. The water was clear and calm; I'd be able to swim along the half-mile beach without risking my life from speed boats pulling parachute water-skiers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ROSE
description: ROSENBERG-Rose., of Sunrise, FL., formerly a resident of Brooklyn, died on November 29, 1999, 93 years young. She leaves behind her brother, Seymour; her daughters, Shelley Lazarus (husband, Herb), Linda Basile (husband, Joseph); her nephews, Gary, Stephen and Ira Rosenthal, whom she loved as sons, and their families. A proud grandmother of eight and great-grandmother of nine. Burial was held on December 2nd. Any donations may be made to City of Hope, Sunrise, Florida.

title: On Language; Tmorras Nglsh
description: Bliss on bem cumendum fiusende geara, Eallum!

title: A Locked-In Vancouver Is Bulging to the East
description: THE direction of growth in the metropolis of Vancouver has been governed by geography. It can't go west because of the Pacific Ocean, or north because of the mountains. It can't go too far south because of the United States boundary. So it has gone eastward, through the broad Fraser River Valley, and now it has reached Chilliwack 65 miles from downtown Vancouver, which is about as far as the growth can go.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNAUER, PHYLLIS
description: GRUNAUER-Phyllis. Of New York, NY, on December 3, 1999. Beloved relative, friend and teacher. Mrs. Grunauer, a lifelong champion of human rights, served in the Human Resources Administration of NYC for many years. Thereafter, she taught at Touro College, where she was the acting head of the Sociology Department until her retirement. Few people have had such a profoundly positive impact on so many. She will be sorely missed by her loving family and all who had the pleasure and honor of knowing her. Memorial services on Sunday at 1PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th. Shiva will be observed on December 6 and 7 from 5-8PM at Mrs. Grunauer's home. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to The Women's International League for Peace and Freedom or The Committee on International Human Rights Inquiry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOVSKY, KERMIT
description: ROSOVSKY-Kermit. On December 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Jay and Barbara Rosovsky, Ann and Neal Beaton, Sandy and Scott Siegel. Adoring grandfather of Adam and Lisa Rosovsky, Brandon Talamini, Justin and Daniel Siegel, Eric, Greg and Andrew Beaton. Greatgrandfather of Jack and Corey Rosovsky. Service Sunday, 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Menorah and a Congregation Stand Tall in Newark
description: On Friday night, Rabbi Samuel Bogomilsky lighted the menorah that stands in front of Mount Sinai Congregation on Mount Vernon Place in Newark. .

title: Gentlemen, and Others, Sometimes Prefer Redheads
description: THE SETTING -- Thirty winners of the Alize Red Passion Operation Red Head contest gathered at the Elizabeth Arden Red Door Salon on Fifth Avenue near 53d Street on Wednesday to find their inner Lucille Ball and have their tresses dyed. Men with names like Samir and Antonio combed through drab blond locks applying dyes that looked like carrot juice while celebrity redheads like Ann Magnuson and Magee Hickey chatted with women whose heads were encased in plastic wrap.

title: Only All-Stars Need Apply as 12th Man
description: With less than a month before USA Basketball announces the three remaining selections for the Olympic men's basketball team, Shaquille O'Neal of the Lakers and Grant Hill of the Pistons seem like shoo-ins. But after those two perennial All-Stars, the competition for the remaining slot should be keen, if not cutthroat.

title: Happy Holiday? Scratch Here
description: THIS holiday season, give the gift that keeps on taking -- a New Jersey Lottery ticket.

title: Hotels Mobbed, But a Bit Less So
description: IF you've tried to book a hotel room in a major American city lately, you may have trouble believing this. The latest figures from the hotel industry, covering the first nine months of this year, show that occupancy rates are still in decline, continuing a trend that began in 1997. In fact, occupancy through September 1999 was down from the same period last year in 17 of the nation's 25 biggest markets, according to Smith Travel Research, the scorekeeper for the United States hotel industry. And industry analysts project falling occupancy for each of the next two years.

title: Plays, Gay and Otherwise
description: ASK Craig Lucas what a gay play is and he is likely to, purposefully, reel off flip definitions: ''A gay play is a play written by a gay playwright.'' Or, ''It sleeps with another play of the same gender.''

title: Laura Mechanic, Anthony Korosi
description: Dr. Laura Jane Mechanic and Dr. Anthony Francis Korosi were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York. Jay Stuart Dankberg, a former judge of Civil Court in Manhattan, officiated.

title: North Toward Home
description: PLACES LEFT UNFINISHED

title: INVESTING WITH: Conrad B. Herrmann; Franklin California Growth Fund
description: CALL it the home-team advantage.

title: Puerto Ricans Gain Ear of Washington But Seek Far More
description: Again and again across the decades, the United States marines have stormed ashore here on Yellow Beach in a full rain of firepower and won the vital mock battleground that has been made of the eastern third of this small, lush island.

title: Designs for the Next Millennium; Designs for the Next Millennium
description: Now I know how Howard Carter felt when he entered the tomb of Tutankhamen. Last May, with a group of other New York Times writers and editors, I walked back and forth through a windowless room deep inside the newspaper's Gothic Revival building on West 43rd Street. No gold glinted, no precious stones sparkled, no sarcophagus exhaled an ancient curse. But here before us were riches of the human mind: 48 entries in a competition to design the Times Capsule.

title: Red Eyes, the Kind You Want
description: Ready to see red? This season, eye makeup is a study in scarlet, with bright lipsticks doubling as the latest eyeshadow trend. Sported by runway models at Chanel's spring show in October, this neon-lidded look has been spotted on young celebrities like Jenna Elfman and Robin Tunney and the singer Christina Aguilera, and can currently be seen in Beauty Cyber-Space, right, Sephora.com's new online beauty magazine. ''The inspiration is 80's glam-punk, all shock and polish,'' said Heidi Lee Crow, the makeup artist who worked on the Beauty Cyber-Space feature and has applied variations of the look on the models James King and Carolyn Murphy, and on the actress Lucy Lawless, among others.

title: Hal F. Rosenbluth
description: Traveling the world with a beaten-up backpack -- bought 15 years ago in a leather shop -- Hal F. Rosenbluth, 47, could be mistaken for a perennial college student. And the jeans and boots he wears in his office could mark him as an urban cowboy. In fact, Mr. Rosenbluth is the chairman of one of the world's biggest travel agencies, the privately held Rosenbluth International, which has headquarters in Philadelphia and offices in 27 countries and in every state but Vermont; it is closing in on revenues of $4 billion this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, ANDREW DOUGHERTY
description: WOLFE-Andrew Dougherty. December 2, 1999 in Pittsford, NY. Founder of Wolfe Publications. He is survived by his wife, Vivienne Tellier Wolfe; children Amy Wentworth Wolfe of North Cohocton, NY; Meg W. (Scott) Lucas of Rochester, NY; Andrew D. (Jaymie) Wolfe Jr. of Wakefield, MA; John S. (Michelle) Wolfe of Chandler, AZ; brother C. Holmes (Susie) Wolfe of Pittsburgh, PA; sister-inlaw Peggy Wolfe of Naples, FL; father and mother-in -law George A. and Margarita Tellier of Fair Lawn, NJ; 13 grandchildren; many neices and nephews. Friends may call Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM at The Anthony Funeral Chapel, 2305 Monroe Ave., Rochester, NY. A funeral Mass will be celebrated Monday 11AM at St. Louis Church, 60 South Main St., Pittsford. Interment at Pittsford Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be directed to a charity of choice.

title: New Home for Science In Downtown Columbus
description: The Center of Science and Industry in Columbus, Ohio, has moved to a new home on the banks of the Scioto River after 35 years on the other side of downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MADELINE
description: KAHN-Madeline. All of us at Kaufman Astoria Studios are deeply saddened by the loss of this wonderful woman who brightened our lives and the stages that she worked on and loved. We will always recall her laughter and grace and remember her fondly. Madeline brought such joy to the world. Everyone who had the opportunity to work with her over the years will remember her with a smile. Kaufman Astoria Studios

title: Rowan Is Now Hoping To Even Another Score
description: To earn a rematch with Mount Union of Ohio, Rowan first had to get past archrival Montclair State today in a quarterfinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament. And that seemed no easy task because Montclair State was playing at home and had handed Rowan its only defeat of the season three weeks ago at Rowan.

title: Heavy Rains Extend Voting in Mozambique
description: Election officials today extended voting until Sunday in presidential and parliamentary elections, saying that torrential rains had prevented some polling places from opening.

title: This Means War
description: RIDING THE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVER, VICTOR ALLAN ''AL''
description: OLIVER-Victor Allan ''Al''. Age 61 of Staten Island, NY, formerly of Edina, Minnesota, passed away unexpectedly on November 23, 1999. Memorials preferred to: Killington Mountain School, Killington, Vermont 05751. (802) 773-3233, Attn: Head Master.

title: A Golden Bounty Reclaimed From the Ocean Floor
description: A GOLD-RUSH treasure, burnished by 130 years in the icy depths of the Atlantic, has finally reached its destination -- New York. Mined, sifted, assayed or minted in California, the three tons of gold bars, ingots, coins and dust was shipped on Aug. 20, 1857 from San Francisco bound for New York, but not even a small portion of it ever made it until a year ago.

title: Manchester Docklands Get Spiffy New Life
description: ASK just about anyone here what he associates most with the paintings of L. S. Lowry and he'll probably talk -- with misty nostalgia or utter relief -- of the passing of the industrial north of England depicted in Lowry's spare cityscapes, where stick-figure people are dwarfed by the smokestacks and viaducts.

title: Doubles Team Recaptures the Magic for Australia
description: As they waved with a mixture of joy and relief at the Australian tennis fans in the upper reaches of the Palais des Expositions today, Mark Woodforde asked Todd Woodbridge, ''How exciting is this?''

title: A Closed-Door Policy For a Beloved Space
description: Tenants in an apartment complex on Irwin Avenue say that despite a letter from Attorney General Eliot Spitzer to their landlord last month insisting that they be allowed into the buildings' community room, it remains under lock and key.

title: Word for Word/Protest Studies; Skywriting, Collective Disappearance And Other Ways to Up the Revolution
description: HEY-HEY! Ho-ho! L.B.J. has got to go!'' The classic syncopated chant from the antiwar movement of the late 1960's was borrowed by protesters who took to the streets of Seattle last week during the meeting of the World Trade Organization. But the words were tweaked to fit the multisyllabic objects of a broad new range of outrages, including corporate globalization, automatic teller machine fees, environmental imperialism, coffee-bar gentrification, genetically modified food, endangered turtles, logging, shrimp farming, aggressive landlords and unemployment among Hollywood studio workers.

title: Let It Shine
description: BASILICO is worth a visit for the atmosphere alone: it is both calming and vibrant. Walls painted brick red alternate with real brick expanses. Pale wood French doors along the front of the building suggest order through symmetry. A large table for eight is nestled next to an arched bar, a sort of private dining room in public. Sconces have shades resembling garlic and onions, and seasonal images are projected on the largest wall: pumpkins and snowflakes at this time of year, basil leaves in the spring and summer.

title: Eh? Faithful to Dickens? No Cartoons or Caricatures?
description: ''Isn't it extraordinary,'' mused Patrick Stewart, who stars in the new TNT production of ''A Christmas Carol,'' ''that a slim volume written 150 years ago should have found such a mark in the 20th century?''

title: Lucile Petry Leone, 97, Recruiter of Nurses During World War II
description: Lucile Petry Leone, the founding director of the United States Cadet Nurse Corps, which recruited more than 100,000 young women to study nursing and helped spare the country of the need to draft nurses in World War II, died on Nov. 25 at an assisted-living center in San Francisco. She was 97.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 28 about the effects of a volcanic eruption in Quito misstated the name of the volcano and misidentified the country. The volcano is Pichincha, not Pichingua. And Quito is in Ecuador, not Peru.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; Just Like Mom Used to Make, and Still Does
description: Proust had his madeleine. For Joseph Zecchino, it's his mother's stuffed artichokes. Mr. Zecchino, 30, offers the dish (still cooked by his mother) on Fridays at Nicolo's. His father, Nicholas, a baker, opened this kitchen-size shop on the Glen Ridge border in 1967, and brought in Joseph and his brother, Nicholas, when they were old enough to count change.

title: Heyns Jumps Back Into Pool In the Right Frame of Mind
description: In a Los Angeles swimming pool in July, Penny Heyns decided to dash all expectations. She was 25 years old, an Olympic champion and a hero in her native South Africa. She was also one of the most reluctant swimming stars in the world.

title: Who Are We? Not That
description: For all the qualities sited in Mr. McEnroe's essay, this Connecticut yank thought it sorely lacking. Sensible shoes, schmensible shoes. Ours is a state of loafers with toppings, fruit boots, and bare feet. No romantics? How about Miss Zelinkawicz, my third grade teacher! No yelling? Angela Davis made it an art form. This well-traveled dotted-line connection between New York and Boston is a petri dish spotted with more ideals than Fafner has (or had) bearings. Ours is a colony of primal discontinuity, a smokin' regional undergird. Anything but understated.

title: Gore on Education Vouchers
description: This 30-second commercial is the sixth from Vice President Al Gore. It discusses education vouchers and is being broadcast in New Hampshire and is expected to run for about a week.

title: The Sound and Feel Of Jazzy Urban Bustle
description: ''I live on C-sharp Street, and my friend lives on B-flat Avenue.'' These are the first words the audience heard in the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's latest premiere on Friday night at City Center. The title of the work, ''C-sharp Street-B-flat Avenue,'' refers to the previous line from ''I Live in Music,'' a poem by Ntozake Shange.

title: Cleaner New York Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Misguided Relief to Sudan
description: For reasons of history, geopolitics and rampant criminality, Sudan has been at war for most of this century. The latest phase of fighting between the Arab and Muslim north and the long-subjugated black African south is in its 16th year. Two million Sudanese have died in what may be the world's worst sustained humanitarian catastrophe since World War II. Now the Clinton administration is edging toward deeper engagement in this conflict as it debates sending food aid to rebels in southern Sudan. This is likely to prolong the war, ally Washington with one of Sudan's pre-eminent war criminals and enlist America in the conflict's most pernicious tactic -- the use of food as a weapon of war.

description: How much media do children actually digest?

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Actor Speaks, and Listens, to Cabbies in Forum on Bias
description: The actor Danny Glover, whose discrimination complaint against a taxi driver last month spurred a city crackdown on cabbies, said after a public forum last night that any driver who fears black people ''perhaps needs to get another job.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANRAHAN, THOMAS, SISTER, RSHM
description: HANRAHAN - Thomas, Sister, RSHM 92, on December 4, in Tarrytown, NY. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 71 years. Educator at: St. Thomas Aquinas School, Bronx; Sacred Heart of Mary Schools: Bronx, Manhattan, Sag Harbor, NY, Rolling Meadows, IL; Marymount School, Umtali, Rhodesia (now Mutare, Zimbabwe); Mother Butler High School, Bronx. Served at Archdiocese of New York Office of Education and Alumnae Office of Marymount Manhattan College. Survived by a niece, Maureen Woods of Bayside, NY, and a nephew, William Hanrahan, of Bronxville, NY. Visiting Tuesday, December 7, Marymount Convent, 32 Warren Avenue, Tarrytown, 3-7:30 PM. Vigil service, 7:30 PM. Mass at Marymount Convent, Wednesday, December 8, at 10:30 AM. Gifts in her name may be made to the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, 50 Wilson Park Drive, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

title: Citing Asthma Worry, Green Asks for Less-Polluting Buses
description: Public Advocate Mark Green said yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority could help reduce asthma attacks if it bought buses powered with natural gas instead of diesel fuel, but a transit official dismissed the plan as impractical.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Women in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Colts Finish Off Dolphins
description: Dolphins fans tried their best to rattle Mike Vanderjagt of the Indianapolis Colts as he practiced on the Pro Player Stadium sideline for his last-second field goal today. They yelled insults and made choking motions. Vanderjagt, however, simply soaked in the scene.

title: Metro Matters
description: WHEN we in the news media complain about government secrecy, we get the general impression that the public is less than empathetic. It's more a ''there, there'' reaction -- placating parent to foot-stomping child.

title: Opera's Heavenly Duo Live Earthly Lives
description: Ben Heppner and Jane Eaglen, the new dynamic duo of Wagner opera, are spending a lot time together these days. They are currently singing the daunting title roles in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' conducted by James Levine. title: Against All Odds, Montgomery and the Giants Find a Way to Run

They unwind in diners with demographically correct cross-sections of American voters, laying out proposals for lifting the tax burden on middle-class families. They stride purposefully with their wives, chatter meaningfully with well-wishers and, oh, yes, kiss and fuss over any child they come across.

title: Mockery of Bush an Attempt To Be Funny, Forbes Says
description: Steve Forbes, who last week mocked Gov. George W. Bush's answers to questions on past drug use, backed down somewhat today, calling his own remarks an unsuccessful attempt at humor.

title: Bangkok Opens Skytrain, but Will It Ease Car Traffic?

title: New Projects Should Rise After 2000

Computer companies and the consulting firms that advise them have been particularly interested in asking their customers for information about how much Year 2000 has affected investment and when the floodgates will open for new projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIVIC, NORMAN

He fought in World War II in the China-Burma area with the Flying Tigers. He was founder and President of Ruth Norman Designs with his wife, Ruth, a fashion designer. Norman is survived by Ruth, his wife of 43 years; his daughters, Dr. Diane Civic of Seattle, WA, and Melanie Civic, Attorney in Washington, DC and also by a sister, Mimi Kerpen of NYC and Southampton. Memorial Services will be held at Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, NY on Thursday, December 9, 1999, at 12 PM. For directions call (516) 487-0900.

The moves are the latest step in the nation's march to hold students to higher educational standards and to hold their parents to higher standards of accountability.

A team that had squeezed out points by the drop for most of the season suddenly gushed 41 points against the Jets. A team that walked the ball up the court was suddenly running fast breaks, executing slam-dunks and riveting alley-oops. A plodding offense with neither weight nor spark turned into a blue streak: the Giants were up by 17 points in the first quarter, 20 by the half.

So, he turned over the responsibilities to his offensive coaching staff and told his quarterbacks coach, Sean Payton, that he would be responsible for calling the plays.

title: The Opposition In Mozambique Finds Fault With Elections

title: Rose Bird, Once California's Chief Justice, Is Dead at 63
description: Rose E. Bird, who became the first woman on California's Supreme Court and whose resolute opposition to the death penalty later led voters to remove her as chief justice, died of complications from breast cancer on Saturday at a hospital near her home in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 63.

title: Dissident's Imprisonment Widens Political Gap in Iran

title: E-Commerce; For the employer, the procrastinator and, of course, the merchant: online holiday gift certificates.
description: TO some, gift certificates represent a cop-out on the part of gift givers -- a way to foist the shopping responsibility onto the recipient. To others, they are the ideal gift -- subsidized shopping that spares others the guilt and drudgery of returning something they hate.

For thirty years we had the honor and privilege of serving him, his family, Republic National Bank of New York and its affiliates. An extraordinarily brilliant and successful person in world commerce, we came to know him as a gentleman and a righteous and upright person. We extend our heartfelt condolences and affection to his wife, Lily; her children and grandchildren, whom he embraced as his own; his brothers, Joseph and Moise; his sisters, Arlette, Gaby and Huguette; and his nephews and nieces. We also extend a personal condolence to each and every member of the Republic family here and around the world whose lives he touched and who we know will miss him dearly.

title: Ten Arrested at Rally Against Crackdown on Homeless
description: Saying they wanted to test the mayor's pledge that homeless people would not be arrested merely for being homeless, 10 people, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, were arrested last night after they spread tents and tarps and sat down on a wet concrete patch of City Hall Park.

title: SEMTECH ACQUIRES USAR, COMPUTER COMPONENT MAKER
description: The Semtech Corporation, a maker of analog and mixed-signal semiconductors, said it had bought the closely held USAR Systems Inc. for about $27 million in stock to add to its business in portable computers. Semtech exchanged 495,000 shares of common stock for all outstanding shares of USAR, which is based in New York. USAR makes embedded devices for notebook and hand-held computers.

title: Sprawl Quickens Its Attack On Forests
description: Despite some progress in conservation, the nation's privately held cropland, forests, soil and wetlands continue to give way to development and erosion, the United States Department of Agriculture is reporting today.

title: Kroger Earnings Rise 23%
description: The Kroger Company, the largest United States supermarket operator, said fiscal third-quarter profit rose 23 percent as sales of store-brand goods increased and acquisitions helped it negotiate lower prices from suppliers. Profit from operations rose to $202 million, or 24 cents a share, from $164 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the quarter ended Nov. 6 fell 10 percent, to $10.3 billion from $11.5 billion. Kroger bought Fred Meyer Inc. in May for $13.5 billion.

title: Of Sons and Mothers in Gritty Surroundings
description: Acting as an art of gentle persuasion, as opposed to one of forcible coercion, is being lovingly demonstrated by the five-member cast of ''Shyster,'' Bryan Goluboff's drama at the Blue Heron Theater.

title: For a Night, At Least, The Nets Are Unstoppable
description: For one night, the Nets finally got it right. They did not self-destruct when victory was at hand. They did not let an early 10-0 deficit doom them for 48 minutes. And when tonight's game was over, the Nets looked at the final score and liked what they saw.

title: Doctors Try a Bold Move Against Schizophrenia
description: By the time most psychiatrists encounter schizophrenia, its symptoms are already in full flower. But scientists have long surmised that the illness starts much earlier, the demons beginning to nibble at the edges of young people's lives well before the most flagrant psychosis appears.

title: The Topography of an Earthquake
description: On Oct.16, a 7.1-magnitude earthquake shook a remote, sparsely populated part of the Mojave Desert, rupturing the surface for 25 miles along the Lavic Lake fault. Using a technique called synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, satellite radars can measure ground movement with stunning precision. Images taken from the European Space Agency's ERS-2 satellite before and after the earthquake show complex patterns of displacements near the fault, which were as much as 17 feet.

title: Majority Stake Sold In Atlanta Agency

title: Pushing Nixon's Restricted Limits

American and Chinese dignitaries had their own walkways and microphones, on the left and right respectively (if not altogether appropriately). Soloists and chorus had some semblance of costume, and the stage was dressed excitingly in red.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERBATOW, PRINCESS KATHLEEN COLE MCLOUGHLIN
description: SCHERBATOW-Princess Kathleen Cole McLoughlin. Princess Scherbatow died unexpectedly on Sunday, 5 December, 1999 at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. Born in Briarcliff, NY on 18 September, 1914, she was the daughter of Gregory Van Zandt McLoughlin, a decendant of Peter Stuyvesant. Her great-grandfather, Cornelius Cole, was the first U.S. Senator from the state of California. An accomplished and wellregarded artist in her younger days, she originally became interested in painting while attending the Bishop School of La Jolla, CA, later perfecting her craft in drawings and oils at the Oldfield School of Baltimore, MD. She was mostly involved in the charitable interests of The Russian Nobility Association in America. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, 8 December, 1999 at 10:00 AM at the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 93rd St. and Park Av., NY. Memorial service will be held at 7:00 PM on Tuesday, 7 December, 1999 at the Cathedral. Burial will be private. By the time you divide one of these tiny units into a thousand minuscule micrometers, you have far exceeded the limits of the finest bifocals.

title: A Stimulating Trip Uptown Without Taking the A Train
description: Harlem -- its history and its personalities, its buildings and its neighborhoods -- is on vibrant display in ''A Walk Through Harlem.'' If you don't mind the occasional burst of effusiveness, tonight's guide, the architecture historian Barry Lewis, makes as informed a companion as anyone could wish. He is assisted by David Hartman, who helps to keep the conversation moving along with the camera, and by an array of Harlemites with stories to tell.

title: The Courtship Of City Officials
description: A state inquiry into Philip Morris's lobbying expenditures in Albany and internal company documents have shown that numerous state lawmakers have accepted gifts from the company. The internal documents are not limited to Albany, though. They show that many New York City officials have been similarly courted.

title: TYSON SAYS ITS DEAL WITH SMITHFIELD HAS FALLEN THROUGH
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the biggest United States poultry processor, said yesterday that its plans to sell its pork business to Smithfield Foods Inc. were scuttled after the two companies were unable to reach a final agreement. Tyson, based in Springdale, Ark., said in September that it would sell its money-losing Pork Group to Smithfield, the nation's largest hog producer, for about $79.3 million in stock. Negotiations ended because the unit ''did not fit'' Smithfield's expectations, Tyson said. Tyson shares fell 12.5 cents, to $17.1875. Shares of Smithfield, based in Smithfield, Va., rose 25 cents, to $25.3125.

title: Ford Announces Its Withdrawal From Global Climate Coalition
description: In a concession to environmentalists, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would pull out of the Global Climate Coalition, a group of big manufacturers and oil and mining companies that lobbies against restrictions on emissions of gases linked to global warming.

title: Anne Francine, 82, Actress and Cabaret Singer
description: Anne Francine, an actress who worked in film, theater and television and who was also a prominent cabaret performer for six decades, died on Friday at the Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in London, Conn. She was 82 and lived in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: A Clinton Order Seeks to Reduce Medical Errors
description: President Clinton will order federal agencies that provide or finance health care to take steps to reduce medical errors blamed for tens of thousands of deaths, administration officials said today.

title: Genes Tell New Story On the Spread of Man
description: Two genetic surveys of human populations bring new evidence to bear on a pivotal event in prehistory, the first dispersal of modern humans from Africa.

title: Panel Advises Adding to Life Expectancies
description: The Social Security Administration is not being optimistic enough about how long Americans will live in the 21st century, and as a result it has underestimated how much their benefits will cost, a federal advisory panel said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, JAMES H.
description: MAYER-James H., 85, husband of the late Dorothy (Lee) Mayer, died at his residence early Sunday morning following a long illness. Born in Manhattan, New York, he was the son of the late Theodore and Rose (Kurzman) Mayer. James attended the University of Miami in Ohio for 2 years and then returned to New York. He entered the United States Army and served during W.W. II. Mr. Mayer was the founder and Executive Vice President of Roxanne Swimsuits in New York City until his retirement in 1974. He and his wife retired to Sarasota, Florida where they resided for 20 years. Mr. Mayer came to Ipswich, MA. five years ago & has lived in Wenham, MA. for the past 3 years. Surviving him are two daughters and sonsin-law; Ellen Lee and Donald Mammato of Clinton, NJ, Robin Lee and W. Kevin Fitzgerald of Hamilton, MA, one brother; Monroe Mayer of Greenville, SC, three grandchildren; Stephanie Mammato of Boston, Jennifer Mammato of NewJersey, Meaghan Fitzgerald of Hamilton, MA, and several nieces and nephews. Funeral services were held on Monday morning at the Campbell Funeral Home, 525 Cabot Street, Beverly, MA. Memorial donations may be made to the Dale Shields Pelican Man's Bird Sanctuary, Longboat Key, Sarasota, Florida 33500.

title: A Different Way to Gauge Carpal Tunnel
description: Two weeks ago, federal officials said the Clinton administration might soon issue sweeping new rules for the workplace that could help protect millions of Americans from repetitive strain injuries, often associated with the heavy use of computers. Under the new rules, employers with even a few cases of R.S.I. will be required to carry out full-scale ergonomic programs.

title: Miranda Endangered
description: The police hated the Supreme Court's Miranda ruling when it was first handed down in 1966. The decision, which requires that arresting officers advise criminal suspects of certain rights when they are taken into custody, was so vilified that Congress passed a statute two years later that tried to nullify Miranda in the federal courts and substitute a more general test of whether a suspect's statement has been given voluntarily.

title: CITADEL COMMUNICATIONS BUYS 11 RADIO STATIONS
description: The Citadel Communications Corporation, the largest American radio broadcaster in midsize markets, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 11 radio stations in Michigan and Massachusetts in two separate transactions for $145 million. Citadel will pay $120.5 million in cash and stock for nine Michigan radio stations from the closely held Liggett Broadcast Inc., exchanging 200,000 of its shares, valued at $10.1 million, and the remainder in cash. It will pay $24.5 million to the closely held Montachusett Broadcasting Inc. for two Massachusetts stations. Citadel, based in Las Vegas, has been expanding in regions like New England to better compete with rivals like Infinity Broadcasting and Clear Channel Communications. Citadel shares fell 93.75 cents, to $49.8125.

title: Doctors Urge Polio Shots To Replace Oral Vaccine
description: The oral polio vaccine, used routinely in the United States since the 1960's, should be replaced by old-fashioned polio shots, the American Academy of Pediatrics said in a statement issued yesterday.

title: San Francisco Faces an Outcry
description: Perhaps no city offers a more public example of the problems of homelessness than San Francisco. The biggest complaint visitors lodge about the city concerns aggressive panhandling and other manifestations of homelessness, city tourist officials say. The No. 1 problem in the city, according to a recent poll by The San Francisco Chronicle, is homelessness.

title: 'Indigent Mexican' Lent Name to Rights
description: Miranda v. Arizona, announced by the Supreme Court on June 13, 1966, was the name for a decision that resolved four separate criminal appeals, all raising the same question of what the Fifth Amendment's right against compelled self-incrimination meant in the context of an interrogation by the police of a suspect in custody.

title: BRAZILIAN AUTO SALES FALL
description: Automobile sales in Brazil fell 6.1 percent to a nine-month low in November, pulled lower by high financing rates and the expiration of an accord providing tax breaks on new car purchases. Nonetheless, November's sales climbed 15 percent when compared with November 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREE, ADELE (MALLAN)
description: FREE-Adele (Mallan), a long time resident of Bronxville, NY., died peacefully on Sunday, December 5, 1999 in Bloomfield, CT at the age of 96. She was born in Washington, D.C. on January 16, 1903 to Dr. Thomas Francis Mallan and Mrs. Marie Adele Blaine Mallan. Adele grew up in Washington, D.C., and attended George Washington University where she was a member of the Pi Beta Phi sorority. On May 9, 1927 she married Walter Henry Free of Davenport, Iowa. The majority of her married life was spent in Bronxville, NY, where she and Walter, a New York patent lawyer, were active members of the community, the Bronxville Field Club and Siwanoy Country Club. Adele was a communicant of St. Joseph's Church. In addition, she was a volunteer with the Bronxville Junior League, Lawrence Hospital and the Girl Scouts. For 22 years following Walter's death in 1965, Adele remained in Bronxville. In 1988 she moved to McAuley Retirement Community in West Hartford, CT, and in 1996 to Scabury Retirement Community in Bloomfield, CT. Adele is survived by her three daughters, Adele Blaine Free and her husband Joseph Booze of Baltimore, MD; Patricia Free O'Connor and her husband Richard of West Hartford, CT; and Blaine Free Foltz of Tustin, CA; ten grandchildren, and ten greatgrandchildren. Funeral services will be held Tuesday (December 7) at 10:00 am in the Church of St. Peter Claver, 47 Pleasant St., in West Hartford, CT. There will be no calling hours prior to the funeral service. Adele will be buried with her husband Walter in Bronxville, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to Catholic Charities/Catholic Family Services, 467 Bloomfield Ave. Bloomfield, CT 06002. Information: The Molloy Funeral Home West Hartford.

title: BEA SYSTEMS SAYS IXL ENTERPRISES WILL USE ITS SOFTWARE

BEA Systems climbed $9.25, to $124.50, on the Nasdaq in heavy trading. The shares had gained 19 percent on Friday on speculation that the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., would announce a possible venture. BEA makes software that helps companies like Amazon.com handle thousands of simultaneous orders and manage invoices and database records. BEA Systems is the largest maker of middleware, which is software linking older corporate computer systems with new Internet technology. Shares of iXL, which is in Atlanta, rose $1, to $38.75.

description: U.S. Bancorp, Minnesota's largest bank, warned yesterday that its profit for the fourth quarter and next year would not meet expectations. The stock fell as much as 28 percent. The bank, which is based in Minneapolis, said fourth-quarter earnings would be 52 to 54 cents a share, shy of the average analyst estimate of 59 cents. The Bank of England is to meet later this week to discuss interest rates, which have helped push the pound to record highs against the euro. With 58 percent of British exports going to the 11-nation euro zone, a strong pound makes exports less competitive, putting pressure on the central bank to avoid a further increase in interest rates.

description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company, the world's second-largest reinsurer, will buy Underwriters Re Group Inc. of the United States for $725 million, doubling its revenue from underwriting property and casualty insurers in the American market, the world's largest. Swiss Re will buy Underwriters Re, based in Calabasas, Calif., from the Alleghany Corporation for cash. Last year, Underwriters Re had premiums of $549 million and assets of $1.7 billion. Alleghany, which is based in New York and has interests ranging from insurance to importing steel fasteners, is increasingly focusing on money management.

The purchase will add a new distribution area for Concord, based in Memphis, which is a provider of electronic transaction authorization to supermarket chains, convenience stores and other retailers and runs the MAC automated teller network. Penney Company said yesterday that it had cut its dividend by almost half so that it can reinvest more in its struggling department stores and prepare for the effect of a new tracking stock for its Eckerd drugstore chain. The retailer said a quarterly dividend of 28.75 cents a share would be payable Feb. 1. The previous dividend was 54.5 cents a share. J. C. Penney, the worst performer this year in Standard & Poor's index of department-store stocks, said it wanted to keep more cash on hand to improve its department stores, and to expand its drugstore chain and its Internet business.

title: Miranda Revisited
description: The Supreme Court agreed yesterday to hear a challenge to one of the most famous decisions of Chief Justice Earl Warren's era -- the landmark 1966 ruling in Miranda v. Arizona that requires police to advise suspects of their rights before beginning an interrogation. The oral argument in the case, to take place sometime next spring, is likely to produce high drama. But as a matter of constitutional law and sound law enforcement procedure, this should not be a difficult decision. The intervening years have powerfully reinforced the essential fairness and workability of the Miranda rule, which says that criminal suspects must be told of their right to have a lawyer present and to remain silent, and that any statement they make can be used against them.

title: NATWEST REJECTS OFFER
description: National Westminster Bank, the target in Britain's largest banking takeover battle, said it rejected hostile offers from Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland. during meetings with their boards. NatWest said its senior managers had met with directors from Bank of Scotland on Friday and with Royal Bank directors on Nov. 28. The NatWest chairman, Sir David Rowland, says shareholders will get the most value out of NatWest's remaining independent.

title: Senator McCain's Health

So Mr. McCain's decision to release 1,500 pages of medical records about his physical and mental health -- along with a volley of self-deprecating jokes about his temper -- has the look of a tactical coup. It also marks the start of the nation's quadrennial discussion about how much the public is entitled to know about a candidate's personal history.

title: Mars, Still Ours to Conquer

Barring some stroke of remarkable luck in establishing contact, we may never know what went wrong on the Mars Polar Lander. This was the mission that we hoped would tell us something about one of the great unanswered questions of science: Could there be, has there been, is there, life on our neighboring planet?

title: A Positive Trend in Foster Care

title: The Powerful Idea of Human Rights
description: A great flowering of the ideal of universal human rights has taken place in the last 50 years, a blink of time in a millennium. It is among the most important political legacies of this century. Despite the persistence of state-sponsored repression and genocidal conflict, the belief that individuals have a claim to basic rights and dignities is being embraced by ordinary citizens on every continent. Freedom of speech and assembly, freedom from slavery, torture and arbitrary arrest, and the right to equality under the law as common values are still quite new in many parts of the world. But leaders who violate these principles now face international exposure, sanctions and even outside intervention, as Slobodan Milosevic discovered this year.

title: ROWECOM TO BUY NEWSEDGE FOR $227 MILLION IN STOCK
description: RoweCom Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the NewsEdge Corporation for $227 million in stock in a deal that will allow RoweCom to combine its electronic catalog of business articles with NewsEdge's current news stories. RoweCom will get NewsEdge's 1,000 corporate clients and more than 650,000 other users. In the transaction, NewsEdge stockholders will exchange each of their shares for 0.26 RoweCom shares. The exchange values each NewsEdge share at $13.025. The shares of RoweCom, based in Cambridge, Mass., rose 25 cents, to $50.375, in Nasdaq trading. NewsEdge, which is in Burlington, Mass., slipped 18.75 cents a share, to $12.625.

title: E.D.S. TO SELL COMPUTER SERVICES UNIT TO WILLIS STEIN

The two companies have not agreed on a sale price, an E.D.S. spokeswoman said. The E.D.S. unit, which had $142 million in sales last year, provides computer services to about 500 small independent banks. After the sale, the division will be based in Dallas and operate as an independent company. E.D.S. shares fell $3.25 each, to $66.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading. The announcement was made after the close of United States markets.

The job cuts from IMC's 8,800 workers account for about half of the $70 million, or 40 cents a share, IMC expects to save annually. IMC, based in Northbrook, Ill., which had $2.7 billion in 1998 sales, warned last month that it would take a big fourth-quarter charge.

title: Panoramic Passions On a Playbill From the 30's

And as the film watches the painter shape his crowded sociopolitical cosmos, populating his canvas with starkly symbolic figures engaged in moral struggle, Mr. Robbins works in much the same way himself. Set in 1936, ''Cradle Will Rock'' is his own sweeping cinematic mural, with both the overarching vision and two-dimensionality that implies. It's a big, brave, sometimes maddeningly reductive film that rises through sheer talent and enthusiasm over its own limitations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHON, JACKSON BARRETT
description: MAHON-Jackson Barrett, DFC, WWII Ace, Errol Flynn's Manager, Producer, December 4, 1999 in Las Vegas. Jackson Barrett (Barry) Mahon born Santa Barbara, California, 1921. In 1941 he joined the Royal Air Force and began flying Spitfires in combat with Eagle Squadron 121. After 98 strategic missions he was reported missing in action following a raid over Northern France just after being credited with his ninth downed plane. The British Air Ministry awarded him the Distinguished Flying Cross, not knowing his whereabouts. The citation declared him to be ''An extremely skillful and confident pilot, whose courage, especially when attacking superior numbers of hostile aircraft has been unsurpassed''. At Stalag Luft III, Mahon worked on the tunnels made famous by the movie, ''The Great Escape'', starring Steve McQueen whose role was based on Mahon's experiences. He escaped before that breakout, and was captured on the Czech border when his feet became too sore to go on. He escaped again only to be recaptured. Mahon was finally liberated by Patton's 3rd Army in 1945. After the war, Mahon became the personal pilot, and later manager of movie star Errol Flynn producing a number of Flynn and Gina Lollabrigida pictures, as well as a considerable output of children's programs. Mahon established ''The Production Machine'', a production company making motion pictures for theatrical and television release. Mahon was the first movie producer to adapt and apply computer technology to the breakdown, scheduling, budgeting and financial analysis of featurelength motion pictures as well as television movies. Jackson Mahon is survived by his wife, Clelle Ann McAllister of Henderson, NV; four children, Doris Keating Schlesinger (Barry) of Los Angeles, CA and Henderson, NV; Chandos (Teri) of Chatsworth, CA, Sharon Scheur (Lawrence) of Williamsville, NY and Summerlin, NV and Barrett (Kathryn) of Agoura Hills, CA, and 6 grandchildren. A memorial service will be a the convenience of the family in Cathey's Valley, California. Information by Desert Memorial Cremation Society, North Las Vegas, Nevada.
