title: The Owner of the Bucs Wanted to Sell His Team to Buy the Jets
description: In a strange twist to the nearly completed process of selling the Jets, the owner of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers last month attempted to engineer the sale of his own team in order to make a run at buying the Jets, three people involved in, or familiar with the proposed transaction, said this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMER, MAX J.
description: ZIMMER-Max J. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our senior Trustee and Benefactor Max J. Zimmer, a visionary in the building of our day school. He headed the three generations of Zimmer family members connected with our congregation. To his devoted wife, Georgia; children, Joel and Karen, and Anita; grandchildren, Gary and Jill; and the entire family our deepest sympathy. Service today at Park East Synagogue, 163 E. 67 St., 9:30 AM. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: High Fashion At New Address

title: Productivity Grew Sharply In 3rd Quarter
description: Worker productivity grew at a faster pace in the third quarter than originally estimated and labor costs fell for the first time in more than two years, government figures released today showed.

title: Hasbro to Cut 20% of Its Jobs and Take $97 Million Charge
description: The toymaker Hasbro Inc. said yesterday that it was eliminating 2,200 jobs, or more than 20 percent of its work force, and taking a restructuring charge of $97 million, or 50 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1999.

title: An Unlikely Organizer as Cabdrivers Unite
description: IT has been a long time since there was a face to go with the taxi drivers when they had a gripe, and now, more and more, the face belongs to a 27-year-old woman named Bhairavi Desai, an organizer for the New York Taxi Workers' Alliance. She has never driven a cab, but unlike most of the people she represents, she has had the benefits of a college education in this country.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The whole world counts down to midnight. Who counts down to sunrise? If anything, most people are in bed with a hangover by the time the sun comes up.''

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Couple and Son Tied to Rape And Kidnapping of Girl, 12
description: A Bronx couple and their teenage son were arrested yesterday and charged in the kidnapping and rape of a 12-year-old girl who the authorities said was held against her will for more than a year.

title: Big Changes Are Planned In Zoning Law
description: The Giuliani administration is to submit the city's most sweeping revision of its zoning laws in 40 years to the City Planning Commission and the City Council today. If approved, the new rules will impose the first broad limits on the height of new buildings in New York City.

title: Moving Fast on Patient Safety
description: The Institute of Medicine reported last week that between about 50,000 and 100,000 patients die in hospitals each year because of medical mistakes. President Clinton responded yesterday by embracing the report and ordering his administration to take immediate action. For Washington, that is a remarkably rapid turnabout.

title: The Safras of Brazil: Banking, Faith and Security
description: When the Safra family built a mansion resembling the palaces of Roman nobles in this city's opulent Morumbi neighborhood, Joseph Safra, the younger brother of the late financier Edmond J. Safra, acknowledged that the structure was ''out of context'' for a relatively poor country like Brazil.

title: A Millennial Free-for-All: Who's on First?
description: The first sunrise of the new millennium will be a cold and lonely moment as the midnight sun dips below the horizon near Dibble Glacier in Antarctica and then, a few minutes later, creeps up again.

title: City Ballet Musicians Accept Contract, and Play
description: Musicians at the New York City Ballet have voted overwhelmingly to accept a new three-year contract and end a two-week strike.

title: Chief of Amgen Plans to Retire
description: Gordon M. Binder, the chief executive of Amgen Inc., will retire after the company's annual shareholders' meeting in May and be replaced by Kevin W. Sharer, the president and chief operating officer, the company announced today.

title: Crux of 2nd Trial in Killings of Pizza Deliverymen Is Suspect's Intent
description: The murder trial of the second suspect in the ambush and slaying of two pizza deliverymen in April 1997 has begun here in rural northwestern New Jersey, with opposing lawyers clashing over whether the suspect's actions satisfy the state's legal criteria for a murder conviction.

title: The Problem With Forgiving Pete Rose
description: Sometimes I think Pete Rose will be with me until I die.

title: Critics Invade Agency Office To Denounce Drug Policy
description: Angered by city policies that would cut welfare benefits to recipients who fail drug tests, 20 protesters stormed the Manhattan headquarters of the city Human Resources Administration yesterday morning and chained themselves to desks and chairs until the police arrived to arrest them.

title: TV NOTES
description: The World On Nickelodeon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETCHAM, PLATT VANDEWATER
description: KETCHAM-Platt Vandewater, 89, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, and most recently of Charlotte, NC, died on Dec. 6, 1999, in Charlotte. He was employed for many years at the law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst, of New York City. He is survived by two daughters, Deborah Abels, and son-in-law Wedge Abels of Charlotte, NC, and Nancy Lagmarsino and son-in-law John Lagomarsino of Emerson, NJ; and by three grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made to The Good Shepherd Lutheran Church, General Memorial Fund, 7420 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11209.

title: The Many Faces of Zinfandel
description: ZINFANDEL is America's own wine, which is remarkably liberating for American winemakers. For once, they don't have to respond to critics who might otherwise compare their pinot noirs and cabernet sauvignons with Burgundies and Bordeaux. The grape is turned into wine only in the United States, hence the attitude, ''We can do anything we want with it.''

title: MINISTER DONATES PENSION
description: Moving to quiet critics and defuse a potential scandal, Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria Trevino of Mexico, said he was donating to charity his pension from Nacional Financiera S.A., the national development bank, where he was formerly director general. Opposition legislators have said that Mr. Gurria's pension, about $75,500 a year, is illegal because he had not served the required 20 years at the bank. Julia Preston

title: Decision Nears on the Fate Of Ex-Los Alamos Scientist
description: The Federal authorities have intensified their deliberations about whether to prosecute a nuclear weapons scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory on charges of mishandling highly classified atomic data, government officials said today.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: JAZZ
description: Ellington in Memory

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on Sunday with an article about some Jets players and their tenuous future with the team misidentified the player shown alongside Steve Atwater. He was Victor Green, not Eric Green.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors Settle For $2.8 Billion In a Fraud Suit
description: Cendant, the big franchiser that operates Ramada Inn hotels and Avis car rental agencies, agreed yesterday to pay its stockholders $2.8 billion to settle accusations of widespread accounting fraud. The settlement is by far the largest ever in a securities class-action suit.

title: New Pressure on Gun Makers
description: The Clinton administration yesterday threatened a lawsuit against gun manufacturers on behalf of the three million people who live in public housing projects long plagued by gun violence. The threat followed last week's ruling by an Illinois state judge that an innovative private lawsuit against gun manufacturers could proceed, despite heavy industry pressure to kill it.

title: To Stop Petty Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Poverty War: Still No Terms Of Surrender
description: THE term ''poverty industry'' did not sit well with City Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins at a hearing on homelessness last Friday. After the term was used by Jason A. Turner, the commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, she angrily said, ''I was not aware that poverty was an industry.''

title: All Sweetness, No Stress: A Cookie Solution
description: THE urge to bake vast quantities of cookies in as short a time as possible feels like a thoroughly modern phenomenon at the holidays. But the tradition dates from way before the home stove, let alone the microwave, to a time when stress had a whole other meaning.

title: Six Summer Employees Charged In Thefts at Mystic Tourist Sites
description: After a four-month investigation, the police have charged six summer employees of the Mystic Aquarium and the Mystic Seaport with stealing at least $60,000 in ticket sales.

title: INVESTIGATOR SAYS TEACHERS IN CITY AIDED IN CHEATING
description: School investigators charged yesterday that dozens of teachers and two principals across New York City's public school system had given students the answers on the standardized reading and mathematics tests that help determine how schools are ranked and whether students move on to the next grade.

title: Boxer Remembered at Service As Questions on Fitness Arise
description: Ira Johnson stood yesterday in the dingy ring at Gleason's Gym where her son Stephan had trained his heart out for his last fight, a bout that led to his death Sunday. She talked about her son's lifelong fascination with boxing, how she had begged him for years to quit.

title: Experts Warn of Mars on the Cheap
description: A string of embarrassing mistakes that doomed the $125 million Mars Climate Orbiter in September may have helped pave the way for the disappearance of the $165 million Mars Polar Lander this week, NASA officials and private experts said yesterday.

title: Three Face Drug Charges After Kitchen Explosion
description: Two men have been arraigned on drug possession charges after investigators at a kitchen fire in Queens last month found that the men had been using flammable liquids to extract morphine from their coffee grounds as part of the process of making heroin.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the New Jersey section on Sunday about the introduction of the E-ZPass toll collection system on the Garden State Parkway misstated the telephone number for enrolling. It is (888) 288-6865.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, DATUS C., JR.
description: SMITH-Datus C., Jr. Died in Princeton, New Jersey, on November 17, 1999 at the age of 92. He played a leading role in the development of American scholarly publishing, and in the promotion of book publishing in the Third World. During his later years, he was also active in international work, particularly with The J.D.R. 3rd Fund, The Asia Society, and The U.S. Committee For UNICEF. His publications include Land and People of Indonesia, and Guide To Book Publishing, each of which has been translated into seven or eight languages. His memory will be cherished by his daughters, Sandra Smith Opdycke, and Karen Houston Smith, his son-in-law, Leo Opdycke, three granddaughters, and one great granddaughter.

title: Socialist Runs in Chile, Disclaiming Radicalism
description: In a country still emerging from a quarter of a century of revolution and counterrevolution, the presidential campaign of Ricardo Lagos flies the red Socialist Party flag and is infused with the memories of revolutionary dreams dashed by the military coup of 1973.

title: NASA Vows Stiff Rethinking Of Mars Exploration Program
description: In the aftermath of the failed $165 million Mars Polar Lander mission, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today promised a thorough investigation of its causes and implications and a ''major rethinking'' of the strategy for the entire Mars exploration program.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REMSON, BELOVED AL
description: REMSON-Beloved Al Your love of life and knowledge was insatiable. We had so much fun. Thank you. All my love forever and always. Alvern

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVE, SAM
description: LEVE-Sam. Scenic designer on December 6, 1999. Survived by his daughter, Teri Leve, his sister, Lottie Weiss, nieces, nephews, friends and the many magical moments he created for the theatre. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to a Jewish school, an Art school or the Yale Drama School. Services are on Wednesday at 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: RAID AT APPLE JAPAN
description: The Japanese Federal Trade Commission swooped into various offices of Apple Japan Inc., the Japanese unit of Apple Computer. The raid was part of an investigation into charges that Apple had refused to allow retailers to sell its popular iMac and iBook computers at prices lower than those it set. Fixed prices are allowed for newspapers and magazines under Japanese law, but not for items like computers. Stephanie Strom

title: New Arms Inspection Plan Could End Sanctions Against Iraq
description: A new arms inspection plan that could lead to the suspension of nine years of sanctions against Iraq sometime next year may go to the Security Council for debate on Wednesday, Western diplomats said today. British and American envoys, augmented by State Department officials, spent today trying to build a consensus that would avoid a Russian veto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANSON, ROBERT A.
description: SWANSON-Robert A. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering note with sadness the death of Robert A. Swanson, our friend and colleague. Mr. Swanson joined the Board of Overseers of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in March of 1998. His potential to contribute to the mission of Memorial Sloan-Kettering will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Swanson family. Laurance S. Rockefeller, Honorary Co-Chairman James D. Robinson III, Honorary Co-Chairman Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman H. Virgil Sherrill, Vice Chairman Richard L. Gelb, Vice Chairman Paul A. Marks, M.D., President, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Here's One by Berlioz: It's Rare and Has Punch
description: In terms of length and variety, James Levine's visit to Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon with his Met Orchestra was less like a conventional concert than a visit to an avid record collector's house to hear his latest acquisitions. Rather than the two-hour concert that is the norm for orchestral performances, Mr. Levine and his players held the stage for nearly three hours, offering a program with a free-form quality that made each piece seem as if it were prefaced with an unspoken ''Hey, have you heard this one?''

title: Suspect in Banker's Killing Had a Yen for the Finer Things
description: There are signs that Ted Maher had a yen for the finer things in life, even here on a dirt road in this Dutchess County hamlet. The house that Mr. Maher had built, for his wife and three children, was grand by local standards, a sprawling Cape Cod with stone pillars out front and a gargoyle guarding the main entrance.

title: HEXCEL STUDIES OPTIONS FOR AEROSPACE COMPONENTS UNIT
description: The Hexcel Corporation, the No. 1 United States maker of aerospace materials, said yesterday that it had retained an adviser to explore alternatives for its aircraft structures and interiors unit, including a possible sale. Hexcel, based in Stamford, Conn., hired Credit Suisse First Boston to consider options. Hexcel acquired the Engineered Products unit as part of its 1996 purchase of the composites business of Ciba-Geigy. It makes interior components for commercial and military aircraft, including a stowage-bin expansion kit to bolster carry-on luggage capacity. The shares in Hexcel, which had 1998 sales of $1.09 billion, have fallen about 35 percent in the last year. They slipped 6.25 cents yesterday, to $5.50.

title: Indictment in the Disappearance Of Atheist O'Hair and Her Kin
description: A federal grand jury here indicted a Michigan man today on kidnapping, extortion and robbery charges in the 1995 disappearance of the atheist leader Madalyn Murray O'Hair and two of her relatives.

title: Animated, Revealing African Folk Tale
description: In an animated film that has been a runaway hit in France, a tiny boy demands to be born, only to crawl out of his mother's womb and find his African village terrorized by a witch. Inspired by a blend of West African fables, ''Kirikou and the Sorceress'' shows how the innocence and perseverance of the boy, Kirikou, help him prevail over ignorance and cruelty.

title: De La Hoya Opponent a Mystery
description: Representatives for the former World Boxing Council welterweight champion Oscar De La Hoya met with officials at Madison Square Garden to put the finishing touches on a Feb. 26 fight here in New York. A news conference announcing the fight will take place next Tuesday in New York.

title: Putting Zing In the Olives
description: ABOUT 20 miles from where I spend many summer weekends, in a remote part of Vermont known as the Northeast Kingdom, there is a tiny strip mall on the outskirts of the town of Newport. I never paid the least attention to it. Then local people suggested that even a foodie from New York City might do well to try Abbie Lane, the restaurant right next door to the health club there.

title: A Footnote Who Endured To Be a Fixture; Rival to Lindsay in '69 Is Set For 24th Senate Campaign
description: It has been 30 years since the election that placed State Senator John J. Marchi forever as a footnote in New York City's political history.

title: Treasury Prices Rise a 3rd Day as Inflation Fears Ease
description: Bond yields fell for the third consecutive day yesterday after government reports showed a rise in productivity and a drop in labor costs, easing concern about inflation.

title: Commercial Real Estate; For Unusual Tower, It's All About Signs
description: The newest addition to the Times Square neighborhood is a 300-foot-tall steel supporting column for the illuminated signs characteristic of the area, with a 550-room hotel added almost as an afterthought.

title: For the Buccaneers' King, a Monday Night to Remember
description: They call him the Smoothie King. Kid Cool. When last seen early this morning, Shaun King was clutching the game ball and running jubilantly toward the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' locker room to thunderous applause.

title: Russia Reacts Angrily Over Western Criticism on Chechnya
description: Russian officials reacted angrily today to Western condemnation of their military tactics in Chechnya, warning that threats to impose sanctions or interrupt aid are unacceptable.

title: Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, 68, A Former Airline Executive
description: Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, president of the American Geographical Society and a former airline executive, died of lung cancer on Monday at Stamford Hospital in Stamford, Conn., his daughter Anne Calder said. He was 68 and lived in Stamford.

title: Gauging 'Isms' in Prisms Of Historical Hindsight
description: REFLECTIONS ON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, RAE KATZ
description: TOBIN-Rae Katz. Age 85, died on Monday, Nov. 29, 1999. The light in Rae's eyes shone with intelligence, love, good humor and wit. With heart and mind, she nurtured her family, fought for a better world and nursed her husband Mike through his terrible battle with Alzheimer's. She left the world a better place. We'll miss this warm and wonderful woman. Rae is survived by her sister Norma Katz Menter, her son Daniel, her daughter and son-in-law Susan and John Schoonover and grandchildren Carl, Danny and Julie. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERN, SAUL
description: ALPERN-Saul, 95. Beloved husband of the late Sara Alpern. Loving father of Joan (Robert) Roman, & Ruth (Bernard) Madoff. Cherished grandfather of Diane Hochman, Debra Brown, Laurie Ekstrom, Mark Madoff and Andrew Madoff. Great grandfather of eleven. Brother of Paul Alpern. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Brandeis University, P.O. Box 9110, MS 126, Waltham, Massachusetts 02454.

title: Foreign Affairs; Senseless in Seattle II
description: Now that the Seattle World Trade Organization summit meeting is over, we can ask: Was it a turning point, or just an exclamation point? That depends entirely on how the protesters and governments interpret Seattle. Here is my own guide:

title: No Holiday Respite For Some U.S. Players
description: WORLD JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIPS

title: Seattle Police Chief Resigns in Aftermath of Protests
description: Amid continuing criticism over the police department's handling of the protests last week in Seattle that eclipsed the World Trade Organization meeting here, the city's police chief announced today that he would resign.

title: Tipsy Falstaff (Who Better?) Toasts a New Covent Garden
description: Its housewarmings completed, its 30-month renovation almost so, the Royal Opera House opened for business here on Monday night with a new production of Verdi's ''Falstaff.'' Put behind it, or so the company hopes, are years of financial turmoil, questionable management and a creaky if endearing physical plant.

title: Judge Sides With Billionaire on Child Support
description: In yet another chapter in the long-running case of Anonymous v. Anonymous -- the not-so-anonymous child-support case involving the billionaire financier Ronald Perelman and his former wife Patricia Duff -- a judge ruled yesterday that he would have to pay her $12,825 a month to raise their 4-year-old daughter, Caleigh.

title: Justices Weigh States' Rights vs. Treaty Rules
description: Adding a foreign policy component to its exploration of federal-state relations, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether states can set safety and environmental standards for ships entering their harbors that are stricter than federal regulations or international agreements the United States has signed.

title: HOUSING AGENCIES TO SUE GUN MAKERS
description: In a move to force the firearms industry to adopt safer ways of making and selling weapons, the federal government said today that housing authorities around the country were planning to file a class-action lawsuit against gun makers.

title: FUEL VENTURE STAKE SOLD
description: The world's third-biggest publicly traded oil company, BP Amoco P.L.C., will acquire the Exxon Mobil Corporation's 30 percent stake in a European fuels joint venture for about $1.5 billion. The two will also dissolve a separate lubricants joint venture; BP Amoco will get 49 percent of the business while Exxon Mobil will get 51 percent. The move is intended to placate European Union regulators, allowing Exxon to win approval for its merger with Mobil.

title: Clinton's Words to Press: On the Mideast, Chechnya and Other Matters
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today in the Dean Acheson Auditorium at the State Department, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Police Charge A Surgeon Murdered Wife in '85
description: Fourteen years ago, Gail Katz-Bierenbaum stormed out of her Upper East Side apartment after an argument with her husband and never returned. At least that is what police documents show her husband, Robert Bierenbaum, said at the time.

title: Test-Cheating Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Honors Nun for Aiding Refugees
description: Monday was a whirlwind day for Sister Jean Marshall, a Dominican nun from the Bronx. She flew to Washington, had lunch at the State Department, then went to the White House to receive the Eleanor Roosevelt Human Rights Award from President Clinton.

title: Raiding Set-Dressers' Bag of Tricks
description: Santa Monica, traditionally short on nightclubs, now has Club Sugar, designed by the young firm of John Friedman Alice Kimm Architects. The designers combined colored lights (right, in the bar) and translucent materials with raw timber, brick and concrete. Stainless steel curtains, honeycomb plastic and polycarbonate sheeting are among the materials that create an effect as diaphanous as silk stockings. Among the revelations of the project, Ms. Kimm said, were the ''warehouses full of materials'' available to the entertainment industry in Los Angeles. Club Sugar is at 814 Broadway (Lincoln Boulevard) in Santa Monica (310-899-1989).

title: DAEWOO DEBT LOSSES
description: The South Korean government decided to impose a loss ratio of 80 percent on noncollateralized foreign debts held by the Daewoo Corporation, the flagship unit of the ailing Daewoo Group, while setting the ratio at 66 percent for those of Daewoo Electronics. The ratios were higher than had been expected. The South Korean government earlier considered losses of 75 percent for the Daewoo Corporation and 50 percent for other major business units, including Daewoo Electronics. Meanwhile, the planned sale of the electronics unit to Walid Alomar & Associates. collapsed, and Daewoo Electronics will be looking for other potential buyers. Samuel Len

title: HOME DEPOT TO EXPAND SALES OF LARGE APPLIANCES
description: Home Depot Inc., the largest United States retailer of home-improvement supplies, said yesterday that it would start selling large appliances like refrigerators and dishwaters at most of its United States stores next year. It will sell only appliances made by the Whirlpool Corporation and the General Electric Company, according to its chief administrative officer, Ronald M. Brill. The Atlanta-based retailer now sells such appliances in 38 markets, covering about 15 percent of its United States stores. Home Depot's largest rival, the Lowe's Companies, already sells appliances. Home Depot has more than 900 stores.

title: Legal Squabbles in Path of Internet
description: ONE of the recurring dreams of technology utopians is the idea of the celestial jukebox. It's a metaphor for the Web of the future in which individual terminals will have access to great digital warehouses in the sky packed with petabits of digitally stored CD's, books, television shows and any other copyrighted information or entertainment imaginable -- all for micropayments too small to pinch the wallet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYRO, JORDAN
description: MAYRO-Jordan. Born November 30, 1929 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, died December 7, 1999. Many friends and cousins mourn his passing. He called friend Elaine Berger his ''sister.'' Jerry's Burlington Bookshop on Madison Avenue near the Metropolitan Museum was a book lover's haven. Jerry was that rare human being that people instinctively liked. He was a compassionate man with a big heart. He enjoyed good conversation. Chesterton said ''there is a great deal of difference between an eager man who wants to read a book and the tired man who wants a book to read.'' Jerry knew the difference. Interment will be private in Philadelphia Friday, December 10, 1999. A Memorial service in New York City for friends and family will be held at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York City, on Friday December 17, 1999 at 4PM. Donations may be made to your favorite charity. Friends & Cousins

title: New Jersey Inmate Charged With Murder of Policeman in 1958
description: Forty-one years after Officer Charles Bernoskie of the Rahway, N.J., police was fatally shot while interrupting the burglary of a car dealership, prosecutors said the assailant is a man now serving a 98-year prison sentence for the murder of a teenage girl.

title: A Better Life in the New Century?
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark City Council Defies Court Order to Reassess Property
description: The City Council today defied a state court order that it begin a long-delayed recalculation of property values, risking a possible contempt of court citation in order to put off a move that would most likely mean staggering tax increases for many property owners.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Two Toddlers Die In Fire in Harlem
description: Two toddlers were killed late Tuesday when a mattress caught fire in their Harlem apartment and the flames engulfed their bedroom, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Miranda Ruling Impedes Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: British Boxer Next for Tyson
description: Everything appears set for Mike Tyson to fight Julius Francis at MEN Arena in Manchester, England, on Jan. 29. It will be Tyson's first bout in England and his first in a foreign country since he lost the undisputed heavyweight title to Buster Douglas in Tokyo in 1990.

title: FINOVA TO BUY FREMONT'S COMMERCIAL LENDING UNIT
description: Finova Group said yesterday that it would buy the Fremont Financial Corporation, the commercial lending unit of the Fremont General Corporation, for $765 million in cash to increase its financing of smaller businesses. Finova will also refinance and assume existing Fremont debt. Fremont Financial, based in Santa Monica, Calif., has a $750 million portfolio composed of loans averaging $2 million to $4 million each. Finova, based in Phoenix, has $12.5 billion in total managed assets.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF GATEWAY TO STEP ASIDE
description: Gateway Inc., the direct seller of personal computers, said yesterday that its chief executive, Theodore W. Waitt, who founded the company in his father's barn, was stepping aside and would be replaced by the president, Jeffrey Weitzen, on Jan. 1. Mr. Waitt, 36, will remain chairman of the company, based in San Diego. Mr. Weitzen, 43, a former AT&T executive who joined Gateway in January 1998, will remain president. Under Mr. Weitzen, Gateway made a series of moves to increase revenue and profit. He focused on selling storage systems and software instead of just low-profit PC's and orchestrated an $800 million investment from America Online. The company's shares have more than doubled this year.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Dec. 1 about an Egyptian man who spent three years in detention while the United States government sought to deport him misstated his comments after his release. The Egyptian, Nasser K. Ahmed, said he hoped to use his freedom to rebuild an Islamic community formerly associated with a Brooklyn mosque, Abu Bakr, which he said was active in human rights causes and which the government described as a haven for the terrorists who attacked the World Trade Center. He did not say he would revive the mosque itself, which has declined in size and become less politically active since his arrest.

title: Convicted Republican Seeks Deal in 2nd Case
description: Five days after being convicted of conspiracy and extortion, John Powell, a former Suffolk County Republican leader, was back in court today, trying to avoid a second trial on charges of helping to run a truck theft ring.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about photo editing software referred incorrectly to the abilities of one program, PhotoGenetics, because its producer, Q-Research provided an incomplete version. A review of the full program appears today on Page 3 of Circuits.

title: H.I.V.-Infected Boy, 12, Held in Sex Attacks
description: A Coney Island boy who is infected with H.I.V. sexually assaulted at least two children in his neighborhood, the police charged last night. His youngest victim was a 3-year-old boy, the police said.

title: Two Steps Forward in the Mideast
description: The pace of Mideast peacemaking quickened this week, improving the chances that Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel can meet his ambitious goal of negotiating agreements with the Palestinians and Syria within the next year. On Monday Mr. Barak wisely removed a major obstacle to progress with the Palestinians by temporarily freezing most new construction in Jewish settlements in the West Bank. Then, yesterday, President Clinton announced that direct peace talks between Israel and Syria would resume in Washington next week, picking up where they broke off in 1996.

title: Furor Over Homeless Plan
description: The mayor's policy has given ammunition to critics who call him mean-spirited and has put his Senate campaign on the defensive.

title: New Law Touches Off Suits Over Names in Cyberspace
description: It has been less than two weeks since President Clinton signed a new law banning ''cybersquatting,'' -- registering trademark names as Internet addresses in the hope of selling them at huge profits. But trademark holders around the country are already filing lawsuits to win the rights to names they consider their property.

title: French Find Cigarette Maker Partly Liable in Cancer Death
description: In a ruling that could open a European front in the war against tobacco companies, a French court ruled today that Seita, maker of the Gauloise and Gitane brands of cigarettes, was partly responsible for the death of a three-pack-a-day smoker from lung cancer and cancer of the tongue.

title: The ABC's of CD's: Read-Only, Recordable and Rewritable
description: A CD-ROM is read-only, which means the data are stamped permanently into the disc, and additional data cannot be written onto it.

title: Light to Make Walls Dance
description: WALLS are vast natural canvases, and sometimes ordinary paint and wallpaper just won't do.

title: Get Navy Out of Vieques
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Dealers Charged in Sale of Bass From Polluted Waters
description: Thousands of pounds of striped bass illegally caught in polluted waters have passed through wholesalers at the Fulton Fish Market to ''prominent and elegant'' Manhattan restaurants and private clubs in recent years, federal authorities said yesterday after filing criminal charges against five fish dealers involved in the trade.

title: On New DVD Formats, the Sound of Good Things to Come
description: THESE are confusing times for anyone stepping into the world of consumer electronics. The established order of things is being shaken on every front. There is MP3, HDTV, digital cable and satellite television.

title: What Becomes a Green Thumb Most
description: EVERY year I try mightily to suggest truly original gifts for the garden, and every year I end up recommending the classic stuff, because the cute, trendy things, like red rubber clogs or that little plastic bird feeder with the suction cup that sticks to the window do not hold up when real life crashes through the holidays like an overweight bluejay.

title: New Looks For Icons
description: Q. How can I convert the icons on my computer desktop to ones I want instead of the regular Windows 98 ones?

title: ADELPHIA TO BUY CABLEVISION'S CLEVELAND ASSETS
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the Cablevision Systems Corporation's cable systems in the Cleveland metropolitan area for $1.53 billion in cash and stock. Adelphia, the sixth-largest United States cable operator, will pay $990 million in cash and $540 million in stock. The acquisition increases Adelphia's total subscriber base to more than 5.3 million customers. Adelphia's other operations include the Empire Sports television network and commercial telephone networks in Cleveland; Pittsburgh; Erie, Pa., and Buffalo. Shares of Adelphia, based in Coudersport, Pa., slipped $1.8125, to $56.8125, and shares of Cablevision, which is based in Bethpage, N.Y., were up $2.5625, to $78.1875.

title: Janis and Jimi Come Back, From the Attic
description: EVEN though the music world long ago shifted to the digital compact disc, people of a certain groovy generation -- you know who you are -- still find it hard to part with their large collections of long-playing vinyl phonograph records.

title: RealNetworks Plans Venture
description: RealNetworks Inc. plans to announce a partnership with WebGlide today to market, develop and distribute a technology that enables high-quality streaming of ''synthetic'' video even over dial-up modem connections. RealNetworks said it planned to integrate WebGlide with its own technology for delivering video over the Internet.

title: 500 WORKERS TO BE DISMISSED AS AGCO CLOSES 2 FACTORIES
description: The AGCO Corporation, the third-largest United States farm-equipment maker, said yesterday that it would dismiss about 500 workers, or 5 percent of its work force, as it closes two factories because of reduced demand for tractors and other agricultural implements. The company, which makes Allis and Massey Ferguson tractors, said the closings in Coldwater, Ohio, and Lockney, Tex., would result in fourth-quarter charges totaling $25 million to $30 million and an additional charge of $5 million to $10 million next year. The closings will save $10 million to $15 million a year starting in 2000, the company said.

title: Old Gear Receives a Second Life
description: It is that time of year when new equipment begins showing up on winter slopes. But what happens to all the old gear: the snowboards with last year's nicks, the skis that look like narrow lumber next to the new curved shapes and the poles so heavy they feel like hammers?

title: General Motors Is Using Buicks to Make Inroads in China
description: When the chairman of General Motors, John F. Smith Jr., drove the first Buick off an assembly line here a year ago -- after fumbling to find the emergency brake -- it looked like an omen of another American company's hapless foray into China.

title: Nathan Jacobson Dies at 89; A Leader in Abstract Algebra
description: Dr. Nathan Jacobson, a renowned mathematician who developed fundamental theorems and concepts and wrote many widely used textbooks, died on Sunday at his home in Hamden, Conn., near New Haven. He was 89.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
description: Bidding to stay on top of the fast-changing optical communications market, the Nortel Networks Corporation is nearing a deal to acquire the Qtera Corporation for $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion in stock, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Mystery, Spunk and Sass In Echoes From the Past
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's current season at City Center celebrates Judith Jamison's decade as the troupe's artistic director, an anniversary embodied on Tuesday night in a program devoted to her choreography.

title: Trapped by War and Politics In a Cheerless Chechen Town
description: The brutish war in Chechnya is alternately portrayed as Russian troops' trying to put down ''terrorists'' or freedom-loving Islamic rebels' seeking to throw off Russian domination. But there are no heroes in Znamenskoye.

title: Scandal's 3 R's: Read, Right, Wrong; Cheating on Scores Cheated the Children, Parents Say
description: Valerie Wright, 37, of the South Bronx said she began to suspect that her sons' school was encouraging cheating two years ago when her older boy came home one day and said his practice test was a lot like the citywide reading exam.

title: Using Every Trick in Fighting Sweatshops
description: YOU know you are in the presence of a certain kind of labor advocate when he begins to talk about the effective use of nuns as weapons.

title: Definitively Correct Behavior, Available in Encyclopedic Detail
description: JUST in time for holiday entertaining, Emily Post's ''Etiquette'' has been published on the Internet.

title: Final Bids Have Been Submitted for Sale of Jets
description: Final bids to acquire the Jets were submitted yesterday to Goldman, Sachs, but the investment banking firm for the Leon Hess estate did not release the names of the potential buyers or their offers. Eric Grubman, a managing director at Goldman, Sachs, confirmed the deadline for the bids and said, ''It's very competitive.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULWEILER, PATRICIA PLATT
description: FULWEILER-Patricia Platt. The Huguenot Society of America records with great sadness the death of Mrs. Spencer B. Fulweiler, Registrar of the Society and a member since 1982. Courtney A. Haff, President

title: Guilty Plea Is Expected In Virus Case
description: A New Jersey computer programmer will plead guilty today to having unleashed a computer virus in March that disabled thousands of corporate e-mail systems, several people close to federal and state prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Pearl Harbor Truly a Sneak Attack, Papers Show
description: Freshly discovered diplomatic papers published here this week seem to overturn standard versions of the events leading up to Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor, which have been told with little disagreement over the essential facts in history books on both sides of the Pacific.

title: Vallone Moves Close To Bid for Mayoralty
description: The City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, all but declared his candidacy for mayor last night, telling 1,000 guests at a fund-raiser that New York needs to elect an experienced leader when most of the city's elected officials will be swept from office by term limits in 2001.

title: EToys Edges Toysrus.com In Ranking of Online Users
description: The holiday battle to be the leading toy store in cyberspace shifted last week as eToys, the Internet start-up, pulled ahead of Toysrus.com, the Web site of the big toy chain, according to the research company Media Metrix.

title: Mets Face Repair Job After Loss Of Olerud
description: One day after John Olerud went home to Seattle and left the Mets with a huge hole in their lineup and in their renowned infield, Steve Phillips began searching for ways to minimize the loss. Before the general manager made his first phone call yesterday, he was already facing a monumental task.

title: INSIDE
description: Gene Therapy Study Faulted

title: TRANSCANADA ASSET SALE
description: Abandoning an expansion effort, TransCanada PipeLines of Calgary, Alberta, plans to sell noncore assets worth 3 billion Canadian dollars, or about $2 billion; cut its dividend by 30 percent; and focus on developing its pipeline systems for shipping Alberta natural gas to customers in the north-central United States and eastern Canada. The restructuring will result in a fourth-quarter charge of 700 million Canadian dollars, or $476 million. Assets to be sold include a division that operates an oil pipeline. Timothy Pritchard

title: Armstead and Strahan Ailing, With Flutie Up Next
description: Thirty minutes into this morning's practice, linebacker Jessie Armstead walked off the field with a swollen right knee. He was joined in the locker room by defensive end Michael Strahan, who is hobbled by the effects of a cyst in the back of his left knee.

title: Emanating Attitude, Even Sitting on the Floor
description: A new variant on the floor cushion? This one is a large (34 inches long, 14 inches wide) rocking bean that can be stacked for storage or scattered around for guests. In orange, yellow, pink, red, gray and blue, the Slug cushion was designed by Monika Kowalska, a clothing designer. These upturned ovals upholstered in wool felt are $350 each from A Detacher, 262 Mott Street in Manhattan (near Houston Street; 212-625-3380), and $455 at the new Kbond clothing store in Los Angeles, 7257 Beverly Boulevard (323-939-8866).

title: The Club, Not Goring, Is Given a Warning
description: After reviewing Islanders Coach Butch Goring's angry comments about the officiating Tuesday night in Washington, the National Hockey League decided yesterday against taking any official action against him. The team, however, did receive a warning.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 19 about ''living wage'' ordinances, which raise pay for low-wage workers and grant them benefits, misstated the purpose of money raised by the Chamber of Commerce in Santa Monica, Calif., to fight a proposed ordinance. The money is going to a general campaign, not to support candidates in next year's City Council election.

title: Hockey Player, 15, Is Charged After Seriously Injuring a Rival
description: Prosecutors have charged a 15-year-old youth league hockey player with aggravated battery, saying he slammed an opponent into the boards with his stick seconds after a game ended, leaving the player partly paralyzed.

title: Tonga Is Set to Go Online To Stake Its Millennium Claims
description: While there is some debate about which piece of inhabited land will be the first to greet the new millennium, the Pacific islands that make up the Kingdom of Tonga seem to have a reasonable claim to the honor. At the stroke of midnight in Tonga on New Year's Eve it will still be 5 a.m. Eastern Standard Time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIALA, SUSAN
description: FIALA-Susan. Friends and colleagues mourn the loss of our fellow Director and honored Master Teacher. We will dearly miss her wise counsel, and faithful service. Alden Prouty, Chair Rippowam Cisqua School Alumni Association

title: Memphis Jury Sees Conspiracy in Martin Luther King's Killing
description: A jury in a civil suit brought by the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. decided today that a retired Memphis cafe owner was part of a conspiracy in the 1968 killing of Dr. King.

title: Killer's Trial Shows Gay Soldier's Anguish
description: The graphic story of the harassment and bludgeon slaying of an Army private who feared expulsion from the service for being homosexual emerged here today at a court-martial that gay rights proponents say lays bare the grave flaws in the military's ''don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue'' policy.

title: When Antiques Follow Function
description: THE old wallpaper roller, inherited from my father, was the first tool I treasured. Its wooden handle was worn, and when I wrapped my hand around it, it was as comforting as a wooden shift knob on a '66 Camaro. Besides its patinated handle, it had a curved head of orange Bakelite, which was gentle in delicate corners -- it didn't rip the paper the way the new hard and heartless plastic ones do.

title: Communications Executive Resigns From MCI Worldcom
description: MCI Worldcom Inc. said today that the president and chief executive of its largest unit, the communications group, would leave on Feb. 28 in the third resignation by an executive of the former MCI Communications Corporation since it was acquired by Worldcom last year.

title: Nets Win Two Straight For First Time This Fall
description: With just over seven minutes left in tonight's game, the Nets' Stephon Marbury drove the ball along the left side of the baseline and challenged three Milwaukee Bucks to stop him. The players went airborne and Marbury, the shortest of the bunch, flew underneath the rim while cradling the ball. As the defenders began to descend, Marbury released a reverse layup that bounced off the backboard and then through the hoop for a dazzling basket.

title: Russia and Belarus Agree To Join in a Confederation
description: Crowning years of negotiations and, many say, calculated delay -- Russia and Belarus agreed in principle today to form an economic and political confederation modeled roughly after the European Union.

title: Metro Matters; An Assembly Of Substance, Not Celebrity
description: ROSIE. The Donald. Charlton Heston. The mayor on Letterman. Jesse the Body on ''Larry King Live.''

title: FORSTMANN LITTLE TO INVEST $850 MILLION IN NEXTLINK
description: The buyout firm Forstmann Little & Company agreed yesterday to invest $850 million in Nextlink Communications Inc., a broadband communications company, in return for an 8 percent stake. Nicholas C. Forstmann, a general partner at Forstmann Little in New York, said Nextlink had attractive telecommunications assets, including an intercity, fiber optic network under construction that would be used to bring high-speed Internet access to many of the top 30 markets in the United States. Forstmann Little will buy Nextlink preferred shares that can be converted into Nextlink common shares for $63.25 a share. Nextlink, based in Bellevue, Wash., gained $6.9375, to $62.75.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Bank of Scotland raises ante in hostile bid for NatWest.
description: THE Bank of Scotland showed some fancy footwork but failed to score a knockout yesterday in its attempt to take control of National Westminster Bank.

description: To the Editor:

title: Texan Who Took Overdose Is Executed
description: With several high-profile death penalty cases in Texas in coming weeks, the execution of a convicted murderer, David Martin Long, was not expected to generate much fanfare. He had been scheduled to die by lethal injection this evening, making him the 32nd person executed in Texas this year.

title: P.S. Send Nicer E-Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: It's California or Bust, It Seems in '00 Campaign
description: Call it the fire wall, the big state where Al Gore and George W. Bush must stop any serious challenge to their presumptive nominations for president.

title: Quintessential, comic, chrome-bright.
description: 1. A plastic corkscrew from Japan, which looks like a futuristic animation figure, is $45 at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street).

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about President Clinton's meeting with leaders of the health industry to discuss accountability for medical mistakes misidentified the man at the right of Mr. Clinton. He was William C. Richardson, who headed a committee that produced a recent report on such errors, not Richard Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association.

title: Work-for-Shelter Requirement Is Delayed by New York Judges
description: A state court yesterday temporarily halted the Giuliani administration's plan to make homeless families work for shelter, saying a measure that would put children in foster care if their parents failed to meet that and other welfare rules was frightening.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I was young, people admired and were even jealous of fat people, since they thought they had a better life. Some older people still think pudgy is O.K. and fat is cute. But now, most of us see a fat person and think, 'He looks awful.' ''

title: Dell Computer Founder Sells Some Shares
description: The founder of Dell Computer, Michael S. Dell, sold 5.7 million shares last month, raising about $231.8 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Sugar's Ship Is Not Sinkin': Richardson Finds an Ending
description: MICHEAL RAY RICHARDSON's voice sounded light and upbeat. The indomitable Sugar sounded happy as he spoke of life after the N.B.A. in Europe. You could hear his 3-year-old daughter, Kimberly, and Richardson's wife, Ilham, in the background. At 44, life is good.

title: Pit's Filled, Tape's Gone: The 'Nutcracker' of Yore
description: Heartwarming sounds brightened the New York State Theater on Tuesday night. Shortly before the performance of ''The Nutcracker'' began, a solo oboe played a sustained A in the orchestra pit. Then came the bustle of other musicians tuning up. A brief silence followed. But as Hugo Fiorato, the evening's conductor, entered the pit, many members of the audience burst into cheers. They did so again during the final curtain calls when, after taking a bow on stage, Mr. Fiorato gestured for the musicians to rise.

title: Plans Are Set For New Agency
description: The former top executive of CommonHealth, a health care communications agency in Parsippany, N.J., owned by the WPP Group, is joining forces with a private equity investment firm to start a health care communications company.

title: OBJECTION TO EMBRAER DEAL
description: Brazil's Defense Minister, Elcio Alvares, has come out in opposition to plans by the aircraft manufacturer Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, or Embraer, to sell a minority stake to a French consortium. Mr. Alvares said he opposed the deal -- in which Dassault Aviation, Thomson CSF, Aerospatiale-Matra and Snecma would pay more than $200 million for 20 percent of Embraer -- on grounds that the military would become subordinated to concerns of the French aerospace industry. Brazil's government has the right to veto the transaction. Simon Romero

title: Pizza Killings Defense Claim Is Disputed By Detective
description: None of the bullets in the barrage of shots fired into the car of two pizza deliverymen during an ambush in 1997 hit the vehicle's dashboard, a New Jersey State Police detective testified today.

title: STAGECOACH PROFITS RISE
description: A British rail and bus company, Stagecoach Holdings, posted strong first-half results and assured investors that its United States business was firmly on track. The company said pretax profits rose 34 percent, to $:130.2 million, or $211.5 million -- well above analysts' forecasts of around $:115 million -- on a 52 percent increase in revenue. Executives said the results reflected strong growth in the core bus and rail operations and a three-month contribution from the recently acquired United States bus company Coach USA. The only area that underperformed was Stagecoach's Swedish bus operation, which the company sold in October.

title: Graves Plays Beat the Clock to Keep the Rangers on a Roll
description: Coach John Muckler termed the Rangers' 2-1 overtime victory over the Edmonton Oilers at Madison Square Garden last night their most emotional performance of the season. And the Rangers' usually mild-mannered goaltender provided the most memorable moment of the night.

title: Conspicuous Consumption For the Internet Generation
description: Looking for just the right gift for that new Internet millionaire on your Christmas list? Something that says both money and technology? The Financial Literacy Center, in conjunction with the Henry Ford Museum and Berner Machine Labs, has just the ticket, or ticker: an exact replica of Thomas Alva Edison's original 1870's Universal Stock Ticker.

title: Ousted Pakistan Leader Charged With Treason and Other Crimes
description: Pakistani prosecutors today formally charged the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, and six others with hijacking, kidnapping, attempted murder and plotting to wage war against the state.

title: Rx for Happy Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer's Perjury Charge Jeopardizes City's First D.W.I. Car-Seizure Case
description: The first criminal case brought under the city's policy of seizing the cars of people arrested on drunken driving charges is in jeopardy because the police officer who made the initial arrest has been charged with perjury in a similar case, officials said yesterday.

title: AIR MERGER ADVANCES
description: The merger of Canada's two major airlines advanced, as the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, agreed to sell its stake in Canadian Airlines to Air Canada and more than half of Canadian's shares were tendered to a $63 million bid by its larger rival. AMR, which has one-third of Canadian Airlines' equity, has agreed to sell to Air Canada for $41 million. Air Canada may also decide to use American's Sabre reservation system. If it does not, it will pay $56 million to cancel a contract with Canadian Airlines. Timothy Pritchard

title: Ending the Brutality in Chechnya
description: In the name of combating terrorism, Russian troops are threatening to destroy anyone who does not, or cannot, leave the Chechen capital of Grozny. Of the more than 20,000 residents, who remain huddled in rooms without heat, light or even windows, many are too old or frightened to leave. Most of these holdouts are innocent bystanders, far from the ''bandits'' who are the declared targets of Kremlin leaders. It is time for Russia to show restraint, to start making certain its armies observe basic humanitarian principles and to begin searching for a way out of this tragic war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRABER, EDWARD
description: GRABER-Edward A., M.D. of New York City, died Tuesday, December 7 at home at the age of 86. Beloved husband of Sylvia Hess Graber. Devoted father of Fredric and Elizabeth Graber. Adoring grandfather of Anne and David. Professor Emeritus of Clinical OB/ GYN at the New York Presbyterian Hospital. Former attending physician of OB/GYN at Lenox Hill Hospital. Funeral Service Friday, December 10, 11:30AM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Weill Medical College of Cornell, Dept of OB/GYN Education Fund, 525 E. 68 St, NYC 10021

description: A hormone trumpeted in the news media and on the Internet as a potential cure for autism worked no better than saltwater in its first controlled clinical trial, scientists are reporting.

description: A chemical explosion this morning at a nuclear bomb factory in Oak Ridge, Tenn., injured three workers, one seriously, and contaminated a fourth worker with uranium.

description: Marvin Kratter, the New York real estate investor whose holdings once included Ebbets Field (which he eventually replaced with an apartment complex), died on Oct. 24 at a hospital in Encinitas, Calif. He was 84.

title: Traveling, Shoulder to Shoulder
description: Travel seems to produce a peculiar sort of licensed bore, the very worst of whom rejoice in the theme, ''When the going was good.'' The point is usually that when they traveled (''Oh, heavens, this was years ago . . .''), it was absolutely marvelous, and too bad you weren't traveling then. But this is largely boastful bunk, and misses the point, for travel is the opposite of a holiday. It is about enlightenment and, at its best, is a form of disappearance.

title: Women's Tourney Could Be Moved Up
description: Amid the euphoria in the qualifying draw for the men's 2002 World Cup, Sepp Blatter, the president of sport's worldwide governing body, announced on Tuesday that the next women's World Cup would be moved up a year, from 2003 to 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, J. GEORGE
description: SPITZER-J. George. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime former member, J. George Spitzer and extend to his bereaved wife Sylvia and the members of his family our sincere condolences. Jeffrey Citron, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: 5 Cuban Exiles Charged With Plotting to Kill Castro Are Acquitted
description: In a defeat for government prosecutors, five Cuban exiles charged with plotting to kill Fidel Castro at a Caribbean summit meeting two years ago were acquitted yesterday of all the charges against them by a federal jury in Puerto Rico.

title: Nassau County's Fiscal Crisis
description: Something is wrong when one of the most prosperous counties in the nation goes broke in boom times. The fiscal disaster in Nassau County on Long Island provides a cautionary tale for political leaders everywhere. Last month voters revolted and put the County Legislature into the hands of the Democrats for the first time in modern history. Now the Democrats have to work with an unpopular Republican county executive to eliminate a huge budget deficit in the year beginning Jan. 1. Layoffs, service cutbacks, pay cuts, tax increases -- all seem possible for the county's 1.3 million residents.

title: A World Champion Teaches On a CD for Computers
description: Among the CD's available to bridge enthusiasts this holiday are two old favorites and one new item that run on a PC with Windows. One is Bridge Master 2000, an upgrade of a program that offers 180 deals on which the user is tested against perfect defense. Now it includes software for the beginner.

title: Gore Concedes Sour Economy Might Require Tax Rise
description: After days of lacerating former Senator Bill Bradley for acknowledging that he might have to raise taxes, Vice President Al Gore today admitted that if the economy took a turn for the worse, he would not rule out a tax increase either.

description: Microsoft Joins Ericsson In a Wireless Web Venture

title: The Knicks Are Cooling Their Heels Over Ewing
description: For more than two weeks, Patrick Ewing's teammates have watched him plodding around the paint like a grape-stomper without signs of a limp, a wince or trepidation. And still, Ewing waits.

title: Enshrining the Flotsam and Jetsam of a Millennium
description: We live now, as any archaeologist can tell you enviously, in a golden age of realia: the artifacts of daily life, the clothes, tools, toys and decorations that are the unacknowledged substrate of a civilization. A golden age, in other words, of stuff, not merely because we have so much more of it but because we invest it with so much significance.

description: VAN BUREN-Margaret W. Died December 4, 1999 at age 74. Beloved wife of James M.; mother of Katrina Claghorn and James, Jr.and sister of Elizabeth Bradley. Funeral service Saturday, December 11th, 11:00 AM at Grace Church, 802 Broadway at 10th St., NYC, followed by reception in the Church parlors. Contributions to Grace Church Restoration Fund.

title: Web Portal for the Arts Promotes Genre-Hopping
description: Culture vultures have a new place to nest on the Internet. ArtandCulture.com, a portal site for all things aesthetic, was scheduled to make its debut today on the Web.

description: European leaders will gather for a summit meeting this weekend and confront one of the Continent's oldest and most perplexing questions: is Turkey part of us?

description: 1. A handmade FM radio constructed of recycled wire and tin cans from a workshop in Capetown is $90 at Tink, 42 Rivington Street (Eldridge Street); (212) 529-6356.

title: From Phone To Fashion, Nokia Style; A Designer Who Sets A Worldwide Standard For Technophiles
description: FRANK NUOVO, chief designer at Nokia, sits in his spacious office in Calabasas, Calif., surrounded by several generations of cell phones he has had a hand in creating, and ponders the serendipitous turns in his career that led to a full-time fixation on mobile communications.

title: State Considers Rise In the Cigarette Tax
description: Negotiators for Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature are considering increasing the state's cigarette tax by at least 25 cents a pack to pay for a health care plan for low-income New Yorkers, according to people involved in the discussions.

description: With negotiations at an impasse over a German fund to compensate Nazi-era slave laborers, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder today dismissed demands to improve Germany's latest offer.

title: Albany Lawmakers Consider Raising Tobacco Tax
description: Negotiators for Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature are considering an increase in the state's cigarette tax of at least 25 cents a pack to pay for a health care plan that would expand medical coverage for low-income New Yorkers, according to people involved in the discussions.

title: Bearcats Blow Out Tar Heels in Final
description: Cincinnati's Kenyon Martin added a running, dunking offense to his shot-blocking defense as the top-ranked and unbeaten Bearcats wiped out seventh-ranked North Carolina, 77-68, in the final game of the Great Eight college basketball tournament in Chicago.

title: Hope May Be at Hand For Cuba's Modern Treasures
description: The Cuban government says it will restore the National Arts Schools in Havana. The five organic Modernist buildings, designed by Ricardo Porro, Roberto Gottardi and Vittorio Garatti, were commissioned by Fidel Castro; construction was halted in 1965. Recently, John A. Loomis, author of ''Cuba's Forgotten Art Schools: Revolution of Forms'' (Princeton Architectural Press, 1999) and others have campaigned to save the buildings. Mr. Gottardi, the only one of the three who remains in Cuba, has been asked to work on the restorations.

description: The state is as ready as it can be for the new year, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman declared yesterday.

title: New Toy Ideas Dance in the Heads of Precocious Inventors
description: As the holiday season marches on, children fill their wish lists with action figures, Furbies and the oh-so-popular Pokemon. Next year there may be a new item on those lists: Mr. Itchy Pants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEHER, STEPHEN J.
description: KELLEHER-Stephen J., Rt. Rev. Msgr. Passed away Dec. 5, 1999 in New York City. Priest of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Born August 31, 1915 to Stephen and Margaret (nee Morrissey) of Charville (Cork) and Johnston (Kilkenny), respectively, Ireland. Ordained in 1940, Monsignor Kelleher received a doctorate in canon law in 1943 from The Catholic University of America and thereafter served as assistant chancellor to the Archdiocese of New York. In 1959 he was appointed assistant national secretary to the Office of the Catholic Near East Association and also assistant to the president of the Pontifical Mission for Palestine. Monsignor Kelleher was honored by King Hussein of Jordan for his service in Palestine. He was appointed Officialis of the Archdiocese of New York in 1962. Soon thereafter he received the additional appointment from Pope Paul VI and Francis Cardinal Spellman to coordinate the drafting of the new code of canon law in accordance with the decrees of the Second Vatican Council. In 1968 he became pastor of St. Pius X Parish in Scarsdale. Monsignor Kelleher also served in the parishes of Nativity of Our Blessed Lady (Bronx), St. Margaret Mary (Staten Island), and St. Agnes, Sacred Heart and Holy Trinity (Manhattan). Monsignor was predeceased by his brother, Michael, and sisters Mary (Hickey) and Margaret. He is survived by nieces Margaret Mary Kelly, Ann Zelezny and Deirdre Dellert; nephew, Michael Kelleher; grand-nephew, Stephen Hickey; grand-niece, Christine Hickey; and sister-in-law, Joan Kelleher. Reposing from 2-5 and 7-9 PM Wednesday and Thursday at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (20-21 Street). Mass of the Resurrection at 10 AM Friday at St. Jerome Church, 138th Street and Alexander Avenue, Bronx, NY. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: INVITROGEN TO ACQUIRE RESEARCH GENETICS
description: The Invitrogen Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Research Genetics Inc. for $139.2 million in stock to improve Invitrogen's efforts to use new genetic tools to design drugs. Invitrogen will exchange 3.2 million of its shares for all the stock of Research Genetics, based in Huntsville, Ala. Research Genetics, which examines and catalogs human genes, will add to the genomic research services Invitrogen provides to companies, universities and governments seeking to decode the raw data generated by efforts to sequence human DNA. Shares of the San Diego-based Invitrogen, which went public at $15 a share in February, rose $3.4375 to close at $43.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APPLIED MATERIALS INC., -- Santa Clara, Calif., the biggest maker of equipment for the semiconductor industry, said it would spend $500 million to expand in chip diagnostics.

title: Holocaust Stories From Some of the Luckier Ones
description: Early in ''Schindler's List,'' Steven Spielberg's eloquent Holocaust film, an impeccably dressed couple -- he in a bowler, she in a fur coat -- are thrown out of their grand Cracow apartment and herded to the ghetto. After carrying their bags up their new building's narrow stairs, they find a tiny apartment, a crying baby and half a dozen other new occupants. ''It could be worse,'' says the wife in a faint voice, straining for optimism. Her husband looks at her as if she's insane. ''Tell me,'' he shouts, ''how on earth could it possibly be worse?''

description: With less than a week to go before a strike deadline, an unusual confluence of factors makes a walkout by New York City's transit workers more likely now than at any time in the past two decades, union members and government officials say.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee dropped as wetter weather in Brazil improved prospects for a crop damaged by drought earlier this year. In New York, coffee for March delivery fell 4.5 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $1.291 a pound.

title: The Conran Has Landed
description: ON the eve of the grand opening of the Terence Conran Shop, which sticks out from beneath the mighty arches of the Queensboro Bridge on the Upper East Side, Sir Terence Conran was clutching a wad of trash. All around him, various kits and caboodles of stylishly pared-down home furnishings were being unpacked in a frenzy and stacked onto shelves, tables and burnished steel display cases. Blue rubber radios, Italian plastic stacking chairs, leather clothes hampers, gigantic white ceramic platters and transparent shower curtains with pockets: the paraphernalia of a knowingly hip modern existence (for the Wallpaper years) stretched out over 26,000 white-on-white square feet. Dressed in a dark suit with a black tie etched in hieroglyphic Eames, Corbu and Rietveld chairs, Sir Terence seemed pleased with his comeback (his last American venture ended in 1988).

title: St. John's Leaves Coach Frowning
description: Coach Mike Jarvis of St. John's has a knack for putting on a tension-free face even after tough games. Following the Red Storm's struggle to put away St. Francis of Brooklyn last night, he adopted a fatherly calm.

title: Microsoft and Ericsson To Create Wireless Venture
description: Ericsson of Sweden and the Microsoft Corporation will create a joint-venture company to market and deliver mobile e-mail and other Internet services for wireless network operators, the companies said yesterday. Ericsson, the world's third largest mobile phone maker, will own a majority of the new venture.

Marilyn was an exceptional person who is deeply loved. We will remember her insightful counsel, kind words and the ways in which she inspired us to challenge complacency and convention. A remembrance will be held Saturday, December 11, at 10:30 AM. For more information, 212-982-5650.

description: When the ghosts refuse to go away, you might as well learn to dance with them. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAUS, MARY DANN
description: CLAUS-Mary Dann. Died on December 7 at Greenwich Hospital after a fierce battle with cancer. She was an active 25-year resident of Bedford, NY, and had a successful career as an associate broker and real estate agent with Houlihan Lawrence Real Estate Centers in her own town. Mary spent most of her formative years in Pawling, NY sharing life experiences with her two brothers Tyler and Harvey Dann. She attended high school at the Emma Willard School in Troy, NY and received a bachelor's degree in history from Hood College in Maryland. Mary was a school teacher for many years, a fashion consultant, and had been a real estate agent and broker for the last 12 years. Mary was actively involved with the Bedford Garden Club, St. Matthew's Church, and the local Pegasus Program. She was an avid horseperson, golfer, tennis player, skier and adventurer. Mary was a true friend with a charitable heart. She leaves behind many friends and loving family including her two children, Lois Fahy Claus of Park City, UT and Carl Regling Claus of Smyrna, GA; her brothers Tyler Dann of Poughkeepsie, NY, and Harvey Dann of Pound Ridge, NY; as well as numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held for her on Saturday, December 11, 1999 at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that memorial donations be made to the Greenwich Hospital Hospice Fund, C/O Dept Office, 5 Perry Ridge Road, Greenwich, CT.06830.

title: Russian Diplomat in Washington Held in Spy Case
description: The federal authorities tonight arrested a Russian diplomat believed to be an intelligence officer who had sought classified information from the State Department, government officials said.

description: KUTNER-Henry. Born May 23, 1910, Brooklyn, New York. Died December 6, 1999, Los Angeles, CA. Remembered lovingly by family and friends. The posters are by West Coast designers, including April Greiman, Lorraine Wild, ReVerb and Tom Bonauro, who did the one above. title: Getting to the Land of Oz Is Easier on the Internet
description: LYMAN FRANK BAUM, a gentle man with a gift for storytelling, was entertaining his sons and their friends in Chicago one day in 1898. He began a tale about a girl named Dorothy and how she met a scarecrow. ''Where did they live?'' a small voice asked. As the account goes, he looked at his two file drawers, A-N and O-Z.

description: IF it just doesn't seem like a Beatles recording without the green apple somewhere on the packaging, CD labeling kits will squeeze a vinyl album cover into a reproduction the size of a CD jewel case.

title: Clinton Defends His Role At the Seattle Trade Talks
description: President Clinton today defended his handling of last week's failed trade negotiations, and said his insistence that labor and environmental issues be central to the talks was not intended to provide political cover for Vice President Al Gore's presidential campaign.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's chief of staff has been questioned by investigators from the Brooklyn district attorney's office who are looking into whether Hasidic builders in Brooklyn benefited from their political connections to City Hall.

description: Goldman, Sachs & Company which set aside $200 million from its public stock offering earlier this year to endow a foundation named after the company, said yesterday that the institution would focus exclusively on education.

title: Hillary Clinton Faults Policy Of 'Don't Ask'
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton told a group of gay contributors this week that the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy, intended to make it easier for gay men and lesbians to serve in the military, had been a failure, her aides said yesterday. Mrs. Clinton, a candidate for the United States Senate, said that if elected she would work to overturn the policy, one of the first put in place under President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTOLOTTI, ERNEST
description: BERTOLOTTI-Ernest J. You're one of a kind and are already missed. Your love of life was infectuous and touched everyone who knew you. Heaven must be singing. Love to Paula, Amy, Sara, Michael, Leah and Jena. The Zipes Family

title: The School Testing Inquiry
description: The special commissioner of investigation for New York City schools has found appalling evidence that some school administrators and teachers have helped students cheat on standardized city and state reading and math tests. The alleged misconduct shows deep cynicism about education and sends the message that the only way some students can pass is by cheating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARION RHODES
description: BROWN-Marion Rhodes. Of Ardsley-on-Hudson, died November 30, 1999 at her home. She was born April 8, 1909 in New York City. She received her B.A. from Barnard College in 1930 and then taught history at Walton High School. She married the late John Albert Brown in 1943. She obtained her Ph.D. at Teachers College, Columbia University in 1958 and became a Professor of Educational Psychology at the City College of New York. She was dedicated in volunteering time and energy to the World Education Fellowship, the American Association of University Women and the United Nations. She cared about issues of protecting the environment and working for peace among all people of the world. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Val and David Brown-Tillotson of Anchorage, Alaska. Memorial service will be Saturday, December 11 at 12 noon at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: An Early Chronicler of the Internet Reflects on a Decade of Growth
description: ED KROL was one of the first chroniclers of the Internet. He helped develop the Frequently Asked Questions format with ''The Hitchhikers Guide to the Internet,'' posted on the Net in 1987. His 1992 book, ''The Whole Internet User's Guide & Catalog'' (O'Reilly & Associates), was considered the bible for the first generation of Net users. He has finally written a sequel with Kiersten Conner-Sax, ''The Whole Internet User's Guide: The Next Generation'' (O'Reilly & Associates). Mr. Krol is an assistant director of computing and communications at the University of Illinois in Urbana, where Mosaic, the first graphical Web browser, was developed. In an interview over the Internet, he talked about the past decade of being online.

title: Bergman, With Extra Entanglements; Ullmann Directs a Film Rich in Real-Life Echoes
description: ''His secrets are his secrets,'' the actress, author and director Liv Ullmann said of the complicated inner life of Ingmar Bergman, the 81-year-old Swedish director. ''What we have to do is use our own experiences, our own lives, our own secrets and our perceptions of Bergman to make the movie.''

description: FIVE thousand years of recorded history provided the House & Home section with a few thoughts on holiday gifts for 1999.

title: FRENCH-POLISH PHONE VENTURE
description: The dominant shareholder in France's second-largest phone business, Vivendi, will almost double its investment in a venture with Elektrim, a Polish industrial company with stakes in telecommunication and power plants, to expand their joint telecommunications businesses. Vivendi agreed to raise its total investment in the venture, Elektrim Telekomunikacja, to $1.2 billion from $615 million, of which $150 million will be paid immediately. Another $100 million will be paid before Dec. 18. Vivendi also agreed to convert the balance of a $615 million loan to Elektrim into shares of the venture.

title: Baldwin to Sell 2 Units
description: The Baldwin Piano and Organ Company, the maker of the Baldwin, Wurlitzer and Chickering brands of pianos and keyboard instruments, agreed today to sell its two retail financing units to Deutsche Financial Services for $35 million. Baldwin is selling the Keyboard Acceptance Corporation, which offers credit to buyers, and the Signature Leasing Corporation, which leases instruments, to reduce debt and increase investments in other businesses. The buyer, Deutsche Financial Services of St. Louis, is a unit of Deutsche Bank Group of Germany.
