title: Fed Says Expansion Continues at Moderate to Strong Pace
description: The economy continued to expand at a ''moderate to strong'' pace in October and November with little sign of inflation, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest regional economic survey, suggesting that policy makers may feel less compelled to raise interest rates again soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNATA, MICHAEL
description: CANNATA-Michael. Our deepest sympathy to his loving family at this very difficult time. Mike was a dedicated professional and devoted member of the Ruder Finn family for almost forty years. We valued his warmth, friendship, wisdom and sense of humor and he will be sorely missed. We are heartbroken by his sudden loss but take comfort in the many fond memories we have of our years together. David Finn, Peter Finn, Kathy Bloomgarden, Amy Binder, Dena Merriam, Roz Safrin, and all at Ruder Finn.

title: Brazil Wizard Makes Books Disappear From Stores
description: Paulo Coelho was visiting Spain last summer when a reporter back home in Brazil called with a piece of news that made it clear to him that the audience for his books no longer knows any bounds: The president of the United States had just been photographed reading ''The Alchemist,'' the best known of Mr. Coelho's slender fables of spiritual growth and fulfillment.

description: In a city that is constantly struggling to reduce crime and improve the quality of life, few have noticed a bedeviling problem on the city's edges: Jet Ski theft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, SADIE
description: KAUFMAN-Sadie. On December 7th in Florida. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Irving, Edward & Vivian. Cherished grandmother of eight & great grandmother of 11. Graveside services Thursday, 10:45 AM, Cedar Park, Paramus, NJ.

title: You Wait Long Enough, They'll Make It a City
description: The very notion of a downtown has been deemed irrelevant for this sprawling metropolis. But there are signs that at century's end, downtown Los Angeles is coming alive. The Staples Arena has just opened; yesterday, ground was broken on Frank Gehry's Walt Disney Concert Hall; Rafael Moneo's new Catholic cathedral is under construction. And a developer has just announced the renovation and expansion of St. Vibiana's, the former Catholic cathedral on the east side of downtown.

title: Racing To Convert Books to Bytes; Evolving Market for E-Titles
description: Rarely does anything between covers astonish a librarian like Dennis Dillon, but he says he is shocked when he examines the latest reports about reading patterns of students at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: F.D.A. Officials Fault Penn Team in Gene Therapy Death
description: Officials of the Food and Drug Administration said today that Jesse Gelsinger, the 18-year-old Arizona man who lost his life in a gene therapy experiment in September, was ineligible for the clinical trial and should not have been treated because his liver was not functioning well enough before doctors infused him with a dose of corrective genes.

title: For the Genuine Gift Box
description: Anyone who has traveled to Asia knows that even simple purchases may be exquisitely wrapped. For the holidays, this service is available at the Warisan Asian antiques and furniture store in Los Angeles. Shoppers can have gifts wrapped in beautifully patterned batik fabrics ($30 to $70) or packaged in brightly colored and decorated beaded boxes (left, $85 to $95 each) or in dyed palm-leaf boxes (three for $10). The wrappings are a gift in themselves. Warisan is at 7470 Beverly Boulevard, (323) 938-3960.

description: Rock and Rhinestones

title: Of Writers Vs. Publishers
description: They've undoubtedly been lamenting about one another since the first author scratched some signs on someone else's cave wall, thus creating the first publisher, and they'll very likely continue to do so well into the millennium beyond the next. Since book publishing has become list tickled -- this year the 100 best nonfiction books written in English; last year the top 100 novels -- how about tabulating the top accusations that writers make against publishers? And vice versa.

title: Tests That Cheat Students
description: The allegations that some New York City teachers may have cheated to raise their students' test scores should surprise no one -- partly because of similar accusations elsewhere but also because of the enormous pressure on educators to produce better results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBE, HARRY
description: TAUBE-Harry, MD, at the age of 85, on December 7, 1999 in New York City. Beloved husband of Annette Nathan Taube, devoted father of Susan Taube Katchor of New York City, Steven Taube of McLean, VA., and Oscar Taube of Baltimore, MD. Beloved father-inlaw of Mary Taube, Jean Taube and Benjamin Katchor. Devoted brother of Shirley Hoffman of Toronto, Sigmund Taube of Burlington, Ontario; adored grandfather of Alexis, Andrew, Matthew, James and Samuel Taube. Dedicated physician in practice for over 55 years and affiliated with New York University Medical Center. Services will be held at the Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Thursday, December 9th, 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers a contribution to the American Heart Association may be made.

title: Christmas Trees (Not for Downloading)
description: IF I am a snob about Christmas trees, blame my mother. When I was small, she would march through the tree lot, suspiciously searching for crooked trunks, missing branches and needle loss. In her quest to acquire the biggest, fullest, freshest Scotch pine, she was not above examining candidates already reserved for other customers. One year she fell in love with a particularly graceful specimen slated for the nuns at a nearby convent. She bribed the lot owner $10 to snip off the ''reserved'' tag.

title: BBDO New York breaks down why, when, where and how young adults get information.
description: NEW study by BBDO New York of consumers' perceptions of the media says that newspapers have the most traditional image of all media and that the Internet has replaced television as the favored medium for escape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, VIRGINIA T.
description: ALEXANDER-Virginia T. (Nina). The officers, leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the untimely and tragic loss of Nina Alexander, a dedicated and generous supporter who embraced the values of her distinguished philanthropic family. She was a devoted wife and mother, a successful businesswoman, and a strong advocate on issues relating to children's health and education. Through the years, Nina was active in many UJA-Federation organizational and agency activities: she served as a member of the executive committee for the Leadership Development Division and as a board member of the 92nd Street Y's Children's Resource Center. She was a Wexner Scholar through the Wexner Heritage Foundation, and a past member of the National Women's Cabinet of UJA-Federation. Despite her long illness, Nina, along with her husband, Richard, remained active in the Mount Sinai Children's Center. She is survived by her husband, Richard; her children, David and Lauren; her sister, Pat Hall; and her parents, Peggy and Alan Tishman. Mrs. Tishman is one of the Jewish community's most extraordinary and dynamic leaders. Among her many accomplishments, she served with distinction as the first president of the merged UJA-Federation, and is a current member of the Board of Directors. Mr. Tishman is a board member of two UJA-Federation beneficiaries, the Jewish Child Care Association and of Mount Sinai Hospital. To the entire family, we express our deepest sympathy and out shared sense of loss during this very difficult time. Judith Stern Peck, Chair of the Board James S. Tisch, President John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: U.S. Hints at Returning Refugee, 6, to Cuba
description: Even as 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez, wrapped in the arms of his relatives, said he wanted to stay in Little Havana here, State Department officials seemed willing today to consider reuniting the boy with his father in Cuba.

title: Fires in Two Subway Stations Force Detours and Slow Traffic
description: Holiday shoppers and commuters were forced to make detours yesterday morning after two separate fires temporarily shut down part of the subway station at Union Square and the station at West 14th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, MARGARET
description: GREENFIELD-Margaret A. died on December 8 after a long illness. She was an art and antiques dealer in London, Washington, D.C., and New York, most recently running Marco Polo on Madison Avenue. She renovated residential real estate in New York. In 1991, she co-founded The Independent Journalism Foundation to foster a free and independent media in central and eastern Europe. She designed and built Centers for Independent Journalism in Prague, Bratislava, Bucharest and Budapest that have become models for programs of this type. She is survived by her husband, James L. Greenfield. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be welcome to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, 1 Penn Plaza, New York, NY 10119-0165.

title: Web Site Helps Disabled Work and Communicate
description: Moving the Internet a step closer toward fulfilling its promise to be all-inclusive, We Media, a three-year-old company serving the disabled and their families, recently unveiled a full-service Web site aimed at that market.

title: Two Years Before the Mast (and the Computer)
description: IF wind, weather and luck hold out, the crew of the Makulu II, a 43-foot sailboat-turned-cyberspace-classroom, is expected to complete a two-year voyage around the world on Saturday by sailing into a Florida marina not far from where it started. But that news would hardly be a surprise to the thousands, perhaps millions, of students and the simply curious who have been following the crew's exploits and explorations by way of e-mail and the crew's Web site.

title: Agency.com Shares Soars
description: Shares of the Internet consultant Agency.com Ltd. closed yesterday at almost triple their initial offering price. The specialist in online branding, which is based in New York, closed at $76 in Nasdaq trading, or 192 percent above the $26 offering price that was set on Tuesday evening. That valuation gave Agency.com, which has 33.7 million shares outstanding, a market capitalization of roughly $2.6 billion. Led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the offering of 5.9 million shares attracted huge demand before the pricing was done. Last week, the pricing estimate was raised to between $22 and $24 a share, double the previous range.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDHAR, MAXWELL
description: GOLDHAR-Maxwell, 82, a man who enriched the lives of his family, friends and the people of Ontario, died suddenly at home Tuesday night from a heart attack. Still active in business and pursuing his dreams through his last days, Mr. Goldhar left major accomplishments and a loving circle of family and friends behind him. Mr. Goldhar devoted over 50 years of his life to voluntary service, and he was recently invested with the Order of Ontario. He was well known for his substantial contributions to technology, manufacturing and natural resources companies in Canada and internationally, in particular Ontario Store Fixtures, Fantom Technologies and Fifty Plus Net International. As a business leader he earned the nickname ''Dr. Business'' for his achievements in helping to ''turn around'' declining Ontario companies. Founding president of the President's Council of the Canadian Opera Company and a founding director of the York Racquet Club, Hockley Valley Ski Club and the Island Yacht Club, Mr. Goldhar was a leader who constructively countered the exclusion of Jews from many of the city's social organizations by opening new opportunities for them through these organizations. Mr. Goldhar was treasurer of the building campaign for the northern YMHA and served for many years as director of the Canadian Society for the Weizmann Institute of Science. At the time of his death, Mr. Goldhar was an active director of ''CARP,'' the Canadian Association of Retired Persons, and a founding director of Fifty Plus Net International, the leading Internet supplier to seniors in Canada. Mr. Goldhar recently joined the board of Sunnybrook and Women's Health Sciences Centre, and served as Chair of the Board of Women's College Health Research Inc. Previously, he served as the Chair of the Hospital Council of Metropolitan Toronto, Chair of the Board of both the Northwestern General Hospital and the Northwestern Health Centre Foundation, a director of Women's College Hospital and treasurer of the Alzheimer Association of Ontario. He is survived by his loving family: by his son, Dan, and Dan's wife, Janet; by daughters Nancy, Heather and Renanah and Heather's partner, James Neal; by his grandchildren Jeremy and Rachel; his brothers Albert and Morty and their wives Booty and Rosemary, respectively; and by his sister, Wendy Rue. Mr. Goldhar was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Jeanette, and survived by his loving spouse, Marilou McPhedran. Services will be conducted at 2:30 PM today by Mr. Goldhar's close friend and tennis partner, Rabbi Gunther Plaut, at Holy Blossom Temple in Toronto.

title: NBT BANCORP TO BUY PIONEER AMERICAN FOR $85 MILLION
description: NBT Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to the buy the Pioneer American Holding Company, which has 18 bank branches in northeastern Pennsylvania, for about $85 million in stock. NBT, based in Norwich, N.Y., is the parent of NBT Bank, a commercial bank with assets of more than $1.38 billion and 36 branches in nine counties in central New York. Pioneer American Holding, based in Carbondale, Pa., is the parent of Pioneer American Bank, which has assets of $420 million. NBT will exchange 1.805 of its shares for each Pioneer share, or a total of 5.2 million shares. The purchase values Pioneer at $29.33 a share, based on Tuesday's closing price. Shares of NBT fell $1 to close at $15.25 yesterday, and Pioneer was down $2.75, to $25.

title: PUMA TECHNOLOGY TO BUY INTERNET SOFTWARE CREATOR
description: Shares of Puma Technology Inc., a maker of software for mobile devices, rose 11 percent after it agreed to buy NetMind Technologies for about $370 million in stock. Puma said late Wednesday that it would swap five million common shares for closely held NetMind, which is based in Campbell, Calif., to gain software that alerts Internet users to content. The company said it expected to complete the purchase by April 30. Yesterday, its shares rose $8.50, to $82.75. Puma, based in San Jose, Calif., plans to combine the software with its Web-browsing and synchronization technology.

title: Technicolor Dreamcoats (Dreams Sold Separately)
description: IT'S not every day that a fashion exhibition resembles a walk-in version of People magazine's annual best-worst-dressed issue, but then ''Rock Style,'' the winter offering from the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is not an everyday kind of show. By turns dazzling, banal and tacky, it examines one of the most organic, commercially lucrative relationships of our day, that between fashion and rock 'n' roll. It covers such an array of sartorial statements and attitudes that an accurate subtitle might be ''Rock Style: Who Had It, Who Lost It, Who Never Stood a Chance.''

title: NEWS BRIEFS      INTERNATIONAL    SQN##825832##RUSSIA VOWS TO RETURN REFUGEES TO CHECHNYA  Russian officials said they would return the flood of refugees in the neighboring republic of Ingushetia to Russian-controlled areas of Chechnya by the end of the year.      SQN##824623##President Boris N. Yeltsin, bristling over President Clinton's criticism of Russia's military assault on Chechnya, complained that the United States was not treating Russia with the respect due a nuclear power.    SQN##820741##U.S. ORDERS RUSSIAN OUT  The United States said it was expelling a Russian diplomat who was found with eavesdropping equipment outside the State Department.    SQN##824593##CONTAINING SPREAD OF WEAPONS  The United States should raise financial support for programs intended to prevent former Soviet scientists from working for rogue states and terrorists seeking unconventional weapons, a research group said.    SQN##822736##REACTION TO ISRAEL-SYRIA TALKS  The news that Israel would hold peace talks with Syria galvanized Israeli opposition and government forces alike.      SQN##822299##The Syrian government and its Arab allies spoke with customary caution even as they welcomed the planned resumption of peace talks between Syria and Israel.    SQN##819190##U.S. OFFERS KOSOVO TOLL  The State Department estimated that 10,000 Kosovar Albanians were killed in the Serbian campaign this year to force out the Albanian population, a figure nearly five times larger than the number of bodies unearthed from mass graves.      SQN##819212##A Serbian court sentenced Flora Brovina, Kosovo's leading poet and a campaigner for women's rights, to 12 years in prison on charges of committing terrorism during the NATO air campaign in Kosovo.      SQN##818852##The Yugoslav Army agreed to reopen the main airport in Montenegro, but warned the Montenegrin police against again trying to build a permanent base at the airport.      NATIONAL    SQN##824291##BRADLEY AND MCCAIN JOIN TO PRESS FINANCE OVERHAUL  John McCain and Bill Bradley, both insurgent candidates for president, have agreed to step across party lines and stage an unusual joint appearance in New Hampshire to highlight their support for overhauling the nation's campaign finance system, aides to the candidates said.    SQN##819565##WIDENING ACCESS TO THE NET  President Clinton, executives of technology companies and representatives of minorities and civil rights groups announced plans to help bridge the ''digital divide'' between technology haves and have-nots, to make online access as common as telephone service.    SQN##825816##TALKING PHILANTHROPY  Nelson Mandela met with William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, at Mr. Gates's Seattle-area estate. They discussed a $750 million fund that Mr. Gates is creating to vaccinate children in developing countries, and a new foundation established by Mr. Mandela to promote health care and education in Africa.    SQN##825638##RECALLING 6 FIREFIGHTERS  Thousands of firefighters and others gathered in Worcester, Mass., to pay tribute to six firefighters killed last week in a warehouse fire.    SQN##825840##ONCE, A MARTIAN SEA  Scientists at Brown University said they had found tantalizing evidence that the northern lowlands of Mars once bore a wide ocean that had waves, hidden depths and long beaches. Although the findings do not bear directly on the issue of alien life, large amounts of water would be an indication that life might once have thrived on the planet.    SQN##821870##GOING COMMERCIAL IN SPACE  An American company that provides space services to NASA has reached an agreement that calls for a Russian company to build and place on the International Space Station a new segment that would be totally devoted to commercial projects.      METRO    SQN##825018##OFFICERS IN DIALLO KILLING LEAN AWAY FROM JURY TRIAL  The four police officers accused of second-degree murder in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo plan to testify in their own defense at trial next month, and are leaning toward choosing a trial by a judge instead of a jury, according to their lawyers. A review of much of the evidence offers a more sharply defined picture of the incident than has previously come to light and underscores what are likely to be the critical issues at trial.    SQN##827037##PLANE CRASH IN NEW JERSEY  A plane carrying four people from Virginia crashed near Teterboro Airport. All four people aboard the plane were killed, officials said, and three people on the ground who came to their aid were injured. title: BAKER HUGHES SAYS ACCOUNTING ERRORS WILL BE COSTLY
description: Baker Hughes Inc. shares fell 15 percent yesterday after the company said accounting discrepancies at its Inteq drilling technology unit could cost it $40 million to $50 million before taxes. Baker Hughes, the No. 3 oil-field services company, said the accounting errors led it to postpone a $200 million bond sale. The company had planned to use the proceeds to refinance debt and pay for a ship used for undersea oil exploration. Earnings from earlier quarters may have to be restated, Baker Hughes said. The company, which is based in Houston, did not say which quarters would be affected. Baker Hughes shares fell $3.25, to $19.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANSON, ROBERT A.
description: SWANSON-Robert A., the founder of the biotech industry, died at his home in Hillsborough, CA. on December 6, 1999, after a 14-month battle with brain cancer. At his bedside were his wife Judy Church Swanson, their daughters Katie and Erica and his mothr, Arline Baker Swanson, of Foster City, CA. He was 52. Selected by Esquire Magazine as one whose life and work exemplified America's highest qualities and values. Courage, Originality, Ingenuity, Vision, Selfless Service. He was regarded as one of the best of a new generation. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Bob grew up in Florida, the only child of a career employee at Eastern Airlines. Bob graduated from Massachusetts Institute ofTechnology, earning both his BS in Chemistry and an MS degree from MIT's Alfred P. Sloan School of Management. Bob was one of the first MIT graduates to complete his MBA in his fourth year of college. Bob was a loyal MIT alumnus serving as trustee, as well as on various visiting committees. Bob gained world acclaim for starting the biotech revolution, which has impacted the lives of millions of people throughout the world. He began his career as an investment officer at Citicorp Venture Capital, Ltd. and later became a partner at Kleiner & Perkins. Bob's life goal was to change the world for the better and he did. In 1976, at age 29, Bob and UCSF scientist, Herbert W. Boyer, founded Genentech, Inc. Genentech was the first and most successful biotechnology firm. Bob served as CEO of Genentech from 1976-1990 and as Chairman of the Board from 1990-1996. Under his guidance, Genentech developed human insulin, interferon, human growth hormone and TPA. In recent years, Bob continued his passion for creating science by working with a wide range of pioneering startup companies, including serving as Chairman of Tularik. Throughout his life, Bob received many awards, but the ones he valued most were for his daughters' soccer teams. Bob's first priority was always his family. He was a loving and committed man who continually supported his community. He served as trustee of the San Francisco Ballet, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, and the San Jose Tech Center and as Chairman of the Board of Nueva School. Regarded by the Japanese press as the Man Who Captured the Rainbow, he was clearly the man who captured the hearts of all who knew him. Memorial Services will be held at the Stanford Memorial Church in Palo Alto, CA, on December 20 at 3 P.M. The family asks that contributions in Bob's memory be made to the Peninsula Community Foundation, C/O The Robert A. Swanson Memorial Fund, at 1700 South El Camino Real, Suite 300, San Mateo, California 94402-3049.

title: Rejecting 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'

That is the position her husband held when he campaigned for president, promising to issue an executive order to end the Department of Defense's ban on homosexuals in the armed forces. But in 1993 the new president allowed opposition in Congress and the Pentagon to drive him to an ill-conceived compromise, the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For turn-of-the-century French, there's Balthazar. For up-to-the-minute French, there's L'Actuel, whose name, as it happens, means ''right now.'' Christophe Lhopitault and Jean-Yves Schillinger, the team behind Destinee, have come up with a slightly wobbly mix of traditional and modern that has France written all over it, right down to the exuberant, slightly loony decor. It's a brasserie of sorts, with huge piles of shellfish and oysters displayed on the bar and presented French-style on large plates elevated by a wire pedestal. The horseradish-fired cocktail sauce that comes with it is American, and very good, too. Brown seaweed bread also adds a distinctive touch.

title: Protector or Protected: Which Is Worse?
description: It's hard to feel much sympathy for Bobby and Cindy Batton, the central characters in ''Witness Protection.'' Bobby is a third-rate weasel, a petty mobster who has profited handsomely from crime but has greedily cheated his own bosses. When they catch on to his clumsy scheme and order him killed, he decides to tell all to the feds to save his sorry skin. He regularly lies to his wife, too, and neglects his children. Cindy knows what line of work Bobby's in, but she chooses to look the other way and enjoy the ill-gotten gains. These two deserve each other, and they deserve whatever unpleasant comeuppance fate tosses them.

title: A Rite of Passage, With Dickensian Sympathies
description: It doesn't take a cryptographer to decipher the meanings in John Irving's sprawling picaresque allegories. But a reader who wants to savor them must be willing to suspend a psychoanalytic view of human nature descended from Freud through Oprah and surrender to an imagination that is more Dickensian than Freudian. Once you give up those expectations, a visit to the world according to Irving is a little like touring a parallel universe where fate is determined not so much by abusive parents as by wondrous tragicomic events beyond the realm of psychology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBE, HARRY, MD.
description: TAUBE-Harry, MD. The Members of The Department of Medicine are saddened by the demise of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Harry Taube. Dr. Taube, Professor of Clinical Medicine, has been with us for over 50 years. He was a gentle man, scholar, researcher, teacher, mentor, and model to all. In the early history of cardiac catherization, he was an active participant in pathophysiological and electrophysiological studies of the heart. His patients benefited greatly from his unusual expertise, his personal devotion to their total welfare, and his deep compassion to each individual. We will miss his amiable presence among us. To his dear spouse, Annette, and our Alumnus Dr. Oscar, Steven, and daughter, Susan T. Katchor, and his family, we offer our deep sympathy. Saul J. Farber, MD, MACP, The Frederick H. King Professor & Chairman, Dept of Medicine Director, Medical Services Bellevue and Tisch Hospitals

title: RUSSIANS DECLARE CHECHEN REFUGEES WILL BE SENT BACK
description: Russian officials vowed today to return the flood of refugees in a neighboring republic to Russian-controlled areas of Chechnya by the end of the year.

title: Lean (Alley-Oop!) And Go (Whoosh!)
description: I want to push my skating to a new level. I bought a pair of Rollerblades in the early 1990's and used them a few dozen times. Then, one winter, I lost track of them in my closet, behind the suitcases. There they stayed. Recently, though, I dug them out and started skating to work. Now, I appreciate the sport as never before. The smooth, powerful strokes are the same as you would use on ice skates. The downhills feel like skiing. I get to work faster, too.

title: Wheeling Shapes in a Virtual World
description: The darkness is vast and engulfing. At the back of the big room, lines, dots and wisps of large dancing figures wheel across a screen filled with the same darkness. For a moment, it seems as if one has stepped into that universe, a flesh-and-blood human let loose in virtual reality. The effect is both startling and exhilarating, as if an immaterial essence has appropriated the viewer's actual three-dimensionality.

title: 'Italy's 1950's: An International Dialogue' -- Works on Paper From the Collection of the University of Pisa
description: Mishkin Gallery at Baruch College

description: GARAFOLA-Ralph S. On December 8, 1999. Owner of Garry's Jewelers. Devoted husband of Rose, cherished father of Michael, Janet and the late Dolores, loving uncle of many nieces and nephews. Mass Monday 10:30AM, St. Thomas Aquinas Church. Reposing at the Chapel of Joseph G. Duffy Inc., 9th Street between 4th and 5th Aves, Brooklyn. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5PM, 7-9PM.

title: Union Questions Investigator's Finding on Teacher Cheating
description: The New York City teachers' union yesterday called an investigator's finding that dozens of teachers had helped students cheat on standardized tests exaggerated and unfair, and officials at the Board of Education suggested that the report was aimed at undercutting Chancellor Rudy Crew while his future was being decided.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, MAX
description: JOHNSON-Max. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member, Max Johnson. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Criticizing M.T.A. and the Transit Union, Giuliani Warns Workers Against a Strike
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani warned New York City's subway and bus workers yesterday against going on strike next week, and chided their union for making what he said were irresponsible contract demands.

title: A Tiny Company Without Profits Goes Public With a Bang
description: Internet mania reached new levels of frenzy today as investors paid huge multiples on an initial public offering, giving a market value of almost $10 billion to a tiny company with powerful competitors, little revenue and no expectation of earnings in the foreseeable future.

title: Who Will Defend the Homeless?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Eagerness for Peace
description: In the Middle East, negotiations come and negotiations go and everyone has learned to be guarded, even jaded, about the possibilities for agreements, much less real peace.

title: Agreements by two agency giants add to a year-end rush to capitalize on Internet advertising.
description: YOU usually don't want to stand in the way of agencies rushing to complete deals before the end of the year. That is even more true this month because the urge to capitalize on the frenzy for interactive advertising, marketing and media is spurring deal makers to finish up in, well, Internet time.

title: Weber McGinn Buys Barbour Griffith
description: Weber McGinn in Arlington, Va., has acquired Barbour Griffith & Rogers in Washington, a leading government lobbyist. Terms were not disclosed.

title: BRITISH LEAVE RATES UNCHANGED
description: Despite a boom in housing prices and a surge in year-end consumer spending, the Bank of England decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.5 percent, postponing until next year any move to repress inflation by raising the cost of borrowing. The bank had raised the securities repurchase rate by a quarter percentage point in both September and November to keep inflation below 2.5 percent. Alan Cowell

title: A Pair of Westward Journeys By Mothers and Daughters
description: Tumbleweeds

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The difference is a few miles, and for Americans, with their expansive continent, it seems pathetic. But this is the proverbial olive tree. For the Syrians, to be or not to be on the water's edge is critical.''

title: Wireless Test by BellSouth
description: The BellSouth Corporation, which provides local phone service in nine Southeastern states, said it would test wireless systems as a way of bringing new services like high-speed Internet access to rural customers. The test will take place early next year in Houma, La., about 60 miles southwest of New Orleans. It is intended to help BellSouth see if wireless connections are profitable and technically feasible. About a dozen customers will participate in the test.

title: Reforms Are Unlikely To Transform the I.O.C.
description: Even if the International Olympic Committee enacted all 50 of its proposed reforms at meetings here this weekend, many Olympic observers do not expect the group to change in more than an incremental way in the aftermath of the Salt Lake City bidding scandal.

title: Big Game by George Stymies Raiders
description: The Tennessee Titans found themselves in a battle with the Oakland Raiders where the offenses looked worn, and the defenses appeared pumped with enthusiasm. All night, big plays -- and points -- would be scarce.

title: Mandela Visits the Northwest and Talks Philanthropy With Gates
description: Nelson Mandela, the former president of South Africa, had breakfast this morning at the Lake Washington estate of the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, William H. Gates. ''I told Bill and Melinda that I haven't got a word in English to describe my impression of the house,'' Mr. Mandela recounted afterward. ''I don't think 'beautiful,' or 'exquisite,' is enough.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARION RHODES
description: BROWN-Marion Rhodes. Of Ardsley-on-Hudson, died November 30, 1999 at her home. She was born April 8, 1909 in New York City. She received her B.A. from Barnard College in 1930 and then taught history at Walton High School. She married the late John Albert Brown in 1943. She obtained her Ph.D. at Teachers College, Columbia University in 1958 and became a Professor of Educational Psychology at the City College of New York. She was dedicated in volunteering time and energy to the World Education Fellowship, the American Association of University Women and the United Nations. She cared about issues of protecting the environment and working for peace among all people of the world. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Val and David Brown-Tillotson of Anchorage, Alaska. Memorial service will be Saturday, December 11 at 12 noon at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Camelot-on-Nile: First Family Basks in a Cosmic Eden
description: Ancient Egypt has an extraterrestrial look. Its tombs are as immense and blank as mother ships; its svelte, bulb-headed kings and queens seem to come from some universe far, far away from ours, one bathed in lunar light, enveloping shadow and an air of imperturbable, futuristic chic.

title: WELLPOINT AGREES TO ACQUIRE HEALTH INSURER IN ILLINOIS
description: WellPoint Health Networks Inc., one of California's largest health insurers, agreed to buy Rush Prudential Health Plans for about $200 million to add more customers in Illinois. Rush Prudential, owned by Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center and Prudential Insurance Company of America, is one of Chicago's biggest health-benefits companies. WellPoint, which already has more than 283,000 medical customers in Illinois, said the state was a growth market. Rush Prudential had 302,775 medical plan members as of Sept. 30, the company said. The transaction needs regulatory approval and is expected to close in the first quarter. Shares of WellPoint, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., fell 81.25 cents, to $59.3125. The acquisition was announced after the close of regular United States trading.

title: Brooks Redux, With Nod to the Future
description: Twenty winters ago, when Herb Brooks was on top of the world, he was a man ahead of his time. He had a global perspective on hockey and the imagination to make it fun to play and to watch. He coached the United States Olympic team that upset the powerful Soviet Union and went on to win the gold medal at Lake Placid.

title: While Barak's Allies Rejoice, His Political Foes Find Fault
description: The news that Israel is sitting down to peace talks with Syria galvanized opposition and government forces alike today, with the right-wing leader Ariel Sharon mobilizing resistance to the expected surrender of the Golan Heights and center-left parties rallying behind Ehud Barak, their suddenly ebullient prime minister.

title: To March or Not: Irish Parade Is First Lady's Latest Issue
description: Wading into one of the more complicated political issues in New York City, Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that she would like to march in the St. Patrick's Day parade in March, an event that many Democrats have boycotted because the organizers exclude gay groups.

title: New Crop Is Said to Aid Nutrition
description: The Monsanto Company said today that it had developed a genetically engineered rapeseed, a crop used to make cooking oil, that can raise the level of vitamin A in humans.

title: Serbs Send Kosovo Poet to Prison for Terrorism
description: A Serbian court today sentenced Flora Brovina, Kosovo's leading poet and a noted campaigner for women's rights, to 12 years in prison on charges of terrorism committed during the NATO air campaign in Kosovo.

title: Grocery Clerk Is Killed During Robbery Attempt
description: A clerk at a small grocery store in Brooklyn was fatally shot and the store manager was wounded during a robbery late Wednesday, the police said yesterday.

title: A Touching Tribute in Worcester
description: At a moving memorial service attended by thousands of firefighters from around the country and several foreign countries, President Clinton paid tribute yesterday to the six firemen who perished battling the inferno-like blaze that broke out at an abandoned warehouse in Worcester, Mass., last Friday. Fittingly, the President also took the occasion to pay homage to the nation's entire family of firefighters -- the men and women whose willingness to risk injury and death in order to protect others, Mr. Clinton noted, is too often taken for granted.

title: Lipinski, More Mature at 17, Blossoms as Artist on Skates
description: When she was in seventh grade, Tara Lipinski burst into big-time figure skating, a 12-year-old jumping jack long on athleticism but, understandably, undeveloped artistically.

title: Diving Into Modernism, School After School
description: He may not be the first to come to mind among the stars of American Modernism, but Alfred H. Maurer (1868-1932) was very much a pioneer. And the exhibition, ''Alfred H. Maurer: Aestheticism to Modernism'' at the Hollis Taggart Galleries, presents the evidence once again.

title: SLUMPING SALES FOR COKE BOTTLER
description: The largest Coke bottler in the Asia-Pacific region, Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd. of Australia, said slumping Philippine sales would hurt its profit in 2000, while a move to recyclable bottles and plant closings would force a one-time loss of 70 million Australian dollars ($45 million) this year. Shares in Coca-Cola Amatil, which is based in Sydney, fell 42 cents, or 8.5 percent, to 4.60 Australian dollars, their biggest one-day percentage loss in three years.

title: 30 Years Together, in Public and Private
description: Richard Morris's small, tender documentary film, ''Wallowitch and Ross: This Moment,'' peers into a cozy nook of New York's cabaret world to pay homage to the partnership (personal and professional) of the prolific songwriter John Wallowitch and his companion of more 30 years, the dancer Bertram Ross.

title: Arnott Gets the Goals, Brodeur Stops Them
description: Two power-play goals by Jason Arnott led the Devils past the hapless Chicago Blackhawks tonight, 4-0, at the United Center.

description: VAN BUREN-Margaret. We mourn the loss of our beloved founding member whose gifts of penetrating intelligence, keen observation, loving and concerned friendship, and profound faith strengthened us for many years. She is forever in our hearts as we were in hers. The Wednesday Morning Women's Bible Study Group Grace Church

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 1 about a campaign appearance by Vice President Al Gore in New Hampshire rendered a passage incorrectly in a comment he made about the contamination of Love Canal. Mr. Gore said: ''I found a little place in upstate New York called Love Canal. I had the first hearing on that issue and Toone, Tenn. But that was the one that started it all.'' He did not say ''But I was the one that started it all.''

title: Kirk Douglas Plays a Guy Resembling Kirk Douglas
description: Leading with his famous chin, Kirk Douglas (who turned 83 yesterday), gleefully devours the scenery in ''Diamonds,'' a simmered-in-schmaltz comedy about a grumpy older man determined not to go gentle into that good night. Mr. Douglas's character, Harry Agensky, a former welterweight boxing champion once known as the Polish Prince, is really a pugilistic stand-in for the star, who is shown slugging it out in the ring in clips from his 1949 movie ''The Champion.''

title: Metro Business; Western Beef Settles Suit
description: Western Beef Inc. won court approval yesterday to settle a stockholder's lawsuit over a $11.2 million management-led buyout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUCHNICK, JANET MCKINNELL
description: MUCHNICK-Janet McKinnell. Beloved wife of Nathan. Loving mother of Jill and Dana, motherin-law of Ben. Dear friend to many. Died after a long battle with cancer on December 9, 1999. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd. Manhasset NY Saturday and Sunday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Services Monday 10AM at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Chemotherapy Foundation of New York or Women's Comprehensive Center of L.I.J. ''Sail on Silver Girl, sail on by, your dreams are on your way''. We'll always love you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABBAT, SAMUEL FRANCES, M.D.
description: TABBAT-Samuel Frances, M.D. December 8, in his 86th year. Alumnus of NYU College of Medicine and Fellow of the Menninger and Austen Riggs Foundations of Psychiatry. Member of Mt. Sinai Hospital Department of Psychiatry since 1948 as Attending Physician and Assistant Clinical Professor of Psychiatry. During WW II, served five years (1941-46) with the United States Air Force as Flight Surgeon in the Pacific Theatre. Survived by wife Berta Klaif Tabbat and daughter Andrea Beth Tabbat; nephews David and Andrew Tabbat and Martin Klaif, nieces Susan Werfel and DR. Phyllis Klaif, sister in-law of Bernice Tabbat and brother in-law Bernard Klaif. Also survived by dear and faithful friends Jane Lee and Dr. Harrison Prescott Eddy, Drs. Helen and Murray Sherman, Drs. Lois and Morton Marcus, and Lawrence Bernstein among others. In accordance with his own instructions, cremation occurred on December 10. Service will be announced at a future date. Memorial tributes may be made to Jewish Family Services of Baltimore, FAMI (Friends and Advocates of the Mentally Ill), to Mt. Sinai Schizophrenia Research or to causes of one's own choice.

title: Don Harris, 61, A Versatile Master Of Rhythm and Blues
description: Don (Sugarcane) Harris, a violinist, singer and songwriter who played blues, jazz and rock, was found dead on Dec. 1 in his Los Angeles apartment by his landlord, Agence France-Presse reported. He was 61.

title: Corrections

She was named acting minister of higher education, not under secretary of education; she has served as under secretary of higher education for many years. The report also referred incompletely to Yusif Muhammad al-Ibrahim's posts. In addition to being the education minister, he is the minister of higher education.

title: FUSION MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIES PRODUCT GIVEN APPROVAL
description: Fusion Medical Technologies, a money-losing company whose shares have doubled this year, won Food and Drug Administration approval for its most important product, a gel used to stop bleeding during surgery. Known as FloSeal, it would be the company's only product on the domestic market. FloSeal combines a collagen-based gel and thrombin, a potent blood-clotting agent. It will be used in surgery on the heart, blood vessels and spine, especially where sutures, staples and fibrin glues do not close wounds well. The company, which had no revenue last year, will market the product for use in spinal surgery with Sulzer Medica, Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic products. Shares in Fusion, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., fell 93.75 cents, to $13.0625.

title: Plane Crashes Into Backyard in New Jersey, Killing All 4 On Board
description: A private twin-engine plane carrying four people from Virginia to New Jersey crashed in a residential section of Bergen County just short of its destination late yesterday and exploded in flames. Three on board were killed, and the fourth, who was hurled burning from the wreckage, died hours later.

title: An Abstract Protest From the Old School
description: The choreographer Donald McKayle is of the old school, which happens to be a valid school. Mainstream modern dance's idea that movement should go beyond design to express emotions and an inner reality is still visible in ''Danger Run,'' his latest work for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: Enberg Nearing Deal With CBS
description: Dick Enberg, one of the signature voices of NBC Sports for 24 years, is on the verge of joining CBS. My agent's working on a deal, Enberg said yesterday. It looks like something's going to happen.

title: The Focus of Diallo Murder Trial: Testimony of Four Police Officers
description: The four police officers accused of murder in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo plan to testify in their own defense at their trial next month and are leaning toward choosing a trial by a judge instead of a jury, according to their lawyers.

title: Residential Real Estate; 14th St. Revival Is Picking Up Pace With Union Square Project
description: Except for their street-level stores, the three buildings along 14th Street in Manhattan's Union Square neighborhood have remained mostly empty for decades. Now, a development group is turning those floors into rental apartments as part of the area's continued revival, which includes a number of other residential projects, dormitories for more than 2,000 New York University students and plans for a hotel.

Dear sister of Gabriel Galperin and the late Leon Galperin. Adored grandmother of Hillary, Alix, Alexander and Natasha. Great-grandmother of Ivan and Miranda. She will be deeply missed. Graveside service on Friday, 2:30 P.M. at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens, New York.

title: Homage to a Catalan's Storytelling
description: In exploring the notion of personal legacy, the longing to bequeath something lasting after death, Ventura Pons's impassioned movie ''Amic/Amat'' (''Friend'') goes where no film has gone before. This prickly psycho-sexual bramble bush of a movie, which opens the 16-film series ''Instituto Cervantes Spanish Cinema Now'' at the Walter Reade Theater today, focuses on a portly middle-aged gay professor of medieval literature who is dying of an unidentified illness and putting his life in order before carrying out an assisted suicide.

description: HERNDON-Venable. title: The Walk on Death Row Can Seem Very Long
description: Two important figures in ''The Green Mile'' happen to be a giant (Michael Clarke Duncan) and a mouse. To watch a film this unhurried (three hours) is to choose a companion for a long ocean voyage. It's a risk, and you hope that neither ship nor speaker runs out of steam.

description: DEER season, no matter how the hunting authorities define it, is in full swing right now for motorists. Indeed, without even trying, drivers of cars and trucks kill far more of the animals than outdoorsmen do with guns or arrows.

His galling defiance and America's frustrations in dealing with him have again made Iraq an issue in a United States presidential campaign.

description: New York today became the first state to produce maps showing the rates of some cancers, county by county, but the maps were quickly dismissed as useless by some of the people who conceived of the project.

title: MAKER OF GEAR-PRODUCTION EQUIPMENT AGREES TO BUYOUT
description: The Gleason Corporation, a maker of gear-production equipment, agreed to be sold for about $332 million in cash and debt in a management-led buyout to take the company private. Gleason shareholders will receive $23 a share, a 28 percent premium to Wednesday's closing price. The proposed buyers are James S. Gleason, the chairman; senior management; and the Gleason Foundation, which together own about 15 percent of the company, along with the New York buyout firm Vestar Capital Partners. Sales of the company, which is based in Rochester, have dropped 18 percent through the third quarter because of lower domestic demand for metalworking equipment. Gleason shares rose $5.50, to $23.50, yesterday.

title: Dating Game: One's a Clown
description: ''Cherry,'' produced and directed by Joseph Pierson and Jon Glascoe, is a romantic comedy in which a supermodel, Shalom Harlow, plays a faux naive 29-year-old virgin, attracting suitors who include a bashful gynecologist and a clown. Toxic as that sounds, this modest, easygoing date movie has its charms. Not least of them are good humor and the refreshing absence of any misanthropic edge. The film's obvious affection for its characters makes up for its case of the cutes.

title: In a House Full of Nudity, Emotions Are Naked, Too
description: The most troubling events in ''The War Zone'' take place inside a cement bunker, but that's not what gives the film its name. The actual battlefield is the rural English home where a teenager named Tom (Freddie Cunliffe) looks at his own family with helpless rage and astonishment.

title: The Joylessness of Sex in Class-Riven 1890's Sweden
description: Filmed with hand-held cameras that chase the characters around a roomy 1890's-style Swedish kitchen, Mike Figgis's screen adaptation of August Strindberg's drama ''Miss Julie'' would like to persuade us that the forces driving its vicious sexual conflict are as volcanic today as they were a century ago.

title: McCain to Sue for Spot on Primary Ballot
description: Senator John McCain announced yesterday that he would sue to obtain a spot in New York's Republican presidential primary, contending that the state party had laid down a thicket of election rules to ensure that its preferred candidate, Gov. George W. Bush, goes unchallenged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUN, AN, CHU
description: SUN-An-Chu, 65 years old, in Shanghai, China. Farewell to a brave, virtuous man and loving father, husband and grandfather. The world will miss him as will his family and many friends. Love, Gu-Yan, Ching, Min, Wen and Ping

title: Arterial-Device Patent Suit
description: A unit of Medtronic Inc., the leading global provider of pacemakers, has accused the Cordis Corporation unit of Johnson & Johnson of infringing on a patent. In the suit, filed in federal court, Medtronic AVE, formerly Arterial Vascular Engineering Inc., stated that it owned a patent issued a year ago for placing stents -- used to hold open arteries -- with a tiny balloon at the end of a wire.

title: Revived Nets Looking for Prosperity
description: After a season-opening month in which they were plagued by nearly every form of negativity imaginable -- from bricklaying to bickering -- the Nets may finally be in for a period of prosperity. The winners of their last two games, the Nets are in position to complete a four-game winning streak by the week's end.

title: Bush the Debater
description: Many well-known Republicans are unimpressed with George W. Bush's debating skills, but they disagree about whether those skills should be of great concern to his supporters.

title: Transportation Board Hurt by 'Serious Overload,' Study Finds
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is facing increasing doubt, from inside its ranks and from outside aviation experts, about its ability to investigate complex airline accidents as it tries to re-structure itself and cope with a variety of high-stakes investigations.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Interrupted Life, Interrupted Work

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRA, EDMOND J.
description: SAFRA-Edmond J. Yad Avraham Institute, its Officers, Directors and members record with deep sorrow and mourn the tragic and untimely loss of our beloved and esteemed patron. For the past decade, he provided a home for us with love and enthusiasm in his Beit Yaakov Synagogue. His support enabled Yad Avraham, an institution devoted to teaching Torah, to grow and flourish. In his merit, thousands have passed through its portals to partake of the wellspring of Torah, and hundreds have returned as committed Jews. He asked little, yet gave so much. We will sorely miss him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Lily, her children and grandchildren and the entire Safra family. May all those touched by his chesed be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yosef Kalatsky, Dean David S. Lobel, President Bruce Rappaport, Major Benefactor Ira Rennert, Director Louis Glick, Director Yad Avraham Institute

title: Who Will Defend the Homeless?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYRO, JERRY
description: MAYRO-Jerry. Bibliophile, Philanthropist, Cherished Friend. He touched the lives of all who entered his Burlington Bookshop. Each time he left a friend he never said ''goodbye.'' So we say: '' 'til we meet again.'' The Partners of LCS & Z Glickman Lutz

title: Lari Pittman
description: Barbara Gladstone Gallery

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell more than 1 percent after Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said the administration would not let prices rise too high. In New York, crude oil for January delivery fell 39 cents, to $26.15 a barrel.

title: Fritz Fischer, 91; German Historian Blamed Germany for First War
description: Fritz Fischer, the German historian who rankled his peers and Germans in general with the thesis that Imperial Germany was squarely responsible for World War I and its consequences, died on Dec. 1 in Hamburg. He was 91.

title: A Death Row Drama
description: In ''The Green Mile,'' Tom Hanks, left, plays one of the death row guards who are awestruck by a huge, childlike prisoner (Michael Clarke Duncan) and transformed by his presence. Frank Darabont's version of Stephen King's drama unfolds at a length more often seen in Eugene O'Neill. Is this greatness or reason to squirm in your seat?

title: Who Will Defend the Homeless?
description: To the Editor:

title: All This Ship's a Stage, Performing on the Waterfront
description: It started out about 30 years ago as a one-wagon operation, traveling around Vancouver Island, putting on puppet shows. Eventually, the founders, Paul Kirby and Adriana Kelder, expanded the company to six large wagons they built themselves. A team of bay Clydesdales pulled the wagons all over the country, and the company put on shows under a tent with 25 actors, musicians, artists and technicians.

title: Albany's Health Care Impasse
description: The fight over health care in Albany is threatening to delay renewal of a crucial state law that will expire on Dec. 31. The Legislature is expected to hold a special session next week, but in typical Albany fashion, the negotiations between Gov. George Pataki and legislative leaders are cloaked in secrecy, and nothing may get done. If the Legislature fails to act, the expiration of the law, the Health Care Reform Act, could cause serious disruptions for the whole health care system.

title: A St. Patrick's Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: To Dare Young Voices, An Opera Not a Warhorse
description: Although the primary mission of the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater is to give the school's students the experience of learning and performing fully staged operas, it accomplishes this in a way that is guaranteed to bring those students committed and discerning listeners. It avoids the ''Bohemes,'' the ''Traviatas'' and the other staples that can be heard in either of New York's big opera houses throughout the seasons.

title: Short Guide to Finding Bargains On-Line
description: PARIS  The Internet offers travelers an enormous resource for finding bargains, for making reservations and for obtaining up-to-the-minute information that printed guidebooks cannot match. As a result, the travel industry is fast becoming a major player on the World Wide Web.

title: Committee Considers Change in Reporting On Gene Therapies
description: Addressing heightened concern about the safety of gene therapy experiments and the openness of the scientists who conduct them, a government advisory committee considered today whether to require researchers to make information about all patient deaths public, whether related to the therapy or not.

title: Bush the Reader, Bush the Debater
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Green Trumps Black and White; In Harlem's Business Boom, Victors and Victims Come in All Races
description: First the rent on Desmond Parkin's optometry business on 125th Street in Harlem went ''through the roof.'' Then a Sterling Optical store moved in across the street. Dr. Parkin, 36, had thought he would retire in Harlem. Instead, unable to compete, he decamped for Brooklyn, abandoning his old space to a Starbucks coffee shop.

title: PRECEPT BUSINESS TO SELL TRANSPORTATION UNIT
description: Precept Business Services Inc., the largest independent distributor of printed business products in the United States, agreed yesterday to sell its transportation-services division to a management-led buyout group. The purchase price is $27 million in cash and about $2 million in additional payments based on future operating results. Precept will also assume $6 million in cash. Ron Sorci, the division's president, is leading the investor group. Precept's travel division provides town car, limousine and livery services in Texas, New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Ohio, Kentucky and Michigan.

title: The Law on Homeless Shelters
description: Many New Yorkers were rightly disturbed when the Giuliani administration argued that excessively harsh new rules allowing the city to eject families with children from homeless shelters should be rushed into effect before Christmas. The administration's decision yesterday to delay imposing the new rules pending resolution of a court challenge was a prudent one. The fact that the appeals court has given both sides until Dec. 20 to submit filings now raises a realistic hope that this overly harsh policy on evictions from shelters will at least be delayed until after the holidays. That will be a relief for every citizen who does not share the feeling voiced by city lawyers that the season should have nothing to do with the city's efforts to make homeless families work for shelter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Composite Index Reaches Yet Another High

title: Historians' Report Blames Swiss for Barring Jews During War
description: A panel of independent historians has concluded that wartime Swiss officials refused entry to thousands of Jewish refugees even after it was known that they faced almost certain death in Nazi Germany.

title: Turkey Accepts European Union's Offer but Without Jubilation
description: With neither side sure what lies ahead, Turkey shook Europe's outstretched hand today.

title: Teen Loses 3 Fingers Making a Bomb at Home
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth lost three fingers from his right hand yesterday morning after he set off an explosive device he made using information from the Internet, police officials said.

title: Growing Economic Strength and Tighter Labor Supply Predicted for Next Year
description: While 1999 has been a good year for Long Island's economy, 2000 is expected to be even better, economists and business executives said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, ALICE
description: TANNENBAUM-Alice. On December 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Dear mother of Lana (Steven) Wechsler and Steven (Doris) Tannenbaum. Adored grandmother of Alison, David, Jeffrey and Stefanie. Services Sunday, December 12, 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, JOHN A.
description: GOLDNER-John A. On December 10, 1999 at the age of 88. Loving husband of the late Helen. John died at his home in Elmhurst, NY. Mr. Goldner worked for the Madison Square Garden his entire career, except for WWII. Mr. Goldner was Booking Manager for all of the Garden's sporting events, and he was particularly influential in the development of both college and professional basketball programs. He helped mold the first National Invitational Tournament in 1938 and the initial N.C.A.A. Tournament in the Garden in 1939. In 1946, Mr. Goldner was appointed the New York Knicks first General Manager and Travelling Secretary. In March, 1999 Mr. Golddner was inducted into the N.I.T. (Hall of Fame). Recently in September, 1999 he was inducted into the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame. Visiting will be at the Neufeld Funeral Home, 88-04 43rd Avenue, Elmhurst, on Sunday, December 12, 3-7PM. Funeral services are private on Monday.

title: Bush the Reader, Bush the Debater
description: To the Editor:

title: Deep in the Wilderness, a Growth Industry Is Blooming
description: For parents like Mitchell and Jill Friedman of Great Neck, N.Y., the decision to enroll a child in a wilderness program for troubled teenagers is born of desperation, a last chance to rescue a life endangered by drugs, crime or simply aimlessness. In the Friedmans' case, the outcome was worth the anguish.

title: Lee's Defenders Say the Scientist Is a Victim of a Witch Hunt Against China
description: Lawyers for Wen Ho Lee reacted to his indictment today with anger and dismay, while a former high-ranking government lawyer said the charges arose at least partly because Dr. Lee is of Chinese descent and the current political climate ''demonizes China.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about life expectancy and Social Security misstated the given name of the professor of demography and economics at Berkeley who predicted that life expectancy would increase more quickly than actuaries foresaw. He is Ronald D. Lee, not Richard.

title: Safety Board Retains Control of EgyptAir Case
description: After appearing eager last month to turn over the investigation of the Egypt Air crash to the F.B.I., the National Transportation Safety Board said today that it would hold on to the case for at least another month and do a thorough investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASHIN, PEARL TAUB
description: SASHIN-Pearl Taub. On Tuesday, December 7, 1999 of respiratory failure. Beloved wife of the late David Sashin, M.D. Beloved mother of Donald Sashin of Pittsburgh, Helene Sashin of New York and the late Jerome Sashin. Beloved mother-in-law of Kathleen Sashin, Bonnie Sashin and Stephen Adophus. Beloved sister of Rose Perlman of New York, the late Allan Taub and Fred Taub. Beloved grandmother of Daphne Sashin, Deirdre Sashin and Courtney Sashin. Great grandmother of Shelby and Monique. Service will be held on Sunday at 11:30am at The ''Riverside'' , West 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. Visitation 10:30-11:30AM. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY. For further information call Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc. Pittsburgh, PA, 1-888-621-8282.

title: Cox Undergoes Surgery And Is Out for Season
description: Rather than endure the pain that came every Sunday and prevented him from practicing the last two months, linebacker Bryan Cox had surgery today on a torn abdominal muscle that ended his season.

title: AOL Is Said To Be in Talks With Wal-Mart On an Alliance
description: The world's biggest retailer and the nation's top Internet access provider are in talks about forming a far-reaching alliance to market each others' products and services, according to people who have been briefed on the discussions.

title: Regulate Doctors' Hours
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing Teenager Makes a Wish, to Play With the Philharmonic
description: Clutching her black oboe case and looking for all the world like any other teenager out with her family to share the merriment of the season, Johanna Johnson arrived at Lincoln Center on Thursday and made her way to the Christmas tree at the fountain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTNETT, ANNE (NEE MCKENNA)
description: HARTNETT-Anne (nee McKenna). On December 9, 1999 in Laurel, MD (native of County Tyrone, Ireland). Beloved wife of the late William P. Devoted mother of William J., Mary Ellen Glasheen, Anne Marie Kelly, Catherine Kiser and Patricia Kelly. Also survived by 11 grandchildren. Reposing at David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball Ave.), Yonkers. Visiting hours Sunday 2-5:00 PM only. Funeral Mass Monday 9:45 AM, St. Barnabas Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Couple Is Found Shot to Death In Their Apartment in the Bronx
description: An elderly Bronx couple known for taking in foster children was found shot to death yesterday afternoon in their Soundview apartment, the police said.

title: So Hobbled and Yet Serenely Certain
description: Kazuo Ohno packed the Japan Society theater on Thursday night with an audience that ranged from solemn gray-haired matrons to magenta-crested teenagers. His performances there sold out so quickly that a matinee has been added tomorrow afternoon at the society (333 East 47th Street, Manhattan). None of that is surprising.

title: Princess Scherbatow, 85; Active in Nobility Group
description: Princess Kathleen Comerford McLoughlin Scherbatow, who had been active in the Russian Nobility Association in America, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 85 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Panama Feels Slighted When Albright Cancels Date at Canal
description: With the symbolic handover of the Panama Canal days away, Panamanian officials were given a disheartening preview of their rapidly changing relationship with the United States when they learned that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright would skip the ceremony on Tuesday to attend Mideast peace talks in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOGARTY, MATTHEW J.
description: FOGARTY-Matthew J. In loving memory. Today you would have been 49. We miss you more than words can say. Mom and Dad

title: Barbaric Death Penalty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Op-Art
description: 1. THE GREAT WALL.

title: China Signs Pact to Give Serbia $300 Million for Reconstruction
description: China has signed a deal to advance the Belgrade government $300 million in cash and credits to aid the reconstruction of Yugoslavia after the NATO bombing this year, according to Yugoslav officials.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLEGHENY TECHNOLOGIES INC. -- Pittsburgh, increased its stock buyback program by 10 million shares. As of Thursday, the company had bought back 7.7 million shares of stock worth $173.3 million.

title: Spy Bug Artfully Set
description: Russian spies or accomplices installed an eavesdropping device in a State Department conference room by removing a piece of molding and replacing it with a nearly identical piece with the electronic bug embedded inside, investigators said.

title: Clinton Goes 'Home' to Arkansas, Talking Like a Former President
description: President Clinton still has more than 13 months left in office, but he was clearly focusing on his future after the White House today as he made a nostalgic homecoming trip to his native state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONTOWNIK, ABRAHAM
description: GONTOWNIK - Abraham. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the loss of Abraham Gontownik, father of our esteemed friend, Jerry Gontownik. May Jerry and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: AOL Waltzes Into Brazil, Unprepared for the Samba
description: At a lavish party here in mid-November to commemorate its introduction in Latin America's largest country, America Online's future in Brazil seemed bright. The top Internet service provider rented a concert hall and treated 1,700 guests to Champagne, hors d'oeuvres and a show by Carlinhos Brown, the dreadlocked percussionist pop star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTOS, ANGELICA
description: SANTOS-Angelica. The Dalton community is deeply saddened by the loss of Dalton parent Angelica Santos. Our thoughts are with the family at this time.

title: Plane Was Off Course Before Fatal Crash
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., Dec. 10 -- The twin-engine plane that plunged into a backyard here Thursday evening, killing its pilot and three passengers, was off course and approaching Teterboro Airport from the wrong direction when it crashed, a federal investigator said today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell more than 3 percent after the United Nations renewed a program that lets Iraq export oil to pay for food and medicine. In New York, crude oil for January delivery fell 92 cents, to $25.23 a barrel.

title: Tudjman Is Dead; Croat Led Country Out of Yugoslavia
description: President Franjo Tudjman, the onetime Communist general who as a reborn nationalist led Croatia in 1991 into secession from Yugoslavia, and from there to independence and war, has died, Croatian state television announced early today. He was 77.

title: The Neediest Cases; Helping a Stricken Family Through a Tearful Year
description: When Besquer Martinez, 37, needs to cry, he takes a walk to the park or locks himself in the bathroom. He weeps alone, he said, because he must be strong for his wife, Eva, whose eyes fill with tears every time she talks about what happened to their sons this year.

title: Giuliani Offers Plan to Handle Transit Strike
description: Warning that a walkout by 33,000 subway and bus workers was ''very possible'' next week, city officials yesterday released parts of a 61-page emergency plan that would ban cars with only one occupant from most of Manhattan during rush hour, allow taxis to pick up multiple fares and close school on the first day of the strike.

title: A Second Job for Fun: That's Living?
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Issues Continue Gain, and Dow Goes Up 89.91
description: Another day, another Internet takeoff.

title: Sports of The Times; Now Ewing Must Fit In, Not Stand Out
description: PATRICK EWING didn't save the Knicks last night. He didn't ruin them either. He helped them defeat Philadelphia in his comeback game at Madison Square Garden. There was no civil war, and by Knick standards, it was actually more of a love-in.

title: AutoZone Raises Buyback
description: The auto parts maker AutoZone Inc. said today that it would buy back up to an additional $200 million of its common stock. The move increases a planned buyback to a total of $800 million. Shares of AutoZone climbed $1.875 each, to $31.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. AutoZone's board approved a similar buyback three months ago. AutoZone, based in Memphis, has annual revenue of $4.22 billion.

title: Basis of Charges Against Wen Ho Lee
description: Following is the United States Code under which Wen Ho Lee was charged:
