description: In percent

title: Trickle of Chechen Refugees Brave a Risky Escape Route
description: After enduring two months of thunderous bombardments, a trickle of dispirited refugees straggled out of the besieged Chechen capital today and made their way to the Russian military checkpoint in the Tersky hills three miles away.

title: Yeltsin in China
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANCE TELECOM SHARES PLUMMET
description: Shares in France Telecom tumbled 8 percent after the company's expansion plans in Germany's profitable wireless phone market were thwarted by a competing bid for the German cell phone provider E-Plus Mobilfunk. The rival bid was a joint offer from BellSouth and the Dutch phone company Royal KPN. In October, France Telecom agreed to acquire a 60.25 percent controlling stake in E-Plus from two German utilities -- Veba A.G. and RWE A.G. -- but that deal was upset after BellSouth teamed with KPN to exercise a pre-emptive right to acquire the shares. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: STRONGER RESULTS AT GUCCI
description: The Italian luxury goods maker Gucci Group N.V., which recently took over the company that controls Yves Saint Laurent, said strong sales in the United States and a revival of its line of leather goods helped to double its profit in the third quarter, to $96 million, or 97 cents a share, up from $47.3 million a year ago. Gucci, which is based in the Netherlands for tax reasons, said revenue from sales in the United States rose 33 percent, helping to increase its overall revenue 21 percent, to $306 million. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONOWITZ, EVELYN G.
description: ARONOWITZ-Evelyn G. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons notes with sadness the passing of Evelyn G. Aronowitz, beloved mother of Ellin Delsener. We extend condolences to Ellin and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Pincay Moves Past Shoemaker With No. 8,834
description: One day after tying the legendary Bill Shoemaker, Laffit Pincay Jr. raced past him today, becoming the winningest jockey in thoroughbred history by picking up victory No. 8,834 in his 44,647th ride.

title: STOCK OF IRIDIUM TUMBLES 45% FOLLOWING WARNING
description: The publicly traded stock of Iridium L.L.C. fell 45 percent today after a warning from Iridium that the stock will probably be worthless after the bankrupt company reorganizes. The shares of Iridium World Communications Ltd., Iridium's investment vehicle, closed yesterday at $3.50, down $2.875, or 45 percent, after the warning late Thursday that it was ''highly unlikely'' that shares would retain any value after a reorganization. Iridium World shares now trade on the pink sheets. Iridium World's shares had surged in the last two and a half weeks, since they began trading again after a three-month halt in the wake of the August filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy by Iridium L.L.C.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the Mercury space capsule that was recovered from the Atlantic last summer referred incorrectly to the dimes found inside. While often called Mercury dimes, the coins depict a representation of Liberty with a winged cap, not the Roman god Mercury.

title: Crowded Knicks Make Room as Ewing Returns
description: There was the clock running down, the ball cradled in his hands and an appreciative crowd egging him on as its gentle applause swelled into a cheer. And at this final moment of the game, neither fatigue nor rust could sway Patrick Ewing from his natural instinct.

title: Beliefs; When all the religions of the world are truly global, some old issues assume new forms.
description: Globalization: it's a curious contraption of a word, a noun built on a verb, globalize, built on an adjective, global, built on a noun, globe. By now, however, the word not only rolls around rather easily in the mouth; it has also become irreplaceable for discussing the kind of issues that brought demonstrators to the streets in Seattle a week ago. It is also a notion applicable to religion.

title: 2 New Bridge Books Capture 60 Years of Hands and Feats
description: For those interested in the history of the game and the great hands that have been played in the last 60 years, one new book and one old one will have considerable appeal. The first is ''The Bermuda Bowl'' by Henry Francis and Brian Senior. The 252-page book, a complete history of the world team championship, is available from Baron Barclay Bridge Supplies at 800-274-2221 for $35.95. This prestigious event will be played next month in Bermuda, where it was first played half a century ago.

title: Datus C. Smith Jr., 92, Leader Of Princeton University Press
description: Datus C. Smith Jr., former director of the Princeton University Press, died on Nov. 17 at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 92 and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDELMAN, JULIUS
description: EIDELMAN-Julius. On December 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Edith Kalmanowitz Eidelman, devoted father of the late Barbara Eidelman Wachs, Arthur Eidelman and Aaron Eidelman, father-in-law of Saul Wachs, Arleen Eidelman and Sherry Eidelman, and grandfather of Sharona Wachs Cashman, Hillel Wachs, Devorah Wachs-Rozner, Aviva Wachs-Botita, Aura Eidelman Geffen, Yael Eidelman Hod, Ronain Eidelman, Elie Eidelman, Dov Eidelman and Ilana Eidelman. Funeral Sunday, December 12th, 12 noon, Jeffer Chapel, 4620 Ft. Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, Shiva until Friday 1 P.M., New Rochelle, New York.

title: U.S. Is Trying To Put Teeth In Inspections Of Iraq Arms
description: As disagreements between the United States and Russia continue to delay action on a new arms-inspection plan for Iraq, independent disarmament experts are divided over how important it is to try to put in place an airtight monitoring system if the cost is Security Council unity against President Saddam Hussein.

title: Costas to Anchor HBO Program
description: Bob Costas will anchor a weekly Nightline-type sports program for HBO Sports starting in February 2001, HBO and NBC Sports will announce Tuesday.

title: Police Poll Finds Strong Support From Blacks and Hispanics
description: A poll commissioned by the New York Police Department to measure the effectiveness of a recent advertising campaign has found that most city residents respect the police, including a solid majority of the blacks and Hispanics interviewed.

title: Letter by Bradley's Doctor
description: Following is a letter to former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey from his doctor, Robert H. Heissenbutel. The letter, which was dated Thursday, was made public yesterday by Mr. Bradley's presidential campaign.

title: 'Don't Ask' Policy Is Utter Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Harrison Sanford, 96, Coach Who Inspired Cornell Rowers
description: Harrison Sanford, a coach revered by his Cornell oarsmen, died last Saturday in Gulfport, Miss. He was 96.

title: Costco Abandons Plans For a 14th Street Store
description: Costco, the national warehouse club that is trying to establish a presence in Manhattan, no longer plans to open a supermarket on the site of the 14th Street Armory, company officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARLIN, SENDER
description: GARLIN-Sender. Tireless fighter in the struggle for social justice, died peacefully at his home in Boulder, CO on December 6 at age 97. Author of the book ''Three American Radicals'' and many articles and pamphlets as a labor journalist. A captivating speaker with incisive wit and remarkable historical memory. The Garlins: his wife, Martha Millet Garlin, daughter Emily, son Alexander, daughter-in-law Virginia Chavez, granddaughter Annelise of Boulder, CO; son Victor, daughter-inlaw Marjorie Baird Garlin, and granddaughters Amy and Rachel, of Berkeley, California.

title: The Transcontinental Railroad as the Internet of 1869
description: After a freezing May night in 1869 at an isolated Utah settlement called Promontory Summit, a crowd gathered to watch as a final iron spike was driven into an unfinished railroad track. The spike and silver hammer, both wired to a telegraph line, made an electrical connection that sent a signal through the nation's network. It proclaimed the completion of the transcontinental railroad whose tracks wound through the Sierra Nevada, thrust across the central plains and splayed across the East Coast.

title: A Spy's Bug Set Artfully In Woodwork, U.S. Concedes
description: Russian spies or their accomplices managed to place a sophisticated eavesdropping device in a conference room on the executive floor of the State Department by removing a piece of wall molding and replacing it with a nearly identical piece with the electronic bug embedded inside, government officials said today.

title: TAKEOVER OFFER IS REJECTED
description: A British newspaper publisher, News Communications and Media P.L.C., rejected a cash offer for the whole company from the Gannett Company, the big United States newspaper publisher. The British company, which has a market value of about $463 million, said the offer ''seriously undervalued'' it. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: It Wasn't Mere Carelessness, the Government Maintains
description: In a 59-count indictment in federal court in Albuquerque, the government today accused Wen Ho Lee not just of being a scientist who inadvertently mishandled classified materials but also of being someone who repeatedly and willfully compromised America's most sensitive nuclear secrets.

title: Back to Haydn and Chopin, Forward to John Corigliano
description: Emanuel Ax's recital program at Carnegie Hall the other night reflected the breadth of his musical interests, so far as one can tell from his discography and his recent concert appearances. Chopin, the composer with whom Mr. Ax was most closely associated at the start of his career, in the 1970's, took up the second half of Monday's program. The passion for Haydn that was evident in his recordings of the late 1980's and early 1990's was represented in his opener, the Sonata in A flat (Hob. XVI:46). There were more recent interests -- works by Debussy that Mr. Ax has not yet recorded, and John Corigliano's ''Fantasia on an Ostinato,'' a new addition to the new-music repertory that has been such an enlivening part of Mr. Ax's repertory in recent years.

title: Just the Best In Ellington's Sacred Works
description: The church of Duke Ellington admitted many denominations: gospel, opera, tap and interpretive dance, European orchestral music and hot, small-group percussiveness. His three Sacred Concerts, given their premieres in 1965, 1968 and 1973, weren't jazz Masses: he insisted on a difference between talking to God and, as he described his own efforts, ''people talking to people about God.'' So he took his jazz conception, complete with elements of a nightclub show, into cathedrals. On record, the Sacred Concerts are bold curiosities, sometimes streaked with greatness, sometimes grand and less than inspired. They're not universally admired and are seldom performed. But one thing about them now seems certain: while the path of incorporating nonjazz into jazz is strewn with failures, Ellington's aesthetic generosity made that experiment succeed.

title: A Pianist's Legacy of Art That Lives, With No Need for Farewell
description: A caress can sometimes accompany the chill of death. Or at least so it seemed when I first heard Arthur Rubinstein play. It was some 30 years ago; the pianist was in his 80's and said to be frail. And the presence of Chopin's Sonata No. 2 on the program, with its familiar ''Funeral March,'' did not lighten concerns that he might never be heard again. In fact when he began that often hackneyed march (linked by popular culture with the words ''pray for the dead and the dead will pray for you''), it seemed as if a shroud had been cast over the audience. A swift, silent intake of breath was held almost without exhale until the movement's final dying chord.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAINE, HANS, DR.
description: WAINE-Hans, Dr., medical leader, pioneer in the then new field of rheumatology, journalist and historian, died on December 5. Born in 1907 in Hagen, Germany, Dr. Waine earned a PhD under the noted Swiss Theologian Karl Barth prior to his medical career. He was Foreign Editor for the Berliner Kreuz Zeitung, and later received an MA from Columbia School of Journalism. Married Edith Sutro Loewenstein. Earned his MD at Harvard Medical School in 1937. Dr. Waine worked in the world famous Arthritis Unit of the M.G.H. He was the first Medical Director of the Massachusetts Chapter of Arthritis Foundation, Chief of Staff of the Boston Dispensary, Director of the Rheumatic Disease Training Program of the Tufts-New England Medical Center, and Professor of Medicine at Tufts University School of Medicine. Dr. Waine was an enthusiastic and inspiring teacher. As Chairman of Grants at the National Institute of Arthritis and Metabolic Diseases, he oversaw research and training at medical schools nationwide. He was an avid sailor and an accomplished amateur horticulturist, winning numerous awards. He was a member of the St. Botolph Club of Boston, the Cambridge Boat Club, the Pelagic Sailing Club and the New Bedford Yacht Club. Dr. Waine is survived by his wife, Edith, and by three children, Martin, Kenneth, and Peter. A daughter, Susan, died in 1996. A memorial is planned for next summer at Salters Point, South Dartmouth, MA where the Waine family has spent summers for over forty years. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Harvard Medical School for research on health and development in early childhood.

title: Lo, the Tourist
description: To the Editor: With regard to Richard O'Mara's article ''The Unapologetic Tourist'' (Nov. 21): While today the word tourist has largely pejorative connotations, it is interesting to note that the Hebrew word ''toor'' -- which is similar in meaning -- appears in the Bible in many places. The possibility that the English word is linked to the Hebrew one is intriguing if uncertain. When Moses is commanded to send spies to the Land of Canaan, the Bible tells us, ''These are the names of the men whom Moses sent to spy out the Land'' (Numbers 13:16). What is often translated as ''to spy'' is, in Hebrew, ''latoor.'' ''La'' means ''to,'' and the root ''toor'' connotes more a notion of searching than spying. This is corroborated in the verse that follows, ''See the Land, what it is'' as well as in Ecclesiastes 1:13, (''To seek and to search'' -- latoor).

Excerpts rather than the full scores prevail, leaving room for a larger number of shorter pieces. Into that space, a globalized ecumenicism has moved. Volpe is to be sentenced tomorrow to a term that could be life in prison without the possibility of parole.

Leaving our kids with their Australian grandparents outside Melbourne, my husband, Warren, and I devoted a day last March -- the end of the Southern summer -- to traveling what may be Australia's best coastal drive.

title: Lo, the Tourist
description: To the Editor: My first trip to Europe took place the summer immediately after World War II. Apropos of the discussion of the difference between a traveler and a tourist, I can vouch that ''tourist'' was often a term of derision and contempt in prewar Europe.

description: Doctors have successfully used gene therapy to treat a form of hemophilia. The results, which produced a blood-clotting protein without adverse side effects, were reported in research connected with hemophilia B, which affects about 5,000 Americans, or 20 percent of all hemophiliacs in America. LAWRENCE M. FISHER

What a shame the writer didn't meet Katherine Kashine, the first Persian P.T.A. president at Baker Hill School, where the Persian population is in the minority. Or that she didn't run across a Peruvian Jew, a Mexican, a Puerto Rican, a Filipino, an American and two Persian women, all 40-something moms who are soccer buddies (we play) and bowling pals; whose children are friends, and celebrate every Halloween together since most of them wore born; who share recipes, happy times and sad, and all consider themselves Americans, Great Neck residents and best friends.

description: DR. PAMELA F. GALLIN knows that if she, despite being a pediatric ophthalmologist, has had trouble figuring out how to get the best medical care for her four children, then so too have parents who do not have a medical degree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUCHNICK, JAN
description: MUCHNICK-Jan. The members of the Steering Committee of Partners in Women's Health at the Ann and Jules Gottlieb Women's Comprehensive Health Center of Long Island Jewish Hospital are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and colleague. Her devotion and exuberance was inspiration to all of us. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband Natie and family.

description: If viewers really want to thank somebody for ''Now and Again,'' CBS's popular new drama, look no further than the executive producer's teenage daughter.

description: Hirschberg's article brought my grandmother, Dorothy Kramer Levy, a Rosalee shopper, back to me in vivid detail. One of my last memories of sharing time with her was sitting in the corner of her dressing room at the Rosalee as she tried on wool suits (for ''the holidays'').

title: Course Records Set At National Meet
description: Dathan Ritzenhein of Michigan and Victoria Chang of Hawaii capitalized on unusually cool and comfortable running conditions to race to course-record victories yesterday in the Foot Locker national high school cross-country championships at the Disney Sports Complex in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

title: Judge Upholds Bar To Mall Expansion
description: Saks Fifth Avenue's proposed move from the Village of Garden City to Roosevelt Field, the Island's largest shopping mall two miles away, met another roadblock last week when State Supreme Court Justice Burton S. Joseph upheld the Hempstead Town Board of Zoning Appeals' rejection of the mall's expansion.

title: Scaling an urban mountain, of steel
description: Sydney, long a staging area for adventures of all sorts, offers some outdoor thrills of its own. I first see the climbers on Sydney's monumental Harbour Bridge from the rooftop spa of the Park Hyatt, where I'm staying. The hotel stands at the base of the 3,770-foot-long bridge, which has only been open for trekking since October 1998. After seeing the clumps of climbers, tiny as ants, along the muscular arch, I ask the concierge to sign me up.

title: Unicef Says War Affects Poor Children In the Millions
description: After centuries of great advances in science and economic development, a rash of brutish, primitive wars is setting back the lives of millions of the world's poorest people, mostly children and their mothers, Unicef says in a new report.

title: Driving Yourself To Distraction
description: OPINIONS about cell phones in cars are running high these days. Sales people, investors and soccer parents say they cannot manage without their electronic links. But the safety of talking on the phone in the flow of traffic is coming under question.

title: Bradley Calls Heart Problem 'A Nuisance,' Not an Issue
description: Bill Bradley entered a conference room in the Hyatt Rickey's here today looking every bit the fit, relaxed presidential candidate. Smiling broadly, he shook hands with the three dozen assembled reporters and said: ''I'm feeling great. No problem. I'm glad you're interested.''

title: The Way We Live Now
description: Like Abbott Combes, I tie one on every day. The necktie is the only purely decorative article permitted the man for whom the ear stud and bracelet are unthinkable.

title: TO DIAL FOR
description: Jonathan Adler

title: At Bush's Ear, A Supply-Sider With a Heart
description: LAWRENCE B. LINDSEY, the former Federal Reserve governor who is now George W. Bush's chief economic adviser, sees himself as a mere technician, helping to turn the presidential candidate's vision into nuts-and-bolts programs.

title: Removing Vestibule At a Co-op
description: Q: Our co-op board decided to remove the inner door to our lobby. This action has resulted in the elimination of the vestibule. For 35 years the building has had a doorman, intercom system and vestibule area that prevented direct access to the lobby. Now there is only one door, and when the doorman opens it, anyone can enter the lobby. Can you tell me if this is a reduction in services since there is clearly a decrease in safety and security? . . . Sheila Perlmutter, Manhattan.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-12-99: Counter Culture; Not a Straight Story
description: Among the benefits of presidential campaigns is that they can provide a cultural snapshot of where the country is. Eight years ago, Bill Clinton was the first major candidate to seek money directly from gay donors. Four years ago, Bob Dole accepted, turned down and then accepted a check from the Log Cabin Republicans, a gay G.O.P. group. This year, George W. Bush drew flak for not personally meeting with the group. And in the latest sign of cultural change, the Gore campaign manager is Donna Brazile, a single black woman. Until recently, Brazile was an advocate in gay politics and sat on the board of the Millennium March on Washington, a gay rights demonstration planned for April.

title: Harking to Sounds Sacred and Secular
description: The ''Holiday Klezmerfest'' is one way to celebrate the season. But orchestras, chamber ensembles, choral groups, jazz bands and church choirs have been rehearsing an abundance of other options. These are some of the holiday concerts scheduled in New Jersey this month.

title: New Directions in the March of Science
description: Here at the threshold of a new millennium, the pace of scientific and technological advance seems overwhelming. Computers are obsolescent the moment we buy them. New discoveries at the farthest reaches of the universe leave us awestruck. Scientists are racing to delineate the entire human genome.

title: Huntington Bias Suit Gets Some Settlements
description: Some settlements have been reached in thediscrimination lawsuit filed against the Town of Huntington by 40 present and former highway department employees.

title: Surfing for Art In Offbeat Places
description: Before museums started exhibiting motorcycles to bring the masses to art, the Percent for Art program was taking art to the masses. With a budget of more than $10 million, the program has shown more than 130 artworks to people in the most public of spaces: schools, courthouses, parks, community centers, police precinct houses and the occasional prison.

title: Clearing a Path To Find Work
description: Mary L. Robinson had been happily employed before an accident sent her into the hospital and out of the work force. It has been a long road back, not just physically, but psychologically. ''I lost confidence in myself,'' she says. Whether with counseling or language training, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund supports programs that prepare people for work.

title: Swap With Developer Saves Pinelands Tracts
description: More than 4,000 acres in the Pinelands that are subject to development will be preserved as open space in return for allowing building elsewhere, under an agreement announced last week by Governor Whitman and the New Jersey Nature Conservancy.

title: Death Sentence for 1876 Building, Reprieve for Its Facade
description: Despite a last-ditch effort to preserve the 1876 Coogan Building, the city's Landmarks Preservation has Commission decided not to restore the landmark status of the red brick building, a former racquet club, a commission spokeswoman said.

Ginger Sullivan and Dr. Louis W. Sullivan of Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. Spenser Simrill performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip in Atlanta.

title: Under Attack, Leading Rival Of Milosevic Joins the Fray
description: A new rancorous round of accusation and intimidation between the authorities and the opposition erupted in Belgrade this week. What has made this bout particularly heated, and potentially significant, is that it involves the largest opposition party and state security officials who seem increasingly tough in cracking down on independent action.

title: A City Emptied, and Revealed
description: For most New Yorkers, Manhattan with empty streets is only a beautiful dream. But Veronica Saddler, a pinhole photographer, can clear out the city with her cameras. The two faded cardboard boxes scribbled over with exposure times could not look more unassuming, yet they have produced dozens of majestic photographs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, BERNARD
description: ROSENBAUM-Bernard. Died on December 7, 1999 at age 92. He leaves his wife Ruth, two children Fred and Laura Randall, and their spouses, a stepson, six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his first wife Frances. Bernard was a CPA, an active community worker and a lover of the visual arts. donations may be made to the Renaissance Project of Westchester.

title: Welcome to Paradise
description: From dot.com executive suites to fast-food service counters, the worker is king. Employers have to roll out the red carpet for potential hires, and multiply the incentives for workers to stay. Competitive pay is only a start. Employers have been known to troll the competition's after-hours hangouts, or to turn their cafeterias into four-star restaurants. What are the most creative ways you have found to hire and keep employees? Or the best blandishments you have been offered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: My High-School Muse
description: I was at Parsons with Deirdre. When she was (not infrequently) late, she enthralled the class, including teachers, with adventurous explanations. She made strong opinions attractive, and always seemed full of good humor and good will. It seems she had positive impact on a lot of folks. Now she can share her gifts with her child and with students too. It seems she's living up to her promise quite well!

title: But How Do They Taste? A Food Critic Answers

Somewhere in the tortured mental software that governs eating behavior, the pleasure principle lives in more or less uneasy proximity to the efficiency principle. We eat to live, but we also live to eat, which means that functional foods have to jump through two hoops at the same time.

But for the New Yorkers, that simple plan has gone terribly awry.

title: The Nation; Here's Something To Sneeze at
description: IF there is a patron saint of nagging mothers, it is surely William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States. Standing in the cold rain, too proud to wear a hat, delivering a 105-minute speech that is still one of the longest inaugural addresses ever, he caught a cold and died of pneumonia a month later (becoming the first president to die in office and thus keeping his campaign promise never to run again).

title: The Way We Live Now

Do Michelle Pfeiffer, Susan Sarandon, Goldie Hawn and Jane Fonda, just to name a few, know that? What else shouldn't women over 40 wear? High heels? Lacy panties? Sheer hose? Necklines that show cleavage? A woman can wear anything she wishes at any age, and if she is 50 years old with fabulous legs -- Tina Turner comes to mind -- a short skirt is definitely an option.

But they cost a third of the price, and their flavor has considerably improved over that of a few years ago, when they were most often sold frozen. Now Cornish hens can make a simple and very good dinner for two (or more), the sort of thing you can pick up on the way back from work and have on the table, without fuss, within an hour of getting home.

With all eyes on the famous faces of Minnie Driver and Puff Daddy, no eyebrows were raised by Stella McCartney's entrance on a recent Saturday night. Slipping into a corner banquette in the back, Ms. McCartney, 28, the designer for Chloe, seemed unimpressed by the marquee crowd.

description: GRUBER-Jessie. 90 years young, of Brooklyn Heights, NY. On December 8, 1999. Loving sister to Golden, Eva and Mary. The planet lost a unique individual whose quick mind and irreverent, yet loving, nature made a lasting impression on all. Adios. Her family and friends are asked to celebrate her life at her home on Saturday, December 18, from 1 to 4 PM.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Cheerfully Doomed
description: Most of the short stories in NAKED PUEBLO (Harmony, $21), Mark Jude Poirier's first collection, take place in or around Tucson; they describe cramped, dysfunctional lives in wide open spaces. Some of the stories here, including the collection's first (''Son of the Monkey Lady'') and last (''Tilt-a-Whirl'') are explicitly related, but throughout Poirier's book the characters and concerns bleed together so comfortably that one might well think that ''Naked Pueblo'' is the cullings from a promising but unfinished novel. In ''Before the Barbecue Hoedown,'' a stripper's daughter named Jackpot gets a job as personal assistant to a wealthy old woman with a pet pig; in ''Cul-de-Sacs,'' an amorous chimp who lives across the street seems to taunt a man whose marriage is slipping away. Poirier's stories skip amiably from the mundane to the freakish. This is a refreshingly unsentimental collection in which rock climbers, mountain bike enthusiasts, slackers and drunks seem almost cheerfully doomed. When a young man who works at Value Village Thrift Center finds a Donny and Marie Osmond record trunk to pilfer in ''Something Good,'' that's about as good as it gets. In the claustrophobic universe of ''Naked Pueblo,'' there seems to be little better to hope for -- tiny epiphanies and bizarre accidents, drunken maimings and ruined marriages are all treated with the same cool, resigned acceptance. The author's skewed, grimly fatalistic perspective on the not-so-great Southwest will probably serve him well should he direct his attention away from his hometown. His jaundiced but unblinking gaze and his quietly confident voice hint at better work to come. Anthony Bourdain

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, FLORA
description: ROBERTS-Flora. For all of us who knew and deeply loved you, knowing you wanted us to go on and aspire to our personal best, today we acknowledge the pain of our loss and our abiding love for you and your spirit. Helen

title: December 5-11; It Was a Very Bad Year

title: Flight Path Dispute
description: Another salvo has been fired in the continuing border wars between Greenwich residents and Westchester County surrounding the County Airport. In the latest skirmish, a group of Greenwich homeowners recently asked the Federal Aviation Administration to consider shifting a flight path away from their homes. The change, if approved, would reroute planes that fly over Long Island Sound so they fly directly over Harrison, Port Chester and White Plains.

title: MUSIC: Already Boxed. Just Add a Little Wrapping.; CAPTAIN BEEFHEART AND HIS MAGIC BAND: 'THE DUST BLOWS FORWARD (AN ANTHOLOGY)'
description: EACH year recording companies dig more deeply into their archives. They are eager to retrieve the obscure recordings that justify expanding greatest-hits collections into the boxed sets that have become fixtures of the holiday market. Theme anthologies are devised; concert tapes and studio outtakes are gleaned; old recordings are remixed. And if there's nothing left in the vaults, then new material is created: electronically assisted posthumous collaborations (as with the latest set by the Doors) or recent live recordings (as with Phish). title: The Golden Legacy of Scythian Warriors
description: IN the fifth century B. C., the Greek historian Herodotus met the Scythians on the northern coast of the Black Sea and was so impressed by their customs and their splendid gold artifacts that he wrote vividly about them in ''History.'' Even today, that account provides historians with a broad sketch of the lifestyle of these nomad warriors, the spiritual ancestors of the Cossacks who moved swiftly -- and with bells on -- through history. They migrated in the eighth century B.C. from Central Asia to Assyria and then to the rich grasslands north of the Black Sea, now called Ukraine, before disappearing.

title: The Haunted Wardrobe
description: Growing up two blocks from the Rosalee on Avenue J, I passed the store daily and was always intrigued by the single outfit shown in the front window and by the two or three coordinated outfits and accessories displayed in the side window. The Rosalee was a destination for women with taste, money and style; for years after they had moved to Long Island and other suburbs, women would come back to shop there.

title: Trickle-Down Civil Rights
description: In early August, some of the country's top business executives made a pilgrimage to Chicago and paid homage to the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The occasion was the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition's annual conference, and before an audience of aspiring black businessmen, a panel that included Sanford Weill of Citigroup, Hugh McCall of Bank of America and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago Bulls and White Sox, swore allegiance to multicultural capitalism.

title: State Dept. Cuba Page Hones Its Point of View
description: It seems that nothing about Cuba can be without controversy. Even an addition to the State Department's Web site that includes a helpful summary of information about the complicated policies on travel to Cuba by Americans has drawn attention for its use of photographs, a first for a State Department country information page. The photos -- of ordinary people, the countryside and the like -- were taken by employees at the United States Interest Section in Havana. They are accompanied by captions that sometimes editorialize, including one under a portrait of an old man that says, ''The dignity of the Cuban people continues to be evident in spite of the hardships endured through 40 years under a repressive regime.''

title: American Pseudo
description: At this late date in the century -- the century defined by the American success story -- the two men considered most likely to succeed to the presidency are both running away from their pasts. One, brought up in a ritzy hotel by a Washington political family, has reinvented himself as a down-home Tennessean; the other, a political prince educated at Andover, Yale and Harvard, is now a man of the people in cowboy boots. The man whose job they covet, of course, is the former Bill Blythe, son of a traveling salesman and product of the disreputable gambling town of Hot Springs, Ark., who, via Georgetown, Oxford and Yale, long ago remade himself (for a while anyway) into the Man From Hope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENNOYER, GERDA ELISABETH (SELLING)
description: PENNOYER - Gerda Elisabeth (Selling)., 97, died peacefully on December 10 in Lakewood, NJ, formerly of Chatham and Colt's Neck, NJ. Predeceased by her beloved husband Douglas Huntington Pennoyer, and her parents Christian M. and Pauline Selling, sister Dagmar, and brother Christian. Born in St. Paul in 1902, as a young child Gerda moved with her family to New York City, where her father's career as a musician and composer flourished in the three decades before World War II. Married in 1930 to Douglas, Harvard Class of 1924 and a design engineer with Bell Laboratories until retirement in 1968. Gerda volunteered tirelessly in support of many community institutions and activities. Devoted and loving mother of Douglas H. Pennoyer, Jr., independent businessman and entrepreneur, retired in Tampa, FL, and of Dr. John C. Pennoyer, District Superintendent for the Dutchess County BOCES, Poughkeepsie, NY. Fond and loving grandmother of Jacki, Andre, Rob, Cindy and Tracy. Services are planned for a later date for immediate family. In lieu of flowers, friends may wish to contribute to the charity of their choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JOSEPH BENNY
description: JOHNSON-Joseph Benny., died November 29, 1999 in Brooklyn, New York at the age of 84. Joseph was educated in DeKalb, Missouri. He later accepted Christ as an adult in Laurel, Missouri. On August 21, 1941 he served in the 761st Tank Battalion, which was known as the First Negro Armored Force Division in the American Army. He served in the military under General George S. Patton, Jr. for four years and saw 182 days of combat. He was awarded the Purple Heart and described himself as ''a good soldier.'' In 1950, he married Ernestine Hayes, his wife of 49 years, and from this union fathered eight children, six sons and two daughters. Joseph retired from the New York Times after 35 years of dedicated service, first as an Elevator Operator, later as a Supervisor in Custodial Services. He was known as ''J.B.'' by his coworkers. He was a handsome man of quiet presence, possessing a unique sense of personal style. He was a man of few words who said what he meant, and meant what he said. He liked to hunt and was knowledgeable about guns. He especially enjoyed being in the presence of his grandchildren, often watching them play. Joseph leaves to honor his life, Ernestine Johnson, his devoted wife, one sister, Elnora Johnson of DeKalb, MS, Larry and Monica Johnson, Joseph and Sheila Johnson of Atlanta, GA, Icie Akoto, Anthony Johnson, Calvin Johnson of Atlanta, GA, Irving Johnson, Antoinette Johnson and Darren Johnson of Atlanta, GA. His grandchildren are Ashanti Marie, Joseph Tyrone, Deshawn, Jordan, Malcolm, Fabian, Kadeem and Elijah.

title: Style; Here's Mud In Your Eye
description: 'Today will be many muds,'' said our Bhutanese guide on the trek. There was firm sandy mud before the pass, a viscous black muck on the down slope and a particularly slippery clay on the other side of the valley. This was but a small sampling; it would take a lifetime to sort out the muds we slogged through that day. Walking in Bhutan, a small rural kingdom in the eastern Himalayas where mud is what food is grown in and houses are built from, made me realize how far I as an urban dweller have distanced myself from this basic stuff of life.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Really, Really Old
description: Over the centuries the Egyptian desert has yielded a seemingly endless bounty of pharaonic antiquities: colossal statues, burial chambers filled with ceremonial objects, detailed reliefs providing tantalizing glimpses of the civilization that flourished along the Nile thousands of years ago. In his introduction to EGYPTIAN TREASURES FROM THE EGYPTIAN MUSEUM IN CAIRO (Abrams, $75) the Italian scholar Francesco Tiradritti points out that all those crumbling temples and toppled columns were ''simply stones'' in the eyes of early 19th-century Egyptians. The Ottoman-appointed pasha, Muhammad Ali, freely allowed European connoisseurs to take them home for souvenirs. He also authorized the dismantling of ancient monuments for building materials. Even mummies had practical applications -- when incinerated, they produced a fine carbon that proved quite useful in the refining of cane sugar. Like this book, EGYPTIAN ART IN THE AGE OF THE PYRAMIDS (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Abrams, $90) contains essays by renowned Egyptologists and is richly illustrated with hundreds of black-and-white and color photographs. It focuses on the Old Kingdom -- a 500-year period beginning some 4,500 years ago when necropolises like the Giza pyramids were constructed and sculptural renderings of the human figure were characterized by their ''spare, tender gestures.'' The book's 15 essays covers topics like the pyramids, royal reliefs, statuary and the history of the Old Kingdom. While its narrow focus and staid presentation are suffused with a scholarly tone, ''Egyptian Treasures From the Egyptian Museum in Cairo'' is more immediately appealing, with artfully arranged photographs and illustrations, and an entertaining introduction by Tiradritti on how the museum came to exist. The subjects covered are as diverse as the museum's collection, with essays on Tutankhamun's treasures, the Valley of the Kings and antiquities from the middle and late kingdoms. Suzanne MacNeille

title: Where 'Once Upon a Time' Is Now
description: THERE are autumns in Germany that show up weeks too early, pushy guests that have clearly misread the invitation, arriving with bleak gray skies, cold winds and rain when you're still dressed in your summer linens. Then there are autumns, like this year's, that drop by fashionably late. The season takes on each leaf with leisure, and with a warm golden light, illuminates the turning trees apparently for the sake of your simple smiling wonder.

title: It's in the Bank
description: THE story goes that the Community Food Bank of New Jersey began with Kathleen DiChiara distributing groceries to needy people in her neighborhood out of the back of her station wagon. But the story she likes to tell is the one about the bull.

It is the Disney company's attempt ''to bring some of the Harlem Globetrotters points of views and life styles to the stage,'' he said. Where? ''Maybe Off Broadway. Hopefully, Broadway. I don't know, sir,'' he said. Mr. Glover, who turned 26 last month, has respect.

description: With a week to go before Russia elects its next Parliament and rushes headlong toward next summer's presidential election, the national political debate can be summed up in two words: mud and war.

title: I Didn't Buy the Stock. So Why Is My Heart Racing?
description: LATELY I've been feeling guilty about my health-club regimen. Yes, I work out enough to stay in shape. But the trouble is, I almost never make thousands of dollars in the stock market at the same time.

title: Ferries to Everywhere In Sydney's Waters
description: FERRY trips make superb lenses through which to see Sydney. Fanning out from Circular Quay, where skyscrapers crowd toward the vast crannied, islanded stretch of water that is the city's reason for being, ferries cruise to coves, beaches, marinas, parks, suburbs and industrial areas. During a three-week trip to Sydney last December, they showed me the city's history and variety. To travel was as good as to arrive. Freighters passed loaded with cement; a paddle boat designed for rivers slapped happily on the waters; three-masters heaved. Tourists on cruise boats looked at us as we looked at them; racers poised for the America's Cup sped past each other. Powerboats and water taxis threw wakes like bridal veils; sailboats, some flaunting spinnakers, danced with wind; busy fishing vessels chugged by; oarsmen sculled. Everything that floats for purpose or pleasure crowded the waters. Meanwhile, we were moving, cooled by breezes, dazzled by ripples, chatting with fellow passengers.

description: MARTHA TRACHTENBERG is gently swaying to the music. Her eyes are closed, and a contented smile runs across her face.

title: Ideas & Trends; Suddenly Hackers Are Sexy, Hip and Evil
description: THE opening of ''Y2K,'' a new play by Arthur Kopit, in an Off Broadway theater last week was notable in a couple of ways, not the least of which was the continued abuse of the millennium's most overused catch phrase.

title: A Convenient Italian Spot in Hawthorne
description: IF a good portion of success derives, as the sage says, from just showing up, then certainly Tramonto's location and perennial welcome help to fill its tables -- and fill they do with parties large and small and of all ages. Just off the Saw Mill River Parkway and near the Westchester Multiplex, convenient Tramonto -- open every day and serving early and late -- makes itself the likely choice for dining in Hawthorne. While some dishes received careless preparation, some others were decent. In sum, the food was less than terrific but, choosing carefully, we would dine here again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, MICHAEL
description: BRENNER-Michael. The staff, Board of Directors, and volunteers of God's Love We Deliver are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of Michael Brenner, our dearly loved friend and evening Head Chef. Mike was always at his best when he was able to help others, whether it was greeting our evening volunteers, preparing meals for our clients, or just making someone smile. He enriched the lives of those who knew him, and through his dedication to our mission made a difference each day in the lives of thousands of New Yorkers. We extend our sincere condolences to his family, his loving partner Ruben, and his many friends. At the request of Mike's family, contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Ave of the Americas, New York, NY 10013.

title: Facing Raised Eyebrows Not New for Immigrants
description: I guess if you just change the names of the ethnic groups, you could be describing just about any new group of immigrants to an established community. I see that here in Glen Cove and out in the Farmingville area with newly arrived Latinos.

title: Streetscapes/Nathan Silver and 'Lost New York'; Author of a Preservation Classic Revisits the Past
description: NATHAN SILVER'S outraged threnody ''Lost New York'' (1967) moved New Yorkers wounded by the losses of Penn Station and other landmarks. But by the time the book came out Mr. Silver had moved to England, and he missed the last three decades of preservation protests and progress. Now he's back, preparing a new edition of a book that still serves as a touchstone for the preservation movement.

description: I got a kick out of Abbott Combes's essay (''Secrets and Ties''). I have had fun with ties since I was a teenager who became ''civilized'' in the service. One learns how to be a rebel in conservative guise.

title: Dance That Helps Every Able Body Get Into the Act

Actually titled ''Hallelujah'' (hallelu meaning praise and Ya meaning God in Hebrew), the forthcoming 3-year, 10-city endeavor is about praise, but not necessarily of any almighty being.

title: Rescued From the Deep, 38 Years Later
description: ''Back when I started thinking about it, I didn't know what ocean it was in,'' said Curt Newport, an underwater recovery expert. ''I thought it might be the Pacific.'' Fourteen years of research taught him otherwise. To be precise, the Mercury space capsule he sought, not much larger than a refrigerator, was in the Atlantic, 300 miles off the Florida coast. To be even more precise, it lay in the three-by-eight-mile patch of water plotted by Mr. Newport. To be absolutely precise, it was exactly the sonar ping he thought it was, 15,600 feet down.

title: It's So You
description: Every woman in New York City and, increasingly, across the country is wearing a uniform that emerged this past summer: long black skirt, tight gray, wine or black V-neck, black tights, black boots, long, dark hair with a middle part. That's it; nothing else. Look around. Every woman is morphing into a single person.

title: Correction

title: Gesturing by Athletes: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
description: The psychiatrist says the throat-slashing gestures in pro football may be a positive force, offering vicarious satisfaction to fans and sublimating the players' desire to really hurt someone. The psychologist says the gestures are symptomatic of something much darker and more complicated than end zone posturing: players are acting out the projections of an angry America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, SUZANNE JILL
description: PRINCE-Suzanne Jill. Writer, died December 8, 1999 in Los Angeles, Calif. Born November 19, 1950 in Brooklyn New York, she spent her early career as a writer for several of the top advertising agencies in Manhattan. She moved to Los Angeles, her new favorite city with her companion, producer Terry Studanski in 1992, where they worked together & generally enjoyed Southern California living. She is survived by her beloved mother, Amy Prince of Delray Beach, FL., her brother and sisterin-law, John and Margie Prince of Stony Point, NY, a niece & nephew and numerous cousins. Memorial gathering in her memory will be held at a later date.

title: The Troubles That Won't Go Away
description: Leonard McCreery's brother Ned was murdered eight years ago by loyalist paramilitaries, the men whose self-imposed duty is the defense of the Protestants against the Irish Republican Army. Ned, a Protestant, had crossed them in some way, which he had kept to himself.

title: The Decorator
description: She's no slave to trends, Diana Vignoly insists, but she is devoted to Issey Miyake, a designer trendy enough to have an exhibition of hisclothes at Ace Gallery, 275 Hudson Street (Spring Street). Ms. Vignoly's love of Miyake design began in 1988, when her husband, Rafael Vignoly, an architect, was commissioned to build the International Tokyo Forum in Japan. There, he bought his wife her first Miyake pieces and she began to think of the designer as ''an architect of clothes,'' she said.

title: The Hunting Has Stopped, but the Decoys Keep Coming
description: Forty years ago when David Rhodes had finished a tour of duty in the Air Force and returned to the Barnegat Bay area, he was dismayed to find that the decoys he liked to use for duck hunting were gone. He figured someone had either collected or stolen them, so he decided to start carving his own.

title: Food; All the Cookies
description: Over the years Ethel Carlegren has acquired about 500 Santa Claus figures, some made out of porcelain, others made from wood, wool or clay. She has also collected at least 10 recipes for Swedish Christmas cookies. Still, you will not catch her decorating her Minnesota home anytime before Dec. 13.

title: Facing Raised Eyebrows Not New for Immigrants

It seems shameful and rather arrogant that this situation is said to involve well-educated, wealthy and cultured individuals who, with their families, appear to have little willingness to assimilate cooperatively into the community unless they can reshape it to their pleasure.

title: Layers of Complexity in a Show of African Objects
description: IT is easy for many Americans to say that they understand African art after having seen just a few exhibitions. They have come to realize that African societies do not regard the objects they produce as art in the Western European sense, and that the objects are usually functional. They may see how the simplification of form characteristic of African art influenced artists like Picasso and had a profound effect on the development of art in the 20th century.

title: As Mr. Britannia, Coward Waived the Rules
description: THE English expression ''taking coals to Newcastle'' pretty much sums up Noel Coward's American career. Arriving in New York on the Aquitania in May 1921, his head soon buzzed with the speed of Manhattan and the pace of Broadway drama; back home, he injected that speed into the staid drawing-room drama of London's West End and in the process invented the Coward style. Five years later he returned to New York with his cocaine and toy-boy succes de scandale, ''The Vortex.'' In years to come, his sophisticated high comedies ''Private Lives'' and ''Design for Living'' would, in turn, influence the screenplays of ''The Philadelphia Story'' and ''Adam's Rib.''

title: December 5-11; Not All Cell Phones Are Safe Calls
description: Two Israeli researchers say they have cracked a cell phone code that protects private conversations and data transmissions. The encryption method is part of the Groupe Speciale Mobile, or G.S.M., wireless phone standard, the most widely used system in the world. The researchers' method may make widespread eavesdropping possible. Most cell phones in America, however, are based on other wireless technologies, but companies like Pacific Bell and Omnipoint Corporation use the G.S.M. standard.

title: A Hot Week on the Hustings
description: Out there on the presidential campaign trail, it was one of those weeks when everything was churning, both in regard to big ideas and the poll numbers. The biggest idea and the smartest tactical move came in the proposed joint pledge by Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, and Bill Bradley, the former Democratic senator, to forgo unregulated soft-money expenditures, should they face one another in the general election. Their plan would bring a voluntary end to a bipartisan abuse that Congress has refused to outlaw -- the use of corporate and union donations by the Republican and Democratic National Committees in circumvention of the limits on candidate spending.

Two states, New York and Connecticut, have threatened to sue, and last week Federal officials announced that they would help public housing authorities nationwide file suit to force gun makers to sell safer firearms and do more to keep them out of criminal hands.

title: A Journey Through the Bleakest of Winters

A man -- barefoot, tottering in the snow -- is glimpsed playing a hurdy-gurdy without cease. He stands alone, ''beyond the village,'' ignored except for some growling dogs. ''Strange old man, shall I go with you?'' the narrator-wanderer asks. And the cycle ends.

title: Three Meals And a Snorkel
description: I'M not an outdoors girl and I would never go out of my way to see a fish. Yet there we were -- my husband and I -- one late afternoon last April, in a lurching miniplane, en route from Cairns to Lizard Island, one of the great marine meccas of the world. Situated on the northern tip of the Great Barrier Reef, Lizard Island was, we figured, a mere thousand or two miles from Sydney, our final destination. So in Australian terms we were in the neighborhood, and we didn't expect to be in the neighborhood soon again.

title: Forget Ravages of Age: Over 40 and Sexy Is Fine
description: MANY of us have been tricked into believing that there can be no hot second acts in American actresses' lives. Suddenly, women of a certain age are also starring in big American movies.

title: When a Book Group Is Not a Democracy

We decided when organizing 18 years ago that the hosts for each monthly meeting would dictate what we were to read.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXAKOS, DEMETRIOS P.
description: ALEXAKOS-Demetrios P.., 72, of 249 Woodruff Ave., Wakefield, RI, a marine engineer and industrialist ship owner, died Thursday at home. He was the husband of Frances M. (Sciabarrasi) Alexakos and the late Yotta (Fanis) Alexakos. Born in Gytheon, Greece, he was a son of Afroditi (Tsigourakos) Alexakos of Wakefield, RI, and the late Panayiotis Alexakos. Mr. Alexakos was owner of Dolphin Maritime Shipping Co. in Athens, Greece, and Alexakos Consulting Marine Engineering in Providence, RI. He was a graduate of Royal Hellenic Naval Academy in Greece and a Merchant Marine 1st Engineer. Mr. Alexakos was a graduate of Columbia University with a Master's in Mechanical/Marine Engineering. He was a member of ''Aheph'' Greek Orthodox Annunciation Church, the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, South County Museum, the Hellenic Cultural Society and the U.S. Navy League. Besides his wife and mother he leaves four daughters, Katerina Alexakos, Alexis Alexakos, Demetra Agadakos and Artemis Agadakos, all of Wakefield; two sons, Costas Alexakos of Manhattan and Panos Alexakos of Tennessee; two sisters, Pia Zombanakias of London, England, and Emilia Alexakos of Athens. Visitation will be from 4-8 PM Tuesday, December 14, in the Avery-Storti Funeral Home, 88 Columbia St., Wakefield. Funeral service will be held at 12 PM Wednesday in the Greek Orthodox Annunciation Church, 175 Oaklawn Ave., Cranston, RI. Burial will be in New Fernwood Cemetery, Kingston, RI. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Alexakos Scholarship Fund or Greek Orthodox Diocese Camp, 249 Woodruff Avenue, Wakefield, RI 02879.

title: Found Money
description: There's no present like one you aren't expecting. There may be one waiting for you on the State of New Jersey's Web site in the unclaimed property lists. Old bank accounts, wage checks, stocks, bonds and certificates of deposit often go unclaimed by their rightful owners. Sometimes the property in question belonged to a deceased relative. The New Jersey Division of Taxation has a system by which residents can check for unclaimed property (this does not include real estate) both in New Jersey and other states just by entering their last name or county and clicking. Once the property has been located, it can then be claimed online. According to Meg Smith, Chief of Operations for the Unclaimed Property Division the turn-around time is three months. Ms. Smith added: ''We just got a call from the Montel Williams Show telling us that they are doing a Christmas show on unclaimed property so that should flood us with inquiries and bump up the time. So pre-Montel is three months. Post-Montel may be six months.'' The Web address is www.state.nj.us/treasury/taxation; click on ''Unclaimed Property Infformation.''

title: Facing Raised Eyebrows Not New for Immigrants
description: The 1950's American suburb was not characterized by ethnic and, for that matter, class homogeneity; that view may be a function of 1990's nostalgia. Rather, tract developments on Long Island and in other suburbs were places where a variety of European-Americans went to achieve the American Dream. Moreover, these groups, especially Jews and Catholics, often encountered considerable prejudice upon arrival. When my Italian-American family moved to Paramus, N.J., in the 1950's from the old tenement neighborhood in Manhattan, many established families shunned the ethnic newcomers and moved away. One of our neighbors' feathers were ruffled when my grandmother hung laundry out to dry in the backyard.

title: CHARITY FOR POOR LAGS BEHIND NEED

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Troikas and Blini In Nice for Christmas
description: As the gilded domes of its Orthodox Cathedral attest, Nice was the favorite resort of the Russian aristocracy at the turn of the last century. Starting this week, Nice celebrates its czarist past with a string of Russian festivities. From Wednesday through Jan. 2, the St. Petersburg Christmas Market will bring everything but frostbite to the sunny Place Massena, two blocks from the Promenade des Anglais.

title: Finding Spiritual Rebirth In a Valley of Male Ennui
description: WELL, at least the movies are approaching the end of the millennium with a bang, which is more than you can say for the rest of us, the real-life inhabitants of this disconnected fin de siecle. But we still might turn things around if we heed the warnings of ''American Beauty,'' ''Fight Club,'' ''Bringing Out the Dead'' and ''Magnolia'' (opening Friday). On one hand, these are films about male rage, regret and reconciliation. But they're also like shock treatment, trying to stir all of us -- both men and women -- into leading more meaningful lives as we enter the 21st century.

title: The Tyranny Of Cool

As long as we accept domestic abuse as a fact of life, in our actions and our language, women will continue to be second-class citizens.

But there he was last Thursday, the day after his career ended, walking into a Philadelphia physician's office at the same time Allen Iverson was walking out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFRA, EDMOND J.
description: SAFRA-Edmond J.. Yad Avraham Institute, its Officers, Directors and members record with deep sorrow and mourn the tragic and untimely loss of our beloved and esteemed patron. For the past decade, with love and enthusiasm, he provided a home for us in his Beit Yaakov Synagogue. His support enabled Yad Avraham, an institution devoted to teaching Torah, to grow and flourish. In his merit, thousands have passed through its portals to partake of the wellspring of Torah, and hundreds have returned as committed Jews. He asked little, yet gave so much. We will sorely miss him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Lily, her children and grandchildren and the entire Safra family. May all those touched by his chesed be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yosef Kalatsky, Dean David S. Lobel, President Bruce Rappaport, Major Benefactor Ira Rennert, Director Louis Glick, Director Yad Avraham Institute

It's irrational, surely, to reject out of hand such a shiny new technology, especially one that comes with the seal of approval of American regulators (the vaunted Food and Drug Administration, no less).

title: From His Act of Betrayal Comes the Stuff of a Career
description: THE defining moment of his life, says Chen Kaige, was the Cultural Revolution, which broke out in 1966, when he was 14. His father, a filmmaker named Chen Huaikai, was known for his films about the Peking Opera, which represented everything the Red Guard despised. To his lasting shame, the younger Mr. Chen publicly denounced his father. Soon after, he left for Hunan province to do labor there as a ''re-educated youth,'' and when his father saw him off at the train station, the elder Chen, who was to be prevented from making films for 10 years, started to cry. ''I had never seen him cry before, and that's when I told him for the first time that I was sorry,'' the son said. ''Years later, we spent a great deal of time together patching things up. I did terrible things to him, but he forgave me anyway.''

title: Malhotra to Play for Canada

title: High Schools Are Said to Have Inflated Attendance Figures

title: Cornish Hens: Flavor and No Fuss
description: SOME cooks are snobbish about Cornish hens. It is true that the hens do not have as much taste as a free-range poussin. But they cost a third of the price, and their flavor has considerably improved over that of a few years ago, when they were most often sold frozen. Now Cornish hens can make a simple and very good dinner for two (or more), the sort of thing you can pick up on the way back from work and have on the table, without fuss, within an hour of getting home.

title: The Nation; Have You the Right to Remain Silent?

Thanks to television and its Kojaks and Andy Sipowiczs, these phrases from the Supreme Court's landmark 1966 Miranda decision are surely among the best-known phrases in the language.

title: The Haunted Wardrobe
description: Clothing has become too serious. Shopping, ditto. Lynn Hirschberg offered the perfect alternative in her article on vintage adventures. In my years of junking with mutually bohemian friends, I have found the experience to be a refreshing change. I have horrified my mother and mystified my husband with the treasures that have followed me home. Some still hang in the closet, unworn but loved; others go out, make their own statement and have fun.

title: Oui, C'est Carmen
description: To the Editor: As a native of Seville, I would like to offer congratulations to Penelope Casas for her excellent ''What's Doing in Seville'' (Oct. 3). Only a little misconception concerning Carmen: If there is no qualm as to her being considered ''the operatic embodiment of Seville,'' it is no less true that she has no stature whatsoever as a daughter of the city. The main character of a novel published in the 1840's by the French writer Prosper Merimee, Carmen has no legitimate claim to Sevillian nor even Spanish citizenship. Carmen is a wholly Parisian creature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, MAX
description: MARKOWITZ-Max, M.D. 86 years. Max Markowitz was a man for all seasons. He was an elegant man with strong values and convictions. An individual of deep intensity and insight, he was always a man of responsibility with a strong sense of right and wrong. Always the professional, he helped so many to lead and seek better lives. He was a man of extraordinary intelligence and always liked to engage others in profound discussion. He was deeply concerned with the issues of the day and addressed life with a strong point of view. He loved music and appreciated beauty at the highest level. Material things were not important as were the principles of life. He graduated high school and college before his time and later graduated from the medical school of Lausanne, Switzerland in 1937. He served his country as a major in the armed forces during World War II. After his service he started a practice in internal medicine. He went on to specialize in the field of psychiatry and achieved the highest training as a psychoanalyst. He was the medical director of adult psychiatry with the Postgraduate Center of Mental Health in New York City. He trained other professionals, lectured, taught, and supervised others in the psychiatric profession in both private and group practice. His standards were of the highest level and he expected the best performance from the people he worked with. He conducted himself with dignity at all times and commanded the respect of others. A truly brilliant man who valued words and concepts, and he did The New York Times crossword puzzle every day with ease. Max Markowitz is survived by his wife of nine years, Anita Bleifeld Beckenstein, Ph.D., and stepson, Kevin L. Beckenstein and wife, Leigh. Max Markowitz was the husband of the late Sarah Kissen Markowitz, MSW for forty one years. He is also survived by his son, Philip Markowitz, M.D and wife, Abby, Miriam and Leah, granddaughters; and by his daughter, Enid Markowitz Garber, husband, David L. Garber, Sumner and Jessica, grandson and granddaughter. Max Markowitz was brother to Lillian Edelman, Claire Greene, and the late Eleanor Rubinstein. He leaves a void never to be filled or forgotten. With deepest love, my mentor, my sweet Max, I was proud to be your wife, Anita B. Markowitz, Ph.D. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. Donations may be made to the Max Markowitz Scholarship Fund. For further information contact Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapels, 6701 West Commercial Blvd., Tamarac, FL 33319; (954) 523-5801.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, SARAH
description: RATNER-Sarah, Dr., a biochemist at the Public Health Research Institute and Professor at New York University School of Medicine, died July 28, 1999 in New York. She was 96. Dr. Ratner was born in New York in 1903, a child of recently arrived Russian immigrants. She received a scholarship to Cornell University and later entered the graduate program at Columbia where she earned a doctorate in 1938. In 1945 she joined the Biochemistry Department at New York University and in 1954 moved to the Public Health Research Institute where she worked until her retirement in 1990 at 87. Her research included pioneering attempts to treat infertility, studies of human metabolism that helped lay the foundation for the fields of nutrition, cell physiology and molecular genetics and crucial achievements in understanding of the urea cycle which provided a rational basis for the treatment of inherited metabolic disorders. Dr. Ratner was a Member of the National Academy of Sciences, received honorary degrees from The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and from Northwestern, presented numerous honorary lectures and served on editorial boards of scientific journals.

With deep and heartfelt sympathy we mourn the loss of our very dear family member and friend, Bernie; our hearts go out to his beloved and beautiful wife Lois, our dear and wonderful daughter-in-law and son, Lisa and Michael Ades, and Bernie and Lois' beloved son and daughter-in-law, Michael and Stacey Bennett. Bernie was the ultimate husband, father, brother, and inspiration and best friend to all who knew him. Always the first there in time of need, he devoted his entire life to bestowing loving kindness upon his family and friends. His pure unselfish nature and thoughtfulness to others will forever be remembered; a great loss of a great man, he will be deeply missed by all of us. We love you, Bernie. Esther and Bob and our Family

title: Galaxies' Vastness Surprises Scientists
description: Using a technique akin to overlaying thousands of faint X-ray images to create one sharp picture, astronomers have discovered that typical galaxies may be twice as large and contain twice as much mass as suggested by previous measurements. The new observations, which have emerged from a five-year census of the heavens called the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, indicate that an average galaxy extends invisibly for well over a million light-years into space and weighs the equivalent of at least five trillion Suns.

title: An Explosive Mix In Chechnya's War
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Depot Buying Apex
description: Home Depot Inc., the largest retailer of home-improvement supplies in the United States, said today that it had agreed to buy the closely held Apex Supply Company as it expands the products and services it offers to professional contractors. Home Depot will pay an undisclosed amount of cash for Apex, which sells plumbing, heating, air-conditioning and other products through 21 stores in Georgia, Tennessee and South Carolina. Apex, which like Home Depot is based in Atlanta, will operate as a subsidiary of Home Depot.

title: The Union Faction That Keeps Talking Strike
description: Like many such rabble-rousing efforts, it began as a newsletter, in this case named ''Hell on Wheels.'' Fifteen years ago its leaders waged what they now unabashedly call ''propaganda campaigns'' to topple their union leadership. For years, slowly and methodically, they stoked the discontent of the city's 33,000 transit workers over wages, benefits and other contract provisions, like the use of welfare recipients to do work done by union members.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: SAGENT TECHNOLOGY TO BUY QUALITATIVE MARKETING
description: The electronic commerce software maker Sagent Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Qualitative Marketing Software Inc. for $70 million in stock. Under the agreement, Sagent will pay about 2.5 million shares for Qualitative, or about 8.7 percent of its stock outstanding. Qualitative Marketing, based in Clearwater, Fla., provides real-time customer information and electronic marketing services through the Internet. Sagent, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., provides electronic-business intelligence products and services.

title: Beware If Smart Dog Gets Lonely
description: Trust the Adobe Theater Company to drive from mind any inkling of how oppressive these official holidays can be. If you can make it to their new play at the Ohio Theater by Saturday, its last day, the fix should hold you right through Jan. 1. It is called ''Poona the . . . Dog and Other Plays for Children (Not a Play for Children).'' Not only is the full title not printable here, neither are the names of a couple of characters. But there are in fact two children in it, and it is impossible to imagine that they come out of the experience scandalized or jaded.

title: This Year 2000 Headache Is a Budget, Not Computers
description: Nassau County is grappling with a nontech year 2000 problem: with the new budget that is set to take effect on Jan. 1 still not balanced, some private agencies that perform services for the county do not know if they will get enough county money to stay open next year.

title: KOREAN STRIKE THREAT
description: South Korea's major labor unions said they would intensify their protests about the government's refusal to guarantee the payment of wages to full-time union workers, and they called for suspension of a government plan to privatize the domestic electricity industry. The federation held a rally in front of the National Assembly yesterday, above, and will hold another today. It plans a four-hour work stoppage on Friday and a nationwide strike on Dec. 23.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 30 about Dr. Mark Plotkin, an ethnobotanist, referred imprecisely to ShamanBotanicals.com, a company with which he has been associated, and to Dr. Plotkin's role in testing medicines. A detailed correction appears today on Page F3.

description: In percent
