description: The thoughts of editors of medical journals apparently turn to depression around this time of year, when more people are known to get depressed. Recent research articles and conference reports have included these findings:

title: VOLPE SENTENCED TO A 30-YEAR TERM IN LOUIMA TORTURE
description: After tearfully pleading for mercy and apologizing to his victim, Justin A. Volpe was sentenced yesterday to 30 years in prison for brutalizing Abner Louima in a Brooklyn police station. The judge denounced the former officer for an ''unusually heinous'' crime that had harmed not only Mr. Louima, but also the Police Department and society at large.

title: Xerox Shares Shake Off Friday's Jitters
description: As shares of the Xerox Corporation regained a modicum of what they lost late Friday, a market truism was reaffirmed yesterday: investors are simply contrarians these days.

title: South of 14th Street, Down Mexico Way; Slow to Come to the Table, New Yorkers Are Reaching for Tacos and Burritos
description: The East Village is hardly Old Mexico. Yet, within two blocks of such ethnic culinary legends as the Second Avenue Deli (pastrami), Veselka (borscht) and Gem Spa (egg creams) there is ample evidence of New York's own Mexican revolution: the burrito boom.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Simple Acts Go a Long Way in Comforting the Bereaved
description: After a drunken driver left Margaret Kramer a young widow with four small children, her Minnesota friends and neighbors pitched in with ready-to-eat meals, took turns mowing the lawn and baby-sitting and a year or so later surprised her by painting the outside of her house while she and the children were away on vacation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGER, DOROTHY
description: MAGER-Dorothy. On December 11, 1999. Beloved wife of Julius; mother of Cyrus and the late Millicent; devoted grandmother of six grandchildren. We'll never forget how she touched our lives.

title: High Court's Plate Piled With Tough Issues
description: In its last term, the Supreme Court breezed through 75 decisions and finished its work on June 23, for the earliest closing in 30 years. This term, the justices will also decide about 75 cases, but at the rate they are going now they will be lucky to make it home by next Labor Day.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Dot-Com Advertisers Quintuple Spending
description: Spending by dot-com advertisers in traditional media quintupled in the third quarter from a year earlier, pushing the total for the first nine months of the year above $1 billion, according to Competitive Media Reporting.

title: Spies Are Always With Us
description: The two espionage cases that are causing so much finger-pointing in Washington are indeed disturbing, but it's also dangerous to read too much into them.

title: Justice and Wen Ho Lee
description: Federal prosecutors say they have assembled substantial evidence that Wen Ho Lee, formerly a scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, illegally copied and removed classified information describing the design, construction and testing of most major weapons in America's nuclear arsenal. In view of the case against Mr. Lee, his indictment last Friday seems warranted. At least for now, he has not been charged with the graver crime of espionage, because evidence is lacking that he passed these stolen nuclear secrets to China or any other foreign power.

title: Security Council Backs Off Again on Vote on Inspections for Iraq
description: The Security Council backed away today from a vote that had been planned on a new arms-inspection system for Iraq. Diplomats said foreign ministers of the five permanent council members were continuing to confer by telephone in hope of broadening support for the resolution.

title: Westchester Forms Rights Panel, The Protection of Gays Included
description: After hours of emotional debate, the Westchester County Board of Legislators voted today to establish a county Human Rights Commission, despite months of criticism from some religious groups over its inclusion of gays among those protected against discrimination.

title: Furs for Evening, But Cloth Was The Stone Age Standby
description: Ah, the poor Stone Age woman of our kitschy imagination. When she isn't getting bonked over the head with a club and dragged across the cave floor by her matted hair, she's hunched over a fire, poking at a roasting mammoth thigh while her husband retreats to his cave studio to immortalize the mammoth hunt in fresco. Or she's Raquel Welch, saber-toothed sex kitten, or Wilma Flintstone, the original Roccer Mom. But whatever her form, her garb is the same: some sort of animal pelt, cut nasty, brutish and short.

title: Patients' Musical Tastes
description: To the Editor:

title: Limitless MetroCard May Be Money Lost
description: And now, there is yet another transit anxiety for New Yorkers: will they lose money on their weekly and monthly MetroCards if there is a subway and bus strike?

title: VITAL SIGNS: OUTCOMES; When Time Heals a Damaged Heart
description: In 1997, the popular diet drug combination known as fen-phen was pulled off the market after Mayo Clinic researchers found an increase in heart valve disease among people taking the medications. In a follow-up study published last week, researchers from the clinic concluded that the valve damage appeared to improve after patients stopped taking the pills.

title: BANK'S WEB PROMOTION
description: In a plan that could shake up Brazil's Internet industry, Banco Bradesco S.A., a leading consumer bank, will offer free World Wide Web access to its eight million customers. Bradesco hopes to lure new clients with the plan and increase use of its online banking and securities trading operations. Internet service providers in Brazil, already embroiled in a price war, are now likely to cut prices further.

title: Abortion Law On Disclosure Is Upheld
description: A New Jersey judge today upheld the state's six-month-old law requiring a doctor to tell a parent before performing an abortion on an unmarried girl under 18.

title: U.S. Reports Mideast Arrests Of New Year's Terror Suspects
description: The Clinton administration said tonight that about a dozen members of a suspected terrorist operation believed to be planning New Year's attacks on Americans around the world had been arrested in the Middle East in the last two weeks.

title: The Columbine Killers' Tapes of Rage
description: Videotapes made by two teenage gunmen as they planned a massacre and their own suicide at Columbine High School show them filled with rage and hopeful of killing 250 people, yet sympathetic to their parents for what they would soon endure.

title: Pearl Resnick, 87, Philanthropist and Head of Real Estate Family
description: Pearl Resnick, the matriarch of a prominent New York real estate family and a philanthropist, died yesterday at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 87 and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGRAM, OLIVE
description: INGRAM-Olive of Nantucket, MA. Beloved wife of George and mother of Patricia (Mrs. S.K. Bone), Sara and John and grandmother of Sara Elizabeth Bone, Jeffrey Bone, and David Ingram Bone on December 9, 1999. Service at Unitarian Church, Nantucket on December 15th at 2:00 PM with reception to follow at the Harbor House. In lieu of flowers memorials may be sent to Maria Mitchell Association or Nantucket Conservation Foundation.

title: Death of a President: A 200-Year-Old Malpractice Debate
description: Two hundred years ago today, on Dec. 14, 1799, the first president of the United States died at the age of 67 in his bed at Mount Vernon. George Washington's doctors said the cause was ''inflammatory quinsy,'' a severe infection of the throat, but to this day controversy has surrounded his death.

title: Weapons Scientist Pleads Not Guilty
description: A former United States weapons scientist pleaded not guilty today to the illegal computer downloading of a vast trove of nuclear arms data, but a federal magistrate ordered him jailed pending trial, declaring that the acts he is accused of represent ''a clear and present danger to the security of the United States.''

title: Manslaughter Charge For Mother of Dead Baby
description: A woman who gave birth to a child that was found dead in a toilet has been charged with manslaughter, the Bergen County prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENTS; Zinc Supplements, for the Life of a Child
description: In America, zinc supplements have mainly been discussed in recent years as a potential cure for the common cold. But in developing nations, according to an article in the December issue of The Journal of Pediatrics, zinc supplements could offer the most cost-effective way of reducing the two leading causes of childhood death: pneumonia and diarrhea.

title: Joseph Heller, Darkly Surreal Novelist, Dies at 76
description: Joseph Heller, the author of ''Catch-22,'' the darkly comic 1961 novel whose title became a universal metaphor not only for the insanity of war but also for the madness of life itself, died on Sunday night at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Pirates' Pushover Turns Into Test
description: Seton Hall scheduled a string of easy opponents in December to gain momentum for Big East Conference play, which begins Jan. 4.

title: Year 2000 Computer Problems May Get an Alibi
description: In the first few days of next year, hundreds of thousands of Americans are likely to discover they cannot get cash from a teller machine. Others will suddenly lose power or be greeted with silence when they pick up their telephones.

title: The Healing Arts, Cast in Shades of Gray
description: All the talk about medical errors in Washington these days leaves the impression that now that the problem is finally acknowledged, a solution is already in sight. Like an alcoholic at his first A.A. meeting, we have finally stood up and said the words out loud: bad errors happen in medical practice. There are drugs with look-alike labels and sound-alike names, there are nurses who mistake micrograms for milligrams and doctors who mistake left for right. The message seems to be that once systems like the ones safeguarding aviation and other high-risk industries are in place, medical care will become safe at last.

title: Gee, Mom, Incest Did Help Your Ratings
description: Sexual abuse of children would not seem the most obvious choice of subject for a playwright looking for material for a rollicking new comedy -- unless, of course, one is a devoted follower of ''Sally Jessy Raphael,'' ''Oprah'' and the other confessionals that have become the staple of daytime talk television.

description: For the last five years, George Steinbrenner has repeatedly promised that he will soon announce where he wants the Yankees to play when the lease at Yankee Stadium runs out in 2002.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: John Popham, 89, Dies; Journalist Was Noted for Perceptive Coverage of South
description: John N. Popham IV, who drove a green Buick 50,000 miles a year across the American South as the first northern newspaper correspondent to cover the region regularly, died in a Chattanooga hospital on Sunday. He was 89.

description: A FLAME OF PURE FIRE

title: ISRAEL LAWMAKERS CLOSELY  APPROVE TALKS WITH SYRIA
description: After six hours of impassioned and often raucous debate, and just two days before talks begin in Washington, Israel's Parliament today tepidly endorsed Prime Minister Ehud Barak's quest for a comprehensive peace settlement with Syria.

title: Tripp Not Promised Immunity In Maryland, Starr Team Says
description: Two prosecutors who helped direct the independent counsel's investigation of President Clinton said in a court hearing today that they had never promised Linda R. Tripp immunity from prosecution in Maryland for taping telephone conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Japan Official Foresees Less Debt Reliance
description: The Japanese finance minister said today that he expected the government to begin trying to gradually wean the country's shaky economy away from its reliance on public borrowing, a practice that has made Japan one of the biggest debtor nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFER, MARGARET ELIZABETH

She was a loving homemaker and school teacher who loved cooking, gardening, traveling, and golf. Marge is survived by her husband, Duane Pfeifer; daughters, Debbie Morrisey, Bonnie Pfeifer, Judi Hans, Mary Pfeifer, Carole Felt; sons, Duey Pfeifer, and Kenny Pfeifer and ten beautiful grandchildren; brother Butch Pfeil. Funeral Mass will be held at 11:00 o'clock Wednesday, December 15 at Holy Trinity Catholic Church. Burial and a memorial service will be held in Annapolis, MD at a future date. The family would appreciate donations to Southwest Christian Hospice, 7225 Lester Rd., Union City, GA 30291. Carl J. Mowell & Son, Peachtree City, GA 770-487-3959.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The yen dropped after a report showed that confidence among large Japanese manufacturers was not rising as much as expected. In New York, the dollar settled at 103.24 yen, up from 102.34 on Friday.

title: Snubbed by the West, Tudjman Receives a Posthumous Rebuke
description: Croatia's first president, Franjo Tudjman, was buried today in a somber ceremony, mourned by tens of thousands of the Croats to whom he helped deliver independence and by a less-than-stellar panoply of foreign dignitaries.

title: WESTELL BUYING TELTREND IN EFFORT TO INCREASE SALES
description: Westell Technologies, a telecommunications-equipment maker, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, the Teltrend Corporation, for about $205 million in stock to strengthen sales of voice- and data-communications products. Westell will exchange 3.3 shares of its class A stock for each share of Teltrend, or $35.48 a share based on its price on Friday. The purchase will give Westell the benefit of Teltrend's so-called local telephone loop service, which allows telephone companies to provide better service to customers without replacing infrastructure. The stock of Teltrend, based in the Chicago suburb of St. Charles, Ill., rose $1.125 a share, to $24.125. Westell, based in Aurora, Ill., rose $1.4375 a share, to $12.1875.

title: Let It Snow, And Put Out The Baby
description: WEATHER reports said it was quite cold in Copenhagen yesterday, with temperatures near freezing and snow on the way. To follow Anette Sorensen's logic, it was a grand opportunity for Danish mothers to bundle up their babies, put them in strollers and leave them outside to enjoy the bracing air while the moms stayed toasty indoors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, PEARL
description: RESNICK-Pearl. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends, mourn the passing of one of our most beloved leaders, who played an important role in our development, Pearl Resnick. Together with her late husband, Jack, she was a longtime patron of the University. After his passing, she continued her involvement not only as a benefactress, but also as a member of both the Global Board of Trustees and the American Board of Trustees. Her interest in every program of the University's mission was tremendous. She loved the traditional dimension of the University and was especially concerned with the personal welfare of faculty and students, particularly those who had emigrated from Russia. Indeed, she established the Jack and Pearl Resnick Institute for the Absorbtion and Retraining of Russian Immigrant Scientists, and subsequently built the permanent home of the Resnick Institute. Beyond the actual programs, her warm and loving personality evoked enormous respect from all who had the privilege to know her. She was truly love incarnate. To her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren she was a loving and devoted matriarch whose love was characteristic of her person and all that she did. With this love, she inspired her family to carry on with her same spirit of matchless generosity for every worthy cause, Jewish, American and humanitarian. There can be no doubt that she will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Aharon Dahan, Chairman, Global Board of Trustees Charles Dimston, Chairman, American Board of Trustees Melvin Stein, President, American Friends of Bar-Ilan University Gen. (Ret.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University

title: Reliant Stock Repurchase
description: Reliant Energy said today that it planned to repurchase an additional $300 million of common stock. The company, a Houston-based utility, said its board initially approved the repurchase of up to $150 million of stock in June 1996 and subsequently raised the authorization to $450 million in September of that year. As of Monday, about $14 million remained under the prior authorization, the company said. Shares in Reliant Energy closed today at $23.125, down 31.25 cents.

description: Even by the inflated standards of high finance, Wall Street is overflowing with holiday cheer this year. Investment banks have set aside $13 billion to pay bonuses, 20 percent more than last year, with pay packages above $10 million no longer a rarity.

description: An editorial on Sunday misidentified the law governing the United States' meat inspection program. It is the Federal Meat Inspection Act, not the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.

title: Taking On Lobbying
description: For years, when self-styled good-government groups have wanted to tighten New York's lax restrictions on lobbyists, the Democrats who control the Assembly have been their most sympathetic audience.

title: COOKSON TO BUY ASARCO UNIT
description: A top maker of circuit board components, the Cookson Group, agreed to buy an electronic chemical business from Asarco Inc. for $503 million, to take advantage of growth in the electronics industry. Cookson -- which focuses on electronics, ceramics and precious metals -- said it would acquire the Enthone-OMI units from Asarco, a New York-based copper producer that was bought by Grupo Mexico S.A. earlier this year for $2.25 billion. The purchase gives Cookson a wider range of products to supply the printed circuit board industry.

title: Public Interests; The New York Fix
description: Every state has shortcomings that its residents don't like to talk about. Wherever you live, I'm sure there are local embarrassments you'd prefer not to see broadcast in the national media -- monster pig farms, a demented governor, whatever. I myself grew up in a Midwestern city that once elected Jerry Springer mayor, and you don't see me bringing it up every time I go back there to visit.

title: BARNETT INC. SEEKS WAYS TO BOLSTER SHAREHOLDER VALUE
description: Barnett Inc., a distributor of plumbing, electrical and security-hardware products, said yesterday that it had hired the investment bank Deutsche Bank Alex. Brown to help it explore ways to increase shareholder value, including a sale of the company and a stock buyback. Barnett is 44 percent owned by Waxman Industries Inc., a supplier of specialty plumbing and other remodeling products. The shares of Barnett, based in Jacksonville, Fla., have lost more than a quarter of their value this year, dragged down by Waxman's plunging share price and 13 straight quarterly losses, the company said. The shares of Barnett rose 12.5 cents, to $10.125.

title: Bush Tangles With McCain Over Campaign Financing
description: In the most spirited Republican debate so far, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona sparred over Mr. McCain's advocacy of overhauling the nation's campaign finance laws, with Mr. Bush declining Mr. McCain's offer that the two take a joint pledge against accepting so-called soft money, largely unregulated corporate contributions.

title: Ex-Financier Is Sentenced to 8 Years for Fraud
description: A federal judge in Manhattan sentenced the former chairman of a financial services company in Rockland County, N.Y., to eight years in prison yesterday, citing his greed and betrayal of hundreds of ''trusting victims'' in a large fraud scheme.

title: POTENTIAL BUYER FOR MARKS
description: The entrepreneur Philip Green, who bought Sears P.L.C. in January, acknowledged that he was mulling a bid for the troubled retailer Marks & Spencer P.L.C. Mr. Green, who hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to advise him, is one of several possible bidders for Marks & Spencer, which owns the fashion retailer Brooks Brothers in the United States. Analysts suggest that Marks & Spencer could fetch about $16 billion. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: A Kodak-Matsushita Deal

Panasonic will hold a 51 percent stake in the new company -- Matsushita Media Manufacturing L.L.C. of America -- and Kodak will have a 49 percent stake.

title: Experts Foresee Few Disruptions : Asia Hopes to Defy Y2K Doomsayers
description: KATMANDU  Less than a year after doomsayers painted Asia and the Pacific as the world's biggest millennium-bug black spot, officials throughout the region are proclaiming that their banks, businesses, governments and airlines will greet the new year with few noticeable computer glitches.

title: Running Away From History
description: Even today it is difficult to watch the operation of the Panama Canal's massive locks, or to navigate close to the manmade Gatun Lake on its route, and not be awed by this enduring feat of 19th century technology and resourcefulness. It wasn't just the digging against the passive resistance of nature, but the struggle of overcoming a Conradian geography, that killed thousands of workers before the first ship steamed from one ocean to the other through the middle of the hemisphere.

title: MAIL.COM TO BUY NETMOVES FOR $173 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Mail.com Inc., a provider of free electronic mail to Web sites, agreed yesterday to buy the NetMoves Corporation for about $173 million in stock, adding Internet fax services and 7,000 corporate customers. New York-based Mail.com said it would exchange 0.385336 of a share for each share of NetMoves, which changed its name in June from FaxSav Inc. Based on Friday's closing prices, the transaction values NetMoves at $9.87 a share. The shares of NetMoves rose $1.3125 each, to $6.9375. Mail.com fell $3.9375, to $21.6875. NetMoves, based in Edison, N.J., offers Internet fax and other document-delivery services to its 146,000 users.

Imparto, based in Palo Alto, Calif., founded in 1995, develops software that allows personalized marketing campaigns for companies. title: Transit Strike Threat
description: With a possible transit strike looming after midnight tonight, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is warning that a walkout would be disastrous for New York City's residents and its economy. Strictly speaking, Mr. Giuliani is a bystander in the labor negotiations between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency, and the transit union. But the mayor is right to step in and assert the city's interest in a deal. As he notes, a strike would be illegal under the state's Taylor Law, and it is irresponsible of the union to speak casually about walking off the job in the absence of a contract. Patient negotiating will be a more effective tactic for bus and subway workers seeking better wages.

Shares of Chemdex, based in Mountain View, Calif., rose $6.375, to $99.375, in Nasdaq trading, while shares of Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., fell 62.5 cents, to $23.5625.

The expansion is part of the company's plans for $33 billion in new investments worldwide by 2005.

title: A Competitive Warrior Displays His Softer Side

The opening movements of Haydn's G major Sonata (Hob. XVI:40) and Prokofiev's Sonata No. 8 could not be more different in tone and texture, yet both were organized in the same thoughtful way. In their beginnings one could predict their endings.

title: Russia's Parliamentary Vote
description: When Russians elect a new Parliament on Sunday, they will be exercising a right long denied them under Communist rule. That itself is the greatest achievement of Russia's young democracy. Voters will choose among more than 20 political parties and 6,700 candidates for the 450-seat lower house, or Duma. Yet this important election, a precursor to presidential elections next June, has also aroused destructive forces that threaten to undermine Russia's political progress.

title: When the Solar Wind Fell, Science Reaped a Windfall
description: The thin wind of interplanetary space blows with a ferocity unmatched by any desert, and on a scale that makes Earth look like a tiny blue oasis within a wasteland billions of miles across. Scientists consider that wind, which originates just above the roiling surface of the sun, to be as ancient and unyielding as the solar system itself. But one day last spring, the wind all but vanished.

title: Candidate Cast as Underdog Pours Resources Into Iowa

title: Panama Journal; A Canal Celebrity Honors Unheralded Workers

He was born one year before the canal was dedicated on Aug. 15, 1914, and has worked for the Panama Canal Commission for 71 years, starting as an office boy in 1928 ferrying papers and filling inkwells.

title: Golly! A Yank Wrote Those Oh-So-British Mysteries?
description: Death by decapitation on a farm in a quiet Yorkshire village, the impaling of a playwright in an isolated Scottish hotel, the kidnapping and drowning of the daughter of a member of Parliament -- Elizabeth George's intricately plotted mysteries take her readers through the English countryside and a wide range of professions and crimes. In the author's current best seller, ''In Pursuit of the Proper Sinner,'' a case of a double murder on a moor in Derbyshire deals more than passingly with a composer of the Andrew Lloyd Webber school of musicals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CADMUS, PAUL
description: CADMUS-Paul. Age 94. Artist. Born NYC 1904. Died peacefully at his home in Weston, CT. on December 12, 1999. Beloved companion of Jon Anderson for the past 35 years. Dear brother of Fidelma Cadmus Kirstein and brother-inlaw of Lincoln Kirstein, both deceased. Paul Cadmus was an elegant, dignified man who was an inspiration to all who knew him. An artist of great talent and integrity, he remained true to his unique, creative vision for 70 years. His support and encouragement of younger artists and his interest in their work was only one example of his great generosity and vitality. Those of us who knew him well and who worked with him over the years have always known that we were truly privileged. We treasure and honor our memories of his love and friendship. He will be greatly missed. Bridget Moore, Edward De Luca and the staff of DC Moore Gallery

The museum's chairman, Ronald Lauder bought an unusually large and turbulent van Gogh drawing of olive trees last week at Sotheby's in London for $8.5 million, a record price for a van Gogh drawing.

title: Translating S.U.V. Into European; Re-engineering The Old World
description: A typical ad for a Hyundai Galloper reads like a zoology text: ''Strong and Savage, Lives in Cities.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Fila Consolidates Worldwide Account
description: Fila Holding S.p.A. in Biella, Italy, has consolidated its worldwide sports shoe and apparel account, with billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million, at two units of the Omnicom Group.

title: Dungy and Buccaneers Keep Their Cool, and Keep On Winning
description: It was the third quarter in the Detroit Lions-Tampa Bay Buccaneers battle here on Sunday and John Lynch was on the bench, gasping for air, squelching the pain. Lynch injured his left knee two games earlier, against Seattle, and it had nagged him since. Now it seemed ready to blow up.

title: AutoNation To Close Stores And Cut Jobs
description: In an admission of serious difficulties, AutoNation Inc. announced today that it was closing most of its used car superstores immediately and laying off their 1,800 employees, while taking a one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings of $430 million to $490 million.

title: Investigating the Abuse of Gay Troops
description: Defense Secretary William Cohen took the appropriate action yesterday when he ordered the Pentagon's inspector general to conduct investigations at major military bases to determine the extent of harassment against gays. But this emergency effort to head off further viciousness is no long-term solution to a problem that can only be fixed by allowing gays to serve in the armed forces on an equal, open basis.

title: Indicted Head of the I.B.F. Steps Aside
description: The International Boxing Federation said today that its president would take a leave of absence to attend to his ailing heart and his indictment on corruption charges, a move that the sanctioning body hoped would let it avoid federal monitoring.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Grey Awarded 2 Accounts
description: Grey Advertising in New York has been awarded two accounts.

title: The Boy From Cuba, Exploited by Both Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Altered Crops Draw Protests, Pro and Con
description: As the Food and Drug Administration held the last of its three public hearings on bio-engineered food today, hundreds of protesters staged what organizers said was the largest rally in the United States against the use of genetic engineering in food.

title: A Nursing Home Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilson to Buy Texas Mill
description: Wilson Industries said today that it had agreed to acquire Texas Mill Supply and Manufacturing in a cash deal that combines two distributors of products and services to the petrochemical and power industries. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Texas Mill, a provider of safety products and inventory management services, employs 530 people and has annual sales of $150 million. Wilson, a unit of Smith International Inc., sells pipe, valves and fittings. Smith makes drill bits and provides drilling services for the oil and gas industry. It had revenue of $1.3 billion in the nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: With the Rangers, Daigle Is Leaving the Doghouse
description: His locker is next to the blue door in the corner of the Rangers' dressing room at Playland Ice Casino. It is not a prestigious location, akin to a restaurant table next to the kitchen. And it's not that secure a place to be either, since the door has seen many Rangers come and go in their last three seasons of struggle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISHER, BENJAMIN GERSHEIN
description: FLEISHER-Benjamin Gershein. Beloved uncle of Phyllis M. and Martin A. Stepper Died on November 27, 1999. Buried at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale, N Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about pretrial hearings this week for Linda R. Tripp misstated one of two felony counts she faces in Maryland as a result of tape-recording conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky. Mrs. Tripp is charged with having authorized her lawyer to play a tape for Newsweek, not with having given the tape to Michael Isikoff, a reporter for the magazine.

title: An Explosive Mix In Chechnya's War
description: To the Editor:

title: Weapons Scientist Pleads Not Guilty; He's Held Without Bail as Security Risk
description: A former United States weapons scientist pleaded not guilty today to the illegal computer downloading of a vast trove of nuclear arms data, but a federal magistrate ordered him jailed pending trial, declaring that the acts he is accused of represent ''a clear and present danger to the security of the United States.''

title: Next Time, Santa, Take the Reindeer
description: Santa Claus may have a lot on his mind at this time of year, but that does not exempt him from New York's motor vehicle laws.

title: Griffey Won't Accept a Trade to Mets
description: The Mets' valiant quest for Ken Griffey Jr. ended tonight when Griffey informed the Seattle Mariners he would not accept a trade to the Mets.

title: NTL to Buy Cablecom in a $3.7 Billion Deal
description: NTL Inc., Britain's largest cable concern, expanded its foothold in Continental Europe today with a $3.7 billion deal to buy Cablecom Group, Switzerland's leading cable television operator.

title: Mayan Carving to Be Returned to Guatemala
description: A 2,000-year-old Mayan stone carving that police detectives discovered in a Brooklyn garage last month will soon be shipped back to Guatemala, where it is believed to have been plundered from a ruin, the Guatemalan consul general in New York said yesterday.

title: Top Athletes Countdown Is a Big Step Up for ESPN
description: If you've watched ESPN's ''SportsCentury'' countdown, your choices for the century's greatest North American athletes may differ from the cable network's. But who ranks where is irrelevant -- except as fodder for amusing debates that go nowhere -- because the 50 profiles stand as ESPN's most creative work in its 20-year history. They, not their order, demand attention.

title: When Back-to-Back Disasters Hit Town
description: On Thursday night, when a small plane fell from the sky and landed in a backyard here, firefighters, police officers and other emergency workers were the rescuers, a job they had been trained to do. The next night, when a six-alarm fire engulfed the Municipal Building, headquarters for the Police and Fire Departments, it was the rescuers' turn to be rescued.

title: Get a Life!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Dead Zone Hit Record In the Gulf
description: The ''Dead Zone'' that is formed in the Gulf of Mexico by pollutants from the Mississippi River was larger than ever this year, say researchers at the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium.

title: Wages vs. Warrants
description: In the months leading up to the current contract showdown, the president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union maneuvered to turn the dispute into one focusing on economic justice for New York City's subway and bus workers.

title: Potent Virus Threatens Babies' Breathing
description: A highly contagious respiratory virus that often overwhelms pediatric clinics in winter has arrived in force, federal officials say, and is sending twice as many babies to the hospital as scientists had expected.

title: REMY PROFIT TRIPLES
description: A prominent French wine and liquor company, Remy Cointreau, said that its first-half pretax profit more than tripled as demand for Champagne booms ahead of millennium celebrations. Pretax profits before special items soared to 193 million francs (about $30 million) for the six months that ended on Sept. 30 from 58 million francs in the period the previous year. The company forecast high demand for Champagne throughout 2000 and a ''very positive'' outlook in general. Remy, maker of Piper-Heidsieck, posted a 32 percent gain in Champagne volumes.

title: 'Bold Move' Disputed
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's remark that she would like to march in the St. Patrick's Day parade referred incorrectly to Empire State Pride Agenda, a gay advocacy group. While a co-chairman of the group, Jeff Soref, was an organizer of a fund-raiser last Tuesday night for Mrs. Clinton, the advocacy group itself had no role in the event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, LOUIS
description: LAZAR-Louis. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences on the passing of our member, Louis Lazar, beloved husband of Rhoda, devoted father of our members, Edward and David Lazar. May the family be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Thomas Is Signed To Replace Pierce
description: The Celtics signed the free-agent forward Jamel Thomas to make up for the loss of their leading scorer, Paul Pierce, who will be out about two weeks with a sprained ankle.

title: Chief Should Command
description: To the Editor:

title: Creating a Brand Image: The Mannequin Is the Message
description: When Robin Kramer uses the word romance, there's a good chance she is using it as a verb, and an even better chance that she isn't referring to a man buying a woman Calla lilies or taking her to Vermont. In Ms. Kramer's vernacular, shoes might be ''romanced,'' which is not to suggest that she advocates unconventional relationships with one's loafers or sling-backs.

title: Peace Quest, Personal And Global
description: Sachiyo Ito and Company offered a ''Concert Dedicated to World Peace'' on Saturday afternoon at the Clark Studio Theater and made the program artistically meaningful as well as idealistically honorable.

title: Russian Troops Advance to Grozny Outskirts
description: Russian forces advanced to the outskirts of Grozny today, as the senior Kremlin policy maker on Chechnya predicted that the city would be seized within 10 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAURER, ESTHER
description: MAURER-Esther. Beloved wife of Gerald, devoted mother of Jani, James, Martin and Mathew. Cherished grandmother, dear sister of Margie Steinhauer and Kate Ludgin. Services today, 10 AM, ''Temple Beth Sholom'' 172nd St and Northern Blvd, Flushing, N.Y.

title: Latest Gym Offering: Shared Training
description: Two years ago Rick Ellis of Bordentown, N.J., wanted to hire a personal trainer to build up what he called his ''98-pound-weakling body.'' But Mr. Ellis, a 47-year-old kindergarten teacher, was not about to go to the gym near his home and ask about one-on-one workouts. ''It was much too intimidating,'' he said. (It didn't help that the gym was called Powerhouse Fitness.)

title: Lowell Is Honored
description: Mike Lowell, the Florida Marlins' third baseman, won the 1999 Tony Conigliaro award, given annually to the major leaguer who overcomes adversity through spirit, determination and courage.

title: As Polio Fades, Dr. Salk's Vaccine Re-emerges
description: It is a turn of events that might have delighted Dr. Jonas Salk. Nearly 40 years after the United States abandoned his injectable polio vaccine in favor of the oral version created by his rival, Dr. Albert Sabin, the pendulum has swung back. Starting in 2000, the government has declared, the Sabin vaccine will be dropped and replaced by a series of old-fashioned polio shots that will use a stronger version of what is essentially the Salk vaccine.

title: Experience? No, but the Zest and Drive of Youth
description: The New York Youth Symphony, which opened its season on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, often gets compared to professional orchestras, and one can hear why. Its music making is alive and full; its players are thoroughly prepared and very able. But at the same time the comparison is a little unfair. The average age of these musicians is 16, and their lack of experience shows in expected ways: in the problems they have playing very quietly, so that balance can sometimes be strange, and in a lack of agility in getting through the occasional quick turn of phrase. On the other hand, they have a freshness and a drive that seasoned ensembles are going to rediscover only very occasionally.

title: COMANY BRIEFS
description: EATON CORP., Cleveland, the second largest maker of hydraulic equipment, agreed to sell its agricultural cylinder business to closely held Hyco International Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: The Military Orders Spot Check of Bases On Gay Harassment
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen today ordered spot checks of major military bases around the country to determine whether gay service members are being harassed, and he told the Pentagon inspector general to report back within 90 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIDMAN, WILLIAM
description: MAIDMAN-William. 95, of Hollywood, FL; formerly of NYC and Great Neck, NY. On Saturday, December 11. Beloved husband of Ada and of the late Aida; father of Richard (Gail), David (Nancy) and Bonnie; cherished grandfather of Patrick (Jacqueline), Mitchel (Arlene), Gregory, Dagny, Randi (Howard) and Wendy; adored great-grandfather of Allison, Beatrice, Harrison and Julia; revered by Evan and Starr and Mark, grandchildren and son by marriage; brother of the late Irving, Moe, Samuel and Lea. Former member of Glen Oaks Country Club, distinguished member of the real estate community, revered and loved by all who were blessed by his long life, humor and sagacity. Services were held at Congregation Emanu-El on Sunday. The family will be at Richard & Gail's Manhattan apt, 9 East 79 St. through Wednesday, at 2-4 & 7-9 PM, & Thursday, at his Port Washington home at the same times.

title: Pataki's Transit Role? It's Behind the Scenes
description: For subway and bus riders hoping to be saved from a possible transit strike, it was easy to look no farther than City Hall, or the Midtown offices of the transit system. But the real power to reach accord with the transit workers lay elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMSTEIN, BOBBIE
description: BAUMSTEIN - Bobbie. Beloved wife of the late Alexander. Devoted mother of Eugene and Barbara, Richard and Barbara, Donald and Tatiana. Adoring grandmother of Amy and Marc Mathios, Douglas, Jeffrey, Scott, Michael and Rachel; and great-grandmother of Jason. She will live in our hearts forever. Services Wednesday, 10:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: CALENDAR
description: Toasts of the Town

title: Mirror on the Past: Canal's Fate Reflects Shift by U.S.
description: Millennium celebrations may still be a couple of weeks away, but symbolically the American Century ended here today with a ceremony marking the transfer of the Panama Canal to Panama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONNESS, BILLIE
description: MONNESS-Billie. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and former longtime member, Billie Monness, who died on December 8, 1999. We extend our sincerest sympathies to her family and friends. The Board of Governors The Woodmere Club

title: N.F.L. Reviews Sale of the Jets
description: Members of the National Football League finance committee, as part of a regularly scheduled meeting, discussed the pending sale of the Jets at the league's offices yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKIRON, SUSAN G.
description: ACKIRON-Susan G. On December 14, 1999 in Stamford, Connecticut. Beloved wife of Lowell Ackiron, of Stamford, Conn. Loving mother of Stephanie Benjamin, Tobyhanna, PA., and Evan Ackiron, of San Francisco, CA. Also survived by two loving grandchildren. Funeral today December 15, at 11 A.M. at Temple Sinai, 458 Lakeside Drive, Stamford, CT (203-322-1649). Burial private. Memorials may be made in her memory to The Multiple Sclerosis Association.

title: Perlman and the Boston Dispatch a War Horse
description: Maybe it's just this critic's New York chauvinism, but you would think that when a major orchestra from out of town comes to Carnegie Hall, an artistically significant program would be in order. The program that the Boston Symphony Orchestra under its music director, Seiji Ozawa, presented on Wednesday night was hardly that, the main offering being a routine performance of the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto with Itzhak Perlman as soloist.

title: Why Europe Seeks A Military Profile
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page yesterday about the award of an Orientation.com account to Grey Advertising include a finalist erroneously among those in the review. DDB Downtown took part but withdrew before the final round.

title: Report Says Isolation Takes Toll on Terrorism Suspect
description: A Harvard Medical School psychiatrist who specializes in the effects of solitary confinement on prisoners has concluded that a defendant accused of having links to the suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden has been so mentally devastated by his imprisonment that he may not be able to assist meaningfully in his own defense, newly disclosed records show.

title: Spreading Harlem's Boom To a Neglected Boulevard
description: If 125th Street is Harlem's Cinderella, emerging from the ashes to a kind of nobility, Frederick Douglass Boulevard, the lean corridor that stretches north through the neighborhood from Central Park West, is her warted stepsister, abandoned in the ruins.

title: Where War Roiled Danube, Nature Is Peacemaker
description: In the soggy lowlands along the Danube, where war raged less than a decade ago, biologists and engineers from three nations are working on an unusual project using nature to promote peace.

title: House Panel to Question Democratic Fund-Raiser
description: After years of investigations, partisan vitriol and accusations of stonewalling leveled at the Clinton White House, Republicans in Congress will at last get what they have long sought, a hearing on Wednesday to publicly question a Democratic fund-raiser at the epicenter of the 1996 campaign fund-raising controversy: John Huang.

title: TN Media Chairman Takes Post at FCB
description: Mike Drexler, 61, a longtime agency media executive who has served since last year as chairman of TN Media, is being named to head media operations at a sibling, FCB Worldwide.

title: The Mideast's Moment
description: Israel and its neighbors have arrived at a critical turning point. When the Syrian foreign minister greets Israel's prime minister at the White House today, Syria will be taking a giant step toward recognizing the state of Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDEN, GLORIA
description: LINDEN-Gloria. On Monday, December 13. We will all mourn the loss of this sweet, loving, caring woman. Beloved wife of Murray Linden. The mother of David, Eugene, and Cynthia Carlaw. Her Australian family sends their love and mourns with her American family. Eight grandchildren will miss her. Memorial service at the Unitarian Church Jackson Ave. Hastings, Saturday, Dec. 18th. 11 AM.

title: MANAGER-LED GROUP OFFERS TO BUY TRUCK PARTS MAKER
description: Transportation Technologies Industries , the second-largest United States maker of heavy-truck seats, said yesterday that an investor group led by senior managers had offered to buy the company for $205.8 million. The group offered $20 a share for about 10.3 million shares outstanding. The company said a committee of independent directors would review the proposal. The Chicago-based company changed its name in June from Johnstown America Industries and sold its railroad freight-car business to focus on truck parts. The company's shares rose $2.4375 each, to $17.9375.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Top-Quality Ingredients For the Serious Home Cook

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, JOSEPH
description: HELLER-Joseph. The GuillainBarre Syndrome Foundation International mourns the passing of Honorary Board Member Joseph Heller. Mr. Heller was an outstanding spokesperson for this rare neurologic disorder educating both the lay and medical communities through his writings and interviews. The Board of Directors and Medical Advisory Board of the Guillain-Barre Syndrome Foundation are saddened by this tragic loss and express their deepest sympathy to his family. Estelle Benson, Founder and Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALESI, CONSTANTINE ''DENNY''
description: GALESI-Constantine ''Denny''. Of New Vernon, NJ on Monday, December 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbara (Nee Ince) Galesi. Loving father of Alexandra, Francesca, Arianna, Constantine ''Pablo'', Gabriel ''Max'' and Christian Galesi. Also survived by his Grandson, Julian and his brothers, Francesco and Michael Galesi. Predeceased by his brothers Vincent and John and his sister Genevieve (nee Galesi) Boitz. Funeral Service from the Burroughs, Kohr and Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main Street, Madison, NJ on Thursday, December 15, 1999 at 9:30 A.M. Then to the Church of Christ the King, Blue Mill Road, New Vernon, New Jersey for the Funeral Mass at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Kidney Cancer Association; 1234 Sherman Avenue; Suite 203; Evanston, Illinois 60202. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: 3Com Up on Plan To Spin Off Palm
description: Shares of the 3Com Corporation rose as much as 16 percent today after its Palm Inc. unit, the maker of electronic organizers, filed for an initial public offering and said that Nokia, Motorola and America Online would buy shares.

title: Spirit of Christmas Past and Present, All Stuffed Into One Man's Collection
description: This is a man obsessed with Christmas. Jock Elliott Jr., 79, retired chairman of the advertising firm of Ogilvy & Mather, has been collecting Christmas books and mementos for more than 40 years. He now has 3,000 objects, most of them the first of something: the first printed picture of Santa descending a chimney, from The New-York Mirror in 1841; the first Christmas card, from 1843; the book in which the words ''Merry'' and ''Christmas'' first appeared together, in ''An Itinerary,'' a travel book by Fynes Moryson Gent, in 1617.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, PEARL
description: RESNICK-Pearl. The Joseph L. Morse Geriatric Center and the Morse Women's Auxilary mourns the loss of longtime friend, supporter and benefactor, Pearl Resnick, and extends its sincerest condolences to the entire Resnick family on their loss. Pearl was a strong advocate of the Morse Geriatric Center and the Women's Auxilary and helped create many annual fundraisers to benefit the Center's residents. In December 1989, Morse Geriatric Center was able to expand through the generosity of herself and late husband Jack Resnick, with the dedication of the Resnick 160-bed nursing pavillion. She served as an inspiration to the entire Jewish community and to everyone she touched with her compassion and grace. She will be greatly missed by all of us. Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County Chaplin, Rabbi Alan Sherman; President, Morse Board of Directors, Norman P. Goldblum; Morse Women's Auxilary President, Joan Simmons; Morse Men's Associates President, Burton M. Katz; Executive Vice President, E. Drew Gackenheimer; Vice President of Public Affairs, Faye Nelson

title: The Workplace Can Be Threatening, Especially for Women
description: It's getting more dangerous for women in the workplace. In a survey of human resource professionals this year by the Society for Human Resource Management, 57 percent of respondents reported incidents of violence or threats involving employees over the previous 43 months. A 1996 survey yielded a lower figure, 48 percent, but because it covered a shorter period, the figures are not analogous.

title: New Jersey Residents and Lawmakers Rally Against Gas Pipeline Project
description: On the eve of a vote by federal regulators, about two dozen residents and four members of Congress held one last rally to denounce a plan to build 90-miles of natural gas pipeline that would cut through 33 New Jersey towns.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Teachers Retain Paterson for Talks

title: Red Storm Shows Two Faces; Neither Wins
description: The talented DePaul Blue Demons have played dazzling games against strong teams (see Duke) this season, and ho-hum games against not-so-strong teams (see Monmouth). St. John's gave DePaul one half of each type of opponent tonight, playing a strong first half before falling, 71-65, to 19th-ranked DePaul in Allstate Arena, formerly the Rosemont Horizon.

title: Country Boys (One in a Dress)
description: Performing for six years in New York, Y'All didn't get the respect they deserved. A cross-dressing guitar-and-ukulele country duo, they searched for their niche in West Village theaters, midtown country bars and East Village gay clubs. But wherever they performed, audiences arrived with the impression that they were a novelty act, that they were poking big-city fun at country music. But Y'All was serious. So serious, in fact, that last year they packed their bags and moved to Nashville.

title: DNA Tests Free Man After 6 Years; Had Been Convicted In Rape of Student
description: A day after being presented with new DNA evidence indicating that a New Brunswick man was wrongly convicted in the 1992 rape of a Rutgers University student, a Superior Court judge today ordered him freed from prison.

title: Rules of the Playground
description: To the Editor:

title: Dip Into the Past: Rediscovering The Pleasures Of Punch
description: LEAFING through a book on drinks recently, I came across an old recipe for punch and realized I could barely remember the last time I had had one. It wasn't that I didn't like punch. I simply hadn't thought about it in years.

title: Corrections
description: A news article and a news analysis article yesterday about negotiations between the Transport Workers Union and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York misspelled the given name of the authority's executive director in some copies. He is Marc V. Shaw, not Mark.

title: Sugar and Spice And Other Nutrients
description: PUMPKIN pie? ''You might as well put this right up there on the food pyramid,'' said Dr. Eric Rimm, an associate professor of epidemiology and nutrition at the Harvard School of Public Health, getting into the spirit of this week's Eating Well column which, in honor of the season, has been temporarily renamed Dr. Feelgood's Eating Well column.

title: EMERSON TO BUY PRODUCER OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS GEAR
description: The Emerson Electric Company, an electronic equipment manufacturer, agreed yesterday to acquire the telecommunications products business of Jordan Industries for $440 million. It will also assume debt of $540 million. The acquisition will give Emerson a broader line of products and services in the Internet-infrastructure and telecommunications areas. The unit being acquired, Jordan Telecom of Deerfield, Ill., makes fiber optic systems, cable TV components, power protection systems, cellular site structures, and wireless and data-communications equipment. Shares of Emerson, which is based in St. Louis, rose 81.25 cents, to $54.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Print the Recipe
description: Whole Roasted Chicken

title: For Hard Hats, a Confusion of Tongues
description: Last summer, as a worker welded steel beams in a church in Aurora, Colo., falling sparks ignited wooden trusses below. Another worker, seeing the flames and smoke, yelled a warning, but the welder did not understand a word.

title: Paul Cadmus Dies at 94; Virtuosic American Painter
description: Paul Cadmus, an American artist noted for a virtuosic figurative style that he applied to subjects ranging from biting social satire to moralizing allegories to sensual, sometimes sentimental male nudes, died on Sunday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 94.

title: GERMANS TO SET UP $5.1 BILLION FUND FOR NAZIS' SLAVES
description: After months of bitter negotiations, German industry and government officials agreed today to establish a fund of $5.1 billion to compensate people who were slave laborers during the Nazi regime.

title: Danish Mother's Claim of False Arrest Is Rejected
description: In a case that set off a trans-Atlantic debate about child-rearing practices, a federal jury in Manhattan rejected a Danish woman's claim yesterday that New York City police officers had falsely arrested her after she left her baby daughter in a stroller on the sidewalk to go inside an East Village restaurant for a drink.

title: Where to Buy Country Hams
description: COUNTRY hams are not easy to find outside the South. But they are worth the effort that is required to soak, scrub and boil them. If you want the flavor without all of that effort, you can buy them already boned and cooked, even sliced.

title: HEAD OF PEMEX RESIGNS
description: Adrian Lajous Vargas resigned after five years as director general of Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state oil monopoly, and was replaced by Rogelio Montemayor Seguy, a former governor of the state of Coahuila. In a letter Mr. Lajous said the energy sector needed ''to unify its approach and work styles,'' implying differences with Energy Secretary Luis Tellez. A $10.5 billion project to increase production at the Cantarell oil field, initiated by Mr. Lajous, is behind schedule and faces an audit by a federal watchdog agency. Mr. Montemayor is a longtime public administrator with no experience in the petroleum industry. The change will take effect on Jan. 1.

title: Scallops, Plus Crunch
description: SCALLOPS have so many virtues -- they're tender, fast cooking, high in protein and flavorful -- that they are perfect for weeknight cooking. There are dozens of simple ways to serve them after they have been simply seared, beginning with lemon and continuing with pan sauces, made by adding other ingredients to the skillet after the scallops are cooked. These take advantage of the flavors and caramelized sugars left behind by the scallops.

title: The Allure of Place in a Mobile World
description: ''This is what I prayed for,'' wrote the Roman poet Horace. ''A piece of land -- not so very big, with a garden and, near the house, a spring that never fails, and a bit of wood to round it off.'' Those words were set down more than 2000 years ago, around 30 B.C. It is easy to understand the emotion prompting them. We still recognize what Horace meant by a rural garden, a place to take refuge, as he did, from the irritations of city life.

title: Reducing Audits of the Wealthy, I.R.S. Turns Eye on Working Poor
description: The Internal Revenue Service is reducing its efforts to find cheating by businesses and high-income individuals, and stepping up investigations into two forms of cheating that are more likely to involve the working poor than the affluent.

title: Recipes of the South That Speak for the People Themselves
description: SOMETIMES recipes say more about a place and the people who inhabit it than an essay ever could. When John T. Edge and his colleagues at the Center for the Study of Southern Culture at the University of Mississippi set out to write a Southern cookbook, they realized this.

title: It's Not the Product That's Different, It's the Process
description: MARSHALL McLUHAN wrote 35 years ago that the medium is the message, a puzzling perception that turned out to be profound. Today, a great many business thinkers, in one way or another, seem to be saying something similar: In the new economy, the process is the product.

title: Carving
description: Its not a great idea to carve the chicken at the table (unless youre a pro) or anywhere near it, since its a bit messy as a process  and the objective is a result that has a sense of neatness and precision about it. You want to end up with eight beautiful pieces of chicken, one dark and one light for each of four servings. The method here is probably the most widely practiced both in the professional kitchen and among advanced home cooks.

title: A U.S. BID FOR UNITED BISCUITS
description: Britain's biggest cookie maker, United Biscuits P.L.C., received an offer of $1.9 billion in cash from the Nabisco Holdings Corporation and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, a Dallas-based private equity firm. The offer is for 245 pence a share. A French-led investment group that includes Paribas immediately said it was mulling making a higher bid for United Biscuits. Shares of United Biscuits surged 20 pence, to 254.5 pence -- higher than the takeover offer -- as investors anticipated a bidding war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 6 about a public forum on discrimination in New York City's taxi industry misspelled the surname of the director of the Pak Brothers' Yellow Cab Drivers Union, a fraternal organization. He is Farooq A. Bhatti, not Bahti.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the ordering of spot checks at major military bases to determine whether gay service members are being harassed misspelled the given name of a co-executive director of the Servicemembers Legal Defense Network. He is Dixon Osborne, not Dickson.

title: De La Hoya and Coley Star in the Latest Soap Opera
description: Oscar De La Hoya and Derrell Coley sat on stage at the Theater in Madison Square Garden yesterday surrounded by the set from ''A Christmas Carol.'' The two fighters were there to promote their bout at the Garden on Feb. 26, but they are also players in another drama that has been unfolding since De La Hoya lost his World Boxing Council welterweight title to Felix Trinidad.

description: Some cities have scaled back their expectations for New Year's now that they have no illusions that holiday visitors will have to camp outside overflowing hotels. In Manhattan, rooms are available at many hotels for New Year's, and events like the star-studded $1,000-a-person Celebration 2000 party at Jacob Javits Convention Center have been canceled.

description: Two members of the militant Palestinian group Hamas were killed by Israeli commandos Monday night near Hebron as they prepared a bomb attack, Israeli army officials said today.

description: Moscow's embattled and combative Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov held a rally at the foot of the Kremlin tonight, under the nose of opponents who for weeks now have been orchestrating his political hanging.

title: VIACOM TO DELAY BLOCKBUSTER SPINOFF FOR HIGHER PRICE
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it would not go ahead with a planned spinoff to shareholders of its Blockbuster Inc. video-rental chain until Blockbuster's price exceeded $20 a share. The plan to distribute Blockbuster stock to Viacom's shareholders also depends upon a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that the distribution will be tax free to Viacom and its shareholders, considering Viacom's planned acquisition of the CBS Corporation. Dallas-based Blockbuster went public in August, selling an 18 percent stake for $15 a share. The company's shares closed yesterday at $16, up 25 cents.

description: ONLY the uninitiated would think there was anything odd about the goings-on yesterday in the county courthouse here.

title: Corrections

title: Confident Samaranch Testifying At Congressional Inquiry Today
description: If Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, felt jittery about testifying before a House subcommittee on Wednesday, he refused to show it tonight. In his corner hotel suite in Georgetown, he sat serenely on a sofa and sounded certain that the reforms enacted last weekend by the I.O.C. will settle all Congressional doubts about the direction of the embattled organization.

title: I Write Copy for a Web Start-up
description: A few weeks ago, I abandoned the sinking ship of newspaper journalism and hopped aboard a pirate vessel, the Internet. Instead of writing news for a venerable newspaper, I'm now providing content for a Silicon Alley start-up founded by two 20-somethings.

title: Voice of N.B.A. Is Albert Again
description: Bob Costas will relinquish his role as NBC's lead announcer for National Basketball Association after the current season to make way for the return of Marv Albert.

title: Study Finds Fault in Tracing of Drug Reactions
description: Federal investigators have identified serious flaws in the Food and Drug Administration's system for tracking adverse drug reactions, and are recommending that the agency move from a voluntary reporting system to a mandatory one in which hospitals would be required to notify the government whenever patients are injured by medication.

title: Cabernet Franc Stars as Itself
description: ANONYMITY is too often the fate of cabernet franc. Its usual role in Bordeaux is as a blending agent, to soften the tannic edges of cabernet sauvignon, its dominant relation. When it does get to shine on its own, it is plagued by issues of identity. Do you know it by the gloriously rich wines of Cheval Blanc, the only major Bordeaux chateau whose wines are largely cabernet franc, or the light-bodied, herbal wines of Chinon, Bourgueil and other towns of the upper Loire? How about the lean, acidic wines of Friuli in Italy?

title: First the New Russia, Now the New Tea Room
description: THE Russian Tea Room has always been more and less than a restaurant. Like some strange, wind-sculptured geological formation, it slowly took shape over many years, adapting itself to the peculiar needs of its core customers, most of them affiliated with the entertainment businesses scattered throughout the neighborhood, most notably Carnegie Hall next door. It retained an irreducibly eccentric personality -- an outsize, stage-Russian role -- that was reflected in the weird decor, dominated by red banquettes, big samovars and year-round Christmas ornaments.

title: A Tailored Path To Graduation; Work Portfolio Is Challenged As Alternative to State Tests
description: Alec I. Reinstein built an I.B.M.-compatible computer from scratch. Luis Cabrera explored the inner workings of the Manhattan borough president's office. And Walamais Cherdkethawut created her own number system.

description: IT has been decided: The duty of ambitious little restaurants is to go where none have gone before, to colonize all corners of Manhattan, neighborhood by neighborhood, until everybody has equal access to foie gras appetizers. Such is the manifest destiny of restaurants, and for the last six weeks, 71 Clinton Fresh Food has been doing its part.

description: My trial begins today. The authorities have forbidden me from speaking out. Yet I feel I must.

title: TALKS ON WINE LABEL DISPUTE
description: A meeting planned for today aims to resolve a dispute involving the European Union and South Africa over the use of terms like port and sherry on the labels of South African-produced wines and spirits. Spain and Portugal have held up a European trade accord with South Africa over the issue, arguing that South Africa should not use terms that have been traditionally European. Finland, which holds the European Union presidency, hopes to convince the two European countries that South Africa will indeed phase out the terms over 12 years.

title: Mentally Ill or Just Feeling Sad?
description: Now that the surgeon general has put his imprimatur on the idea that one-fifth of America is in need of mental health care, we are in danger of seeing a burst of indiscriminate and misplaced new spending that could end up hurting, rather than helping, the people who need treatment most.

title: Justly Harsh Punishment for Mr. Volpe
description: Short of murder, it is hard to imagine a crime more vicious than the torture Justin Volpe inflicted on Abner Louima. The corrosive effect of Mr. Volpe's crimes on trust between New York City police and many communities may take years to mend. The suffering he caused Mr. Louima and his family cannot be fully measured. The 30-year sentence imposed by Federal District Judge Eugene Nickerson will not heal those wounds, but it sends a strong message to law enforcement officers that police brutality will face severe punishment.

title: SANWA TO CUT 1,000
description: The brokerage affiliates of Sanwa Bank Ltd. -- the Universal Securities Company, the Dai-Ichi Securities Company, the Taiheiyo Securities Company and the Towa Securities Company -- said they would cut nearly 1,000 employees and almost a third of their branches after merging next April. The combined brokerage firm, the Tsubasa Securities Company, will have about 3,700 employees. The new firm will have 128 branch offices, down from 168.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar rose as reports showed only a 0.1 percent increase in consumer prices in November and a bigger-than-expected rise in retail sales. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0043, down from $1.0141.

title: SWAZILAND SUGAR
description: In a move to consolidate its control of the Swazi sugar production market, the Royal Swaziland Sugar Corporation has made an offer to buy a rival, the Mhlume Sugar Company, for an undisclosed amount. If successful, Royal Swazi would be the biggest employer in the tiny African nation, with 8,000 workers. The new company would produce about 315,000 tons of sugar annually.

title: TRANSIT UNION REPORTS PACT AVERTING A CITYWIDE STRIKE; MAYOR EXPECTS NORMAL DAY
description: New York City's transit workers and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority drew close to a deal last night to avert a threatened strike, union officials said, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he expected that bus and subway service would be near normal today.

description: Al Gonder had a heart attack a few years ago and now takes six different prescription drugs every day.

title: CHS ELECTRONICS AGREES TO SELL EUROPEAN OPERATIONS
description: The microcomputer distributor CHS Electronics Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its European operations to its senior managers in a transaction that it valued at about $300 million, most of which consists of the assumption of debt. The Miami-based company, which has been battling financial problems, said the agreement would relieve it of its long-term debt. Under the pact, CHS will also receive $11 million in cash -- or be relieved of an equivalent amount of liabilities -- and receive a 10 percent stake in the purchasing group. Shares of CHS closed at $1.50, up 12.5 cents.

title: Oracle 2nd-Quarter Results Beat Analyst Expectations
description: Shares of the Oracle Corporation soared this evening in after-hours trading.

title: UBS TO LIST SHARES IN U.S.
description: Europe's second-biggest bank, UBS A.G., said it would list shares in New York as it weighs United States acquisitions. The Swiss bank, also the world's biggest money manager, may want a United States purchase to get back on track after profit from private banking dropped 42 percent in the third quarter, analysts said. UBS shares have fallen this year, while competitors rose. The Swiss institution joins Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank in planning to trade in the United States, where last month's repeal of a 1933 law separating securities firms and banks could ease mergers among European universal banks and United States rivals.

title: Julie Andrews Sues Throat Surgeon
description: JULIE ANDREWS, who says the singing voice that proclaimed the hills alive in ''The Sound of Music'' was silenced by a throat operation in 1997, filed a malpractice suit yesterday against the doctor who did the surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, W. FRANCIS
description: FITZGERALD-W. Francis. The Board of Managers of Lincoln Hall mourn the passing of our beloved Board member, W. Francis FitzGerald. Frank faithfully served on the Board for 50 years as Vice President, Secretary and Treasurer. He was also Chairman of the Executive and Finance Committees and was a member of the Audit and Insurance, Buildings and Grounds, Pension and Program Committees. Frank was highly instrumental consummating the sale of land of the original site of the Catholic Protectory in Parkchester to Metropolitan Life; the sale of land to the Town of Somers School District, and finally, he was principal in the sale of land which is presently the Anglebrook Golf Course. Frank's history with our agency is rich with his contributions. A strong advocate of children's rights, and his dedication to the youth served by Lincoln Hall are exceeded only by his total commitment to the Hall. All of us who knew Frank personally will miss his wonderful sense of humor and cherish his memory. James G. Nugent, President and the Lincoln Hall Board of Managers

title: Rangers' New Style Is a Winner With Coach
description: After his team completed a stretch of five games in eight days, Coach John Muckler said last Wednesday that the Rangers had earned some well-deserved rest. They had run off a season-high unbeaten streak of four games. Thanks to the National Hockey League schedule makers, the rest was a little longer than Muckler desired.

description: You're on your own, Charlie Brown.

description: Treasury yields rose sharply yesterday as investors chose to ignore November's moderate consumer price data and instead focused on stronger-than-expected retail sales.

title: Designing The Nouveau Building On the Block
description: Acclaim doesn't appear to turn Christian de Portzamparc's head. The French architect designed the East 57th Street American flagship office tower for the French luxury goods conglomerate LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, a building many critics have called one of the most successful to rise in Manhattan in the last generation. Ask him how that feels and he shrugs.

This spirited and elegant lady has left many warm and enduring memories. Funeral mass Tuesday 11:00 a.m. at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Thomas Choir School, 202 West 58th St, NY, NY 10019.

title: Bronx Man Killed In Ambush at Home
description: A Bronx man was shot and killed Monday night by two men who forced their way into his apartment and ambushed him when he arrived home with his wife and daughter, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSON, HAROLD E., M.D.
