Diane and Mark Lebowitz, and Denise and Mitchell Tanzman, loving grandfather of Alex, Emily, Danielle and Olivia. Past President of the Brooklyn Psychiatric and Neurology Societies. Life fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and delegate to its assembly. Funeral services Thursday noon at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, RICHARD
description: FENTON-Richard. The Board of Directors of 936 Fifth Avenue Corporation offers its condolences to the family of Richard Fenton. Mr. Fenton was a neighbor and valued member of the Board of Directors of 936 Fifth Avenue. His contribution through the years to the building's operations and success were numerous and will be missed. Board of Directors, 936 Fifth Avenue Corporation

title: Housing Secretary Chides Mayor For 'Criminalizing' the Homeless
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the secretary of housing and urban development, said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had ''overreacted'' to a brick attack on a Midtown street last month by ordering the police to remove homeless people from the streets.

title: Charles Earland, 58, Soul-Jazz Organist And Saxophonist
description: Charles Earland, an organist and saxophonist who was a popular exponent of the soul-jazz idiom in the 1970's, died on Saturday at the Holiday Inn hotel in Kansas City, Mo., the morning after playing a concert. He was 58 and lived in Matteson, Ill.

title: Abstinence Is Focus of U.S. Sex Education
description: Sex education in the nation's schools is increasingly focused on abstinence, with more than 1 in 3 districts using an abstinence-only curriculum that permits discussion of contraception only in its failures, according to two national studies released today.

title: HONG KONG INTERNET DEAL
description: Shedding one of its Asian assets, AT&T has decided to sell its Hong Kong operation that sells Internet services to consumers and small-business customers to a start-up company backed by venture capitalists, executives close to the deal said yesterday. The companies do not intend to disclose financial terms, but the executives said the value of the deal was less than $100 million. Iasiaworks, the company buying the AT&T unit, is trying to become a communications carrier throughout Asia.

title: MERCK TO SELL IMAGING UNIT
description: As part of its strategy to focus more on drugs, Merck of Germany agreed to sell its stake in a joint venture that makes X-ray and ultrasound materials to the Bracco family of Milan for $880 million. The Bracco family will pay for the 50 percent of the company it does not already own over a period of five years, Merck said.

title: From Rank-and-File, Relief Mixed With Resentment
description: As news of a possible settlement between the transit workers union and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority spread last night, rank-and-file members expressed relief edged with resentment, saying they were pleased a strike had apparently been averted but angry over the way the Giuliani administration handled the situation.

title: William Maidman, 95, Real Estate Figure
description: William Maidman, a plumbing and fittings manufacturer who was also a major real estate owner and manager in New York, died on Saturday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 95.

title: BRITISH INFLATION UNCHANGED
description: Britain's annual inflation rate, excluding mortgage interest payments, remained unchanged at 2.2. percent in November, the Office for National Statistics said. The figure was comfortably below the Bank of England's inflation target of 2.5 percent but did not dampen speculation that the bank would raise interest rates in the coming months to head off inflation fueled by forecasts of economic growth next year. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRK, STANLEY E.
description: SHIRK-Stanley E. Former executive who served as a member of the Board of Directors of Bache Securities and many of the Prudential Mutual Funds, died on December 7 at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 83. Mr. Shirk also received an Honorary Doctorate from his alma mater, St.John's University in 1994. Mr. Shirk is survived by his wife Barbara; a daughter, Susan Shirk; a son, Richard Shirk, and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 17, at 11AM at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave (at 80th St). In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Stanley E. Shirk Scholarship Fund, St.John's University, 8000 Utopia Parkway, Jamaica NY 11439.

title: A Breakdown on the Sales Lot; Superdealerships Have Trouble Turning a Profit
description: The AutoNation operation here looks more like a gigantic Starbucks than a place to sell used cars.

title: The Grace Of Generations
description: Coming down through Bluegrass Country from Lexington to this bustling little farming town, it's not at all difficult to envision central Kentucky as it must have been 150 years ago. The stately farm homes -- mansions, really -- the well-kept barns and stables and the spotless white fences and handsome stables are ample proof that Kentuckians are proud of their land and their heritage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CADMUS, PAUL
description: CADMUS-Paul. Age 94. Artist. Born NYC 1904. Died peacefully at his home in Weston, CT. on December 12, 1999. Beloved companion of Jon Anderson for the past 35 years. Dear brother of Fidelma Cadmus Kirstein and brother-inlaw of Lincoln Kirstein, both deceased. Paul Cadmus was an elegant, dignified man who was an inspiration to all who knew him. An artist of great talent and integrity, he remained true to his unique, creative vision for 70 years. His support and encouragement of younger artists and his interest in their work was only one example of his great generosity and vitality. Those of us who knew him well and who worked with him over the years have always known that we were truly privileged. We treasure and honor our memories of his love and friendship. He will be greatly missed. Bridget Moore, Edward De Luca and the staff of DC Moore Gallery

title: CIBA TO SELL UNIT
description: Switzerland's second-biggest chemical maker, Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G., agreed to sell its polymers unit to Morgan Grenfell Private Equity for 1.8 billion Swiss francs ($1.2 billion) to concentrate on more profitable specialty chemicals. Ciba has been considering the sale since last year after high raw material costs pulled down first-half earnings in the unit, which makes resins used in products from paints to sports equipment. Morgan Grenfell, a private equity unit of Deutsche Bank, has more money than Ciba to spend to build up the polymers business and then sell or spin it off, analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, TODD G.
description: MERRILL-Todd G. Died Tuesday, December 7, 1999 in Bronx, NY. In loving memory of our beloved son and best friend. The years we shared together as a family are treasured forever. Todd will always be a part of us and our love for Todd is without end. Todd is always in our hearts and thoughts. Todd rests in peace with his grandparents at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Mom, Dad, Tim, Jose All your family and friends

title: Now Playing, the Special-Interest Fighter
description: This is a 30-second commercial created for Senator John McCain of Arizona, a Republican candidate for president, concerning the eradication of Congressional pork barrel projects. It began running last week on television stations in New Hampshire, which holds its presidential primary on Feb. 1.

title: THE BOSS; A Son With a Conscience
description: As a child, I saw how hard it was on my father, who came to this country in the 50's when Italians were a scorned minority group, to be an unwanted immigrant. My American grandfather, on the other hand, was a Wall Street insider who taught me how to read an annual report when I was about 16 years old. He complained bitterly about the inflated salaries and fees that executives and directors made in the 70's. I think he'd be sick at heart today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNER, ANNA
description: ZELNER-Anna. Of Brooklyn, NY, in her 88th year. Passed away on December 14, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Hyman, her husband of 66 years. She was a sweet and caring mother, mother-in-law and grandmother. Her sons, Martin and Larry; their wives, Barbara & Marjorie; and her grandchildren, Bennet, Emily & Jonathan, adored her and will miss her profoundly. Services will be held Thursday, 11:30AM at Garlick-Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Contributions may be made to the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Walkout at the Modern Over Wages for Curatorial Staff
description: Yesterday, when most New Yorkers were worried about a transit strike paralyzing the city, a group of union employees tried to draw attention to their own relatively obscure contract dispute by staging a two-hour walkout at the Museum of Modern Art.

description: In the kitchen of this kibbutz the other day, an old favorite was playing on the radio, a pop tune titled ''Going to the Unknown.''

title: Books That Go Beyond 'Red With Meat'
description: I WISH Dr. Seuss were still around. I could make him still another fortune and come off with a tidy little sum for myself. How? Simple. Persuade him to write a how-to book about wine. You know: big print, silly pictures, a 300-word vocabulary, mostly one-syllable words like ''wine'' and ''vine,'' and a title like, oh, how about ''The Ape That Ate the Grape''?

title: The Way to Relight A Fire in Burnouts
description: THE signs of burnout in a teacher who has reached a certain age are timeless: the sigh of resignation upon opening a daily instruction plan yellowed from repetition; the realization that while the students never seem to get older, you certainly do; the gnawing sense that a can't-miss lesson has long ago lost its punch.

title: S.E.C. in Formal Inquiry on Abercrombie

description: It once seemed that the word ''failure'' was not a part of Bill Bradley's lexicon. He had been a Rhodes scholar, an Olympic gold medalist, a two-time N.B.A. champion and, on his first foray into politics in 1978, the winner of a Senate seat from New Jersey. In 1984, during the Reagan landslide, he won re-election in a walk.

title: Romancing the Nut: First, Get It Open
description: MOST kitchen equipment is purchased with the task in mind: you want a tool that works easily and efficiently. So it is rare to come across a tool like the nutcracker, which is used both for the task and for the pleasure of breaking open a nut and retrieving the meat.

title: Carter, Proclaiming 'It's Yours,' Celebrates New Era for Panama
description: With a choir singing ''Ode to Joy'' as the prelude, nearly a century of American power and presence along the shores of the Panama Canal symbolically ended today when former President Jimmy Carter exchanged diplomatic notes with President Mireya Moscoso and said simply, ''It's yours.''

title: Cordiant Is Buying Stake in Hyundai Unit
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London is acquiring a majority of the advertising unit of the Hyundai Group as Cordiant expands operations in Korea.

title: Once Again, Inflation Is a No-Show
description: Despite booming retail sales and strong consumer demand, the Consumer Price Index barely rose in November, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Even gasoline prices did not make their usual contribution to inflation.

title: MARKETING RESEARCH COMPANY TO CUT STAFF 10 PERCENT
description: Information Resources Inc., the marketing research company, said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 325 jobs, 10 percent of its work force, as part of a series of moves to improve profits. The cuts, expected by the end of next year, will affect virtually all of the company's operations, it said. Information Resources, which had $405.7 million in revenue in the first nine months of this year, expects to save $15 million a year, starting at the end of next year. The Chicago company sells systems that collect information from bar code scanners in stores and sells it to businesses. Its stock slipped 62.5 cents, to $9.50.

Mr. Brook was a frequent guest performer with the New York Philomusica and performed with the Philharmonic Woodwind Quintet. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Alice, and to the entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, LEONARD, DR.
description: NELSON-Leonard, Dr., founding Chairman and Emeritus Professor of Physiology at the Medical College of Ohio at Toledo, died Wednesday, December 8, in the Heartland of Perrysburg Nursing Center near Toledo. He was 79. He died almost eight weeks after suffering an incapacitating stroke. Born in Philadelphia, Dr. Nelson received his Bachelor's Degree in Zoology at the University of Pennsylvania and his Master's and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. After eight years in the Department of Physiology at the University of Nebraska, he pursued research in reproductive physiology at the University of Chicago from 1953 to 1956. The following seven years at Emory University were interrupted by a year at Cambridge University in England, where he did research as a visiting scientist. Although Dr. Nelson actively engaged in research and medical teaching at Medical College of Ohio from 1967 until his retirement in 1991, he was given many opportunities to present papers at international conferences. He worked as a visiting scientist as a guest of Professor Prudent Padieu at the University of Dijon in France and of Professor Marco Crippa at the University of Geneva in Switzerland in 1975-76. As the guest of Professor Alberto Monroy in 198384, he spent a year in Naples, Italy, at the internationally renowned Stazione Zoologica. Dr. Nelson leaves his wife, Anne (Saturen); a daughter, Pamela Nelson, of Raleigh, NC, and a grandson, Phi lip Gordon, at Brown University. There will be no funeral. A remembrance is planned by the family in Woods Hole in early July. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Marine Resources Department at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts.

description: La HAYE-Peter. All of us at ORBIS International, the non-profit organization dedicated to saving sight worldwide through hands on training, public health educaton and improved access to eyecare in the developing world, are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of Peter La Haye of Medina, Washington, a member of the ORBIS International Board of Directors. A prolific inventor and successful entrepreneur in the field of optics, Peter was a true visionary who dedicated both his professional career and his philanthrophy to saving and improving sight for millions of people around the world. He was especially committed to helping those living in the developing world who suffer from treatable causes of blindess. Peter La Hay was an inspiration to every member of the ORBIS family. His enthusiasm for ORBIS also moved others to join him in generously supporting our work. We express our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Sandy, his children, his grandchildren and to the employess of La Hay Laboratories and NEOPTX. A. L. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUNITZ, DR. PAUL EHRLICH
description: KAUNITZ-Dr. Paul Ehrlich. Of Westport, Connecticut died in Jacksonville, Florida on December 12, of complications following upon a stroke. For more than forty years, Dr. Kaunitz was a professor of clinical psychiatry at the Yale University College of Medicine where he was an esteemed mentor to generations of residents. At Yale, he also was a founder of Department of Psychiatry Consulting Service. Born in New York City on October 6, 1914, Dr. Kaunitz was a graduate of Columbia University, the New York University Medical School and the Columbia Psychiatric Institute. He was a fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and an examiner for the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology. A practicing psychiatrist for fifty years in New York City and Westport, Connecticut Dr. Kaunitz also was a former president of the Connecticut Psychiatric Society. During World War II, Dr. Kaunitz served as a Lieutenant Colonel in the United States Army and was awarded the Bronze Star by General Omar Bradley for ''meritorious service'' in planning and executing the medical evacuation system for the D-Day invasion. Dr. Kaunitz was the beloved husband, for 52 years, of Dr. Rita Davidson Kaunitz; brother of Elizabeth Kaunitz Wallman, and her husband Dr. Lester Wallman of Burlington, Vermont; father of Victoria Kaunitz Klein of Pelham, New York, and her husband, Joseph; Dr. Jonathan Davidson Kaunitz of Santa Monica, California and his wife Christine Lee; Dr. Andrew Moss Kaunitz of Jacksonville, Florida, and his wife Karen Koppel, Esq., beloved grandfather of Sophia and Theodore Kaunitz-Klein, Justin and Genevieve Kaunitz, Kate and David Kaunitz. In 1998, Dr. and Mrs. Kaunitz retired and moved to Jacksonville, Florida. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Alumni Office, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons; Attention: Anke Nolting, 630 W. 168th St, NY, NY 10032-3795; or to River Garden's Senior Care Center, Development Office, 11401 Old St. Augustine Road, Jacksonville, Florida 32258. A memorial service will be held 10AM Thursday, December 16, 1999 at River Garden Hebrew Home, Jacksonville, Florida with Rabbi Michael Matuson officiating. A memorial service will be held in New York in January. Forinformation Hardage - Giddens Mandarin Funeral Home, 11801 San Jose Boulevard, Jacksonville, Florida 32223.

description: Nearly two decades after they were swept ashore in the Mariel boatlift, a group of Cuban inmates is staging a violent bid to be released or deported, holding three hostages at knifepoint in a parish jail here.

title: Ward Enters Plea; Eligible for U.S. Club
description: McLain Ward of Brewster, N.Y., the 1998 American Grand Prix Association rider of the year and the winner of five major events this season, entered a plea agreement yesterday that was accepted by the American Horse Shows Association and will allow him to try for a spot on the United States equestrian team at the Sydney Olympic Games next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALTER, MARJIANN
description: BALTER-Marjiann The Packer Collegiate Institute records with sorrow the passing of Marjiann Kurtz Balter, a loyal alumna and outstanding member of the Class of 1939, on December 9, 1999. Our sympathy goes to her husband Henry, son Jason and their families.

title: Vertical Typing Easy on Wrists
description: FOR the last decade, the computer industry has been haunted by the fact that typing on a keyboard for long periods can often lead to painful conditions called repetitive stress injuries, including carpal tunnel syndrome, one of the most painful and potentially damaging.

title: DUANE READE AND BERGEN BRUNSWIG AGREE TO SUPPLY PACT
description: The drugstore chain Duane Reade Inc. agreed yesterday to buy about $1 billion of products from the Bergen Brunswig Drug Company, a pharmaceutical distributor, under a five-year agreement. Under the agreement, Duane Reade, a major drugstore operator in the New York area, will buy about $200 million worth of products a year from Bergen Brunswig, a unit of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation. Duane Reade, which has 149 stores, said the deal would help cut costs. Bergen Brunswig, based in Orange County, Calif., reported revenue of $22.25 billion in the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDY, FRANCES
description: GRANDY-Frances. On December 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Mother of the late Maria Schorr. Grandmother of Allegra Fitch and Lydia Silverman. Greatgrandmother to Julia and Evan, Zachary and Maria. Services Thursday 9:45 a.m. at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIGH, DOUGLAS B.
description: LEIGH-Douglas B. December 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Elsie Leigh, father of Lucinda Leigh, Heidi Duke and step-father of Amanda Borghese, Pidgie Chapman, Prudence Blair and Winthrop Lewis, grandfather of eight. Brother of Ted F. Leigh. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Damascus Encourages Optimism With Limits
description: It was 32 years ago that Israeli forces drove Syrians by the many thousands from the Golan Heights. Today, many of those same Syrians were fixing eyes and ears at Washington, in the hope they were witnessing a watershed.

title: Development Work Finished On Microsoft Windows 2000
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it had completed the development of its Windows 2000 operating system software. The often-delayed program was sent to manufacturing plants and should reach the public on Feb. 17.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Our Towns column on Dec. 5 described neighbors' resistance in Greenwich, Conn., to a homeowner's plan to add a new wing, an ice rink and a golf course to a $14.8 million house on a 14-acre lot. The column commented that Greenwich ''is not a community of Airstream trailers where people sit outside on cinder blocks whiling away the hours by taking aim with their BB guns at upturned Buicks.''

title: At Children's Expense
description: To the Editor:

title: Tall and Thin, Appetite to Match
description: The ConServ 375 refrigerator looks like a Sub-Zero's tall, lean, Scandinavian kid sister. Its trendy details are crammed into a compact package that suits what are euphemistically called kitchens in New York. Less than 24 inches wide and deep, the Danish-built 375 stands flush with standard cabinets and even has its freezer on the bottom. It is 78 inches tall -- about 10 inches taller than average.

title: An Eclectic Site for Arts News
description: A NEW online arts digest is fashioning a daily journal out of the cultural world's daily jumble.

title: In This Holiday Tale, the Postman Chases the Dog
description: Somebody spiked the eggnog with attitude, and the results are yummy. See for yourself tomorrow when Fox unveils ''Olive, the Other Reindeer.'' This animated Christmas special will delight the preadolescent wise guy who lurks in your head (whatever your age) without tweaking the wide-eyed child in your heart (ditto).

title: Good Grief!
description: To the Editor:

title: PRE-EMPTIVE BID FOR UNITED BISCUIT
description: An investment group consisting of the Nabisco Holdings Corporation and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Ltd. bought 54 million shares of United Biscuits P.L.C. in hopes of thwarting a French-led group from starting a bidding war for the company, Britain's largest cookie maker. The United States group paid 254 pence a share, raising their stake in United Biscuits to 30 percent from 18 percent. Earlier this week the Nabisco group bid $1.9 billion for the company, but the French group, which includes Paribas, said it would consider a counteroffer. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAVESE, EDITH
description: PAVESE-Edith. Devoted mother of Marc. Dear sister of Dorothy and sister-in-law of Fred. Loving aunt of Christopher and Jennifer. Cherished friend of many. Services Friday, 9:45AM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home ''Riverside Building'', 180 W. 76 St., NYC.

title: Senate Atomic-Spying Panel Cancels Hearings at Freeh's Urging
description: A Senate Judiciary subcommittee investigating the government's handling of evidence of Chinese nuclear spying has canceled two closed hearings scheduled for this week because the F.B.I. director, Louis J. Freeh, feared that testimony there might harm the prosecution of Wen Ho Lee.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed against the yen and the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 103.70 yen, compared with 103.53 on Tuesday. The euro traded at $1.0070, compared with $1.0043.

title: Senate Legislation Proposes To Close Puerto Rico Base
description: The Senate will hold hearings next month on a bill to close the $3 billion naval station in Puerto Rico, a move that would clearly hurt the Puerto Rican economy, if the commonwealth refuses to allow live-fire exercises to resume on the island of Vieques.

title: Drug Agent Is Charged in Murder-for-Hire Plot
description: An American anti-drug officer based in Mexico was detained by F.B.I. agents in Texas, where he was charged with trying to hire a contract killer, the authorities said yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street Snarls at S.E.C. Proposal on Disclosure
description: It sounds like something that no one would support: the selective disclosure of important information by companies. Such a practice enables those favored with early knowledge to make money at the expense of traders not so favored.

title: Army Corps Reduces Impact Of Road Link on Wetlands
description: As the Army Corps of Engineers considers a permit to build the long-debated Route 92 highway link in central New Jersey, it has found that the road proposal, first conceived 61 years ago, would not affect as large a wetland area as planners had predicted.

title: A Local Front Of a Global War
description: As Russian armies surround, bombard and flatten Grozny, only one party has a chance of winning this conflict, and only because it cannot lose: the Chechen fighters. Either they will halt the Russian offensive and create a stalemate, or they will retreat into the mountains and come back to fight another day.

title: When Politicians Cite the Personal
description: To the Editor:

title: A Virtual Mood Ring Tracks Nation's Emotions
description: Happiness is two kinds of ice cream, catching a firefly and, possibly, living in the Upper Penisula of Michigan. Dailyrating.com, a site that started up in June, tracks the nation's emotional state based on daily messages from more than 4,000 e-mail correspondents. Dailyrating.com then maps relative degrees of happiness three ways: state by state on a USA Today-style weather map, on a nationwide graph and on a chart that compares the moods of men and women. Recent results indicate that people in Minnesota are not happy, nationally the mood appears to mirror the Dow Jones industrial average and men have rallied to have better days than women.

title: Where the Risk Is Riskier Yet; A New Breed of Venture Capitalist Scouts Latin America
description: Upon arriving in the big Amazon port of Belem several months ago, Patricia Moles, the manager of a venture-capital fund, was faced with an unusual investment-related decision: whether to continue by boat to the hearts-of-palm plantation in which her fund was hoping to acquire a minority stake, a trip that would take 12 hours, or to rent a propeller plane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CADMUS, PAUL
description: CADMUS-Paul. All of us at SAGE are deeply saddened by the passing of Paul Cadmus. He enriched our community with his wit, his exceptional powers of observation and his artistic skill. In November 1999, SAGE honored him with a Lifetime Achievement Award for his honesty and his insight, and for being true to his vision, even when that vision proved to be ahead of its time. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his partner and muse of 35 years, Jon Andersson, and join him in mourning the loss of a great artist, a lover of beauty and a true pioneer. The Board of Directors and Staff of SAGE (Senior Action in a Gay Environment)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, MILTON
description: RUDIN-Milton (Mickey). Mentor, counselor and friend. You will be greatly missed by all whom you touched. We loved you much. Marty and Dottie

title: Linking Wall Street To the Ski Slopes
description: First, laptop computers were dragged along on vacations. Then came the cell phones, small enough to go anywhere and everywhere.

title: Parcells Puts Five Young Jets On Hot Seat for Rest of '99
description: Just a few days after Bill Parcells held a meeting with five of his underachieving young Jets, and warned them that their careers were on the line, the season ended today for an older, underachieving tight end, Eric Green.

title: GOLAN WATER DEAL
description: An Israeli-owned marketer of bottled water from the Golan Heights, Eden Springs, tentatively agreed to sell up to 25 percent of the company to Aqua International Partners, a San Francisco-based venture capital firm, in a deal valued at about $47 million. The timing of the announcement, coming as Israel began negotiations on the possible return of the Golan Heights to Syria, was ''a mere coincidence,'' said Eden Springs, the biggest Israeli enterprise in the area. Though an Israeli withdrawal presumably would include the evacuation of all Israeli citizens and properties, Eden Springs' general manager, Yariv Shapira, said the company could survive such a transition. William A. Orme Jr.

title: Vanishing Oases
description: To the Editor:

title: A Diverse Africa at the Smithsonian
description: One exhibit shows step by step how Nakunte Diarra, an artisan from Mali, uses mud and other organic ingredients to dye cloth. Another, a detailed floor plan, visually condenses the sprawling Makola market in the Ghanaian city of Accra into a two-dimensional rendition of its teeming activity. And a life-size television monitor shows two Somalis, who now live here in Washington, sharing memories of growing up in migrant herding communities.

title: REXALL SUNDOWN TO BUY MET-RX FOR $108 MILLION
description: Rexall Sundown Inc., a maker of vitamins and nutritional supplements, agreed yesterday to buy MET-Rx Nutrition Inc., the closely held maker of sports-nutrition bars and drinks, for $108 million. Rexall Sundown, based in Boca Raton, Fla., makes Sundown products, which are the top-selling herb and vitamin supplements in the nation. It said it had bought MET-Rx to expand its sports-nutrition offerings. MET-Rx's sports bars and powdered-drink mixes are sold in health food stores as well as retail stores. MET-Rx, based in Irvine, Calif., is expected to have sales of about $105 million this year.

title: Anticipated Ferry Boom Founders
description: Erik Keller, the engineer on the 9 a.m. ferry from Sunset Park, Brooklyn, to Wall Street, surveyed the largely vacant passenger area yesterday and saw one thing: lost opportunity. Instead of carrying dozens of strike-stranded commuters, Mr. Keller's 149-seat boat held a familiar group of two dozen ferry veterans.

title: CHARTER TO BUY TV BOXES FROM GENERAL INSTRUMENT
description: Charter Communications Inc., the cable-television operator controlled by the billionaire Paul Allen, said yesterday that it would buy one million digital set-top TV boxes from the General Instrument Corporation for about $300 million. General Instrument shares jumped $5.625 each, to $73.5625, and the shares of Motorola Inc., which is acquiring General Instrument for about $10.7 billion, rose $10.8125, to $130.1875. Charter, based in St. Louis, will buy the set-top boxes, which let standard televisions connect to the Internet, next year and in 2001, Charter's senior vice president, John Pietri, said. The boxes will let customers receive digital cable, which can carry more channels than analog and features music.

title: Top Court in Hong Kong Upholds Ban on Defacing Chinese Flag
description: Steering clear of another legal confrontation with the Chinese government, the top court in Hong Kong ruled today that defacing the Chinese flag is a crime. The decision was a victory for the local government and reversed a ruling by a lower court that said defacing the flag was a form of expression guaranteed by the constitution of this former British colony.

title: Belgium Pedophilia Scandal /Did Authorities Cover Up Its Scope?: Book Revives Fear of Grand Conspiracy
description: BRUSSELS  In Belgium, the X-Files refer not to the U.S. television series but to a series of horrific witness accounts of an alleged pedophile network.

title: Cell Phones Designed to Call Only a Single Number: 911
description: While it may resemble a sleek cell phone, the Magnavox Mobile911 can't call home or even the office. As its name suggests, it is designed to dial only one number: 911.

title: McCain and Bradley Collect Big Money, but It Isn't Soft
description: Even as Senator John McCain and former Senator Bill Bradley plan to meet on Thursday to demand an end to unregulated corporate contributions known as soft money, executives of companies that are among the biggest soft-money donors continue to pour hundreds of thousands of dollars into their campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTONE, ESTELLE
description: SILVERSTONE-Estelle. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of its esteemed Founding Member and Past President. We extend deepest sympathy to her husband, Sidney, her children, Harris, Alan, David, and to the entire family. Alfredo F. Borodowski, Rabbi George Sommerfeld, President Charles Rosenzweig, Chairman

title: Web Is No Place for Last-Minute Gift Buyers
description: IN early December, I received e-mail offering me $10 off my next purchase at Buy.com. This immediately reminded me that during this gift-giving season, I had not bought nearly enough presents for myself.

title: Fund-Raiser For Pataki Faces Charges
description: A businessman and political fund-raiser was charged yesterday with promising favorable state parole rulings to the families of three convicted violent felons in exchange for more than $36,000 in donations to the election campaign of Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Strict New Rules for Proposed Gas Line
description: In a ruling that elated opponents of a natural gas pipeline project, a federal commission imposed some stiff environmental and sales conditions today on a proposed 622-mile project that would bring Canadian natural gas to New Jersey and New York City.

title: Fund to Help Save Open Space in New Jersey
description: Seeking to stem the loss of undeveloped land to suburban growth in the Northeast, the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation will give $14 million to projects protecting fields, marshes and forests in New Jersey and Rhode Island, the most densely populated states in the country, foundation officials said yesterday.

title: Medical Report on Gore Finds Him in 'Outstanding' Condition
description: Vice President Al Gore is in top physical condition with excellent heart function, although his blood lipids are mildly elevated, according to a three-page medical summary that was prepared by the White House physician and released yesterday by Mr. Gore's campaign for president.

title: GREATER BAY TO ACQUIRE COAST BANCORP FOR $125 MILLION
description: Greater Bay Bancorp said late on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire Coast Bancorp for about $125 million in stock. Greater Bay, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., is a bank holding company with $1.9 billion in assets. It said the acquisition would probably add about 1.5 percent to its earnings per share in 2000. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial project earnings of about $2.64 a share next year. Coast Bancorp, based in Santa Cruz, Calif., is the holding company for Coast Commercial Bank. It has assets of about $326.4 million.

title: BB&T TO BUY FIRST BANKING FOR $123.6 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The BB&T Corporation, a bank with branches throughout the Southeastern United States, agreed yesterday to buy the First Banking Company of Southeast Georgia for $123.6 million in stock. BB&T will pay 0.74 share for each First Banking share, or $22.11, based on BB&T's closing price yesterday. First Banking, based in Statesboro, Ga., has $419 million in assets and 12 branches in southeastern Georgia. Its shares fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $21.625. BB&T has $41.6 billion in assets. Its shares rose 37.5 cents, to $29.875.

title: Standing Up To Censors, Mexican Film Finds Its Voice
description: An advertisement he read in the morning newspaper made Luis Estrada, a Mexican film director, feel that his darkest anxiety dream had become real.

description: The tentative contract that the transit workers union reached early yesterday would effectively increase pay by more than 18 percent over three years, giving subway and bus workers the largest annual raises received by any of New York City's public-employee unions in more than a decade.

title: An abortion rights coalition hopes its campaign will get young women to discuss their choices.
description: THE Pro-Choice Public Education Project, a consortium of abortion rights groups nationwide, will resume television advertising for the first time in several years to expand its efforts to reach young people.

title: Back to Where He Once Belonged
description: No concert by any of the former Beatles has created quite the anticipation that attended Sir Paul McCartney's return tonight to the Cavern Club here. He gave a solid, energetic performance at a time when he is gradually returning to the stage after the the death of his wife, Linda, in 1998.

title: VOLKSWAGEN SUBSIDIES REJECTED
description: The German automaker Volkswagen A.G. is not eligible for planned state subsidies of 241 million marks, about $124 million, the European Court of Justice ruled. In 1990, Volkswagen and the state of Saxony had agreed on subsidies totaling 780 million marks for investments in the former East Germany. A part of that sum was later rejected by the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union. Volkswagen is considering an appeal. Christian Baumgaertel (NYT)

title: Red-Faced Kings Head Home on the Red-Eye
description: The Los Angeles Kings were scheduled to fly by charter from New York late last night and to land in California in the early morning. Too bad they couldn't stay an extra day or two in the metropolitan area. After losing by 7-1 to the Devils on Tuesday and by 8-3 to the Rangers last night, the Kings could have scheduled a scrimmage with the Islanders, who have not defeated anyone in a long time. Or the Kings could have dropped by the rink at Rockefeller Center to build the confidence of any six persons they would encounter.

title: Gore Proposal Would Set Aside $115 Billion for Education Fund
description: Proposing a broader federal role in education than any other presidential candidate, Vice President Al Gore will call for an infusion of $115 billion over the next 10 years to get more good teachers for schools in poor areas and to provide preschool education for all 3- and 4-year-olds.

title: Wall Street's Embrace of Diversity Lauded Despite Its Poor Record

Netoy.com, a Web-based toy retailer, isn't promising to stick toys together before shipment. However, this month it will introduce a series of animated drawings and assembly directions on its site, www.netoy.com, that may make the job a little easier.

title: Corrections

In addition to studying at Harvard, Oxford and Georgetown Law School, Mr. Berrios graduated from Yale Law School.

title: PRINCIPALS GIVE UP TENURE FOR A RAISE
description: The union representing New York City school principals said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with city officials and the Board of Education for a new contract that would end principals' virtually ironclad job tenure, require them to work a longer school day and eliminate their two-month summer vacation.

title: But Yossarian Lives
description: When Joseph Heller was growing up in Brooklyn in the 1930's, he read the books of an American childhood then: the ''Tom Swift'' and ''Rover Boys'' series. When he also read a child's edition of ''The Iliad,'' he thought he might want to be a writer. He became one, and because he had a diamond eye for the phony, the funny and the lunatic in life, and because he milled his own experience into characters and dialogue no novelist had employed before, the young of the last four decades have grown up with a different kind of classic: Mr. Heller's great satire of war and American culture, ''Catch-22.''

So letters are in, and it should be acknowledged that there are few things more fun than reading someone else's mail.

''The Shattered Mind'' offers hope in new generations of psychotropic drugs that cannot cure the ailment but can subdue its outbreaks while scientists strive for a better understanding of the workings or misworkings of the brain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBRIGHT, EDWARD EGON
description: HALBRIGHT-Edward Egon. Of Teaneck New Jersey. Died peacefully after forty six years of marriage with Willie (nee Goldschmidt) at the young age of seventy-one, after an illness. His childhood in Berlin was interrupted by World War II, during which he and his brother Irwin became refugees in Belgium, France and Switzerland and lost their beloved parents, Rudolf and Greta. Arriving in the USA in 1949, he became a successful and respected travel agent, most recently with Liberty/ GoGo, as well as a student of history and world affairs and an adjunct professor at NYU. He leaves behind his wife, his brother, and his children, Ronald, of Thalwil Switzerland, and Rita of London England, as well as their four children. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, December 19 at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Funeral Home in Hackensack NJ at 2 p.m. Memorial contributions may be sent to ''Friends and Alumni of OSE-USA'', PO Box 4029, Great Neck NY 11023, to support a French children's relief organization which offered him protection during the war.

He was 92 and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

title: French Stalling on Iraq
description: Negotiations have dragged on for months on a United Nations Security Council resolution to send an international inspection team back to Iraq, while Saddam Hussein takes advantage of each delay. This week, as the council prepared to vote, France balked at the plan, asking for more time to see if new language could be crafted that would move Russia and China from abstention to support. The French tactic is mischievous and dangerous. The Security Council can and should act immediately and get inspectors back into Iraq.

Sinks made in Norway by Intra come 12 inches deep, 13 inches deep, even 16 inches deep. Made from highly polished heavy-gauge stainless steel, they are especially strong, and they have an undercoat that helps dampen the clatter of pots and pans.

title: CMGI TO ACQUIRE YESMAIL FOR $523 MILLION
description: CMGI Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Yesmail.com Inc., which makes e-mail marketing software, for $523 million. Under the agreement, CMGI will swap 0.1252 shares for each of Yesmail.com's 20.3 million shares. That values Yesmail.com at $25.76 a share. Shares of Yesmail.com surged $3, to $24, in Nasdaq trading, where CMGI shares dropped $6 each, to $199.75. Yesmail.com, based in Vernon Hills, Ill., sends promotional material to subscribers who agree to receive it by e-mail. The company, with revenue of about $8.9 million in the last year, sold its stock to the public for the first time in September. CMGI, which is based in Andover, Md., manages and invests in Internet companies. With the deal, Yesmail.com will become a majority-owned operating company of CMGI.

title: Shaping Cities, Pixels to Bricks
description: MIKE ROSEN, an architect, first glimpsed the future of his profession in an unlikely spot -- the video game arcade at a nightclub. At the time, Mr. Rosen, who is the head of his own firm in Philadelphia, was having trouble getting local approval for a planned community he had designed in Chester County, Pa.

title: Nuns and an Architect in a Meeting of Two Credos
description: FOR a moment, Sister Ancilla Armijo seemed like any proud new homeowner. Looking heavenward, she swept her hand across the towering, domed ceiling to the skylight windows of the new chapel here. And she extolled the virtues of simplicity, scoffing at the thought of stained glass where there are now views of snowy mountaintops.

title: A Water-Powered Model That Even Eats Glass
description: It slices, it dices, it purees, it chops. It's not a Veg-O-Matic; it's a garbage disposal, and more important, one that is friendly to the environment. The HydroMaid uses no electricity and is the only fully water-powered disposal on the market. Its maker says the HydroMaid's five oscillating stainless steel blades chop food so fine it will not clog drains, a plus for finicky co-op boards concerned about old pipes.

title: One Drawer or Two?
description: Fisher & Paykel's DishDrawer dishwasher (left) offers a solution for the single person in a small apartment, for big families with loads of dishes and for those who keep kosher kitchens. How? It's as simple as one drawer or two. A single drawer (23 inches wide and 16 inches high) holds seven place settings. Two drawers take up the same space as a traditional dishwasher but hold 40 percent more. One drawer can wash the crystal, while the other tackles dirty pots. In stainless steel, white, black or custom colors; one stainless drawer, $999; two drawers, $1,599. At P. C. Richard, 120 East 14th Street; (212) 979-2600.

title: The Skewed Attendance Report
description: The record-keeping problems at New York City's Board of Education were vividly illustrated when slipshod attendance surveys made it difficult to determine if the children who were required to attend summer school this year actually did so. Faced with embarrassments like that, even the board has accepted that its record-keeping needs improvement. But Gov. George Pataki served the reform effort poorly when he made a premature, unsubstantiated accusation this week that the city's schools were engaged in widespread, systemic fraud to inflate the attendance figures that determine state aid. Whatever the merits of the charge, it should not have been aired until the governor could cite concrete evidence to back it up.

That the grime he's chasing is human doesn't much daunt Edward F. Stancik, a fragile sparrow of a fellow with a hawk's hubris, a secret devotion to Jimi Hendrix and Neil Young and a squeaky-clean approach to falsehoods like the one that incubated the George Washington cherry tree anecdote.

title: JOBLESS RATE AT 19-YEAR LOW
description: The unemployment rate in Britain fell to 4.1 percent in November, a 19-year low, the government said. The number of people claiming unemployment benefits dropped by 10,600, to 1.2 million. In addition, wages grew by 4.9 percent in the quarter that ended on Oct. 31, an increase from 4.7 percent the previous three months. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, PAUL C.
description: COLE-Paul C., 86, of Merriam, KS, died December 13, 1999. Funeral services will be at 10 AM Dec. 20, 1999 at St. Michael and All Angels Episcopal Church, Mission, KS. Paul was born in 1913 in Brooklyn, NY. Paul worked for R.H. Macy & Co., 1933-1993. He was vice president and director in Missouri and Kansas, 1950-1965; senior vice president in New York, 1965-1978; and consultant, 1978-1993. He was a former member of the Church of the Transfiguration. He served as Grand Marshall for the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade in 1948 and 1949. He was preceded in death by his wife, Florence. Survivors include his son, Garrett Cole, two granddaughters and one great-grandson.

YouthStream, based in New York, said the deal would help make its Web site more popular with young people, its target audience. Sixdegrees operates sixdegrees.com, a Web site that helps users find people they know or have something in common with. Begun in January 1997, the Web site now has three million registered members. The News Corporation, the parent of the Fox television network, is an investor in the privately held sixdegrees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, PEARL
description: RESNICK-Pearl. Ohr Torah Stone Colleges and Graduate Programs record with deep sorrow the passing of Pearl Resnick, elegant, regal and wise, mother, grandmother and philanthropist par excellence. Pearl's inner goodness emanated and formed her outer charm and her manifold good works. Her commitment to her people and her faith encompassed New York, Palm Springs, Ramat Gan and Jerusalem. The building of Midreshet Lindenbaum in Jerusalem, where our Programs of Social Work are dedicated in memory of her beloved daughter, Susan, of blessed memory, will, upon its completion, proudly bear her Hebrew name, Peninah, literally a jeweled pearl. May her luster continue to shed light, love and understanding from her heavenly abode upon those of us on earth who will truly miss her beautiful and heartfelt presence. May Burt, Marilyn, Ira and the rest of the magnificent family that she and Jack created together, and of which she was so very proud, be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shlomo Riskin, Chancellor Ohr Torah Stone Colleges and Graduate Programs

description: Ang Lee, a sly explorer of family dynamics and social convention in films like ''Eat Drink Man Woman,'' ''Sense and Sensibility'' and ''The Ice Storm,'' has a simple explanation for why he is here with some of Hong Kong's biggest action stars making, of all things, a Chinese-language kung fu movie set in the early-19th-century Qing dynasty.

title: Essay; Outsider's Day
description: At his Christmas party a year ago, I went up to John McCain and asked an off-the-wall question: What would it be like if he and Bill Bradley ran against each other for president?

title: Exxon Mobil Plans to Cut Payroll by 16,000 Jobs
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 16,000 jobs, or about 13 percent of its work force, in an effort to increase its cost savings to $3.8 billion a year by 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRK, STANLEY E.
description: SHIRK-Stanley E. The partners and employees of KPMG mourn the loss of their respected colleague who died in New York City on December 7, and offer their condolences to his family. A teacher and mentor, Stanley will always be remembered for his dedication and devotion to the firm and its clients. His legacy will continue. Born in Brooklyn, NY, in 1916, Stanley worked his way through St. John's University at night by doing accounting work for several firms and also by being a Western Union messenger during days. After graduating in 1939 with a bachelor's degree in business administration, Stanley was employed by Barrow Wade Guthrie and Co. (BWG), the oldest and most prestigious accounting firm in the U.S. at that time. During World War II, he handled recruiting duties for the U.S. Navy in San Antonio. After the war, he returned to BWG and became a partner in 1949 at the age of 33. In 1953, three years after BWG merged with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell, Stanley took over the helm of Peat Marwick's banking practice and innovated the specialized department, the precursor to today's Line of Business structure. Stanley created the first formalized mentorship program between partners and staff and introduced long-range planning and budgeting disciplines to the firm, now known as KPMG. In 1955, he played a vital role in getting approval of a major financial industry merger that would create Chase Manhattan Bank. After retiring from the firm in 1976, President Gerald Ford nominated Stanley to become Comptroller of the Currency, but Congressional hearings were never held about it. Stanley went on to be a consultant for the Association of Bank Holding Companies and The Bank Administration Institute. The Stanley E. Shirk Scholarship Fund was established in 1992 at St. John's University through funds raised by retired and active KPMG partners and matched by the KPMG Foundation. In 1994, St. John's University bestowed upon him an Honorary Doctorate of Commercial Science. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Stanley E. Shirk Scholarship Fund, St. John's University, 8000 Utopia Parkway, Jamaica, New York 11439. A memorial service will be held for Stanley on December 17, 11 A.M., at All Soul's Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue (80th Street), New York City.

title: The Nets Do No Wrong (No One Saw the Shove)
description: The Nets were so charmed tonight that at one point Jamie Feick, their undersized yet somewhat lumbering center, was swishing long jump shots. At other times, Kendall Gill, who has spent much of the season in search of his touch, was on target from the perimeter. And once, Stephon Marbury scrambled for a loose ball, penetrated desperately and sank a contested 12-footer that barely beat the 24-second shot clock while he lost a shoe.

title: Fossett and Crew Ready for Test
description: Steve Fossett, the skipper of the catamaran PlayStation, planned to set off this morning from Chelsea Piers on Manhattan's West Side on his trans-Atlantic crossing. Fossett and his nine-man crew expect a following wind as they attack the North Atlantic and Serge Medec's nine-year-old record.

title: When Politicians Cite the Personal
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Tributes to Thomas Nast, Kingmaker Cartoonist
description: NOT so long ago, political cartoonists were regarded as hired hacks. Illustrators did the job of today's paparazzi, targets of caricature were selected for their moneymaking potential, and editorial cartoonists would take on the coloration of their employers.

title: 2 Adult Day Care Centers in Brooklyn Accused of Overbilling Medicaid by $62 Million
description: The state attorney general yesterday accused the owner of two adult day care centers in Brooklyn of illegally billing the Medicaid program for invented or inflated services totaling $62 million.

title: SYRIA AND ISRAEL BEGIN PEACE TALKS AFTER 4-YEAR HALT
description: Israel and Syria today resumed peace negotiations that stalled nearly four years ago, with the modest goal of surviving two days of breaking the ice in a relationship long frozen by mutual mistrust. That goal appeared likely to be met.

title: School Creates Own Commandments, and a Fuss
description: Given its druthers, the school board in this southern Indiana town would post the Ten Commandments in classrooms.

title: Using Market Forces To Model Election Races
description: For years, professors at the University of Iowa have provided political junkies a financial outlet for their wild speculation. The Iowa Electronic Markets is an online system that enables people to bid on the presidential or congressional candidates they think are most likely to win. Anyone could jump in -- as long as he was willing to spend at least $5 and had a Telnet connection to the Internet.

title: F.A.A. Orders Toddler Seats On Airliners
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would require safety restraints for small children on all commercial aircraft, meaning that a toddler will no longer be able to ride in the lap of an adult but must be strapped in a small seat as though riding in a car.

title: Fire on the Mountain Puts Resort on Plan B
description: When the 31-year-old base lodge at the Mountain Creek ski area in Vernon, N.J., burned to the ground in less than two hours on Oct. 10, the resort not only lost 3,500 pairs of rental skis, but also 40,000-square feet of cafeteria, restaurant, bar and lounges, kitchens, offices, restrooms and other services -- basically its entire base of operations.

title: Technology as the Guiding Hand of History
description: SOME people see history as a set of names, dates and points on a map. Other people see it as the evolution of ideas that drive society: science, religion and politics. In Age of Empires 2, a computer strategy game published by Microsoft, the grand sweep of human events is expressed as a series of technological upgrades. Picking up where the original ended, with the fall of Rome, the game takes place over a thousand years, leading up to the Renaissance, as civilizations race to replace their hardware and software with more elaborate versions, at considerable cost.

title: National News Briefs; General Motors Pledges $2.5 Million to MADD
description: In the midst of the winter holidays, the prime season for drunken drivers, a group that seeks to prevent drunken driving has received a pledge of $2.5 million from General Motors.

title: IBERIA SELLS 40 PERCENT
description: The Spanish state-owned airline Iberia sold a 9 percent stake to British Airways, 1 percent to the AMR Corporation's American Airlines unit and another 30 percent to five Spanish concerns for a total of about $1.1 billion. In the contract signed in Madrid, British Airways included an option to drop out if Iberia did not fully privatize by the end of next year. Al Goodman

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after an industry report showed United States fuel inventories dropped more than expected last week. In New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 63 cents, to $26.36 a barrel.

title: Cancer in Township Is Correlated With High Tap Water Use
description: A report by New Jersey health officials has found that the households in Dover Township in which cancer has been diagnosed in children consumed more tap water than cancer-free households did, although the officials cautioned against drawing any quick conclusions from the survey.

title: E-Mail on the Screen Replaces Letters to Santa on the Fridge
description: IF my sons are organized about anything, it is Christmas, or at least their Christmas wish lists. So I wasn't surprised during a snack break in early December that they were writing their annual letters to Santa. Or more precisely to Mrs. Santa, which is how I think of myself at this time of year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, JANE
description: ROSENBAUM-Jane. Age 45, cherished daughter of Sally and Herb Rosenbaum, devoted sister of Linda and the late Adrienne, loving aunt to Tal and Daniel, died suddenly on December 12, 1999 after a long illness. Services Thursday December 16th at 12:45pm at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave, NYC. Peace be with you, Jane, on your journey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNER, ANNA
description: ZELNER-Anna. Of Brooklyn, NY, in her 88th year. Passed away on December 14, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Hyman, her husband of 66 years. She was a sweet and caring mother, mother-in-law and grandmother. Her sons, Martin and Larry; their wives, Barbara & Marjorie; and her grandchildren, Bennet, Emily & Jonathan, adored her and will miss her profoundly. Services will be held Thursday, 11:30AM at Garlick-Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Contributions may be made to the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Rangers Skate a Figure 8 Around the Kings
description: The crowd was still filing into Madison Square Garden as the first period was winding down. The game had a rare 7 o'clock start, and as the fans hurried to their seats, they probably did a double take upon seeing the scoreboard.

title: Extra! Sly Cat Upstages Stuart Little!
description: The plucky title character of ''Stuart Little'' may be an adorable three-inch-tall digital mouse, but the scene stealer in this delightful screen adaptation of E. B. White's classic children's book is Stuart's feline nemesis, Snowbell. A white Chinchilla Persian cat played by five nearly identical felines and voiced by Nathan Lane in a sly, streetwise New York accent tinged with hauteur, Snowbell is one of the most fully rounded nonhuman characters to appear in a family film in quite some time. Every imperious toss of Snowbell's head and twitch of his petulantly bowed mouth synchronizes so smoothly with Mr. Lane's dialogue that at times he seems remarkably close to being like a real-life talking cat.

title: Rowan Escapes a Shadow And Hopes to See the Light
description: Rowan Coach K. C. Keeler said this week that someone compared his football team's situation to the 1980 United States Olympic hockey team that upset the Russians but still needed to beat Finland to win the gold medal.

title: Long Contract Battle Justified, Principals' Leader Says
description: Three years ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani offered the union representing New York City principals a contract quite similar to the one that the union leadership finally accepted this week. Then, as now, Mr. Giuliani was offering the principals a pay raise of roughly 11 percent, plus significantly more money for working more days and longer hours, if the principals agreed to give up tenure.

title: Plus: Boxing - I.B.F.; Officials Ordered To Turn Over Papers
description: Responding to a motion by the International Boxing Federation, Judge Julio Fuentes of State Superior Court in Newark ordered three former officials of the federation yesterday to turn over financial records and control of federation accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, RENEE
description: RESNICK-Renee. Beloved wife of Murray, loving mother of Jay and Marla Resnick, Dr. Gene Resnick & Roberta & Jeffrey Ort. Devoted grandmother of Stephanie, David, Jason, Justin and Jonathan. Her impression will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services today, at 12 noon, at Sherman'sFlatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J).

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS JUMPS. Natural gas prices rose 6 percent on forecasts of colder weather in the biggest markets for heating fuel. In New York, natural gas for January delivery rose 15 cents, to $2.636 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: The McCain-Bradley Show
description: The air and even some of the questions in New Hampshire were frosty yesterday at the unusual joint appearance of Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey. But these two presidential candidates were making a significant contribution with their attempt to give the issue of campaign finance reform a more prominent place on the agenda for 2000. This marked the first time that two serious contenders from opposing parties have come together to challenge the Washington establishment on so fundamental a problem as the two parties' joint dependence on special-interest money.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: RINGO STARR: ''I Wanna Be Santa Claus'' (Mercury). It may seem strange that a percussionist would center his rendition of ''The Little Drummer Boy'' around a bagpipe choir. But Ringo Starr has always been a personality artist as much as a musician, and the pleasant moments on this holiday disc emphasize his loping charm. The first track uses Gary Glitter-style glam rock to goad Christmas into coming; the blustery rendition of ''Blue Christmas'' evokes the local pub. Mr. Starr errs with a few corny ballads, but the upbeat tracks here make a perfectly adequate case for him to get the job of Jolly St. Ringo. ANN POWERS

description: The art of Africa is still terra incognita to the West. A few sculptural types -- Benin bronzes, Fang reliquary figures -- have become museum staples. But they serve as stand-ins for an entire aesthetic universe, one all but unchartable in its novelty and invention.

title: NEW TWIST FOR BANK BALI
description: The former owner of Indonesia's Bank Bali, Rudy Ramli, could get a chance to buy his family's bank back later this month. Standard Chartered Bank P.L.C. of Britain said late Wednesday that it was abandoning a deal to buy 20 percent of Bank Bali after an employee revolt induced the government to remove the British bank as Bank Bali's manager. Wayne Arnold

title: New York Boycotts Port Authority's Meeting
description: The bitter relations between New York and New Jersey over Port Authority projects in both states soured further yesterday when the New York delegation boycotted the monthly board meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, MAX
description: MARKOWITZ-Max. The staff, faculty and Trustees for the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health were deeply saddened to learn of the loss of Max Markowitz, M.D. Dr. Markowitz was affiliated with the Center from its inception in the 1940s through his retirement in the 1970s. He served brilliantly as Medical Director of the entire facilty and as Senior Supervisor and Training Analyst in both the adult and group psychoanalytic training programs. His compassion, integrity and intellectual prowess will be missed. Dr. Jacob Barak Acting President & CEO

description: Senator John McCain and former Senator Bill Bradley joined forces across a partisan and ideological divide today to pledge support for revamping the nation's campaign finance system and to take some sharp shots at each other's front-running opponents for president.

title: How to Make a Scientific Breakthrough Seem Horrifying
description: CONSIDER the possibilities of a scientific breakthrough that could allow farmers to grow more food while using less pesticide, or to add vitamins to vegetable oils to prevent malnutrition. Maybe some plastic products now made from petroleum could instead be produced from plants.

description: Receiving a gushy cinematic Christmas card from Robin Williams has become almost an annual rite of commerce. But in trying to be all things to all people, ''Bicentennial Man'' easily takes the cake as the star's most grandiose holiday greeting yet.

description: The angry Cubans holding hostages in the local jail could not be farther from home than they are in this revered heart of French Acadiana, where countless Cajun surnames end in X and Spanish is a distant third language.

description: Mannesmann A.G. of Germany may be willing to consider a friendly takeover deal from Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. if the British mobile phone giant adds a cash sweetener to its hostile all-stock offer, executives close to Mannesmann said tonight.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: JOHN WILLIAMS: ''Greatest Hits: 1969-1999'' (Sony Classical). When future historians and sociologists look back on the late 20th century, no music will better capture the swollen ego and solipsistic ambition of the bipedal animals that stalked the earth and stuck gum under movie theater seats than the compositions of John Williams. The king of grandiosity, Mr. Williams composed the swelling orchestral themes from ''Superman,'' the ''Star Wars'' series, ''E. T.'' and multiple Olympic games, all of which are included on this two-CD set, with Mr. Williams conducting the London Symphony, the Boston Pops and other orchestras. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, MILTON (MICKEY)
description: RUDIN-Milton (Mickey). Mentor, counselor and friend. You will be greatly missed by all whom you touched. We loved you much. Marty and Dottie

title: Buchanan, In a Change, Calls for End To Sanctions
description: Conceding ''a dramatic departure from what I've argued and believed,'' Patrick J. Buchanan today called for an end to economic sanctions by the White House as a ''sword that slaughters children'' and entrenches dictators.

description: ESPN's ''SportsCentury'' tribute to Jesse Owens as the sixth greatest athlete of the century, airing tonight, shows the late track and field star crushing Hitler's claims of Aryan supremacy at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin. But Owens's four gold medals and his status as a champion of social justice were not the first memories of Marty Glickman, a fellow sprinter on the United States team.
