title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: THERE'S a deluge of albums every holiday season. It's not enough that procrastinating superstars release albums just in time to show up on fourth-quarter profit sheets; seasonal albums also suddenly appear. There are new assortments selected from recording-company vaults, current hit makers taking a break from songwriting and lesser-knowns looking for a way to be heard. If that doesn't offer enough choices, an Internet option has appeared: on www.ktel.com, listeners can compile their own sets of Christmas songs, to be turned into a custom CD. There's also a low-tech alternative: people can get together and sing the carols themselves.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: New Site For Trial Often Factor In Outcome
description: For police officers facing brutality charges, moving a trial to a new location can mean the difference between conviction and acquittal, legal experts say. There is no more powerful example than the case of the Los Angeles police officers who beat Rodney G. King, a black man, in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, JACK A.
description: KLEIN-Jack A. Age 64. A 5th-6th grade teacher at P.S. 175, Queens for 33 years. Died December 16, 1999 of cancer. Survivors are his sister Jill Chaliff, two nieces and one nephew of Atlanta, and life partner Keith Olds of Forest Hills. Services at 10 A.M., on Sunday, December 19, Schwartz Brothers Chapel, Forest Hills. Private burial. Contributions in lieu of flowers to P.S. 175 School Library, 64-35 102 Street, Rego Park, New York 11374, Attention: Pearl Schulson.

title: Deconstructing Another Kennedy Myth
description: IN LOVE WITH NIGHT

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: BLOWFLY: ''Blowfly Does XXX-Mas'' (Pandisc). Flying around the fringes of comedy and funk music for a quarter-century, Blowfly (the prolific and foulmouthed alter ego of the pious 60's songwriter Clarence Reid) comes on these days like a Las Vegas nightmare. Presented here are raunchy parodies of 14 Christmas carols, complete with Blowfly's usual overdubbed audience responses to his corny wordplay. It may be fun to slip one song from this compilation into your office party Christmas mix tape, but a whole album of ''XXX-Mas'' isn't recommended for anyone with an I.Q. higher than, say, Beavis and Butt-head's. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Kaffe Fassett and Steve Lovi -- 'Two About Color'
description: Luise Ross Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIGH, DOUGLAS B.
description: LEIGH-Douglas B. December 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Elsie Leigh, father of Lucinda Leigh, Heidi Duke and step-father of Amanda Borghese, Pidgie Chapman, Prudence Blair and Winthrop Lewis, grandfather of eight. Brother of Ted F. Leigh. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: THE RZA: ''The RZA Hits'' (Epic). When one thinks of the RZA, the deep-thinking producer and mastermind behind the high-chaos 10-man rap force the Wu-Tang Clan, the first thing that comes to mind is rhythm. This is a man who makes beats as effortlessly as blinking, who claims that he has perfected the craft and is ready to become a doctor instead. An ideal RZA compilation would highlight his greatest beats, but instead ''The RZA Hits'' is set up as a beginner's introduction to one of the greatest East Coast rap acts of the 90's. It features hits from the Wu-Tang Clan and its members' solo albums interspersed with a distracting narration by the RZA and, for a conclusion, an advertisement for the band's clothing line. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Smooth Grooves: A Sensual Christmas'' (Rhino). Maybe it wasn't advisable to start out with the Jackson Five's rah-rah, up-tempo ''Santa Claus Is Coming to Town,'' but the rest of this set of early-70's soul, taken from Motown, Stax and other labels, slides by like Santa down a greased chimney. This is from an era when the high craft of studio musicians could still make ephemeral pop records sound lavish, and tracks like Bill Withers's ''Gift of Giving'' and Donny Hathaway's ''This Christmas'' could get by on their own terms without a seasonal gimmick. BEN RATLIFF

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''A Motown Christmas'' (Motown). Motown's 1960's hit makers released Christmas albums in 1965 (the Supremes), 1967 (Stevie Wonder) and 1970 (the Temptations, the Jackson Five and Smokey Robinson and the Miracles). This collection, originally released in 1975, culled two dozen songs from them, full of youthful exuberance and Motown studio flair. The arrangers like to reverse what's expected, doing slow songs fast or spiking pop with touches of gospel, and the singers seem even more innocent now than they did at the time. The Supremes and Smokey Robinson albums have also been rereleased this year as CD's. JON PARELES

title: Entangled Lives on the Cusp of the Millennium
description: The great uh-oh moment in Paul Thomas Anderson's ''Magnolia'' occurs about two-thirds of the way through this artfully orchestrated symphony of L.A. stories. A song bursts out: it is heard first from one character, then from another, until all the film's assorted lost souls are brought together by a single anxiety-ridden refrain. ''It's not . . . going to stop,'' each one sings resignedly, signaling the approach of an impending group meltdown. But the effect is less that of a collective shiver than of directorial desperation.

title: 3-Way Merger Will Challenge Japanese Phone Giant
description: Japan's dominant telecommunications company confronted a new competitive challenge at home today with the announcement that three smaller rivals would soon be merging.

title: Disney Official Guilty in Pornography Case
description: A prominent Internet executive for the Walt Disney Company was convicted today of possessing child pornography on his computer, but a Federal jury deadlocked on the most serious charges against him: that he enticed a minor to have sex and traveled across state lines with the intent of doing so.

title: Failed Supercomputer Chips Return in Consumer Guises
description: A microprocessor that failed commercially when it was introduced for supercomputers in the 1980's is about to find new life in consumer electronics devices of the next decade, many of which will require more computing power than the most powerful machines from a decade ago.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: GARTH BROOKS: ''Garth Brooks and the Magic of Christmas'' (Capitol Nashville). Garth Brooks not only does not do things halfway, but he also lives to combat the very existence of that concept. On this compendium of holiday standards he is tirelessly chipper, his glowing smile palpable in his bright, schmoozy tone, while strings, horns and a choir that sounds like the one Beck sampled in ''Where It's At'' carry him along. This record is soaked like a rum ball in Christmas joy. It will give many people a toothache, but if sugar is your thing, this is it. ANN POWERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ROSE
description: ROSENBERG-Rose. On December 15, 1999. Wife of the late Carl Rosenberg of the Leader store in Mt. Vernon, NY. Mother of Seymour and Zachary Rosenberg and Diane Kaiden. Grandmother of Ronney, Joanne, Amy, Michael, Stephen, Jonathan and Matthew. Great grandmother of Jack, Robert and Zachary. Services Friday, 12 noon, at Riverside Chapel in Mt. Vernon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, HELENE
description: BLUM-Helene. At the age of 87. Beloved wife of the late David. Proud mother of Nancy (Blum) and Larry Rosenfeld and the late Dennis Diamond. Loving grandmother of Ashley and Drew. She will be fondly remembered and sorely missed by all who knew her. Service Sunday 2pm at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Guttman Breast Diagnostic Institute or The Parkinson Disease Foundation.

title: Cowboys Changing On and Off the Field
description: The Dallas Cowboys are not what they once were. For the Cowboys, this is a bad thing and this is a good thing.

title: U.S. Indicts Money Manager on Fraud and Kickback Charges
description: Alan B. Bond, a Wall Street money manager, was indicted yesterday on federal charges that he took $6.9 million in kickbacks from commissions paid to brokers to whom he had steered his clients' investments.

title: Earnings Decline 6.6% at FDX
description: The FDX Corporation, the parent of Federal Express, the overnight-delivery company, said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 6.6 percent as jet-fuel costs rose and shipments in the United States grew less than forecast.

title: When They Said No to Frills
description: PROVING once again that it can mount a boutique of a show with the same panache as a five-alarm blockbuster, the Metropolitan Museum has unveiled an exquisite sampling of 20th-century design objects from its own collection.

title: Uncharacteristic Adventures in Comparative Viewing
description: The Dia Center for the Arts has a certain hauteur. It tends to favor the Minimalist-Conceptualist elect, showing their work in splendid isolation, fastidiously installed, for a year or even more. Dia's efforts have a distinct intellectual slant that can sometimes feel slightly medicinal. It is possible to emerge from a Dia show feeling that good deeds have been done: by Dia, for organizing it, and by oneself, for seeing it.

title: As Sales Boom Online, Some Customers Boo; Beam Us Down to Earth, Scotty: E-tailers Rush to Form Alliances With More Traditional Retailers
description: Electronic commerce, explosive as it is, clearly cannot keep growing by going solo.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: REBA McENTIRE: ''Secret of Giving: A Christmas Collection'' (MCA Nashville). Leave it to the queen of post-sexual-revolution heartache to find a song about a divorced mom torn apart by her ex's annual return to play Santa Claus. That and the one about the weary soccer mom renewed by her child's obnoxious school play, complete with a chirping children's choir, are the highlights on this typically intense foray into holiday cheer. The one in which Ms. McEntire interrogates the Virgin Mary is quite excellent, too. The rest is reassuringly perky, especially the swinging version of ''I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus,'' which, perhaps to Ms. McEntire's regret, isn't about adultery. ANN POWERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSIDY, CORNELIA F.
description: CASSIDY-Cornelia F. Of Kings Park, New York, passed away on December 14. at Bishop Jonathan G. Sherman Episcopal Nursing Home in Smithtown, N.Y., following a brief illness. After retiring as administrator at the South Oaks Hospital in Amityville, N.Y., she served eight years as a national field representative with the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals. Viewing from 2-4:30 and 7-9 PM today at Hughes Funeral Home, Kings Park. Mass of Christian Burial at 9:30 AM Saturday, December 18, at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Kings Park, followed by interment at St. Philip Neri Cemetery, Northport, New York.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: 98 DEGREES: ''This Christmas'' (Universal). The hunkiest boy band continues to assert its artistic seriousness with a disc pairing seasonal quiet-storm seductions with notably solid turnouts of holiday classics. The group's vocal interplay on ''God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen'' actually tingles the spine, and the group does better on ''The Little Drummer Boy'' than Ringo Starr manages on his album. Still, did we need two versions of the make-out ballad ''This Gift''? We're all surely hearing it enough wafting through the malls. ANN POWERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPLEY, DONALD F.
description: TAPLEY-Donald F. The Health Sciences Division of Columbia University mourns the loss of Donald F. Tapley, Dean of the College of Physicians & Surgeons from 1973-1984 and, at the time of his death, Senior Deputy Vice President for the Health Sciences and Alumni Professor of Medicine. As a faculty member since 1956, Don not only could recall much of our school's history, he also was part of our history. His influence on the school and the entire ColumbiaPresbyterian complex is wide and deep. He generated considerable support for facilities, young researchers, and students. He was an honorary alumnus of P&S and as dean started a series of meetings with P&S alumni throughout the nation; annual giving from alumni doubled during that time. Among his important legacies is ''The Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons Complete Home Medical Guide'', first published in 1985. The third revised edition of the guide was published in 1995. Proceeds from sales fund scholarships at P&S. A memorial service will be held at 3PM Saturday, December 18, at Palisades Presbyterian Church on Washington Spring Road in Palisades, NY. A reception will follow. Donations may be made in his memory to The Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons Scholarship Fund or the P&S Endowment, c/o Alumni Office, BB2-250, 630 W. 168th Street, NY NY 10032. Our condolences go to his wife, Caroline, three daughters, and five grandchildren. Herbert Pardes, M.D. Vice President for Health Sciences Dean, Faculty of Medicine Columbia University

title: Paying for Peace Is Clinton's Challenge
description: Peace is expensive.

title: Fear of Losing Out in Race for Damascus
description: After nearly four years of being the sole Arab partner in peace talks with Israel, Palestinians are concerned that they may be left in the dust as Prime Minister Ehud Barak goes off in pursuit of Damascus.

title: Sports of The Times; Griffey Needs To Do What He Does Best
description: KEN GRIFFEY JR. needs to play in a game somewhere, anywhere, soon. Even if it were one of those silly, celebrity softball games on MTV, Junior needs to show us that sweet swing, that majestic arm, the climbing-up-the-outfield-fence catches and that once-ubiquitous smile.

title: Penalties Will Be A Notre Dame First
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is expected to announce penalties against the University of Notre Dame football program today, the first time the school has ever been cited for major rules infractions.

title: Pity the Cobbler With a Scuffed Soul
description: Bernard Malamud's ''First Seven Years'' is a love story in which the lovers are never caught meeting, neither on the page nor in Sunday's quiet screen adaption. Emotions are subdued in Feld's shoe repair shop on the Lower East Side, but passion for Feld's pretty 19-year-old daughter, Miriam, bubbles in the bosom of Sobel, a 35-year-old concentration-camp survivor who has been Feld's sole employee for five years.

title: ABC News Trains for 2000 Like Team in a Bowl Game; An On-Air Marathon for Peter Jennings, Taking In New Zealand and Western Samoa
description: Don't offer Peter Jennings a cup of coffee anytime in the next two weeks. He is abstaining, on doctor's orders, so a sudden surge of caffeine will really pack a wallop on Dec. 31, when he'll be on the air, virtually nonstop, for 24 hours.

title: New England Lawmakers Consider Drug Strategies
description: Legislative leaders and analysts from the four northern New England states gathered here today to plot joint strategies for lowering the price of prescription drugs, from imposing local price controls to pooling their residents to demand a regional mass discount.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Long a Force In Lighting And Crafts
description: How's this for a quintessential New York client list: the New York Stock Exchange, City Hall, Waldorf-Astoria, Morgan Bank, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Ronald McDonald House and Trinity Church, on Wall Street? These institutions have all been clients of Rambusch, a small 101-year-old family business that makes high-quality custom light fixtures, stained-glass windows, mosaic murals and wrought-iron gates for projects all over the world.

title: Transit Faces Tougher Pact: With Riders
description: NOW that the transit honchos and grunts have a tentative labor deal, maybe it is time to consider a different contract, this one between New York City Transit and the millions of subway and bus riders. The existing agreement is clearly not working.

title: A Queen, Even in Exile
description: IN a city where snubbing is an advanced social sport, Rosemary Harris is offering a master class in the form's more refined elements that no climber (or actor) should miss. The lessons are being administered with serene majesty from the stage of the Walter Kerr Theater, where Noel Coward's ''Waiting in the Wings'' opened last night, and there are few sights more warming on Broadway at the moment than that of Ms. Harris being chilly.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Musique de Nordeste, Volume 1: 1916-1945'' (Buda). If you want a second course in the roots of Brazilian music after hearing Gilberto Gil, Caetano Veloso, Tom Ze or any of the other Brazilian musicians who basked in the attention of North Americans this year, this is an excellent one-volume anthology of popular northeastern Brazilian music from the first half of the century. It includes great examples of embolada, the rapid-fire satiric vocal style; frevo, the fizzy carnival music developed out of military brass bands; and some fluid virtuosity on the bandolin, coming from the Portuguese-Mediterranean influence. BEN RATLIFF

title: It's All About the Bonus
description: This week and next, as Wall Street records the latest in a stream of yearly profits for investment banks and the lawyers who feed on them -- courtesy of the surging stock market and the endless hunger for anything made of silicon -- bonuses will be announced. A few tears may be shed, but mostly there will be the satisfied hum of a certain smugness that comes with predictability.

title: Twists of Fate In L.A. Lives
description: In ''Magnolia,'' the colossally talented Paul Thomas Anderson has set up an artfully orchestrated symphony of intersecting L.A. stories, with many of the cast members from his ''Boogie Nights'' assembled to form a charismatic ensemble. Too good to be missed, the movie is saved from its own worst ideas by the intimacy of the performances, including the film's biggest single surprise, Tom Cruise (right).

title: Chechens Say They Were Shot At in Safe Corridor
description: Desperate civilians fleeing the blistering Russian bombardment of Grozny said today that they had to run a gantlet of gunfire in the ''humanitarian corridor'' set up by the Russian Army. It was not clear who was doing the shooting.

title: Europe Court Faults Trial Of Boy Killers Of Toddler
description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that two 10-year-old boys who kidnapped and killed 2-year-old James Bulger in a suburban Liverpool shopping center in 1993 had not received a fair trial in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ISIDORE
description: GORDON-Isidore. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of Isidore Gordon, father of Nahum, David and Daniel, distinguished supporters of NJOP for more than a decade. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Yehi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: UNISYS PLANS TO ADD 4,000 TO WORK FORCE IN COMING YEAR
description: The Unisys Corporation plans to add about 4,000 employees next year, expanding its work force 11 percent. Unisys, which has transformed itself from a mainframe maker into a computer-services company, plans to hire a total of 7,000 people, after accounting for normal attrition. About 85 percent of the new employees will work for Unisys's services business, the company's chief executive, Larry Weinbach, said in an interview. The rest will work in computer manufacturing. Unisys, based in Blue Bell, Pa., also hired 7,000 people this year, bringing its global work force to 35,000.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: BOB MARLEY: ''Chant Down Babylon'' (Tuff Gong/Island). The basic idea has an undeniable tinge of morbidity, but this assortment of posthumous duets between the Abraham of reggae music and some of his spiritual (and actual) progeny frequently triumphs. Unlike similar studio excavations of Frank Sinatra, this one turns its trickery into hip-hop, a music grounded in historical revision. The talent is top-notch on both sides of the mortal divide. Stephen Marley, who led the project, chose songs that would feel fresh to old Marley fans and revelatory to new ones. His remixes honor hip-hop's link to dub rhythms. And his crew, including Lauryn Hill, Busta Rhymes, Erykah Badu, Krayzie Bone and Guru, exercise their wits to go beyond idol worship, making these urgent, timeless songs speak anew. ANN POWERS

title: Israeli-Backed Militia's Shells Wound 15 Pupils in Lebanon
description: At least 15 Lebanese schoolchildren were reported wounded today, some seriously, when Israeli-allied militia forces fired rockets at a village Israel says is a base for Hezbollah guerrillas.

description: To the Editor:

title: What? No Singing? Is a Puzzlement!
description: If any movie could be said to be haunted (maybe cursed is a better word) by another movie, it is Andy Tennant's picturesque but stodgy ''Anna and the King.'' The film that does the haunting (and the cursing) is the 1956 film adaptation of Rodgers and Hammerstein's classic Broadway musical ''The King and I,'' based on the same material.

title: Get the Homeless Into Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Earn High Praise, Then Stumble to Defeat
description: The night started so well for the Nets. They drained 3-pointers like layups, had a 7-point halftime lead over the Washington Wizards and received praise from President Clinton, who attended tonight's game as a guest of Lewis Katz, the Nets' principal owner.

title: Abbott Drops Plan to Buy Alza, Blaming F.T.C. Antitrust Concern
description: Continuing in its string of recent public misfortunes, Abbott Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that it was abandoning its $7.3 billion acquisition of the Alza Corporation because of antitrust opposition from the Federal Trade Commission.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: THE CLASH: ''From Here to Eternity Live'' (Epic). It is rare that an album released 17 years after a band's creative dissolution is good enough to be added to its canon, but this one culled from Clash concerts from 1978 to 1982 ranks as essential listening for fans of a punk-rock band so smart, intense and iconoclastic that, unlike the Sex Pistols, no one has been able to follow the trail they blazed. Made up of previously unreleased and studio-polished live tracks, this collection -- the Clash's first official live album -- bounces from snarling revolutionary rock to smoldering dub reggae commentary, with a bias toward songs from the band's explosive first album. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: CELINE DION: ''All the Way: A Decade of Song'' (Epic). One thing we won't have to worry about in the New Year will be Celine Dion, who has pledged to take at least two years off music. This is her parting shot, a No. 1-selling album that mixes nine hit ballads with seven new songs. Far from throwaways, the new material is big-budget pop (featuring hit producers like Max Martin and Mutt Lange) overflowing with self-help lyrics that come on like an audio companion to ''Women Who Love Too Much.''

title: Quarterback Plays as Tough as She Talks
description: IT was a heck of a game. The quarterback would show you some of her better bruises, but modesty forbids.

title: Taxes Drain 'Prosperity'
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Lewinsky Testifies in 1997 Taping Case
description: Alternating between deep concern and lightheartedness, Monica S. Lewinsky testified in a Maryland court for more than an hour today in an effort to help state prosecutors put Linda R. Tripp in jail for secretly tape-recording their conversations.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: DANNY GATTON: ''Hot Rod Guitar'' (Rhino). Guitarists were awed by Danny Gatton, who combined invincible technique with deep affection for all sorts of American music: country, be-bop, blues, soul, Western swing, Tin Pan Alley, rockabilly. He could bend notes every which way or slalom around a harmony; he could make his guitar croon a melody or race spirals all around it. And for nearly all of his career until his death in 1994, he played uncelebrated club gigs and recorded for small labels. This two-disc set is a selection from his albums from the 1970's to the 1990's, and even when the compositions are generic, the solos go wriggling and zooming and swaggering out of bounds. JON PARELES

title: A Bloodthirsty Unification of China
description: It is a measure of Hollywood's global reach that Chen Kaige's historical epic ''The Emperor and the Assassin,'' reputed to be the most expensive Asian film ever produced, should closely resemble one of Cecil B. DeMille's grandiose cinematic circuses. In its blend of pomp, suds, swashbuckling action and moralizing (about the price of power and imperial ambition), the movie conveys the sweep of history with a capital H.

title: Once Invisible, Jones Takes Off Wraps
description: If Giants defensive end Cedric Jones had played as well in the past three seasons as he has in the past few weeks, he might have appeared in a Pro Bowl game or two by now. Maybe a few people, getting carried away a bit, would be using his name in the same sentence with Bruce Smith or Reggie White. Jones has been that good, after being so invisible.

title: People
description: * Patrick Furey was named to the vacant post of president at Rapp Collins Worldwide, New York, part of the Omnicom Group. He had been vice president and general manager at Caribiner International, Detroit.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: TAKE SIX: ''We Wish You a Merry Christmas'' (Reprise). Wait a minute: these arrangements aren't easy. These voices sound as if an organist were playing them, or as if they took days to mix. This doesn't sound like the usual knocked-off Christmas album. We're in the domain of Take Six, the vocal group whose talent and desire to please the public are both freakishly high. The singers arrange a song in many segments, jumping among keys and bass lines; in ''Let It Snow'' they imitate sampling. It's some of the most saccharine, most accomplished music imaginable. BEN RATLIFF

title: Arias of the Airwaves
description: OPERA has long been saddled with the perception that it is a pricey art form for elitist audiences. This is not quite fair. After all, decent seats for a Knicks game at Madison Square Garden are comparably expensive, and more difficult to obtain than decent seats for the opera.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Warp 10+1 Influences,'' ''Warp 10+2 Classics 89-92'' and ''Warp 10+3 Remixes'' (Matador/Warp). This trilogy of two-CD sets traces the history of electronic dance music from the mid-80's to the present, as seen through the eyes of Warp, the pioneering label in Sheffield, England, on its 10th anniversary. One of the great tragedies of electronica is that its greatest underground singles and compilations tend to go out of print within a year. The ''Influences'' CD's in this series remedies that by collecting music from Chicago acts like Phuture and Mr. Fingers, who helped inspire the development of techno in Britain. The discs also include that British techno precursor known as acid house, with tracks from A Guy Called Gerald and 808 State. ''Classics'' focuses on rare early singles from Warp by LFO, Nightmares on Wax and others. And ''Remixes'' points to a clinical future, with the soulful minimalism of the ''Influences'' CD giving way to a dry laboratory approach as rock and electronic acts (from Spiritualized to the Aphex Twin) are given music from the Warp back catalog to remix. NEIL STRAUSS

title: As Sales Boom Online, Some Customers Boo; Electronic Traffic Is Up, But Customer Satisfaction Is Heading South
description: The thrill of shopping online is that it replaces the shopping cart with a vehicle that has the power and responsiveness of a fighter plane. Shoppers can rapidly scan the horizon for available products, dive to examine individual items, and then track them with radar-like precision as they are shipped from a warehouse to their front doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIND, DAN
description: LIND-Dan. On December 14, 1999. Beloved father of Richard and Larry. Loving father-in-law of Karen. Dear grandfather of Betsy and Diana. Wearer of the Cornell ''C''. Funeral services 10:45 a.m. Friday December 17th. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: In Surprise, Reformists In Russia Look Strong
description: If you think it's easy being a pro-Western, pro-market politician in Russia these days, get an earful of the first question asked Anatoly M. Chubais during a radio interview this week.

title: A 10-Gallon Place With Dreams to Match
description: The words and music have stuck in my mind for 40-odd years, because they seemed so apt. Frank Loesser wrote them for a musical called ''The Most Happy Fella,'' and they stopped the show every time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUFMAN, JUNE
description: LAUFMAN-June Friend Moses. On December 16, 1999. Beloved wife of Dr. Harold Laufman. Loving mother of Jill Kohlmann and stepmother of Dionne Laufman and Laurien Kogut. Adoring grandmother of Jennifer, Allison, Penny, David, Robin and Gabriela and great grandmother of Matthew. Dear sister of Shirley Abrams and Arlene Rieser. Interment private. A memorial service to be announced.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: JIMMY MURPHY: ''Electricity'' (Sugar Hill) and ''The Legendary Starday-REM Sessions'' (Ace). Poor Jimmy Murphy. An Alabama bricklayer by trade, he had a rough time getting his work released in his lifetime. Now, 18 years after his death, two albums come out showing off his erratic but prodigious talents as a country singer and songwriter in the vein of Jimmie Rodgers and Hank Williams, but without the success and opportunities for development. The Ace album collects his mostly unreleased 60's recordings, from rockabilly to blues to gospel (plus a Vietnam protest song from 1965), while the Sugar Hill reissue focuses on his rediscovery in the late 70's, when he recorded an album for the label with backing from Ricky Skaggs and Jerry Douglas. And his lyrics, on both albums, could have been roadhouse classics: ''Just 'cause your head looks like a hubcap,'' he sings, ''it's no sign that you're a big wheel.'' NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'My Christmas Album'' (MCA). ''Yuletide carols sung by a choir/Damn, Daddy just got fired,'' goes ''Christmas Came to the Ghetto,'' a dose of realism by a group called Avant on a collection featuring MCA Records' current rhythm-and-blues roster. Mary J. Blige heads halfway to Motown for the antiwar, pro-compassion ''Someday at Christmas.'' Then the album turns plush and saccharine: familiar carols delivered with all the melismata the singers -- most of them wishing they were Stevie Wonder -- can cram in. JON PARELES

title: Stopping Medical Errors
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis, Critical of I.O.C., Says It's About the Athletes
description: Carl Lewis had just stepped off a red-eye flight and had not had a chance to hear or read exactly what had happened in Wednesday's questioning by Congress of Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee. But Lewis did not need to hear the latest details to believe that the ugly part of the Olympic Games was being exposed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, DR. JESSE
description: APPEL-Dr. Jesse On December 16, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Loving father of Richard, Kenneth and spouse Janis Appel. Beloved brother of Dr. Louis and Rhoda Appel, Anita Posner and sister-in-law Muriel Jacobson. Cherished grandfather of Gavin, Brendan, Rachael, Matthew, Jesse and Sarah. Devoted companion of Natalie Epstein and adored by many cousins, friends and former patients. Funeral Services today 12 noon at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Blvd & 76th Road, Forest Hills. Interment Beth David Cemetery

title: Collins Shocked by Situation
description: Giants quarterback Kerry Collins, who played on the Carolina Panthers with Rae Carruth for two seasons, from 1997 to 1998, was shocked by Carruth's arrest on murder charges stemming from the drive-by shooting of his pregnant girlfriend in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Eye-Openers
description: Too often, New Yorkers skip breakfast or eat it on the run, in the subway or at their desks. Going out for a relaxing breakfast can feel like a minivacation. Here are 12 restaurants where you can pause and savor, if you can take the time. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Tackling Drug Costs
description: Lawmakers from Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont are plotting strategies for lowering the price of prescription drugs, from imposing price controls to getting a regional mass discount. At a brainstorming session, they said they were acting because Congress had not solved the problem.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: JEWEL: ''Joy: A Holiday Collection'' (Atlantic). Continuing her effort to present herself as the most spiritual pop star around, Jewel takes Christmas very seriously on ''Joy.'' She has written her own setting of the Gloria, as well as a devout pop hymn, ''Face of Love.'' Orchestra, choir and chimes swell behind her in a new arrangement of her hit ''Hands'' that insists, ''We are reflections of God.'' She sings familiar carols sweetly and carefully, with a boy soprano's clarity in ''Ave Maria,'' a breathy intimacy in ''O Holy Night'' and a country singer's torchy throb in ''Hark, the Herald Angels Sing''; she tries to lighten up with yodeling in ''Winter Wonderland.'' But through the album, Jewel projects more steely professionalism than reverence. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANTOR, B. GERALD
description: CANTOR-B. Gerald. (12/17/16-6/3/ 96). My darling Bernie, Happy Birthday. I will always remember how you touched my life. Love, Iris

title: Fixing a Building, Building a Career
description: For decades this city's grand old City Hall a national historic landmark -- sat boarded up and abandoned, decaying from the inside. Passersby would shake their heads at the brick edifice splattered with pigeon dung, and students at Kingston High School across the street would avert their eyes.

title: Other Networks Will Skip A Worldwide Countdown
description: While Peter Jennings is announcing that the New Year has arrived in Djibouti, anchors at the other networks will be taking things a little easier.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA TO INVEST IN CENDANT INTERNET OPERATIONS
description: The Liberty Media Group will spend $400 million to help the Cendant Corporation develop Internet operations related to Cendant's travel, mortgage and real estate businesses. News of the deal sent Cendant's shares soaring $6.0625 each, to $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Liberty Media will receive 18 million Cendant shares and rights for two years to buy about 29 million Cendant shares at $23 each. The agreement, expected to close early next year, may include joint ventures as well as investments in other businesses by Liberty Media and New York-based Cendant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDLICH, MEYER
description: ENDLICH-Meyer. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to his family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

description: His Life As a Director

title: Account Awarded For Migraine Drug
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it had awarded the assignment to create campaigns aimed at consumers for Relpax, an anti-migraine drug awaiting approval from the Food and Drug Administration, to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York, part of the MacManus Group. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Early Modulations: Vintage Volts'' (Caipirinha). The same company that produced ''Modulations,'' a recent documentary film packaging the history of electronic music as a straight line from Stockhausen to Detroit techno, has put out this nine-piece sampler of the genre's first steps. It includes the rather square 50's recordings from the Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center by Otto Luening and Vladimir Ussachevsky; Pierre Schaeffer's chopped-up tape music of locomotive noises in ''Etude aux Chemins de Fer''; John Cage's groundbreaking 1939 ''Imaginary Landscape No. 1''; Morton Subotnick's ''Silver Apples of the Moon''; and other remarkable works by Vittorio Gelmetti, Iannis Xenakis and Luc Ferrari. This is the kind of music that it has previously taken a considerable record-store tab to crack; this album has the virtue of doing it succinctly. BEN RATLIFF

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DYNEGY INC., -- Houston, a natural gas and electricity trader, agreed to sell four gas-processing plants and 675 miles of accompanying pipelines in East Texas for an undisclosed price to a closely held company that it would not identify.

title: France Seeks Unified Vote at the U.N. on Iraq Arms Inspections
description: France, which has delayed a vote in the Security Council on a new arms-inspection system for Iraq until Friday, is hoping for an agreement that all five permanent council members can support.

title: McKay or Holik? Who Gets the Credit?
description: Just two days after scoring seven goals, their largest production of the season, the Devils barely mustered two goals tonight. But that was still enough for a 2-1 victory over the lowly Montreal Canadiens, who have had more injuries this season than any other team in the National Hockey League.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Hard-to-Get Cars Are Hot Wheels, but Cold Investments
description: WHAT is the common thread among Tickle Me Elmo dolls, Egghead.com shares and the Plymouth Prowler? Prices of all three skyrocketed when they were chased by speculators looking to flip them for quick profits, and all have come crashing back to earth.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: GUNS 'N' ROSES: ''Live Era 1987-93'' (Geffen). W. Axl Rose is the Jack Kerouac of hard rock, embodying the myth of masculinity in all its beauty and horror. In 1980's Hollywood, fleeing Midwestern conformity, he found his Neal Cassady, a laconically romantic guitar-slinger named Slash. Together they formed Guns 'n' Roses and proceeded to make a noise as complex and fascinating and gorgeous and repulsive as any heard since the Reagan era. This double CD tells their story, in the roar of an audience Mr. Rose craves but constantly scorns, in his sarcastic onstage patter, which oddly resembles that of his purported enemy, Kurt Cobain, and in 22 tracks of overbearing, awesome rock 'n' roll. Now Mr. Rose is a studio hermit with Slash as a rival. This set, in its excellence, only reasserts the heavy weight of his self-made legend. ANN POWERS

title: Behind Hard-Line Talk: Willingness to Concede
description: Facing the cameras Wednesday during a ceremony meant to herald the resumption of Israeli-Syrian peace talks, Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara of Syria sounded every bit the unreconstructed foe of the Jewish homeland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLANTY, EMMA ''SALLY''
description: GALLANTY-Emma ''Sally'' died on December 12, 1999 in Tacoma, WA. Survived by her son Robert Gallanty of Virgina Beach, VA; two grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Private services were held.

title: Early Wright, 84, Disc Jockey Who Made the Delta Blue, Dies
description: Early Wright, who became a legend in the blues-drenched Mississippi Delta as one of the South's first black disc jockeys, died in a Memphis hospital on Dec. 10. He was 84.

description: TOMORROW 12:40 p.m.

title: Woman Fatally Stabbed At Home in Queens
description: A 39-year-old Queens woman was found stabbed to death in her home on 15th Avenue in College Point yesterday, the police said.

title: Transit Official Says Labor Accord Won't Increase Fares in Near Future
description: The executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority took pains yesterday to assure subway and bus riders that the tentative agreement with the transit union would not force a fare increase in the next few years.

title: Jury Sides With Ex-Athlete in Job Lawsuit
description: A jury in Newark awarded more than $10 million yesterday to Philip J. McConkey, the former New York Giants football player, after finding that Frank G. Zarb, the chairman of the group that runs the Nasdaq stock market, deceived Mr. McConkey into working for him at a previous concern.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: OS MUTANTES: ''World Psychedelic Classics One: Brazil: The Best of Os Mutantes'' (Luaka Bop). Take the Brazilian gift for melody, agitate it in the ferment of the late 1960's, throw in a double handful of surrealist humor and cosmopolitan connections and simmer under the Rio de Janeiro sun, and the result is tropicalia. At once a relic of psychedelia and a harbinger of the mix-and-match 1990's, tropicalia still resounds within and beyond Brazil. Os Mutantes (the Mutants) were at tropicalia's most whimsical fringe. They borrowed songs from their friends Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil and wrote their own; they built arrangements from garage-band guitars, or marimbas and glockenspiels, or Baroque recorders, or tape tricks, or elaborate vocal counterpoint featuring their breathy Brazilian chanteuse, Rita Lee. The two-CD set combines a best-of selection and the previously unreleased album ''Technicolor,'' which includes songs in English (as well as French, Spanish and Portuguese). The band's blithe irreverence is as trusty as its tunes. JON PARELES

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: CHUCK D: ''Chuck D Presents: Louder Than a Bomb'' (Rhino). The approval stamp from Chuck D of Public Enemy, whose song ''Fight the Power'' is emblematic here, predicts the mix on this anthology of political hip-hop. The beats are mostly hard, the rhymes straightforward, although the album's newest cut, ''I Used to Love H.E.R.'' by Common, is sly in its critique of a once-radical subculture whose stars are now as wrapped up in making dollars as any Republican fund-raiser. Groundbreaking tracks by Run D.M.C., Boogie Down Productions and Stetsasonic set a bold tone that expands to include the black-power sounds of Paris and Poor Righteous Teachers, the bohemian musings of the Jungle Brothers and the paranoid realism of Ice Cube and Dr. Dre. Some classics are omitted; new radicals like Mos Def and Lauryn Hill are absent, and Doug E. Fresh's arrogantly moralistic ''Abortion'' is not tempered by even one cut by a woman. But ''Louder Than a Bomb'' powerfully highlights hip-hop's revolutionary heart. ANN POWERS

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: ''ENGLISH VILLAGE CAROLS'' (Smithsonian Folkways Recordings). The eight pints of beer next to the organ on the record's cover get the message across. A perfect antidote to commercialized Christmas goop, these are recordings of regular people singing carols in pubs, hotels and churches around Sheffield, England. (They're jolly, informal recordings; you hear the people saying ''wonderful'' after a good one.) But what makes the album a little better than regular is that the songs aren't familiar: they're local to the region, originating in English country churches, written by artisans and tradesmen. The massed unison voices may make the songs sound similar after a while, but it's the most down-to-earth, least puffed-up holiday record around. BEN RATLIFF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, EVA
description: ROSENTHAL-Eva. On December 15, 1999 of cancer. Eva was born in York, England and spent her early years in Manchester, England. She was educated at Lowther College in Wales, in France, and at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts in London. During World War II, she served in the Royal Air Force as a commissioned officer specializing in cryptography. Eva emigrated to the United States in 1953 and married Sumner Rosenthal in 1958. Among her survivors are her husband, her cousin Richard Benson, niece Merry Newman and nephew Jim Siegel of New York; sister-in-law Bernice Newman of San Diego; and cousins Esme Raye and Vivian Rabin of London. Her family and friends in the United States and England will never forget Eva's insight and wit nor the grit with which she fought her final illness. They recall her elegance dressed either in cashmere and pearls or in blue jeans, her fondness for Jack Russells long before the breed became trendy, her love and her loyalty. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 19 at noon at Park West Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street in Manhattan. Contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., Attn: Box E, NY, NY 10021

title: BURLINGTON RESOURCES TO TAKE $265 MILLION IN CHARGES
description: Burlington Resources Inc., which explores for oil and natural gas, said yesterday it would take pretax charges totaling $265 million in the fourth quarter because of disappointing production at a Texas project and an acquisition. The company, based in Houston, will take a $225 million charge to write down the value of oil and gas properties in West Texas and in shallow waters in the Gulf of Mexico. Burlington also will record a $40 million charge related to last month's $2.25 billion buyout of Poco Petroleums Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas producer. The charges equal $1.22 a share. Burlington is expected to earn 38 cents in the fourth quarter, according to analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Burlington shares fell 75 cents, to $32.50.

Mr. Veloso is increasingly known outside Brazil as an album artist, an intellectual singer and songwriter who embarks on sets of songs as long-form projects. At home he's that, combined with a mass-pop carnival-song composer. This album collects those carnival hits plus other odds and ends from 1968 to the early 80's. It's a collection that encompasses a little bit of quiet hippie-rock (''Samba da Cabeca'' grounds that aesthetic in Brazilian rhythms), frenetic frevos and a cover from the Rolling Stones' ''Let It Bleed.'' title: When a Museum Displays Its Heart
description: Once upon a time, as recently as the 1970's, people did not live on the street in cardboard boxes with their feet sticking out the end. Homelessness, always with us but nowhere near as rampant as it is today, was essentially invisible. Then a combination of circumstances, including the emptying of mental institutions and cutbacks in federal funds for housing, drove all sorts of people onto the streets.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: LITTLE JIMMY SCOTT: ''The Savoy Years and More . . .'' (Savoy Jazz/ Atlantic). At last, the records from the 1950's that built the jazz singer Jimmy Scott's deep cult reputation have been released in a single three-disc batch with proper annotation. He didn't have the cracks in his high voice back then that he does now, and the producer Fred Mendelsohn let Mr. Scott's endlessly elongated vowels flood the tracks at crescendos, making the tunes feel like a blush going through your body. The bulk of the set leaves off at 1960 and jumps to a single 1975 session; there's some histrionic stuff here, but some of these songs -- ''When Did You Leave Heaven?'' or ''Imagination'' -- are the sorts of things you can put on to amaze friends. BEN RATLIFF

title: GTE AGREES TO SELL MORE PHONE LINES TO CITIZENS UTILITIES
description: The GTE Corporation, a local telephone company being acquired by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, agreed yesterday to sell 106,850 phone lines in Illinois to the Citizens Utilities Company for $303 million as it sheds slower-growing businesses. Eighty-nine GTE employees will be offered jobs with Citizens. Earlier this year, Citizens, based in Stamford, Conn., agreed to buy 245,562 GTE lines in Arizona, California, Nebraska and Minnesota. The transaction completes GTE's plan to sell 1.6 million telephone lines in 13 states to pay for investments in new businesses like data, Internet and wireless.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: FAIRPORT CONVENTION: ''Meet on the Ledge'' (A&M). Fairport Convention was England's pioneering folk-rock band. It still exists after numerous lineup changes, but this two-disc collection sums up its best years, 1967 to 1975, when Sandy Denny was its lead singer and Richard Thompson was writing songs. The album follows the group from its early phase, influenced by Bob Dylan and Jefferson Airplane, to its rediscovery of England's traditional repertory, which it rearranged with electric guitars and modal fiddle lines. Denny, who died in 1978, had an indelible voice, smoky and gentle but indomitable. While Fairport's later male vocalists were jaunty enough, it's Denny's songs that remain haunting. JON PARELES

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: TIM BUCKLEY: ''Works in Progress'' (Rhino Handmade). This collection, which can be purchased only on the Internet, may not be the best introduction to the melancholy singer who linked folk to jazz before dying of a drug overdose in 1975, but several cuts weave his mystical spell thoroughly enough to enrapture newcomers. The survival of these tracks is miraculous: they were unearthed by an archivist working on another project and proved to be completed versions, not demos or rough takes. Despite their quality, the songs do repeat, one of them three times. The album will most interest fans seeking insight into Buckley's creative process. Others will note the music's beauty but want to start elsewhere for Buckley's full story. ANN POWERS

title: Playing Politics at the Military's Expense

His statement to that effect came on the heels of Hillary Rodham Clinton's recent campaign speech, in which she asserted that the policy does not work and proposed that gays be allowed to serve openly. Other candidates for office, including Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore, have taken the same position.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: MARK MOTHERSBAUGH: ''Joyeux Mutato'' (Rhino Handmade/Mutato Muzika). Devo's mastermind, Mark Mothersbaugh, has come up with a mostly instrumental album that sounds like the Christmas party at the semiconductor factory. Electronic gizmos buzz and ratchet, hum and click, and as the notes go cheerfully Ping-Ponging around, bell tones tinkle and chime with glimmers of familiar carols, making the tracks subliminally seasonal. The last song reverts to Devo's old tricks; it's a delirious version of ''Silent Night'' that lurches from woozy pedal-steel guitars to funk. The limited-edition album (3,000 copies) is available through www.mutato.com. JON PARELES

Nina was unable to help because she could not speak English well, nor did she have a license to practice medicine in the United States.

description: Rae Carruth, the former wide receiver for the Carolina Panthers, was brought shackled and in prison clothes into a courtroom in Jackson, Tenn., today and agreed to return to North Carolina to face charges that he engineered the murder of his pregnant girlfriend.

title: Looking Back at Rwanda
description: Five years after the slaughter of as many as 800,000 Tutsi in Rwanda, the world is still grappling with its failure to prevent the killing. The United Nations published a sobering, self-critical report yesterday that catalogued in painful detail how it ignored abundant warnings of impending carnage and withdrew most of its peacekeeping force as the massacres began. In Tanzania, meanwhile, the U.N.'s war crimes tribunal charged with prosecuting those responsible for the genocide in Rwanda faces questions about its very survival after an appeals court ordered the release of a suspect because he had been held for nearly two years without being formally charged.

description: A New York investment group wants to build a billion-dollar resort on the Jordanian-Israeli border. In meetings in Jordan with King Abdullah and Shimon Peres, Israel's minister for regional cooperation, Joseph Bernstein of the group Americas Partners presented plans for a ''desert kingdom'' of marinas, golf courses and floating casino hotels. Jordanian and Israeli officials agreed to consider the proposal. William A. Orme Jr.

description: Usually, Allan Houston creeps up on a game with the stealth of a cat burglar and slips away unnoticed with points in his pockets. Sometimes, he will take 20 or 30 with him as he leaves the floor and vanishes in the dramatic stir Latrell Sprewell has created on that same night.

title: Pfizer Seeks Ouster of Warner Board
description: Pfizer Inc. filed plans yesterday seeking to replace the board of the Warner-Lambert Company with directors who do not oppose Pfizer's $72 billion hostile takeover bid. Pfizer, the No. 2 United States drug company, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to begin soliciting votes from shareholders of Warner-Lambert, the maker of the best-selling anti-cholesterol drug Lipitor. It is expected that the commission will take several weeks to review the filing. Earlier this month, Warner-Lambert said it could consider other offers in a letter to shareholders defending the company's planned $58 billion merger with the American Home Products Corporation.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: MARC ANTHONY: ''Desde un Principio/From the Beginning'' (Sony Discos/RMM). With its glut of overblown ballads, Marc Anthony's English-language album ''Marc Anthony'' was a letdown. This compilation from his three salsa albums, plus duets with India and Jennifer Lopez, shows what the excitement was about. His voice sounds as sincere and ardent as any lover could wish, and salsa's leading producers and arrangers surround him with up-to-the-minute pan-American music, full of brisk percussion and alert horn sections. With any luck, his next English-language album will mesh rhythm and romance as easily as these songs do. JON PARELES

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: Q-TIP: ''Amplified'' (Arista). A Tribe Called Quest disbanded last year, but its great insight lingers on with Q-Tip's ''Amplified,'' the first solo album by a Tribe member. Where hip-hop is saturated with booming bass lines and larger-than-life voices, Q-Tip defies both mandates to breeze through the din. The tracks on ''Amplified,'' produced by Q-Tip and Jay Dee, pare bass lines to clipped syncopations, and Q-Tip raps without rushing or raising his voice. Although Busta Rhymes and a self-parodying Korn show up at the end of the album, most of ''Amplified'' is Q-Tip on his own or with the women he's sweet-talking. He's secure in his boasts and playful in his seductions, and the syncopations of his monotone are as much percussion as speech. With electronic blips, tersely swinging drumbeats, two-chord vamps and tightly rationed doses of melody, ''Amplified'' turns weightless, transparent rhythms into hypnosis. JON PARELES

title: Inquiry Says U.N. Inertia in '94 Worsened Genocide in Rwanda
description: A strongly worded report issued today by an international panel of experts holds both the United Nations and leading member countries, primarily the United States, responsible for failing to prevent or end the genocide in Rwanda in 1994, which cost hundreds of thousands of lives.

title: Critics Voicing Fears Over Kensico Reservoir Road Project
description: The Kensico Reservoir, nestled in green hills three miles north of White Plains, has long been considered a linchpin of New York City's sprawling upstate water supply, a way station for 90 percent of the city's drinking water as it flows from larger reservoirs farther north.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKELLEY, OLGA K. (NEE KAPAVICH)

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Everything Is Nice'' (Matador). Cantankerous as always, Matador Records celebrates its first 10 years by ignoring releases before 1996 and skipping its best-selling songwriter, Liz Phair. Except for Pavement's ''Stereo'' and Yo La Tengo's ''Sugar Cube,'' both college-radio anthems, the songs are by no means hits. But the set -- two CD's of previously released songs, one of unreleased odds and ends -- maps late-1990's college radio: punk frenzy (Guitar Wolf), post-punk guitar tangles (Chavez, Modest Mouse, Sleater-Kinney), heartsick introspection (Cat Power, Arab Strap), inexorable minimalist crescendos (Mogwai, Matmos), hip-hop (Non-Phixion, the Arsonists), electronica (Jega, Khan). The unifying principle is that the music sounds homemade and happy to be apart from any mainstream. JON PARELES

title: Once Again, Albert Is at Top of His Game With the N.B.A.
description: When NBC rehired Marv Albert to call National Basketball Association games in late June, he was more than pleased to return just two years after his guilty plea to misdemeanor assault led to his firing by the network.

title: DOW EXERCISES WARRANT TO BUY SCHLUMBERGER SHARES
description: The Dow Chemical Company has exercised a warrant to buy $450 million of stock in Schlumberger Ltd., the world's second-biggest oil field services company. Schlumberger gave Dow the warrant in 1993 as partial payment for a 50 percent interest in an oil field joint venture. Schlumberger also paid Dow $675 million. Shares of Schlumberger, which has its main offices in New York and Paris, fell 62.5 cents, to $57.1875. Shares of Dow, which is based in Midland, Mich., fell $6.0625 each, to $121.875.

title: Land Mine Kills G.I. in Kosovo, And U.S. Wonders Who Laid It
description: An American soldier in Kosovo died early today after his vehicle struck a land mine that may have been planted in a recent act of sabotage, Pentagon officials said. His was the first American death in the NATO's peacekeeping operation not caused by an accident or suicide.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: ROSIE O'DONNELL: ''A Rosie Christmas'' (Columbia). Ms. O'Donnell wins the prize as the gutsiest karaoke singer of the year. An average-to-good vocalist, she teams up with such world-class singers as Celine Dion, Trisha Yearwood, Elton John and, uh, Elmo (of ''Sesame Street'') for duets on this surprisingly winning Christmas album. Highlights include a collaboration with Cher to recast the Phil Spector production ''Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)'' in the image of Cher's hit ''Believe'' (complete with the robotic vocal effect) and a version of ''The Little Drummer Boy'' with Lauryn Hill giving a laid-back jazz reading. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: LOW: ''Christmas'' (Chair Kicker's Union/Kranky). ''Silent Night'' is very silent indeed when Low, a trio from Duluth, Minn., that specializes in quiet dynamics, minimal instrumentation and morosely droning rock, gets its hands on it. This may not be a typical Christmas album, but it is one of the best. That's not only because it's an oddity for a minimalist rock band with a small cult following to record an entire album of Christmas classics and originals, but also because the group approaches its subject without irony, without synthetic joy and without deviating from its ever-improving slow-motion pop. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: JIMI HENDRIX: ''Merry Christmas and Happy New Year'' (MCA/Experience Hendrix). It's no ''Star Spangled Banner,'' but Hendrix's groaning, piercing guitar medley of ''The Little Drummer Boy,'' ''Silent Night'' and ''Auld Lang Syne,'' recorded with his Band of Gypsies in 1969, is a breath of fresh feedback in a stale holiday genre. Packaged in a 16-minute CD with Hendrix's rare retelling of ''Goldilocks and the Three Bears,'' this shambling holiday outtake may not be classic rock so much as classic novelty. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Exposed Roots: The Best of Alt. Country'' and ''Exposed Roots: Country Legends'' (K-Tel). Garth Brooks, George Strait and Riders in the Sky all have new albums of Christmas favorites (mentioned here in ascending order of quality), but get your country fix at K-Tel instead. ''Country Legends'' is a deftly complied collection of classics by Willie Nelson, George Jones, Lefty Frizzell and Bob Wills. If the classics are old hat to you, then explore ''The Best of Alt. Country,'' a strong two-CD collection attempting to contain this uncontainable, unclassifiable genre of singer-songwriters caught in the radio-free space between folk and country. Included here are Lucinda Williams, Gillian Welch, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, and Vic Chesnutt, with Gram Parsons, a dark father figure, closing out the set. Also recommended for fans of country sin stories is ''Rebels and Outlaws: Music From the Wild Side of Life'' (Capitol). NEIL STRAUSS

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: TALKING HEADS: ''Stop Making Sense'' (Sire/Warner Brothers). When a new version of the 1984 concert film ''Stop Making Sense'' was released to movie theaters this year, Talking Heads took advantage of the full length of a CD to add seven songs to the original album. The expanded Talking Heads band was unstoppable in 1984; David Byrne's arty conceits were embedded in funk that was simultaneously precise and reckless, a polyrhythmic chatter of guitars, keyboards and percussion. The new album sequence restores the gradual buildup of the concert, adds some unhinged guitar in ''Making Flippy Floppy'' and reaches a new peak in the finale, ''Cross-Eyed and Painless.'' JON PARELES

title: Why India and Others See U.S. as Villain on Trade
description: The week after global trade talks collapsed in Seattle, India's commerce and industry minister rose in Parliament here to denounce what he called a pernicious attempt by the richest, most powerful nations -- led by President Clinton -- to rob developing countries of their great advantage in trade: cheap labor.

title: Holiday Albums; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: ''MR. HANKEY'S CHRISTMAS CLASSICS'' (Columbia). This is a disgusting record, and thank the angels (the ones with dirty faces) for that. The hugely underserved members of the population who despise holiday sentimentalism will find an antidote in these songs composed and performed by Matt Stone and Trey Parker in the guise of their creations from the animated sitcom ''South Park.'' There's something here to offend everyone: sex jokes, religion jokes, odes to bodily functions, morbid celebrations of death. Listening will renew you, just like a good dose of ipecac. ANN POWERS

description: Leaders of Syria and Israel agreed today to begin intensive and accelerated talks early next month intended to end the state of war that has existed between them for 50 years, President Clinton announced.

title: Peter G. La Haye Sr., 59, Developer of Sight-Improvement Devices
description: Peter G. La Haye Sr., a leader in developing technologies to help people see better, died Sunday when his private plane crashed in Pennsylvania on its way to New Jersey from Seattle. Mr. La Haye was 59 and lived in Medina, Wash.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''From Spirituals to Swing: The Legendary 1938 and 1939 Carnegie Hall Concerts'' (Vanguard). These three discs chronicle the concerts staged by John Hammond at Carnegie Hall, the first instances of black popular music's being admitted into the shrine of concert music. (Here, too, is a studio session that Hammond made with some of the artists in 1938.) The list of talent is incredible. Imagine an evening with even one of the following: Count Basie's group at its miraculous peak; a relentless three-piano gang-up with Meade Lux Lewis, Albert Ammons and Pete Johnson; Benny Goodman's sextet with Charlie Christian; some gospel performances by Sister Rosetta Tharpe; the Golden Gate Quartet; and a beautiful set by the Kansas City Six, the jazz supergroup. Warning: the live tapes, especially in the first half, sound distant. But the compilation is a milestone in jazz's history, and in New York's. BEN RATLIFF

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: If a cafe is a small restaurant, they should have coined a new word for Morrell Wine Bar and Cafe. The place is a pipsqueak, with miniature proportions that seem even smaller because of its location on the fringes of Rockefeller Center. There's a little bar and a few tables downstairs, a few more tables upstairs and a kitchen just about the right size for a private jet. The waiters have mastered the complicated dance steps familiar to sailors on a submarine.

title: The Transit and School Contracts
description: As New Yorkers scrambled into the last hectic weeks of the year, two tentative labor contracts offered much-needed relief. One saved 3.5 million commuters from a disruptive transit strike, and the other will facilitate more responsible governance of New York City's 1,100 public schools.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''20th-Century Time Capsule'' (Buddha Records). In a highly ambitious project, this album's compilers try to chronicle the entire 20th century, from Theodore Roosevelt's ''square deal'' to Bill Clinton's ''I did not have sexual relations,'' in 75 minutes of sound bites. The result is like a movie scene in which an alien or thawed Neanderthal absorbs American life by sitting in front of a television set and watching a fast-paced collage of events, people and hairstyles. Although the few songs breaking up the collage on this CD tend to be self-serving (most are from the catalog of BMG, which owns Buddha), this whirlwind ride still provides a fascinating lesson on the evolution of political rhetoric, human tragedy and public obsession since the advent of recorded sound. It's also an audio paradise for those looking to add new sound bites to their computers, answering machines or mix tapes. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Cardinal Writes About His Health
description: After missing Sunday Mass for two weeks because of his health, Cardinal John O'Connor wrote in his weekly column in the newspaper Catholic New York yesterday that he had ''no idea what the immediate future brings'' but that ''under no circumstances will I give up.''

description: Articles on Tuesday and Wednesday about the conflict in Chechnya misstated the given name of the chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, who is seeking an end to the fighting. He is Knut Vollebaek, not Kurt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, MARTIN
description: SHERMAN-Martin. 83, of Forest Hills, died on December 16 at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. Mr. Sherman was the owner of ''Glass Art'', located on East 75th Street in Manhattan, which he established in 1967. Mr. Sherman was well known to many in the antiques and interior decoration professions for his mastery in creating and repairing Venetianstyle cut-glass and mirrors. He came to the United States in 1967 with his wife Piry, who died in 1998, and their two daughters. He is survived by his daughters, Erika Safran, of New York, and Carmelita Watkinson, of Rockville, MD, and 5 grandchildren. Services today 12:30 at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills.

title: At Lancome, campaigns for the new year will show models with freckles and all.
description: THERE'S a saying that beauty is not a pretty business. If there isn't, maybe there should be, because competition in the cosmetics field, particularly at the higher-priced end, is getting almost, well, ugly.

title: Ambulance Dispute Delays Changes in Budget
description: A disagreement between the Giuliani administration and the City Council over a plan by the mayor to increase the use of private ambulance companies on some overtime shifts now handled by the Fire Department has delayed the city's first-quarter budget modification.

title: Connecticut Lottery Account Awarded
description: The Connecticut Lottery Corporation in New Britain, Conn., has awarded its account to Cronin & Company in Glastonbury, Conn., for another two and a half years. Billings were estimated at $5.6 million a year.

title: Disputed Madonna Painting In Brooklyn Show Is Defaced
description: A painting whose elephant dung and pornographic touches have incurred the wrath of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and stirred a religious, cultural and political furor in the city was attacked at the Brooklyn Museum of Art yesterday by a man who smeared paint on it but did no permanent damage.

title: Left Field Partners Form New Group
description: Two agency executives in San Francisco have formed an agency named Tonic 360 as a successor to Left Field, a shop where they had been managing partners until October. Kevin Burke, 38, is managing partner for account management and business development at Tonic 360 and Fred Schwartz, 37, is managing partner and creative director. Tonic 360 has 50 employees, they said, working with previous Left Field clients like Macys.com, Sun Microsystems and Visto. Michael McMahon, 35, the third managing partner at Left Field, said in October that he would start his own agency.

title: Purchase of Pathmark Canceled
description: Royal Ahold N.V., Europe's third-biggest food retailer, said today that it had canceled its $1.75 billion purchase of Pathmark Stores Inc. after ''strong opposition'' from United States regulators.

title: Hits, Live Albums and Compilations; Musical Merry-Making, From Raunchy to Reverent
description: BILLY NICHOLLS: ''Would You Believe'' (Immediate/Sequel). Never properly released and worth more than $1,000 on vinyl, ''Would You Believe,'' one of the great lost pop masterpieces of the late 60's, has finally been reissued on CD. Recorded in 1967 by Billy Nicholls, best known as a backing vocalist for the Who and the Small Faces (members of which play on the album), this is an impeccably arranged, sweetly sung, harmony-happy pop ode to lost love in the vein of the Zombies 1969 masterpiece ''Odessey and Oracle.'' And for lyrics of unrequited love, nothing beats Mr. Nicholls's wistfully crooning, ''Life is short, and you won't even talk to me.'' NEIL STRAUSS

title: Lautenberg Makes Pick Official: Gore
description: Senator Frank G. Lautenberg, a three-term Democrat from New Jersey, today announced his endorsement of Vice President Al Gore over his state's favorite son, former Senator Bill Bradley, for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Rich Nations Fault Russia On Chechnya; Call for Truce
description: The world's biggest industrial countries, meeting with Russia in the Group of 8, today issued another condemnation of Moscow's actions in Chechnya and called for an immediate cease-fire there.

title: DALEEN TECHNOLOGIES BUYS INLOGIC FOR $68 MILLION
description: Daleen Technologies said yesterday that it had acquired Inlogic Software Inc. in a $64.8 million stock transaction. The deal combines two providers of Internet customer-management software. Daleen, based in Boca Raton, Fla., offers Web-based products to handle customer management and billing. It lost $6.3 million on sales of $13.2 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. Inlogic, based in Toronto, was privately held and makes software used by online businesses for customer service and billing. It employs 120 people. Shares of Daleen closed at $30.5625, up $3.375 or 12 percent, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Sale of Stock in AltaVista Is Planned
description: CMGI Inc., which invests in several online companies, filed today to sell its Internet search engine, the AltaVista Company, to the public and said it might sell shares in its venture fund unit.

description: Every day this week, the war in southern Lebanon wore on as usual, with mortars, rockets and air attacks.

title: Divided U.N. Council Approves New Iraq Arms Inspection Plan
description: A divided Security Council voted today to create a new arms inspection system for Iraq with the promise to President Saddam Hussein that sanctions against his country could be suspended within a year and eventually lifted if he cooperates.

description: Robert W. Maxwell, a United Nations official who headed the organization's post office in the late 1960's, died Nov. 30 at a nursing home in Hanover, N.H. He was 78.

description: The German government and business leaders formalized an accord today to pay $5.1 billion to forced laborers under the Nazi regime. The pact effectively ends all such claims arising from the Hitler era.

title: Albany County Is Friendly Place for Police Officers on Trial
description: The Bronx will never be confused with Albany County, a place where cornfields and deer are more common sights than body shops, and their differences could have a profound effect on the Amadou Diallo shooting case, sent here by an appellate court order on Thursday.

title: Group Buys Hunt House, Women's Rights Shrine
description: Ending seven months of uncertainty over the fate of a historic property that was central to the movement for women's rights in the United States, a nonprofit organization acquired the Hunt House in Waterloo, N.Y., at auction yesterday, pledging to restore it and donate it to the National Park Service.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHULSKY, ALEXANDER
description: SCHULSKY-Alexander. You left us much too soon, you are a grandfather now, & we know you would have loved your grandson, Grady. Someday, we will share our memories of you with him.

title: Shelters Vow To Defy Mayor On Work Rule
description: A coalition that provides shelter for more than 70 percent of the city's homeless mothers and children said yesterday that its members would defy Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's policy requiring that homeless families work as a condition of keeping their beds. The mayor responded by saying that if the shelters disobeyed him, he would in effect shut them down.

title: Divided by a Common Language
description: In the beginning of the decade, best-seller lists were sure to include Deborah Tannen's ''You Just Don't Understand,'' a book about how men and women use the same words to communicate different things. A new book chronicles a similar gap between parents and children. ''What Did I Just Say!?!'' by Dr. Denis Donovan and Deborah McIntyre, a husband-and-wife team, argues that children from 3 to 10 are ''consummate literalists'' and ''usually register exactly what is said.'' Thus, what a parent says and what a child hears don't necessarily match.

description: The state of Maryland has dropped rape charges against Brian Carcaterra, an all-American lacrosse goalie at Johns Hopkins University. The Maryland state attorney's office said there was insufficient evidence.

description: Ralph Briggs was helping his son Sean with his seventh-grade vocabulary homework on Tuesday, when he asked the boy to use the word ''cardinal'' in a sentence.

description: Two of the eight Cuban detainees holding hostages inside a parish jail here surrendered late Thursday night while a hostage came out at about the same time, the sheriff said today. Though negotiations to end the five-day standoff continued, there was no indication that it was drawing to a close.

Cherished mother, mother-in-law, grandmother and great-grandmother of Daniel, Eileen, Royce, Shepard, Stuart, Jill, Jennifer, Zoe & David. Services, Sunday, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, at 9:30 AM. Mom, there was never a day you were not loved.

description: In a decision that could eventually free some minority inmates, a state judge has ruled that those arrested after June 13, 1995, can seek to have their convictions overturned if the issue of racial bias was raised at trial.

description: MANZAR-Rose. In her 97th year, beloved wife of 72 years of Jack. Devoted mother of Kenneth and Sybil and the late Barton. Dear sister of Pearl Cohen, Alice Cohen and Selma Fibus. Cherished grandmother of four, and great grandmother of five. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont Road, Elmont, Long Island, Sunday at 10 A.M.

title: Catering to a Family as It Tries to Make Ends Meet
description: It is the shrimp jambalaya, mustard chicken and savory lobster that Bronwyn Woods remembers most from her childhood in Far Rockaway, Queens. Her father, a native of Jacksonville, Fla., and her step-mother, from South Carolina, both spent hours at the stove, creating recipes and filling her urban home with fragrant reminiscences of the South.
