description: Notre Dame, which for generations has symbolized the glamour and glory of college football, was placed on probation yesterday for the first time. However, the penalties the South Bend, Ind., university received were minor.

title: The Dow Flirts With a Record Close Until a Late and Large Selloff
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, powered by a jump in General Electric after it announced a 3-for-1 stock split, flirted with a new high yesterday but then gave up the gains in a selloff at the end of the day.

title: An Isolde Legend Salutes the Future
description: This afternoon's performance of ''Tristan und Isolde'' at the Metropolitan Opera, the last of the season, with the acclaimed new duo of Wagner opera, Ben Heppner and Jane Eaglen, in the title roles, will also commemorate an illustrious night in the history of the company, indeed, a milestone in the annals of 20th-century opera: exactly 40 years ago today, Birgit Nilsson made her Met debut in the role of Isolde.

title: Bonfire Danger Warning Had Been Issued in March
description: Seven months before the Nov. 18 collapse of a bonfire structure that killed 12 people and injured 27 others at Texas A&M University here, a university vice president warned in a memorandum that ''we are dangerously close to having a serious incident that connects alcohol, residence halls and bonfire,'' according to documents released on Thursday.

title: Good Health Truly Becomes the Knicks
description: As an indication of how omnipresent Marcus Camby was on the court Thursday night -- levitating above the hardwood for blocked shots and plunging onto it for loose balls -- there was a purplish floor burn on his shoulder getting some attention from a trainer after the game.

title: Donald Tapley, 72; Led Columbia Medical School
description: Prof. Donald Fraser Tapley, dean of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons during 10 years of robust growth, died on Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 and lived in Palisades and Hamden, N.Y.

title: TV RENTAL MERGER
description: A British operator of television networks and hotels, the Granada Group, plans to merge its television rental unit with a division of Thorn U.K. The new company, called Box Clever, will acquire Granada's operation for $966 million and buy Thorn U.K.'s rental unit for $612 million. The merged company will be the largest renter of television in Britain. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, J. EUGENE
description: BANKS-J. Eugene. A limited partner of Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., died on December 16, 1999 at Hightstown, New Jersey. He was 91 years old. He maintained homes in St. James, New York and Hightstown, New Jersey. Mr. Banks had been with Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. from 1942 until his death. Shortly after he joined the firm, Mr. Banks went into service in the U.S. Coast Guard. At the time of his discharge in 1945, Mr. Banks was a Lieutenant Commander. Upon his return to Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., Mr. Banks worked as an economist until he was named head of its institutional investment department in 1950. He was appointed a manager of the firm in 1957, and became a general partner in 1962. A leading authority on investments, Mr. Banks was the author of the ''Guide to Stock Market Policy'' in 1949, ''Institutional Investment Guides'' in 1955, and ''Guides to Growth Stock Investing'' in 1959. Mr. Banks was born in Kirksville, Missouri on January 26, 1908. After his graduation from Washington University in 1930, Mr. Banks joined the Boatman's National Bank in St. Louis. From 1932 to 1938, he managed the funds of a St. Louis family. He worked as an analyst with Fenner & Beane, one of the forerunners of Merrill Lynch, from 1938 until he joined Brown Brothers in 1942. Long active in civic affairs, Mr. Banks served for many years as a warden of Trinity Church, as a trustee of the Trinity Church Association, and director of St. Margaret's House. He was also a trustee of Teachers College at Columbia University, a member of the American Economic Association, the Military Order of the World Wars, Theta Ki, the Church Club, the University Club and the Down Town Association. Mr. Banks is survived by his wife, the former Barbara Hall, his stepdaughter, Mrs. Gardner Mundy, and two stepgrandchildren, Philip Mundy and Catherine McKee. Services will be held at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, on Saturday, December 18 at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. James Episcopal Church, 490 No. Country Road, St. James, N.Y. 11780, or Teachers College at Columbia University, 525 W. 120th Street, New York, New York 10027, would be appreciated.

Other residences include Colorado Springs, CO; Oak Park and Schaumberg, IL. She lived in Greenwich from 1970 until her death. Survived by her son, Joseph C. of Cos Cob, CT; daughter, Jennifer A. of Cincinnati; sister, Carlene Kaniasty of Aurora, CO; and two brothers, Thomas Zehnle of Morrison, CO and Mark Zehnle of Bailey, CO. title: EGLOBE IS ADDING TRANS GLOBAL COMMUNICATIONS
description: EGlobe Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Trans Global Communications Inc. for stock that values the private telecommunications company at $80 million. EGlobe, a Denver-based seller of communications and information services, said that Trans Global expected 1999 revenue of $100 million. That compares with the $35 million in revenue reported by EGlobe for the 12 months ended Sept. 30. The companies expect to complete the deal over the winter. EGlobe's shares closed at $2.9375, up 12.5 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: PROTOCOL SYSTEMS REJECTS $80 MILLION BID FROM INVIVO
description: The Invivo Corporation offered yesterday to acquire Protocol Systems Inc., a rival maker of patient monitoring systems, for $80 million in cash and stock, but Protocol rejected the proposal. Protocol shareholders were offered $5 in cash and $5 in Invivo stock for each share. Protocol's stock gained 27 percent, rising $1.9375, to $8.9375, in Nasdaq trading. Invivo, based in Pleasanton, Calif., said a combined company would increase revenue and reduce costs. Invivo had $48.9 million in revenue for its fiscal year ended June 30. Protocol, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., had $47.6 million in revenue for the first nine months of this year.

title: A Teacher's Gift? Why, Most Certainly
description: Jane Smith, a middle school teacher in Fayetteville, N.C., was always telling Michael Carter, a student of hers, to pull up his baggy pants. What Ms. Smith did not know was that Michael suffered from kidney disease and that the illness, and resulting dialysis, left him routinely sore.

title: Down And Out In Rural Canada
description: A century ago, European farmers spilled across Canada's western prairies, creating ''little Europes.'' As recently as the 1950's, this farming village outside Winnipeg could have been in Germany, supporting one restaurant, two churches, three stores and a high school.

title: PARK NATIONAL SET TO ACQUIRE BANK HOLDING COMPANY
description: The Park National Corporation agreed to acquire the SNB Corporation and its Second National Bank unit for $96 million in stock. In the transaction, Park National will exchange 835,500 shares for SNB's shares outstanding. Second National of Greenville, Ohio, operates eight bank offices and has $300 million in assets. Park National, based in Newark, Ohio, is a bank holding company with 59 branches and $2.6 billion in assets. Shares of Park National closed at $111.50, down $3.375, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Peace Isn't Up to Israel and Syria Alone

But they will have a hard time forging an agreement on the Golan Heights, the slice of Syria that Israel has occupied since 1967, when they return to Washington next month. Even if they can come to a deal, there are two other factors that are potential deal-breakers: Mr. Barak's political problems at home, and the murky role of Lebanon, Syria's junior partner in the talks.

title: A Century Ends in Panama
description: It may be emblematic of our headlong, high-tech rush into the next millennium that a chance to reflect on one of the signal achievements of the American Century -- and one of its less noble subplots -- passed this week with hardly a ripple. The United States handed over the Panama Canal to Panama in a ceremony so bereft of American interest that neither President Clinton nor a single top official in his administration bothered to attend. It was a shabby way to treat a monumental human achievement created at the dawn of this century. Further, it slighted a profound and welcome evolution of American power as the century comes to a close.

title: Editorial Observer; Dividing Up the Money From the Bush Tax Cut
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas projects genuine sympathy when he talks about the single mother earning $20,000 a year and struggling to move her family into the middle class. The identification with salaried workers is a key ingredient of the ''compassionate conservatism'' that he says can remake the image of the Republican Party. For that reason, Mr. Bush says, his plan, which would cost $480 billion over five years, focuses ''on low- and moderate-income families,'' and provides the ''greatest help for those most in need.'' In fact, Mr. Bush's plan is fairer than the 10-year, $800 billion plan passed this year by the Republican-controlled Congress and vetoed by President Clinton. It would have tilted dramatically in favor of wealthy families, throwing financial crumbs to nearly everyone else.

title: GOODRICH MOVES TO DISMISS 24% OF ITS WORK FORCE

Goodrich Company, the No. 1 United States maker of airplane landing gear, said yesterday that it would dismiss 500 workers, or 24 percent of the business's work force, close one plant and partly close another to cut costs after its purchase of the aircraft-parts maker Coltec Industries. The 500 workers represent the bulk of the job cuts associated with the Coltec purchase, said Kevin Ramundo, a Goodrich spokesman. Goodrich will close a plant it owns in Seattle and close part of another in Euless, Tex., that was owned by Coltec. Goodrich, based in Charlotte, N.C., expects to save about $35 million annually, beginning in 2002, as it eliminates overlapping costs, Mr. Ramundo said. An additional $25 million in savings will come in 2000 from consolidating corporate headquarters, he said.

And presto: theater. It has the bite of journalism and the power of performance.

The times have changed, and most of those under scrutiny are dead.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-19-99: The Economics Of Online Toy Shopping; Funny Business

In the scramble to lure customers and establish themselves as brand names in the new millennium, they've been readily absorbing huge financial losses. To demonstrate this improbable calculus, we visited eToys, a large online toy retailer, and made a typical purchase. Then, with the assistance of an industry analyst, Mitchell P. Bartlett of Dain Rauscher Wessels (who supplied us with the estimates), we unwrapped our gifts, took them apart and saw how the pieces fit together.

title: Holiday Care

And so there are beautiful black-and-white photographs in the airy lobby of the gods of Fantasy Records: Miles, Mingus, Bill Evans, Coltrane. Saul Zaentz produced records long before he did movies. (He was a professional poker player a couple of years before that.) In the corridors, past the lobby, there are posters for the movies he has done, including his three Oscar winners for best picture -- ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' ''Amadeus'' and ''The English Patient.'' Upstairs, there is a special sense of work being done, as two men -- one round and small, the other long and lean -- are together again in cartoon opposition and what, for want of a better word, you'd have to call collaboration. That's not adequate, truly. Rather, call it the marriage of two kinds of amazingly knowledgeable innocence.

title: With a New Century, a Promise of New Sounds
description: THE state of classical music now is strangely appropriate for the turning of a millennium. After a period of rapid change, from late Brahms to electronic music and John Cage within a lifetime, music in recent decades has been relatively stable, and the achievements of composers have been correspondingly solid. There is a lot from the 1990's, in particular, to be carried into the next century. But there are signs, too, of imminent change. Economic conditions threaten concert life and the record industry with a purge that one can only hope will be refreshing; composition is bound to be affected, perhaps radically again. The art is ready for a new generation of composers, who are likely to be dissatisfied with the increasing marginalization accorded their predecessors of this century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNERY, MAURICE F.
description: CONNERY-Maurice F. Professor emeritus at UCLA's School of Social Welfare, died at age 81 of cancer at his Pacific Palisades, California, home on Dec. 10, 1999. He was born in 1918 in Beverly, Massachusetts, to William Patrick Connery of Cork, Ireland, & Ellen McEvilly Connery of Galway, Ireland. He was a scholarship student at St. John's Preparatory and at The Johns Hopkins University, where he received his B.A. degree. After military service for the duration of the Second World War, he entered the New York School of Social Welfare (Columbia University), where he met his wife, Mary Haifleigh, who died at home in 1995. He received his M.A. and doctorate degrees in Social Welfare from Columbia University and taught at the University of Minnesota, Smith College and Syracuse University. Dr. Connery joined the faculty of UCLA's School of Social Welfare in 1962, became acting dean in 1969, and dean shortly thereafter, a position he occupied until his retirement in 1985. In addition to his work as dean and educator, he was involved professionally in many aspects of social work, including psychiatric social work and public policy. Dr. Connery is survived by his sister, Catherine Simpson, of Prides Crossing, Massachusetts; his sons Christopher, of Santa Cruz, and Peter, of La Selva Beach, California; and his five grandchildren: John, Laura, Sandy, James and Christina. His sons would appreciate any reminiscences or memories of their father, which may be addressed to Professor Christopher Connery, Oakes College, University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, or via email to cconnery@cats.ucsc.edu.

title: Unearthing a Riot
description: Tulsa grew explosively between 1910 and 1920, built by the oil families who have dominated business, politics and cultural life right up to the present. Downtown Tulsa has changed so little in the last half-century that a traveler who returned after 50 years would find it familiar. But since 1997, Tulsans who thought they knew the city well have been startled to learn of a 1921 riot in which hundreds of people were shot, burned alive or tied to cars and dragged to death. These grim facts have been churned up by the Tulsa Race Riot Commission, created by the Oklahoma Legislature two years ago to investigate the country's bloodiest civil disturbance of the century. The commission report, due on Gov. Frank Keating's desk early next year, will attempt to fix a death toll, provide an estimate of property damage and explain what caused the disturbance in the first place. But the most controversial mission is to determine whether or not the state should pay reparations either to the black district of Greenwood or to individual survivors. The issue has spawned a contentious dispute in the city as a whole -- and reopened interest in the race wars that swept the country early in this century, when whites and African-Americans engaged in armed combat in the streets.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Cash Crop
description: It's not corn that's as high as an elephant's eye in Oklahoma these days. In Tim Tharp's first novel, FALLING DARK (Milkweed, $21.95), harvest season in America's heartland means rounding up old friends and heading out into the fields with axes, machetes and scissors to bring in this year's marijuana crop. The marijuana hidden among the bloodweed is one of several incongruities in the book, some lovely, some forced. The farm's owner, Sam Casey, is no drug lord; in fact, he is mild-mannered, even-tempered and looking to get out of the pot business. A straight-arrow plainsman? Actually, he purchased the farm from the Sunshine People, a commune to which he once belonged, whose constitution consisted of a single word: ''We.'' Then there is Sam's associate, Roy Dale, whose nice-guy name (think Roy Rogers and Dale Evans) belies a dark heart. When a beleaguered, alcoholic single mother is almost raped outside a bar, Roy pummels her attacker -- but then gets her drunk and has sex with her himself. When we later learn Roy once wanted to run a farm for children, though, it's too much (and too late -- he's too evil). Tharp's story tumbles out in a rush -- he lets his dialogue run free without quotation marks, and his sentences become long streams of detail. The result is a fast-flowing, vivid tale of a new kind of prairie that is home to an old kind of conflict, good versus evil. Liam Callanan

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Click! Click! for a Century
description: Americans embraced photography in the mid-19th century; 150 years, and countless millions of photographs later, their ardor has not diminished. It is hard to imagine an aspect of 20th-century American life, whether personal or political, intellectual or commercial, that photography has not influenced. The United States has been a dominant force in photography for the last hundred years, thanks to the sheer mass of its output, its technological innovations and the continual infusions of creativity from its immigrants. In AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHY: A Century of Images (Chronicle, $40), the photography critic Vicki Goldberg and the art historian Robert Silberman have neatly divided the century into three chronological parts and written 30 brief essays, each focusing on notable aspects, from a photographic point of view, of a particular period. From the authors' vantage point, it certainly seems as though the first two-thirds of the century are when the innovation, energy, passion and commitment are, and the last period is more analytical and self-referential -- rather like life itself. There is a photograph for each year of the century, plus others to illustrate chosen themes like war photography or the rise of the news agencies. Goldberg (who also writes about photography for The Times) and Silberman have succeeded in bringing a semblance of order to the past century of photography and have given a lively and informative overview of its many facets. Rosemary Ranck

It was suddenly possible for a viewer to comprehend the charm that people who have seen him in person have noted, but that had been missing from his television appearances. Before that, pop quizzes about foreign leaders and reading lists had caused him to send a panicky look into the camera; during an hour-long interview with Tim Russert on ''Meet the Press'' he had seemed prepared and cogent, mostly in comparison to the low expectations he had carried along.

title: The Boom in Stocks Reverberates in Collectibles
description: AS stocks soared this year, the New York market for antiques, collectibles and 20th-century objects eclipsed even the levels reached in the boom years of the 1980's. Auctions, fairs and exhibitions at museums and galleries attracted new collectors and dealers as well as a new art fair to Manhattan, heightening the awareness of the decorative arts, especially in the Art Deco style.

title: $1.17 Billion Budget Cuts Taxes 1.8%
description: WITH a budget for 2000 in place that has a property tax break and increased spending for many social service and cultural programs, county officials are now looking to see who -- themselves included -- might deserve a raise.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on Dec. 5 about Kozmo.com, an Internet service that delivers food, videotapes, gifts and other items, included an erroneous listing supplied by the company's public relations representative for the hours and service area. The company takes orders from 10 a.m. to 1 a.m. in Manhattan up to 125th Street on the West Side and 116th Street on the East Side and in Brooklyn Heights and nearby areas.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 14 with an article about dressing and identity misstated the year of a photograph of the actress Gina Gershon taken when she was 5. It was 1970, not 1967.

title: INSIDE
description: Crime in New York May Rise, Experts Say

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONNESS, BILLIE HELLER
description: MONNESS-Billie Heller. The members of the Museum Mile Festival Committee express their sympathy to the family and friends of Billie Heller Monness. Her professionalism, dedication, and friendship will be missed. The Museum Mile Festival Commmittee

title: 'Play Slam' at a Pizza Parlor: Homegrown Drama Uptown
description: It was a standing-room-only crowd Tuesday night at A Slice of Harlem, a tiny pizza parlor at 135th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, as teenagers pressed through the door to watch four-minute plays written and performed by their neighborhood peers.

title: Ideas & Trends; To Denmark, Something Is Rotten
description: ANETTE SORENSEN, the Danish mother arrested for leaving her baby unattended on a sidewalk outside an East Village restaurant in 1997, wept openly this week when a federal jury rejected her multimillion-dollar false-arrest claim against New York City.

title: Blood on the Tracks
description: If ''The Sopranos'' - the HBO series about a Mafia family that lives outside Newark - has shown television audiences what New Jersey looks like, a collection of music from the show adds a soundtrack. Judging from the 14 selection on ''The Sopranos: Music From the HBO Original Series,'' just released by Play-Tone/Columbia/Sony Music Soundtrax, the sound of the state is varied. It could be ''Woke Up This Morning (Chosen One Mix)'' performed by A3, which plays over the opening credits each week, or ''The Beast in Me'' performed by Nick Lowe, which was played at the end of the pilot, or Bruce Springsteen performing ''State Trooper,'' which ended the first season. Martin Bruestle, co-executive producer of the soundtrack and one of the show's producers, noted that music was not composed for the show but licensed and used ''as it exists in the lives of our characters.'' That could be, he said, ''in a strip club or in a girl's bedroom.'' A track by a very New Jersey performer, Frank Sinatra, ''It Was a Very Good Year,'' will appear in the premiere episode of the show's second season, Jan. 16. The suggested price for the disc is $17.98; a cassette is $11.98.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, JOHN G.
description: STEWART-John G. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John G. Stewart, associated with The Times from 1958 until retiring in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALVO D'URSO, GIACINTA LA FERLA
description: FALVO d'URSO-Giacinta La Ferla, of Lamezia Terme, Italy, on Saturday, December 4, 1999. Devoted wife of Renato. Wonderful mother of Marina and Dr. Paul Gusmorino, Ivan, Danilo, Rosetta, Francesco, Anna Falvo d'Urso, Rossella and Pino Mercuri. Adoring grandmother of Paul and Sabrina Gusmorino and Antonio Mercuri. She brightened the lives of many. We will miss her warm and gentle heart, her courage, generosity, dignity, inner strength, intellect, and optimism. She was a real paragon of beauty and virtue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISNER, EDWARD H., JR., M.D.
description: REISNER-Edward H., Jr., M.D. 84 years old. Entered into eternal rest on Thursday, December 16. Beloved husband of the late Marguerite (nee Martin). Loving father and father-in-law of Barbara and Herbert Kaufman, Edward M. and Manda Weintraub Reisner, Christine, and Thomas C. and Terry Reisner. Adored grandfather of Royce Jason and Justin Scott. Dear brother of Dr. David Reisner. A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 8, 2000, at 3 PM, at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Chapel, West 114th Street and Amsterdam Ave, Manhattan, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of your choice in memory of Dr. Edward H. Reisner, Jr. For more info call Feeny Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ; 201-444-7650.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a passage in an article yesterday about the Bradley-Gore debate Friday night in New Hampshire included several extraneous words in some copies. The affected sentence should have read, ''While Mr. Gore was less combative than in the first debate, he was still far more aggressive than Mr. Bradley.''

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about Nathan Silver, the author of ''Lost New York,'' misstated his role in the design of the Argosy Book Store on East 59th Street. While Mr. Silver worked on the project, it is credited to the firm of Kramer & Kramer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGAN, MARTHA SHARP
description: COGAN-Martha Sharp. The Unitarian Universalist Service Committee mourns the death and honors the life of Martha Sharp Cogan, one of our founders. This courageous woman undertook our first dangerous mission to Prague in 1939 to rescue countless women, men and children fleeing Nazi persecution. She then served in Europe as our first Co-Commissioner. Her life is an inspiration to us all. Our sympathy to her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren, and to her nephew and his family. Valora Washington Executive Director Unitarian Universalist Service Committee

title: Allies of Bush Say Missteps Cost Him in New Hampshire
description: Many of Gov. George W. Bush's allies in New Hampshire are blaming his Texas-based campaign for early lapses that they say have left him unnecessarily vulnerable against Senator John McCain in the state that holds the first presidential primary in only six weeks.

title: Square Meals
description: TEN SQUARE, an intimate restaurant in Morristown, shares the town with at least 75 competitors. But it has managed to stand out, securing a formidable reputation over the past two years for its New American cuisine with French and Asian influences, and for its professional service and muted atmosphere. However, it has recently lost its most important draw: Zod Arifai, the Albanian-born chef known simply as Chef Zod.

title: A Deep Thinker With an Idea How to Score
description: An aura surrounds Marshall Faulk, an air of mystery and intrigue that makes most people take a second look and sometimes a third. He says what he means, but words do not flow from his lips unless he makes the thoughtful decision to share his wealth of opinions and feelings. And Faulk rarely makes that choice.

title: Delectable Fish, In Every Guise, In Goteborg
description: IF the world thinks about Sweden's second city, Goteborg, at all, it is as the home of Volvo automobiles and Hasselblad cameras. It is, in fact, the lively, friendly capital of the prosperous west Sweden region, a port city that faces west in more ways than one.

title: Peace. Period.
description: In the unusually orderly town of Kochav Yair, home to much of Israel's military elite, ranch houses perch neatly on small manicured plots behind wooden fences. Just a few miles from Palestinian territory, the town at night is as dark, still and tranquil as a Westchester suburb.

title: Saving Historic Sites For Historic Troves
description: AT a time when nearly everyone is looking ahead to the next century, many of the local historical societies here in the county are too, with plans and projects to ensure that the region's past is preserved for future generations.

title: A Kiss of Death?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Skaters, There's No Holiday From the Ice
description: It is the season when figure-skating specials, those sparkling confections starring famous Olympians from the not-so-distant past, sprinkle the networks like snowflakes. No two are exactly the same but, as it goes with snowflakes, no two are so terribly different. They are eye-candy, fusing athletics and artistry, and now that the International Skating Union has relaxed its rules and recognized television as a career tool for aspiring champions, some shows mix amateur and professional skaters for exhibitions and occasionally pit them against each other in competitions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN P.
description: SEVIN-MALVIN P. Giants are not measured in inches. Always in our hearts and thoughts with love. Rhoda, Herbert, Alice, Mark

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Patterson, N.Y.; A Farming Town, Switched to Horses
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a federal order for 392 industrial plants to reduce emissions that add to smog on the Eastern seaboard misstated the given name of New York State's commissioner of environmental conservation, who endorsed the plan. He is John P. Cahill, not William.

title: Union of Right Forces: A Call to Shake Up the Privileged Class
description: THE SCRIPT -- In a cartoon, two men working at a computer hear a siren. They wheel about, saying ''What?'' ''Where?'' ''Look, here!'' and see a huge cockroach crawling toward them, a flashing blue light on its back.

title: A Different Strategy For Going for the Gold
description: TO say that ice has been a leitmotif in the life of Elaine Zayak is to state the obvious. More than a shimmering stage on which to spin and jump before cheering spectators and poker-faced judges, the ice is, and has been for more than 20 years, a workplace for this champion figure skater, who is now a skating coach at the Ice House here.

title: Who Needs Philosophy?
description: Kudos to Robert Boynton for capturing Martha Nussbaum's ability to relate ancient philosophical ideas to current political issues. Nussbaum shows us that understanding philosophy is neither a mystical free-for-all nor an exercise limited to the intellectual/social elite. The mental rigor and focus that philosophy demands applies to many facets of our daily life, including our examination of the world around us and, in Nussbaum's case, having the focus and tenacity to run a race steeped in ancient Greek tradition -- the marathon.

title: A Synagogue's Artistic Route To a Rebirth
description: In 1986, a European artist in search of studio space in New York happened to peer through the windows of a boarded-up building at 172 Norfolk Street, on the Lower East Side. Inside, he saw a soaring interior resembling that of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris. The building turned out to be the oldest synagogue in New York City, which had stood unused and in near total disrepair since 1974.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, HELENE
description: BLUM-Helene. At the age of 87. Beloved wife of the late David. Proud mother of Nancy (Blum) and Larry Rosenfeld and the late Dennis Diamond. Loving grandmother of Ashley and Drew. She will be fondly remembered and sorely missed by all who knew her. Service Sunday 2pm at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Guttman Breast Diagnostic Institute or The Parkinson Disease Foundation.

title: Whose Park Is It Anyway? Elderly vs. Skateboarders
description: A proposed skateboarding park in Bay Ridge has sparked a quarrel among many residents. Some worry about encouraging a potentially dangerous sport; other fear that the park will lower their quality of life.

title: December 12-18; Sentencing in Louima Case
description: The former police officer convicted of torturing Abner Louima in a police stationhouse bathroom in 1997 was sentenced to 30 years in prison. Justin A. Volpe, 27, could have received life behind bars without the possibility of parole. Under the sentence imposed by Judge Eugene H. Nickerson in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, he could be freed in 25 years if he behaves well in prison.

title: Children's Books
description: THE TUB PEOPLE'S CHRISTMAS

title: With a Multiplicity of Voices, a Paper Beckons Newcomers
description: To read everything in the September issue of DiverseCity, you would have to be literate in English, Chinese, Arabic, Spanish, French, Korean, Hindi and the Nahuatl language of Mexico and Central America. And that is precisely the point.

title: Y2K Hooray/Y2K No Way; King of Glitter Is Staying Home
description: TRADITIONALLY, I have gone to St. Barts for the holidays. I started 15 years ago and continued the annual sojourn after marrying and having children.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GILBERT, GEORGE R.
description: GILBERT-George R. 12/19/94. It is five years since you have left us. Not a day goes by that we don't miss you. Love, Simonne, Roger and Vivian

description: To the Editor:

title: December 12-18; Israel and Syria Agree On January Peace Talks
description: After co-existing uneasily for 50 years in a state of war and the last 4 years in cold silence, Israel and Syria have agreed to agree. President Clinton announced that the two countries would begin intensive and accelerated peace talks Jan. 3 at a site near Washington, to be determined.

title: Caring for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Telling Time, From Stonehenge On
description: Timekeeping, from sundials to wristwatches, is the subject of the National Watch and Clock Museum in Columbia, Pa., in Lancaster County, which recently reopened in an expanded building.

title: Empty Seats Are a Concern for the N.B.A.
description: In the foreground of a recent television highlight, Bob Sura of the Cleveland Cavaliers goes in for a two-hand reverse dunk against the Boston Celtics. In the background, a smattering of fans stand and applaud -- amid several hundred vacant seats at Gund Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENHIRSCH, BLANCHE (NEE SCHOEN)
description: ROSENHIRSCH - Blanche (nee Schoen), ninety, on December 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Alfred E. Rosenhirsch. Devoted & loving mother of Gloria and the late Mel Wallick, Suzi and Martin Oppenheimer. Cherished ''Nana'' of Michael and Gayle, Larry and Carolyn, Jim and Cathy Wallick and Claire Wallick and Kai Moy; Marcy, Evan, Josh and Ali Oppenheimer. ''Nana Blanche'' to seven great grandchildren, sister of Dr. Stephen Schoen and cousin of Gina Reder. She devoted her life's work to volunteer service. She understood society's problems and took action to remedy them, aiding the sick, poor and needy, supporting & providing energetic leadership to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, UJA Federation and American Jewish Committee, and numerous other philanthropic causes. Her generosity and thoughtfulness will always remain an inspiration to those blessed to have known her. Funeral services to be on Sunday, December 19th, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street in Manhattan. The family will receive friends on Sunday and Monday, from 3-9PM at the Rosenhirsch residence, and on Tuesday at the Oppenheimer's or at the Wallick's from 3-9PM.

title: A Film Director And a Novelist Of Like Minds
description: SCOTT HICKS was in China in 1995, an itinerant filmmaker shooting a documentary, when he got a message from his wife back in Australia that as relayed by the Chinese hotel clerk, ''C.A.M. had called.'' Mr. Hicks couldn't figure out what that could possibly mean. C.A.M.? Who was C.A.M.? And why were they calling? Finally, he got a line through to Australia. No, not C.A.M., he was told, C.A.A.

title: Turn Left at Cloud 109
description: James Fallows's (Nov. 21) vision of a sky filled with affluent commuters fails to take into account those below for whom life will become a nightmare. If the Klapmeier brothers' dream materializes, there will be as many personal aircraft aloft as there are now S.U.V.'s hogging the roads. You do the arithmetic.

title: Flying to Telluride
description: To the Editor: In her article about her ski trip to Telluride, Colo. (''Riding Telluride's New Age Spirit,'' Nov. 14), Deborah Weisgall wrote: ''The town has an airport, one of the highest in the United States. But in the winter, planes often aren't able to land, so we flew from Boston to Denver and on to Montrose, about 65 miles north.''

title: Foreign Affairs; Saddam Does Vegas
description: Because of rising oil demand from Asia, and the OPEC cartel's limiting of its production, the oil market has been very tight for the past six months. In this tight market, Saddam Hussein's Iraq became the enormously powerful swing producer -- the only country willing and able to suddenly turn on or off its oil tap. When Saddam was pumping his two million barrels a day, prices stayed steady or fell. But if he suddenly stopped, oil prices could skyrocket. On Nov. 23 Saddam suddenly stopped, sending prices soaring. He said he was doing this in protest of continuing U.N. sanctions. Don't believe it. Here's my guess at what Saddam and his oil minister were really saying to each other:

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-19-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Spinner's Family Fun Center, Macedon, N.Y., April 1999

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Ben Heppner; Tackling Tristan, Loving Bugs Bunny
description: EXCUSE me while I slip into something a bit more flame-retardant,'' said Ben Heppner, the Canadian tenor who concluded his role as Tristan in the Metropolitan Opera's sold-out ''Tristan und Isolde'' with Saturday's broadcast performance.

title: On Literary Bridge, Poet Hits a Roadblock
description: At the podium in a makeshift lecture hall at Brooklyn College recently, Billy Collins was not exactly a commanding figure. A balding 58-year-old with crow's feet around the eyes, he looked like the college professor he is, a little weary after almost 30 years of teaching English at Lehman College in the Bronx. It was hard to imagine him holding the attention of the 150 high school students, squirming a bit as they waited to hear him read his poems.

title: Russia Sends Force to Cut Off Chechens' Route Into Georgia
description: In an effort to block the southern escape routes for Islamic rebels in Chechnya, Russian paratroopers have cut the road between the breakaway region and Georgia, its neighbor to the south.

title: Study Sees Little Change in Youth Drug Use
description: After receding modestly for two years, the use of marijuana and other illicit drugs by American adolescents remained largely unchanged in 1999, according to the latest findings in an annual national study that is the leading barometer of teenage substance abuse.

title: Who Needs Philosophy?
description: Robert S. Boynton (Nov. 21) was so dazzled by Martha Nussbaum's self-aggrandizing statements that he failed to do the job we expect of a good journalist. He did not offer any evidence to support her contention that she is an important force for political reform and a stimulus for political action in the United States and in the world. Perhaps this is because no such evidence exists. He did tell us, however, that Robespierre was a major influence on her thought. Given the French revolutionary's advocacy of terror in defense of virtue and his impact on history, we can only be grateful that Nussbaum's writing has failed to secure a following and has had no discernable political consequence.

title: It Never Did Run Smooth
description: In Our Time

title: St. Barnabas Won't Renew City Contract
description: St. Barnabas Hospital, which won a coveted contract almost three years ago to manage Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, one of the city's public hospitals, has decided not to renew the contract when it expires in June, executives from both sides said yesterday.

title: Christmas in New York; An Angel's Light Was Enough
description: EVERY year on Christmas Eve, my father would drive my mother, my three brothers and me around our neighborhood in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, to look at the Christmas lights. And what lights they were!

title: An 1850 Cast-Iron Fence Finds Friends, Needs Money
description: With backing from state politicians, residents near Stuyvesant Square Park are urging the city to finish renovating an 1850 fence that surrounds the grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON ELM, CHARLES A.
description: VON ELM-Charles A. On Dec. 14, 1999, of Forest Hills Gardens, NY. Princeton Graduate-1941. TrusteeKew Forest School. Member West Side Tennis Club. Husband of the late Nancy Rogers. Wonderful father of Carol McDonnell, Barbara Von Elm, Judy C. Bond and Roger. Also survived by five grandchildren. Memorial service St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY, Friday, January 7, 2000 at 3:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to League for Hard of Hearing, 71 West 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010, would be appreciated.

title: The Moral Minority
description: ONE NATION,

title: A Fraction at a Time
description: The bull market hasn't lured everyone.

title: $6 Billion in Online Holiday Sales by the End of This Month! $24 Billion in Internet Ads by 2003! 2.3 Trillion E-Biz Predictions by 2010!
description: You don't need an expert to tell you we're living in the middle of a technological revolution. Everybody knows that the Internet is a big deal and getting bigger, and all those claims that its significance rivals that of the telephone, the railroad, the television and the automobile don't seem as delusional as they did a few years ago. Still, it's easy to wonder, to want to know, to need to know, exactly how momentous the Internet's impact will be. How big will, say, the online advertising industry get over the next three years? Just how many people will trade stocks online? And how much money will be spent shopping on the Web this holiday season, anyway?

title: Jill Craigie, 85, Film Director And Devoted British Socialist
description: Jill Craigie, a devoted socialist and feminist who became one of Britain's first successful female film directors and whose half-century marriage to the Labor Party leader Michael Foot put her at the heart of the country's leftist politics, died on Monday in London. She was 85.

title: A Homey Cafe Scales The Heights, Bearing Music
description: After quadrupling the space of the Tin Room Cafe seven months ago by moving next door to 1 Front Street in Brooklyn Heights, Bruce Mendes opened a second Tin Room Cafe in the Heights at 136 Montague Street (off Henry Street) on Dec. 11.

title: Italy's Premier Steps Down As Coalition Crumbles
description: Seeking to forge a stronger coalition from his fractured center-left majority, Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema resigned today, bringing to an end Italy's 56th government since World War II.

title: Building Collapse Injures Several Workers
description: Three floors of a building under renovation in Harlem collapsed yesterday, injuring several workers as they fell into the basement, officials said.

title: Many Questions After Young America Loss
description: The breeze was building and the seas were stacking up in the waters off Auckland, New Zealand. It was Nov. 9 and Young America, the New York Yacht Club's challenger for the America's Cup, had just begun a race with Japan's Nippon Challenge in the preliminary trials to determine who would face Team New Zealand in February's cup finals.

title: A Sea of 10,000 Objects From 75 Cents to $7,800
description: THE first sight of the Creative Arts Workshop is of its architecturally daring two-story angled window. The nonprofit three-story workshop is located in New Haven's restored Audubon arts district, which is rife with brick walks, lacy iron railings and green courtyards.

title: Food; Party Hearty
description: No ordinary cocktail could countermand the anxiety of this New Year. A society pondering its fate in a thousand-year context needs a stiff drink.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Wendy Anne Wax and Jon Alan Holderer misstated the given name of the bridegroom's father. He is Bernard Holderer, not John.

title: Cold War Without End
description: Weisberg's article is a grand example of modern revisionist methodology. First, muddy the water: Joe McCarthy meant well, though he lied and libeled; Hiss and the Rosenbergs meant well, though, likely, they were spies. Indeed, nobody acted insincerely. In short, it never happened.

title: IN BRIEF; Welfare Recipients Down; Unemployment at Record Low
description: The number of recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children has fallen drastically since state welfare changes went into effect in 1997, Governor Whitman says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAPLEY, DONALD F.
description: TAPLEY-Donald F. The trustees and staff of the Morris-Jumel Mansion Museum express their deepest sympathies to the family of Dr. Donald F. Tapley. Unwavering supporter and longtime Treasurer, Don was a true champion of the Museum. Nancy A. Goshow, President Ken Moss, Executive Director

title: Personal Business; Housecleaning, Before the Party
description: IT'S the holiday season, and you're too busy sipping eggnog, wrapping presents to tying up loose ends at the office to spend much time with year-end personal financial matters. That's fine - you probably won't need to do a millennial reconstruction of your finances anyway. But minor changes in tax law, the volatile financial markets and the coming of the Year 2000 may call for some adjustments and precautions. Here are some suggestions from experts. JAN M. ROSEN with KATHLEEN O'BRIEN

title: I Liked a Pol
description: It was with some incredulity that I read Michael Lewis's (Nov. 21) lamentation that the problem with journalism today is that reporters aren't close enough to the politicians they cover. The reality, obvious to anyone outside the Beltway, is that the public's cynicism about the news media is based on the contrary belief that they are, in fact, too close. Lewis's example only lends weight to this perception -- flattered by ''an important politician . . . willing to speak'' to him, he seems much more concerned about getting close to the big guy than about getting the story for the little guy.

title: Guerrillas In the Mist
description: TOM CRUTCHFIELD stands, on a hectic pre-Christmas Friday afternoon, as he has for most of the last 15 years, on Bloomingdale's main floor. Today he's saying, ''Ferragamo? Ferragamo?'' to passersby. Two years ago it was, ''Tiffany? Tiffany?'' And before that, ''Giorgio Beverly Hills?''

title: Sharpton Enlists an Ally: Winnie Mandela
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton continued to protest the decision to transfer the trial of the four white police officers accused of shooting Amadou Diallo to Albany, and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela appeared with him yesterday and condemned police brutality.

title: He Dropped Out Of Drugs, and Put Them in His Art
description: WHEN the painter Fred Tomaselli pulls out a drawer from a flat file in his studio, a visitor gasps. Inside are cardboard palettes with meticulously cut out photos of birds, flowers and insects scavenged from field guides and arranged by size, color and species. There are also pictures of lips and eyeballs clipped from fashion magazines and palettes of pressed leaves and organic narcotics likes hemp, datura and ephedra. These items, along with scores of pills and tablets -- over-the-counter remedies as well as prescription and recreational drugs -- are Mr. Tomaselli's primary materials. The drugs are stored nearby, sorted in old aspirin bottles.

title: December 12-18; New York Escapes a Strike
description: For days, a contract dispute involving New York City's transit workers had shaped up as a heavyweight bout between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. The mayor threatened to hit the union with huge fines if it went on strike. But minutes after the strike deadline passed, union and transit officials agreed on a tentative contract that would increase the pay of bus and subway workers by more than 18 percent over three years.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-19-99; Feast of Burden
description: Early December found me on a cookie-baking spree. I bought a sleek new hand mixer; I clipped recipes for pfeffernuesse and Finnish chestnut fingers, and when the time came, I started rolling out the old family Christmas cookies by the dozen. I was up past midnight, with flour in my hair and colored sugar on the floor and the radio playing quietly in the only lighted room in the house. My husband and children slumbered on upstairs, and I imagined them dreaming vanilla-scented dreams. I felt like such a bountiful purveyor of life's little treats, such a good, sweet mother.

title: Persian Jews Join America's Melting Pot
description: The Iranian Jews came to this country without using any government money. They have a zero crime rate and no drug problem, have never been seen in family court, pay their taxes and build businesses that, by my rough estimate, add close to $1 billion to the gross national product and create jobs for their fellow Americans.

title: Lives; Close to the Bone
description: A friend called one morning last April to ask if I'd seen the news. The slight catch in her voice made me straighten my back, put me off, made me lie and say I had.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, LEON
description: HART-Leon. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Leon Hart, associated with The Times from 1956 until retiring in 1980.

title: Jennifer Li, Michael Conjalka
description: Li Fang and Dr. Michael S. Conjalka are to be married today at the Plaza in Manhattan. The Rev. Karl Gillmeister, a Presbyterian minister, will perform the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Faith In Search Of Votes
description: On the two-thousandth anniversary of His birth, it was bound to happen. George W. Bush, asked to name the philosopher most influential in his life, replied, ''Jesus Christ, because He changed my heart.'' Not to be outdone, Al Gore confessed on television that he himself had been ''born again,'' that is, had consciously accepted Jesus Christ as his personal Savior. And John McCain's campaign ran TV ads in South Carolina praising him for the moving sermons he had preached for Christmas in a North Vietnamese prison.

title: Aid Plan for the Uninsured Carries a National Message
description: By agreeing Friday on a $1 billion plan to provide health insurance for a third of the state's 3.2 million uninsured, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders sent a message to the rest of the country that New York is trying to regain its stature as a leader on health care policy.

title: December 12-18; Finger-Pointing on Rwanda
description: In a scathing report that he commissioned, Secretary General Kofi Annan and other high-ranking United Nations officials were described as weak and ineffectual in stopping the genocide in Rwanda in 1994. Mr. Annan is a former head of the United Nations peacekeeping department.

title: The Face Definitely Looks Familiar
description: EARLIER this month my 3-year-old daughter's body double arrived in a U.P.S. box, resplendent in a midnight-blue velour dress, patent leather shoes and dark coffee-bean eyes selected from 26 choices of colors and shades.

title: Hope for Family Farms
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; Hatch Does Better With Democrats
description: Senator Hatch was the last candidate to jump into the Republican presidential contest. And in many polls he continues to run exactly where he started -- last, sometimes pulling so little support that pollsters put a zero next to his name.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDWERT, MARVIN, PROFESSOR
description: GOLDWERT-Marvin, Professor. Remembered, missed, and loved every day. Sidney and Suzanne

title: One Among Equals
description: To the Editor:

title: Colonialism Ending in Asia As China Reclaims Macao
description: Five hundred years of European colonialism in Asia sputters to a close here this weekend on a desolate, rain-swept waterfront dredged out of Macao's once beguiling harbor. At the stroke of midnight on Sunday, China will reclaim this tiny enclave from Portugal, raising its red flag over another patch of Chinese soil and setting the stage for what it hopes will be eventual reunification with Taiwan.

title: To Visit Site on Jordan Call First, Be Cautious

title: Still Full of Jazz, Still Pouring It Out
description: TODAY is the jazz trombonist Bob Brookmeyer's 70th birthday, and he's surprised. He never expected to outlive such illustrious colleagues as Al Cohn, Stan Getz, Gerry Mulligan and Zoot Sims, with whom he worked back in the days when he was doing his best to drink himself to death. ''I didn't think I'd see 30,'' he said in the matter-of-fact tones of a man whose memories were horrendous enough to need no embroidery. ''I almost didn't make 45. My major accomplishment back then was not falling down more than, oh, 10 times a day.'' Now he is a distinguished teacher here at the New England Conservatory of Music, known throughout the small world of jazz for his wry, furry-toned valve trombone playing and arrestingly fresh compositions -- as well as his willingness to speak his mind, frankly and for the record.

title: Persian Jews Join America's Melting Pot

Every single part of me was hurt and ashamed to read the article on Iranians in Great Neck [''Circling the Welcome Wagons,'' Dec. 5]. As a Jew, I was very disturbed to read prejudice being spoken by Jews about Jews. As an American, I was ashamed to see such close-minded views present in what should be an enlightened region of the country. As a student and as a teenager, I was discouraged at reading the feelings and resentments which adults are passing on to their children, my peers. Finally, as a Persian, I was outraged at reading such blatant racism directed at my community and my culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORZACH, JACK C., DDS
description: ORZACH-Jack C., DDS, formerly of NYC and Great Neck, on December 12 in Sarasota, FL, after a long illness. Dr. Orzach was born August 8, 1915 in NY and educated at CCNY and at NYU Dental College. An Army veteran of WW II, for 35 years he practiced dentistry in NY, volunteered at Northern Dispensary Clinic, and taught at NYU. He moved with his loving wife, Lucille, to Longboat Key, FL, in 1979. He became active with Mote Marine Laboratory as a volunteer, where he analyzed pathologies in marine mammals and fish, and was known fondly as the Dolphin Dentist. Dr. Orzach's survivors include Lucille and his beloved daughters, Adi Gevins Couzens, married to Michael Couzens, Oakland, CA, and Dr. Robin Scherm of New Paltz, and a brother, David Lawrence of Hillsdale, NJ. Jack's family and friends will remember always his fineness of spirit, humor, loving devotion and dedication to his profession. Memorial donations may be made to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 650 West 168th St., NY 10032.

title: Who Wants to Live Forever?

I always assumed she carried genes for longevity and a strong constitution. There were some in her family, similarly healthy and long-lived, who inherited those genes, and others, less blessed, who did not.

description: The news came during the flight home from Dallas: the Jets were eliminated from playoff contention. It was hardly a revelation since their Super Bowl dreams were dashed long ago by a dreadful 1-6 start.

title: Added Plaintiffs Proposed for Racial Bias Suit Against Coca-Cola
description: Lawyers for four former and current employees who have brought a racial discrimination lawsuit against the Coca-Cola Company filed a request today to add four new plaintiffs.

title: Morgan Stanley Exceeds Expectations With Record Operating Profit
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company reported record quarterly income of $1.63 billion yesterday, up 86 percent from its operating profit in the period a year earlier and well ahead of analysts' estimates.

title: Russia's New Parliament
description: Several distinct messages can be drawn from Sunday's parliamentary elections in Russia, some more encouraging than others. Most hearteningly, voters showed a clear preference for centrists, selecting what may turn out to be the first reform-minded Duma majority since the Soviet collapse. But the main centrist party, Unity, allied with President Boris Yeltsin and Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, built its success on jingoistic exploitation of the brutal Russian military campaign in Chechnya. The results were also skewed by the unequal enforcement of election rules, dirty campaign tricks and the crude bias of television stations allied with the Kremlin. These outlets fed Russians a stream of unproven criminal accusations against the two leaders of a rival party, former Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov and Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow.

title: An N.B.A. Acrobat With Feet on the Ground
description: Dell Curry rifled the inbounds pass from halfcourt, a bullet that careered off the right side of the backboard. The ball looked awfully misguided until Vince Carter, the Toronto Raptors' spectacular forward, came streaking in from the right wing, perfectly timing and catching the ricochet. Spectators in the Air Canada Center looked on in awe as he tried to cradle it between his right palm and wrist -- before losing the ball, and his most recent chance at video immortality.

title: Attacking Eye Cancer Early (in the Womb)
description: Terry Hoddinot, 36, of London, Ontario, has been blind since the age of 3. His son, Riley, 3 1/2, lost his left eye a month ago. And the same rare eye cancer, retinoblastoma, was diagnosed in his baby daughter, Katie, while she was still in the womb.

description: Ever since Ronald Reagan's victory here in 1980 put it on the map, the South Carolina primary has had a central place in Republican politics. And Senator John McCain and Gov. George W. description: BORG-WARNER AUTOMOTIVE, Chicago, named Lawrence Skatoff chief financial officer. He had been chief financial officer and senior vice president at Premark International.

description: Barbie is about to become environmentally correct. Her creator, Mattel Inc., the world's largest toy maker, announced this month that it would begin an effort to eliminate petroleum-based plastics, which have been linked to an assortment of environmental and health problems, from its most popular doll and many of its other toys.

description: NATO peacekeepers in Bosnia today arrested a former Bosnian Serb general charged with war crimes.

description: Buying contact lenses has never been easier. Besides the traditional outlets, like optometrists' offices and mail order stores, they can be found on hundreds of Web sites and even at beauty salons and local flea markets.

title: Virgin Airlines Sells a 49% Stake to Singapore Carrier
description: Richard Branson, the British entrepreneur who started Virgin Airlines 15 years ago with a single jumbo jet flight across the Atlantic, sold nearly half his business today to Singapore Airlines for $965 million.

title: BRAZIL INFLATION GAUGE EASES
description: The inflation rate in Sao Paulo, a barometer of broader Brazilian inflation trends, showed signs of slowing. Prices in the city, Brazil's largest, rose 1.01 percent in the four weeks through Dec. 14, compared with 1.34 percent in the previous four-week period.

title: Ousted I.R.S. Collector Charges Favoritism
description: The top Internal Revenue Service official here repeatedly gave wealthy and politically connected taxpayers unwarranted breaks including reduced tax bills, a refund, and deferred payments in 1996 and 1997, the government's former chief tax collector for the district testified today.

description: In the absence of a strong international police force in Kosovo and facing a rise in crime, the commander of peacekeeping troops in the province has ordered his soldiers back out onto the streets in force.

title: He's Still An Institute You Can't Disparage
description: We've all heard about sins of omission. Now it's time to talk about some of the virtues. One measure of the integrity of the musically savvy cabaret revue ''Our Sinatra'' is what is left out of this delightful tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes. In the course of about 100 minutes (with intermission), there's not a single mention of the Rat Pack, the Mafia, the Kennedys, Mia Farrow or Kitty Kelley.

title: Attacking Prisoners' Rights
description: The push in Congress and in many states to limit the ability of prisoners to seek redress for civil rights violations has intensified in recent years. But no effort has been as sweeping as legislation approved recently by the Michigan legislature that removes all prisoners in state and county jails from the protection of the state's civil rights law and the state disabilities law. Incredibly, the legislation now awaiting Gov. John Engler's signature would apply retroactively to eliminate a pending class-action lawsuit brought under the Civil Rights Act by women prisoners who have been sexually abused by prison guards.

title: Russia Votes, Like It or Not
description: The West has long seen the development of democracy in Russia as a check against the Kremlin's military ambitions and a way to bridge the political divide between East and West.

title: A Handshake Refused
description: Vice President Al Gore may have won the battle of the headlines by offering to debate former Senator Bill Bradley twice a week and refrain from television ads during the primary season. But Mr. Bradley, who responded to Mr. Gore's offer of an on-air handshake with amused disdain on ''Meet the Press'' on Sunday, had sound tactical reasons for rejecting the suggestion. Debates are healthy and enlightening, and the Democratic contenders' two televised encounters over the weekend showed the strengths and weaknesses of both. But there is no reason to insist that Mr. Bradley, a challenger who is much less well known than Mr. Gore, give up a crucial avenue to communicate with voters.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

Pactiv, based in Lake Forest, Ill., agreed to sell an aluminum foil plant in Clayton, N.J., and an aluminum packer-processor plant in Shelbyville, Ky., to Charter Oak Capital Partners. The company has sold its forest-products business in Buchin, Romania, to New Bay Enterprises and an aluminum foil container plant in Belp, Switzerland, to Hans Kolb Wellpappe. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAGE, BETTY
description: CAGE-Betty. Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief, Howard Solomon, Chairman of the Board, Robert I. Lipp, President of the Board of Directors, and the entire New York City Ballet family mourn the passing of Betty Cage. General Manager of New York City Ballet at its inception, Betty spent nearly four decades with the Company. An extraordinary woman who worked side by side with Lincoln Kirstein and George Balanchine, Betty's contribution to New York City Ballet is unsurpassed. Through her unwavering commitment to our founders' vision and her steadfast dedication to the Company, Betty was of crucial importance to the formation and growth of New York City Ballet. During her remarkable career with New York City Ballet, Betty oversaw the early years at City Center, our move to the New York State Theater, as well as some of the most memorable chapters in our Company's history. Throughout it all Betty was a determined leader, and a treasured colleague, mentor and friend to the entire New York City Ballet family. We will miss her.

title: CONEXANT SYSTEMS TO BUY MAKER COMMUNICATIONS
description: Conexant Systems Inc., which makes computer chip components, agreed yesterday to buy Maker Communications Inc., which develops processors for communications equipment, for $990 million in stock. Dr. Tapley's vision, together with the gracious philanthropy of the Irvings, provided Columbia with the outstanding center for the conduct of patient-oriented research in the country. Dr. Tapley's leadership of our General Clinical Research Center grant from the National Institutes of Health ensured that we would combine the highest level of scientific inquiry and the best patient care. title: Columbine Parents Ask Sheriff To Resign Over Tapes of Gunmen

title: Op-Art; It's in the Stars
VODAFONE TO BEGIN OFFER
description: The British wireless telephone provider Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. said it would begin its tender offer on Friday for Mannesmann of Germany, officially starting a hostile bid. Vodafone said it would keep its offer on the table until Feb. 7. Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone, said, ''We have set our timetable to bring our offer to a rapid conclusion so that we can move quickly to take full advantage of the opportunities available to the new group.'' Mannesmann quickly issued a statement rejecting the offer, continuing the verbal sparring match. ''It is a matter of extreme regret that Vodafone insists on pursuing this hostile route,'' the German company said.

title: CISCO DEAL WITH PIRELLI
description: The world's biggest maker of Internet equipment, Cisco Systems Inc., will acquire the optical systems unit of Pirelli S.p.A., the Italian tire and cable company, for $2.15 billion in stock. Cisco, which is buying equipment that expands the capacity of fiber optic telecommunications networks, will also acquire for $100 million a 10 percent stake in each of two Pirelli units producing optical components and undersea cables. Analysts said the companies might cooperate closely in the future. John Tagliabue

title: A New 'Fantasia' to Irk the Purists
description: Walt Disney's animated ''Fantasia,'' approaching its 60th anniversary, still evokes mixed feelings in the classical music audience, for it seems to give and take away at the same time. Putting works by Bach, Beethoven, Stravinsky and others before large and mostly young audiences is obviously all to the good. Yet some already committed classical music listeners consider the use of truncated versions of those works to be a betrayal. And some are still made uneasy by imagery and story lines that in some cases have nothing to do with the music -- particularly in cases where the music has its own specific pictorial associations.

title: TRADE SURPLUS NARROWS
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus narrowed in November as a stronger yen and a recovering economy drew in a record amount of imports. Japan's trade surplus is shrinking as the economy recovers from recession and the stronger yen makes it cheaper to import.

title: In Tiny Fossils, Botanists See Flowery World; Empty Lot Yields Trove of Ancient Plants
description: Ninety million years ago, on what is now an empty lot in Sayreville, N.J., a flower-filled tropical forest stood in flames, its many blossoms burning and smoldering away not into ashy oblivion, but into paleontological perpetuity. For, as scientists now know, the fires that periodically swept these woods so long ago preserved its blooms as perfect charcoal fossils, creating the most bountiful and exquisitely preserved cache of ancient flowers in the world.

title: The Essence Of 'Figaro': It's Young, It's Ensemble
description: The fine singers who assembled on Thursday night for the Met's current revival of ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' have much in common. Their voices, all light and lively, match each other well, blend beautifully together and come across vividly, using the help provided by Peter Davison's sets, which not only give an apt impression of shabby grandeur but serve as a series of acoustic shells. This is, too, a very musical cast, responding well to the generally quick, flowing movement brought to the score by Edo de Waart, who conducted a run of performances earlier in the season. It is a cast that ably displays one of the most important, extraordinary and even revolutionary features of ''Figaro,'' that this is an ensemble piece.

title: OERLIKON-BUEHRLE AGREES TO ACQUIRE PLASMA-THERM
description: The Swiss technology company Oerlikon-Buehrle Holding agreed yesterday to acquire Plasma-Therm Inc. for $150 million in a cash tender offer. Plasma-Therm, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., makes equipment used for chip etching. It had sales of $29 million in the nine months that ended on Aug. 31. Oerlikon-Buehrle's cash offer of $12.50 a share for Plasma-Therm is to begin within five days. The Zurich-based company sees the deal as strengthening its position in the semiconductor equipment industry. Plasma-Therm shares closed Monday at $11.75, up $2.375 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Ralston Share Buyback

The pet food maker said its previous eight million share buyback program, authorized in September, is almost completed. After the buyback, the St. Louis-based company would have about 297 million shares outstanding. Shares in Ralston closed Monday at $26.375, up 18.75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: American Tower Expands
description: The American Tower Corporation, an owner and operator of communications towers, said today that it had agreed to buy U.S. Electrodynamics Inc. for $60 million in cash and stock to provide Internet access to customers in the Pacific Rim and India. American Tower, based in Boston, with 1998 revenue of $103.5 million, will add 52 antennas to provide video, voice, data and Internet services via satellite. The so-called teleport antennas are in Brewster, Wash.; Whitinsville, Mass.;and Kingman, Ariz.

title: Sly Parasite Menaces Pets and Their Owners
description: Lurking in the guts of many pets and people is a sneaky parasite that may well be the most common cause of gastrointestinal distress in this and many other countries. The organism, a protozoan called giardia (pronounced jee-AR-dee-ya), is easy to acquire but hard to diagnose and often difficult to treat effectively. It can cause no symptoms at all or it can turn its host into one sick puppy suffering from abdominal cramps, diarrhea and weight loss. It may even result in food allergies. In its various forms, giardia can infect most vertebrates, but one form, Giardia lamblia, has a particular penchant for mammals, including dogs, cats, livestock and people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MARTIN
description: BERNSTEIN-Martin. On December 19 in New York City, age 95. Beloved husband of Virginia Lubkin, M.D. and loving father of the late Ellen Schanzer of Elizabeth, N.J., James of Washington, DC, Roger of New York City, and John of Baltimore, Md; affectionate grandfather of Bruce, Bella, Juliet and Philip Schanzer, Susannah, Rachel, Martin and Sarah Bernstein, Lara and Danielle Bernstein and Elizabeth and David Bernstein; and great-grandfather of Jesse Schanzer and Jared and Elana Rutner. Decorated Army veteran (Bronze Star) who volunteered for service in the Second World War. A renaissance man who, in his long life, played the double-bass in the New York Philharmonic in the 1920s under the baton of Richard Strauss, Furtwaengler, and Toscanini, among others. Professor Bernstein was chairman of the Music Department of New York University, founded the NYU Washington Square College Chorus and Orchestra and the American Bach Society, and wrote one of the first university textbooks on musicology ''An Intrduction to Music''.

title: OLD NATIONAL SEEKING TO EXPAND IN INDIANA
description: Old National Bancorp agreed yesterday to acquire Permanent Bancorp Inc. for about $92 million in stock to expand in Indiana. Permanent Bancorp shareholders will receive Old Bancorp shares worth $20.59 for each of their shares. The shares rose $3.4375 each, to $18.1875, after reaching a 52-week high of $19.9375. Old National has 119 banking offices in Indiana, Illinois and Kentucky. It also owns subsidiaries that provide consumer finance, brokerage and other services. Permanent has branches in five counties in Indiana. Both companies are based in Evansville, Ind.

title: Inquiry Focuses on Building Rules and Political Influence
description: On Nov. 22, the floor of a building under construction in the Williamsburg section in Brooklyn collapsed, sending an immigrant day laborer to his death in a grave of wet concrete. But more than a funeral followed.

title: Microsoft Objects to an Analyst In U.S. Antitrust Case Against It

title: MEXICO LUXURY HOTELS FOR SALE
description: Mexico's bank rescue agency said it would try to sell the Camino Real hotel chain, which includes several of the country's best-known luxury hotels. The agency will auction the Camino Real Mexico City as well as others in Cancun, Guadalajara, Puerto Vallarta, Acapulco and El Paso, Tex., in the first half of 2000. The agency seized the hotels along with Banco Union S.A., the failing bank that had owned them, after Mexico's economic crisis five years ago.

He is 6 feet 8 inches, with a 43-inch vertical leap and a jump shot that belies the general state of bricklaying in the modern game.

description: BERGER-Adolph R., M.D. The faculty and staff of New York University School of Medicine mourn the passing of Adolph R. Berger, M.D., age 89, a longtime faculty member and alumnus. Dr. Berger served as the Director of Student Health Services at both the medical and dental schools from 1942 to 1949, and was an early participant in one of the first cardiac catheterization laboratories in the country. He retired as Emeritus Professor of Medicine from the full-time faculty in July 1997. Even after retirement, he maintained a strong interest in medical education and the relationship between physicians and their patients. Kenneth G. Langone Chairman, NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees Robert Glickman, M.D. Dean, NYU School of Medicine

Mrs. Marshall develops computer codes for the X Division of the nuclear weapons lab here, where Dr. Lee also worked before he was fired in March for security violations.

Bathed in deepening shades of snow-lit Prussian blue, this screen adaptation of David Guterson's popular 1994 novel is admirably high-minded and visually gorgeous but fatally anesthetized by its own grandiosity.

title: A Recovering Nerd
description: My husband says I've always been a workaholic. When I was a kid, I worked all the time. I got 50 cents allowance, and in high school I got a raise to $1 a week. That was not enough to get your big toe into a movie theater. So I used to baby-sit a lot. And in high school, I became known for cleaning houses. I was a parking lot attendant at the University of California at Berkeley. I also worked in the dean's office. One summer I was accepted into a program that sent 80 students to Washington. Ninety-five percent of the students ended up as unpaid aides to members of Congress. I was one of three who had paying jobs.

title: ShopNow to Buy Ubarter
description: The online shopping service ShopNow.com Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Ubarter.com Inc., an online business-to-business barter service, for about $45 million in stock. Ubarter.com's shares were up 56.25 cents, to $4, and ShopNow.com dropped $1.6875, or 9 percent, to close at $17.0625. The deal will enable ShopNow.com to expand its business-to-business revenue more rapidly. Ubarter.com, founded in 1996, has more than 3,800 business members with more than 7,000 product listings.

Innovator in the computer software field since 1966, he worked on virtually every type of equipment, programming language and operating system in use during the last three decades, and provided training in software engineering and UNIX here and abroad. An expert in communications & middleware, he set up one of the first Internet service providers in New York City. A wise, bold thinker with an indomitable will, generous heart and irreverent sense of humor. A man with a rare talent for friendship and a great enthusiasm for life. Respected, loved and admired by family and colleagues everywhere. Services today, December 22, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. title: No Need to Avoid Times Square On New Year's Eve, Giuliani Says
description: Responding to rising concerns about possible terrorist acts on New Year's Eve, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that there was no evidence of any specific plot against New York City and outlined painstaking plans to maintain order as up to 2 million people gather in Times Square to ring in 2000.

title: Treasury Prices Slip a Bit More After Monday's Huge Drop
description: Government bond yields rose moderately yesterday, continuing the run-up that has taken them to two-year highs even as the Federal Reserve decided to leave short-term interest rates unchanged and to keep its stance neutral.

title: AIRCRAFT MAKER DEFENDS SALE PLAN
description: Responding to criticism from Brazil's military officials, Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, or Embraer, said its plan to sell a minority stake to a French consortium is legal and reasonable. The aircraft manufacturer said that the sale of 20 percent of voting shares is within a limit established before its privatization allowing for a transfer of 40 percent of such equity to foreign concerns. Still, air force authorities reiterated worries over the consequences of French company access to Brazil's military aircraft technology. Simon Romero

title: Incentives Could Raise Some School Principals' Pay by 70%, to $143,000

title: Gotcha! Space Shuttle Crew Captures Broken Telescope
description: After a spirited chase across the sky, the space shuttle Discovery grabbed the Hubble Space Telescope with its robot arm today, retrieving the observatory to begin a critical repair mission.

title: New, With a Familiar Face
description: A COOKBOOK becomes a keeper when you want to take it into the kitchen after you flip through it once. Usually, the attraction is not the book's new culinary horizons but comfortable yet alluring recipes that do not demand hours of work. Joanne Weir's cookbooks are like that. They have a familiar feel and offer the best advice for any home cook: prepare dishes made with the finest ingredients of the season.

title: CHECKFREE TO ACQUIRE BLUEGILL FOR $250 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Moving to broaden its electronic billing service, the CheckFree Holdings Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Internet billing software company BlueGill Technologies for $250 million in stock. CheckFree, based in Atlanta, provides electronic and Internet bill payment services. It also serves investment portfolio managers with more than 760,000 portfolios and some $400 billion in assets. BlueGill has about 100 employees and sites in Ann Arbor, Mich., and Toronto. Its electronic and Internet billing and payment software is used by financial services companies, telecommunications companies and utilities.

His father's eyes followed him with an intent to chide, but he used his deep, persuasive voice to coax his son into a chair.

title: End Zone As War Zone . . . Hut!
description: As a cinematic flasher of not-so-secret mass culture fantasies, Oliver Stone is Hollywood's R-rated answer to P. T. Barnum. Instead of clowns, aerialists and lion tamers, he parades his own hyper-macho vision of modern American life as a primitive bread-and-circuses carnival of power, greed, lust, fame and violence (especially violence). And in ''Any Given Sunday,'' his viscerally charged, razzle-dazzle ode to professional football as a blood sport, he comes up with some quintessentially zany Oliver Stone moments.

description: In the past, the Rangers could have blamed their inability to defeat Buffalo on Dominik Hasek. Last night, the Sabres demonstrated that it does not matter who protects their goal.
