title: Stolen in '92, Rubens Portrait Is Recovered
description: A portrait painted four centuries ago by the Flemish master Peter Paul Rubens and stolen seven years ago from its owner in Belgium has been recovered from a New Jersey collector who did not know it had been stolen, the authorities said today.

title: Vermont's Momentous Ruling
description: Vermont's highest court has awarded the gay rights movement its biggest victory so far in the struggle to achieve legal recognition and acceptance for same-sex marriages. The court stopped just short of legalizing such marriages, deferring at least for now to Vermont's state legislature. But even if it decides against gay marriages, the court said, the legislature must give same-sex couples the same legal rights and protections enjoyed by heterosexual married couples, covering everything from joint tax returns to the ability to make medical decisions involving a spouse.

title: Dodgers Get to Keep Beltre, but Are Penalized
description: Finding the Los Angeles Dodgers guilty of a foreign transgression for the second time in six months, Commissioner Bud Selig shut down their base of operations in the Dominican Republic for a year yesterday, but allowed them to retain the good young third baseman they had signed a year early.

title: THE CHEF
description: BRINING is a centuries-old method of food preservation, with the most basic formulas using salt, water and sugar. Recently, there has been a surprising resurgence of interest in the technique. Chefs are brining everything from salmon to pork loin, but most commonly the method is being used for turkeys and chickens.

title: ITALIAN BANK DEAL COLLAPSES
description: A leading Italian bank, San Paolo-IMI, said talks to buy Banca del Salento had collapsed, setting back a plan to expand in Southern Italy. The banks did not say why the talks had ended. The Salento reversal follows San Paolo's thwarted $8.8 billion bid for Banca di Roma and an unsuccessful attempt to acquire Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni, Italy's third-largest insurer. San Paolo, based in Turin, planned to combine Banca del Salento, based in the southern region of Puglia, with the 600 branches of Banco di Napoli that it is buying and with San Paolo's own 150 branches in the region to create a powerhouse in the South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEY, PETER J.
description: HOEY-Peter J. On December 21, 1999. Of Northvale, NJ. Born on July 29, 1925 in Dublin, Ireland, he served in the U.S. Army and was decorated for his honorable service during the Korean War. Mr. Hoey was presented the Distinguished Service Award by the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-conditioning Engineers for his innovations and expertise in his field, where he served as lecturer, past president of the NYC Chapter and chairman of the Refrigeration Handbook. He also held various leadership positions of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York and was a past president of the Dublin Society. Mr Hoey is survived by his loving wife, Eileen (nee Hughes); his loving children, Kevin of Norwood, NJ, Peter of Doylestown, PA, Terrence of New York, NY, Brian of Monroe, CT, Stephen of Dumont, NJ, Eileen McCabe of Closter, NJ, and Kathleen of Dumont, NJ; his dear brothers and sisters, Murty of New York, NY, Sean of Texas, Daniel, Rachel and Noreen of Ireland; & his nine inspiring grandchildren. Funeral mass will be celebrated Friday, 9:00 AM at the Immaculate Conception RC Church in Norwood, NJ. Visiting hours will be today, 7-9:00 PM and Thursday, 24:00 and 7-9:00 PM at the Moritz Funeral Home, Tappan, New York. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer St., Hackensack, NJ 07601.

title: SOFTBANK VENTURE FUND IN SOUTH KOREA
description: Masayoshi Son, chief executive of the Japanese Internet company Softbank, will establish a $100 million investment fund in South Korea in the first half of next year to nurture 100 high-technology companies. Mr. Son is among the world's richest individuals, holding assets worth more than $80 billion, spanning 140 Internet-related concerns around the globe. Mr. Son, whose ancestry is Korean as well as Japanese, said he would establish Softbank Holdings Korea to lead investments in Korean concerns with innovative ideas and creativity. Softbank will hold 80 percent of the new concern, while Naray Mobile Telecom will hold the rest. Samuel Len

description: JAKARTA  "One thing I lament," says Pramoedya Ananta Toer, Indonesia's best-known novelist, "is the use of language. We had a clear, simple and concise language, but our simple vocabulary was somehow made complex."

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on Dec. 11 about the rise in Internet-related patents referred to one recently granted to LinkShare, a New York company. The article said the patent gave LinkShare the right to block other Web sites from using an arrangement in which they earn commissions from purchases by users they refer to online stores. The article described the LinkShare patent as a technique for doing business, a claim with potentially broad implications, rather than a narrow technological innovation.

title: Not Quite a Mass, but It's Praetorius
description: Choir directors and audiences have made Handel's ''Messiah'' the most popular work performed in the weeks leading up to Christmas, and with good reason (its composition for Easter performances notwithstanding). But of course there is a rich literature of less frequently heard music for the holiday, and on Thursday evening at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, the British conductor Paul McCreesh presided over a speculative recreation of Michael Praetorius's Mass for Christmas Morning, or at least a Christmas Mass of the sort Praetorius might have overseen in a German church around 1620.

title: F.T.C. Decides Not to Ban Nuclear Ads

title: The Receding Influence of Empires
description: For all the strife at the dawn of a new millennium, one enduring source of conflict may be receding. At least for now, the earth's empires have disappeared as anchors of international order. Some fear that a suffocating American imperium now enforces its culture and unforgiving economic rules. But in today's global environment, the cost and complexity of one people trying to control the sovereignty of broad stretches of the globe no longer seem worth bearing. Today's challenge is to make the new system of established states, new states, failed states, would-be states, regional conflicts and tenuous alliances work better than the old.

title: A Cold Comeuppance in St. Petersburg
description: If the camera spends enough time contemplating an attractive face, isn't it bound eventually to uncover the mysteries of the Mona Lisa? That seems to be the guiding principle of the first-time director Martha Fiennes (Ralph's sister) in photographing Liv Tyler's scenes for the film ''Onegin.'' In this rickety screen adaptation of Alexander Pushkin's verse novel ''Eugene Onegin,'' Ms. Tyler is Tatyana, an enigmatic heartbreaker who reduces the arrogant, rakish title character (Mr. Fiennes) to a quivering wreck.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PLUMMETS. Coffee prices fell after a Brazilian government forecast showed drought did less damage than expected to the world's largest crop. In New York, coffee for March delivery fell 14.6 cents a pound, to $1.207.

title: Take Hundreds of Epochs And Digest in Two Hours
description: So if you're in need of another millennium-season fix, here's a two-hour special from good old reliable National Geographic. ''Adventures in Time,'' made up mainly of material that fans have seen before, offers little by way of fresh ideas or incisive thought, but it is a picturesque grab bag. The notion of packaging billions of years of happenings in two hours is a television conceit, so don't take too seriously the pretense that the program has much to do with time, except the timeouts for commercials.

title: Hillary Clinton Seeks Uniform Sex and Violence Rating for a Range of Media
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton called today for scrapping the existing array of entertainment rating systems and replacing it with a uniform system intended to warn parents about sex and violence in video games, movies, television and music.

title: That Which Can't Be Bottled
description: BIRTHDAYS do not make me feel nearly as old as I feel come New Year's Eve. I think it's the communal countdown in the final seconds, then weeks of miswriting the date on checks because I'm still living in the past, that make me acutely aware of the passage of time. I've had 365 days, my psyche whines. Where did they all go?

title: A One-Man Cross-Dressing Duo (Whew!)
description: Elsa Maxwell, the plump social impresario known for her enviable party lists, and J. Edgar Hoover, the meaty F.B.I. director known for his grim party lists, first met at the Senate dining room in the early 1940's. Maxwell was so charmed that according to the F.B.I.'s file on her she decided to rat on Paul Robeson, Lillian Hellman and Dorothy Parker to help Hoover out. She became his ''special service contact,'' until she herself was suspected of being a Communist.

description: Facing a threatened layoff of 500 workers on Wednesday, the largest union representing Nassau County workers said today that it would go to court to try to block the job cuts.

title: WELLS FARGO AGREES TO BUY ALASKAN BANK
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the seventh-largest United States bank, agreed to buy National Bancorp of Alaska Inc., Alaska's biggest bank, for $907 million in stock to expand into Alaska. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, is already in 21 states, with almost 6,000 branches. It offered $30 a share for each share of National Bancorp. The offer is far below the company's stock price of $40, which was up 56.25 cents, when Nasdaq trading was halted yesterday for the announcement. National Bancorp, based in Anchorage, was founded in 1916. It has $3 billion in assets, 1,250 employees and 54 branches, including a full-service branch in Seattle.

description: Behind a display case filled with cassettes of Cuban music from decades past, Wilfredo del Rio keeps another oldie under glass. It is a photograph of Fidel Castro, smiling and youthful, taken in the heady days after the revolution triumphed in January 1959.

title: Grand Central's Little Secret: It's a Destination for Cooks
description: IF you happen to come up from the Lexington Avenue subway line in the right part of Grand Central Terminal, you will walk into the train station's biggest surprise. Under the lights of 5,000 shimmering Austrian crystals suspended from a sculpture in the form of an olive tree are two fresh-fish stands, a cheese market, a spice bazaar, a greengrocer, a butcher shop, a bakery and six other small food stalls.

title: U.S. Wresting Homeless Fund From Giuliani
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said yesterday that HUD would take direct control of a program that provides $60 million in federal money for services for the homeless in New York City, because, he said, the Giuliani administration could not be trusted to distribute the money fairly.

title: Pompidou Unearths the Museum Within
description: For its 20th birthday in 1997, the Georges Pompidou Center got a much-needed paint job that made the polychromatic neo-industrial building in eastern Paris look more like the cultural fun palace it was designed to be. Then it shut down for 27 months to allow its insides to be torn apart and thoroughly reorganized. Now, on the inevitable date of Jan. 1, France's most visited arts institution finally reopens to the public.

title: No Foul Play Is Seen in Death of Yale Student Found in the River
description: The death of a Yale University senior whose body was found in the Harlem River last month was not the result of foul play, university officials and the New Haven police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MARTIN
description: BERNSTEIN-Martin. On December 19 in New York City, age 95. Beloved husband of Virginia Lubkin, M.D. and loving father of the late Ellen Schanzer of Elizabeth, N.J., James of Washington, DC, Roger of New York City, and John of Baltimore, Md; affectionate grandfather of Bruce, Bella, Juliet and Philip Schanzer, Susannah, Rachel, Martin and Sarah Bernstein, Lara and Danielle Bernstein and Elizabeth and David Bernstein; and great-grandfather of Jesse Schanzer and Jared and Elana Rutner. Decorated Army veteran (Bronze Star) who volunteered for service in the Second World War. A renaissance man who, in his long life, played the double-bass in the New York Philharmonic in the 1920s under the baton of Richard Strauss, Furtwaengler, and Toscanini, among others. Professor Bernstein was chairman of the Music Department of New York University, founded the NYU Washington Square College Chorus and Orchestra and the American Bach Society, and wrote one of the first university textbooks on musicology ''An Intrduction to Music''.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Coat Of Many Colors
description: After the Allies' first successes against German forces in Egypt in World War II, Winston Churchill told the British Parliament that this was not the end of the war, not even the beginning of the end, but it might just be the end of the beginning.

But in a Mediterranean context, it lies at the very heart of things. It stands sentinel between Iberia and the Middle East, closer to Tunisia in North Africa than to Rome and Naples in the boot of Italy.

Her passion, integrity, and sheer determination in everything she did was truly extraordinary. The courage and strength with which she battled her illness was tantamount to the love and energy she brought to everyone around her. Our sincerest condolences to her husband, Charles Ross, adored sons Jonathan and Zachary, and best daughter in the world to Pearl Donshik. We will deeply miss her. title: Robert Bresson, Film Director, Dies at 98
description: Robert Bresson, the acclaimed French movie director whose best-known films, among them ''Diary of a Country Priest'' and ''Pickpocket,'' reflected a strongly aesthetic and spiritual approach to cinema, died on Saturday at his home in Droue-sur-Drouette southwest of Paris. He was 98. He made his last film in 1983 and had been unwell for some time.

description: Grace Huang, a 23-year-old viola student at the Juilliard School, was chatting with two classmates and a professor in Room 524 recently about her latest composition: a jazzy score to a mock television commercial for Ethan Allen, the furniture maker and retailer.

description: Last month Bruce Teitelbaum punctuated his speedy ascent from little-known campaign volunteer to Rudolph W. Giuliani's ubiquitous adviser by promoting the mayor's expected run for the Senate on ''Meet the Press.'' But when ''Face the Nation'' offered a similar opportunity several days ago, Mr. Teitelbaum declined.

title: Fidelity Buys a Building
description: Fidelity Investments, the principal unit of the FMR Corporation, has agreed to pay $185 million to acquire the Boston headquarters building of Stone & Webster Inc., which, by sales, is the seventh-biggest engineering, construction and consulting company in the United States. The deal for the 867,000-square-foot building is expected to close next Tuesday. Fidelity, the world's biggest mutual fund company, currently leases half the space in the 14-story building, at 245 Summer Street, next to South Station.

title: GERMAN TAX-CUT PLAN
description: Swinging from the political left to right with the greatest of ease, the chancellor of Germany, Gerhard Schroder, announced plans to cut taxes for corporations and individuals by about 70 billion marks, or $38.8 billion, in 2001. The plan would reduce the main tax rate on corporations to 25 percent from 40 percent in 2001. It would also speed up tax cuts planned for individuals, lowering the top rate in 2001 to 48.5 percent from 53 percent. Mr. Schroder, who rattled investors last month by attacking hostile takeovers and by bailing out the bankrupt construction company Philipp Holzmann, said the tax cuts were intended to stimulate economic growth and job creation. Edmund L. Andrews

title: MARKS & SPENCER RESHUFFLES
description: The troubled British retailer that owns Brooks Brothers in the United States, Marks & Spencer, said it would reorganize its British business into seven product groups, to keep its profits from sliding further. The new product groups will give Marks & Spencer ''a new impetus and sharper focus'' on the buying side, according to the company, which has made several missteps in recent years by betting on the wrong fashions. This is the third time in less than a year that the retailer has reshuffled executives under Peter Salsbury, its chief executive. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: City Officials Seek Ways to Skirt Ruling on X-Rated Shops
description: On a tree-lined residential street on the Upper West Side, just half a block from a Starbucks and Zabar's, is a neighborhood video store decorated with Christmas wreaths and lights, piped-in holiday jingles and shelves filled with features like ''The Kermit and Piggy Story,'' ''Barney in Concert'' and ''Suzanne Somers' Thighmaster Exercises.''

title: INVESTORS TO ACQUIRE MICRO WAREHOUSE FOR $725 MILLION
description: Micro Warehouse Inc., a computer direct marketer, said yesterday it had agreed to be bought by an investor group for $19 a share in cash, or about $725 million. The investor group is led by the closely held Los Angeles-based investment firm Freeman Spogli & Company; Northwest Airlines' chairman, Gary L. Wilson; and the former chief financial officer of the International Business Machines Corporation, Jerome B. York. The investors also include Alfred D. Boyer, Alfred Checchi and Michael Ovitz. Micro Warehouse, based in Norwalk, Conn., had sales of $1.78 billion for the nine months that ended on Sept. 30.

title: Reno Called Inquiry Too Focused on Scientist
description: Attorney General Janet Reno told Congress in June that she thought federal investigators had prematurely focused on the weapons scientist Wen Ho Lee in their initial inquiry into whether China had stolen United States nuclear secrets, according to newly declassified Senate testimony.

title: OFFICE SPECIALTY PLANS TAKEOVER BID FOR SMED
description: The Canadian office furniture maker Office Specialty Inc. said yesterday that it planned a takeover bid for SMED International Inc. in a cash and stock transaction valued about 247 Canadian dollars, or $167 million. The bid for SMED, a Canadian manufacturer of office interiors and related products, includes about $53 million of SMED's debt as of Sept. 30. Office Specialty said there was little overlap between the two companies' operations, so the combination will expand production and distribution capabilities.

title: Yonkers Girl Dies in Crash As Suspect Flees Police
description: A 4-year-old girl was killed Monday night when a car that was being chased by the police in the Bronx went through a red light at a Yonkers intersection and smashed into a car being driven by her mother, the police said yesterday.

title: Exploring the Outer Limits of an Odd Comedic Universe
description: Andy Kaufman's mind games with his audiences played on an element of the unknown. Whether he was treating everyone in Carnegie Hall to milk and cookies or spewing abuse in his corrosive Tony Clifton mode, it was crucial that the viewer never know whether to laugh or squirm. Kaufman's precocious genius for ironic detachment seemed extreme, to the point where his death in 1984 struck even his loved ones as a possible put-on. But time has turned Kaufman into a hugely influential avatar of confrontational comedy. Jim Carrey, to name just one spiritual descendant, would not be possible without him.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the historian C. Vann Woodward on Sunday gave a misspelled surname in some editions for the Civil War figure whose diary formed the basis of a book he edited. It was ''Mary Chesnut's Civil War,'' not Chestnut's.

title: CAIS SAYS KOHLBERG WILL INVEST UP TO $200 MILLION
description: CAIS Internet Inc., a provider of high-speed Internet access to hotels and apartment buildings, said yesterday that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company was investing as much as $200 million to help finance an expansion of its services. Kohlberg Kravis, the world's largest leveraged-buyout company, will buy 17 percent of CAIS through the purchase of $100 million of preferred stock that is convertible at $16.50 a share. Kohlberg Kravis also has a one-year option to buy an additional 9.5 percent for $20 a share, or $100 million. Shares of the Washington-based CAIS rose $3.6875 each, to $23.6875.

title: PHONE.COM AGREES TO BUY AT MOTION FOR $284 MILLION
description: Phone.com Inc., a maker of software for connecting wireless phones to the Internet, agreed to buy At Motion Inc. for $284 million in stock to gain voice-activated browsing capabilities. Phone.com will exchange 2.25 million shares for closely held At Motion, which is based in Redwood Shores, Calif. At Motion's software lets people use voice commands to gain access to e-mail, phone messages and other information services. Phone.com wants to jump on the expected explosion in demand for wireless data services. Because At Motion's software sits in the network operator's systems, any phone can provide access to its services without modification.

title: HONG KONG REVISES G.D.P. GAIN
description: The Hong Kong government revised higher the city's rate of economic growth in the second quarter of 1999 for the second time. The Census and Statistics Department said that the city's economy grew 1.1 percent compared with a year earlier in the three months ended June 30, compared with its previous growth figure of seven-tenths of a percent, which had already been revised upward from five-tenths of a percent. Hong Kong's economy, helped by improved trade, better consumer spending and increased tourist arrivals, ended its worst-ever recession in the second quarter after five quarters of economic contraction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, JOHN C.
description: CARR-John C. Age 70. Educator and arts advocate died Sunday, December 19, of a heart attack. Dr. Carr was Professor Emeritus at the University of Maryland, where he had been a Professor in the Department of Education. From 1965 until 1994, he was Adjunct Professor in the Drama Department at The Catholic University of America. In his role as arts advocate, he had a longstanding association with The Kennedy Center where he co-designed two programs that have become models for the country: The Kennedy Center Partners in Education Program and the Artists as Educators Seminar. He was also co-director of a pilot program for the development of national guidelines for performance guides for students and teachers. Dr. Carr was co-author and co-editor of five books, including Modern Methods in Secondary Education. He was a columnist for the Los Angeles Drama-Logue and a theater columnist for the Annapolis Capital newspaper. A memorial service will be scheduled for later this winter at The Kennedy Center. For more information call 202-416-8255

title: EMC BUYS BUSINESS SOFTWARE MAKER FOR $192 MILLION
description: In a move to bolster its storage-management software business, the EMC Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the business software developer Softworks Inc. for $10 a share, a total of about $192 million. EMC said Softworks shareholders, with 42 percent of the company's shares outstanding. had already agreed to support the offer. EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., provides business storage-management systems, software and services. Softworks, based in Alexandria, Va., provides business software and services for data and storage management. It has revenue of $53.6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, JOHN L.
description: SIMON-John L., M.D., J.D. 86, born in Philadelphia January 18, 1913. Attended Jefferson Medical College of Thomas Jefferson University and served as a physician in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade during the Spanish Civil War. Practiced neurology and psychiatry in New York and Puerto Rico. Obtained law degree from the University of Puerto Rico. Known as an independent thinker with a wry wit and egalitarian political convictions. Dedicated member of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. Survived by wife Myrtle D. Simon, former wife Ruth B. Simon, six children, two step-children, 14 grandchildren and his sister. Died December 20 after goodbyes to loving family.

title: Ireland's Wayward Writer, Still Raising Eyebrows
description: George J. Mitchell, the former United States senator who recently forged an unexpected alliance between Ulster's unionists and republicans, had a hand this year in bringing ceremonial closure to another feud, this time between Ireland's conservative establishment and its favorite hate object, the writer Edna O'Brien.

title: Hidden At the Heart Of the House
description: THE house, like a family, has its secrets. The domestic surfaces lie, until you start listening to your memory of them, until you look at their commonplaces as clues.

title: Antonio Martinez, 73, Immigration Lawyer
description: Antonio Claudio Martinez, an immigration lawyer based in Manhattan who was a longtime presence in Dominican-American and other immigrant communities, died last Thursday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 73 and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: GAME THEORY; Movies and Games: So Alike, So Different
description: YEARS ago, when society at large became aware of product placements in films, we invented a game called ''Spot the product placement,'' wherein the audience would try to deduce contractual arrangements between Hollywood and corporate America. Of course, there were some obvious hints outside the theater. Fast-food and packaged good promotions were dead giveaways. But in the end, every product on screen was suspect. It changed the nature of the moviegoing experience in a subtle but irrevocable way.

title: The Neediest Cases; Donating With a Mere Click of a Mouse
description: The notion of donating to charity this time of year may evoke images of tossing change to a sidewalk Santa, but with so many daily transactions now done with a click of a mouse, it is no surprise that the Internet has become an increasingly popular way to give.

title: Fear Erases Hope as Venezuelans Search for Dead
description: On Tuesday, Alirio Luque Diaz watched as the body of his five-year-old son, Yoel, was pulled from a pile of rubble here and quickly interred in a mass grave. Today he stood dazed as rescue workers searched for his wife, Yaname, who was eight and a half months pregnant when an avalanche of mud and rock engulfed the family's small house on a mountainside here late last week.

title: Toys 'R' Us Falls Behind On Shipping
description: What could possibly be worse than venturing into a toy store two days before Christmas?

title: Pilot in Fatal Hasbrouck Heights Crash Was Facing License Suspension
description: The pilot of a small plane that crashed into a Hasbrouck Heights neighborhood on Dec. 9, killing him and his three passengers, was facing two possible suspensions of his license, and had previously had it suspended after he crashed another plane, federal aviation records show.

title: A Lively Choir Hastens to the Stable
description: Apart from so many other things, 2000 will be a Bach year, coming a quarter of a millennium after the composer's death, and Lincoln Center's Great Performers series intends to mark the occasion. On Sunday evening, a little early, the marking began with a seasonal performance at Avery Fisher Hall of the first four of the six cantatas collectively known as the ''Christmas'' Oratorio, for which Ton Koopman conducted his Amsterdam Baroque Orchestra and Choir, together with an estimable quartet of soloists.

title: Mercedes and Motorola Revive Idea of Car Phone
description: In their early days cell phones came in two models: bulky units that were intended to stay in cars and slightly less bulky versions that were ostensibly for handheld use. Now Motorola and Mercedes-Benz U.S.A. have revived the idea of the car-specific cell phone although thankfully without the heft.

title: BRAZILIAN JOBLESSNESS FALLS

Separate union statistics also showed a decrease in joblessness in the industrial belt of Sao Paulo, Brazil's business center, with the rate falling to 20.1 percent from 20.6 percent. Simon Romero

description: Scientists in Oregon report today that they have installed jellyfish genes in monkey embryos, using a technique that might eventually be used to create monkeys with added human genes.

title: Woven With Love And Telephone Wire
description: Years ago, when Zulu men began taking sedentary jobs, as night watchmen for instance, in South African cities, they fought boredom with basket weaving, their tribal craft. When palm fronds were not on hand, they harvested the multicolored wires inside telephone cables. When the craft caught on, the telephone company began selling the wire directly to the weavers. The weavers, in turn, began selling their art to South African galleries and collectors.

title: GPU MAKES $215 MILLION DEAL FOR A POWER LINE COMPANY
description: GPU Inc., the owner of utilities in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, agreed to buy MYR Group Inc. of Rolling Meadows, Ill., which builds and maintains power lines and cellular towers, for $215 million. GPU will pay $30.10 a common share, a 43 percent premium to MYR's closing price on Tuesday. GPU is also buying MYR's restricted stock and options. GPU, based in Morristown, N.J., is expanding beyond electricity sales in the United States as its utility markets open to competition. The MYR acquisition is the company's first in the utility infrastructure industry, which has domestic sales of $80 billion a year, said GPU's chief executive, Fred Hafer.

description: The death of an infant boy, found last month in a laundry bag near a Brooklyn doorstep, has been ruled a homicide, the police said yesterday.

title: TELLABS TO BUY SWITCH MAKER, SALIX, FOR $300 MILLION
description: Tellabs Inc., a maker of equipment used to manage traffic on telephone networks, agreed to buy the closely held voice- and Internet-switch maker Salix Technologies of Gaithersburg, Md., for about $300 million in stock. Salix's switch is made for Internet service providers and so-called competitive local exchange carriers, which do not require the larger, costlier circuit switches Tellabs sells to traditional phone service providers. The switch handles regular phone calls and Internet protocol, data and voice traffic. Shares of Tellabs, which is based in Lisle, Ill., fell 81.25 cents, to $64.4375.

title: Good News From Russia (Yes, It's True)
description: The results of Russia's third post-Communist parliamentary elections on Sunday augur an improvement -- yes, improvement -- in her prospects. There will at last be a centrist, reform-oriented Duma able to work with the president. The point bears emphasis, since Boris Yeltsin's Russia is currently presented by the news media as a disaster domestically and a revived menace internationally. All week, pundits have seen the evil twins of nationalism and corruption in the election results.

title: Rocker Blasts New York, Drawing Ire

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUER, PAUL H.
description: BRAUER-Paul H.. M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health mourn the passing of our friend and esteemed colleague, Paul H. Brauer, MD, lecturer in the Department of Psychiatry, who was associated with Mount Sinai for more than five decades. A graduate of the University of Michigan School of Medicine, Dr. Brauer joined the attending staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital in 1946 and subsequently served on the faculty of the Mount Sinai School of Nursing and the New York School of Social Work at Mount Sinai. On the establishment of Mount Sinai School of Medicine in 1966, he was appointed Associate Clinical Professor of Psychiatry, and served with distinction until his retirement in 1982. Admired as both teacher and clinician for his dedication to students and patients, he will be remembered most fondly, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Arlette, his son, Alan, his daughter, Janet Weinberger, to his grandchildren and to the entire family. Helene L. Kaplan, Chair Mount Sinai School of Medicine Stephen M. Peck, Chair Mount Sinai NYU Health Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine John W. Rowe, MD, President Mount Sinai NYU Health Barry R. Freedman, President The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: TELEFONICA EXPANDS IN BRAZIL

title: Eames-Inspired: A Sofa That Flaunts Its Plywood Foundation
description: Since the 1940's, the Herman Miller furniture company has been known for molded plywood, those layered wood veneers that bend when steamed. Charles and Ray Eames are probably best known for their Herman Miller molded plywood chairs. Now, Herman Miller for the Home has created the Goetz Sofa, a cushion-lined plywood container that looks like a baking dish split lengthwise. Most sofas hide their wooden structure; this one flaunts it. A new computerized cutting technique allows the plywood (in walnut, cherry or ebonized ash veneers) to wrap smoothly around the sofa's back and sides. Zippered cushion covers can be peeled off for cleaning. A protective finish called Milfin makes the wood more durable. The sofa (available in a range of fabrics and leathers) starts at $3,750. Information is available from (800) 646-4400.

title: CURRENTS: PLANETARIUMS; Producing the Big Bang: A Reality Check
description: Meanwhile, the American Museum of Natural History in New York is preparing for a February opening of the Rose Center for Earth and Space, home to a new Hayden Planetarium. The center, designed by James Polshek as a sphere floating within a glass box, also features a potentially awesome light show. The exhibition designer Ralph Appelbaum was the one who made the proposal to use the bottom half of the planetarium sphere as the Big Bang Theater, where a sound-and-light production will approximate the computer model astrophysicists created to illustrate their theory. Standing on a see-through vibrating floor, visitors will lean into a fountainlike bowl while videos, lasers and subwoofers bombard them with explosive sounds and light. ''It's the real thing,'' Mr. Appelbaum said. By that he means, it will reflect real science.

title: A Fresh Take on Dotted Swiss
description: In his quest to provide interesting texture and shadows at windows, Jack Lenor Larson has created two new patterns suggestive of dotted swiss for his collection of sheer white curtain fabrics. Snowdrift's wispy texture (above, $108 a yard) is made by combining materials -- tufts of felted wool over a sheer polyester and silk. The flat, geometric pattern of Square Dance (below, $102 a yard), a cotton mesh, is produced by eliminating material through a chemical process. Both patterns come in winter white at Cowtan & Tout, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street), to the trade. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: NIELSEN PAYS $246 MILLION TO RAISE NETRATINGS STAKE
description: Nielsen Media Research Inc., the television audience ratings service, said it had increased its stake in NetRatings Inc., which measures the size of Internet audiences, to 54 percent from about 11 percent, for $246 million. Nielsen, acquired by the Dutch publisher VNU in October, will now hold 18.8 million shares in NetRatings, a VNU spokesman said. Shares in NetRatings, which were first sold to the public for $17 each on Dec. 8, rose $3.50, or 11 percent, to $35.50. The company, based in Milpitas, Calif., is seeking to challenge Media Metrix as the top provider of services to track Internet use.

Coler, the former Comptroller of New York City and the former Brooklyn Borough President. Daughter of the late Eugene Bird and Helen Fischer Coler, wife of the late Sidney Jeffrey Norton, mother of the late Richard Sidney Norton and sister of the late William B. Coler, she is survived by a daughter and son-in-law, Linda and Gerald Johnson of Bedford, New Hampshire; two sons and daughters-in-law, Bird Coler and Carol Norton of Huntington, New York & Jonathan & Lynn Norton of Englewood Cliffs, NJ and four grandchildren, Ashley Rose, Erika Lee, Stephen and Brian Norton. Funeral services were private at A.S. Cole Funeral Home, 22 N. Main Street, Cranbury, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mrs. Norton's memory to the Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon St., Bklyn, NY 11201.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIDMAN, ELIZABETH
description: ZEIDMAN - Elizabeth. Beloved mother of Lewis & Sue Zeidman, Dolores and the late Bernard Zeidman. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Audrey, Roy, Arthur and Roger Zeidman, & Laurel Glassman. Adored great grandmother of Jordan, Jessica, Steven, Joseph, Adam and Alex. Service today, 1:45 PM at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORENCE, LEE
description: FLORENCE-Lee. On December 21, 1999 at age 91. Adored husband of Estelle. Loving father of the late Michael. Most beloved grandfather of David, Diana and Scott. Cherished brother-in-law of Miriam. Dear uncle of Jonathan and Esther, Mattye and Robert, Elaine, Phyllis and Harold, and all their children and grandchildren who were so precious to him. Services today, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREMONT, ANNA
description: BREMONT-Anna. On December 20, 1999, of Forest Hills, New York. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Joseph, John & Rita Bremont. Dear grandmother of Michael, John and Adrianna. Funeral mass St. Vincent Ferrer RC Church, Lexington Avenue and 66th Street, New York City, on Thursday, Dec. 23, at 10:30 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Shuttle Crew Starts Repairs On Telescope
description: A pair of spacewalking astronauts today began the intricate process of repairing the dormant Hubble Space Telescope, replacing the faulty gyroscopes that forced the observatory into hibernation last month.

title: When an Indian's Unwise Double Made Pakistan a Champ
description: International championships have been tense, dull, contentious and controversial. Now, for the first time, one has been interrupted by a death. In Sri Lanka in October, the final of the African, Asian and Middle East Championships was beginning when one of the players, Asrar Umar of Pakistan, died of a heart attack. Pakistan and South Africa were declared to be joint champions, and they will compete in the world championships in Bermuda next month.

title: BP AMOCO CONFIRMS RUSSIAN DEAL
description: BP Amoco, in a move that could preserve its half-billion-dollar investment in Russia, announced it had reached a deal with a Russian company, Tyumen Oil, that would return a prized Siberian oil field to BP Amoco control. Tyumen, which is 49.8 percent owned by the Russian government, had seized the Siberian field from BP Amoco in a questionable bankruptcy auction last month, purchasing the field at a fraction of its value. The deal between Tyumen and BP Amoco, which had been expected, could help Tyumen obtain a $500 million loan from the United States Export-Import Bank that has been blocked by the State Department. Neela Banerjee

title: Updating the Record Album
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweep, Dust: Fussy as Mom
description: I grew up with a mother who baked bread, ironed everything from sheets to jeans, vacuumed the carpet in straight lines and cleaned the entire house the night before our cleaning person came. The running joke among my friends was, ''At the Hessers' house, you do cry over spilled milk.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRUCHTER, DAVID
description: FRUCHTER-David. Happy Birthday, Dave. With all our love, Mom, Dad, Francine and Brent

title: Yanks' Irabu Experiment Ends in a Trade to Expos
description: He was the American League pitcher of the month once in each of the past two seasons, displaying the kind of dazzling pitching the Yankees anticipated when they spent months three years ago trying to secure the right to sign him. But in too many other months the enigmatic Hideki Irabu confounded the Yankees with his efforts, creating more consternation than congratulations.

title: Doctors Complain About Promise by H.M.O.
description: UnitedHealth Group, the big managed care company, was widely praised last month after it said it was eliminating tight controls over decisions by physicians, which the doctors had derided as second-guessing. United said then that doctors would no longer need advance authorization for most treatments and that the company would not refuse payment afterward.

description: To the Editor:

description: EUROPE

title: Alton A. Lindsey, 92, Dies; Ecologist Left Global Imprint
description: Alton A. Lindsey, a pioneer ecologist who was believed to be the last living scientist from the Antarctica expeditions of Adm. Richard E. Byrd, died on Sunday at his home in Tulsa, Okla. He was 92.

title: Crazy, Sexy, Cool: Virtual Beauty Makeovers
description: ISTYLE PERSONAL MAKEOVER

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BANK OF CANADA, Ottawa, named Pierre Duguay deputy governor at the central bank; he has served as an economic and monetary policy adviser since 1992.

title: Armstead and Strahan Are Voted to Pro Bowl
description: Jessie Armstead and Michael Strahan went to the Pro Bowl as a pair for the first time in 1997, and apparently, it's a Giants duo the majority of coaches, players and fans who vote for the Pro Bowl are unwilling to split up.

title: A Spat Among Audiophiles Over High-End Speaker Wire
description: IN the last year, Lewis Lipnick has tested high-end audio cables from 28 manufacturers. As a professional musician with the National Symphony Orchestra and as an audio consultant, he counts on his exacting ear to tell him if changing cables affects the accuracy of the sound from his $25,000 Krell amplifiers.

title: Grandma and the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Naya Seeks Bankruptcy After End of Coke Link
description: Naya Inc., the bottler of spring water, has filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada, in a reversal of the stellar rise that had much to do with its having once been distributed by the Coca-Cola Company's largest bottler.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Fall Nearly 1.5% on the Big Board
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange slipped 1.47 percent in the most recent monthly period, according to the exchange.

title: Browser
description: An eclectic selection of events and sites on the Web.

title: A Resurgence of Blacksmithing
description: TO understand blacksmithing's current appeal, forget about Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's village smithy under the spreading chestnut tree with his arms like iron bands. Instead, suggests Brian Gilbert, consider the lowly kitchen spatula. Everybody has one.

title: Kodak has given its Times Square billboard a face lift to keep up with the neighborhood.
description: ONE of the original extravagant signs at the crossroads of the world has undergone a face lift to keep up with its glitzy high-technology neighbors.

title: Pataki's Cigarette Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Very British Pedals
description: Nothing is quainter than a town full of bicycles with baskets attached, and few bikes are cuter than those that have been hand-built by the British in Stratford-on-Avon for more than 70 years. Pashley Cycles makes freight tricycles that are designed to transport heavy loads, vending trikes with rolling freezers and courier bikes for city errands. The low-gravity Delibike, above, is equipped with a giant wicker basket and intended for delivering food, but it could also serve to transport kittens to the veterinarian or pack a weekend's worth of clothing and a tent. It's $1,100 plus shipping from Pashley (44-178-929-2263).

title: Barkley Returns, but Glover Sets Pace With 35
description: Erick Barkley took the floor with the game less than five minutes old and the St. John's Red Storm threatening to run away with things. The question of whether his arthroscopically repaired left knee was sufficiently recovered was answered seconds later as he took the ball, executed a crossover dribble and left a Hofstra defender in his wake as he drove and passed to Bootsy Thornton for a layup.

title: Filmmaker Says U.S. Suppressed His Work
description: Last summer, as he contemplated the news media's coverage of plans for New Year's Eve, Michael Zieper, an independent filmmaker, conceived a script that would explore the themes of distrust for the government and public anxiety over the new century. What if, he wondered, the United States Army were to incite an enormous race riot at the stroke of midnight on Dec. 31, as the streets become darkened by computer-related power failures? What if it were to happen in Times Square?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBFINGER, ABRAHAM
description: HALBFINGER-Abraham. On December 20, 1999, age 99. Beloved husband of Sara for 68 years. Loving father of Martin Halbfinger, the late Phillip Halbfinger, the late Ruth Posner, and father-in-law to Lynn Halbfinger. Proud grandfather of Marla and Scott Hyndman, Felicia Posner, Bonnie & Caroline Halbfinger. Great grandfather of Melissa and Justin Hyndman. Service on Wednesday at 12:45 P.M., at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st St.

title: Butterflies And Spice, Not Sugar Plums
description: For those perverse souls suffering from ''Nutcracker'' fatigue, an antidote is at hand at the Joyce Theater, where Eliot Feld's young Ballet Tech troupe opened its two-week ''Notcracker'' season on Tuesday night. There wasn't a sugar plum or snowflake in sight.

title: 3 Shifts Are Planned in S.& P. 500 Index
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporpation said yesterday that it was revising the makeup of its stock indexes.

title: U.S. Banks Report Sharp Rise in Profit
description: United States banks earned $19.4 billion in the third quarter, a 29.1 percent increase from a year ago, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: U.S. WILL MONITOR NEW JERSEY POLICE ON RACE PROFILING
description: Citing extensive evidence that New Jersey State Police officers have discriminated against minority motorists, the Justice Department announced today that it would appoint an outside monitor to oversee the police agency and to ensure that it enacts policy changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DENISE
description: ROSS-Denise. The Congregation of The Community Synagogue of Port Washington, NY, notes with sorrow the passing of its member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family.

title: Rejoicing in a 'Messiah' of Good Taste (No Mad Scenes, Please)
description: For the critic on ''Messiah'' watch this year, growing increasingly unhinged through five presentations of Handel's masterpiece in seven days, a vengeful logic began to attach to Millennial Arts Productions' staging of the work set in the infamous lunatic asylum Bedlam in London, which had been performed earlier and harshly criticized here. Indeed, as masochistic obsession tightened its grip on a mind awash in jaunty tunes, biblical cadences and lofty sentiments, the question arose, how to fill the gaping emptiness of the other two days?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Home Products To Settle Fen-Phen Cases

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENNARD, JEROME
description: LENNARD-Jerome., December 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Emily, adoring grandfather, and father of Amy Goehner and Jeffrey. Brother of Blossom and the late Larry, son of the late Minnie and Sam. Paratrooper, journalist, jokester, tinman, gaming & travel executive. He will be remembered by all for his humor, loyalty and upbeat personality.

title: U.S. Wins Round in Trade War With Europe
description: The World Trade Organization has backed the United States in a trade battle with Europe, ruling that Washington can still use a much-contested law to take retaliatory measures against nations it deems guilty of unfair trade practices.

title: Ruth Welting, 51, a Soprano Admired for Coloratura Roles
description: Ruth Welting, a soprano who sang a wide variety of roles at the Metropolitan Opera between 1976 and 1994, died on Dec. 16 at her home in Asheville, N.C. She was 51.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ABRAHAM
description: ALLEN-Abraham. Born May 28, 1909, Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully at home in Manh., December 21. Abe was a wonderful artist and tireless supporter of just causes. He was a founder and first director of public information for Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Abe was an inexhaustible source of support, humor and strength to his family and large circle of friends. He was the beloved husband of the late Ruth Allen and companion for many years of the late Rose Kane, both of whom he heroically saw through long debilitating illnesses. He is survived by his son Philip Allen, his daughter-in-law Laura, grandson Daniel, and sister Miriam Lipton. He was loved immeasurably and will be painfully missed. Services today, 9:30AM, ''Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam.

title: Help the Venezuelans
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMMODORE HOLDINGS LTD., Hollywood, Fla., a cruise line operator, said it would buy the ship Crown Dynasty from the closely held Neptune Maritime, Helsinki, Finland, for $86.2 million.

title: Melodic Development, Strict; The Technique, Classical
description: Chico O'Farrill's 18-piece Afro-Cuban big band has been getting the watering it needs in weekly gigs at Birdland for the last two years. That regular opportunity is all-important for his music: it's complicated and leaves little to chance. Mr. O'Farrill, who conducts the band, has hung on to mostly the same core of players that he gathered upon coming out of obscurity in the mid-1990's to revive a curious career. This week, upon the release of a new album, ''Heart of a Legend'' (Milestone/Fantasy), the band is playing two sets a night through Sunday at the Iridium (44 West 63rd Street, Manhattan).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, JEANNE
description: FISHER-Jeanne. Beloved wife of Mead Hunt and adoring mother to Laura. Died with bravery and dignity at her home after a long illness. Jeanne attened Elmira College and New York School for Visual Arts & had a distinguished career as a commercial illustrator. Viewing will be Thursday, Dec. 23, 1999, from 7-9PM at the Stevenson Funeral Home, Piermont, N.Y. Services will be Friday, December 24th at Nyack Reform Church, 18 South Broadway, Nyack. Burial will follow at Rockland Cemetery in Sparkkill, New York. Memorial donations requested to Doctors Without Borders, POB 110, New York, New York 10277.

title: With Assist By Ewing, Sprewell Takes Off
description: He had not taken a shot in the fourth quarter and for all of 47 minutes stood in the background like an old sofa. Patrick Ewing was comfortable and still usable, but no longer the focal point of this plush, new living space. Vince Carter's vertical leap and Latrell Sprewell's scoring savvy were on display all evening -- vibrant, young players sprinting toward the next millennium.

title: Women's Soccer Team Won't Go to Australia
description: The women on the United States national soccer team that captured the World Cup last summer said yesterday that they would refuse to play in a tournament in Australia next month because the United States Soccer Federation will not raise their salaries.

title: Good Company For Book Lovers To Greet the New Year
description: If your idea of a perfect New Year's Eve is turning in early with a good book, you may want to acquire a new wall lamp, one that looks ready to greet the new century with you. Recent offerings from David Weeks Lighting Studio include the Shell Sconce ($210, above), which swivels 360 degrees, in black- or white-painted aluminum, and the One Arm Sconce ($380, top), with a 27-inch arm and an adjustable shade of white-painted aluminum or silver anodized aluminum. Either one would be good company on New Year's Eve, as long as the power stays on. David Weeks's lamps are designed and produced in Brooklyn. From David Weeks Lighting Studio, www.davidweekslighting.com, or at Troy, 138 Greene Street (Houston Street); (212) 941-4777.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about profits at the Goldman Sachs Group misstated the title of David Viniar. He is chief financial officer, not chief executive.

title: Wrong Call on Bell Atlantic
description: The Federal Communications Commission's approval of Bell Atlantic's application to enter the market for long-distance service in New York State looks more like a bow to political pressure than to consumer protection. The 1996 Telecommunications Act requires that for Bell Atlantic to gain permission to go after the long-distance customers of AT&T and other competitors, it must first open up its own network of wires and switches so that these competitors get a fair shot at wooing Bell Atlantic's customers for local service. Bell Atlantic comes close, but does not pass some key tests.

title: SportsLine.com Acquires Daedalus
description: Sports-Line.com Inc. said today that it bought the privately held Daedalus World Wide Corporation, the developer of SportsLine's Commissioner.Com sports fantasy products, for $31 million in cash and stock.

title: Strengthening Mr. Castro's Hand
description: Forty-one years after he came to power and a decade after the end of the cold war, Fidel Castro maintains his repressive rule over Cuba, in part with the unwitting collusion of the United States. The resolution this week of a hostage standoff with Cuban detainees in a Louisiana jail and the unresolved custody battle over 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez in Florida are examples of how an outdated American attempt to isolate Cuba and weaken Mr. Castro's regime accomplishes just the opposite.

title: Designer Cubes for the New Ice Age
description: FIRST came Sub-Zero, Thermidor, Viking, Vulcan and all those other powerful appliances with names like comic-book superheroes. Now, a new kitchen god has joined the pantheon: the stand-alone ice maker, the latest unnecessary professional-quality accessory to domestic luxury.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts section on Tuesday about the 40th anniversary of the Second City comedy troupe misstated the role of an alumnus in the film ''Ghostbusters.'' Although Harold Ramis appeared in the film, the director was Ivan Reitman.

title: Mood Swings and All, Moss Rules
description: Where Randy Moss goes, a crowd will follow. On the field, it is usually an army of defensive backs trailing him like puppies. Off the field, there may be no athlete in professional football whose every word, movement or action is dissected like those of Moss, the moody Minnesota Vikings wide receiver who is redefining his position.

title: BRUNSWICK TO SETTLE PRICING SUITS FOR $65 MILLION
description: The Brunswick Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $65 million to settle two class-action suits in which boat builders accused it of using predatory pricing to drive competitors out of business. Brunswick, based in Lake Forest, Ill., makes a variety of recreational equipment. The settlements ended the last of four related lawsuits. One resulted in a $133 million damage award in June 1998 that the company is appealing. In October, Brunswick settled the fourth suit, brought by a competitor in the marine engine business, Volvo Penta of the Americas, by agreeing to buy diesel engines from Volvo Penta. Brunswick said it would record a fourth-quarter charge of $40 million in connection with the two final settlements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ADOLPH, M.D.
description: BERGER-Adolph, M.D.. The Society of Alumni of Bellevue Hospital records with profound sorrow the death of its fellow member. Ariel Distenfeld, M.D., President Estelle Devito, M.D., Secretary

title: 'Tis the Season
description: What is it about this Christmas that is driving New York's political leaders into a frenzy of vilification? The answer is that two strong candidates for Senate are preparing for a titanic struggle with a level of bitterness already at full boil. Yesterday Mayor Rudolph Giuliani asserted that the Democrats were conspiring to get him, while Hillary Rodham Clinton declared that the mayor lacked the temperament to serve in the Senate. Specifically, Mr. Giuliani sees politics in a decision by Andrew Cuomo, secretary of Housing and Urban Development, to seize control of a federally funded homelessness program, as well as in a separate grand jury investigation into City Hall's handling of building inspections.

title: Sports of The Times; Isn't There Anyone Listening?
description: KATHY REDMOND cried when she first heard the name, and the horrible story that went with it. This was when the breath of life was still within Cherica Adams. Rae Carruth, the Carolina Panthers' wide receiver whose son Adams was carrying, was already implicated in the shooting by the authorities in Charlotte, N.C. But where were the national news media? Where was the outcry?

title: Ethnic Rivalry in Remote Bhutan Leads King to Free 200 Prisoners
description: Bhutan, a Himalayan kingdom caught in a decade-long refugee crisis that has opened the country to charges of ''ethnic cleansing,'' has released all prisoners that human rights groups regarded as political detainees, according to Bhutan's representative at the United Nations.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS SLIDES. Prices for natural gas prices fell as mild weather in large United States markets reduced heating demands. In New York, natural gas for January delivery fell 7.8 cents, to $2.444 a million B.T.U.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMBERG, LEE
description: GOMBERG-Lee. The Have A Heart Foundation sadly acknowledges the passing of our past President and esteemed board member and extends our condolences to his family. His compassion and guidance resulted in providing dignified assistance to those in need.

title: GENZYME ENDS $350 MILLION OFFER FOR CELL GENESYS
description: The Genzyme Corporation of Cambridge, Mass. terminated its $350 million takeover of Cell Genesys Inc., whose board withdrew support for the offer because it did not reflect a recent rise in an investment's value. Cell Genesys develops gene-based treatments for cancer and cardiovascular disease. It owns a 19 percent stake in Abgenix Inc., a biopharmaceutical company whose shares have almost tripled since the merger with Genzyme was announced on Oct. 18, raising the value of Cell Genesys's Abgenix holdings by about $240 million, the company said. Cell Genesys, which is based in Foster City, Calif., said on Tuesday that it had urged shareholders to reject the merger. As a result of the termination, Cell Genesys will pay a $15 million breakup fee to Genzyme.

title: 10 Years After Revolt, Little Glee in Romania
description: Iona Berbelescu wasn't going to let the young man whose life she saved 10 years ago be forgotten. But she was upset at how few other Romanians cared. There were 20 fat wreaths from political parties leaning against the stone crosses in University Square, but precious few of what she had brought -- a single red carnation.

title: 6-Year-Old Cuban to Spend Christmas in Miami as I.N.S. Interview Is Put Off
description: Elian Gonzalez, the 6-year-old Cuban refugee who was rescued from an inner tube off Florida on Thanksgiving Day, will remain in Miami at least through Christmas, immigration officials said today.

title: Gore, in Iowa, Duels an Absent Bradley
description: Vice President Al Gore stumped through central Iowa today and sparred at long distance with former Senator Bill Bradley's campaign organization over farm problems and preschool education.

title: SALE OF PUBS APPROVED
description: Britain's Office of Fair Trading approved the $:2.75 billion ($4.4 billion) sale of Allied Domecq's 3,500 bars to Punch Taverns Group Ltd., Britain's second-largest pub owner, and Bass P.L.C. Punch agreed to sell pubs in 13 licensing districts to appease regulators. Bass said last month that it would also sell less than 50 pubs to gain approval for the acquisition. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People think technology is forging way ahead of biology, ethics, and common sense. All of us think about this all the time. All of the clinicians wonder what we are doing.''

title: Caught in the Headlights? No, Bradley Was Right
description: To the Editor:

title: INFLATION SIGNAL IN GERMANY
description: German import prices rose in November by the highest amount in more than a decade, putting pressure on the European Central Bank to raise interest rates early next year. Import prices rose 1.4 percent in November, or at an annual rate of 5.9 percent. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Life Throws Morris Lapidus a Few Good Curves
description: IN the early 1990's, after his wife's death, the legendary architect Morris Lapidus found himself staring at a calendar white with blank dates. The designer of Miami Beach's Fontainebleau and Eden Roc hotels, Mr. Lapidus, then in his early 90's, had retired from active practice and was sitting alone in his ocean-front duplex, bored.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, MAY
description: LIEBERMAN-May. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Philip, Esther King, Lillian Eisman and Joyce Robbins; and devoted son-in-laws Harry King, Elliott Eisman and Kenneth Robbins. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services private.

title: INSIDE
description: Point and Counterpoint

title: U.S. Economy Kept Surging In 3rd Quarter
description: The nation's economic performance in the third quarter was its strongest in almost a year, Commerce Department figures showed today.

title: Jets' Ferguson Returns After a Four-Game Ban
description: After serving a four-game suspension for testing positive for steroids, a bitter Jason Ferguson returned to the Jets today and lashed out at the league and the union.

title: Man Arrested In Bomb Threat To City Tunnels
description: The authorities posted police officers and bomb-sniffing dogs at several tunnels leading into New York City yesterday morning after a New Jersey man posted a threatening message on the Internet saying that a van filled with explosives would be left in a tunnel leading into the city, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIZER, STELLA Y.
description: PIZER-Stella Y.., 83, of Great Neck, NY, on November 26, 1999. She was engaged in actualizing her life as a productive, useful person. She is survived by her daughter and son (his wife), her sister, and grandchildren. Memorial Service to be announced.

title: New Yule Log Tradition Glows With Eerie Light
description: Back in the electronic Dark Ages -- say, a decade ago or so -- many an apartment-dwelling New Yorker celebrated Christmas by getting friends and family together, setting them up with mugs of holiday cheer, and gathering around the television set. On the screen, broadcast by WPIX, a local station, was a continuous-loop tape of a yule log burning in a fireplace, accompanied by holiday music.

title: A Cadre of Familiar Foreign Policy Experts Is Putting Its Imprint on Bush
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is counting on a small group of conservative experts steeped in the intricacies of arms control, military budgets and geopolitical security to counsel him on a subject that has caused him the most trouble in his presidential campaign: foreign affairs.

title: Bye Bye Birdie, For a While, Anyway
description: ''Birds are very smart animals,'' said John Gellerstedt, the president of operations at Nixalite of America, the bird-control company that has been keeping birds from loitering on buildings for 50 years. Fake owls, he said, ''work for a day or two, but eventually the birds catch on and sit on top.'' For permanent deterrence, the company recommends Nixalite strips, prickly stainless steel. But for temporary dispersal, they offer the Tanglefoot Tangle Guard Repeller Ribbon, a holographic foil strip (above) that is almost accidentally decorative. Hung from trees or festooned around a garden, the ribbon's tinny sound and reflected flashes annoy birds instead of intimidating them. Available from Nixalite for $7.98 for a 25-foot roll (800 624-1189), it wouldn't look out of place on a Christmas tree.

title: California Man Charged In Airline Bomb Threat
description: A 30-year-old California man was charged yesterday with making terroristic threats on a Continental Airlines flight Tuesday night after arguing with crew members and suggesting that a bomb might be in his luggage.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar dropped against the Japanese yen on expectations that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates in the near future. In New York, the dollar settled at 101.70 yen, down from 102.18.

title: Microsoft Unveils Tax Product But Bill Gates Can't Use It
description: What do you give a man with everything? Why, tax software, of course. Microsoft's TaxSaver software started arriving in stores this week, joining a crowded tax software market dominated by Intuit's TurboTax product line. Microsoft joined with the accounting giant Arthur Andersen to produce the package.

title: U.N. Panel Agrees On Two-Year Budget
description: A General Assembly committee reached agreement today on a two-year budget for the organization that American diplomats hope will fall within the ''nominal no-growth'' spending demanded by the United States Congress in return for releasing money to pay overdue American debts.

title: Board Reportedly Moving Toward Vote Against Crew
description: As the Board of Education prepared to meet today to decide the fate of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, a high-ranking board official said last night that a majority of the seven board members were leaning toward ending Dr. Crew's tenure as chancellor.

title: Artists Are Evicted From Apartments They Built in a Vacant Factory
description: A decade ago, a small band of poor but hardy artists moved into a vast, vacant factory on Bedford Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. With their own hands, they transformed the space into a warren of crudely built communal apartments and art studios.

title: Russia's Democratic Test
description: To the Editor:

title: The Blame in Rwanda
description: To the Editor:

title: BAXTER IN $130 MILLION DEAL TO BUY SWEDISH DIALYSIS UNIT
description: Baxter International, a maker of medical devices based in Deerfield, Ill., agreed to buy the unprofitable dialysis equipment maker Althin Medical A.B. of Sweden for about $130 million in cash, stock and debt to expand in the $7 billion renal care market. Baxter said it had exchanged an unspecified number of its own shares for those of Althin's chairman, Anders Althin, and his family, and would offer 100 kronor a share for the rest -- a 47 percent premium to the stock's closing price on Monday. Althin's debt is about $50 million, according to Baxter. Shares of Baxter gained $1.25, to $60.6875.

title: New Jersey Court's 1st Woman Justice Retiring
description: Associate Justice Marie L. Garibaldi, who in 1982 became the first woman appointed to the New Jersey Supreme Court, announced her retirement today to a blizzard of praise from politicians, professors and members of the New Jersey bar. Her retirement is effective on Feb. 1, nearly a month after the court begins its next term.

title: 4-Year-Old Is Killed In Brooklyn Fire
description: A four-year-old boy died and a pregnant woman was seriously injured last night when fire swept through two stories of a brownstone apartment building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, officials said. The woman gave birth to a healthy girl within minutes of arriving at the hospital.

title: The Year 2000 Bug: Check That Desktop
description: There is still time for home computer owners who have somehow missed Y2K mania, or who have decided to wait until all their last-minute shopping is done before they check their desktops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESLIE, STEPHEN H.
description: LESLIE-Stephen H.., M.D. The Society of Alumni of Bellevue Hospital records with profound sorrow the death of its fellow member. Ariel Distenfeld, M.D., President Estelle Devito, M.D., Secretary

title: Web Sites Bloom in China, and Are Weeded
description: On a recent evening, Zhang Aijing sat at her terminal at the Internet division of People's Daily, watching comments drop from cyberspace into the Communist Party newspaper's chat room.

title: For Baby Sitters Around Nation, New Year's Eve Is Best of Times
description: On New Year's Eve, many of the 1,000-some couples attending the Memphis Junior League's charity ball at the Peabody Hotel will take their children along. So the parents can be free to cavort, they have corralled 40 baby sitters from the Annie's Nannies agency. Each sitter will be paid $330 for the 11-hour affair, triple the agency's usual rate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAL, WILLIAM G.
description: KRAL-William G.., 53, of Eagle Lake in the town of Ticonderoga, NY, died unexpectedly December 20, 1999. Mr. Kral was born in the Bronx, New York on October 16, 1946. He was a veteran, had his J.D. doctorate in law, and was a founding partner in the New York law firm of Kral, Clerkin, Redmond, Ryan, Perry & Girvan. Survived by his wife, Mary (Shuman) Kral; mother Eleanor Kral of San Diego, CA; 3 daughters, Marianne, Elizabeth and Emily Kral; and a brother Richard. Funeral Mass, Thursday 11 A.M., at St. Mary's Church, Ticonderoga, NY.

title: Elias Scores Twice; Devils Win by One
description: The Devils and the Flyers, the strongest teams in the Atlantic Division as the season nears its midway point, met for the third time tonight and the Devils got the upper hand with a 3-2 victory.

description: To the Editor:

title: $20 Million in Pay Deferrals Prevents Union Layoffs in Nassau
description: After a tense bargaining session that lasted through the night, Nassau County's unions averted 500 threatened layoffs today by reluctantly agreeing to make $20 million worth of concessions to help the fiscally challenged county close its persistent budget gap.

title: Virtual Data Storage, Complete With Ads
description: Personal computer users who want to clean their desk of scattered storage disks, and Macintosh owners whose computers don't have disk drives, can get 300 megabytes of storage space online. The service is free to people who sign up at FreeDiskSpace.com (www.freediskspace.com), that is, free to users who agree to view advertisements and receive promotional offers.

title: Snowboarders Backed by Nike In Campaign to Open Slopes
description: Grass roots campaigns just aren't what they used to be.

title: Mozambique Says President Is Re-elected; Rivals Protest
description: President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique was declared the victor today, after three days of voting this month, touching off cries of protest from opposition leaders who said the balloting was rigged.

title: Retired Agent Is Accused Of Conspiring With Mobsters
description: A federal grand jury here indicted a retired F.B.I. agent today on charges that he conspired in crimes with two reputed mob leaders who had been longtime F.B.I. informers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, SYLVIA B.
description: FINKEL-Sylvia B.., 81, died Dec. 19, 1999. She is survived by her sons and their wives Paul and Eileen Finkel & Lewis and Andrea Finkel, sister Frances Chubinsky, brother Irving Brill & grandchildren Michael, Diana and Lauren.

title: Troublesome Attachments
description: Q. I often get attachments with an ''.exe'' file extension sent to me by e-mail, and I can never get them to open. Is this a problem with my Macintosh, or does this type of file get easily corrupted?
