title: The End Is Near. Reboot.
description: FOR many personal computer users, Y2K preparedness has meant getting a date or finding a baby sitter and having sufficient Champagne and MP3 party tunes on hand for New Year's Eve. The digital event of the century is less than 10 days away, and perhaps you are not quite certain whether you or your PC is going to have the bigger hangover on Jan. 1. If so, here are some last-minute tips.

title: Wounded Sri Lankan Sees 'Gift of Gods' in Re-election
description: Gulping back tears, a white bandage on her right eye from a bomb attack four days ago, Sri Lanka's president claimed a divine mandate today to pursue and defeat the rebels who had tried to kill her.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHN, HARRY (AARON)
description: COHN-Harry (Aaron). Dear Daddy, happy 80th birthday in heaven. We hope you play some great golf and have Chinese food for dinner. Five birthdays have passed already and it doesn't get any easier without you. We love and miss you. Diane and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANLEY, JOHN
description: SHANLEY-John. Died peacefully on December 14. Born June 17, 1914 in New York, he was the son of the late John Shanley and the late Mary Burke Shanley. A 1937 graduate of St. John's, he was the captain of the 1936/37 St. John's basketball team. During World War II he served in the Army Counter Intelligence Corps. In 1944 he was assigned to the Manhattan Project. He returned to the New York City Police Department in 1947. Over the course of twenty years, he served in all branches and ranks, and was appointed as Chief Inspector of the NYPD in June of 1965. He retired to Boca Raton, Florida in 1970. He was predeceased by his wife Anna O'Brien Shanley in 1965 and his wife, Ethel Muffatti Shanley in 1991. He is survived by his devoted brother Frank Shanley of Brooklyn, his brother Bob Shanley of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, his son, John Shanley of Dallas, Texas, daughters Peg Hickey of Stamford, Connecticut, & Dr. Catherine Shanley of White Plains, New York, 7 grandchildren and one great grandchild. There will be a memorial mass at St. Patrick's Church, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn at 11 AM Tuesday, December 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOXER, ENID
description: BOXER-Enid. We mourn Enid's passing, who together with her late husband, Harold, were the lay force driving the creation of our NCSY, National Conference of Synagogue Youth. May we find consolaton in the legacy they left behind. Mandell I. Ganchrow, M.D., Pres. Orthodox Union Rabbi Pinchas Stolper Founding Director, NCSY Rabbi David Kaminetsky National Director, NCSY

title: Barak, in a First for Top Israeli, Meets Arafat in the West Bank
description: Despite speculation that the resumption of Israeli-Syrian talks would derail the Palestinian peace track, an intimate meeting here overnight between Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat apparently made significant progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MILDRED (MILLY)
description: KLEIN-Mildred (Milly). An exceptional woman who lived for others. She will be sorely missed. Her friends and co-workers at Honest Ballot Jay and Murray Schwartz Maralin Falik

title: The Scoop on Local Business
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Space Travel in a Loft
description: CLIENTS willing to indulge the futuristic whims of architects are notoriously rare. But Winka Dubbeldam, a Dutch-born architect based in Manhattan, seems to have a knack for attracting patrons susceptible to her visual poetry and her sculptor's passion for combining natural materials to achieve novel effects. Among her fans, the famously demanding architect Peter Eisenman called her ''a very talented, highly energetic and motivated person.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Mannesmann-Vodafone fight takes on a decidedly American tone.
description: THE battleground for the struggle between Mannesmann A.G., the German telecommunications conglomerate, and its unwanted suitor, Vodafone AirTouch of Britain, may be in Europe, but it has all the trappings of a Wall Street scuffle, complete with Wall Street investment bankers and tactics.

title: Algerian Is Indicted; Warning by Clinton
description: A 32-year-old Algerian man pleaded not guilty to five counts in a federal indictment stemming from his arrest last week near Seattle after customs agents said they found a cache of bomb-making components in his rental car, moments after he drove off a ferry from Canada.

title: Weis Markets to Consider a Sale, Pleasing Dissident Shareholders
description: The two groups of cousins who jointly control Weis Markets agreed yesterday to explore all options for enhancing shareholder value, including selling the 164-store chain of supermarkets, ending the threat of a proxy fight by one faction.

title: President Adds His Voice to Warnings About Terrorism
description: President Clinton warned Americans today to be watchful about terrorism during the coming holidays, as other senior administration officials also urged caution but said there was no specific information that any extremist group had planned an attack in the United States.

title: Ex-Officer's Testimony Sought in Louima Case
description: Federal prosecutors in the Abner Louima case said in a letter yesterday that they planned to seek testimony from a former police officer who they say was approached by a defendant in the case for help in preparing a false account of the attack in a Brooklyn station house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, BARBARA
description: FRIEDMAN-Barbara, died on Tuesday at the age of 69 at her home. Loving wife of Arnold. Devoted mother of Stuart, Bruce and Jeffrey Friedman, and grandmother of Jenna, Nicholas, Stacie and Hannah. Donations can be made to the American Leukemia Society.

title: Harold Eugene Berson, Neuropsychiatrist
description: Dr. Harold Eugene Berson, a prominent neuropsychiatrist associated with Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn for more than 40 years, died on Dec. 14 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 and had homes in Stuart, Fla., and Manhattan.

title: How to Make a Museum More Fun to Visit; A Director Does What He Was Hired To, and the Criticism Won't Let Up
description: On a speedy tour of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, where he has been director for five years, Malcolm Rogers stopped in the high-ceilinged corridor that was once a tapestry gallery and is now the entryway to the museum's collection of European paintings. Fifty-four paintings from the 16th and 17th centuries, including works by Titian, El Greco, Velazquez and Rubens, are mounted two and three high. It is a commanding medley, a brazen array of artistic riches that tends to make visitors halt in their tracks.

title: An Upstate Utility Gets a Deal on Two Nuclear Reactors
description: A utility in upstate New York said today it was buying the controlling share of two nuclear reactors, including the state's biggest, most expensive reactor, at a small fraction of what they cost to build, and would turn the reactors over to an outside group to operate.

title: Grand Jury Charges Man Found With Bomb Materials
description: Ahmed Ressam, the 32-year-old Algerian arrested last week when customs agents discovered what they said was a cache of bomb-making components in his rental car moments after he drove off a ferry from Canada, was indicted by a federal grand jury today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDERMAN, HILDA
description: SCHINDERMAN-Hilda. Of Teaneck, NJ. On December 22. Beloved wife of the late William; devoted mother of Marc; sister of Aaron Zicherman; loving grandmother of Alan and Warren; and great-grandmother of Connor and Danielle. Services Thursday. ''Gutterman Musicant'', 1-800-378-1892. Contributions to City of Hope would be appreciated.

title: Alarmism Abets the Terrorists
description: The guiding tenet of terrorism is to do a lot with a little. From the Assassins in the Middle Ages to Osama bin Laden, terrorists have aimed at targets that will help magnify their real strength. Killing a sultan or bombing an embassy is an ideal way to gain attention and spread fear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDEL, SANDRA (NEE WASSERMAN)
description: HANDEL-Sandra (nee Wasserman). December 22, 1999. Beloved wife and best friend of Seymour, devoted mother of Rebecca and Matthew, dear mother-in-law of Andrew and Amy, adoring grandmother of Arianna, Molly and Josselyn, beloved sister of the late Phyllis Kaminer. Loyal friend, dedicated librarian, educator, and lover of literature. Her heart of gold touched the lives of many and she will live on in our hearts forever. In place of flowers, donations can be made to the home of Sages of Israel in New York City. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hacksensack, New Jersey, Thursday at noon. For information, 1-800-322-0533.

title: Treasuries Finish Mixed After Auction
description: Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the government's auction of $15 million of two-year notes weighed on the bond market.

description: Several dot-com companies have named agencies.

title: Utility Sells Australia Unit
description: The TXU Corporation, the owner of Texas's largest utility, agreed to sell Enetech, its Australian engineering and maintenance unit, to the closely held Tenix Group for $36 million. Tenix is a Melbourne-based military and technology contractor. Enetech will remain under contract to provide engineering and maintenance for TXU's natural gas and electricity networks in the state of Victoria. TXU, based in Dallas, has nine million customers in Texas, Britain and Australia.

title: Israel to Import Natural Gas From Egypt
description: Egypt will provide natural gas to Israel through a long-delayed ''peace pipeline'' across the Sinai Desert, the prime minister's office said tonight. The deal will radically change Israel's energy policy and its economic relationship with its most powerful neighbor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIND, JOHN K.
description: LIND-John K.. (December 23, 1998). Love never dies, you are always with me. But oh, how I miss your voice. Deena

title: Death Stirs Up Opposition Of Japanese To Atom Use
description: The death late Tuesday of a worker exposed to radiation in Japan's worst nuclear accident brought renewed calls today for curbs on the country's atomic energy program.

title: Corel Expects Quarterly Loss As Software Sales Fall Short
description: Shares of the Corel Corporation, the maker of WordPerfect software, fell 29 percent today after the company forecast an unexpected fourth-quarter loss, blaming lower sales of its software and higher-than-expected operating costs.

title: Metro Matters; In Diallo Trial, Best Option Is Albany
description: EVEN many of those who agree with the decision to move the Diallo trial out of the Bronx lambaste the judges who did the deed for transferring it to Albany.

title: Attacker Mistook Boy, 12, for His Older Brother, Police Say
description: Moments after 12-year-old Arsalan Malik's skull was fractured by three swift blows to his head, Ahmed Nezamuddin bragged that he had succeeded in retaliating against the man who had harassed his girlfriend, according to a complaint filed yesterday against Mr. Nezamuddin in Queens Criminal Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINITZ, RUDOLPH
description: REINITZ-Rudolph. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of its esteemed Member. We extend deepest sympathy to his children, Naomi, Joshua, Sima, and to the entire family. Alfredo F. Borodowski, Rabbi George Sommerfeld, President Charles Rosenzweig, Chairman

title: Microsoft's Finance Chief Resigns Post
description: Microsoft's chief financial officer, Gregory Maffei, resigned yesterday to join a Canadian builder of high-speed telecommunications networks, becoming the latest Microsoft executive to depart for entrepreneurial opportunities elsewhere.

title: Of Trials and Race
description: To the Editor:

title: THAI PHONE CONCERN SELLS STAKE
description: Thailand's largest fixed-line telephone operator, TelecomAsia P.C.L. said it would sell a 24 percent stake to a German bank, Kreditanstalt fur Wiederaufbau, for $150 million as part of a deal to restructure 61.79 billion baht ($1.63 billion) in debt. The bank holds about a quarter of TelecomAsia's outstanding loans, on which the Thai company stopped paying the principal in May 1998. The deal cuts the stake held by the Bell Atlantic Corporation to 13.8 percent. Wayne Arnold

title: BRITISH INTEREST RATES
description: Minutes from the Bank of England's meeting on Dec. 9, when interest rates were held at 5.5 percent, revealed that the monetary policy committee might increase rates early next year, analysts said. The committee voted 6 to 3 to hold rates steady in December. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, JOHN L., M.D.
description: SIMON-John L., M.D.., J.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife Myrtle Simon and family. Avi Barbasch, M.D., President Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Ross Roy Changing Its Name and Focus
description: Ross Roy Communications in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., is changing its name, relocating and refocusing its business strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, JOHN C.
description: CARR-John C.. Age 70. Educator and arts advocate died Sunday, December 19, of a heart attack. Dr. Carr was Professor Emeritus at the University of Maryland, where he had been a Professor in the Department of Education. From 1965 until 1994, he was Adjunct Professor in the Drama Department at The Catholic University of America. In his role as arts advocate, he had a longstanding association with The Kennedy Center where he co-designed two programs that have become models for the country: The Kennedy Center Partners in Education Program and the Artists as Educators Seminar. He was also co-director of a pilot program for the development of national guidelines for performance guides for students and teachers. Dr. Carr was co-author and co-editor of five books, including Modern Methods in Secondary Education. He was a columnist for the Los Angeles Drama-Logue and a theater columnist for the Annapolis Capital newspaper. A memorial service will be scheduled for later this winter at The Kennedy Center. For more information call 202-416-8255

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Monday about Ernest Freycinet, a restaurant worker who died Saturday after inhaling toxic fumes, referred incorrectly to a woman interviewed about the worker's life. The woman, who identified herself during the interview as Ivy Freycinet, said by telephone after the article appeared that she was not married to Mr. Freycinet but lived with him.

title: When a Broker Becomes an Investor
description: BARBARA CORCORAN, who runs the Corcoran Group, one of the biggest and most visible real estate companies in New York City, has agreed to help finance a new condominium development in Chelsea. She and a colleague have taken a 3 percent share in a new 12-story building planned for the old Barneys parking lot at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 17th Street.

title: Jenne-Jeno Journal; Mali's Present Is Poor. Can It Build Future on Past?
description: Standing at the bottom of a 10-foot-deep pit, in a field where the only other activity came from a nomadic herdsman urging his cows to munch on yellowing shrub, the American archaeologist and his African students were surrounded by tantalizing clues to life here in the oldest African city south of the Sahara.

title: Metro Business; Frankel Aide Admits Guilt
description: A former office assistant to Martin R. Frankel, the Connecticut money manager who was indicted in October on charges of stealing more than $200 million from several southern insurance companies, admitted in court yesterday that she concealed money laundering by her boss and others, federal prosecutors said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Broad Rally Pushes Stocks To New Highs
description: A year-end buying spree drove the three main stock gauges to new peaks yesterday, with the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index surging briefly above the 4,000 mark before falling back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INWALD, CHESTER
description: INWALD-Chester. Beloved husband of the late Doris. Loving father of Sarah Herzl Kadesh, Eliza and David Rosen and Jacob & Lynne Inwald. Adored grandfather of Ben, Adam, Mital and Liad Kadesh, Jesse, Daniel, Ezra and Doris Emily Rosen, Jethro and Charles Inwald. Dear brother of Martin, Samson and Frieda. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 10 A.M. Friday.

title: MEXICO AIRLINE TROUBLES
description: Aviation authorities who investigated Taesa found 69 deficiencies in the airline's administrative, maintenance and financial practices and labeled correction of 43 as ''indispensable conditions'' for a resumption of flights, suspended since Nov. 23. Authorities ordered 6 aging planes retired from the 26-aircraft fleet. A Taesa spokesman characterized the findings as clearance to resume operations eventually, but acknowledged that satisfying the government's financial requirements might be difficult. Sam Dillon

title: Dr. Edward H. Reisner Jr., 84, Cancer Specialist
description: Dr. Edward Hartman Reisner Jr., a cancer specialist known for his work with vitamin B12, died Dec. 16 at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. A longtime resident of Tenafly, N.J., he was 84 and lived in a retirement community in Allendale, N.J.

title: SNYDER HIRES INVESTMENT BANK TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: Snyder Communications Inc., the world's largest direct marketer, said yesterday that it had hired the investment bank Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown to explore strategic alternatives, including the possible sale of the company. The company's shares rose $3.1875 yesterday, to $19, and are up about 48 percent this week. Snyder Communications provides customer relationship management, sales support and public relations services. It had 1998 revenue of $815.3 million. Snyder's chairman and chief executive, Daniel M. Snyder, bought the Washington Redskins football team for $800 million in July. In recent months, Snyder spun off its health care marketing company, Ventiv Health Inc., and issued tracking shares for its interactive agency, Circle.com.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Rock
description: * YO LA TENGO: Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-0406. Yo La Tengo's songwriters, the husband-and-wife team of Ira Kaplan on guitar and Georgia Hubley on drums, prize succinct, tuneful songs about the modest pains and pleasures of daily life and love. From those songs, however, a welter of fuzz-tone and feedback can erupt at any time, like a psychedelic disruption of quotidian reality. For New Year's Eve in its hometown, Yo La Tengo will have guest performers sitting in. Music begins at 10 p.m.; admission is $30. JON PARELES

description: In percent

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.

title: Indictment Doesn't Stop Flow of Medicaid Money
description: The State Health Department will allow two adult day-care centers in Brooklyn to continue operating, with little of their Medicaid payments withheld, even though their owner was indicted last week on charges of illegally billing the state Medicaid program for $62 million in invented or inflated services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSS, DONALD
description: GOSS-Donald. Died December 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Anita, loving father of Sue, Gus and Nina Michelson. He was an accountant and retired Petty Officer 2nd Class, U.S. Coast Guard. He will be deeply missed.

title: Portrayal Of Injury Displeases Hamilton
description: Even to some Giants teammates, cornerback Conrad Hamilton's knee injury was mystifying. A clicking noise in his knee in training camp developed into a painfully debilitating injury, one the team's doctors could not diagnose or treat.

title: Suit Contends Mental Care For Children Is Inadequate
description: The Legal Aid Society has filed a class action lawsuit accusing New York State's mental health system of letting hundreds of severely mentally ill children languish in hospitals, juvenile jails and foster care homes instead of providing them with a place in community-based mental health centers.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Friday with an article about the Israel-Syria peace talks and a corrected version yesterday with an article about Prime Minister Ehud Barak's meeting with Yasir Arafat referred incompletely to the chronology of changes in the effective border between Israel and Syria. A corrected map appears today on Page A3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ADOLPH R.
description: BERGER-Adolph R.., MD. Died on December 17, 1999 at age 89. The devoted husband of his beloved late wife, Margaret Lielman Berger. Dr. Berger was a graduate of NYU School of Medicine and an Attending Physician and Professor of Clinical Medicine at Bellevue and Tisch Hospitals for more than 50 years. He trained many physicians, imparting to them the high standards he demanded of himself. To the end he maintained a great interest in the relationship between physicians and their patients. He will be missed by his former colleagues and his friends, but they are comforted by the knowledge that his final wish, to join his beloved Margaret, has been fulfilled.

title: Private Schools: Who Is Included?
description: To the Editor:

title: Crystal Corridor in the City of Glass
description: SEASON'S greetings! Time to tickle another sacred cow.

title: SOVEREIGN ISLANDS/A special report.; For Cruise Ships' Workers, Much Toil, Little Protection
description: The kitchen on a cruise ship starts bustling for breakfast before 6 a.m., and some days the workers do not stop peeling, cooking and washing until after the midnight buffet. For laboring as long as 18 hours a day, seven days a week, most galley workers are paid $400 to $450 a month.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Rock
description: DEEP BANANA BLACKOUT: Wetlands Preserve, 161 Hudson Street, at Laight Street, TriBeCa, (212) 966-4225. For this big night, the team that runs Wetlands could have highlighted any number of musical styles that pass through the club, from Grateful Dead homages to neo-bluegrass, techno-tinged progressive rock or earthy hip-hop. But who could blame them for choosing a band that adheres to the fundamentals of body-shaking funk? Deep Banana Blackout is one of the Northeast's favorite party bands, so the vibrations in the room should be excellent. With Electric Hill; 9 p.m., admission is $60. ANN POWERS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Bruce Teitelbaum, an adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani who has been under scrutiny for his role in dealing with Hasidic builders in Brooklyn, misstated an account from Brooklyn prosecutors about their interviewing of Anthony V. Carbonetti, Mr. Giuliani's chief of staff. According to prosecutors, Mr. Carbonetti spoke with investigators once in person and later by telephone. But they say the telephone conversation was initiated by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, not by Mr. Carbonetti.

title: College By the Numbers
description: When I was provost of the University of Michigan, the medical school had a student prize for medical diagnosis: the S.S.W. Award. The initials stood for ''swift, sure and wrong.'' I am reminded of it when I hear reports celebrating Texas's ''10 percent solution'' -- its experiment in maintaining diversity in its public universities by guaranteeing admission for every student graduating in the top 10 percent of any high school in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, IRWIN H.
description: KRAMER-Irwin H.. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and President. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Board of Governors and Members

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERARD, LOIS K.
description: GERARD-Lois K.. 12/24/98. Dear Mommy, one year later, we're still numb from the shock of your suffering and leaving us. We miss you every day and try to focus on your love of life and laughter. Love always, Daniele and Gregory

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ABRAHAM
description: ALLEN-Abraham. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our first director of public information and a member of our Society of Founders. We will always be grateful to Abe for the crucial role he played in the development of our institution. To his son, Philip, and his entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Plans Hastened for the Start Of Trading in Nasdaq Japan
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is speeding up its plans for an electronic stock market in Japan that will promote cross-trading of United States and Japanese stocks.

title: The Trails Of Klezmer, Always Evolving
description: Klezmer follows two very different tangents in the music of Matt Darriau's Paradox Trio, a quartet, and Marty Ehrlich's Dark Woods, a trio. They opened the fourth annual Jewsapalooza Festival at the Knitting Factory (72 Leonard Street in TriBeCa) on Monday night. The festival, which runs through Sunday, has marked and encouraged the latest variants of klezmer, the music of itinerant Jewish musicians that immigrants carried from Eastern Europe to the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, MELVIN
description: KURTZ-Melvin., 74, of Monroe Township, formerly of Brooklyn, died December 23, 1999. Husband of Philetta Lobo. Father of Alan Kurtz, Donnie Kurtz and Gail Freiberg. Brother of Selma Freedman. Grandfather of six. Funeral at 9:15 AM Sunday at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Burial at Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ.

title: Christmas, Just Like The Ones I Never Knew
description: There has never been any doubt that in the spectral trinity Dickens created to preside over the Yule holiday, the Ghost of Christmas Past reigns as first among equals -- the prime mover of mood and spirit. Christmas might, in fact, be characterized as a holiday in continual, necessary decline, a celebration whose emotional center is our insistence upon the superiority of Christmases gone by. White Christmases are, by definition, the ones you used to know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, CHRISTOPHER
description: HENRY-Christopher. Dear son of the late William and Catherine and brother of the late William. A lawyer, author, and member of the Brehon Law Society. An individual always. Visiting Sunday, December 26th, 2PM to 9PM at HorneDannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23 Street, New York City.

title: Even Crew's Critics Long for Continuity
description: With opinions of Rudy Crew's tenure as schools chancellor running the gamut, one common thread emerged yesterday from the reaction to his departure: Here we go again.

title: A Weimar-Era Antihero, Crushed by Naivete and Impersonal Forces
description: REBELLION

title: BOARD OUSTS SCHOOLS CHIEF, SAYING CREW LOST HIS FOCUS; MAYOR'S ROLE BECOMES ISSUE
description: After weeks of complaining that Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew had lost his focus and slipped into deep ambivalence about his job, the New York City Board of Education voted 4-to-3 yesterday not to renew Dr. Crew's contract when it expires in June.

title: Van Gundy Sees the Good, But Knows the Bad Lurks
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy has seen too many big leads squandered to feel blissful. Being an eternal worrier, he still sees too many things that can go wrong with his team to dream of what is so right about the Knicks.

title: U.S. Reports a Link To Algeria Terrorism
description: Federal authorities said they had linked a couple who were arrested at a Vermont border crossing with a fake passport to a man associated with Algerian terrorists. But they did not specify what, if anything, they think the couple's plans were. In particular, they did not cite any connection with Ahmed Ressam, who was stopped as he tried to enter Washington State in a car with what officials said were bomb materials.

title: An Instant Ad on a Plan to Lower Taxes
description: On Tuesday, the Bush campaign began running the first of what it calls ''crash ads,'' swiftly assembled commercials designed to be broadcast within a day of filming. This 30-second spot was recorded on Monday in a speech by Gov. George W. Bush at Manchester West High School in Manchester, N.H.

title: Christmas
description: The holiday, actually Dec. 25, is legally observed today.

title: Treasuries Fall on Worries About the Fed
description: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, rounding out a second week of losses that pushed yields to 27- month highs on expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in February.

title: It's a Sort of Family Dinner, Your Majesty
description: A director seeking a path into Shakespeare's goriest play, ''Titus Andronicus,'' basically has two choices. One is to keep a safe distance from a repellent story that many regard as one of Shakespeare's lesser efforts by treating it as a slice of stylized Grand Guignol and staging its chain of murders and mutilations as the blackest of comedies. The other, riskier way, which the director Julie Taymor has adopted in her shattering screen adaptation, renamed simply ''Titus,'' is to shoot the moon and take the play extremely seriously. In peering into the raging hearts of characters hellbent on destroying one another and inflicting maximum pain and humiliation, Ms. Taymor discovers many unsettling contemporary resonances.

title: Old Home Movie Captures the Shot The Babe 'Called'

title: In Search of a New Chancellor
description: The New York City Board of Education's decision not to extend Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's contract beyond its expiration next June was almost inevitable, given the persistent friction between Dr. Crew and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the chancellor's failure to say definitively whether he wished to serve an additional term. To avoid a lame-duck period during which little would get done, the board needs to buy out the remainder of Dr. Crew's contract and install an able interim chancellor as swiftly as possible. Steady leadership in the coming months will be crucial if the system is to move forward with reforms that were begun on Dr. Crew's watch but have yet to reach fruition.

title: Public Interests; Where Were You In 1002?
description: Maybe a millennium is too big a thought. There's a lot of resistance to this celebration. If we were just turning over a century, people might have found it easier to wrap their minds around the whole concept. Or they could be afraid that if they engage in a conversation about the last 1,000 years, somebody will ask for their opinion of the Song dynasty or the St. Bryce's Day massacre. And of course we're being deflected by critics who complain that the real turn of the millennium won't happen until Jan. 1, 2001. (Note to the 2001 purists: It doesn't matter. The whole thing is arbitrary, and we're in it for the zeroes.)

title: KOREAN AIR SANCTIONS
description: After Thursday's crash of a Korean Air cargo plane in England, the South Korean government said it would extend punitive sanctions against the airline by six more months. Last month, United States investigators cited Korean Air pilots as playing crucial roles in a 1997 jet crash in Guam that caused 228 deaths. The Seoul government banned the airline from adding international routes and flights for one year. The Korean Air cargo plane went down after taking off from Stansted Airport outside London on its way to Milan. Korean Air, the world's 13th-largest airline, has had a string of disasters, resulting in 750 deaths, in the last 16 years. Samuel Len

title: Mae West's First Play (for the Stage, That Is)
description: If it helps a writer to know a lot about her subject, Mae West brought great authority to her first play, ''Sex,'' written and first produced in New York in 1926. The writing is not as accomplished as it is in some of her later film scripts, but there are enough characteristic West lines to let you know who the author was, and it was good enough to get her tossed into jail in 1927 as the creator and star of an indecent public performance. As a publicity stunt the trial was perfect; from then on she was a star whatever she did.

title: INVESTMENT BANK IS SUING SPRINT OVER MISSED PAYMENT
description: The Sprint Corporation is being sued by the investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson for $54 million because the company failed to make a scheduled payment on a debt, according to court papers. Sprint missed a $7.6 million payment in June, according to the lawsuit, which was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Dresdner, a division of Dresdner Bank of Germany, says the missed payment gives it the right to demand the full $54 million debt immediately. A spokesman for Sprint declined to comment. According to the suit, Sprint agreed in May to buy $90 million of software, support and education services from the Oracle Corporation. The purchase agreement gave Oracle the right to assign the debt to a third party, the suit says, and Oracle assigned $58 million of the debt to Dresdner in June.

title: GERMAN BROADCASTER SALE
description: CLT-UFA, Europe's biggest television broadcaster, agreed to buy the News Corporation's 49.9 percent stake in the German channel Vox for 650 million marks ($338 million) to gain control of the channel. The purchase will give 74.8 percent of Vox to CLT-UFA, which is owned by Bertelsmann of Germany and Audiofina of Belgium. Canal Plus of France owns 24.9 percent. The Luxembourg-based CLT-UFA already owns RTL, Germany's most-watched commercial TV station, and has stakes in other free over-air broadcasters like Channel 5 of Britain. In contrast, the News Corporation has focused its European investments on pay TV, with stakes in Britain's Sky Broadcasting Group and Italy's Stream.

title: ORBITAL SCIENCES SELLS 33% STAKE IN ROBOTICS BUSINESS

Shares of the company, which makes small satellites, rose $3, or 23 percent, to $15.9375. Its stock is down 64 percent this year. The company said a group of Canadian investors, led by CAI Capital Partners, bought a 33 percent stake in its MacDonald Dettwiler & Associates robotics unit. Also yesterday, Orbital, based in Dulles, Va., announced that it had received a $35 million contract to launch two satellites for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONIN, STANLEY MICHAEL
description: ARONIN-Stanley Michael. A long time resident of Pelham, died Thursday, December 23, 1999 at Sound Shore Medical Center. Born Feb. 16, 1918, he was the beloved husband of Anne, nee Metzger, beloved father of Michael, Patricia Sherrill, Nancy Fanelli, and Kevin. He also leaves behind 11 grandchildren. Beloved father-in-law of William Sherrill, Harry Fanelli, and Anne Stevens-Aronin. Brother of Howard Aronin of Daytona Beach, FL and Paul Aronin of Atlanta, GA. He graduated from New York University. He was a prolific civil engineer who built renowned projects as far away as Guantanamo Bay, Cuba to the foundation of the World Trade Center in New York, and many of our local highways and bridges. As proud as he was of his career endeavors, he was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather. He was dedicated to charitable church and civic organizations. He was a member of the Knights of Malta, a fourth degree Grand Knight and state deputy of the Knights of Columbus, past president of the Holy Name Society of St. Catharine's Church, past chairman of the Pelham Zoning Board of Appeals, former Town councilman, member of the Pelham Country Club, life member of the New York Athletic Club and former member of its Board of Directors, chairman of the Travers Island Committee, member of the Moles, board member of the Associated General Contractors, and arbitrator of the American Arbitration Association. He was a veteran of World War II as a captain in the European Theater. He was a proud member of the American Legion. All who knew him will remember him for his charity, ethics, and tireless efforts on behalf of his community, family and friends. He will be sorely missed. Visiting hours at the Pelham Funeral Home Sunday, December 26, 1999 from 2-4 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Catharine's Church 10 AM Monday, December 27, 1999. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Catholic Charities in his memory will be appreciated.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 4 First-Time Drug Offenders Granted Clemency by Pataki
description: Gov. George E. Pataki granted clemency today to four state prison inmates, and, following his pattern of years past, he chose first-time offenders who were serving long sentences under New York's harsh drug laws.

title: On-Again Devils Are Off Again Against Toronto
description: This habit of losing the second of back-to-back games has reached epidemic proportions for the Devils. They have played eight such games this season and have lost every one, and by at least two goals. They suffered their eighth such loss tonight by 4-1 to the Toronto Maple Leafs, one of the National Hockey League's elite teams again this season.

title: Justice on Trial in Pakistan
description: Two and a half months after the military coup in Pakistan, the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, is about to go on trial on charges of conspiracy, kidnapping and waging war against the state. If convicted, he could be hanged. But in a real sense, it is Pakistan that is now on trial. Gen. Pervez Musharraf and the other military rulers behind the coup have an obligation to ensure that any former government officials charged with crimes have full rights to defend themselves. So far the government's performance has fallen short, particularly in the case of one important former minister kidnapped by the army last week.

title: On New Year, Even Japan's Premier Will Be on Duty
description: While President Clinton and many other world leaders will be attending lavish banquets or otherwise feting the arrival of the new millennium, Japan's prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, will reportedly be cloistered with senior aides throughout the night just in case major Y2K problems erupt.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium
description: WITH New Year's Eve just a week away, revelers looking for live music should make reservations soon or expect to face a modest pre-Y2K problem. On New Year's Eve New York becomes a magnet for people who want to celebrate with fellow fans of salsa or punk, jazz or hip-hop. Musicians and disc jockeys can count on bookings as clubs start laying in the party hats and plastic Champagne glasses and ordering video screens to show the ball dropping in Times Square.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINITZ, RUDOLPH C.
description: REINITZ-Rudolph C.. Of Greenwich, CT. Died December 22, 1999. He was 77. Born September 12, 1922 in Czechoslavakia to Joseph and Serena Greenberg Reinitz. He married the late Ahuva Krasiko in 1950. Rudolph was a Corporate Executive for the Mobile Corp. He is survived by his loving partner Eva Gregory, a son Josh Reinitz of Maryland, 2 daughters Sima Kazaz of Israel, Naomi Saxe of Rye Brook, NY, 9 grandchildren and a sister Magdalena Franklin of Florida. Donations to American Society for Technion, 3475 Sheridan Street, Suite 207, Hollywood, Florida 33021-3659. For further information please contact Zion Memorial Chapel, (914-381-1809).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, HENRY T. (HANK)
description: CRAWFORD-Henry T. (Hank). On December 22, 1999. He leaves behind his beloved wife and friend Blanche Christian Crawford, his sons Tyrone, Jeffrey, Gregory and Gary, step-son Dwayne, stepdaughter Deborah, father Henry, mother Eunice, four brothers Raymond, Vernon, Leroy and Douglas, four sisters Laverne, Marilyn, Deborah, Viola. Eleven wonderful grandchildren, scores of nieces, nephews, friends and associates. A Memorial Service will be scheduled for a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Hank T. Crawford Scholarship Fund C/O M. Brackett, Dakota Realty, 445 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10022.

title: Injustice Can't Prevail
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by Reuters on Monday about the actor Desmond Llewelyn, who played the gadgetry expert Q in 17 James Bond films, misstated the number of actors who played Bond in those films. There were five -- Sean Connery, George Lazenby, Timothy Dalton, Roger Moore and Pierce Brosnan -- not just four.

title: German Plan Buoys Stocks Across Europe
description: European stock markets rose to records today for a third time this week, led by German banks and insurers, including Deutsche Bank, Allianz and Munich Re, after the German government proposed to cut taxes on the sale of corporate assets.

title: A Lifelong Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDDY, JOHN POST BOARDMAN
description: EDDY-John Post Boardman. In Boca Grande, Florida, on Tuesday, December 14th, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathryn King Eddy. Loving father of Elizabeth A. S. Eddy. Devoted son of Randolph Post Eddy and Jeane S. Eddy. In addition, he is survived by his brothers Paul C. Eddy & Randolph P. Eddy, Jr. and their families and many other devoted friends. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, December 28, 1999 at Trinity Episcopal Church in Newtown, CT. at 1PM. In lieu of flowers the family would be grateful if contributions were made to The John Post Boardman Eddy Memorial Scholarship Fund for St. Mark's School, C/O Linda Taylor at Fleet Bank, 6 Queen Street, Newtown, CT. 06470.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: JAVON JACKSON QUARTET: Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 242-1785. Without staging a full-scale subversion of jazz, the tenor-saxophonist Javon Jackson makes good decisions about material and instrumentation; there might be a Hammond organ on the bandstand, and you might hear music written by Frank Zappa, Caetano Veloso or Carlos Santana.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Blues, Funk and Rhythm-and-Blues
description: KID CREOLE AND THE COCONUTS: Greatest Bar on Earth, 1 World Trade Center, lower Manhattan, (212) 524-7000. August Darnell, or Kid Creole, runs his band like a compact Broadway revue, with Kid Creole -- a suave would-be Casanova who's not always lucky -- flanked by the Coconuts, who are both all-purpose temptresses and a chorus line. Long before the rediscovery of Latin rhythms, his early songs acted as if Manhattan were the northernmost Caribbean island; more recently, he has raised the quotient of funk. Music begins at 10 p.m.; admission is $300. JON PARELES

title: Terrorists Said to Hide In Canada's Melting Pot
description: All street and shop signs here, by Quebec provincial law, must be in French. But walk a few blocks from the modest bachelor apartment at 1250 Fort Street where Ahmed Ressam lived under the name of Benni Antoine Noris, and sometimes Mario Roig, and the signs tell of a rich ethnic bouillabaisse.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: DAVID HAZELTINE: Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662. This pianist plays with a cooperative quartet including the trumpeter Jim Rotondi, the bassist John Webber and the drummer Neil Smith; they can play hard-hitting, involved music, and this new, small jazz club, frequented by students, seems like a cheerily low-key place to spend the evening. Music is from 10 p.m. to 3 a.m.; there is an open bar, a raw bar with shellfish, party favors and a Champagne toast for $195. From 1 to 8 a.m., there is one more live set and a D.J. dance party for a $20 cover, $15 in advance; early guests may stay for no additional charge. BEN RATLIFF

title: 2 by Puccini, Up Close and Unexplained
description: The vast majority of opera companies in the United States have incorporated supertitles into their productions. Audiences seem to love this aid to comprehension. The use of supertitles may account for the new prosperity of American opera.

title: 'Saved From Europe'
description: Galerie St. Etienne

title: Islanders Stand Up To Fleury And Rangers
description: Although the Rangers have not been very good in recent seasons, their fans could always say that at least they were better than the Islanders. Almost everyone else in the National Hockey League was better than the Islanders, so why should their nearest neighbors be any different?

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Rock
description: DR. ISRAEL: Knitting Factory Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. The deep, leisurely bass lines of dub reggae are the foundation of jungle, which layers jittery electronic drumbeats on top of those bass lines. Dr. Israel (alias Douglas Bennett), a reggae singer, reunites the two branches of reggae's family tree, singing uplifting messages over vertiginous grooves. Music at 11 p.m.; admission is free. JON PARELES

title: NEW XEROX BUSINESS GROUP WILL FOCUS ON THE INTERNET
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had formed an Internet business group to enhance its Web-based business activities and Internet-related technologies. The group will add more interactive communications to Xerox's Web site. Michael Miron was named president of the new organization. Mr. Miron previously served as senior vice president for corporate business strategy and development. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., makes copiers, printing systems and software. It had revenue of $13.79 billion for the nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: Trade Panel Rules Against U.S. Penalty on Subsidized Steel
description: A World Trade Organization dispute panel sided with the European Union today in a challenge to American duties imposed to counter state subsidies for British-produced steel. If upheld, the ruling could prevent the United States from levying penalties on products made by state-owned companies that are later privatized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSON, JOSEPH E.
description: HANSON-Joseph E.. (Pete) Jr. On Wednesday, December 22, 1999. Of Summit, New Jersey, formerly of South Orange, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Helen Marie Waldron Hanson; Devoted father of Robert E.; John V.; Jane M.; Marie M.; Margaret M. Payeur; Sarah M.; Helen Marie Dewey and the late Joseph E. Hanson III. Also survived by 15 grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, on Monday, December 27th at 10 AM, thence to St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills where a Funeral Mass will be offered at 11:15 AM. Interment St. Rose of Lima Cemetery, Short Hills. Visiting hours Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Rosary Shrine/ Dominican Nuns, 543 Springfield Avenue, Summit, New Jersey 07901, would be appreciated.

title: Dolan Leads Bidding for Jets
description: In the race to buy the Jets, Charles F. Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision, is in the lead, followed closely by Robert Wood Johnson IV, an heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune, according to several persons with knowledge of the negotiations. Although the team is expected to sell for about $600 million, Dolan is not believed to have reached that level yet.

title: A.C.L.U. Suit for Removal of Creche and Menorah Is Denied
description: A federal judge in Newark refused yesterday to order a New Jersey town to dismantle its holiday display, and accused the state American Civil Liberties Union of looking for publicity by filing its request so close to Christmas.

title: VODAFONE BEGINS TAKEOVER BID
description: Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone AirTouch, officially started the largest hostile bid ever, tendering the British wireless operator's $127.7 billion offer for Mannesmann of Germany. Shareholders of the German telecommunications conglomerate will have until Feb. 7 to decide the fate of the offer. Vodafone said it expected to squeeze savings of about $803 million in 2003 and about $970 million in 2004 by combining the two telephone concerns. Vodafone reiterated its hope to negotiate with Mannesmann. In a statement, the German company rejected the offer again. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: BULGARIAN TELECOM STAKE
description: Royal KPN, the biggest Dutch phone company, and the Hellenic Telecommunications Organization said they would pay $410 million in cash for 51 percent of Bulgaria's national phone company plus a mobile phone license. The Greek and Dutch companies said they would pay the remaining $100 million of the $510 million purchase price agreed in July into an escrow account in an international bank based in Bulgaria. They had also earlier agreed to invest $200 million in the Bulgarian company over the next three years.

description: GOLDRING-Norman J.., 75, of Boca Raton, FL and formerly of Roslyn, NY. Died in Florida on December 23, 1999 after a long illness. Loving husband of Sondra (nee Wien), devoted father of Lysa and Gary. Beloved brother of Carole and Stuart. Cherished grandfather and uncle.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Houses in Bronx Will Extend Neighborhood to Waterfront
description: Earthmovers are clearing 22.5 acres that hug the East River in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx in preparation for a residential development that will extend the neighborhood to the water's edge and add to an old staple in the area: the two-family house.

title: Henry W. Large, 94, Ex-Railroad Executive
description: Henry W. Large, who briefly served as president of the Wabash Railroad and was a longtime executive with the Pennsylvania Railroad, died Dec. 9 at his home in Blue Bell, Pa. He was 94.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMENT, ESTHER
description: DIAMENT - Esther. Beloved daughter of the late David and Gussie Goldreich. Devoted mother of David Leon, Matthew Robert, Elizabeth Rose. Dear sister of Gloria (Sheldon) Horowitz, Cherie (Eli) Kaplan, Kayla (Martin) Silberberg. Dear sister in-law of Margery & Aaron Ziegelman. Wonderful aunt, cousin and friend. Funeral services, Friday, December 24, 9:30AM, Shaarei Tikvah, 46 Fox Meadow Rd, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELVISO, ROBERT HUGH
description: BELVISO-Robert Hugh. On December 23, 1999 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Beloved husband of Freida (nee Sawyer), loving father of Melanie. Funeral Service private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Yale Alumni Fund, POB 803, New Haven, CT 06503-0803, Class of 1955.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Hip-Hop
description: EMINEM: Tunnel, 220 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 695-4682. With his cutting, nasal voice, droll productions by Dr. Dre and an imagination that turns carnage into comedy, Eminem (named for the initials of Marshall Mathers, his original name) was the leading bad-boy rapper of early 1999. He mocks every propriety and everyone including himself, and while he is not the most skillful rapper onstage -- he needs backups to keep him somewhere near the beat -- it hardly matters when his fans are eagerly shouting along. The Tunnel has also scheduled eight disc jockeys in three rooms, among them Ivan Gonzo and Eddie Baez. Tickets are $99, or $175 with open bar; the club is also offering a weekend pass for New Year's Eve through Jan. 2 for $150. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOSH, LAVETA BELL
description: McCOSH-LaVeta Bell. On December 17, 1999. Recently of Lambertville, NJ. Born July 1, 1912 in Terre Haute, Indiana to Herbert F. and Nellie Bolen Bell. Noted fashion designer in New York, Switzerland, Philadelphia and most recently in Spain for 30 years. Cherished mother of Delyn McCosh and Deloris Verchere; grandmother of Troy Pinciotti, Charles ''Jock'' Gable, Christopher Gable, Madelaine Verchere and Christina Verchere; great-grandmother of Julie, Tiffany and William Pinciotti and Carley and Charles ''Jason'' Gable.

title: Which Way The Wind Blows
description: D. A. Pennebaker gave a literary feeling to ''Don't Look Back,'' his 1967 documentary about Bob Dylan. ''The songs had a Kerouac quality,'' he said in an interview the other day. ''They continually surprised you: always the pig who flew through the window. He took you into literature, whether he intended it or not.''

title: New York Is Ground Zero, All Agree. But for Festivity, or Fear?
description: Three generations of the Errico family were making their way through Times Square yesterday, craning their necks at the panorama of neon and disagreeing about whether the gridlocked triangle was tourist heaven or ground zero for possible terrorist activity on New Year's Eve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACON, KAREN L. (LAGEMANN)
description: BACON-Karen L. (Lagemann)., of Hyannis Port, died Tuesday, December 21, 1999 at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. She was 75. She is survived by her four children, Robin Greenwood of North Salem, New York, Carter Smith Bacon, Jr. of Sherborn, MA, Wells W. Bacon of Somesville, ME and Eric Bacon of Needham, MA. Also survived by two brothers, Derek Lagemann of Port Washington, New York, and Peter Lagemann of Greenwich, CT; 13 grandchildren, 3 nieces and 1 nephew. A Memorial Service will be held on January 3, 2000 at 2 P.M. at St. Andrew's By the Sea in Hyannis Port. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Child and Family Services of Cape Cod, 1019 Route 132, Hyannis, MA 02601, 508778-1839. For information J.S. Waterman & Son-Waring Funeral Home of Wellesley.

description: EUROPE

title: Further Rise In Spending By Consumers Lifts Economy
description: Consumers accelerated their spending in November, pushing the economy closer to a record expansion, government figures showed today.

title: Nets Shake Off A Big Critic And Feisty 76ers
description: Kendall Gill is one of Don Casey's favorite players in the National Basketball Association. Gill is also a close friend to Casey, the Nets' coach. But that did not stop Casey from wincing, praying and crossing his fingers when Gill received a pass from Kerry Kittles with 14 seconds left in tonight's game against the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, DONALD EDWARD
description: MINTZ-Donald Edward. On December 22, 1999. Loving father of Peter, Hayley and daughter-in-law Etta, dear brother of Robert and sister-in-law Helene, adoring grandfather of Alexander. He was a professor of psychology and former Chairman of the Deparment of Psychology at City College, City University of N.Y. Service Friday, 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAZIL, JUNE
description: BRAZIL-June., acupuncturist, of Tarrytown, New York, passed away peacefully on December 17 at age 43. For more information see www.acor.org/mm.

title: A Canvas of Concerns: Race, Racism and Class
description: For art, the 1990's started in a mood of agitation. The market went down the drain. AIDS was rampant. The 1993 Whitney Biennial, the most important American contemporary showcase of the decade, was a full-voiced chorus of long-excluded voices, black, Latino, gay and feminist among them.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Salsa
description: * MANOLITO Y SU TRABUCO: S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston, South Village, (212) 243-4940. A top Cuban band leader with his eye on the world, the pianist Manolito Simonet has his ear to music across Latin America, from older Cuban styles like charanga (with violin and flute answering voices) to trumpet-topped Cuban conjunto to cumbia to current salsa romantica and songo. He's a traditionalist on one song, up to the minute on the next as the singers announce his intention to reach listeners in Venezuela, Colombia, Puerto Rico and New York. Since Cuban bands play constantly for dancing crowds, Manolito y Su Trabuco (War Machine) has honed its music to keep people in motion. The club is offering packages at $95 a person (general admission after 1 a.m.), $195 (general admission after 10 p.m., with hors d'oeuvres and a Champagne toast) and $395 (including a five-course dinner and breakfast at dawn). JON PARELES

title: Pact Between New Jersey and Netherlands May Mean Cleaner Air for State
description: New Jersey and the Netherlands have agreed to a pilot project they hope will show the world how to help reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, MAY
description: LIEBERMAN-May. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of May Lieberman, beloved mother of Lillian Eisman, a distinguished member of our Board of Directors and honorary chair of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York, a beneficiary agency. We extend our sincerest condolences to Lillian, her husband, Elliot, and the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: The Expanding Reach of Civil Rights
description: For people who cared about civil rights and civil liberties, America at midcentury was a forbidding place. Demagogues and cold-war politics threatened freedom of speech. Racial discrimination was rampant, separate-but-equal the law of the land in education. Women were equal at the polling booth but not in the workplace. It was not uncommon for people to be convicted on illegally obtained evidence, without the aid of counsel. There were no class-action lawsuits to protect the environment from commercial exploitation or consumers from dangerous products.

title: Small Houses a Big Step for South African Pride
description: The lacy curtains from the secondhand shop flutter over the bedroom window. The white tiles salvaged from the garbage dump gleam on the kitchen floor.

title: For Some Lawyers, It's Not About Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: GATO BARBIERI QUINTET, REGINA BELLE, MIRI BEN-ARI TRIO: Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. All gatos have a few lives, and Mr. Barbieri, the saxophonist, has had three: first as a free-jazz wailer in the early 70's, then as the soloist on the celebrated ''Last Tango in Paris'' soundtrack and now as a smooth-jazz balladeer. He is on the bill with the singer Regina Belle and the up-and-coming violinist Miri Ben-Ari, whose attack is so ferocious that she may give you your necessary second wind.

title: Robbery Is Suspected as Landlord Is Found Dead
description: A Brooklyn landlord was found dead in her apartment late Wednesday night, bound with duct tape and with a garbage bag pulled over her head. She appeared to have been a robbery victim, the police said.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: ANGELA BOFILL: Iridium, 48 West 63rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. The singer Angela Bofill, a virtuoso with a four-octave range, has moved in and out of jazz and pop. She lavishes lung power and ornamentation on her love songs. Two shows: one at 7:30 p.m., including a three-course dinner, for $125 a person, and one at 10:45 p.m., with a four-course dinner and unlimited Champagne, for $295 a person. JON PARELES

title: Mall School Tries Reading, Writing and Retail
description: If retail is war, then the students of Providence Place Academy are the first cadets in the country to have their boot camp on the field of battle.

title: Irving Berlin, the Quiet King of Song
description: The silence at the center of ''Irving Berlin: An American Song'' is the program's subject himself. Berlin utters scarcely a word in Sunday's two-hour tribute on A&E to his prodigious career. When we hear directly from him, it is his famous rendition of ''Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning,'' from ''This Is the Army.'' His reticence offstage can be taken as his way of telling the world that what he had to say he said in his music and lyrics, and that there was nothing he could add to that, so why bother?

title: Fireside Chats
description: In a December like this one the weather may or may not be frightful, but inside, a fire is still delightful. Here are 12 places for cozying up to a fireplace to warm the spirit and the toes. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: JOE LOVANO TRIO, GLORIA LYNNE: Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. Mr. Lovano is one of the modern masters of the saxophone, beloved by older players as much as by the students who find him one of the hipper musicians around, and he plays with a warmth and a generosity that go beyond the front of the stage; odds are he's not a bad guy to spend New Year's Eve with. He and Ms. Lynne, the singer, trade off sets from 9 p.m. to 4 a.m.; the $250-a-person package includes a four-course meal, open bar and breakfast buffet. BEN RATLIFF

title: Pro Bowl Rejection Has Green Still Miffed
description: ''I'm not the type to brag,'' Victor Green said today, still seething over his perceived slight at not being voted to the Pro Bowl. ''But I thought it was all about statistics and performance. To be a third alternate, that means there's five other guys in the A.F.C. that played better?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINSKY, REBA
description: MINSKY-Reba. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Devoted mother of Barbara and Michael Herzog and Allan and Ruth Minsky. Adored grandmother of Jonathan, Peter, Heather and Keri. Services 11:30 Friday at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFIN, GEORGE M.
description: JAFFIN-George M.. Adored and beloved husband of Janet, loving father of Doris Greenberg, Lois Levine and David Jaffin. Caring father-in-law of Lee Greenberg and Rosemary Jaffin. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan Greenberg, Walter Greenberg, Matthew Greenberg, Daniella Cava, Julie Levine, and Carl Levine. Loving great-grandfather of Eliza Cava, Teddy Cava, and Aron Cava. His memory will be a blessing because he was a blessing to us and so many others. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 26, 12 Noon, at Kol Ami Synagogue, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: A New Gloss On Poverty In Ireland
description: Anyone who thinks poverty is not pretty would think twice after watching the film version of Frank McCourt's best-selling boyhood memoir. Not since Walker Evans distilled the mournful beauty of Appalachia, or at least not since the latest fashion layout flirted with arty desolation, has misery looked this fabulously pristine.

title: On Second Outing, Astronauts Continue Upgrade of Telescope
description: The Hubble Space Telescope got smarter and better able to point at distant astronomical targets today as spacewalking astronauts replaced two major pieces of the observatory's gear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORENCE, LEE
description: FLORENCE-Lee. It has been said before, but I will say it again. Though you have been an angel to countless people, but Jonathan's, Mattye's and my name have always headed that list. Our endless thanks and love will continue to go with you forever. Love, Miriam

title: PFIZER PLANS TO DROP TESTING OF EXPERIMENTAL DRUG
description: Pfizer Inc. will drop testing of the experimental drug droloxifene, one of two compounds it had been developing to treat osteoporosis and breast cancer, according to Ligand Pharmaceuticals, Pfizer's research partner for the drugs. Pfizer, the No. 2 United States drug maker, will continue work on a second, newer compound called lasofoxifene, which it developed in collaboration with Ligand. Pfizer plans to start advanced studies of lasofoxifene, Ligand said. Both compounds are members of a class of drugs called selective estrogen receptor modulators that also includes Eli Lilly & Company's Evista.

title: Sports of The Times; Ted Should Just Fire The Bigot
description: THAT'S the perverse part. John Rocker would feel right at home in Shea and Yankee Stadiums, beating up on opposing fans, shouting all kinds of vile things, often with racial connotations.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Rock
description: BLACK 47: Connolly's Pub, 14 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 867-3767. Black 47 plays Irish neighborhood music from the Bronx, not Dublin. Bainbridge Avenue runs through a Bronx neighborhood where new Irish immigrants meet the New York mosaic. In Black 47's songs, jigs and reels mesh with rock and hip-hop. Music begins at 10 p.m.; admission is $20, or $200 with an open bar, hors d'oeuvres and a buffet. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, ALBERT Y.
description: NATHAN-Albert Y.. On December 23, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Sarah. Loving father of Irwin. Cherished grandfather of Alan and Mitchell. Graveside service Sunday, 2PM, at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York.

title: VISITING U.S. AIDE CRITICIZES MOSCOW
description: Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott ended two days of talks on a sour note here today, accusing Russia of ''indiscriminate killing'' in Chechnya and failing to break a lingering stalemate between Washington and Moscow over a major arms control treaty.

title: The Neediest Cases; Tenants Join Together For a Building Solution
description: In May, a Roman Catholic priest was invited to a six-story apartment building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to perform a blessing ceremony.

title: Floods Confuse Venezuela's Political Outlook
description: A week of immense landslides and floods has done more than destroy lives, homes and public works here. The country's worst natural disaster of modern times has also left an institutional vacuum and deepened uncertainty about how the government and economy are to be run over the next few months.

title: JUNO SHARES FALL ON NEWS OF AN ADDITIONAL STOCK SALE
description: Juno Online Services Inc., whose shares surged more than fourfold this week after the company offered free Internet access, said yesterday that it would sell additional shares, sending its stock down nearly 25 percent. Juno fell $15.0625, to $46.1875. Juno, based in New York, said on Monday that it was shifting its strategy to offering free access from building a fee-based subscriber service. The company, which is controlled by the hedge fund manager David Shaw, wants to build revenue through increased online advertising. Juno has 500,000 paying subscribers and 2.4 million users who receive its free e-mail service. It did not say how much stock it intended to sell.

title: Rehearing Sought in Reversal On Test-Based Eligibility Suit
description: Lawyers for four African-American athletes who sued the National Collegiate Athletic Association over the minimum test score requirement for athletic scholarships said yesterday they would ask the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to rehear their arguments and promised to pursue legal remedies, if necessary, all the way to the Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRAW, ANNE SCHUYLER WILLIAMS
description: McGRAW-Anne Schuyler Williams. Of Gulf Stream, FL and of Wianno, MA., passed away on December 22, 1999 after a long illness with cancer. She was married to Donald C. McGraw, Jr. for over 50 years and had four sons, Donald III, Robert, David and the late Peter McGraw plus thirteen grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on August 8, 2000 at 11AM at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, MA 02655. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to either St. Peter's Episcopal Church or St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 188 S. Swinton Avenue, Delray Beach, FL. 33444. For information contact Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL.

title: A Sad Case Confounded By Discord
description: ABSOLUTELY nothing is funny about the Amadou Diallo case. (There's a bold statement for you.) Still, it was hard to repress a grim smile while studying the reasoning of the appellate judges who moved the Diallo murder trial from the Bronx to Albany.

title: Santa Treads on Grandfather Frost's Toes
description: Santa Claus is coming to town. And is Ded Moroz ever annoyed about it.

title: Another Last Word on Y2K
description: Recently I went to my doctor for a complete physical, which seemed like the closest I could come to ensuring my body was Y2K-compliant.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The mayor's fingerprints are on this.''

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Rock
description: THE VOLUPTUOUS HORROR OF KAREN BLACK: CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 982-4052. Punk, heavy metal and plenty of mascara add up to the Voluptuous Horror of Karen Black, a long-running punk-rock show band whose songs hark back to the Cramps and early Blondie. Kembra Pfahler, the band's semiclad singer, makes promises like ''Take my hand and you will see/What a maniac I can be.'' The bill also includes Motor Betty and Probe. Music begins around 9 p.m.; admission is $30 in advance; $35 the day of the show. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JURIST, ESTELLE
description: JURIST-Estelle. On December 23, 1999. Beloved mother of Joseph Jurist and mother-in-law of Lynda Jurist and ever proud grandmother of Julie and Alison.

title: DAEWOO SHARES PLUNGE
description: Hurt by rumors of an imminent court receivership filing, Daewoo shares plunged by their daily limit of 15 percent, despite official denials by the troubled company, and the Korea Stock Exchange temporarily suspended trading of its stock. Trading resumed later in the afternoon. But court receivership is becoming more likely every day for Daewoo. Foreign creditors of the ailing Daewoo Group rejected a proposal from local creditors on Wednesday to buy out the group's $6.7 billion in debt owed to foreign banks. Samuel Len
