description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Royal

title: Buchanan Starts Push Through Reform Party Hedgerows
description: Patrick J. Buchanan styles himself lately as ''that troll still waiting out there under the bridge,'' hoping for political magic to strike his impish presidential candidacy as a Reform Party insurgent.

title: Judge With Reputation for Toughness is Chosen for the Diallo Trial
description: A judge who once represented a police officer in a lawsuit over a controversial on-duty shooting was picked yesterday to preside over the trial of the four officers accused of murdering Amadou Diallo last February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, BARBARA
description: FRIEDMAN-Barbara. The Murray Hill Medical Group notes with profound sorrow the passing of Barbara Friedman, the mother of our esteemed colleague and friend Dr. Jeffrey Friedman. We extend our deepest sympathy to Jeffrey, her husband Arnold and her sons Stuart and Bruce.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; American Fights for Control of Prague TV Station
description: A vicious legal battle over Eastern Europe's most successful television station has turned an important American investor against the government of the Czech Republic and now threatens to taint the country's reputation in the business world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUDYKOFF, CHARLES
description: RUDYKOFF-Charles. Dear Poppa, today is your 100th. Fools celebrate the coming New Age, but I mourn the passing of the old and the best. Love, David.

title: Clinton Sallies Forth; Merchants on Alert
description: President Clinton plans to embark on his annual Christmas shopping trip on Friday afternoon, joining thousands of other procrastinating holiday shoppers.

title: BOARD OUSTS SCHOOLS CHIEF, SAYING CREW LOST HIS FOCUS; MAYOR'S ROLE BECOMES ISSUE
description: As recently as last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was grudgingly content to leave the fate of his former friend, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, in the hands of the seven members of the Board of Education. After all, the mayor is on the verge of declaring his candidacy for the Senate. He needs stability, not complication.

title: Sailor From Mutiny in '44 Wins a Presidential Pardon
description: President Clinton pardoned an 80-year-old former sailor yesterday, forgiving a World War II conviction for mutiny that had become a reminder of the history of segregation in the armed services.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS (AND ONLY THE YEAR)

title: G.M. Official Gives Upbeat Review of Year
description: As the hottest auto market on record winds to a close, a General Motors executive gave an upbeat assessment of 1999 yesterday, a year in which his company has earned record profits even as its market share has declined.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: * JOHN ZORN'S MASADA, MARC RIBOT Y LOS CUBANOS POSTIZOS, CYRO BAPTISTA'S BEAT THE DONKEY: Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503. Masada is a collection of 205 klezmer-tinged tunes by John Zorn, who oversees various ensembles that play them, including a quartet that recalls Ornette Coleman's pianoless lineups. With Joey Baron on drums, Greg Cohen on bass, Dave Douglas on trumpet and Mr. Zorn on alto-saxophone, Masada moves from the pulse of dance music to modal Middle Eastern inflections to Romantic filigree. Less fragmented and more melodic than most of Mr. Zorn's music, Masada finds connections to Jewish tradition everywhere.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Cheaper Ride In a Checker Cab

title: Approval Lifts Genentech
description: Shares of Genentech Inc. rose after the company said it won government clearance to sell Nutropin Depot, a long-acting version of its Nutropin growth hormone drug. Shares of Genentech gained 7 percent, rising $6.25, to $139.25. Shares in the California company, which is majority-owned by the Swiss drug maker Roche Holding, have gained as much as 70 percent since Dec. 1, amid high expectations for Nutropin and other drugs in the Genentech pipeline. Alkermes shares rose $2.625, to $53.625.

title: Rock Crystal For Kings And Gods
description: Christmastime is just the season for rock crystal, which has long been revered for its purity, its lucidity and its magical play of light.

title: 'Let's Make a Deal,' Now on the Web
description: BY giving shoppers instant access to model comparisons and price information, the Internet is clearly changing the way cars are bought and sold. And a virtual gold rush has ensued as new dot-com companies spring up, promising to wring the pain -- and some of the dealers' profit -- out of the process. Now, a few Web sites are going further in challenging the established order of selling cars, with systems that force dealerships to bid against one another.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; How a Driveway Dreamer Was Turned Into a Slam-Dunker
description: When Balzac got writer's block, he took off all his clothes and hung a wreath of garlic around his neck. When I get writer's block, I play basketball. When the paragraphs aren't flowing, and I find that I'm spending more time checking the word count than adding to it, I lace up my Chuck Taylors, grab my well-worn Wilson from the bathroom closet and make a beeline to the hoop attached to my garage.

title: A Firebrand Who Seemed to Lose His Spark
description: Just a year ago, Rudy Crew seemed poised to be the first chancellor in years to make a lasting difference on New York City's public schools. From the time he arrived from the comparatively tiny Tacoma, Wash., embraced by almost everyone in New York's troubled and politically divided system, he promised quick results and often seemed to deliver.

title: Selling Online, Delivering on Bikes; Low-Tech Courier Services Thrive On Growth of Web-Based Retailing
description: Here at the high noon of holiday shopping in Manhattan, the future of the e-commerce revolution is increasingly dependent on a low-tech, often-despised grunt: the bicycle messenger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, ROBERT B.
description: FLEMING-Robert B.., Sr. The Pace University community mourns the passing of Robert B. Fleming Sr., founding dean of its School of Law, who passed away on December 16. Fleming served as dean from 1976 to 1982. He then joined the Pace Law School faculty prior to returning to Buffalo in 1987, where he served in private practice through most of this year. The public service ethic that he brought to campus is thriving 23 years later. Our condolences are extended to his wife, Jeanne; his sister, Scottie Walton, and brother, David Fleming; sons Robert Jr., Mick & Andrew; daughters Molly, Kate (Cohen) and Jane (Fottrell); and 14 grandchildren. Aniello A. Bianco, Chairman Board of Trustees Patricia O. Ewers, President David Cohen, Dean, School of Law

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCGUIRE, MURIEL MARGARET
description: McGUIRE-Muriel Margaret. Dearest Mom, Merry Christmas. Happy New Millennium. This year I miss you most of all. Love you more. Sissy

title: ''Ballads and Blues: The Brooklyn Session'' (Criss Cross).
description: The first two albums by Rodney Whitaker, the bassist for the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra, were valentines to his hometown, Detroit; he surrounded himself with players he had known before moving to New York, mixing them in with his new colleagues. The albums were ambitious and a little unwieldy and often lost focus and balance with so many different kinds of players.

title: New Video Releases
description: Michael Fugate (Hugh Grant, left) works hard to get himself into proper cultural alignment to marry the daughter (Jeanne Tripplehorn) of a genial Mafia chieftain (James Caan). An Englishman with the brittle manner, slight stammer and practiced helplessness of Mr. Grant is bound to make an awkward fit with raucous, wear-it-on-your-sleeve future in-laws who are lovable one minute and deadly the next. With plenty of suave comic timing, Mr. Grant's Mickey negotiates the gangsterish shoals in, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, ''a lightweight comedy that has more than enough laughs to justify its silly, scatterbrained premise.''

title: Retailers Look Back and See Online Shopping Is Gaining
description: Online holiday shopping is increasingly gnawing at the business of traditional retailers this year, with preliminary indications that seasonal Internet sales may nearly triple from last year.

title: Arthur Wesley Dow
description: 'His Art and His Influence'

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Rock
description: MEAT LOAF: Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070. Perhaps only a few people gazing back over the artistic milestones of the last millennium would single out the magnum opus by the multitalented Meat Loaf, ''Paradise by the Dashboard Light.''

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: DR. MICHAEL WHITE'S ORIGINAL LIBERTY JAZZ BAND OF NEW ORLEANS: Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. Dr. Michael White takes his chosen idiom -- New Orleans jazz of the 20's -- very seriously, and his band, nearing a decade of New Year's shows at the Vanguard, performs lively versions of tunes associated with Louis Armstrong, King Oliver and others from the Crescent City. If the concept is strictly classical, the players have presence and nerve. Doors open at 10 p.m.; there is one set, at 11 p.m.; $125 a person includes the $25 drink minimum (which can include Champagne), party favors, a New Year's Eve T-shirt and New Orleans-style food. No credit cards. BEN RATLIFF

title: Lear Meets Hannibal Lecter? O.K.
description: In a splashy interpretation of ''Titus Andronicus'' the stage director Julie Taymor takes a risky path into what is often considered one of Shakespeare's lesser plays. Ms. Taymor's first film turns this tragedy of revenge, starring Anthony Hopkins (left) and Jessica Lange, into a fluid time-traveling fantasia that ventures from ancient Rome to Mussolini's Italy to a video-game arcade, discovering unsettling contemporary resonances along the way. The violence becomes addictive as the carnage builds to a cannibalistic feast.

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Jazz
description: PAUL WINTER: Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at West 112th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 662-2133. In the cathedral's annual New Year's Eve concert, hopes for peace are expressed in New Age music with multicultural ambitions. The Paul Winter Consort plays one-world music full of reassurance, good intentions and candy-coated exoticism. It shares the stage with the African-style Forces of Nature Dance Company and with Madafo Lloyd Wilson. The concert begins at 7:30 p.m.; tickets are $75 to $100. JON PARELES

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Online Holiday Shopping Cuts Into Traditional Sales

title: WILMAR INDUSTRIES TO GO PRIVATE IN $300 MILLION DEAL
description: Wilmar Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to be taken private by an investor group in a buyout that values the company at $300 million. The group will also assume $65 million of Wilmar debt. The investor group, which includes Wilmar senior management, is led by Parthenon Capital of Boston and Chase Manhattan's Chase Capital Partners. The group agreed to pay $18.25 a share for Wilmar of Moorestown, N.J., which distributes building maintenance supplies. Wilmar shares were up $3.1875, or nearly 23 percent, at $17.1875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVVOCATO, ROY A.
description: AVVOCATO-Roy A.., M.D. On December 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary Eileen nee Shea. Devoted father of Mary Ann O'Halloran, Roy A. Jr., Eileen, Regina Petersen, Paul J. and the late James Shea Avvocato. Proud grandfather of nine. Viewing at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn, Saturday, 7-9 PM and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10:15 AM, Our Lady of Angels Church.

It is a private organization and does not have ties to the National Institutes of Health.

title: BREWER RECALLS BOTTLES
description: Shares in Companhia Cervejaria Brahma, Brazil's leading brewery, fell as much as 2 percent after the company said it would recall about one million defective beer bottles. Brahma said it feared some of the bottles, which are wrapped in white plastic as part of a special series to celebrate the new year, might shatter upon opening. The brewery took out full-page ads in newspapers to warn consumers of the problem. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, FREDERICK, D.D.S.
description: LEVY-Frederick, D.D.S.. Died December 17, 1999 at age 86. Beloved husband of Martha. Devoted father of Susan Levy and Alan Rosen, Judith Levy and Donald Nisonoff. Dear brother of Helen and Jules Goldschmidt. Adored grandfather of Alexander, Miriam, Lara, Elena and Micaela.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HIGH RIVER L.P., -- Washington, an investment partnership controlled by the financier Carl C. Icahn, said that it sold its 14 percent stake in the Philip Services Corp. to Jack Gumpert Wasserman for $1.5 million.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: First Amendment Champion, Subject Aside
description: NEW YORK CITY'S sex-entertainment industry cleans up real good for dates with justice: its front man is a genteel First Amendment lover who all but gets the vapors when speaking of his clients' triple-X-rated magazines and videos. ''It's dismally unpleasant,'' says Herald Price Fahringer in his whispery voice. ''But that's not the issue.''

title: Auld Lang Syne All Revved Up For the Millennium; Pop
description: PAULA COLE, THE ROOTS: Life, 158 Bleecker Street, at Thompson Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 420-1999. In keeping with its thriving system of hierarchical V.I.P. rooms, Life presents a three-tiered party. The priciest ticket includes a buffet dinner at 6:30 p.m. and a performance by the bohemian pop-soul singer Paula Cole; $100 less gets you no chow but a 10 p.m. set by Ms. Cole. And for $125, and well worth the price, you can show up tipsy at 3 a.m. and welcome 2000 with the best live band in hip-hop (and one of the best in any genre), the Roots. Shows are at 8 and 10 p.m., and 3 a.m.; tickets are $350, $250 and $125. ANN POWERS

title: Serb Rejects Dead Son's Medal, and the Whole War
description: Last week, eight months after his 20-year-old son was killed in Kosovo, Dusan Vukovic lashed out at the man he holds responsible: President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Seeing the Strangest Number From 2 Sides
description: Before the millennium gasps its last tired breath, a final tribute must be paid to something overlooked. It might seem to be nothing, yet during the last 1,000 years it has transformed physics, mathematics, commerce and the shape of Western civilization. That something is nothing.

title: Russia, a Power on Ice, Frets About the Future
description: The Soviet system is gone but not forgotten. It formed the basis for Russia becoming the most powerful nation in the history of figure skating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALBERT B.
description: COHEN-Albert B. Died December 24th, 1999, at age 76. Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of Jeffrey and Shelley, Steven and Laura, Marla and Jim, and Robert. Proud grandfather of Rachel, Jordana, Brad, Jennifer, Emily, Daniel, Joseph, Anna and Michael. Board Member of North Shore University Hospital and The Jewish Theological Seminary. Dedicated philantropist, risk arbitrageur, gentleman farmer and combat pilot. Funeral services will be held 10 A.M., Sunday at Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Road, Roslyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFIN, GEORGE M.
description: JAFFIN-George M. Adored and beloved husband of Janet, loving father of Doris Greenberg, Lois Levine and David Jaffin. Caring father-in-law of Lee Greenberg and Rosemarie Jaffin. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan Greenberg, Walter Greenberg, Matthew Greenberg, Daniella Cava, Julie Levine, Carl Levine, Raphael Jaffin and Andreas Jaffin. Loving great-grandfather of Eliza Cava, Teddy Cava, Aron Cava, and Aron Noah Jaffin. His memory will be a blessing because he was a blessing to us and so many others. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 26, 12 Noon, at Kol Ami Synagogue, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAGODA, GRACE
description: YAGODA-Grace. It is with profound sorrow that we extend our heaftfelt sympathy and condolences to Mr. David Yagoda, who was a very dear friend of Chabad Vocational Schools in Israel, and his daughters Barbara and Janet on the passing of their beloved wife and mother O.B.M. May you all be comforted amongst the mourners and Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Efraim Wolff-Dean Rabbi David Laine, Exec. Dir.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, BEN
description: ISRAEL-Ben. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father to Ira, Phyllis and Paul and adored grandfather. We mourn your passing and will forever treasure your memories as you have deeply touched us all. Robin and Dan Foxx

title: Official Resigns After Charges Of Brutality in Juvenile Jails
description: The head of California's troubled juvenile corrections service has resigned amid demands by state officials for a stronger response to brutality in the system.

title: Rosenthal Lets His Play Do the Talking on Field
description: The rookie guard Mike Rosenthal of the Giants could be called for holding on every play against the Vikings this Sunday. But the penalty would not be for grabbing the defensive man in front of him; it would be for holding his own tongue.

title: Paying Our U.N. Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Felicia Lamport, 83, a Satirist Devoted to Rhyme
description: Felicia Lamport, a poet and satirist who took delight in skewering the high and mighty with verse, quips, puns and parodies, most of them first appearing in a column in The Boston Globe called Muse of the Week in Review, died on Thursday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 83.

title: The Internet's Gift Is a Wider Bazaar
description: The 1999 holiday season has shaped up as the time when Internet shopping solidified its place in mainstream culture, measured both by the number of purchases made on-line and by the values Wall Street is assigning to cyberstores. According to the market research firm

title: Sports of The Times; A Timely Gift Is Bestowed On New York
description: ''No one should come to New York to live unless he is willing to be lucky.'' -- E. B. White

title: Lights Cast Christmas Spell On a City of Brick and Steel
description: There is something generous about lights on the exteriors of city apartment buildings, something that creates a quick shock of warmth in the beholder. Coming across Christmas lights on a side street in the city is like having a stranger hand you the unused portion of a MetroCard. It is a gift from strangers to fellow strangers, from one anonymous New Yorker to another. It makes you remember, for a minute, why you put up with the crazy rents.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Hijackers Send Indian Jetliner On an Odyssey
description: Five Sikh men said to be armed with grenades, rifles and knives hijacked an Indian Airlines jet yesterday and killed at least one of the 189 people aboard, during a forced odyssey across India, Pakistan, Afghanistan and the Persian Gulf, before touching down in Kandahar, Afghanistan, last night.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with an article about International Style buildings on Park Avenue misidentified the one at the left. It was the Bankers Trust Building, at 280 Park Avenue; the plaza in the foreground was that of the Chase Building at 270 Park Avenue.

title: Next Steps on Iraq
description: Iraq's reflexive rejection of a new United Nations weapons inspection plan need not be taken as the last word. With some assistance from France and Russia, which have an interest in limiting Iraq's development of chemical, biological and nuclear arms, an effective monitoring system can yet be put in place.

title: Reclaiming the City Is Phillips's Obsession
description: Steve Phillips was not at his office yesterday; at least he didn't answer the telephone there. His wife, Marni, said he was not at his office. But when she answered the telephone at their home in Connecticut, he was not there either.

title: Yen Falls Against Dollar; Global Markets Extend Rally
description: The yen posted its biggest decline against the dollar in more than a month yesterday after the Bank of Japan sold its currency for the 12th time since June.

title: California Treasurer Favors Shedding of Tobacco Stocks
description: The state treasurer of California said yesterday that he would press the state's two big public employee pension funds to sell off their large holdings of tobacco company stocks.

title: MITSUBISHI TO CUT DEBT
description: The Japanese automaker, Mitsubishi Motors, said it planned to slash its interest-bearing debt, as well as reduce its domestic production capacity and administrative work force further, by the end of fiscal year 2003-2004 as part of a new midterm revamping plan. Katsuhiko Kawasoe, the company's president, said that the strong yen and global market conditions had made it necessary for Mitsubishi to come up with new measures to remain competitive. The company has been battered by slumping sales of cars and trucks at home and abroad.

title: Effects of Economic 'Sunspots'
description: What do sunspots and economic forecasts have in common? Both affect the economy only if the public believes they do, according to a commentary by the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.

title: Joao Figueiredo, 81, Dead; Revived Brazil's Democracy
description: Gen. Joao Baptista de Figueiredo, who restored democratic government to Brazil in the face of economic turmoil and sabotage attempts by hard-line officers and political right-wingers, died yesterday at his house in Rio de Janeiro. He was 81.

title: Poems for a Millenial Year; A Toast for 2000
description: And here's to Memory, that numbers all the years.

title: Gay Rights Advocates Plan to Press Clinton to Undo Policy of 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'
description: Gay rights advocates and their supporters in Congress are pressing the Clinton administration to combat harassment against homosexuals in the armed forces while laying the groundwork to overturn the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy, now enshrined in law.

title: Health Plan Would Not Aid All Uninsured
description: The landmark agreement reached by Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature to provide medical coverage for the poor by raising the state's cigarette tax contains a little-noticed provision denying those benefits to thousands of legal immigrants during their first five years in the country.

title: Drug Industry Under Pressure From President
description: Brandishing new data showing that the drug industry earns higher profits and pays lower taxes than most other industries, White House officials say drug companies may bring price controls on themselves if they continue to resist President Clinton's plan to have Medicare provide pharmaceutical benefits.

title: Inverting the Pyramid in Egypt; A Beer Maker Blossoms With Its Nonalcoholic Brew
description: When the Egyptian government put the national beer company up for sale a few years ago, nobody was buying.

title: To a Long Life! (But How Long?)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Debut on the Island That's Worthy of Broadway
description: For a goalie who needs to build confidence, the Islanders are not the best team to play for. Over the last few seasons, they have lost many more games than they have won and they have not made the playoffs since 1994. The business philosophy of their ownership has not been conducive to building a winner and they have churned their roster constantly. Goalies like Felix Potvin and Tommy Salo and Eric Fichaud and Tommy Soderstrom and Jamie McLennan have served their time and escaped.

title: Little Town of Bethlehem Not Lying Still on Millennium's Last Christmas
description: In this little town, by tradition the birthplace of Jesus, the Palestinian police stood guard on the rooftops of Manger Square on Friday night as Italian nuns prayed with clasped hands, American gospel choirs belted out carols and Filipino immigrants wearing Santa hats boogied on plastic chairs.

title: Accused of Plotting Prison Strike, 40 Upstate Inmates Are Moved
description: Forty inmates were transferred out of a maximum-security prison in upstate New York yesterday because correction officials said they had discovered that the inmates were planning a strike.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At this hour, the word 'today' rings out with a unique sound. It is not only the commemoration of the birth of the Redeemer, it is the solemn beginning of the Great Jubilee.''

title: Nets Hope To Avenge Their Loss To the Bulls
description: The Chicago Bulls hardly present a rivalry or a challenge to look forward to this season, but as the Nets practiced today in preparation for Sunday night's meeting with the 2-21 Bulls, they had more than Christmas on their minds. In a season that has offered more than one low point before a recent resurgence, a 71-69 loss to the Bulls two weeks ago stands as one game that the Nets believe they can pay back.

title: Latin America Tackling Possible Computer Woes
description: Approximately 37,000 clients of Banco Itau S.A., one of Brazil's largest banks, got a glimpse last month of the problems Latin Americans might encounter from the Year 2000 computer problem when they received a letter saying certain fees would be charged to their accounts as of Jan. 4, 1900.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ADOLPH R., MD.
description: BERGER-Adolph R., MD. Died on December 17, 1999 at age 89. The devoted husband of his beloved late wife, Margaret Liebman Berger. Dr. Berger was a graduate of NYU School of Medicine and an Attending Physician and Professor of Clinical Medicine at Bellevue and Tisch Hospitals for more than 50 years. He trained many physicians, imparting to them the high standards he demanded of himself. To the end he maintained a great interest in the relationship between physicians and their patients. He will be missed by his former colleagues and his friends, but they are comforted by the knowledge that his final wish, to join his beloved Margaret, has been fulfilled.

title: Op-Art; Turn of the Century
Of Mouse and Man: Rebirth of Stuart Little
description: M. Night Shyamalan was sitting in a rest stop restaurant on the New Jersey Turnpike having something to eat and watching CNN on one of the television sets that give travelers something to stare at while they chew.

title: The Pakistan Conduit
description: To the Editor:

title: ACQUISITION OF DAEWOO OPPOSED
description: Unionized workers at South Korea's four automakers joined forces to protest the acquisition of the Daewoo Motor Corporation by foreign companies. Union leaders of the four companies -- Daewoo Motor, Hyundai Motor, Kia Motors and Ssangyong Motor -- met Wednesday and decided to form a committee to prevent a foreign takeover of Daewoo Motor. ''The sale of Daewoo Motor to foreigners would lead to the collapse of parts suppliers, undermine the motive for research and development and cause instability to the labor market,'' said Yon Byung Chul, vice chairman of the Daewoo Motor union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLNER, WARREN
description: KELLNER-Warren, age 84, of NYC, on Thursday, December 23, 1999 in Norwalk, CT. A member of Temple Emanu-El of the City of New York, the former President and owner of the Kitty Kelly Shoe Corporation, and in later years was Vice-President and General Manager of Michele Perkins and Associates. Dearly beloved husband and best friend of Natalie Steinhardt Kellner. Cherished father of Michele, John, Herbert (Skip) and Mary. Adored and adoring grandfather of Joanna, Catherine and Jennifer. Memorial contributions to American Heart Association or American Cancer Society. Services will be private.

title: So New Relationships Form
description: A Bach suite, then something by Jackson Mac Low, followed by Richard Strauss's ''Metamorphosen'' before a bit of Cage, and this was just the first half of the concert. Nobody else creates programs the way Peter Kotik does. It was a long evening he presented with the Orchestra of the S.E.M. Ensemble at the Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea on Tuesday night, and a switchback ride. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASZLING, RICHARD A.
description: ASZLING-Richard A. Richard Anderson Aszling, a retired corporate communications executive, died of pneumonia on Wednesday in Middletown, Connecticut. He was 85. Mr. Aszling retired in 1979 as vice president/corporate relations for General Foods Corp. He graduated from Oberlin College in 1936 and began his career as a writer/editor for the Dayton, Ohio Daily News. In 1940, he entered public relations, serving as manager with the Ohio State Medical Association, the Borden Company (in Columbus, Ohio, and New York City), and General Foods. In the late Fifties and early Sixties, he was a partner at Earl Newsom & Co. and a vice president of the Interpublic Group. Returning to General Foods in 1964, he was made a vice president in 1968. At Borden and General Foods, he pioneered corporate strategies for promoting convenience foods and maintaining positive relations with consumer activists. Mr. Aszling was an elected member of the Representative Town Meeting in Greenwich, Conn, where he and his family lived for 43 years. In retirement, he served as chairman of the International Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. He is survived by his wife, Carolyn Gill Aszling, and by four children: Philip, Kristen Howard, Gretchen Leache, and Jill Aszling Shek. He has six grandchildren and one greatgrandson. Memorial donations to the International Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 381 Park Ave, Suite 507, New York, New York 10016, will be appreciated.

title: This Millennial Christmas
description: The list of things we will do for the last time in this century and this millennium grows shorter and shorter as the minutes and seconds pass. But few of those things feel more meaningful than celebrating today the final Christmas in this old epoch, our long-familiar calendrical home. It was the problem of Easter's date that led a Scythian-born monk in the sixth century to determine the Roman year of Jesus' birth and to designate a new era, a Christian re-reckoning of time, beginning there. The scholarly judgment is that the historical Jesus was probably born around 4 or 6 B.C. And yet the popular idea prevails, though there are no carols or hymns to quite this effect, that on that ancient, first Christmas in Bethlehem so long ago, the one told in Luke, the counting of time began all over again, an old world departing and a new one ringing itself in to the sound of a heavenly host.

Naturopathica's Herbal Remedy Travel Kit, $65 at Henri Bendel or from 800-669-7618, includes Valerian Tincture, touted as an herbal Valium, and Peppermint Essential Oil, intended to ease nausea and motion sickness. Healing Hands offers the Holistic Nine Yards, $35 from Sephora's Web site, www.sephora.com, with a Courage Inhaler, Pressure Point Lotion and Clear Thoughts Face Mist, among other products. Molton Brown's New Age Traveler, $69 at Barneys New York, is a collection of natural balms intended to relax and rejuvenate tired eyes, faces and feet en route, while Bloom's Herbal Body Kit, $18 at Clyde's on Madison Avenue at 74th Street, provides herbal hand cream, foot balm and body gel. The new winners were the students of Roosevelt Elementary School in Garfield, who beat out 65 other schools from around the country with their rendition of a coral reef, 6 feet wide and 3 feet high, made from 50 boxes of cereal and 63 bags of marshmallows. It is now on display in the Garfield Public Library, and as it is coated with varnish, definitely not for eating. title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Big Dream of 1499
description: During December of 1499 in Venice, Aldus Manutius finished printing HYPNEROTOMACHIA POLIPHILI: The Strife of Love in a Dream (Thames and Hudson, $70), a brilliantly designed folio filled with elaborate engraved plates that may have bankrupted its publisher and has nearly bankrupted collectors ever since. Written by a rascally Dominican priest, Francesco Colonna, who lived to 94, it is a dream allegory about one Poliphilo's journey through an enchanted isle where he tells the story of his fatal love for a perfect woman. It lavishes such minute attention on all the senses and so thoroughly encompasses the passions of the Renaissance -- for painting, clothes, jewelry, music, language, theater, dance, Greek and Roman ruins and literature and the beauty of the human body -- that it is hard to think of any book quite so sensuous. It intoxicated European writers for two centuries, although few were so foolish as to try imitation, for Colonna invented his own language, an Italian so crammed with words borrowed from recondite Latin sources that it bewildered even his learned countrymen. At last, Joscelyn Godwin, a professor of music at Colgate University known widely for studies of ancient mystical religions, provides the first clear English version. No translation, if it is to be useful, could reproduce the effect of the original, but Godwin gives a hint, rendering a small passage literally -- and hilariously. He gives a brief history of the book but does not burden the text with notes or corrections of Colonna's often amusing misunderstandings of the ancients he worshiped. The publisher is similarly restrained in paying its respect; this edition reproduces the size and typography of the Aldine original and is printed in a modern Poliphilus, the typeface Aldus had designed for it 500 years ago. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: PULSE; Where's the Food Court?
description: With its underground art scene and booming night life, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, doesn't exactly feel like mall country. But in the Real Form Girdle Building (Bedford Avenue and North Fifth Street), a mini-mall of 16 local businesses opened last month, offering suburban shopping convenience for urban aesthetes. With no aviaries, fountains or Pottery Barns in sight, the former girdle factory has curving white walls, a concrete floor and objet-trouve light fixtures. The tenants, mostly designers and artisans setting up their first retail ventures, range from Otte, a tiny, bright pink clothing boutique dominated by a giant chandelier, to AK-ME, a card and gift shop painted with hot-rod-style flames. The building's common area is available for performances and readings, and unleased store fronts are being used as temporary art galleries. George Mansfield, an artist who designed and helped to develop the space, said: ''When you say 'mall,' people think chain stores, color schemes, matching signs. That's not what this is about. The idea was to create an intimate, inviting place -- a center for the community, not just a place to shop.'' NANCY MACDONELL SMITH

The election is over and it is time for Republicans and Democrats to work together.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE

The warm, touching cinematic retracing of the quarter-century path to friendship between Miss Daisy, a wealthy Jewish Atlanta widow, and Hoke Colburn, the black chauffeur hired for her by her son, won the Academy Award for best picture. It also won Oscars for Jessica Tandy as best actress and for Mr Uhryfor his adaptation, as well as Oscar nominations for organ Freeman as Hoke and Dan Aykroyd as Miss daisy's son - Sunday at 8 p.m on Channel 9.

title: Travel Advisory; Scythian Treasures To Tour U.S. Museums
description: For 400 years the Scythians, a tribe of nomadic horsemen, ruled over the European steppe stretching from the Danube, east across what is now Ukraine and into Russia, with their reign reaching its height more than 2,500 years ago. Among the legacies of their culture is some of the most accomplished gold artwork ever produced.

His hands fly from the cash register to the computer to the videos stacked behind him and then to the push-button clicker he keeps around his neck to buzz the door open for the steady flow of customers.

I like a nice, hearty blaze in the fireplace over the holidays, and small tests in early December had suggested that a hearty blaze might end in a total conflagration of the house and all its inhabitants. Smoke puffed back into the living room, the fire refused to draw, and the smell of roast squirrel filled the air. It was time to call the sweep.

So when Ghostface Killah, a member of the rap collective Wu Tang Clan, set out to make the video for his single ''Apollo Kids,'' he included the things held closest to his heart: a silver Mercedes sedan, beautiful women in skimpy black bikinis, and his very own Clarks Wallabee shoe factory.

With Oprah's Book Club, there is no organization to join, and Winfrey doesn't sell or send her readers the books. The club is simply a way for Winfrey to include novelists in the mix of her show: ideal kitchens, Brad Pitt, the septuplets' birthday . . . and now, Wally Lamb or Toni Morrison!

A maker of software used to manage the sale of digital content like music, InterTrust has a clever business plan, strong partners and respected management. The shares took off, closing at $187.25 on Dec. 8, buoyed by positive analyst reports from three of the four brokerage firms that underwrote the offering.

Responsible for the seamless shift is Vasco Cabral, the new owner and still the maitre d'hotel, as he has been almost since this restaurant's inception. He remains a charming and professional presence -- welcoming guests and seeing that service runs smoothly.

title: A Money Player in A Power Town

Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, sits in the front row of his personal luxury box, and after almost every play he jumps out of his chair, yells something at the field, hitches up his pants and takes a swig from his bottle of Evian. The routine is followed throughout the game with the Buffalo Bills: jump, yell, hitch, swig, jump, yell, hitch, swig.

Designed in the familiar style of current road signs, they carry images of long ago, such as a wigwam or a Colonial house, as well as logos that still apply today, like a boat launching or a deer-crossing symbol.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Since designating Los Angeles International Airport as a hub last spring, United Airlines has been steadily expanding its West Coast operations. In September the airline inaugurated direct nonstop service between Sacramento and Washington and between Los Angeles and Dallas, Houston and Atlanta. In addition, service from Los Angeles to Miami and Orlando and from San Jose to Washington was expanded. At the end of October shuttle service using 737's was introduced from Los Angeles to Santa Barbara, Palm Springs and San Diego, and -- outside the state -- to Reno and Medford, in southwest Oregon. There are two round-trip shuttles to Medford every day, three to Reno, four to Santa Barbara and Palm Springs, and seven to San Diego.

title: Ivory Coast Coup Draws French Reply

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; New York Transformations
description: ''The city is like poetry,'' E. B. White wrote of Manhattan: ''it compresses all life, all races and breeds, into a small island and adds music and the accompaniment of internal engines.'' NEW YORK: An Illustrated History (Knopf, $60) is a fit metaphor for a great metropolis -- big enough for two laps, it can easily fill a winter of reading and browsing. In addition to the authors, Ric Burns and James Sanders, and the picture editor, Lisa Ades, the book lists a team of contributing historians: Carol Berkin, Marshall Berman, Robert A. Caro, Daniel Czitrom, Kenneth T. Jackson, David Levering Lewis, Phillip Lopate, Robert A. M. Stern and Mike Wallace. The book is, as such collaborations go, narratively crisp, balanced and well researched, with room for everyone from Washington Irving to Allen Ginsberg and from Emma Lazarus to Le Corbusier to have a say, but without any particular authorial voice or tone. The illustrations, many published for the first time, are the glory of the book, capturing a sense of the city changing and evolving, spreading over and transforming -- many times. From the cover photograph of bright intersections shining out of the nighttime grid of the city, to the back cover photo of a crowd inside the golden glow of Pennsylvania Station, this ravishing book is the visual equivalent of the poem White describes, ''whose magic is comprehensible to millions of permanent residents -- but whose full meaning will always remain elusive.'' David Walton

title: 1999: THE YEAR IN REVIEW - THEATER; It's a Wonder He Had Time to Become Shakespeare
description: ELIZABETHANS had rudimentary and childlike needs when they went to the theater. But, like audiences today, they also wanted to be gripped. Acquainted with basic, well-known plots, more often than not they would ask themselves, ''What will they make of the story this time?'' To become a devilishly clever manipulator of familiar tales, to weave together two or three of them at a time, this was the height of mastery for an aspiring playwright. ''We will do it in action,'' says Peter Quince, the bookkeeper, or prompter, in ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' though more often than not the words were the action.

title: Thinking Globally, Artists on AIDS
description: EVER since there has been an AIDS epidemic there has been art about it. At first artists were trying to make sense of the mysterious virus, and to build a sense of community and shared grief.

title: 2 Killed, 4 Hurt In Brooklyn Fires
description: A 90-year-old woman was critically injured and her 15-year-old grandson was also hurt yesterday morning after a Christmas tree caught fire in their apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn, officials said.

title: December 19-25; Flooding in Venezuela
description: Instead of celebrating the adoption of a new Constitution, Venezuela spent the week digging out from under the worst natural disaster in its modern history. Massive landslides and flooding brought on by torrential rains displaced more than 150,000 people, but with so many still missing, the death toll from the calamity may never be known: the government's own estimates range from less than 500 to more than 25,000 dead. LARRY ROHTER

Described as ''part library, part technology center,'' by Dr. Dennis J. Murray, the college's president, the $19.6 million facility marks the first time in the school's 70-year history that a campus building has been designed as a library.

title: Misfortune in Our Midst
description: In this season of prosperity and good cheer, it is worth considering the images of need that we live with day by day. The familiarity of the misery right among us often has the unfortunate effect of blurring its reality. Sometimes it seems easier to act charitably toward people who have suffered calamitously in other places than to do so in the city we call our own. But the conditions that are often most debasing to the human spirit are not the swift, abrupt earthquakes or floods but the chronic misfortunes that are the slow, certain consequence of poverty, ill health, mental instability, or a critical lack of opportunity.

description: THE 1990's were the decade of the Polo Grill. This opulent dining room, in the lobby of the Garden City Hotel, has set the standard for sumptuous hotel dining on the Island. It was not always so. In the early years of the hotel's current incarnation (the 1980's), it had two restaurants: the somewhat casual Polo Grill and a more formal back room, where the cuisine changed over the years from haute French to upscale Italian to elegant seafood.

title: The Pesky Job of Repairing Corners
description: MANY do-it-yourselfers are unsure how to repair damaged corners on wallboard. There are two types of wall corners: outside corners that jut out into a doorway or hall and inside corners that are recessed in the angle between two walls or a wall and the ceiling.

title: The Times Capsule
description: As much as I enjoyed the articles in the Times Capsule issue, what I found most interesting was the message you sent to those who will be looking at this issue in the year 3000. Of the 214 pages, 138 were either full- or partial-page ads (not to mention the 28 pages of inserts). I can't imagine a better way to depict American culture in 1999. (Note to readers in 3000: you know all those tall, frail, pouty-lipped women you see throughout the magazine? They're what we called ''supermodels.'' And although they may appear malnourished, fear not; we took good care of them.)

title: Help With That Perfect Gift
description: Even deep-pocketed executives stumble in buying the right Christmas gift for their spouses. Al Piergallini, head of worldwide consumer health at Novartis in Summit, N.J., acknowledges having even more trouble than most. ''I always try to to find out what my wife really wants,'' he said, ''but it is very difficult for me to buy Christmas presents for women.''

title: Back to Aluminum Bats For the State's Colleges
description: The ping of the bat will ring out again at college baseball games in New Jersey, after state officials reversed a November 1998 decision to switch from metal to wood bats. Following a finding by the National Collegiate Athletic Association that metal bats are safe, the state Board of Athletic Administrators voted unanimously last month to follow suit, said Donna Ledwin, commissioner of the New Jersey Athletic Conference. Metal bats hit the ball faster than wooden ones, which some fear jeopardizes infielders. They also hit balls farther, and Ms. Ledwin said the board, made up of representatives of the 10 colleges in the athletic conference, felt that banning them would put New Jersey teams at a disadvantage in games against out-of-state opponents, when the bats would be permitted. STEVE STRUNSKY

The combined 50,000 miles of track would stretch from Nova Scotia to the Gulf of Mexico, linking lumber and coal markets in Canada to oil and chemical plants in Texas. Robert Krebs, chairman of Burlington Northern, said consumers will benefit from lower costs because of the combined company's ability to send goods nonstop over long distances. CHARLES V. BAGLI

They stretch, skate and even shimmy a bit before breaking into groups for their lessons.

Pandora fell prey to temptation and missed her opportunity; a thousand years hence, let's hope we will have learned enough to resist taking a peek.

title: In Istanbul, a Biennial Offers the Solace of Art
description: ROME was ever Rome, and thus counts as eternal. Istanbul bears a more recent name, but its history as Constantinople and Byzantium goes back just as far. Here is a city that has seen it all. By comparison, New York was born yesterday. Which may account for the uproar over Chris Ofili's ''Holy Virgin Mary'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art's much-scrutinized and reviled show ''Sensation.'' Could the same thing have happened on the Bosporus? As it happens, Mr. Ofili was among the 56 artists from 32 countries invited to the sixth International Istanbul Biennial this fall (Sept. 17-Oct. 30). His hip, jazzy pieces gave the catalog its most eye-catching pages. His unorthodox materials went unremarked. Sacred or sacrilegious, this, too, would pass.

title: Correcting the Record On Westchester History
description: Regarding the article ''A Village Here, a Village There. But Why?'' [Special Issue: The Best of Westchester, Nov. 21] it would be nice to think that in today's quaint-looking villages, civic pride and the desire to stay out of New York City had inspired the formation of Westchester's many villages. But the historical record simply does not bear this out. In fact, Westchester lost the entire southern portion to New York City without protest. We ended up today with 17 towns, 22 villages, 6 cities, 90 hamlets, 59 fire districts, 40 school districts and a tangle of other districts for other reasons entirely.

description: SHACTER-Jean (nee Heller), of Delray Beach, FL and Manhasset, NY, passed away on December 21, 1999 at her home in Delray Beach. She was the beloved wife of the late Charles Banks Shacter and the cherished mother of Carol and Peter Romanow and the late Bobbi Shaw. Mrs. Shacter was the adored ''Nana'' of Marc and Allison Romanow, Paula and Kevin Romanow Etzel, Allison Shaw, Merry Taylor Martensson, Leigh Sanders, Keith Shaw and the late and treasured Misty. title: The Curse Of Blood and Vengeance
description: By conservative estimate, at least 200 people witnessed the murder of Shtjefen Lamthi in Shkoder, the northernmost city of Albania, early on the afternoon of Aug. 3, 1998. The 43-year-old farmer was walking south along Zyhdi Lahi Street, one of the main thoroughfares of the Rus marketplace in downtown Shkoder, his hands weighted down with plastic bags filled with his day's purchases. Just in front of a small tobacco kiosk at the northwest corner of Rus Square, a burly man who looked to be in his mid-30's suddenly stepped into Lamthi's path, brought up a Kalashnikov assault rifle, shot him 21 times and walked away. None of the witnesses came forward to identify the killer. Instead, a wall of silence immediately descended. Today, 16 months later, Lamthi's murder remains officially unsolved, despite the fact that almost everyone knows exactly who killed him. A strange event, but not in Albania.

title: No Retreat on Clean Air
description: Early last summer, clean-air advocates were on the run. Back-to-back rulings in May by conservative, anti-regulatory judges in the Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit had shredded much of the administration's air pollution strategy, invalidating tough new federal health standards and blocking efforts to reduce smog in the eastern half of the United States. But in some mysterious way the ruling seemed to stiffen the resolve of federal and state officials, and ever since then the big polluters have been the ones on the run. In the last week alone, the Clinton administration issued several major rulings that will require big investments by the oil, automobile and utility companies to reduce smog-causing chemicals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEN, WALTER
description: TURKEN-Walter, age 67 of Naples, Florida and Bedford, New York died Wednesday, December 22, 1999 in his Naples home. Born in Jersey City, NJ, he graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania and later served in the U.S. Air Force. He was a Certified Public Acountant and then became a Real Estate Developer. He is survived by, and was the beloved husband of, Jane (Parker) Turken, two children Randi (Michael) Cannon and Risa Turken both of New York City; three step-children Kim (Jordan) Dickstein of New York City, John (Lisa) Reisman of Naples, FL. and Jill (Brett) Fischer of New York City; eight grandchildren, Zachary, Juliette and Jack Cannon, Ben and Joey Dickstein, Julia and Jayda Reisman and Jake Fischer: Sister, Joyce Postal of Naples, FL; Father-in-law and mother-in-law Norma and Jack Parker of New York City and Boca Raton, FL; Sister-inlaw and brother-in-law Nancy and Robert Magoon of Aspen, CO; and niece Jane Palmese of New York City. A memorial service will be held on a later date to be announced. Donations in his memory may be made to The Walter Turken Foundation For Stray Dogs Training And Adoption, Inc. 9400 Gladiolus Drive, Fort Myers, Florida 33908.

title: A 'Pianist'? Less, Perhaps, and More
description: IN his 1869 pamphlet ''On Conducting,'' a classic text on the art of musical interpretation, Richard Wagner complained that performances of the keyboard works of Bach were diluted by a misguided ''smoothness'' and ''mildness,'' that ''there was no trace of somber German Gothicism.'' In frustration, Wagner reports, he begged his friend Liszt ''to cleanse my musical soul of these painful impressions.'' Liszt complied by playing the Prelude and Fugue in C sharp minor from the first book of ''The Well-Tempered Clavier.'' With this single performance, Wagner concludes, ''Liszt revealed Bach to me.''

title: OUT THERE/London; Knocking the Stuffy Out of Private Clubs
description: VISITORS to Home House could be forgiven for supposing that they are crossing the hallowed portals of a traditional gentlemen's club, one of those temples to upper-class masculinity that have played a key role in London life since the 17th century.

title: Laurels for a Stately Symbol In Granite, Bronze and Slate

title: Issues Behind Issues In Single-Sex Swimming
description: The Town of Hempstead recently rejected a proposal that would have accommodated Orthodox Jews (whose modesty laws prohibit men and women from bathing together) by designating certain swim times at a public pool ''single sex only'' [''Debating Who's Going to Swim, and When,'' Dec. 12]. The proposal was rejected because town authorities were concerned that catering to religious beliefs would have violated federal and state laws. Arguably their concern was misplaced if, as a local civic group contended, the purpose of the proposal was not to inject a religious issue into a public pool, but to accommodate as many people as possible. However, accommodation would also be inappropriate if the religious practice were imbued with ultra-conservative belief about women.

title: The Times Capsule
description: My congratulations, both on your Times Capsule issue and on the capsule itself. At the end of this year I will be opening a time capsule sealed in an egg-shaped pantyhose container by a 12-year-old in the early 1980's, and addressed to his 30-year-old self in 2000. Next year, my fiancee and I plan to create a 50-year capsule, continuing my lifelong interest in these simple, wonderful time machines.

title: New York Starts to Look Beyond Its Past
description: WHEN the Arkansas state flag was run up the pole at City Hall this summer, New Yorkers were finally forced to acknowledge the fact that our mayor is campaigning against the city he was elected to serve The campaign has continued with assaults on neighborhood parks, the Brooklyn Museum of Art and the right to exercise free speech on the steps of City Hall. This hostility toward creative life -- the soul of New York -- could have the effect of a wake-up call. Our long day-dream of complacency, our willingness to take culture for granted, could be coming to an end. This would have a major impact on the city's architecture. For too long, this art form has been riding on the coattails of architectural preservation instead of generating the forward movement on which a great city's vitality depends. This year, however, brought a few welcome signs that New York's architecture may be rousing itself from its Sleeping Beauty coma.

description: BY now, the original headquarters of the New York Yacht Club has logged almost as many sea miles as some club members.

title: Fierce 'Woolf,' Joyous 'Contact,' Classic 'Salesman'
description: AN 80-year-old actress sheds decades to become a fierce middle-aged tigress with unsheathed claws; classic dramas shed decades of accumulated tarnish to glimmer like newly polished silver, and even the American musical sheds its decades-old status as an endangered species, with shows that instead reflected its singular role as a mood elevator.

title: The Nation: Ad-In; But What if Bradley Had Called Gore's Bluff?
description: ON one level, Vice President Al Gore's proposal to scrap all 30-second television spots in favor of twice-weekly debates with former Senator Bill Bradley was just what the senator said it was: a campaign ploy. To be sure, it was a modestly imaginative gambit that seemed to annoy Mr. Bradley by making him defend the political system he prefers to deplore.

title: Corrections
description: The Your Home column last Sunday, about extended-stay lodgings, misspelled the surname of the marketing manager of Manhattan East Suite Hotels, who described the company's facilities. She is Jennifer Colman, not Coleman.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/A Squad of Rockettes; 'Chorus Line,' Part 2
description: TO our day off!'' said Jaime Windrow, raising her cosmopolitan.

title: The Sound and the Furniture: A Band and a Lawsuit
description: When NBC invited the band then known as Lazy Boy to play on an episode of ''Homicide,'' its guitarist, Stephen Ulrich, thought he had staged a coup. Sales of the band's independently produced CD soared after the trio's self-described ''twangy, lurid, primeval, mournful, rocking, reverb-drenched instrumentals'' were sent into the living rooms of several million Americans in 1996.

title: The Graphic Designer
description: ''When I saw the sequins on it, I knew it was for me,'' said Baree Fehrenbach, 38, referring to her azalea-pink wool hat ($55) by Antik Batik from Tracey Feith at 209 Mulberry Street (Spring Street). ''The sequins make people smile. They're unexpected.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sea Cliff, N.Y.; Walkable, Victorian On L.I. Sound
description: THERE are no stoplights in Sea Cliff, a close-together, square-mile North Shore Long Island Victorian and Gothic village that has escaped the tyranny of the automobile by virtue of pedestrian-friendly narrow streets, veneration of the past and a just slightly out of the way harborside location.

title: The Nation; Behind One Man's Mind
description: TREATING mental illness is not one of society's big priorities, and public policy in the field often gets made in strange, circuitous ways. Last June the president held the first White House conference on mental illness; this month, Dr. David Satcher released the first surgeon general's report on the subject.

title: RUSSIA ARMY OPENS FIGHT TO CONTROL CHECHEN CAPITAL
description: Russian forces advanced into Grozny today, as what was billed as the decisive battle for the capital of Chechnya got under way.

title: Football Player Nears Two Goals
description: TRE JOHNSON, the Washington Redskins starting guard who grew up in Peekskill, is closing in on two firsts in his sixth season in the National Football League: the playoffs and all-pro status.

title: At Stony Brook, Study of Alternative Medicine Faces Skeptics
description: JOSHUA KANNER of Merrick was already sitting on the examining table when Sam Benjamin arrived, hugged his 5-year-old patient, asked Joshua's mother, Gail, about her son's progress since their last visit, and then carefully inserted several fine needles into the boy's hands and legs.

description: Correction Appended

title: Fireworks in Venice, an Ice Floe in Antarctica
description: LET'S get the lists out of the way first. The year's handsomest shows of old art, by medium: bronzes by the sculptor Adriaen de Vries at the Getty, drawings and paintings by Ingres, and photographs by Carleton Watkins, both at the Metropolitan. The biggest surprise of the year: Frank Hurley's photographs, at the American Museum of Natural History, from Ernest Shackleton's epic 1914 expedition to Antarctica, one of the great stories of modern exploration, which turned out to have produced remarkable pictures of the end of the earth.

title: Ideas & Trends; Look What's Hot A Hundred Years From Now
description: ''LIFE is short,'' Hippocrates once said. ''Art is long.''

title: New York, When They Were Young
description: AS the millennium draws to a close, a handful of New Yorkers prepare to enter their second century. Born in the 1890's, in the waning years of the Victorian era, they survived the turbulence of the 20th century and now, in their 11th decade, they prepare for the 21st.

title: Americans' Secret Deal Shows a Trap for Russia's Transition
description: A few years ago, when an American company was seeking a toehold in the newly privatized and potentially lucrative Russian telecommunications market, it cut a secret deal with directors and officers at the Moscow telephone company.

title: Word for Word/Seasonal Scolding; Flying Corks, Killer Poinsettias And Other Holiday Hazards
description: IT'S the peak of the holiday season, and the air is filled with apocalyptic warnings tied to the turn of the millennium. But there is plenty more to worry about than serious threats like terrorism, doomsday cults and Y2K calamities.

title: West Side Isn't Manhasset. That's the Point.
description: To the Editor:

title: A United Nations Of Queens Choices
description: 18 DE JULIO +

title: Style; Little Women
description: Do you think porcelain figurines are hopelessly stuffy? Do you think of them only as part of your great-aunt's ''don't touch'' living-room decor? Do you think of them at all? Well, that's about to change, and you have Ann Agee to thank for it.

title: December 19-25; Tracking Bullets
description: Gun advocates like to say that it's people who kill, not guns. Others say it's bullets that kill: If you can trace them, you might find the shooters. The White House has advocated the creation of a computerized catalog of the distinctive markings that each gun leaves on discharged shell casings. Such a system ''has the potential to do for gun crime what fingerprints have done for forensics,'' said Bruce Reed, the administration's domestic policy adviser. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-26-99: Shoptalk: Year 2000 Problem; Who Built the Y2K Bug?
description: Amid all the speculation about what miseries the Y2K bug might or might not bring, one question has been overlooked: Who is to blame? Didn't anyone worry about this back when the basic systems that govern computers were being built? And if so, why did no one build them right the first time? We gathered some of the leading engineers of the 1970's for a bit of millennial hindsight.

title: At Least E-Tailing Works in High Places
description: Even President Clinton, for the first time, shopped online this holiday season. Not surprisingly, he hasn't reported the delivery problems that some constituents have had.

title: Japanese Offer Limited Experience and Unlimited Desire
description: When their fair-haired Australian captain barks the commands in his native tongue, many of them don't understand a word. They are racing in sailing's most visible and prestigious event against a field of multifaceted sailors who have tasted success aboard everything from dinghies to maxi-boats, yet several of them have never trimmed a sail on anything other than an International America's Cup Class yacht.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYNES, JOHN M., PH.D.
description: HAYNES-John M., Ph.D., of Northport, NY, on December 22, 1999, of leukemia. Survived by Gretchen, his daughters, Karen and Julia, and grandchildren, Charlotte and Oliver. John was the founding president of the Academy of Family Mediators and an international trainer of mediators and court personnel. He was also a prolific author of journal articles and three books. A memorial service is to be held on January 16 at 2:00 PM at Westbury Friends Meeting, Westbury, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to a memorial scholarship fund at The Union Institute in Cincinnati, Ohio.

title: Three Metropolitan Area Teams, and None Figure to Go Very Far
description: National Hockey League crowds usually grow larger and louder around Christmas, as winter officially arrives and division races take shape. Nearing the halfway point of the schedule, the good teams have made themselves obvious and so have the bad ones. Even struggling teams still hope to salvage their seasons with the right trades or line changes. As for fans, people are off work, the kids are home from school and the relatives come around. Why not take in a game?

title: Norman E. Rothstein, 63, Broadway Producer
description: Norman E. Rothstein, a producer and general manager for more than 40 years on and Off Broadway and in the national and international theater, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: Click and Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTA, SANDY
description: KURTA-Sandy. We will always remember you. You were a very gifted man. Fay and Allen

title: SPOTLIGHT; Soap Stardom May Be Just a Click Away
description: It wasn't the allure of being on television, or the promise of a fancy designer wardrobe, or the chance to hobnob with the beautiful people of the tiny town of Harmony. No, I wanted to be on ''Passions'' for one reason only: to rescue a town that was spiraling out of control.

title: Liability On a Lease After Death
description: Q. Five months ago I signed a lease guarantee to help my friend qualify for an apartment rental. My friend has since died and the landlord is claiming that I must fulfill the tenant's rent obligations for the remainder of the lease. The pledge I signed says that I guarantee the strict performance of the lease and that I agree to be equally liable with the tenant so that the landlord can sue me directly without first suing the tenant. It doesn't say anything about what happens if the tenant dies. What are my legal obligations as guarantor? . . . Ronald Kargan Jr., Manhattan.

title: As Memory Itself Runs Out of Time
description: In 1975, when my father was my age, he had a bronze plate engraved with his name and two dates. ''Edward Lynch,'' it read, ''1924-1999.'' He put it on a bronze casket in our casket showroom to demonstrate how the up-market units could be customized. It was a sales aid. He was a funeral director. So am I.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the rush to have plastic surgery before the millennium misstated the given name of a doctor shown in a consultation. He was Alan Matarasso, not James.

description: CATHY SMITH was willing to leave her distinguished old house in Ridgefield, Conn., with its two acres, mature lavender bushes, swimming pool and guest house and move to New York City so her husband, Geoff, a financial journalist, could be closer to his work.

description: For Budding Baritones

title: The Times Capsule
description: It is not the things placed inside the capsule that will afford our descendants the greatest insight into our age but rather the information regarding the role that things played in our lives. As an example, a lipstick tube would say little about us. But a panoramic photograph of the cosmetics floor at Bloomingdale's would tell us much -- a thousand or more lipsticks alone to choose from, with more reds, plums and pinks than one could ever imagine existed.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JIM STRUPP; Thinking Smaller About Beer
description: WHAT does Platinum Holdings see in the also-rans of the beer business?

title: Happy Events in the Year Gone By
description: IT is again time for a look at the highlights of the year. Among other events were initiatives, openings, new appointments and happenings bearing the optimistic designation ''first annual.''

title: Army's Fire Island Study: Send in the Sand
description: EVER since storms in the early 1990's ravaged dunes and inundated their beaches and summer houses, landowners in the 17 private summer communities on Fire Island have been crying out for relief.

title: Singing in the New Year, for Spenders Big and Small
description: IF you were Cher, where would you be on New Year's Eve? Or Tony Orlando. Or Brenda Lee.

title: Like Galaxies In a Suburban Universe
description: WHILE the tiniest apartment can be trimmed in holiday lights, it takes a suburban environment -- bigger houses, and especially lawns -- to really bring out the megalomaniac in the homeowner with a penchant for seasonal decoration and kilowatts to burn.

title: Lives Lived Well And the Lessons That They Teach
description: THEY never made the cover of People magazine. Sometimes they didn't even make headlines in their community's weekly newspaper.

title: The Future Looks Gloomy for a Popular Greenmarket
description: In the film ''You've Got Mail,'' Kathleen Kelly and Joe Fox, rival booksellers and cyberflirts played by Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks, stroll through the Verdi Square greenmarket. Kathleen buys a clutch of lilies of the valley, Joe chooses a mango and pretzels, and the film evokes (relentlessly) an Upper West Side with small-town, neighborly charm.

title: Ideas & Trends; Even in the Best of Times, The Ultimate Consumer Fix
description: AMERICANS are clearly of two minds when it comes to shopping at the fin de millennium. Their appetite for luxury goods has never been greater. The big sellers this holiday season -- cashmere, diamond pendants and DVD players -- also speak to pampered sensibilities.

title: December 19-25; Arrest at the U.S. Border Points to a Terrorist Ring
description: When a customs agent began asking questions at a remote ferry boat border crossing near Seattle, the nervous driver, Ahmed Ressam, bolted. His car contained timing devices and enough explosive chemicals to level a building. By the week's end, the Algerian from Canada's immigrant underground was at the center of a spreading international investigation of an Islamic gangster-terrorist ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, BENJAMIN
description: ISRAEL-Benjamin. On December 22, 1999 at age 95. Adored husband of Ruth for 65 years, loving and devoted father of Felicia, Ira and Paul, father-in-law of Arthur, Mora and Beverly, precious grandfather of Steven, Michael and Shoshanna, Brian, Bonnie, P.J., Michael, Joel and Sarah. Cherished greatgrandfather of Lucas. Benny was a unique and memorable individual whose hallmark was honor, truth and generosity of spirit. He was loved immeasureably and will be greatly missed. Burial Sunday, 10:00 AM, Floral Park Cemetery, Deans, New Jersey. A memorial service will be held at the Village Temple, 33 E. 12th St., New York City, Monday, 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Adults and Children With Learning Disabilities, Bethpage, NY or God's Love We Deliver, NYC.

title: At Midnight Mass, a Thankful O'Connor Reflects
description: Weakened by illness and close to retirement, Cardinal John O'Connor was determined to celebrate midnight Mass with New Yorkers yesterday, perhaps for the last time, and so all week he husbanded his limited energy.

title: Our Towns; In a Setting Most Unlikely, Seasonal Oasis
description: HOLIDAY travel sounds like something you might do while wearing a party hat and sipping one of those drinks with an umbrella stuck in it.

title: Carrying Tune Is Easy. Carrying Her Tuba is Hard.
description: What's the hardest thing about playing the tuba?

title: Fleeing New Year's Eve
description: I WANT to believe that I'm a free spirit, immune to social conventions, but I have an obsession with New Year's Eve. Ever since my parents let my brother and sister and me stay up until midnight and bang pots and pans while they waltzed into the night in ball gown and tuxedo, I've felt compelled to have a magical evening. But my karma just isn't right. In high school, when I finally had a boyfriend who invited me out for a night on the town, there was a blizzard and we wound up snowbound at my house playing foosball with my brother. I went 30 years without being invited to a good party.

title: Issues Behind Issues In Single-Sex Swimming
description: I agree that no one religious group should have preferential treatment when it comes to public institutions. But I would strongly urge those who oppose bringing religion into public life to open their eyes and minds to the fact that as long as our taxes pay for a ''nation's Christmas tree,'' fire trucks driving around with Santa throwing candy, nativity scenes or menorahs, or even public schools having holiday assemblies, there is never going to be a true separation of religion and state.

title: If This Is Brooklyn, Why Ever Leave?
description: THERE is something that feels a little illicit about checking into a neighborhood hotel for a weekend, even if the man you are checking in with is your own husband. But we can see a bit of the building that contains the New York Marriott Brooklyn from the back of our house, and we are curious.

title: The Hunt for Cybercrime
description: TRACKING down embezzlers, computer hackers, money launderers, shady stock promoters and other white-collar criminals may lack the pizazz of James Bond outwitting Goldfinger or decapitating Oddjob.

title: Scandal and Greed Make Room for the Richness of Victory
description: There was a certain fin de siecle urgency to the past year, the sensation of rushing willy-nilly toward some brave new sports world even more expensive, aggressive, chemical and hyperbolic than the past.

title: December 19-25; Have Wrench, Will Travel, Once Again to the Hubble
description: America's eye to the universe is opening again. The Hubble Space Telescope is fixed and should be back in business shortly after the first of the year, project officials say. Teams of spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Discovery swarmed over the observatory. They replaced the faulty gyroscopes that last month forced Hubble into hibernation when it couldn't point itself properly, and updated other equipment. After a rocky year, NASA was ending the millennium with a success. WARREN E. LEARY

title: A Room of Their Own: Girls Club Seeks a City-Owned Site
description: Ten-year-old Amanda Wright mingled on the steps of City Hall last week with a dozen of her friends.

title: Betty Cage, 82, Quiet Force Behind City Ballet
description: Betty Cage, an administrator of the New York City Ballet who played a quiet but important role in creating the company, died on Sunday at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. She was 82 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Charlotte Unstained
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROHN, MICHAEL HERBERT
description: CROHN-Michael Herbert, on Friday, December 24th, 1999 at home. Beloved son of Janet and George. Loving companion to Marian O'Neill. Dear brother to Jeffrey and Kathleen. Special uncle to Nolan and Leah. Michael was a truly remarkable person who touched the lives of many. He fought a courageous battle over a long time against the devastating diseases Dysautonomia and Muscular Dystrophy. Michael will be deeply missed by his friends and co-workers as well as countless cousins and family members. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY, on Monday, December 27th, at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Foundation for Jewish Genetic Diseases, 250 Park Ave., NY, NY 10017 or Dysautonomia Association, 20 East 46th Street, #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYSON, JOHN BARNES
description: TYSON-John Barnes. Died after a long illness on December 19, 1999 in Richmond, Virginia. He was 64. He is survived by his brother, Michael M. Tyson of Santa Fe, NM, a sister, Posy Beer of Farmington, CT, a half-brother, Anthony Tyson of Easthampton, NY, and a halfsister, Holly Tyson of Key West, FL. A private family service will held. Contributions may be made in his memory to: Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, N.H. 03833.

title: Imagine 'Riverdance' via the Danube
description: THE Budapest Ensemble calls its touring folk dance program ''Csardas: The Tango of the East.'' A producer of the show readily volunteers comparisons with the popular Irish revue ''Riverdance.'' Clearly, a few bets are being hedged here. But scratch the surface of the marketing campaign and genuine passion and pride are quickly evident. The csardas is not only the Hungarian national dance, but also an embodiment of Hungarian soul and the country's respect for dance in all forms.

title: The Times Capsule
description: Taking a look into the future, all the way to the year 3000, I predict that archaeologists will be fascinated by the contents of the Times Capsule issue. Their fascination, however, will ultimately turn to rage when they decipher David Letterman's ''Top 10 List to Last'' and prematurely learn the surprise ending of ''The Sixth Sense.''

title: $850,000 to Museum
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and State Senator Nicholas A. Spano have announced that $350,000 in state aid has been made available for a permanent exhibition, titled ''Hudson Riverama,'' at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. In addition to the money from the governor and Senator Spano, the National Science Foundation has committed $500,000 to the project.

title: Burlington Wants Big Tower In the Pinelands
description: Burlington County says it needs a 275-foot tower in the environmentally sensitive Pinelands to upgrade its aging emergency management communications system. The problem is, there is a 200-foot height limit in the area.

title: Sports of The Times; John Rocker's Persona and 'Corporate Synergy'
description: I'VE been mulling over rational explanations for why John Rocker would so willingly stand up in front of the world to model the naked truth about his fundamental life tenets, if that's what they really are. I've been wondering what -- besides stupidity that is almost beyond belief -- would induce a young man on the brink of stardom to volunteer his neck for a national tomahawk chop?
