description: A Jerk on One End

title: Suffrage in Kuwait
description: To the Editor:

title: A Seamstress Sues Donna Karan, Claiming Retaliation for a Lawsuit
description: On one of the busiest shopping days of the year, a rowdy crowd gathered outside the Donna Karan store on Madison Avenue near 60th Street. But the several dozen people who spilled into the street last Sunday weren't trying to stuff their stockings with $1,000 jackets. Instead, they burned DKNY shirts and waved signs with slogans like ''Donna Karan: Sweatshop Queen.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFIN, GEORGE M.
description: JAFFIN-George M. Adored and beloved husband of Janet, loving father of Doris Greenberg, Lois Levine and David Jaffin. Caring father-in-law of Lee Greenberg and Rosemarie Jaffin. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan Greenberg, Walter Greenberg, Matthew Greenberg, Daniella Cava, Julie Levine, Carl Levine, Raphael Jaffin and Andreas Jaffin. Loving great-grandfather of Eliza Cava, Teddy Cava, Aron Cava, and Aron Noah Jaffin. His memory will be a blessing because he was a blessing to us and so many others. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 26, 12 Noon, at Kol Ami Synagogue, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: David and Maddie, So Young
description: IT was a match made in hell: she with the cool gaze and the silky long legs, he with the rhythm-and-blues soul and that incessant smirk. And from the moment Bruce Willis called Cybill Shepherd a rude five-letter name and she returned the compliment with a quick hand across his face, viewers were smitten by the bickering sweethearts and their television love nest, ''Moonlighting.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODFLIESH, CHARLES
description: GOODFLIESH-Charles. Died Saturday, December 4. Retired from Town and Country Shoes, Inc. Served in World War II with honor. Survived by wife Anne, children Robert, Marsha, Philip, Larry and Elise, their spouses and grandchildren Sandra, Greg, Ronald, Michael, Jacob, Sharon, Deborah and great-grandchildren Brandon and Nicole. He was loved and will be missed.

title: INSIDE
description: Tension in Ivory Coast

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Turning a Factory Site Into Mixed-Use Development
description: FOR nearly 10 years the former Lily Tulip plant, where Dixie cups were once made, stood empty -- a million-square-foot industrial hulk at the corner of Route 35 and Laurel Avenue in the Monmouth County community of Holmdel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRAW, ANNE SCHUYLER WILLIAMS
description: McGRAW-Anne Schuyler Williams. Of Gulf Stream, FL and of Wianno, MA., passed away on December 22, 1999 after a long illness with cancer. She was married to Donald C. McGraw, Jr. for over 50 years and had four sons, Donald III, Robert, David and the late Peter McGraw plus thirteen grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on August 8, 2000 at 11AM at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, MA 02655. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to either St. Peter's Episcopal Church or St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 188 S. Swinton Avenue, Delray Beach, FL. 33444. For information contact Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Cute As a Button
description: Marjorie Nezin is that rare person who dresses to her own beat. If you're on the street in Midtown or on the benefit circuit, you may have seen her and wondered who she was and what she was wearing. The dresses are a form of patchwork, made of 1,000 to 8,000 small circular scraps of fabric, each stitched around the edge and pulled in to a button-size puff. The puffs are variously called yoyos, periwinkles or Suffolk puffs.

title: 1 Killed and 3 Hurt In Gunfire at 3 Bars
description: One man was killed and three were injured yesterday in shootings at bars in Brooklyn and Queens, the police said.

title: Your Home; Deadlines For Meters Approach
description: NEW YORK CITY property owners who have not installed water meters in their buildings -- and there are still tens of thousands who fall into that category -- have some serious thinking to do about how to address a couple of hard deadlines set by the city and thereby avoid surcharges that could double their water bills starting in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKOWSKY, LIBBIE
description: BURKOWSKY-Libbie. Fairwell to our beautiful, sweet, loving Libbie. Mother to daughter Carol and sonin-law Ezra, grandmother to Nina, Danny, Richie and wife Geeta, Lisa and husband Geovanny, and three most wonderful great grandchildren, Joel, Rachel and Naava. We will miss her dearly.

title: Thomas Loses Cool And Knicks Lose Game
description: There was enough adrenaline and emotion pushing the vengeful Indiana Pacers along tonight without a foolish nudge supplied by the Knicks' Kurt Thomas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRAGE, BERNARD
description: SCHRAGE-Bernard. Of Jersey City, NJ. On Friday, December 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Anita. Devoted father of Alvin and Howell. Proud grandfather of Ezra, Joseph, Jonathan and David. Dear brother of Shirley. Services 12:45 PM, today, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., corner of Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Where to Get Green Eggs. (The Ham Is Not Included.)
description: If you've come to 572 Pascack Street in Washington Township, Bergen County, to have your antique clock repaired by Russell Andrews, you may notice the chickens out back. If you have a child with you, he is likely to ask, ''Did you ever read the book ''Green Eggs and Ham''? Then he'll ask, ''Did you ever wonder where Dr. Seuss got the idea?'' Next he will show off his hens that lay green eggs.

title: The World; America Moves Apart From the U.N. on Iraq
description: A YEAR ago, the world was mesmerized by the spectacle of exploding rockets lighting the skies over Baghdad as American and British warplanes taught Saddam Hussein a lesson about defying United Nations arms inspections. A year later, it is clear that the fireworks were obscuring another reality: the final retreat of the Clinton administration from a policy of making the United Nations the focal point of policy on Iraq -- and, indeed, from making Iraq a focal point of policy.

title: The Incredible Disappearing Unloved Luxury-Car Tax
description: IF buying a Mercedes-Benz S500 or a Cadillac DeVille is on your list of Y2K resolutions, Congress brings you New Year's cheer. When the ball drops in Times Square, the luxury-tax rate will fall, too.

title: Playing in Concert
description: Musicians and trustees of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra obviously have no use for the posturing and brinksmanship featured in New York's recent transit brouhaha. Even though the orchestra's present contract does not expire until September, a three-year agreement has just been successfully negotiated. It shows evidence -- unusual for the music business -- of mutual respect and innovation.

title: Hans Waine, 92, Prominent Rheumatologist
description: Dr. Hans Waine, who earned a doctorate in history in Germany and worked as a journalist in Berlin before immigrating to the United States and becoming a prominent rheumatologist, died Dec. 5 at a nursing home in Stamford, Conn. He was 92.

title: December 19-25; A Monitor for the Law
description: The Justice Department's decision to appoint a monitor to oversee the New Jersey State Police sends a resounding message to dozens of other law enforcement agencies accused of racial discrimination. Among them is the New York City Police Department, which is now negotiating with the federal department and hoping to avert outside oversight. DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

title: Old Plants With New Parts Present a Problem to E.P.A.
description: In the roaring hot interior of the Philip Sporn electric plant here, giant pulverizers work around the clock to reduce coal to the consistency of talcum powder. Howling fans then blow it into giant boilers.

title: Board Gives Itself and County Officials a Raise
description: THE county's Board of Legislators has raised its own salary as well as that of the next county clerk and county executive.

title: Two Are Killed and Four Are Hurt in Separate Brooklyn Fires
description: A 90-year-old woman was critically injured and her 15-year-old grandson was also hurt yesterday morning after a Christmas tree caught fire in their apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn, officials said.

title: Hijackers Demand That India Release Cleric and Kashmiris
description: The hijackers of an Indian Airlines flight that was taken on a 15-hour odyssey across three countries before landing in Afghanistan demanded yesterday that India release a Pakistani religious leader and several Kashmiri fighters.

title: Going Home, After the Holidays
description: Charles I. Clough, chief investment strategist for Merrill Lynch, hasn't been wild about American stocks lately, but he is bullish on Boston.

title: Welcome to the Doll House
description: Free spirits who are not afraid of color and pattern can take a lesson from Ann Agee's diminutive creatures, perfectly cast in designer clothes.

title: Ideas & Trends: High Society; When You Got It, Flaunt It
description: ''TO live on little, with contented mind,'' may be the classically proper attitude toward wealth, but ''little'' and ''contented'' aren't seen together very much these days. A more appropriate motto would be Oscar Wilde's ''Nothing succeeds like excess.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-26-99; The Big Peep Show
description: We've been hearing for years that Times Square is becoming a theme park, and so it is. But the million and a half revelers who gather there on New Year's Eve may have some difficulty, as I have, discerning exactly the theme. When a million and a half cameras flash at midnight, what will they be photographing beyond a million and a half other flashes?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, ANNE BARNARD
description: GILL-Anne Barnard. Wife of Brendan Gill, died at the bungalow in Norfolk, Ct. on December 22, 1999. Her children and grandchildren are thankful for her joyous life and infinite love. Service at 2PM Monday, December 27, Church of Christ Congregational, Norfolk, Ct.

Over the years, karaoke lounges and other Japanese restaurants filled the building, serving legions of Japanese bankers and traders who arrived to do business from this hub of Southeast Asian commerce.

description: A beef processing company that had consistently failed the Agriculture Department's new safety standards announced yesterday that it was recalling 180,000 pounds of ground beef that might contain a deadly form of the E. coli bacterium.

title: First Events and Other Highlights
description: IT is time once again to review a year's musical highlights. Among other happenings were a number of initiatives, openings, new appointments and first events.

title: THEATER; For Pittsburgh, The Latest Stage In a Long Revival
description: AUGUST WILSON is renowned for setting plays in the Hill district of Pittsburgh, his hometown, but on a balmy afternoon earlier this month he stopped for a moment on this city's Penn Avenue and reminisced instead about another Pittsburgh neighborhood: downtown. Mr. Wilson was here to inaugurate the downtown O'Reilly Theater, a 650-seat house designed by Michael Graves, where Mr. Wilson's play ''King Hedley II'' is being given its world premiere by the Pittsburgh Public Theater.

title: Deer Hunting, Day 1 Is for Early Risers
description: It seemed that dawn finally decided to take a day off, but that's how a hunter always feels in the early-morning hours of opening day of deer season. I sat in the sturdy tree stand built on the edge of the north field on Steve Renehan's mountaintop property high above the Delaware River, watching the darkness. And I knew that some time soon, in 2 minutes or 4 or 8 or 10, I would begin to discern shapes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN CLEVE, ELLEN G.
description: VAN CLEVE-Ellen G. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ellen G. Van Cleve, associated with The Times from 1983.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-26-99: On Language; Scribble
description: 'Another damned, thick, square book!'' said the Duke of Gloucester in 1781 to a hard-working historian, Edward Gibbon, whose ''Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire'' would ultimately run to six damned, thick, square volumes. ''Always scribble, scribble, scribble, eh, Mr. Gibbon?''

title: Parents File Complaint About Survey of Students
description: The results of a survey of Ridgewood students in 7th through 12th grades that asked their experience with sex and drugs among other issues, are expected to be released to the community in February despite two complaints filed with the federal Department of Education from parents who said the tests were not administered legally because they were given without the parents' consent.

title: Seen Through Federal Eyes, State Is Being Paved Over
description: From the federal government comes news that to many New Jerseyans does not sound like news: More than 40 percent of the state is developed. New Jersey is by far the most built-over state in the nation, and it is also No. 1 in the rate at which it is losing open space.

title: The Internet Wears Out Its Welcome
description: E-NUFF already. It is the surest sign that the Internet is totally mainstream: Everyone is tired of it, not just the sleep-starved workers at dot-com startups, but everyone -- man and beast alike. Turn on the television and you are assaulted by an endless parade of jabbering advertisements for e-commerce companies. Newspapers are so bloated these days with ads for dot-com marketers that dogs across the nation must be loosening their teeth and straining their necks to fetch them.

title: Three Shows of Subtleties, Icons and Fauna
description: ONE of the most satisfying art experiences involves looking at the work of an artist who has been working a long time but who is not so well known that the art has been distilled into a quick catch phrase. With few advance clues, viewers have to look, ponder and weigh what is in front of them. But if the art shows evidence of growth while the vision has remained steady, that task is undertaken pleasurably.

title: Gardeners Visit a Plague of Giant Frog Upon a Developer
description: In spring 1977, Alicia Mendes and her neighbors cleared a burned-out lot next to their building on East Seventh Street between Avenues B and C and planted sunflowers, vegetables and herbs. They named the garden Esparanza (Spanish for hope), and during the last 22 years it has been the site of birthday parties, neighborhood meetings and annual pig roasts.

title: Bill Bowerman, 88, Nike Co-Founder, Dies
description: Bill Bowerman, a renowned track coach at the University of Oregon who spawned a revolution in athletic footwear and helped build a worldwide marketing powerhouse as the co-founder of Nike in the mid-1960's, died at his home in Fossil, Ore. He was 88.

description: Admiral's Brief Glory

title: Who Was Locked in When the Prison Door Shut for Life
description: IN adopting a ''three-strikes'' law to punish violent repeat offenders, New Jersey took up an idea that had captivated the public and still does: if so many crimes are committed by incorrigibles on parole, then close the revolving door. Then it turned out that, for all but a few prisoners, the door was already shut.

title: December 19-25; A New Internet Face
description: General Electric is famous for only wanting to compete in markets where it can be a top player. So it was odd that its NBC unit said it would back Telocity, a Silicon Valley start-up offering Internet access to homes. America Online now reaches 20 million subscribers, 10 times more than the nearest rival. But Telocity is 30 times faster than A.O.L. -- fast enough to offer Internet television programs, an area where NBC is still on top.

title: They've Got Dogs and Sleds. Who Needs Snow?
description: NO one yells ''Mush'' at the sled dog races in Voluntown. Nor do the drivers hold whips. And since there was no snow on a recent Saturday afternoon of races, the dogs didn't even pull sleds, but odd looking wheeled rigs that resembled giant scooters.

description: Only days after ending a hostage siege at a Louisiana prison, six hostage-takers -- all of them Cuban inmates awaiting deportation -- got their wish: a return flight home.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-26-99: The Ethicist; Substandard Behavior
description: Leaving the subway, I came across a disheveled, troubled-looking man urinating at the bottom of the stairs. I'm pretty sure no restaurant in the area would have allowed him to use the restroom, and I had no idea where the nearest public bathroom was. I believe in speaking up when I see a law being broken, but what should I do in this case? /H.L., New York

title: December 19-25; School Vouchers Found Unconstitutional
description: A federal judge has ruled that a program in which 3,761 Cleveland schoolchildren receive up to $2,500 in taxpayer money to attend private schools violates the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry

title: Among New York Centenarians, a Few Factories
description: FOR the last two centuries, New York has been a home to industry. From sugar refining to candy making, from printing to the manufacture of musical instruments, clothing, pharmaceuticals, paints, barrels and tanks, industry has helped shape the city. Perhaps that was no surprise, given the city's wealth of immigrant labor, its port and the number of buyers.

title: New York Century: Who We Are, How We Live
description: How different were New Yorkers at the beginning of the 20th century from New Yorkers at its tail end? A glance at the census of 1900 shows that the city's attraction for immigrants has remained constant, but that its diversity has broadened considerably. Most New Yorkers then, as now, rented rather than owned their residences, but living conditions were a bit more snug. While the city's population in 1900 was roughly half its current size, New Yorkers had to squeeze into a housing supply only a tenth as large as the current one. Perhaps families were closer then because they had no choice. MICHAEL PORTER

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-26-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Juno Cole, Ojai, Calif., August 1999

title: Life Stories in an Artistic Framework
description: EXPLORING the facts of an artist's life as an entree into his or her work is a comparatively recent approach to appreciating art. Biographical details are now often close to essential to full comprehension. This can be because a work of art comes out of a specific incident, but often it's because the general situation from which the artist springs provides a framework for the work.

While their friends celebrate, travel or just spend a quiet evening at home toasting in the third millennium, thousands of workers who provide the county's essential services will be at their work stations or on call, just in case.

title: Wood, Stone and Water, a Town's Timeless Elements
description: THE first time I saw Clinton, I hardly noticed. I was visiting a college friend who lived in Hunterdon County, and as we drove around in her parents' car we happened to breeze down Main Street. ''This is Clinton,'' she said. ''It's kind of touristy.''

title: Lives; Santa's Little Helper
description: I'm always a bit cranky the day after Christmas, when I promptly take down those flattering white lights and toss the remaining gingerbread limbs that would just go stale anyway. I might try to cheer myself up with my ''Acoustic Christmas'' CD, but the Hooters' cover of ''Silent Night'' has no charm now that the moment has passed. This morning-after dejection, I realize, would be a common response to a favorite holiday's end -- except that I'm Jewish.

title: AMBITIOUS EFFORT TO CUT MISTAKES IN U.S. HOSPITALS
description: Spurred by an Institute of Medicine report last month, big employers, health care organizations, state regulators and the federal government are stepping up pressure to revamp a health care system that calls itself the best in the world, yet hides and ignores mistakes that kill tens of thousands of patients a year.

title: Highways as Speedways? Drivers Push the Limits
description: Early last Monday morning, Mathew Hennessy, mild-mannered computer programmer, was driving down the Saw Mill Parkway toward Manhattan at 100 miles an hour. Inside his Jeep Grand Cherokee, things were calm. An old song by the Cure played low on the radio as Mr. Hennessy, 27, from New Rochelle, sank into his leather seat, gripped the wheel and watched rush-hour traffic stream past his window in one long Manet-like smudge.

description: Most brilliant plays are uncovered in the post-mortem, with 52 cards in view, but there are exceptions. Cover the East-West hands in the diagramed deal, and plan the play in three no-trump. East has opened one club, and West leads that suit.

title: Industry View; Products that pack many uses into a single unit rarely catch on. So why all the blind faith today in media convergence?
description: IN the 1970's, the Popeil Pocket Fisherman spawned numerous mocking parodies as the ultimate all-in-one device. It not only caught fish, but through the miracle of its many hidden compartments, it could also gut, clean and even weigh your catch. Today, as the hype surrounding the convergence of PC's, television and the Web continues to dominate headlines, the familiar ''but that's not all!'' nature of the convergent device begs a question. Is convergence really a good thing?

St. John's had two winners in Tiffany Barnes, who won the women's 500 meters in 1:16.25, and George Maringapasi, winner of the men's high jump at 7 feet. Althea Johnson of McKendree (Ill.) College was the meet's only double winner. She placed first in the 60 meters in 7.63 seconds and in the 300 meters at 39.19 seconds. BILL MILLER

title: Pension Giveaway in Albany
description: New York City's politically powerful labor unions have a bad habit of trying to grab special benefits from the State Legislature that they are unable to achieve through collective bargaining. This month, Gov. George Pataki has on his desk a bill passed by the Legislature to enrich the pensions of city corrections officers. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani asserts that the bill would cost the city $100 million a year and has asked Mr. Pataki to veto it. The governor should do just that, sending a message that such benefits should be obtained by negotiation, not by political clout in Albany.

title: Two Visions on Health Care

Mr. Bradley proposes an expensive plan that invites uninsured people to buy coverage, with the help of federal subsidies for families with incomes of up to about $50,000, from any one of hundreds of private plans that serve federal employees. Mr. Gore, arguing that Mr. Bradley's plan would lead to unacceptably high tax increases or federal spending cuts, proposes taking modest steps that would reduce the number of uninsured people by expanding existing federal-state programs to cover more low-income children and their parents. He would also offer tax credits to individuals and small businesses that acquire coverage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE KRUYF, JOHANNES
description: de KRUYF-Johannes. A legendary expert on Netherlands philately, passed away at his home in Bergenfield, NJ on Wednesday, October 6, 1999 at the age of 92. Johannes, ''Jo'' to his friends, left Holland for Canada in 1928 and came to New York the following year. There he worked 40 years for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. His philatelic accomplishments are many. In 1934, together with Professor Schiller of Columbia University, C.W. Gibbs, and Sidney Lake, he founded the Netherlands & Colonies Philately group of New York. They met on a regular basis at the famed Collector's Club on 35th Street until 1976. Membership lists read like a virtual Who's Who of Dutch philately. For 42 years, Jo was the driving force behind the NCP, serving in various capacities from treasurer to president. He edited the NCP publication for almost its entire existence and it remains the definitive philatelic resource to this day. In May 1940, Schiller and de Kruyf co-authored and published, with the help of A.M. Benders and P.C. Korteweg, the now famous Manual of Stamps of the Netherlands, Netherlands Indies, Curacao and Surinam. No more comprehensive catalogue has been issued to date. Its cover was orange to emphasize the solidarity with the House of Orange, the Dutch royal family in a time of war. Jo managed to assemble at least two dozen major collections and generously shared his knowledge in numerous articles and lectures at the Collector's Club. One of his areas of expertise was the detection of stamp forgeries of the Netherlands and Dutch East Indies, and for many years he served as consultant to the American Philatelic Society in this field. His contributions to Dutch philately were recognized when the Nederlanse Bond van Filatelisten Verenigingen awarded him its highest honor, the Costerus medal in 1964. Jo was also an accomplished painter of landscapes, where he reveals his keen sensitivity to the natural world. His special skill in capturing the essence of certain sites in Canada, Maine, the Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles, Scotland, Norway, and other locales gives his oils and watercolors a certain intimate immediacy appreciated by all who see them. Jo's large-scale paintings and miniatures have been exhibited in Maine, where he often vacationed with his wife Alma who predeceased him in 1994. A selection of these works were recently exhibited in the Bergenfield Public Library and the New Milford Library where some of the miniatures were on display in November. Jo credited his parents with starting him on his lifelong hobbies when he was sick as a child for two years with tuberculosis. He said that he got stamps from his father and paints from his mother to keep him from being bored while resting. Although Jo has no direct descendants, nor any known relatives left in the Netherlands, he will be remembered by those privileged to know him as a wise human being with a wry sense of humor, who enjoyed life. His many kindnesses will not be forgotten and he will be greatly missed, especially by Betsy, Janet and Jock Morrison, Jan and Clay Morrison, Karin de Vries, neighbors, and members of the Central Unitarian Church in Paramus, New Jersey and Kees Adema.

title: SPRINT TO OFFER FREE SUNDAY CALLS TO FIGHT COMPETITION
description: The Sprint Corporation said it would offer a free hour of calling on Sunday nights for six months in a bid to draw new customers after the Bell Atlantic Corporation received approval to sell long-distance service in New York. Consumers will receive the free hour by signing up for a plan that offers 5-cents-a-minute calling from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. and 10 cents a minute at other times, Sprint said. Sprint, which is being bought by MCI WorldCom Inc., introduced the 10-cents-a-minute rate in 1995. Shares in Sprint, which is based in Westwood, Kan., fell $1.25, to $69.25. MCI WorldCom, based in Clinton, Miss., fell $3 to $78.

title: Italian Directory Publisher Offers to Buy Office Supplier
description: Seat Pagine Gialle S.p.A., the Italian publisher of yellow pages that has expanded into online businesses, has offered to buy Buffetti S.p.A., which operates a chain of office supply stores, for 708.4 million euros ($718 million) in cash and stock.

title: Experiment of Privatized Mental Hospital Shows Benefits
description: Mental health care advocates long viewed South Florida State Psychiatric Hospital here as a dumping ground, a place where patients were treated poorly, languished for years and died mysteriously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHENEY, DAVID HOWELL
description: CHENEY-David Howell. Age 95. Of Litchfield, CT., formerly of Manchester, CT. Husband of Eleanor (nee Gray) Cheney. Died Monday, December 27, 1999, at his home. Mr. Cheney was born May 20, 1904 in Manchester, son of the late Howell and Anne (nee Bunce) Cheney. He was a 1927 graduate of Yale University and went on to work in the former Cheney Brothers Silk Mills of Manchester for many years. Besides his wife Eleanor, he is survived by his son David W. Cheney, three daughters, Lydia McKiernan, Clarissa Street and Susan Ham, a sister Mary C. Hart, nine grandchildren.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; BP Amoco Withdrawing From Natural Gas Fields in Ukraine
description: BP Amoco has decided not to develop a series of natural gas fields in Ukraine, dealing a blow to the country's hopes of decreasing its dependence on Russian gas.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, ELIZABETH ARONSOHN
description: SALTZMAN-Elizabeth Aronsohn age 90, of Boca Raton, Florida formerly of Fort Lee, NJ. Predeceased by her husband I. William Aronsohn and son Richard F. Aronsohn. Survived by her husband Lawrence Saltzman, daughter Joan Katz of Stowe, VT, six grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. Services are Today, 1:00 PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: New Plays Can't Find Broadway Openings
description: Despite booming business on Broadway, the theater district is experiencing a steady erosion in the tradition of the straight play. New plays are more likely to thrive Off Broadway, where, for the last five years, the Pulitzer Prize-winning plays have opened.

title: Vending Machines Enlisted in AIDS Fight
description: In Marseille, France, some vending machines dispense neither soda nor candy but free sterile needles for drug users. In Vancouver, British Columbia, a stack of colorful coupons sits next to the register at a local drugstore, offering 10 percent off on condoms.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday, about checking the Y2K compliance of personal computers, misstated the Web address of a Y2K reference page at the ZDNet site. It is www.zdnet.com /zdhelp/filters/y2k.

title: VITAL SIGNS: STANDARDS; Gauging How Badly a Head Is Hurt
description: Getting hit in the head, it turns out, is not a simple thing. As a result, researchers from the Henry Ford Health Systems in Detroit have been working with the National Football League, the National Hockey League and the National Collegiate Athletic Association to promote a new, more individualized system to determine when a player who has suffered a concussion can safely return to competition.

title: Zipping Up: A Substitute For Stitches And Staples
description: When Benjamin Brody awoke from abdominal surgery, he was groggy and disoriented. As he slid back his surgical gown to take a look at his new incision, he did not see the usual cross-hatching of sutures or the minirailroad track of staples. Instead, he saw a zipper.

title: U.N. Votes for a Plan That Would Cut Off Funds for Terrorists
description: In the waning days of this fall's General Assembly session, a majority of nations, united by concerns about terrorism, voted to establish an international agreement to stop the flow of money to terrorist organizations.

title: DAEWOO RECEIVERSHIP DELAYED
description: The South Korean government will delay until late next month a decision on whether to place the Daewoo Corporation under court receivership, while continuing talks with foreign creditors, a top official of the nation's financial watchdog agency said yesterday. Lee Hun Jai, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, held a breakfast meeting with representatives of local banks to discuss the progress of the ailing Daewoo Group's debt restructuring efforts. The Daewoo Corporation, a flagship subsidiary of Daewoo Group, holds a majority of the conglomerate's overseas debts.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, Rosemont, Ill., to August, Lang & Husak, Bethesda, Md.

title: VITAL SIGNS: Rx MEDICINE; An Up-Front Approach to Malpractice
description: A Veterans Affairs hospital in Lexington, Ky., says it has found a way to keep its malpractice costs below those of most similar hospitals: make full disclosure to injured patients, even when they would not otherwise have learned of the problem.

title: People
description: * Kris Coontz was named to the new position of executive vice president for entertainment at Mediacom, Burbank, Calif., a unit of Grey Advertising. He had been vice president for marketing at the ABC Television Network, New York, part of the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company.

title: SONY STOCK SPLIT
description: The Sony Corporation said its board approved a two-for-one stock split effective May 19, after a threefold surge in its shares this year. Sony shareholders of record as of March 31 will receive an additional share for each share held. After the split, Sony will have about 893 million shares outstanding. The split will also affect Sony's American depository receipts. Shares of Sony, which is based in Tokyo, have surged on optimism that a far-reaching reorganization plan announced earlier this year and the release in March of the successor to its PlayStation game console will support strong earnings growth.

title: Metro Business; Wheelchair Maker Files for Chapter 11
description: Graham-Field Health Products Inc., the nation's No. 3 wheelchair maker, filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors yesterday.

title: Urban Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Set to Monitor the Clock Shift From a Central Office
description: It does not resemble a bunker. Its computers have suffered the same routine glitches that computers do in every other office suite. But as the millennium approaches, two floors of a nondescript building near the White House have been transformed into command central for the federal government's response to Year 2000-related emergencies.

title: Charity Group To Foreclose On 14 Homes
description: Habitat for Humanity, the organization that gathers volunteers to hammer together houses for poor families, is preparing to foreclose on as many as 14 of the 70 families it has housed here.

title: Dementia, Or Simply Old Age? A Guidebook
description: Dementia strikes four million Americans every year, according to the American Medical Association, sapping their memories and their ability to live independently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, RUTH
description: MARX-Ruth. The Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Ruth Marx. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, President

title: Chiquita Is Said to Consider an Auction
description: Chiquita Brands International may consider an auction to put some or all of its assets up for sale, according to a regulatory filing by a shareholder.

title: Giuliani Seeks Administrator In Schools Job
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the best candidate to replace Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew would be a good administrator and manager, not necessarily someone with experience as an educator.

title: A Quick Montage on Taxes
description: This 30-second commercial is one of six new ones from Gov. George W. Bush of Texas for use in New Hampshire and Iowa. Three deal with taxes and three with education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARROW, RUTH F.
description: DARROW-Ruth F. Beloved wife of the late Martin M. Darrow. Loving mother of Kenneth and Marsha Darrow and Marcia and Howard Shafran. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Joshua, Brad and Kendra. Devoted sister of Nat Fuchs. Services 10:00 AM today at Temple Israel of Jamaica, 188-15 McLaughlin Avenue, Holliswood, N.Y. For information contact Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 888-377-7303.

title: Fireworks Over Display At Monument
description: In the final seconds of the century, the Washington Monument will turn into a giant sparkler, with most of the 555-foot obelisk ablaze with diamonds of light at the stroke of midnight. ''And please don't call them fireworks!'' the pyrotechnician in charge said today.

title: Rap Performer Puffy Combs Is Arrested After Shootings at Times Sq. Nightclub
description: Sean (Puffy) Combs, the multimillionaire rap entrepreneur whose career and lavish East Hampton parties have been fodder for the gossip columns, was arrested on gun possession charges with the actress and singer Jennifer Lopez after shots were fired at a Times Square dance club early yesterday, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLL, KARL
description: STOLL-Karl. On December 27, 1999. Beloved brother of Bella Katz (nee Stoll), Max Stoll, Leo Stoll and Harry Stoll. Loving uncle and great uncle. Service is on Wednesday, 11:30 AM, Schwartz Bros Funeral Home, Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: KOREAN ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: The Bank of Korea, South Korea's central bank, said it expected gross domestic product to grow 7.2 percent next year, much lower than this year's estimated 10.2 percent. Growth in 1999 was unusually high because it followed a severe recession in 1998. The state-run Korea Development Institute had earlier projected growth of 7.8 percent for next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKLEY, JAMES E.
description: BECKLEY-James E. The Public Investors Arbitration Bar Association (''PIABA'') is sad to announce the death of our current President, James E. Beckley. Jim Beckley, a distinguished attorney from Chicago, worked tirelessly for the protection of individual investors, and he will be missed by our members, and all who shared his commitment, his sense of history, and his sense of humor.

title: JOINT CHIP-MAKING VENTURE
description: The United Microelectronics Corporation, Taiwan's second-largest chip maker by revenue, and Hitachi Ltd., Japan's third-largest chip maker, said they would spend $682 million on more sophisticated production lines to enable them to cut costs on future generations of chips. Hitachi, which is based in Tokyo, will take a 60 percent stake, and United Microelectronics a 40 percent share, in a joint venture to be based on existing Hitachi production operations.

title: Medical Meddling?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Treating Patients for Pain, a Racial Gap
description: Black patients with broken arms or legs were less likely to be given painkillers in an Atlanta emergency room than white patients with similar injuries and complaints of pain, a new study has found.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: At Latest Gatsby, Great-Grandkids

title: Thomas, Suspended and Fined for Fight, Keeps Lashing Out
description: On the same day his teammates preached tolerance to him, his coach discussed restraint with him and the league handed him a penalty for instigating a fight with Indiana's Jalen Rose on Saturday night, Knicks forward Kurt Thomas was still fuming today as he all but trampled on olive branches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERWISE, SYDELL
description: ZUCKERWISE-Sydell. Of Laguna Hills, CA, age 68, mother of Drew and Debra, passed away in her sleep on December 26, 1999. Graveside services Wednesday December 29th at 1 P.M. at New Montifiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. For information call Schwartz Brothers in Queens, NY.

title: Paying the Price for Cheating on Sleep
description: There is probably no time of year when America's sleep debt is greater than it is right now. Starting with Thanksgiving week, holiday preparations and parties, gift shopping and packaging, family visits and extra hours of work to make up for days off prompt millions of Americans to cheat on their sleep even more than usual. Many are used to being tired and think, optimistically, that they'll catch up with lost sleep after the New Year.

title: The Defining Styles of Capitalism
description: Malt liquors and boots were among America's 10 largest industries at the beginning of the 20th century. A third of Americans worked in agriculture. Fifty years later, cars, aircraft and chemical manufacturing dominated the economy and only about 4 percent of Americans worked in agriculture. The United States started the century on an economic par with Great Britain. By the middle of the century, living standards were 50 percent higher in the United States than in Britain.

title: World Bank's Aim: Beef for China
description: The World Bank has proved again that the pen is mightier than the sword. The sword -- in this case a scythe harvesting the grains that have kept the Chinese free of the diet-related health problems plaguing Westerners -- was defeated last week when, with the stroke of a pen, the World Bank signed off on a $93.5 million loan to build 130 feedlots and five processing centers for China's nascent beef industry.

title: Carlesimo Is Dismissed By the 6-21 Warriors
description: After surviving speculation about his firing for more than a month, P. J. Carlesimo was dismissed as head coach of the Golden State Warriors yesterday, a little over two years after being involved in one of the ugliest incidents in National Basketball Association history.

title: In Panama Canal Display, Engineers Get the Glory
description: As interest in the Panama Canal began to focus this year on its impending transfer out of United States hands and the geopolitics involved, scholars at the Smithsonian Institution began to lament that something important was being overlooked. Lost in the hoopla was an appreciation of the canal as an engineering feat.

title: Steel Maker Low on Cash
description: The Birmingham Steel Corporation's shares fell as much as 35 percent after the company said it was running low on cash and must cut costs to stay in operation. Birmingham lost $224.2 million in the fiscal year ended June 30. Its shares fell $1.5625, to $3.4375, today. The company will have only about $35 million left of a $300 million line of credit, analysts said. It might lay off employees and temporarily shut down plants, John Correnti, the company's chief executive, said in a letter to shareholders last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLINGER, JIM
description: HELLINGER-Jim. On December 27, 1999, at age 84. Husband of Eleanor; father of Doug, Steve, John, and Bob; grandfather of Danny, Sam, Abigail, and Laura. Retired President of Anglo-African Shipping Co. of N.Y.; Harvard Law School Class of 1937; CCNY Class of 1934; Townsend Harris Class of 1930. He was one of a kind, and will be sorely missed. Please consider donations to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, New York 11590.

title: Leonard Goldenson, Force Behind ABC, Is Dead at 94
description: Leonard H. Goldenson, the self-contained man who bought the American Broadcasting Company in 1953 and made it an incubator of television innovations while he pushed it from also-ran status to parity with its more senior rivals, died at his home in Sarasota, Fla., yesterday. He was 94.

description: The Nasdaq composite index sustained a much-anticipated round of profit taking yesterday, but later rose to its eighth consecutive record high, pulled up by big jumps in Internet favorites like Qualcomm, JDS Uniphase and Yahoo.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Nary a Drama on Broadway; Straight Plays Are Thriving, but Elsewhere in Manhattan
description: The play ''Epic Proportions'' was greeted with mostly negative reviews two months ago and attracted only modest audiences, but its closing on Dec. 19 brought a historic moment to New York theater: for the first time, at least in memory, no recently written comedy or drama is running on Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, ETHEL (NEE WOLFSON)
description: REICH-Ethel (nee Wolfson). Died peacefully on December 27, 1999 in Atlanta, GA. Dear wife of the late Martin Reich. Survived by daughter, Anita Greenfield and son-in-law Bill, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Graveside service Tuesday, 1:30 PM at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, HAROLD L.
description: FISHER-Harold L. Lawyer, public official, civic and political leader. At the age of 89. At his home in Fort Lauderdale. He was born on December 10, 1910 to the late Jacob and Pauline Fisher. He graduated from Seward Park High School and from St. John's University College of Law Cum Laude. He was devoted to the former Betty Kahn, his late wife of 63 years. He was the proud father of H. Leonard Fisher, Jr., Assistant Professor at the University of San Francisco, married to Yvonne Derrick Fisher; Alice Fisher Rubin, Judge of the New York Civil Court, married to Lowell Rubin; Stephanie Cooper Harrison, a businesswoman in Ashville, N.C., married to Joseph Harrison; Andrew S. Fisher, Managing Partner of the law firm founded by his father, married to Barbara Fisher, Ph.d, and Kenneth K. Fisher, member of the New York City Council, married to Kirsten Fisher. He had eleven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. He was active in Democratic party politics for four decades and widely recognized as the leading expert on the State's election law. His career in government, likewise, spanned decades including service as council to the Speaker of the New York State Assembly and Chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. He had been Chairman of the American Public Transit Association, Chairman of the Convention Center Development Corporation, Chairman of the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburg and a delegate to the 1967 New York State Constitutional Convention. He was most proud of his term as President of the Brooklyn Bar Association. He served in the New York State Bar Association House of Delegates and on the Board of many Brooklyn institutions. Funeral services Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale. Shiva at the home of Judge Rubin begnning on Wednesday. A memorial service will be held at 1 P.M., on January 7 at Congregation Mount Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Transit Museum.

title: Public Interests; A New New Year Agenda
description: This week it's hard to avoid thinking about the future, particularly if you work half a block from Times Square, soon to be the scene of the very biggest and best New Year's celebration that our local holiday planners and anti-terrorism squads can provide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, ROBERT M.
description: BARRY-Robert M. On Dec. 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Robert Jr., Mary Burkhardt, Ellen Barry-Tung, Jane Joyce & John. Dear father-in-law to Maura, Clyde, Andrew, David, and Mary Gail. Cherished grandfather of six. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, N.Y., Tuesday, 7-9, and Wed. 2-4, 7-9. Funeral Mass at St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont, 10 AM Thurs. Donations in Bob's memory may be made to Padre Pio Shelter, Box 55, Larchmont, N.Y. 10538, or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: A Picture That Divided The Old From the New
description: No one photograph or, for that matter, style could sum up the century of fashion that rose on the pinched bosoms of Edwardian ladies and ended, for all practical purposes, one night in December with rap stars exiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art in a flourish of diamonds and couture silk. It would be impossible, if not outrageous, to ignore the influence of Chanel and Saint Laurent, the glamour of Hollywood, the contagion of youth or the spirit of absolute freedom that drove designers as different as Paul Poiret and Ralph Lauren to invent their own worlds.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Politics is the same everywhere in the world. Nobody wants to give up their power. But times are changing.''

title: A Wasteful Christmas
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrant Diversity Slows Traditional Political Climb
description: As a teenager, Morshed Alam dodged enemy soldiers to deliver food to Bangladeshi independence fighters. And as a student at Dhaka University in the mid-1970's, he endured police beatings to organize pro-democracy demonstrations against the newly formed nation's military regime.

title: Medellin Journal; A Terrorized University Fights to Be True to Itself
description: Some days it is hard to tell just how profoundly this country's brutal, deepening civil conflict has affected the University of Antioquia here. Outside the library, at the school's main plaza, students relax in the sun, study for final exams, play soccer or flirt with each other, just like their counterparts anywhere else.

title: Peru's Leader to Seek a 3rd Term, Capping a Long Legal Battle
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru announced his candidacy for an unprecedented third term today, arguing that his country needed him to guarantee an end to terrorism and to complete its economic recovery.

title: Dizzying Scenarios In Playoff Cuisinart
description: This morning some coaches around the National Football League woke up from their two hours of sleep, gulped their caffe latte and broke out the calculators. If it's late December, it must be time for playoff possibilities. Oh, those dizzying and annoying postseason scenarios.

title: Joseph McGahn, 82, Pioneer Of Casinos in Atlantic City
description: Joseph Leo McGahn, a New Jersey obstetrician who, as a Democratic state senator, paved the way for Atlantic City's gambling industry in the 1970's, died Friday at Meadowview Nursing Home in Northfield, N.J. A longtime resident of Absecon, N.J., he was 82.

title: Path to the Nobel Began in a Pond
description: Why would anyone want to get up at 5:15 every morning to study microscopic pond organisms? It makes perfect sense if, like Dr. Thomas R. Cech, one has a thirst for hard scientific data and does not want to waste a second.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Internet sites run by major news organizations referred imprecisely to the operations of the staff that provides financial news updates to The New York Times on the Web and TheStreet.com. The staff is a joint venture of The New York Times and TheStreet.com -- not operated solely by TheStreet .com, in which The Times also has a financial interest.

title: EQUISTAR TO CUT BACK OPERATIONS AND TAKE TAX CHARGE
description: Equistar Chemicals L. P., North America's largest producer of polyethylene, said it would take a pretax charge of $95 million in the fourth quarter to close some production lines. Equistar is a joint venture of Lyondell Chemical, Millennium Chemicals and Occidental Petroleum. Lyondell owns 41 percent while Millennium and Occidental each have 29.5 percent. Equistar said last month that it would shut production lines at its plant in La Porte, Tex., and cut as many as 180 jobs to reduce costs.

description: Clinton to Seek New Rules For Pharmacies on Internet

title: A Queens Performer Faces Drug Charge
description: Victor Santiago, a fast-rising rap performer from Queens who performs under the name Noreaga, was arrested Sunday night on narcotics charges after undercover officers spotted him and three other men sharing a marijuana cigarette in his car, the police said yesterday.

title: U.S. Back on Top in Industrial Research
description: American industry is pouring extraordinary sums of money into research and development in an effort to nurture strong growth, private and federal officials are reporting.

title: Woodrow Borah, 86, an Expert On Spanish Conquest of Mexico
description: Woodrow Borah, a former professor of Latin American history at the University of California at Berkeley who documented the decimation of Mexico's native population resulting from the Spanish conquest, died on Dec. 10 at Kaiser Hospital in Oakland, Calif. title: Sports of The Times; Giants Just Don't Have Who It Takes
description: GIANTS fans are a peculiar mix of contradictions. They have confidence born of deep tradition and the equally deep insecurity of never being able to recapture that glorious past. Unlike Jets fans who look for misery in every silver lining, Giants fans look at two-game winning streaks as a return to the empire the Giants once knew.

description: FARRELL-Marie Lucille, Sister. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen died on December 26, 1999. Lewinsky, the woman known for her relationship with President Clinton, is marching down yet another professional path: as a television pitchwoman for a diet plan.

description: To the Editor:

title: SIRIUS RADIO TO SELL A 10% STAKE TO INVESTMENT BANK
description: Sirius Satellite Radio Inc., which plans to broadcast satellite-to-car music digitally, said it would sell a 10 percent stake to a New York investment bank, Blackstone Group Inc., for $200 million to help finance the project. Sirius shares rose $5.1875, to $36.125. Sirius, formerly named CD Radio, is building a satellite system to transmit as many as 100 channels of music and other programming to motorists throughout the continental United States.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise About 2% on Nasdaq Market
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market crept up roughly 2 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the market, said yesterday.

title: 15 Passengers Hurt On Bus to Atlantic City
description: Fifteen passengers on a New Jersey Transit bus suffered minor injuries yesterday morning when the driver struck a utility pole as she swerved the bus to avoid a deer, officials said.

title: One Man's Nightmare in Serbia: Life With Virtually Nothing Left
description: For Vlada, a unit commander for the Yugoslav Army during the Kosovo war, the months since have been a wretched period of guilt, poverty, doubt and repression, stemming from his participation in anti-government demonstrations in this conservative, wary town.

title: GERMAN PRODUCER PRICE INDEX
description: Prices charged by German factories rose a less-than-expected 0.1 percent in November, mostly because of rising oil costs. The index rose 0.7 percent from November 1998, the Federal Statistics Office said.

title: With Fresh Discoveries, Egyptology Flowers
description: Two centuries ago, an engineer with Napoleon's army in Egypt snatched intellectual triumph from the jaws of military defeat by discovering the Rosetta Stone. This marked the start of scientific Egyptology, a field that, more than ever, is bursting with discoveries and new ideas about one of the most splendid and durable civilizations in the ancient world.

title: Richardson And Claxton Carry Hofstra
description: With less than four minutes to play last night and the game slipping away, Hofstra put the ball in the hands of Craig Claxton. Claxton, a senior point guard known as Speedy, had piled up 70 points in his previous two games, but this time he took over without scoring.

title: Cap, Gown and Yearbook Are Supplied to Go With a Hard-Earned Diploma

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, JAMES ANDERSON
description: BAKER-James Anderson. Born October 6, 1927 in Garland Texas, Died December 27, 1999 in Naples, FL. Graduated from Garland Texas Public Schools. Attended Texas A & M then on to study and graduate with a BSEE from Southern Methodist University in Dallas, TX. Later attended and graduated from the Harvard AMP Program. He served in the Merchant Marines as well as a 1st Lt. in the U.S. Army. He joined the General Electric Company in 1952 and worked in many areas such as Heating, Service Shops, and Industrial Controls. In 1973 he became Vice President of General Electric's Lamp Division at Nela Park, Ohio. He was named a Senior VP and moved to GE Headquarters in Fairfield, CT in 1979. Prior to retiring he coined the phrase, ''Automate, Emigrate or Evaporate.'' In 1986 he retired from GE as Sector Vice President. He was a lay minister in the United Methodist church, active in United Way and was acting 1986 United Way Chairperson for Tri-State (Connecticut, New York, New Jersey) United Way. He was an active patron of the arts. He is survived by his wife, Patsy Smith Baker of 50 years. Daughters and sons-in-Law Janet and Greg Henley of Clinton, SC; Carol and Chris LeSesne of Noblesville, IN; and Laura and John Flick of Naples, FL. Twelve grandchildren; one great grandson; two brothers, Paul Baker of Garland, TX and Donald Baker of Satanta, KS and many nieces and nephews. Memorial services will be held at Moorings Presbyterian Church, Naples, FL on Friday December 31, 1999 at 11:00 AM. There will also be a memorial service at South Roanoke United Methodist Church, Roanoke, VA at a later date. Memorials may be made to the American Diabetes Association, Inc., 1101 N. Lake Destiny Road, Suite 415, Maitland, FL 32751, South Roanoke United Methodist Church, 2330 So. Jefferson St., Roanoke, VA 24014, or Moorings Presbyterian Church, 791 Harbor Dr., Naples, Florida 34103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENSON, LEONARD H.
description: GOLDENSON-Leonard H.. The Board, staff and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with profound and deep sorrow the passing of Leonard Goldenson, who helped to create both ABC and UCP. As a result of rubella during pregnancy, Leonard and Isabelle's eldest daughter, Genise, nicknamed ''Cookie'', was diagnosed with cerebral palsy. They joined other parents of children with cerebral palsy, notably Jack and Ethel Hausman and Irving Sloan, founders of UCP/NYC, to build a state-wide and national movement. Leonard recruited celebrities including Marlene Dietrich, Jinx Falkenberg, Arlene Francis, Bob Hope, Tex McCrary and Jane Pickens to support UCP and, in 1950, launched the first UCP telethon hosted by Dennis James. For nearly 50 years, both in New York City and throughout the nation, Leonard helped to make UCP the largest health organization in the U.S. He can never be replaced. We extend our condolences to Isabelle, his daughters Loreen and Maxine, and grandson Lucas. Leo Hausman, Chairman Martin C. Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews, Exec. Dir. Ronald J.H. Napal, Associate Executive Director, Development & Public Relations United Ceberal Palsy of NYC, Inc

title: KCS PLANS TO FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: KCS Energy Inc., an oil and natural gas exploration company, said it reached an agreement with noteholders to restructure its debt and will file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection by Jan. 18. Under the agreement, KCS must secure a new credit line for as much as $190 million by Jan. 15 to replace its two current bank lines. KCS's shares have fallen about 97 percent since October 1997, when recessions in Asia led to a slump in oil and gas prices. KCS is based in Houston and had sales of $123.5 million last year. The company said holders of its 8.875 percent senior subordinated notes due in 2008 will swap $125 million of the principal, plus interest, for $46.9 million in cash and newly issued convertible preferred stock.

The candy maker was expected to earn $2.12 a share, the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Hershey has said that problems with a new computer system for tracking orders and distributing its candies left some customers without adequate supplies and drove up costs. Shares of Hershey, which is based in Hershey, Pa., fell $2.3125, to $47.8125, yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRY, ROBERT LEE
description: TERRY-Robert Lee. Born June 20, 1919 in Princeton, N.J. and was brought up in Princeton. He attended Groton School & Princeton University. This intelligent, well-acted movie is not helped by the fact that its story in some ways parallels that of ''Stigmata,'' the trashy supernatural spookfest that flared briefly at the box office earlier this year.

title: Millencholy
description: An acute rapid-onset condition characterized by pervasive sadness, feelings of commemorative inadequacy and a morbid preoccupation with the passage of time. (This last fixation may lead sufferers to blurt out, ''Doesn't it seem like only yesterday that the Peace of Utrecht was signed?'' or ''I can remember the invention of the fork as if it were just last Thursday.'') Often accompanied by an intense desire to relive the last thousand years all over again, but without the plagues, pointless wars or telemarketing.

title: New Year's Eve Security Issues
description: Anxiety about terrorism and other forms of mayhem is rising as cities around the country prepare for the millennial New Year's Eve celebration. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir are taking the wise approach of ordering tough security measures without allowing the fear of terrorism to prevent New Yorkers -- and millions who will be watching the events on television -- from enjoying the traditional Times Square festivities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MEL
description: GORDON-Mel. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute bids farewell to a leader. A member of the Institute's Board of Trustees, Mr. Gordon joined the Board in 1965 and served as its President from 1969 through 1993. He was instrumental in helping to pilot White into international prominence by his canny cognizance of what was consequential, challenging and beneficial. Mel was deeply loyal to the Institute and to its purposes and he was passionate in his belief in people, in psychoanalysis, and in the ability of both to make the world a better place. Principled and generous, Mel also had the courage of his convictions, both adding to the Institute's assets and urging the use of its resources for the benefit of the many. He was idealistic though pragmatic, and his drive to serve and to get things done kept us focused and on target. In this regard, he could be a tantilizing provocateur but his unflagging optimism and doggedness sustained the respect and devotion of the Institute membership. Most important, Mel was warm, wise, and wonderful. His wit, humor, and his love of life and gift of laughter enveloped and inspired us. And no one here could fail to be moved by Mel's extraordinary devotion to his family, who must feel this loss acutely. We shall always miss him. We shall always remember him with love, with gratitude, and especially with joy. Charles C. Harrington, Ph.D., President, Board of Trustees Marylou Lionells, Ph.D., Director, White Institute

title: Champagne Drought? It's a Deluge
description: SAM AARON, who died in 1996, was a founder of the Sherry-Lehmann shop in New York and probably the greatest wine salesmen I've known. He could have sold Bordeaux to the Burgundians. Whatever he was flogging at the moment, he would add this to his catalog: ''When this is gone there will be no more.'' The Rothschilds' best or Romanian plonk, it didn't matter: the people came, waving money, demanding one of those precious last bottles. He was a master of the fine art of creating demand.

title: Swords Into Whimsy Instead of Plowshares
description: Push through the black iron gate, slip into the tiny garden and there, amid crab grass, wild flowers and snake plants, lies the detritus of this country's savage civil war. Only now rusting AK-47's have been fashioned into a baby's cradle. Empty machine guns curve into a globe, frozen on its axis. A rifle's snout becomes the spinal cord of a half-made human being. The aging weapons in this open-air studio, disabled now, were the ones that killed and maimed during the 16-year-war that raged until 1992 and took more than a million lives.

title: JOSTENS, MAKER OF CLASS RINGS, AGREES TO BUYOUT
description: Jostens Inc., a maker of school yearbooks, class rings and achievement awards, accepted an $850 million buyout yesterday from a company controlled by Investcorp. The takeover group, which includes Jostens management, will pay $25.25 a share. The group will also take on about $100 million in Jostens' debt. Jostens, which is based in Minneapolis, said it would cut about 1.5 percent of its 6,500 workers, including its chief operating officer. It expects to take a fourth-quarter charge of $13.2 million. Investcorp is a Bahrain-based manager of real estate and other assets.

title: It's Show Time, Folks, In an Exotic No Man's Land
description: Even a lifetime circusgoer is unlikely to have come across a troupe as remarkable as the Tadjibajev family circus. Not because one of the acts requires the eldest of the family's six children to grip a red kerchief with his teeth and lift an attached 70-pound weight to chest level before his father smites it repeatedly with a sledge hammer. Or because that feat is followed by lying on a bed of glass, using his forearms to support a metal plate over his upper body while his father drops that selfsame weight on him.

title: Toyota to Increase Prices
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, the No. 4 automaker in the United States, plans to raise prices on its 2000 model Toyota and Lexus luxury cars and trucks to take advantage of record demand. The automaker, which is based in Japan, said it would increase average retail prices on Toyota vehicles by 0.8 percent, or $175, starting Feb. 1. Lexus prices will climb 1.2 percent, or $454. The move follows a 1.9 percent increase on Toyotas announced in August. Toyota's American depositary receipts rose $7.625, to a 52-week high of $96.875. The company's United States sales in the first 11 months of the year rose 10.7 percent, to 1.35 million vehicles, a rate that outpaced the five largest United States automakers. Industrywide, United States sales this month broke the 1986 record of 16.03 million.

title: The End Is Near. What's for Dinner?

title: A Delicate Time for the Schools
description: The New York City Board of Education made the sensible move yesterday when it voted to buy out the remainder of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's contract, with the aim of installing an interim chancellor by the middle of next month. But after forcing out one of the most popular chancellors in recent memory at the behest of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, the board bears a heavy responsibility not to politicize the search for a successor. A replacement who is perceived as a political ideologue -- or a puppet of the mayor -- could easily poison the administrative process, undermining school reforms that have been agreed upon in principle but not yet instituted.

title: The Pulling a Rabbit Out of a Hat Diet
description: THE diet of the moment, low in carbohydrates and high in protein, will attain the distinction in a few days of having survived into a third century. Its current proponents, like Dr. Robert Atkins, Dr. Barry Sears and Drs. Michael and Mary Eades, should say a little prayer of thanks to the man who helped make them rich. For this diet, like so many too-good-to-be-true prescriptions, has gone in and out of fashion, in the great American search for the holy grail of easy weight loss.

title: TAIWAN BULLET TRAIN

title: MEDIA 100 EXPANDING ITS VIDEO-EDITING SOFTWARE LINE
description: Media 100 Inc., a maker of software that allows broadcasting over the Internet, agreed to buy Digital Origin Inc. for about $87 million in stock. Each Digital share will be exchanged for about half of a Media 100 share, or $14.44, a 67 percent premium to Digital's closing price Monday. Shares closed unchanged yesterday at $27. Digital, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., makes software for digital video camcorders. The combined company would offer software that lets personal computer users capture, edit and stream video on the World Wide Web using a single application. Media 100 is based in Marlboro, Mass.

title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM SEEKS CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: Fruit of the Loom Ltd., a maker of underwear and T-shirts, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday after reporting five consecutive quarters of losses. Fruit of the Loom and 33 of its units filed for protection from creditors in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., where it is incorporated. The company listed $258.3 million in assets and $72.3 million in debt. Fruit of the Loom has had difficulty moving manufacturing overseas to save money in the face of about $1.3 billion in debt, analysts said recently. Its banks in October agreed to waive financial covenants through Jan. 31. But in a regulatory filing last month, the company said it could have further losses from problems keeping track of inventory.

description: SOLOMON-Jerry. December 28, 1999. Survived by wife, Sandy, daughters Robin Solomon and Sharon Meyer (Robert), grandchildren Josh and Brooke Meyer. Services today, 9:15 AM, Star of David, North Lauderdale, FL.

title: Special Metals Warns of 4th-Quarter Loss

title: There's Another Countdown Before the Famed '10, 9, 8 . . .'
description: The work of creating one of the world's biggest parties continued hurriedly in Times Square yesterday. The Waterford crystal ball that will kick off the millennium did a practice drop or two, glittering like daytime stars in the afternoon sun. Sound technicians hooked up 54 speakers over a dozen square blocks for a 26-hour concert, while electricians threaded cables so that 45 newscasters could come to you live on New Year's Eve.

description: ASTRONOMER'S COMPUTER COMPANION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOSTAK, JOSEPH
description: SHOSTAK-Joseph. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Joseph Shostak, the executive vice president and past executive director of The Shield Institute, a new affiliate of JBFCS. Mr. Shostak's committment and dedication to people with disabilities made him a model for other community leaders and a figure whose presence will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Shostak's wife, Claire, and other members of his family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Alan B. Siskind, PhD, Executive Vice President

title: A Hop, Skip and a Jump by Ballet Tech
description: Ballet Tech offered an abundance of perky hopping on Monday night at the Joyce Theater. The dancers also did some jolly skipping and jumping.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resignation of Nicholas A. Spano as chairman of the Westchester County Republican Party misstated the County Legislature post of Thomas J. Abinanti. Mr. Abinanti, a Democrat, is majority leader; the chairman of the legislature is George S. Latimer.

title: Who, What, When, Where and Y2K; Watching for Bugs
description: WATCHING Webcams from around the world appeals to one sort of surfer; keeping track of the effects of the Y2K computer problem is something entirely different and more serious. A number of governmental and other types of sites can keep you up to date on problems in the United States and other countries.

title: Giants and Cowboys Are 7-8 Playoff Hopefuls
description: If it seems almost comical that the 7-8 Giants still have dreamy playoff hopes, then what is there to say about the 7-8 Dallas Cowboys?

title: Metro Business; Insurer to Cut Jobs To Lower Its Costs
description: Highlands Insurance Group, a property and casualty insurer, announced a plan yesterday to cut 120 jobs, or 12 percent, and to lower costs by about $4.4 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SEYMOUR R.
description: BERNSTEIN-Seymour R.. Formerly a long-time resident of North Bellmore, New York. Died on December 27th, 1999 in Boca Raton, Florida. A veteran of W.W. II, he had been a manufacturing furrier and salesman in retail pharmaceuticals until his retirement in 1982. He is survived by his loving wife Ruth, his children, Jess, Ellen, Robert, Kenneth, and Matthew and his grandchildren, Daniel, Joanna, Jade, Jared, Cassie, Chad, and Max. We will all miss this loving, generous man.

title: Risky Political Tactics in Israel
description: Israel's Shas Party, having received most of the money it sought to subsidize its private schools and expand the budgets of its cabinet ministers, has mercifully withdrawn its threat to desert the governing coalition on the eve of Israel's crucial peace talks with Syria. Prime Minister Ehud Barak was right to do what he could to keep the allegiance of this ultra-Orthodox movement representing Sephardic Jews. He needs the broadest possible coalition to negotiate peace. But Shas's bargaining ploy was recklessly timed and dishearteningly parochial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELICH, MATE
description: ANGELICH-Mate. Husband of Kay Radoslovich. Father of Michael and Anton. Proprietor of Three Star Auto, Grand Central Motors and Mike's Service Station. Viewing hours Jacobsen Funeral Home, Huntington, Sta. NY, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Glaucoma Research Foundation.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDSTROM, FRANK
description: SANDSTROM-Frank., of Denver, CO, died December 21, 1999. Born in 1915, son of Frank O. Sandstrom and Virginia Foster. Survived by a sister, Barbara Gurtler, of Denver; daughters Virginia Emley and Judith Stephan; and four grandchildren. Graduated 1938, Princeton University, summa cum laude. Married the late Sybil King, 1941. Captain, U.S. Army. Chairman, Credit Policy Committee, Morgan Guarantee Trust Co. Financial manager to Kuwait Finance Minister. Consultant to Goldman Sachs. Board member, School of American Research, Santa Fe Opera, First Interstate Bank. Memorial gifts to Princeton, MIT or the charity of choice.

title: 2 Die in Louisiana Prison Hostage-Taking
description: A prison guard and an inmate were killed on Tuesday night in a bloody hostage-taking at the Louisiana State Penitentiary that may have been inspired in part by the recent success of Cuban inmates in negotiating their deportation during a hostage standoff at another Louisiana jail, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ESTHER
description: SHAPIRO-Esther. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Esther Shapiro, mother of Sandra Adler, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Israel Destroys Shrine to Mosque Gunman
description: The Israeli Army today razed a shrine built around the grave of Baruch Goldstein, the Brooklyn-born physician from this West Bank settlement who gunned down 29 Muslims at prayer in neighboring Hebron nearly six years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, ALAN
description: MARKOWITZ-Alan. Loving husband to Vivian, dear father to Fran, Bernard and Gail, Jay and Susan, Robin, and Steven, and grandfather to Caroline, Jonathan, Sarah, Elissa, and David. We love you and miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DROGIN, LEE
description: DROGIN-Lee. We remember our walks, our talks...in the woods, beaches and ponds on Cape Cod as well as on Broadway and Riverside Park. It won't be the same without you. Love, your Wellfleet family

title: Veteran Returns to the Hunt for Terrorists
description: SIX years after stepping down as New York City's police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly finds himself playing cop again -- this time as commissioner of the United States Customs Service, with a mission that includes tracking down terrorists who might try to cross the borders in time for this week's millennium celebrations.

title: BENETTON SHARES SURGE
description: Benetton Group S.p.A. surged as much as 8.5 percent after Luciano Benetton, its chairman, said Italy's biggest clothing company will sell products on the Internet next year, allowing it to penetrate markets where it has no shops. The shares advanced as much as 0.17 euro to 2.23 euros, a 52-week high. The gain came after Benetton said in an interview with the Milan daily Il Giornale that the company, which is based in Treviso, Italy, is ready to sell clothes and sports equipment online next year.

Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, December 30th, 10AM at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave at 84 Street. Burial in Cemetery of the Gates of Heaven, Valhalla.

title: Argentina's New Chief Wins $2 Billion Increase in Taxes
description: After weeks of tough negotiations, the Congress gave President Fernando de la Rua his most important victory today by raising taxes more than $2 billion to counteract an expanding budget deficit.

title: Nassau Deficit Twice Earlier Estimate, McCall Says
description: The news about Nassau County's fiscal crisis went from bad to worse today as the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, released a report estimating that the budget set to take effect Jan. 1 is $190 million in the red, a shortfall nearly twice as large as previously predicted.

title: VALUE AMERICA PLANS TO CUT NEARLY HALF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Value America Inc., an Internet retailer of computers, office products and consumer goods, said yesterday that its founders, Craig Winn and Rex Scatena, had resigned and that it would cut 47 percent of its work force. The company, based in Charlottesville, Va., has about 290 employees; it said it would take a $5.6 million fourth-quarter restructuring charge. The company said fourth-quarter sales would be 6 percent to 9 percent below estimates because of problems that arose from a new computer network. Value America said it expected to lose $1.03 a share, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by IBES International. The retailer lost $53.4 million on sales of $41.5 million last year. Its shares fell 84.375 cents, to $6.03125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYANT, C. WILLARD
description: BRYANT-C. Willard., 92. In New London, New Hampshire, on Dec. 29, 1999. Formerly of Greenwich, CT. General Electric employee for 47 years. His wife of 58 years, Dorothy (Johnson) Bryant, died in 1993. He is survived by his daughter, Susan B. Chacho, of New London, NH; a grandson, Marine Captain Jonathan D. Foster, of Frankfurt, Germany; a granddaughter, Kimberly F. Hickman, of Knoxville, TN; seven greatgrandchildren and several nieces and nephews. No calling hours. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM Saturday, January 8, 2000 at the Chadwick Funeral Home, 174 Main Street, New London, NH. Services at Christ Church in Greenwich, CT., at a later date.

title: Figure in Japanese Cult Freed From Jail, and Mobbed by Press
description: Amid an explosion of camera flashes and a frenzy of speculation over future threats from the sect, Japan today released the charismatic spokesman of the religious cult responsible for the deadly gas attack on Tokyo's subway system in 1995.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SIPEX CORP., -- Billerica, Mass., a maker of integrated circuits, said it would cut jobs, close its Fremont, Calif., operations and reorganize its work force as a result of its $45 million purchase of the Calogic Corporation. It did not say how many jobs would be cut.

title: Mixed Views of Rapper as Role Model
description: Max Julian, 14, and Mario Thatcher, 13, stood on a Bronx street corner Tuesday and pondered Puff Daddy.

title: The Playwright's Other Pursuit
description: In the novel ''Mansfield Park'' Sir Thomas Bertram is a dignified and stalwart aristocrat, a man very much of his time, the early 19th century. For that reason, when casting a film version of the Jane Austen classic, a director might not readily think of Harold Pinter for the role. Although Mr. Pinter is an actor as well as a playwright, he has specialized in playing contemporary characters with an air of menace, most of them, he said in a recent interview, ''written by H. Pinter.''
