title: TWO PENNSYLVANIA BANKS TO MERGE IN $30 MILLION DEAL
description: The Harleysville National Corporation, a Pennsylvania bank with 35 branches, said yesterday that it agreed to buy Citizens Bank & Trust Company for about $30 million in stock. Harleysville, which is based in Harleysville, Pa., has more than $1.6 billion in assets and owns banks under the names Harleysville National Bank and Trust Company, Citizens National Bank and Security National Bank. Citizens, based in Palmerton, Pa., and has about $130 million in assets and branches in seven towns. It will merge its businesses into Harleysville's Citizens National Bank subsidiary.

title: The Rangers Fade After a Fast Start
description: The Rangers dominated the Dallas Stars for the opening 15 minutes of tonight's game. They tried desperately to protect a two-goal lead, but their tired legs gave out in overtime.

Services will be held Thursday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

He was 81 years of age. A memorial service will be held at noon on Thursday, Dec. 30th at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. Jacques is survived by Miriam, his wife of 57 years, his son Dr. Charles Linker, his wife Helene and their children Sarah and Alex of Piedmont, CA, daughter Laurie Tako, her husband Reuben and children Eitan, Ayelet and Daphna of Kibbutz Naan, Israel, Naomi Yanis of Amherst, MA and her children Lynn, Lloyd, his wife Caren, and their children Lia and Sam, and Lauri Majewski, her husband Mike and their children Zachary and Aliza. Jacques also leaves a sister Adrianne Rosenberg of Tamarac, FL and a brother Elias of Monroe Township, NJ.

title: New Jersey Will Buy 1,000 Acres to Preserve Farmland
description: New Jersey officials announced a deal yesterday to buy more than 1,000 acres of fields and orchards in a fast-growing region of South Jersey -- the largest single purchase under the state's 16-year-old Farmland Preservation Program.

title: Report Says Many Officers Avoid Misconduct Penalties
description: Since 1996, the New York Police Department has disciplined police officers in only 24 percent of the cases of brutality and other misconduct substantiated by the civilian agency that investigates complaints from the public, a report released yesterday said.

title: FEWER BAD LOANS IN THAILAND
description: Nonperforming loans at Thailand's banks fell nearly 4 percent between October and November to 2.36 trillion baht, or $62.8 billion, the Thai central bank said. About 42.3 percent of all Thai bank loans are still considered problem loans, down from 43.8 percent the month before. Economists say clearing the bad loans from banks balance sheets is key to restoring sustainable economic growth to Thailand. Investors in Bangkok seized upon the announcement as a signal to bid up banking shares, sending Thailand's benchmark stock index 2.67 percent higher. Wayne Arnold

title: Once Upon a Time, Only Kings Had Castles
description: AS you sit reading the newspaper in your armchair, with a scant day left to the millennium, consider this almost too obvious fact: You couldn't have done it a thousand years ago. The newspaper was there. Thanks to Julius Caesar, the Romans had posted news.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Appropriate for Millennial Reflection
description: Somehow, the last thing I feel like doing on the eve of the new millennium is go to some big bash of a party. This sobering event makes me want to settle down for a bit and take stock of it all. Those who agree might find three new CD's conducive to an appropriately reflective millennial mode.

title: The Calendar's New Clothes
description: How lonely, how isolated, how un-American and uncontemporary one is made to feel, unable to comprehend either the literal or ''symbolic'' significance of The Millennium, and wholly impervious to millennium fever. My cautious answer to millennium questions I've been asked (''What will be the fate of the novel in the 21st century?'' ''What will be the fate of the printed word in the 21st century?'' ''What will be the fate of feminism in the 21st century?'' etc.) has been, ''Things will probably continue more or less as before, with some differences.''

title: RealNetworks Suit Defends Its Copyright on Audio Files
description: In what could be a precedent-setting case in Internet copyright law, RealNetworks Inc., whose products deliver audio and video content over the Web, is suing a company that makes software that converts RealNetworks' products into the format marketed by its rival, the Microsoft Corporation.

title: SINGAPORE'S MALAYSIAN SHARES
description: Two Malaysian companies pitching for disputed Malaysian shares that once traded in Singapore said that they hoped Kuala Lumpur would extend a Friday deadline it has set to resolve the dispute. If the participants cannot agree on what do with the shares, which once traded on Singapore's over-the-counter Central Order Limit Book system, Kuala Lumpur has said it will hand responsibility for them to Malaysia's finance ministry. The shares are held by about 172,000 investors, mostly Singaporeans. Effective Capital Sdn Bhd. and Bintang Melewar Sdn. Bhd. both urged authorities to give investors more time to consider their offers.

title: Criminal Inquiry to Look Into Funds Donated Secretly to Kohl
description: German prosecutors said today that they would begin a criminal investigation into secret political funds maintained by Helmut Kohl, Germany's chancellor from 1982 until last year and Europe's most powerful leader for most of this decade.

title: Watching for the Y2K Bug
description: Years from now, historians will be fascinated by the combination of arduous planning, breathless hype and stubborn indifference that have gone into preparations for the computer glitch known as the Y2K bug. By now it seems clear to experts who have followed the saga that when the new year arrives tomorrow night, the most dire predictions of crises in computer systems in this country will not come to pass. Air travel and the banking system are expected to continue uninterrupted, and there will probably not be widespread power failures. Americans may need to brace for inconveniences and localized problems, but the worst potential disasters are expected overseas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONEY, MARTHA BOWERS DOHERTY
description: MOONEY-Martha Bowers Doherty. of Floral Park, NY at age 85. Beloved wife of the late Vincent J. Mooney. She is survived by her sons Vincent Jr., Christopher, Roger, Walter and Neil and by her daughters Martha Waltien and Katherine Pryor as well as 11 grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. A graduate of Emmanuel College in Boston (class of '35) who also studied at Radcliffe College, Martha founded the St. Thomas More Bookstore in Harvard Square. She is past president of the Emmanuel Club of Long Island and of the Radcliffe Club of Long Island, and was a member of the Board of the West Nassau Mental Health Clinic. Visiting hours at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, Floral Park, on Thursday, December 30 from 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Victory Church, Floral Park, Friday December 31st at 9:30 AM. Burial at Holy Rood Cemetery. Contributions in memory of Martha may be made to the Monastery of the Carmelite Sisters, 1000 Lincoln Street, Santa Clara, CA. 94050-5285.

ABB, based in Zurich, said the sale was in line with its plan to reposition the company away from heavy industry and toward high-technology operations.

title: CHILEAN INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT
description: Chile's industrial output rose in November at its fastest pace in almost two years and the jobless rate fell for a third month. Production rose 8.5 percent from a year ago, the fastest pace since 8.8 percent in December 1997, the state-run National Statistics Institute said. The jobless rate slid to 10 percent in the three months to November from October's 11 percent.

title: Tito Guizar, 91, Mexico's Singing Cowboy of Stage and Screen
description: Tito Guizar, the limpid-eyed singer and actor who brought Mexican cowboy music to New York and opened the way for Mexican performers in Hollywood, died on Friday in San Antonio. He was 91.

title: Yarmouth Journal; Indian Affairs Heat Up (Witness the Lobster War)
description: For Ashton Spinney, who has fished the Bay of Fundy since the early 1960's, the conflict this fall with Mi'kmaq Indians over the lobster catch was ''the only time in my lifetime we were at the brink of civil war in my community.'' At stake is Atlantic Canada's most valuable fish harvest.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE
description: South Africa posted an unexpected November trade deficit, as rising oil prices drove up import costs and as exports slowed from October. South Africa posted a trade deficit of 567 million rand, or $92 million, in November, the Revenue Service said. A surplus of 290 million rand had been expected, according to the mean estimate of 10 economists. The country had a surplus of 911 million rand in October. Imports rose 5.5 percent while exports fell 4.7 percent.

title: Once Upon a Time, Only Kings Had Castles; Milestones, Millstones As Design Marches On
description: BY the year 1000, homeowners throughout the world enjoyed a remarkable range of creature comforts: coal stoves in China; crystal tableware in Baghdad; libraries in Ghana. All and all, it wasn't a bad time to be alive -- unless, of course, you lived in Europe. Peasants there dwelt in filthy one-room hovels heated by an open fire. The family, along with the goat, huddled on a single vermin-infested straw mat. Not that kings and queens in gloomy castles had it much better. Privacy was nonexistent, and the nobility, one historian has written, ''didn't so much live in their houses as camp in them.'' They spent most of their time on the road, visiting far-flung estates. Tellingly, the French and Italian words for furniture at this time -- mobilier and mobilia -- meant ''movables.'' It would be a while before Europeans settled down.

title: Couch Sweet Home

The three of us hunker into the pages before us as if doing so will shut out the noise, like closing a window. But the dog has soulful eyes, and they are trained on me in an inescapable, it's-up-to-you kind of way, until I have no choice but to relent. The dog smiles broadly while the others scowl. I've seen that look before, on the Broadway local at rush hour, when the train door opens and people push their way on, subdividing space as if everyone were part of a living math problem: what's one-half divided by half; what's zero divided by half?

title: EUROPEAN INTEREST RATES
description: The European Central Bank is in no hurry to raise interest rates to restrain inflation in the 11 nations that share the euro, the Bundesbank president, Ernst Welteke, indicated. ''I don't see a necessity to think about interest rate changes right now,'' Mr. Welteke, one of the 17 members of the bank's policy-making council, said. ''We want to stabilize interest rate expectations'' among investors. The bank on Nov. 4 raised its benchmark refinancing rate by half a percentage point, to 3 percent, to prevent rebounding economic growth from stoking inflation. Many analysts expect the central bank to raise rates again early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAMADA, TADAYOSHI
description: YAMADA-Tadayoshi, one of Japan's leading internationalists, passed away on November 6, 1999. He was born on January 10, 1909 in Tottori Prefecture, Japan, received a Bachelor of Laws degree from Meiji University in 1933 and a Master of Arts degree in American history from Columbia University in 1935. He was Senior Managing Director at Yawata Iron and Steel Company until 1969 and then Senior Executive Adviser at Nippon Steel until 1981. A founding Director of Malayawata Steel Corporation and a Director of Honshu Rheem Corporation, he also served as Vice Chairman of the Japan-America Society and as President of the Canada-Japan Society. Among his many accomplishments, he negotiated the first loan from the World Bank to a Japanese company after World War II. Morever, Mr. Yamada helped found the World Trade Centers Association in 1970 and served as Vice President and Secretary from 1970 until 1987, when he was elected Chairman. Today, the Association has 330 member organizations in 98 countries. He also was Chairman of the World Trade Center in Tokyo from 1974 to 1999. In a long and productive career, he received numerous awards, including the Order of the Sacred Treasure from the Emperor of Japan and both Chevalier de l'Ordre de la Couronne and Officier de l'Ordre de la Couronne from the King of Belgium. Mr. Yamada's wife of 50 years, Takako Takami Yamada, died in 1985. He is survived by daughter Kazuko Nitta of Tokyo, Japan and sons Akiyoshi Yamada of Miami, FL., and Tadataka Yamada of Philadelphia, PA., and seven grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, FLORENCE HEMLEY
description: SCHNEIDER-Florence Hemley. 85 years old; Ph.D Bryn Mawr College. Resident of Ashland, Oregon; formerly of Tucson, AZ, and Crestwood, NY. Departed peacefully in her sleep December 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Bill Schneider; loving sister of Eugene and the late Arnold and David; a devoted mother of Patty and Burton; and grandmother of their children. With her husband Bill, she was the founder and manager for many years of Treehaven School in Tucson, AZ; the Schneider Art Museum of Southern Oregon State University and the Ashland Community Educational Services Volunteer Organization for the Ashland Oregon School District. Also the Schneiders were major contributors to many charitable, religious, cultural and educational funds including a Scholarship Fund for the Graduate School of Social Work and Research at Bryn Mawr College; Rogue Valley Symphony; Oregon Shakespeare Festival; Rogue Valley Opera; Temple Emek Shalom; Special Facility for Ashland Community Hospital and endowments for Providence and Rogue Valley Memorial Hospitals; a general charitable fund with emphasis on the underprivileged in Jackson County, Oregon; and many others. During her life, Florence taught at the University of Arizona-Tucson, Santa Monica College, Rogue Valley Jewish Community Religious School, Southern Oregon State University, and conducted ''Perspectives For Women'', a monthly series of breakfasts for professional women at the Medford Chamber of Commerce. She started her working career as Director of Fact Finding of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs. The documentary film ''The Women of Summer'' was prompted by her doctoral research work at Bryn Mawr. All who knew Florence appreciated her intense interest in participating in the life of the communities she lived in, with a primary interest in helping the underprivileged. She was an energetic, dynamic, ethical, loving and sympathetic person who throughout her life devoted herself to many worthy causes. She will be sorely missed by those with similar interests but primarily by her extended family and her many, many friends throughout the country. In life she made a significant, beneficial difference, and now will live on in her good work. ''Still are thy pleasant voices, thy nightingales, awake. For Death he taketh all away, but them he cannot take''.

title: TRANSCANADA FINISHES SALE OF NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS UNIT

The loss will be part of a planned $482 million fourth-quarter charge, as TransCanada sheds unprofitable operations to focus on the regulated business of transporting natural gas. The Coastal Corporation of Houston bought the Louisiana-based gas liquids unit. The natural gas processing operations can process as much as 2.1 billion cubic feet of natural gas and 90,000 barrels of natural gas liquids a day. The sale includes 380 miles of natural gas liquids pipelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOEMAKER, PERRY MONROE
description: SHOEMAKER - Perry Monroe. Former railroad executive Perry Monroe Shoemaker, 93 of Tampa, FL, died in Tampa on Christmas Day, December 25. He was a native of Elmira, NY, graduated from The University of Michigan with a BS in Engineering in 1928 and received a graduate degree in transportation from Yale University in 1929. He was President and Chairman of the Board of The Delaware Lackawanna & Western Railroad, Chairman of the Board of The Erie Lackawanna Railroad and President of the Central Railroad of NJ. He was a member of The Eastern Railroad President's Conference and The NY Railroad Club. In the 1950's Shoemaker served on The Hoover Commission Task Force as Chairman of the Committee on Goverment Defense Procurement Recommendations. He was also a Past President of The NY State Chamber of Commerce, a director of The National Biscuit Company, The Railway Express Company, as well as many other organizations in NY, NJ and Tampa, FL. He received many honors and awards throughout his years of service to the railroad industry and local communities and most recently was inducted in The Cooperstown Conference Hall of Fame in July of 1996. He is survived by his wife Iva Brown Shoemaker and four children by his first wife, the late Emily Hane Shoemaker: Linda S. Wolfberg of Canandaigua, NY; Kent P. Shoemaker of Minneapolis, MN; Karen S. Fitzgerald of Washington, D.C.; and Craig M. Shoemaker of Jamestown, NC, seven grandchildren and one great grandchild. Funeral services will take place at 2PM, Park Church, Elmira, NY on January 22.

Leif was quite the millennial man himself, having stumbled on North America around the year 1000. And when the first Norse settlement there was attacked, Freydis led the defense, despite her advanced pregnancy. ''She took her breasts out and whetted the sword upon them. At that, the [enemy] became afraid and ran away,'' reported a Viking chronicler. Why, in the era of Xena and Buffy the Vampire Slayer, does this woman not have a TV series of her own?

The conjurer of this frenzied orgy of creation, destruction and renewal is a whirling sprite, a shape-shifting purple comet of an animated figure summoned from a volcano by an elk in the forest.

title: Hurdles That Go Beyond the Slope
description: ''It's the freedom on snow,'' says Kevin Murray. I've asked him why he skis. Freedom must mean a lot, I think, to be out on a bitter day like this. We've been riding the chairlift through a gray sky. The snow guns are pounding ice into the air to cover the trails. The machines are as loud as jet engines, and a gusting wind hurls the crystals against our faces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, IRA L.
description: FRIEDLAND-Ira L. Died December 27, 1999 at JFK Medical Center in Edison, New Jersey. He was 72 years old. At the start of his career, Mr. Friedland owned Diamond Management, a real estate management company in Edison, and AMI Construction, a building & development firm in Middlesex County. He then merged Diamond Management with Amherst Management in Edison. Mr. Friedland served in the Navy during World War II and was a member of the New Jersey Builders Association of New Jersey. Born in Irvington, he lived in Linden & Edison before moving to Metuchen, New Jersey ten years ago. Surviving are his wife, Sandra; a son, Ken; a daughter, Barbara Trimarchi; a stepdaughter, Cathy Kobrin; a brother, Martin Friedland; and four grandchildren. Donations may be made in Mr. Friedland's memory to Temple Neve Shalom, Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, 250 Grove Street, Metuchen, NJ 08840.

He was 92.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone, especially during the holiday season when many galleries close for longer periods. Also, some museums are closed New Year's Day. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Reggie Carter, 42, a Star Guard In '79 Tournament for St. John's
description: Reggie Carter, an outstanding guard for the unheralded St. John's University basketball team that came within one game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's Final Four in 1979, died last Friday at Huntington (N.Y.) Hospital. Carter, who lived in Huntington Station, was 42.

title: The Pathos Of Deceit By a Victim Of Longing
description: In one film after another, the great Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami twists around the equation that the author Neal Gabler calls ''Life: The Movie'' to make films whose aesthetic might be described as ''The Movie: Life.'' Mr. Kiarostami's films frequently feature nonactors playing themselves in unglamorized reconstructions of actual events. And in his brilliant, knotty 1990 film ''Close-Up,'' which has its New York theatrical premiere today at the Screening Room, those reconstructions are seamlessly embedded in a documentary about the trial of Hossein Sabzian, a young man arrested on charges of fraud.

title: Janet Bode, 56; Wrote for Young Adults
description: Janet Bode, the author of 14 nonfiction books with socially conscious themes for young adults, died yesterday at her home in Greenwich Village in Manhattan. She was 56.

title: Marsalis's Daring Symphonic Step
description: Wynton Marsalis's tap didn't turn off in 1999. Eight new discs bear his name, ranging from new extended jazz works to rearranged Jelly Roll Morton and Thelonious Monk; he has a seven-CD boxed set of live material; six months of the year were spent touring worldwide and playing the music of Duke Ellington. And finally, in its premiere performance on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, there was ''All Rise,'' a symphonic piece commissioned by the New York Philharmonic in a collaboration with Jazz at Lincoln Center.

title: TOMKINS BUYS MAKER OF VENTILATION EQUIPMENT
description: Tomkins P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had acquired Hart & Cooley, a privately held manufacturer of fans and blowers, for $320 million. Tomkins, a diversified manufacturer based in London, said the combined ventilation business will have annual sales of more than $684 million. Hart & Cooley, which is based in Holland, Mich., has 2,700 employees and 10 manufacturing plants in North America. Its 1999 sales are estimated at $330 million. Tomkins has annual sales of more than $8.5 billion.

title: A World Without Brussels Sprouts, Pesky Brothers or Long School Days
description: In the year 2030 people will have dolphins and gorillas for roommates, one girl from Canada predicts in ''Nickellennium,'' Nickelodeon's New Year's Eve special. In 2040, a boy from Romania announces, he will live on an island ''in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean'' with 1,000 cats. In the future, a little girl from England says, ''you'll have e-mail in your head.''

title: Crossing Spiritual Thresholds
description: EVERY New Year's Eve, we would like to think, one small story closes and another opens. But this year the story arrives in a deluxe edition. The ball dropping in Times Square at midnight will punctuate not just a chapter or a volume, but a boxed set titled ''20th Century.'' And it will be the first mark of an ellipsis into the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, TIM C.V.
description: ELLIOTT-Tim C.V. Tim, passed away at home in Manhattan, early morning December 30 after a short but courageous battle with pancreatic cancer, at age 51. Born in Dorset, England, educated at Harrow School, Cambridge University, and in the far flung reaches of the world, Tim's humor and selfless concern for others remained intact until the end. While several global advertising agencies have lost a rare breed of leader, the world has lost an irreplaceable eccentric and lover of life far too soon. May his generosity, spirit and enthusiasm be remembered with more than the glasses that will be raised to him tonight, the end of this millennium. Tim is survived by Daryl, his wife and partner in life's great adventures, family members in England and Canada and a legion of godchildren, friends and admirers around the world. A service will be held in celebration of his life on Friday, January 7th at 1:PM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave and 66th. Contributions in his memory in lieu of flowers can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of NY, 1250 Broadway, 4th Flr, NY, NY 10001, care of Renee Martinez or The Lustgarten Foundation for Cancer Research, P.O. Box 2141, New York, New York 10116.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, WALTER
description: FRIEDMAN-Walter. Died at the age of 80 in Boca Raton, Florida. Devoted husband of his late wife, Sylvia. Beloved father of Diane Freed Conway and Alexandra Palley. Loving grandfather of Molly Conway, Skyler Conway, Thea Palley and Aaron Palley. Loving and devoted companion of Jeanne Halevy and her children, grandchildren and great-children who embraced him as their own. Known and loved as ''Willie'' by his many friends and relatives, he retired from the New York City Police Force as a Lieutenant, practiced law for many years and returned to public service with the New York State Commission for the Blind. He was a longtime resident of Ocean Beach, Fire Island. He loved to paint and was greatly admired for his beautiful singing voice, particularly of Yiddish songs. He always loved a good joke. We will all cherish his memory and will miss him terribly. There will be a memorial service for Willie in Ocean Beach, Fire Island in September. Arrangements will be announced.

title: TAIWAN CHIP MERGER
description: The world's largest computer chip foundry, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, said it would buy the remaining 70 percent stake in the TSMC-Acer Semiconductor Manufacturing Company that it does not already own for 47.1 billion new Taiwan dollars ($1.5 billion). Taiwan Semiconductor, which bought 30 percent of Acer in June, will issue 282 million new shares to swap a share in itself for every six shares in the venture.

title: NO OFFER FOR AEROLINEAS ARGENTINAS
description: Argentina's flagship airline, Aerolineas Argentinas S.A., will return to Spanish government management in January because its current manager, the AMR Corporation, has not made Spain a purchase offer, said Josep Pique, the Spanish industry minister. Under an agreement with the Spanish state holding company Sepi, AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, was allowed to manage Aerolineas Argentinas provided that it found investors to buy out the government before 2000. In return, AMR agreed to buy 10 percent of Interinvest, the biggest shareholder in the Argentine airline, from Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana S.A., owned by Sepi.

title: Clear Lenses but Cloudy Crystal Balls
description: If the 21st century starts tomorrow -- and that's the rumor -- great wonders (or horrors) must be just around the corner. But dedicated moviegoers and video viewers have seen it all before -- robots, dystopias, flying taxis -- with film foretastes of the 21st, 22nd, and 23rd centuries and points beyond. For a refresher course in the future, heare are 10 movies on video that dared to look ahead in their own ways. Based on this selection, filmmakers' greatest fears for the centuries ahead seem to be cannibalism, overzealous police officers (who burst into homes un-announced) and the end of book publishing. ANITA GATES

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the restoration of Madison Square Park misstated the history of Madison Square Garden. The original Madison Square Garden, at 26th Street and Madison Avenue, was razed in 1925. It then moved to Eighth Avenue and 50th Street before moving to its current site atop Pennsylvania Station in 1968.

title: EATON SELLS MACHINE TOOL CONTROLS BUSINESS TO SIEMENS
description: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday it had sold the machine tool controls business of its Vickers Electronic Systems division to the Siemens Energy and Automation Inc. unit of Siemens A.G. The purchase price was not disclosed. Eaton, a Cleveland-based maker of aerospace, construction and semiconductor products, acquired Vickers in its purchase of Aeroquip-Vickers Inc. last April. The division, based in South Lebanon, Ohio, makes computer controls for machine tools and plastic processing equipment. Including an Italian plant that Eaton intends to sell separately, the division had 1998 revenue of $109 million and 610 employees. Siemens Energy and Automation, based in Atlanta, markets electrical and electronics products and services.

description: Power poles have always been a favorite perch for birds, especially eagles, hawks, owls and falcons which use them to spot their prey.

title: The Journey to 2000
description: The concluding day of the 20th century and therefore of the second millennium -- that event so freighted with various meanings by historians, politicians, fictionists and doomsaying preachers -- is upon us. With allowances for the dateline, it will fall everywhere with equal finality, evoking all around the world the same feelings of solemnity for humanity's catalogue of travails and triumphs, and stirring in every corner of our common planet the desire to celebrate our hope for a peaceful and healing future. Those aspirations will stir with an equal inexorability in quiet villages on far continents and in the digital glitter of Times Square.

title: Princess Miscarries, Dashing Japan's Hopes
description: Three weeks after press reports of Crown Princess Masako's pregnancy touched off a wave of hopeful speculation about the imperial succession, officials announced tonight that she had suffered a miscarriage.

title: MAKER OF TESTING INSTRUMENTS ACCEPTS CHIEF'S BID
description: The CEM Corporation said yesterday that its chief executive, Michael Collins, had offered to buy all shares outstanding for about $34.4 million, as the maker of testing instruments accepted his third bid to take the company private. Mr. Collins agreed to pay $11.15 for each CEM share. He already owns more than 15 percent of the shares outstanding, which totaled 3.04 million on Sept. 30. CEM rose $2.25 yesterday, to $10.6875. CEM's microwave-based testing and analysis instruments are used in laboratories and by the food- and chemical-processing industries. Mr. Collins first offered to buy the company on Oct. 18 for $8.40 a share and raised the bid to $9.25 on Nov. 10. The sale needs approval from investors who own about 67 percent of the company, which is based in Matthews, N.C.

title: In America; Miracles At Warp Speed
description: Just 50 years ago, no time at all in the long excursion of history, Americans were driving cars with divided windshields, listening to ballgames on radios that crackled with static, and reading comic strips that suggested someday there might be a portable electronic device (a wrist radio, perhaps) that would allow individuals to have the equivalent of a telephone with them at all times.
